title: 2 Names Familiar in Malibu Battle Over Anti-Development Measure
description: MALIBU, Calif.  Steve Soboroff is a police commissioner in Los Angeles, a former candidate for mayor and a developer whose latest venture is a supermarket complex on an open field off the Pacific Coast Highway here. Rob Reiner is an actor and a director who has a history of political advocacy in California going back 20 years.

title: Tim Cooks Coming Out: Reporters Notebook
description: James B. Stewart provides insight into The Coming Out of Apples Tim Cook: This Will Resonate, his column in Fridays New York Times. Mr. Stewarts piece explored the impact Mr. Cooks announcement is likely to have.

title: Five Football Players Charged in a Beating in Pennsylvania
description: Five football players from California University of Pennsylvania, who reportedly chanted Football strong as they left after brutally beating a 30-year-old man outside a popular off-campus restaurant, were arrested Thursday.

title: Opposing Gun Measures in Washington State Draw Cash and Sow Confusion
description: SEATTLE  The nations only major gun-control ballot initiative this year, here in Washington State, is drawing big money and star-power names like Bill Gates and former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York as backers. But the defining aspect is confusion, many residents say, because there are in fact two gun measures on the ballot, side by side, and they are diametrically opposed.

title: Friday Night Music: Amason
description: Actually Saturday morning music where I am, but anyway. I dont have anything Japanese themed ready to go, so heres what I tried to post last week only to have the system eat it. Amason is a Swedish group, record not yet out, who did a live performance on Seattles KEXP  but they actually did the performance at the Cutting Room in NYC, and the nice people at KEXP invited me to sit in the control room and watch:

title: Bill Simmons Discusses Suspension From ESPN, Until He Doesnt
description: When Bill Simmons was suspended by ESPN in September for three weeks, it was for saying on his popular podcast that N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell was a liar for his remarks about when he saw the elevator video of Ray Rice punching his fiance. He also effectively challenged ESPN to punish him for the comments.

title: Democrats Count on Edge With Women to Limit Election Losses
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats are nervously counting on an enduring edge among female voters in most states to prevent a Republican rout in Tuesdays elections. Yet so great is the uncertainty that even before the returns are in, some are second-guessing the partys strategy of focusing more on issues like abortion and birth control than on jobs and the economy.

title: Roderick M. Hills, Counsel to Gerald Ford and S.E.C. Chairman, Dies at 83
description: Roderick M. Hills, who marshaled political acumen and legal agility to become an influential counsel to President Gerald R. Ford and was later appointed chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, died on Wednesday in Baltimore. He was 83 and lived in Washington.

title: Underwriting the Next Housing Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  SEVEN years after the housing bubble burst, federal regulators backed away this month from the tougher mortgage-underwriting standards that the Dodd-Frank Act of 2010 had directed them to develop. New standards were supposed to raise the quality of the prime mortgages that get packaged and sold to investors; instead, they will have the opposite effect.

title: At First Look Media, Personalities Prove Tough to Manage
description: When First Look Media, the journalism enterprise backed by the billionaire founder of eBay, Pierre M. Omidyar, started about a year ago, its mission was clear.

title: Fluid, Plucky and Injury-Free, a Gelding Faces a New Test
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  Jerry Hollendorfer began learning about thoroughbreds when he worked as a groom at Bay Meadows Racetrack in San Mateo, Calif., in the late 1960s. He cleaned stalls and began to understand the qualities of good horses as he tended to their needs.

title: David Armstrong, Photographer of Subcultures, Dies at 60
description: David Armstrong, a photographer who gained prominence exploring the often overlapping worlds of gay men, drug addicts, transvestites, fashion models and artists, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 60.

title: How to Mend the Conservation Divide
description: A SCHISM has recently divided those who love nature.

title: Transcript of New York Times Interview With President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan
description: Following is a transcript, provided by the Taiwanese government, of an interview with President Ma Ying-jeou conducted by The New York Times in Taipei on Friday. Mr. Ma mainly spoke in Chinese, but briefly answered a question in English.

title: Home and Campaigning Lure Bill Clinton to Arkansas
description: During a recent visit to Arkansas, former President Bill Clinton took issue with a news story that implied he has been returning to his home state lately only because of the midterm elections.

title: When to Shut Down Failing Schools
description: During his mayoral campaign, Bill de Blasio did not give high priority to the crucial issue of how and when the city should intervene to abolish or remake failing schools.

title: On Visit, Obama to Face a Backsliding Myanmar
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama made his historic visit to Myanmar two years ago, he answered critics who charged that he was prematurely rewarding the countrys military-dominated rulers by saying, If we waited to engage until they achieved a perfect democracy, my suspicion is wed be waiting an awful long time.

title: Cuomo, Backed by Working Families Party, May Chip Away at Its Clout at the Polls
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo wants to win as many votes as possible in the election on Tuesday. Some liberals suspect he has a second goal: to weaken the Working Families Party.

title: Street-Level Views of the Protests in Burkina Faso
description: As my colleagues Herv Taoko and Alan Cowell report, protesters in Burkina Faso forced President Blaise Compaor from office on Friday, one day after they ransacked Parliament to prevent a vote that could have allowed him to extend his rule.

title: Better Staffing Seen as Crucial to Ebola Treatment in Africa
description: Dr. Rick Sacra, a missionary who contracted Ebola in Liberia this August, was first treated there. Each nurse on the ward cared for 15 or 20 patients, and none could work for more than an hour at a time because the protective gear was so suffocatingly hot. They never drew his blood for lab tests. There was no lab.

title: Deceptions of the F.B.I.
description: If your Internet service goes down and you call a technician, can you be certain that the person who arrives at your door is actually there to restore service? What if he is a law enforcement agent in disguise who has disabled the service so he can enter your home to look around for evidence of a crime?

title: The Peoples Choice on Gun Safety
description: When Congress displayed its timidity about gun safety legislation last year after the school massacre in Connecticut, it became clear that only direct political action from voters could force the tough new controls that most Americans wanted.

title: The 41st Annual Halloween Parade in Greenwich Village
description: The parade, along Avenue of the Americas from Spring Street to 16th Street, brought out ghouls, zombies and Daft Punk.

title: With Political Rift Still Deep, Russia-Ukraine Gas Deal Is Widely Seen as a Patch
description: OTTAWA  A deal struck on Thursday to restart Russian natural gas supplies to Ukraine will keep homes heated this winter, but it does not fully settle a fierce, long-running fight over energy prices that is likely to resume early next year if not sooner, analysts said Friday.

title: Spy Allegations in a Presidential Race Conjure Romanias Authoritarian Past
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  The front-runner in a presidential election here on Sunday disappointed his 10-year-old son recently by informing him that, contrary to feverish talk on the campaign trail, he was not a Romanian James Bond.

title: Subdued Chris Christie Still Finds Center Stage
description: SCHOFIELD, Wisc.  Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey on Friday played a rare second fiddle at a campaign rally here for Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, dialing back his intensity after a week in which he dominated headlines for his handling of Ebola procedures and a heckler back home.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 31, 2014
Alarmed by Ebola, Public Isnt Calmed by Experts Say
description: When public health leaders and government officials make the case against isolating more people returning from the Ebola hot zones in West Africa, or against imposing more travel restrictions from that region, time and again they cite science and experts. It isnt working very well.

title: Inspiration Outside the Bun
description: I couldnt remember the last time Id voluntarily gone out for brunch, but after two mixed experiences at 14 & Hudson in Piermont, I decided to cross the Tappan Zee Bridge one last time to see the place in the daylight, and take a chance on the French toast. A fall tableau of gourds and chrysanthemums met us at the door, and the hostess smiled broadly as we stepped inside.

title: The Guantnamo Tapes
description: Jihad Ahmed Mujstafa Diyab is a Syrian man who has been a detainee at the prison in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, since 2002. In 2009, the Guantnamo Review Task Force ruled that he was not a threat to national security and could be released. Yet here we are five years later, and Diyab is still imprisoned at Guantnamo, having never been tried, or even accused of a crime, and with no idea when  or if  hell ever get out. Last year, to protest their continued confinement, he and many other detainees began a hunger strike. Most of the detainees have since given up their hunger strikes. Diyab, however, has never completely stopped his.

title: G.O.P. Ads Chase Voters at Home and on the Go
description: WASHINGTON  Commuters on the sea-hugging Montauk line of the Long Island Rail Road had a shared experience while browsing the Internet on their smartphones recently: A half-screen ad popped up attacking Representative Timothy H. Bishop as one of Congresss most corrupt members.

title: Italian Food That Wont Drag You Down
description: In these carbophobic times, when every third person seems to have self-diagnosed a gluten intolerance or embraced a paleo diet, it can be easy to forget the simple, uncomplicated love affair many of us once had with Italian food. These days, a rendezvous with a hunk of lasagna or dish of pappardelle can feel more like an illicit tryst  delicious, but fraught with guilt, and often concluding with a resolution to avoid further temptation.

title: In Nigeria, Fragile Hopes of Boko Haram Freeing Schoolgirls Are Dashed
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The news from Nigeria sounded almost too good to be true  and so it appears to have been.

title: U.N. Says Iran Is Silent on Efforts for a Bomb
description: WASHINGTON  At a moment when American negotiators say they see some signs of movement on the part of Iran toward a broad nuclear deal with the United States, the head of the United Nations nuclear inspection organization declared Friday that Iran had stopped answering the agencys questions about suspected past efforts to design the components of a bomb.

title: A Kennedys Campaign Is Sharply Questioned on Finances
description: BRANFORD, Conn.  Getting a scion of the Kennedy family elected to an open seat in the State Senate in this heavily Democratic state must have seemed as though it would be a cinch.

title: Stopping Street Harassment
Former U.S. Envoy to Moscow Says Russians Are Still Spying on Him
description: CHICAGO  During two years as ambassador to Russia, Michael McFaul was constantly followed, harassed and demonized on state television. But though Mr. McFaul has left government service and returned home, the spying on him doesnt seem to have stopped.

title: Not at All Creaky
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  It was the mathematical symbols that got me. They got me good.

title: Favored Untapable Rallies to Win Breeders Cup Distaff
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  As long as the 3-year-old filly Untapable stays away from the boys, she appears to be unstoppable.

title: Election Day Pop Quiz
description: Are you ready for the midterms? Its time to test your political smarts.

title: Mets Juan Lagares Soars, Attaining New Heights
description: Sometimes Juan Lagares plays so shallow in center field for the Mets that he looks as if he is hoping to bait the batter into swinging too hard in an effort to hit the ball over his head. But as opponents have learned over the past two seasons, Lagares has the speed and instincts to get to almost any ball hit in the air. If you do hit the ball deep, he will probably catch up to it. And if you try to tag up and advance a base after he runs the ball down, he might just throw you out.

title: Iran Hints at Possible Release of Washington Post Correspondent Soon
description: GENEVA  A senior Iranian emissary hinted on Friday that Iranian authorities might be prepared to free a Washington Post correspondent who has been inexplicably imprisoned and kept virtually incommunicado since July 22.

title: Wheelies: The Technology and Stuff Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Schumer Hits the Trail for a Goal in Albany: A Democratic New York Senate
description: With control of the New York Senate hanging in the balance, one of the states most prominent Democrats was once again on the campaign trail on Friday, appearing with an upstate candidate and trying to tip the upper chamber into friendly hands.

title: What Is on the Line in the Midterm Elections
description: Things to look for in Tuesdays midterm elections:

title: Herb Schapiro, Playwright Behind The Me Nobody Knows, Dies at 85
description: Herb Schapiro, a writer and teacher whose idea to create a stage play from the collected essays of poor city kids resulted in a hit musical, The Me Nobody Knows, died on Oct. 17 at his home in Brooklyn. He was 85.

title: Saturdays College Football Games to Watch
description: 4 AUBURN at 7 MISSISSIPPI

title: Mets Deny Bias in Ticket Officials Firing
description: The Mets and their chief operating officer, Jeff Wilpon, in court papers filed Friday, denied all the accusations made in a lawsuit by a former senior ticket-sales executive who said that she had been discriminated against for being pregnant out of wedlock.

title: Ukrainians in the Battered East Scramble in Darkness as Winter Nears
description: NOVOSVITLIVKA, Ukraine  On one of the last warm days of autumn, Father Vladimir shed his priests robes and scaled a rickety wooden ladder to replace the shattered windows on the once-golden cupola of his village church.

title: Brook Lopez Stays on Sideline as the Nets Say Little
description: Fans and reporters hoping to understand the extent of an injury to an N.B.A. player are often reduced to guesswork.

title: With Gadgetry, New York Marathon May Be Watched Like No Other
description: This years New York City Marathon on Sunday could be the largest road race ever staged, with about 50,000 runners registered.

title: The Grove: Ole Misss Living Room
description: The Grove at the University of Mississippi is a place of refuge. But on football game days the 10-acre space turns into one of the most raucous and distinctive tailgating parties in the country.

title: Tailgating Goes Above and Beyond at the University of Mississippi
description: OXFORD, Miss.  Perhaps there isnt a word for the ritualized pregame revelry on the University of Mississippi campus. Tailgating certainly does not do it justice. It might be a gathering of football fans before a game, but it hardly resembles those celebrated scenes in Green Bay and Kansas City, which are modest by comparison.

title: Girl, 14, Dies of Wounds in Washington School Shooting
description: A 14-year-old girl who was shot in the head last week when a classmate opened fired in a high school cafeteria in Washington State has died, hospital officials said Friday.

title: Whats On TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) WINTERS TALE (2014) The high-spirited consumptive daughter (Jessica Brown Findlay) of an early-20th-century mogul (William Hurt, above) is confronted by a thief (Colin Farrell) who breaks into her mansion to steal the silver  and absconds with her heart, aided by a flying white horse  in Akiva Goldsmans adaptation of Mark Helprins 1983 best seller. Russell Crowe, rejoining Mr. Goldsman, the writer for A Beautiful Mind, is the gangster intent on putting their love asunder. Mr. Goldsman, making his directing debut, suppresses the morbid and even the merely sad implications of the story in favor of wide-eyed, mystical wonder, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. But a thin line separates the magical from the preposterous, and by insisting so strenuously on its own magic, Winters Tale pitches helplessly into earnest ridiculousness.

title: 3 Girls Killed in Hit-and-Run While Trick-or-Treating in Santa Ana
description: Three 13-year-old girls dressed in Halloween costumes and carrying bags of candy were killed by a hit-and-run driver while trick-or-treating in Santa Ana, Calif., on Friday evening, the authorities said.

title: Corrections: November 1, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: We never lose a party here at Ole Miss.

title: Timeline: Manny Being Manny
description: The Dodgers Manny Ramirez has been one of the most feared hitters and controversial personalities in baseball.

title: Grading Your School
description: The performance history for more than 3,500 schools and 700 districts since 1999.

title: For Everything There Is a Season
description: TIMES INSIDER  November is a busy month. Nature prepares for its winter rest, going to sleep after one last blaze of glory. Elections are held, so we can start the new year with a fresh slate of public officials. It feels like we cook all month long for our Thanksgiving feasts. Theres the unbelievable amount of gift shopping to be done. And before you know it, the month is over and we are lighting candles and untangling strings of light bulbs in preparation for the winter holidays.

title: Deborah Harmon, on Playing to Your Teams Strengths
description: This interview with  Deborah Harmon, chief executive of Artemis Real Estate Partners, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Their Steps Make Her Dance
In the Office of the Hard Rock C.E.O., Riffs on a Theme
description: The office of Hamish Dodds, chief executive of Hard Rock International, reflects the restaurant chains eclectic, rock n roll aesthetic.

title: Cracks in the Stress Tests of European Banks
description: The sigh of relief was almost audible last week when the European Central Bank published its long-awaited safety and soundness report on 130 banks in 19 countries in the region. Many investors seemed comforted that just 13 banks had failed the comprehensive exam.

title: Paying for Smoke Detectors
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: What Goes Up Must at Least Slow Down
description: Good news sometimes causes its own problems. That is, arguably, whats happened with the American stock market.

title: That Devil on Your Shoulder Likes to Sleep In
description: It is often asked why good people do bad things. Perhaps the question should be when.

title: Polls Show Tight Senate Races in Iowa and North Carolina
description: Many polling outfitswill be releasing their final surveysover the next few days, polls on which bragging rights for most accurate for the next election cycle could rely.

title: Macys Opens on 34th Street
description: The original article on Macys 34 Street location in the New York Times.

title: Variety: An Acrostic Discovery
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  I dont know about you, but I solved this more inside the grid than in the clues.

title: The Vital Role of the Occasional Voter
description: Low voter turnout is a bad thing. Lets get that out of the way immediately.

title: With Turbulent Season Looming for Lakers, Kobe Bryant Demonstrates an Early Calm
description: LOS ANGELES  It was an unusual scene. Here was Kobe Bryant, casually comfortable in his hooded sweatshirt, calmly reflective late Friday after the Los Angeles Lakers lost their third consecutive game to start the season.

title: Military Backs an Interim President, but Burkina Faso Remains Unsettled
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso  A day after President Blaise Compaor fled the country, ending 27 years in power in the face of revolt on the streets, military commanders on Saturday appeared to have resolved an internal power struggle by endorsing a colonel from the presidential guard to oversee a transition to elections.

title: Which President Cut the Most Nukes?
description: DOVES who once cheered President Obama for his antinuclear crusades and later fell silent as he backpedaled are now lining up to denounce him. A recent skewering by the Federation of American Scientists details how Mr. Obama, despite calling repeatedly for a world without nuclear weapons, has reduced the size of the nations atomic stockpile far less than did any of his three immediate predecessors, including both Presidents Bush.

title: Putins Friend Profits in Purge of Schoolbooks
description: MOSCOW  The purge began in late winter. One by one, hundreds of textbooks that Russian schoolchildren had relied upon for years were deemed unsuitable for use in the countrys 43,000 schools. The reasons varied, but they shared a certain bureaucratic obstinacy.

title: Coach Trains 900 Runners, Never Meeting Many of Them
description: Of the 900 marathoners John Honerkamp coaches, most skip workouts for the usual reasons: a sore knee, a looming work deadline, a toddler who screams through the night. Others are more particular, like the soldier in Afghanistan who could not fit in a run until he had helped move his base. Afterward he measured an 800-meter loop in the sand and made up the missed miles.

title: New York Ebola Patients Condition Improves, Officials Say
description: Doctors have upgraded the condition of New York Citys first Ebola patient, health officials said on Saturday.

title: Change of Scenery in N.H.L.: Crackdown on Theatrical Falls
description: Anaheim Ducks defenseman Sami Vatanen felt a stick blade jab him in the face during a game last week against the San Jose Sharks. Vatanen fell and lifted his hand to his mouth, either to draw attention to the foul or simply as a reaction to being stabbed by a stick.

title: Pouring One for the Muse
description: Believe it or not, people are still getting together in the flesh, and blood, to express themselves and socialize, leaving Facebook and Instagram behind, at least temporarily. Take painting parties, combined art classes and cocktail hours, which are becoming more prevalent on Long Island. Pamela Paredes just opened a Wine and Design franchise in Syosset in August and said business was already booming. Last weekend was absolutely fabulous, she said of the team-building event she had organized at Fox Hollow in Woodbury.

title: Wistful but Having Fun, Obama Gives Last Push
description: DETROIT  The giant white letters spelling V-O-T-E were already hoisted and the audience was on its feet in the gold-and-green-painted gymnasium as Gary Peters, the Democratic candidate for Senate, roused the room for President Obama.

title: Cricket Contract Dispute in India Forces Schedule Change
description: Indias millions of television-watching cricket fans will get their fix of top-class action this weekend, just not the match that was originally scheduled.

title: Mother Who Provides Round-the-Clock Care Finds Solace in Her Home
description: Whenever Geraldine Kentish and her daughter Ena return home  from whatever errand or doctor appointment lured them out  Ms. Kentish gently takes away Enas walker so that she can climb the stairs to their second-floor apartment on her own.

title: Wild Messengers
description: About a decade ago, a brain tumor came to steal my mother away. It was diagnosed after shed exhibited a series of strange behaviors (stranger than usual, I should say, as she was a quirky lady to begin with), and she very quickly went to a dark, quiet place that none of us could reach. Still, for a number of weeks, as she curled into an ever tightening ball under a growing mound of blankets, she continued caressing her three cats as they snuggled against her. When her hands finally went still, a week or so before her death, I knew we were nearing the end.

title: The New Wars Rising Cost
description: The Pentagon disclosed last week that Americas ever-shifting new war in the Middle East has cost taxpayers more than half a billion dollars since it began in August. Yet Congress has not bothered to hold a vote to authorize the Obama administrations decision to get into another war.

title: A Catholic Debate
description: Readers discuss a column by Ross Douthat about the recent synod on the family.

title: How Obama Lost America
description: THE 2014 midterms have featured many variables and one constant. Whether theyre running as incumbents or challengers, campaigning in blue or red or purple states, Democratic candidates have all been dragging an anchor: a president from their party whose approval ratings havent been north of 45 percent since last October.

title: They Call Me Doctor Berry
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind.  I HAVE never been big on titles. Many people I interact with outside my job dont even know that I am a professor, or that I have a doctoral degree. When I introduce myself in public, Im Carlotta Berry.

title: Debra Granik
description: Debra Granik is an independent filmmaker whose credits include Down to the Bone, Winters Bone and, most recently, the documentary Stray Dog.

title: Why 2014 Isnt as Good as It Seems for the Republicans
description: The Republicans are looking forward to having a good week. They are favored to win the Senate, and they could pick up enough House seats to finish with their largest margin since 1928.

title: The Kind of, Sort of Era
description: IVE sort of noticed something about the way we speak, and I wonder if youve sort of noticed it, too. Let me kind of explain. Its about sort of, and its twin, kind of, and how these adverbial downtoners, as the British grammarian Sir Randolph Quirk calls them, have totally, completely, 100 percent taken over casual speech.

title: Flying Blind in Iraq and Syria
description: THE Islamic State, also known as ISIS and ISIL, has accompanied its brutal takeover of large swaths of Iraq and Syria with the kidnapping and beheading of journalists. Any Western journalists who would dare to venture into ISIS territory today would be risking their lives every second. So the United States is now involved in the first prolonged war in the modern Middle East that American reporters and photographers cant cover firsthand on a daily basis, with the freedom to observe and write what they please and with the sustained presence to offer perspective on how the story is evolving. That is not good.

title: The Missing Campus Climate Debate
description: CLIMATE CHANGE is our eras defining challenge, but most of Americas universities are planning to sit this one out. Though students and faculty members at more than 400 colleges have called for administrators to divest from fossil-fuel energy companies, fewer than 20 have committed to doing so. Stanford recently divested from coal, but none of the other schools had endowments within the 150 largest in 2013.

title: New Buildings for Older People
description: SAN FRANCISCO  I HEARD about the new building for months before I saw it. Part of a leading medical center, its green architecture and design were getting a lot of attention, as was its integration of top-notch modern medicine with health and wellness spaces inspired by cultures from around the world. My fathers doctor had moved there, and driving to his appointment we looked forward to experiencing the cutting-edge new building firsthand.

title: There Is No Healthy Microbiome
description: LONDON  IN the late 17th century, the Dutch naturalist Anton van Leeuwenhoek looked at his own dental plaque through a microscope and saw a world of tiny cells very prettily a-moving. He could not have predicted that a few centuries later, the trillions of microbes that share our lives  collectively known as the microbiome  would rank among the hottest areas of biology.

title: The Terrible 32s
description: WHAT ARE THE TERRIBLE 32S?

title: Teenagers Stand Up to Backpage
description: IF prostitution of children is illegal, why is it that we allow an estimated 100,000 underage girls and boys to be sold for sex in America each year  many on a single American website, Backpage.com?

title: A Cup of G.I. Joe
description: WHEN I close my eyes, I can easily flash back to a time when it was cool to call people in uniform pigs and baby killers.

title: American Partisanship, From Sports to Disease
description: This is the time of year when this expatriate most acutely misses the American homeland, where nature is staging one of the most spectacular color shows on earth and the greatest of sports follow in exhilarating succession.

title: The Pitiful Whimper of 2014
description: IMAGINE a house ablaze. Now picture a team of firefighters pulling up to it. They behold the flames shooting through its roof. They feel its heat on their faces. And they get in position to fight it.

title: Tax Cuts on Trial in Governors Races
description: There is only so long a governor can do great damage to a state before voters start to demand a change. In Kansas, Gov. Sam Brownback, a Republican who has driven down his states credit rating and cratered its budget with ill-advised tax cuts, is paying a huge price in popularity for his actions.

title: The Knicks Way Starts to Change
description: Only hours removed from expressing even more uncertainty about his new role in a new offense under a new coach, J. R. Smith was in a good mood. It was late Thursday in the visitors locker room at Quicken Loans Arena, and Smith had played a major role in the Knicks unexpected victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: What Were Watching: Sunday Shows
description: Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, is not running for re-election this fall, but hes certainly kept busy this fall stumping for candidates in North Carolina, Georgia and Iowa. On Sunday, Mr. Paul will continue to promote his party, which many forecasters say will retake Congress, on several network shows, including CNNs State of the Union, CBSs Face the Nation and NBCs Meet the Press.

title: Week 9 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Broncos (6-1) at Patriots (6-2)

title: In North Carolina, Campaigns for Senate Play to Dislikes in an Effort to Stoke Interest
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  Thom Tillis, North Carolinas Republican candidate for the United States Senate, is partial to the first page from his partys national playbook this year. It involves mentioning his Democratic opponent, Senator Kay Hagan, in the same breath as President Obama, and doing so as often as possible.

title: Endurance Test of a Race, for Candidates and Voters in Iowa
description: NEWTON, Iowa  A small crowd of the faithful had gathered at the county Democratic headquarters here to listen to Representative Bruce Braley make his closing case, giving little hint of the blunder-pocked road he has traveled during his campaign for the United States Senate.

title: Republicans Setting the Early Pace in Colorado With 104,000 More Ballots
description: MANITOU SPRINGS, Colo.  It was warm and sunny and smelled of cinnamon-orange tea inside a roadside cafe here in the mountains, but as a dozen Democrats waited for Senator Mark Udalls campaign bus to arrive for a last-minute pep rally, the air was laced with dread.

title: To Rebuild, Jets Can Use Chiefs Blueprint
description: Once there was a 1-7 team. It had the worst turnover margin in the N.F.L. and the worst quarterback situation, too. It gave up a lot of points, despite Pro Bowl talent on defense, and scored not nearly enough. Its fan base fumed and frothed, shamed by the on-field product and disenchanted with the leadership and direction.

title: In France, Dam Is the Catalyst for a Flood of Young Peoples Anger
description: LISLE-SUR-TARN, France  The protests began a year ago in this quiet corner of southwestern France, as a small and peaceful gathering of hippies, environmental activists and utopians of all types set up tents to oppose the construction of a nearby dam.

title: In Torrent of Rapes in Britain, an Uncomfortable Focus on Race and Ethnicity
description: ROCHDALE, England  Shabir Ahmed, a delivery driver for two takeout places, did not have to go looking for young girls. Runaways and rebellious teenagers would show up at the restaurants, often hungry and cold. He slipped them free drinks and chicken tikka masala. Call me Daddy, he would say.

title: Handling of Sexual Harassment Case Poses Larger Questions at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN  A sexual harassment case that has been unfolding without public notice for nearly five years within the Yale School of Medicine has roiled the institution and led to new allegations that the university is insensitive to instances of harassment against women.

title: Both Parties See Campaign Tilting to Republicans
description: WASHINGTON  Republicans entered the final weekend before the midterm elections clearly holding the better hand to control the Senate and poised to add to their House majority. But a decidedly sour electorate and a sizable number of undecided voters added a measure of suspense.

title: Sundays Matchup: Jets (1-7) at Chiefs (4-3)
description: 1 p.m., CBS

title: Electricity Returns to Bangladesh After Power Failure
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  A power failure swept through Bangladesh on Saturday after a transmission line in the electrical grid failed, causing a nationwide blackout.

title: Clashes on Syrian Border Split Lebanese Town
description: RAS BAALBEK, Lebanon  Waleed Fayyad coaxed his sport utility vehicle through a chilly rain, peering down dark streets in search of suspicious vehicles. Later that night, a few miles down the road, Lebanese soldiers and Hezbollah fighters would rush to thwart insurgents trying to descend the mountains from the Syrian border, but on Mr. Fayyads patrol through this remote Christian village, nothing moved.

title: Scott Walker Leaves His Mark on Vikings New Stadium
description: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, locked in a tight race for re-election, may have just scored a few points with voters by ratcheting up the rivalry between his states Green Bay Packers and their arch rivals, the Minnesota Vikings.

title: Marriage Built on Miles Finds Hope in Marathon
description: John and I had been married for 16 years, and lately it felt as if we couldnt get through a day without bickering. It didnt matter if we were discussing the best way to get our 10-year-old to sleep in his own bed or our health insurance plan; the result was the same  another fight. Even a simple dinner was a minefield: He couldnt call when he was running late, I couldnt cook chicken that tasted edible, and we both wavered on whether our 12-year-old should have to finish his broccoli before starting his hours of homework. Was this what marriage was all about?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Golf Gives Short Shrift to Women

title: Regional Classics, Many Moods
description: In August, pasta gave way to grits when the business at 348 East Jericho Turnpike in Mineola, known as a home for Italian restaurants like Lula Trattoria and Circa Ristorante Enoteca, reopened with a classic American menu. True American Kitchen offers popular dishes like New England lobster rolls, Georgia peach barbecue baby back ribs and Louisiana shrimp and grits.

title: Escaping Civilization, but Not His Former Family
description: Ulysses is one major oddball. Not the hero of The Odyssey, in this case, or James Joyces novel, but the wreck of a middle-aged American man portrayed in Sharr Whites Annapurna, which is the strong and poignant opening production of Theaterworks Hartfords 2014-15 season.

title: Even Brutes Can Learn to Cry
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  The Mountain is crying and it looks like a thunderstorm, a shaking of colossal shoulders and a soaking of crocodile tears. Hafthor Julius Bjornsson, known to most as Thor and to anyone who watches Game of Thrones as the Mountain, is acting, or at least trying to show that he resembles a skilled thespian as much as he does a refrigerator.

title: For Man in Ebola Virus Cleanup, a History of Fraud
description: The chief safety officer of the hazardous-materials company that cleaned the apartment of New York Citys first Ebola patient was, in a past career as a mortgage negotiator, accused of fraud in 2009 by the attorney general at the time, Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: Proud. Elegant. Feathered.
description: Eagles were made to soar, canaries to sing and peacocks, obviously, to dazzle the eye. But in Strut: The Peacock and Beauty in Art, the gorgeous creature with the magnificent plumage is dissected and found to have hidden depths and multiple personalities. Through some 150 objects created in the 19th, 20th and 21st centuries, this fascinating exhibition from the Hudson River Museum recounts the many ways artists, designers and the rest of us have made use of this astonishing bird.

title: Pitchers, Hitters and a Panda
description: On Thursday, more than 100 players became free agents, and a few dozen more could be granted free agency depending on the status of their contract options. Though the 2015 season is five months away, Monday represents a huge deadline: Teams will have to decide whether they want to offer their eligible free agents a $15.2 million qualifying offer that will protect them from receiving no compensation if a player decides to sign elsewhere.

title: Diageo Is Said to Be in Talks on Exchange of Brands With Jose Cuervo
description: Diageo and the family that manufactures Jose Cuervo tequila are in advanced talks to swap two of their best-known brands, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Saturday.

title: BP Station
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  You know what I like? I like a nice, relatively easy puzzle with a nice, relatively easy theme after a puzzle like yesterdays Trip Payne tour de force. No math symbols. No tricks. No rebuses. Like todays puzzle: a nice, well put-together letter-swap theme. And by Brendan Emmett Quigley, yet. That means lots of good pop culture. Just what the doctor ordered.

title: A Few Election Answers That Will Define the State of Political Power in Texas
description: AUSTIN  Republicans appear poised to maintain their grip on every statewide office in Texas for a 16th straight year, yet Tuesdays election results will yield information beyond winners and losers. Political observers will be looking closely at voter turnout and exit poll data, seeking insights into where Texas is politically, and where it may be headed. Here are the questions most drawing their attention:

title: A Broad Consensus Emerges on Senate Races
description: Republicans were growing increasingly confident on Saturday that they would win the Iowa Senate race, picking up a Democratic-held seat that could ensure that they gain the majority.

title: A Band That Couldnt Wait to Quit Now Lingers a Bit
description: In 2007, on the message boards at Absolutepunk.net, a fan posted a picture of a tattoo he had commissioned featuring a lyric from the long-defunct Austin band Mineral: How blessed we are.

title: Senior Senator Waits Quietly in the Wings
description: While the junior United States senator from Texas hogs the limelight, the senior senator could soon move into management of that chamber.

title: Fleeing a Mexican Border Town Amid a Yearslong Drug War
description: GUADALUPE DISTRITO BRAVO, Mexico  Remnants of small-town charm were still visible last week from the outskirts of this Mexican border city as bolls of damp cotton weighed down branches and a rancher slowly chased a stray cow headed for the highway.

title: In Thailand, Tracking the Dog Trade
description: Thai police are ramping up efforts to slow the trafficking of dogs who are being captured and killed for their meat and skin.

title: Dog Meat Trade in Thailand Is Under Pressure and May Be Banned
description: BAAN KLANG, Thailand  The dog-eating community here, a small minority of rice farmers and day laborers, has long understood that its culinary habits do not sit well with people from other parts of Thailand, especially the pet-loving urban middle and upper classes.

title: Virgin Galactic Is Rattled, but Undeterred, by Deadly Space Plane Crash
description: A team of about 15 investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board began its inquiry on Saturday into the crash of a Virgin Galactic space plane on Friday in the Mojave Desert that killed the co-pilot and severely injured the pilot.

title: Alagappa Alagappan, 88, Dies; Founded Hindu Temples Across U.S.
description: In 1968, on a trip to his native India, Alagappa Alagappan dreamed that an ancient Hindu god told him to visit a medium. So he did, and on his first visit the medium read palm leaves to tell him that the Lord Ganesha  another deity, this one beloved for his laugh and his elephant head  wanted to settle in a city beginning with the letter N.

title: Bernard Mayes, 85, Dies; Started First U.S. Suicide Hotline
description: Bernard Mayes, a multifaceted Anglican priest who started the first suicide hotline in the United States and a decade later became the founding chairman of National Public Radio, died on Oct. 23 in San Francisco. He was 85.

title: Braced for a Shift in Congress, Obama Is Setting a New Agenda
description: WASHINGTON  Whipsawed by events and facing another midterm electoral defeat, President Obama has directed his team to forge a policy agenda to regain momentum for his final two years in office even as some advisers urge that he rethink the way he governs.

title: Labour Party Leader Backs Replacing House of Lords
description: LONDON  The House of Lords traces its roots to the 14th century. Now the Labour Party is proposing to consign it to history.

title: Breeders Cup 2014: In Classic, Bayern Bumps the Favorite, Shared Belief, Then Wins in a Wild Finish
description: ARCADIA, Calif.  When the gates swung open for the start of the $5 million Breeders Cup Classic late Saturday afternoon at Santa Anita Park, it did not so much resemble a high-stakes horse race as it did Nascar on hooves.

title: Defects Found Before Debut of Health Insurance Site for Small Businesses
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has discovered a number of defects in the online marketplace that will offer health insurance to millions of small-business employees, but federal officials said the problems could probably be fixed before the website goes live on Nov. 15.

title: Michigans Win Is Easy; Questions on Future Are Anything But
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  The day after Dave Brandon resigned as the University of Michigans athletic director resembled most other football Saturdays in this college town.

title: Fire Kills 5 in Building Near College in Maine
description: A three-alarm fire swept through an apartment house in Portland, Me., early Saturday morning, killing five people and critically injuring one, in what the authorities said was the deadliest fire in the state in 30 years.

title: Armys Rough Week Gets Worse as Air Force Secures Commander-in-Chiefs Trophy
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.  Wind and rain did not diminish the line of cars that stretched for miles before Thayer Gate, one of two main entrances to Armys hilly campus. For all intentions, Saturday afternoon was the last meaningful home game of the Black Knights season, and a sellout crowd crammed into Michie Stadium to see it.

title: In Rhode Island Governors Race, Pension Issue Could Hurt Raimondo
description: CRANSTON, R.I.  Serena Mancini, who has worked at Rhode Islands Department of Transportation for 25 years, had planned to retire in four years, at 54. But when Gina M. Raimondo, the state treasurer, restructured the states failing pension system, Ms. Mancini had to recalculate. She has had to put off retirement until 59, and will be receiving fewer benefits.

title: Netanyahu Urges Restraint in Row Over Sacred Site
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel called Saturday night for responsibility and restraint regarding this citys most sensitive sacred site, urging members of Parliament to work to calm the situation after days of mounting tension.

title: Argentine Judge Orders Arrest of Spanish Ex-Officials
description: BUENOS AIRES  A judge in Argentina has ordered the arrest of 20 former Spanish officials accused of torturing dissidents during the dictatorship of Francisco Franco, from 1939 to 1975, renewing efforts to pursue cases of human rights abuses beyond the countrys borders.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 1, 2014
Inside the Guts of Macys Herald Square
description: Macys Herald Square has been undergoing a luxury makeover. But with a building that is more than a century old, everything from the loading bays to the stockrooms also needs to be overhauled.

title: For Macys, a Makeover on 34th Street
description: Terry J. Lundgren, the chief executive of Macys, strode through the womens shoe department of the companys flagship store in Manhattans Herald Square, determined to find a bargain.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 2, 2014
description: I have never seen such a level of cynicism and chaos before.

title: Patterns on Repeat
description: Geometric graphics made strong statements this season, with designers taking their cues from art and architecture to play tricks on the eye.

title: A Hotel Room of Ones Own
description: As writers have long known, checking into a luxurious hotel room  even in your own city  is a glorious escape and its own kind of holiday.

title: Eric Menkes, Sean Davis
description: Eric Gerald Menkes and Sean Lyons Davis were married Saturday at Perry St., a restaurant in New York. Geoffrey A. Blatt, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Hilary Sledge and Lateef Sarnor
description: Hilary Ruth Sledge and Lateef A. Sarnor were married Saturday at Cornerstone Sonoma, an event space in Sonoma, Calif. Judge Denise Page Hood of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan officiated, with her husband, the Rev. Dr. Nicholas Hood III, a minister of Plymouth United Church of Christ, taking part.

title: Kathryn Michalek, Geoffrey Exum
description: Kathryn Marie Michalek and Geoffrey Graham Exum were married Saturday at Highlands Country Club in Garrison, N.Y., by Joan Clauss, a marriage officer and a deputy town clerk in Philipstown, N.Y.

title: Marissa Hayat, Samuel Eisner
description: Marissa Nicole Hayat and Samuel Heiden Eisner were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Gary Katz at Studio 450, an events space in New York.

title: Christina Tafaro, David Munczinski
description: Christina Lyn Tafaro and David Richard Munczinski were married Saturday by the Rev. John P. McGuire at St. Josephs Church in Greenwich Village.

title: Suzanne Walter, Zachary Sherman
description: Suzanne Michelle Walter, the daughter of Rene L. Walter and Dr. Thomas S. Walter of Palm Harbor, Fla., was married Saturday evening to Zachary Michael Videka Sherman, the son of Lynn M. Videka of Manhattan and Barry R. Sherman of Delmar, N.Y. Rabbi Gary Klein officiated at the Vinoy Renaissance Hotel in St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: Emily Millen, Christopher Heffernan
description: Emily Anne Millen and Christopher Heffernan were married Saturday at St. Marys Church in Tuxedo Park, N.Y. The Rev. Elizabeth S. McWhorter, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Katherine Wheaton and Michael Warner
description: Katherine Hamilton Wheaton and Michael Douglas Warner were married Saturday at the Chicago Cultural Center. Judge Bruce A. Peterson of the Hennepin County District Court in Minneapolis officiated, as allowed by Illinois marriage law.

title: Bonnie Malone, Alexander Fleming
description: Beverly Elizabeth Malone and Alexander Harrison Fleming were married Saturday. The Rev. Robert S. Taylor, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Lost Tree Chapel in North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: David Melanon Jr. and Michael Mosca
description: Warren David Melanon Jr. and Michael Joseph Mosca were married Saturday at Havens Kitchen in New York. Judge Sarah Netburn, a federal magistrate judge for the Southern District of New York, officiated.

title: Kimberly Brownstein, Jason Greenberg
description: Kimberly Dana Brownstein and Jason Gelvan Greenberg were married Saturday evening at Rosewood Tuckers Point, a hotel in Hamilton Parish, Bermuda. Cantor Joshua R. Konigsberg officiated.

title: Lucinda Watson and Ted Bell
description: Lucinda Watson, a daughter of the late Olive Cawley Watson and the late Thomas J. Watson Jr., who lived in Greenwich, Conn., was married Tuesday to Ted Bell, the son of the late Mary Howell Bell, who lived in San Juan, P.R., and the late Theodore A. Bell, who lived in Dallas. The Very Rev. Dr. Jane Shaw, an Episcopal priest and the dean for religious life at Stanford University, officiated at San Ysidro Ranch, a resort and hotel in Montecito, Calif.

title: Julia Conway and Benjamin Slovis
description: Dr. Julia Claire Conway, a daughter of Patricia A. Conway and Joseph R. Conway of Agawam, Mass., was married Saturday at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation in Montclair, N.J., to Dr. Benjamin Heritier Slovis, a son of Maria Heritier and Michael A. Slovis, who live and work in Montclair. The Rev. Charles B. Ortman, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Rachel Tofel and Cameron Ferrante
description: Rachel Straus Tofel, the daughter of Jeanne H. Straus and Richard J. Tofel, both of New York, was married Saturday to Cameron Adams Ferrante, a son of Alison A. Ferrante and Dr. Giovanni A. F. Ferrante of Bristol, Va. Susan J. Kohlmann, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life Minister for the event, officiated at the Barn at Flanagan Farm in Buxton, Me.

title: Elizabeth Gancher, Jonathan Lustgarten
description: Elizabeth Anne Gancher, the daughter of Betty N. Gancher and Paul D. Gancher of Glens Falls, N.Y., is to be married Sunday to Jonathan Llyle Lustgarten, a son of Dr. Jacqueline S. Lustgarten of New York and Eli S. Lustgarten of St. Louis. Rabbi Alex Freedman is to officiate at the New York Country Club in Spring Valley.

title: Fenaba Addo, Senay Goitom
description: Fenaba Rena Addo and Senay Goitom were married Saturday. The Rev. Benjamin J. Dueholm, a Lutheran minister, officiated at the Wisconsin Institutes for Discovery, a science center and events space in Madison.

title: It Was the Best Date She Never Had
description: Elizabeth Kate Murphy and Ben Malik Karambiri are to be married Sunday evening at the Liberty Warehouse, an event space in Brooklyn. Mike Dipalma, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

title: Kaitlyn Collins, James Weingarten
description: Kaitlyn Elizabeth Collins and James Harris Weingarten were married Saturday. The Rev. Adam Y. Park performed the ceremony at the Epiphany Roman Catholic Church in Washington, with Rabbi Harold S. White taking part.

title: Abby Green, Nathan Singh
description: Dr. Abby Margaret Green and Dr. Nathan Singh were married Saturday in Healdsburg, Calif. Alan B. Green, an uncle of the bride who was ordained for the occasion by the American Marriage Ministries, officiated at Barndiva, an events space.

title: Elizabeth Kellogg, Nikhil Bahadur
description: Elizabeth Bradley Kellogg and Nikhil Bahadur were married Saturday. Pandit Prabhakar Sharma, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Plaza hotel in New York.

title: Nicole Donato, Keenan Rose
description: Nicole Katherine Donato, the daughter of Paul J. Donato of Manhattan and the late Kathleen B. Donato, was married Saturday evening to Keenan Thomas Rose, a son of Janet K. Rose and Russ B. Rose of Springfield, Mo. Andrew R. Cafourek, a friend of the couple who became a minister of the American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated at the Greenpoint Loft in Brooklyn.

title: Maris Bish, Jonathan Sotsky
description: Maris Marta Bish and Jonathan Morris Sotsky were married Saturday at the Miami Beach Botanical Garden. Rabbi Gayle Pomerantz officiated.

title: Casey Herzog, Kenneth Gold
description: Casey Alexandra Herzog and Kenneth Robert Gold were married Saturday evening by Rabbi David Kraemer at the Inn at Longshore in Westport, Conn.

title: Katherine Locke, Courtney Wilburn
description: Katherine Anne Locke and Courtney Janelle Wilburn were married Saturday under Pennsylvanias self-uniting marriage statute, at the Old Pine Community Center in Philadelphia.

title: Bieber Bangs and Bibles
description: Tiffany Stanley and Alan Bennett Krill were married Saturday at the Unitarian Church in Charleston, S.C. The Rev. Taylor Lewis Guthrie Hartman, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Something to Dance About
description: Summer Elliott Wilkie and Sean Patrick Mahoney were married Saturday evening at the Brooklyn Historical Society. Pamela J. Wilkie, an aunt of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Deadly Halloween Across the Nation
description: Halloween took a deadly turn for trick-or-treaters, paradegoers and party guests across the country, on a holiday that federal safety regulators say is one of the deadliest on Americas roadways.

title: Corrections: November 2, 2014
description: NEW YORK

title: Eclectic and on Point, Prince Hijacks 8 Minutes on S.N.L.
description: Its America; we commercialize everything, said Chris Rock in his opening monologue for Saturday Night Live. That would be the cynical take on the episodes carefully hyped musical performance: a mid-show appearance by Prince. Booked for the show at Mr. Rocks request, Prince departed from longstanding S.N.L. custom for musical guests; instead of two brief, single-song performances, he played an eight-minute mini-set.

title: Off Color and on Target About Race in America
description: In his comedy album Waiting for 2042, Hari Kondabolu pokes fun at the shifting demographics in the United States, where minorities are expected to outnumber whites by 2042. But theres no need to freak out, the Indian-American comic advises whites. You were the minority when you came to this country, he said. Things seem to have worked out for you.

title: China Approves Security Law Emphasizing Counterespionage
description: BEIJING  President Xi Jinping of China has signed a new Counterespionage Law, replacing the 1993 National Security Law with an updated set of rules that will more closely target foreign spies and Chinese individuals and organizations who collaborate with them.

title: Heartache for New Yorks Catholics as Church Closings Are Announced
description: There were gasps and tears at Holy Rosary Church in East Harlem. At Sacred Heart in Mount Vernon, congregants shared mournful embraces. And at Our Lady of Peace on the East Side, parishioners pledged a fight.

title: U.N. Panel Issues Its Starkest Warning Yet on Global Warming
description: COPENHAGEN  The gathering risks of climate change are so profound that they could stall or even reverse generations of progress against poverty and hunger if greenhouse emissions continue at a runaway pace, according to a major new United Nations report.

title: Monster Moves to Restore a Faded Job Search Brand
description: Remember Monster.com?

title: Republicans Hold Edge in Early Voting in Colorado
description: It would be a galling symbol of Democratic misfortune this cycle if Colorado turned out to be where the Democratic turnout machine most obviously fell short of its lofty goals.

title: When a Teacher Is Arrested for Child Pornography, Students Will Talk
description: Can I ask a question about Mr. W? 10-year-old Brennan asks, and my stomach takes a roller-coaster dip. We have just left the school potluck, where he spent hours playing a game of tag on the playground. But when I went to retrieve him, I was surprised to discover that he had dropped out of the action and sat alone atop the playgrounds chain-link fence, kicking his feet. I asked him what was up but he avoided my eyes and shrugged, saying only that he was ready to go home. Now that we are buckled in and on the road, he is ready to talk.

title: Bracing for the Falls of an Aging Nation
description: Across the nation, places like The Sequoias are trying to reduce the number of falls among their increasingly elderly residents while satisfying peoples desire to live life as they choose.

title: 1914: Parisians Flock to Cemeteries on All Souls Day to Honor Dead Soldiers
description: All Souls Day, when French custom decrees one shall make a pilgrimage to the tombs of the dead, is always an impressive occasion in Paris, but yesterday was especially so, owing to the bereavements of the war, and the great outpouring of the public to the cemeteries at Pantin, Ivry and Bagneux, where soldiers fallen in the conflict have been buried. It was a throng typically Parisian, typically proletariat, which filed through the massive stone gates of the cemetery at Bagneux to the section where most of the soldiers who have died in the great military hospital of Val-de-Grce lie buried. Perhaps half of the women were hatless. Many carried children in their arms. By half-past two oclock in the afternoon the street in front of the cemetery was an unbroken phalanx moving toward the gates. At half-past four, when the autumn sun was disappearing behind the trees, the stream was still coming from Paris.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 3, 1914

title: The Economy Elects Presidents. Presidents Elect Congress.
description: In 1992, Bill Clintons strategist, James Carville, made famous a presidential campaign mantra: Its "the economy, stupid. He meant that presidential election outcomes are tied to the nations economic conditions, something that should not surprise many people. The same, however, is not true for midterm elections. Those are much more tied to the president himself.

title: Hong Kong Police Arrest British Banker After 2 Womens Bodies Are Found
description: HONG KONG  A 29-year-old British man has been arrested after the bodies of two women were found in his upscale apartment, the Hong Kong police said over the weekend. One womans throat had been slashed, and the body of the other was found decomposing, stuffed in a suitcase on a balcony.

title: List of Merging Churches and Those That Will Cease Regular Services
description: A list of churches in the region that will merge. The parish listed on the left and the parish on the right will merge. Masses and other sacraments will cease to be celebrated on a regular basis at the church in the right column. The merger is expected to take effect by August 2015.

title: List of Merging Churches; All Parishes Will Hold Services Regularly
description: A list of churches in the region that will merge. The parish listed on the left and the parish on the right will merge. Both churches will remain open for the regular celebration of Masses and other events. The merger is expected to take effect by August 2015.

title: 1939: American Ships Hasten to Sail Before New Bill Takes Effect
description: NEW YORK  United States liners and freighters scheduled to sail for belligerent ports tonight [Nov. 2 ] speeded preparations to get away within the next day or two before the Administrations neutrality bill, passed by the House of Representatives today, would become effective. The United States liner Washington, scheduled to sail for Europe next Wednesday, will leave New York tomorrow morning, and the President Roosevelt is sailing tomorrow noon instead of Saturday. The American Farmer will make a special trip without passengers, sailing today or tomorrow. Under the terms of the existing neutrality legislation American vessels are permitted to carry merchandise of a non-military nature to belligerent ports, but when the new law goes into effect, all American ships will be forbidden to enter the waters of states designated as belligerents by the President. Although ships of the United States merchant marine may not call at French, British or German ports in the actual war zone, they may carry cargo and passengers to ports belonging to the belligerents definitely outside the zone of combat, such as Australia, New Zealand, India, Indo-China and the West Indies.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 3, 1939

title: A Rise in Falls
description: As the population ages, hospitals and retirement communities are bracing for an increase in the number of falls among the elderly, The Times reports. Read the full story. Update: A second story on falls was published in Science Times.

title: Bomber Kills at Least 50 in Wagah, Town on India-Pakistan Border
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  At least 55 people were killed and at least 120 more were wounded Sunday evening when a suicide bomber set off explosives at a border post in eastern Pakistan, police officials said.

title: Kenyans Duel in Close Womens Race
description: Another show of Kenyan dominance in distance running came down to a two-woman race Sunday at the New York City Marathon.

title: Arm Bump Precedes Late Burst in Mens Race
description: As Wilson Kipsang of Kenya and Lelisa Desisa of Ethiopia ran stride for stride into the last stretch of the New York City Marathon on Sunday morning, a long run turned into an unusually personal sprint. As Desisa, the younger challenger, tried to surge ahead, his left arm pushed Kipsangs arm away.

title: Panels Latest Warming Warning Misses Global Slumber Party on Energy Research
description: The year-long rollout of the latest assessment of climate change science and solutionsby the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change ended today in Copenhagen with the release of a final synthesis report offering an overview of the worlds climate trajectories and choices.

title: Nightcrawler Leads Halloween Weekend Box Office
description: Nightcrawler (Open Road Films), an $8.5 million crime drama starring Jake Gyllenhaal, took in an estimated $10.91 million over the weekend, enough to rank atop the North American box office.

title: The Guts of a Neighborhood Center, Tossed Out in the Trash
description: Brother Bill Fecteau banged on the padlocked door of the Highbridge Community Life Center in the Bronx. No answer. Inside, beyond the vestibule where scraps of paper littered the floor like confetti, he spied dark figures moving about. They ignored him. He went around to the back and peered through a window, only to see classrooms with no books, furniture or computers.

title: Rebel-Backed Elections to Cement Status Quo in Ukraine
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  The campaign billboards in this city suggested a tight race between Aleksandr Zakharchenko and Aleksandr Zakharchenko.

title: It May Be Too Late, but Colorado Early Ballots Are Shifting Toward Democrats
description: In an article published this morning, I wrote that the trend lines for early ballots werent moving fast enough for Democrats in Colorado. The ballots received over the last week leaned Republican by about six percentage points  no better for Democrats than in 2010.

title: U.N. Employee Under Treatment for Ebola in France
description: France was treating a United Nations employee who contracted the Ebola virus in Sierra Leone, the health ministry said in a statement posted Sunday on its website.

title: Reaction to the Merging of Catholic Churches
description: As part of the largest reorganization in the history of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, 55 area parishes will merge into neighboring churches by August 2015.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) OLIVE KITTERIDGE Frances McDormand, above, aging 25 years on screen, portrays Olive, a dowdy, gruff math teacher who witnesses the affairs, crimes and tragedies in an unremarkable Maine town alongside her husband, Henry (Richard Jenkins), a kindly pharmacist, in Lisa Cholodenkos adaptation of Elizabeth Strouts Pulitzer Prize-winning collection of stories. John Gallagher Jr. plays the couples son, Christopher, who resents his mothers ways; and Bill Murray is Jack Kennison, a lonely widower who shares Olives inner sadness. This mini-series, shown on Sunday and Monday, is a rare treasure, a measured, understated portrait of a marriage that finds poetry in the most prosaic of settings and circumstances: flinty, stolid citizens of a small, insular town in coastal Maine, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. There is no glamour and little romance, yet there is a fine-grained mystery to the most ordinary, blunted lives.

title: In Iowa Senate Race, Joni Ernst Increases Her Edge
description: Joni Ernst has taken a bigger lead in her bid to become the nextsenator from Iowa, according to a new poll, but her advantage remains within the polls margin of sampling error.

title: N.B.A. Pounds Pavement for Fitness Effort
description: N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver had just finished an icy three-mile run over the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. His lips, ears and nose were red from the blistering gusts of wind.

title: Israeli Lawmakers Tour Stokes Tension Over Holy Site
description: JERUSALEM  A hard-line Israeli lawmaker from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus Likud Party toured this citys most contested holy site with a police escort on Sunday, and a far-right minister reiterated a contentious call for Jews to be allowed to pray there, despite Mr. Netanyahus plea for politicians to show responsibility and restraint.

title: A Verdi Test Where Nuance Is Just One of the Many Demands
description: Six weeks into its season, the Metropolitan Opera has presented all three pinnacles of the standard repertory, the so-called ABCs of opera: Verdis Aida, Puccinis La Bohme and Bizets Carmen. While none of these revivals has been thrilling, most dismaying is the listless Aida that opened Thursday. It begins in a chill and barely thaws.

title: Microsoft Band Is a Welcome Surprise in the Wearable Market
description: Microsoft surprised the tech world last week by introducing a new fitness tracking wristband, along with an app and cloud-computing technology for tracking health and fitness data.

title: Contortions, Clowning and Confetti
description: Metamorphosis is the theme of the latest edition of the Big Apple Circus, now nested at Lincoln Center for the holidays. And considering the scale of this troupe  more intimate, in the European tradition, than the Ringling Brothers behemoth  you could say this impressive production starts modestly, only to spread its wings and soar.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: After Eighth Loss in a Row, the Jets Sound a Lowly Refrain
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  As always, the Jets had a terrific week of practice. They always do. Always, always, always. Then comes game day, when they are required to line up opposite people wearing different-colored uniforms.

title: Elite Runners Serve as Muses for Shoe Design
description: LEXINGTON, Mass.  On a $100,000 two-lane treadmill surrounded by cameras in a studio near Boston, the elite runner Michelle Lilienthal easily pounded out seven-minute miles, her stride widening as she approached her marathon race speed and dipped below a six-minute pace.

title: Like One-Word Answers
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Janet R. Bender has been contributing puzzles to The New York Times since 1992, and if you look at her track record, she seems to have a real thing for themes where the beginning letters of multiple-word phrases are the same.

title: With Magazine, CNET Tech Site Makes Jump From Screen to Page
description: A LEADING technology website, CNET, is expanding into a platform that its users praise as portable, accessible and affordable. And unlike tablets, smartphones or laptops, it is also good for squishing bugs.

title: An Eclectic Evening to Start a Season
description: In the musical world, we still have work to do to broaden and update our canon, perhaps to go beyond the very idea of a canon at all. But even beyond the major orchestras and star soloists, plenty of performers have been engaged in such an effort for years.

title: First Draft Focus: Common Ground
Naughty in Spite of Himself
description: The issue of street harassment has received wide attention recently, with men and women often disagreeing on what constitutes harassment versus harmless flattery in a public space. This longstanding (and serious) issue surfaces in lighthearted form in Gilbert and Sullivans Ruddigore (The Witchs Curse), when the virtuous maiden Rose Maybud consults her etiquette manual about the appropriateness of a strangers complimenting her appearance.

title: Legions of Faiths, Girded for Battle
description: Jack Miles has undertaken no less ambitious a project than writing a biography of God, winning a Pulitzer Prize in the bargain.

title: Quarantine, North Korea Style
description: Pyongyang tackles human rights.

title: Chilling Story of Friendship and Death, Served Chilled
description: The French choreographer Gisle Vienne has said that she doesnt think of Kindertotenlieder, her staggeringly dark work of dance-theater, as scary. Its more uncanny, as she sees it. I saw things differently during the productions United States premiere on Wednesday at New York Live Arts. Scary definitely applied.

title: Michelle Nunns Hopes in Georgia Are Fading in Final Stretch
description: One of the few bits of bad news for Republicans over the last couple of months was the Georgia Senate race, where the Democrat, Michelle Nunn, pulled into a tie with the Republican, David Perdue, after a 2005 deposition was revealed in which Mr. Perdue said that he was proud of his record of outsourcing.

title: The Guys Who Just Watch
description: Its been almost three decades since we first met Frank Bascombe in Richard Fords milestone 1986 novel The Sportswriter. In the years since, Frank has become his creators Everyman, as much a representative of middle-class American life and its discontents as John Updikes Harry Angstrom was for another generation in the Rabbit novels.

title: Medal for American Pair at World Championships
description: The only American medalists in the three concluding pair events at the world championships in China last month were Reese Milner of Los Angeles and Hemant Lall of Dallas. They won the silver medals in the Senior Pairs, which followed on their victory in the Rand Senior Teams.

title: When Deal Wobbles, a Double Steps In
description: Sordid seems too mild a word for The Lookalike, an arch, clotted new noir. A convoluted plot begins when Sadie (Gillian Jacobs) agrees to sleep with her fathers former business associate for $500,000. The assignation will leverage a drug connection for a gangster, Bobby (John Corbett, sounding like Jeff Bridges). Then Sadie dies in a freak accident: Bobbys criminal partner (Steven Bauer) shakes a desk, causing a chandelier to fall on her. Hey, it happens. But it leaves the men scrambling to find a double.

title: Man Behind Operation Needs One Himself
description: Cavity Sam of the classic board game Operation recently got a makeover, and the man who helped create him will, too. John Spinello, above, inventor of what became Operation in 1965, is able to afford a $25,000 dental procedure because of a crowdfunding campaign begun by his fellow game inventors Tim Walsh and Peggy Brown. The campaign, which began Oct. 22 at crowdrise.com, raised over $31,000 by early Sunday. The experience, Mr. Spinello said by phone from Bloomington, Ill., has been mind boggling. Its really rewarding to have people calling me right now from all over the world, he said. You cant put a price tag on it. Mr. Spinello, 77, invented the buzzer game while studying industrial design at the University of Illinois. He sold his idea to a toy invention firm for $500, and it was then licensed to Milton Bradley. Through the years there have been various riffs on the character, including Homer Simpson, SpongeBob SquarePants and a version with 21st-century ailments like headphone headache and gamers thumb. Though Mr. Spinello still owns the patent for the game, he said he receives no royalties. In recent years, the recession hurt his trucking warehouse company, and he and his wife have filed for bankruptcy. In addition to the donations at Crowdrise, money has also been raised through the sale of signed copies of the game and $3 Dear John thank-you letters at iloveoperation.com. Hasbro, which owns Milton Bradley, has pitched in by agreeing to buy the original prototype from Mr. Spinello. Calls requesting comment from Hasbro were not returned. Mr. Spinello said he hoped any leftover money would go to saving his home. But, he added, he would be grateful for a decent smile and the ability to chew.

title: $10 Million Gift for Madison Estate
description: The Virginia estate of President James Madison may soon look more like the home he knew, complete with 19th-century furnishings and slave quarters, through a $10 million gift from the businessman and philanthropist David Rubenstein. The Montpelier Foundation announced on Saturday that the money would be used to further restore the mansion to its original 1817 appearance and provide more context about the lives of Madisons slaves. Part of the gift, $3.5 million, will support reconstruction of the mansions south yard, where the familys domestic servants lived and worked. The plans include three slave quarters, two smokehouses and a detached kitchen. The rest of the money will go toward restoring, researching and refurnishing the home, including purchasing items authentic to the time period or the home; much of what was there has been dispersed over the years through family members or sales. Dolley Madison sold the property in 1844 after her husbands death, and Montpelier had various owners until it was purchased in 1901 by William duPont. In 1984, it was bestowed to the National Trust for Historic Preservation by Marion duPont Scott, following her death in 1983. This is Mr. Rubensteins third major recent gift to presidential estates in Virginia.

title: In a World of Whimsy, a Perilous Journey Home
description: Cartoon Networks new 10-episode series, Over the Garden Wall, isnt quite like anything else on television, but its a little bit like a lot of things youve seen. Guessing at what has influenced its creator, Patrick McHale, is one of the pleasures of watching it.

title: Amazement Befitting a Miracle, Translated to Sound
description: Why did you live? Why did you suffer? Is it all nothing but a huge, frightful joke? As Gustav Mahler explained to an admirer, Max Marschalk, his Second Symphony tries to answer the loftiest of questions. Lasting 90 minutes and requiring two female vocalists, full chorus, organ and what the musicologist Deryck Cooke described as much percussion, one would hope so.

title: Angry About War and Liars All Over Again
description: Bob Dylan and Leonard Cohen: As much as you may think you know the songs of these two musical patriarchs, the British singer Barb Jungr interprets their work with a ferocity and truthfulness that demolishes every cover version youve ever heard. Her show, Hard Rain, at 59E59 Theaters, interweaves classics old and new, and emphasizes their contemporaneity, even though some of the Dylan selections were written half a century ago in a spirit of boiling rage.

title: Lone Star Candidate
description: This short documentary profiles Mike Minter, an underfunded Democrat who seeks election against a Republican incumbent in one of the most conservative districts of Texas.

title: Lone Star Candidate
description: Mike Minter, a Democrat, is under no illusion that he will be elected as the next congressman from the 13th Congressional District of Texas. He freely admits to anyone who will listen that he is there to get his butt whipped. And based on his opponents war chest, the slammed doors, and recent elections  a butt whipping is exactly what Mr. Minter is going to get on Tuesday.

title: Lighting a Flamenco Fire Under an Ancient Heroine
description: There are dancers, and there are spellbinding creatures for whom movement emanates from deep within the body and erupts like a volcano. Soledad Barrio is such a force. Beating out rhythms with rattling heels and swirling her arms overhead with emphatic bearing, she leaves one world for another. In her latest adventure, seen Wednesday at the Joyce Theater, her company, Noche Flamenca, travels to ancient Greece.

title: A Flood of Late Spending on Midterm Elections, From Murky Sources
description: A stealthy coterie of difficult-to-trace outside groups is slipping tens of millions of dollars of attacks ads and negative automated telephone calls into the final days of the midterm campaign, helping fuel an unprecedented surge of last-minute spending on Senate races.

title: We Are Not the Only Political Animals
description: Homo sapiens has long sought to set itself apart from animals  that is, apart from every other living species. One of the most enduring attempts to define humanity in a way that distances us from the rest of animal life was Aristotles description of the human being as a political animal. By this he meant that human beings are the only species that live in thepolisor city-state, though the term has often been understood to include villages, communes, and other organized social units. Implicit in this definition is the idea that all other animals arenotpolitical, that they live altogether outside of internally governed social units.

title: A Comedy Moment in New York
description: With scores of funny people plying their trade at bars, clubs and theaters, the city feels like a comedy festival every night. So why get excited about the annual New York Comedy Festival? Simple: Size matters. From Wednesday through Sunday, more than 200 comics will play more than 60 shows, including more major headliners in big rooms than at any other time of the year. The quantity of performances, large and small across the city, means a dizzyingly array of talent, and some fascinating story lines. Here are a few to keep an eye on.

title: An Artifact Once Was Just Home
description: Rita Ascione made her way slowly up the steep, narrow staircase at 97 Orchard Street, on the Lower East Side, one recent morning, letting out a few moans and groans along the way. Her daughter Valerie Carmody tried to jolly her along. Come on, Ma, youre always telling me that you used to fly up these stairs.

title: Punch Line With Real Political Punch
description: Bill Maher has wrung the most comedy  and attention  he can out of his campaign to unseat a little known Republican congressman from Minnesota. But on Tuesday, things get serious for Mr. Maher, the host of HBOs Real Time: He wants to win.
