title: Italian Bank Monte dei Paschi to Sell Shares to Meet Capital Demands
description: The Italian bank Monte dei Paschi di Siena said on Sunday that it would ask investors to help it raise the money it needed to satisfy demands from the European Central Bank that it bolster its ability to survive an economic downturn or other crisis.

title: Finding a Job After Serving Time
Personal and Political: Judging People by Their Party
description: To the Editor:

title: Treating Acid Reflux, With Drugs and Lifestyle Changes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Effects of Optimism
description: To the Editor:

title: Invest in Poor Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Hudson Yards Tax Breaks
description: To the Editor:

title: An Encore Vote on Hunting in Alabama
description: PARRISH, Ala.  It is easy to stop in a back room of Brady Johnsons home and miss the bowls of individually wrapped peppermints and oatmeal cream pies.

title: Cancel the Midterms
description: DURHAM, N.C.  By Tuesday night about 90 million Americans will have cast ballots in an election thats almost certain to create greater partisan divisions, increase gridlock and render governance of our complex nation even more difficult. Ninety million sounds like a lot, but that means that less than 40 percent of the electorate will bother to vote, even though candidates, advocacy groups and shadowy super PACs will have spent more than $1 billion to air more than two million ads to influence the election.

title: Wheelchair Racers Tumble Doesnt Keep Her From Win
description: Late in her final push through Central Park in the womens wheelchair race at the New York City Marathon on Sunday, Tatyana McFadden felt her herself begin to tip. She was falling, literally, and the hopeless sensation of imbalance gave way to waves of panic.

title: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Nov. 3
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: European Union Economic Data, and Octobers U.S. Job Figures
description: EUROPEAN UNION TO PUBLISH GROWTH AND JOBS FORECASTS

title: Masterpiece Franchise on PBS Is Adding Broadcasts
description: PBSs Masterpiece, the enduring Sunday night British drama and mystery franchise, will expand by at least 20 hours next year, an approximate 50 percent increase, with the new hours being broadcast either before or after the programs traditional time slot of 9 p.m. Eastern time.

title: A Brother Runs Past His Sorrow
description: For Stephan Shay, the downhills were the worst.

title: In Korean Baseball, Louder Cheers and More Squid
description: BUSAN, South Korea  It was the bottom of the ninth and the home team was behind, 10-6. In an American ballpark, fans might have started glumly filing out of the stands to beat the traffic.

title: Bouquet, Used Only Once
description: Dear Diary:

title: De Blasios Plan to Eliminate Workfare Lifts Hopes for Job Seekers
description: Every workday morning, Phedra Schliefer-Tobias mops floors, cleans toilets and scrubs sinks just like the rest of the members of the custodial staff in a nine-story office building in Lower Manhattan. But her city-issued identification card  her badge of shame  makes it clear that she stands apart.

title: Women in New York City Marathon Lead a Glorious Cross-City Sprint
description: The lithe women ran back and forth in high-stepping sprints, their pink and yellow sneakers a blur. Then they stopped to bounce, and to shake their arms, as if to banish the cold.

title: E-Book Mingles Love and Product Placement
description: The heroine of Find Me Im Yours, a new novel by Hillary Carlip, is a quirky young woman named Mags who works at an online bridal magazine and is searching for love in Los Angeles.

title: Wolves at the Door
description: In the 1990s, the federal government reintroduced the gray wolf to Yellowstone National Park. It was considered a big success. And thats when the real fight began.

title: For Gray Wolves, a Success Story Not Without Detractors
description: Few mammals are as unloved as the wolf. Not that the feeling is universal. Some North American Indian tribes traditionally honored the predator as a worthy fellow hunter. Other societies have shown comparable reverence. How can anyone bear a grudge against the she-wolf that suckled Romulus and Remus, mythological founders of Rome? Without her, would we have had all that glorious architecture, those inspiring Michelangelo frescoes, Sophia Loren? Still, in popular culture and many a metaphor this animal is far from adored. There it is at the door in hard times, disguising itself in sheeps clothing, tormenting the likes of Little Red Riding Hood and the Three Little Pigs.

title: Over the Hill, and Beyond It
description: Wilson Kipsang of Kenya won the New York City Marathon in 2 hours 10 minutes 59 seconds  or as I like to call it at my age, a good nights sleep.

title: House Democrats Dig Deep for Cash, From Their Colleagues Campaigns
description: Democrats in the House of Representatives have poured more than a half a million dollars from their own campaigns into their colleagues tight races during the final weeks leading to Tuesday, more than twice the amount their Republican counterparts have given.

title: In a Partisan Atmosphere, It Can Even Be Hard to Find Numbers That Agree
description: Since his second term began, President Obama has had a solid answer to Republicans Where are the jobs? complaint. The jobless rate has fallen two full percentage points.

title: Journalism, Independent and Not
description: Last week, I read an interesting article about how smart hardware can allow users to browse anonymously and thus foil snooping from governments. I found it on what looked like a nifty new technology site called SugarString.

title: Seeing a New Future for French Nuclear Site, After the Toxic Dust Has Settled
description: VAUJOURS, France  On a walk through her garden on a recent afternoon, Lisa Leclerc ran a Geiger counter over her mushrooms.

title: Blacks, Obama and the Election
description: President Obamas name wont be on any ballots Tuesday, but he will most certainly be on them in spirit  a fact that many Republicans are trumpeting and some Democrats are hoping to downplay.

title: Money and Judges, a Bad Mix
description: Follow the money: Its a truism of the mechanics of political influence, and no less so when that money is spent on judicial campaigns.

title: As Tours Evolve, Indoor Tennis Tournaments Are Increasingly Being Left Out
description: PARIS  Professional tennis is increasingly finding sunshine preferable to having a roof overhead. In 1994, 25 mens and 16 womens tour events were held indoors. Two decades later, those numbers are 15 and 8.

title: Dells Life After Wall Street
description: A year after spending $24.9 billion taking his computer company private, Michael S. Dell is gleeful to have his namesake firm to himself. And to be done with Wall Street.

title: Business vs. Economics
description: TOKYO  The Bank of Japan, this countrys equivalent of the Federal Reserve, has lately been making a big effort to end deflation, which has afflicted Japans economy for almost two decades. At first its efforts  which involve printing a lot of money and, even more important, trying to assure investors that it will keep printing money until inflation reaches 2 percent  seemed to be going well. But more recently the economy has lost momentum, and last week the bank announced new, even more aggressive monetary measures.

title: One Day in an Elevator With Obama, Then Out of a Job
description: ATLANTA  Kenneth Tate toiled for years as a construction worker and corrections officer, and he has no doubt that his last job  working as a $42,000-a-year private security guard at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention  was the best he ever had.

title: Woman in Iran Sent to Prison After Going to Sports Event
description: TEHRAN  An Iranian-British woman who was arrested in June when she tried to attend a mens volleyball match in Iran has been sentenced to a year in prison, her lawyer said Sunday.

title: Europe Shifts on Priorities for Telecoms
description: LONDON  Poor cellphone and Internet service is a fact of life in many parts of Europe.

title: Previewing the N.B.A.s Game of the Week: Spurs at Rockets
description: Houston is 3-0, but the record and attendant statistics are largely meaningless. The Rockets have beaten the Lakers, the Celtics and the Jazz, the worst team in the Western Conference last season. It still feels blasphemous to say, but the traditional powers are nearly automatic wins for any contender. The Rockets first real test comes at home Thursday (8 p.m. Eastern on TNT), when they face the defending champion San Antonio Spurs.

title: Bernard Spitzer, New York Developer and Philanthropist, Dies at 90
description: Bernard Spitzer, a prominent New York City real estate developer and philanthropist who supported his son Eliots political career and at times became entangled in it, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: Independent Journal Review Website Becomes a Draw for Conservatives
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  Last week, with the midterm elections fast approaching, the conservative website Independent Journal Review was not focused on the control of the Senate or crucial statehouse races. Instead, it led its home page with a gruesome beheading on Long Island and a video of a belligerent drunk being arrested at a Dallas airport.

title: Falling Short on Concussion Warnings
description: More than four years after the National Collegiate Athletic Association held its first concussion conference, some universities are still not doing enough to protect athletes from the lasting effects of head injuries.

title: A Prisoner Swap With Cuba
description: Nearly five years ago, authorities in Cuba arrested an American government subcontractor, Alan Gross, who was working on a secretive program to expand Internet access on the island. At a time when a growing number of officials in Washington and Havana are eager to start normalizing relations, Mr. Grosss continued imprisonment has become the chief obstacle to a diplomatic breakthrough.

title: Un canje de presos con Cuba
description: Hace casi cinco aos, las autoridades en Cuba detuvieron a Alan Gross, un subcontratista del gobierno estadounidense que estaba trabajando en un sigiloso proyecto para expandir el acceso a Internet en la isla. Aunque un creciente nmero de lderes en Washington y La Habana parecen estar ansiosos por comenzar a normalizar la relacin entre los pases, el caso de Gross se ha convertido en el principal obstculo para lograr un avance diplomtico.

title: Alan Gross and the Cuban Five: A Timeline
description: To understand why The Timess editorial board is calling for a prisoner swap with Cuba, it is instructive to revisit the history of both cases. The spies Cuba wants back were detained long before Alan Gross, an American contractor, was arrested in Havana in 2009. But soon after, officials on the island came to see him as the the best pawn to get their prisoners back.

title: Arriving Where Hes Supposed to Be
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Until he was 14, Damontre Moore lived most of his life in a hardscrabble, rough-edged Dallas neighborhood. Then his mother boldly moved the family to a leafy suburb 35 miles to the northeast.

title: Keeping Mexicos Revolutionary Fires Alive
description: AYOTZINAPA, Mexico  In their first week of school, the new students eat and drink nothing but beans and cold coffee, and spend sleepless days cleaning up the buildings and planting crops.

title: Colts (5-3) at Giants (3-4)
description: 8:30 p.m., ESPN

title: Washington Redskins Draw Protesters in Minnesota Before Losing in Griffins Return
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The protesters arrived from as far as Oklahoma, Montana and New Mexico. They marched across the University of Minnesota campus on a cold, sunny morning to a grassy patch outside TCF Bank Stadium, near the Minnesota Tribal Nations Plaza, which honors the states 11 federally recognized Native American tribes.

title: Egyptian Journalists Protest Editors Pledge Not to Criticize State
description: CAIRO  Hundreds of Egyptian journalists objected on Sunday to a pledge by newspaper editors to refrain from publishing reports critical of the government, calling the curb on freedom of expression a victory for terrorism.

title: Obama Lending Support, but Only in Democratic Bulwarks
description: PHILADELPHIA  President Obama implored voters to cast aside cynicism and turn out to elect Democrats who are fighting for you, making his closing argument before midterm congressional elections that will shape the contours of his final two years in office.

title: Winning Powerball and Lottery Numbers for Nov. 2, 2014
Showdown of Rivals and Passers Ends in Rout
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The marquee games on New Englands schedule are getting to be like pretty much every other game at Gillette Stadium: unending torment for whichever unfortunate team happens to be playing the Patriots.

title: Montana Judicial Race Joins Big-Money Fray
description: HELENA, Mont.  In a coffee shop on Last Chance Gulch, a woman approached Mike Wheat to say she was planning to knock on doors for him. Its getting pretty brutal out there, she said.

title: The Mind of the Undecided Voter
description: From Louisiana to Kansas, voters are still struggling to make up their minds about which candidates to vote for in the midterm elections Tuesday.

title: Popular Demand
description: HuffingtonPost.com is the most visited political website according to eBizMBA. eBizMBA derives its visitor numbers based on data from Alexa, Compete and Quantcast.

title: Cond Nast Moves Into the World Trade Center as Lower Manhattan Is Remade
description: For two days last weekend, moving trucks shuttled a total of 2,800 orange crates crammed with files, photographs and books from a Times Square office tower downtown to the tallest skyscraper in North America, 1 World Trade Center.

title: Iraqis Prepare ISIS Offensive, With U.S. Help
description: WASHINGTON  Iraqi security forces, backed by American-led air power and hundreds of advisers, are planning to mount a major spring offensive against Islamic State fighters who have poured into the country from Syria, a campaign that is likely to face an array of logistical and political challenges.

title: Rubber-Legged Red Bulls Make a Charge
description: HARRISON, N.J.  Since 1996, the first year of Major League Soccer, D.C. United has been the guys in the black hats  actually the all-black uniforms  first against the MetroStars and now against the Red Bulls.

title: Racing the Wind
description: Scenes from a blustery 44th running of the New York City Marathon.

title: Homeland Recap: Carries Deadly Decision and Quinns Dissent
description: Season 4, Episode 6, From A to B and Back Again

title: De Blasio and Bratton Unite to Quash Allegations of Rift
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio called the New York Police Department the best its ever been. Extraordinary things are happening, he said.

title: Capitol Book Club, With a Bonus
description: WASHINGTON  Its the first Tuesday of the month, and the book club is in session. Between bites of their lunch buffet, two dozen members leaf through classics, best sellers and the latest nonfiction.

title: Voters Express Resignation in Connecticut Governors Race
description: HARTFORD  At the Its a Gee Thang barbershop in the neglected North End, the clippers have gone quiet and the only hair being sculpted sits on a plastic mannequins head.

title: Standing Out in the Stands, an Artist and Nets Fan Shows His Moves
description: Jeffrey Vanchiro has been a conspicuous fixture at Barclays Center since the Nets began playing there two years ago, but his signature game-day outfit did not come together until a few games into the inaugural season.

title: Rangers McDonagh May Miss Four Weeks
description: Rangers defenseman Ryan McDonagh is expected to miss three to four weeks while recovering from a separated left shoulder.

title: At a Bronx Park, Dreams of Greener Landscapes
description: There are a lot of things wrong with Lyons Square Playground in the South Bronx.

title: A Tepid Thumbs Up Is the Best Many Can Muster for Cuomo
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo gets strong marks for his aggressive response to the Ebola virus. But some voters are unsettled by what they view as his back-room, bullying style and by a federal investigation into an anti-corruption commission he established.

title: Learning as They Go, Knicks Pass Another Test
description: So much of what the Knicks are doing this season feels so very different. The offensive sets. The coaching. The absence of distractions, at least for now.

title: The Good Wife Recap: Enter a New Candidate (and Welcome David Hyde Pierce)
description: Season 6, Episode 7, Message Discipline

title: The Affair Recap: Between the Covers, Real Emotion
description: Season 1, Episode 4

description: daub \dob, db\ noun and verb

title: Finally Drug-Free, Hes Putting Together Pieces of His Life, Day by Day
description: Days after James Boyds mother died of a heroin overdose, he attended her wake in handcuffs. He was 17 and in the midst of a 90-day jail sentence for marijuana possession.

title: After the New York City Marathon
description: After completing the 2014 New York City Marathon, participants fight through fatigue and physical exhaustion on the streets of Manhattan.

title: Quotation of the Day for Monday, November 3, 2014
description: We have to pray. There can always be a miracle, only God knows.

title: In New York and Connecticut, a Last Big Push for Votes
description: As Tuesdays election loomed, candidates worked hard over the weekend. Below are some snapshots from the campaign trail.

title: Senate Control May Be Decided by Runoff Votes in Louisiana and Georgia
description: NEW ORLEANS  As the 2014 midterm elections barrel toward a close and Democrats brace for losses around the country, operatives in both parties are already preparing for likely runoff elections here and in Georgia  and the chance that control of the Senate will not be determined until next year.

title: Stung Last Year, Retailers and Shippers Retool for the Holiday Season
description: This year, Santas reindeer will be huffing and puffing their way from the North Pole, carrying more than they usually do.

title: Parishioners Mourn as Mergers are Announced
description: Throughout the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, many parishes will be merged and their churches effectively shut down in the largest reorganization in the history of the archdiocese.

title: Corrections: November 3, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 8 P.M. (CMT) WINTERS BONE (2010) Jennifer Lawrence, above, received her first Oscar nomination for her role as Ree Dolly, a teenager living in the Ozarks of southwestern Missouri who goes in search of her meth-cooking father after he puts up the family home to cover his bail and disappears. But her efforts to find him place her in a terrible dilemma: either betray the code of silence that keeps her clan proudly on the wrong side of the law or face destitution. The harshness in Debra Graniks regional-realist morality tale, based on the novel by Daniel Woodrell, is not there to illuminate a sociological condition, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. Something more primal, almost Greek in its archaic power, is at stake in Winters Bone, and its visual and emotional starkness do not feel like simple badges of authenticity.

title: Who Would Have Health Insurance if Medicaid Expansion Weren't Optional
description: A new data set suggests that more than three million people would have gained health insurance across 24 states if the Supreme Court had ruled differently.

title: Investigators in Virgin Galactic Crash Focus on Tail Booms
description: The Virgin Galactic space plane that broke apart over the Mojave Desert on Friday shifted early into a high-drag configuration that was designed to slow it down, federal accident investigators have said.

title: Portraits of Those Braving Ebola
description: Hours from the nearest city, in a clearing in the Liberian jungle, a small army of doctors, nurses, sprayers and gravediggers is battling the Ebola virus at a clinic run by an American medical charity. Weeks of sustained, hard-hitting coverage by the photographer Daniel Berehulak chronicled in detail the urgent, grim and unrelenting work. But after more than two months, how could he find a new way to tell the story?

title: Diageo and Cuervo Swap Brands: Bushmills Whiskey for Don Julio Tequila
description: LONDON  Diageo and the family that makes Jose Cuervo tequila have agreed to swap two of their best-known brands, giving the global spirits maker a bigger presence in the tequila market.

title: Programmers Deploy Cellphone Game to Support Hong Kong Protests
description: Hong Kong residents love their mobile phone games. Look around in any subway car and youll see passengers launching birds, constructing imaginary cities or battling zombies.

title: Test Yourself  | Bobby Shmurda, Young Jeezy and T.I. at Powerhouse
description: Below are the first six paragraphs of the Oct. 31 article 10 Minutes, and Theyre Gone.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Kenyans Finish First at the New York City Marathon
description: Note: This feature requires the reading of two articles to answer the following questions about Sundays New York City Marathon: Kenyan Wins as Bump Fuels Late Kick by Lynn Zinser and Kenyans Turn Womens Race Into a Four-Mile Duel by Mary Pilon.

title: Hong Kong Court Charges British Banker With Murder of 2 Women in Apartment
description: HONG KONG  A 29-year-old British banker was charged with two counts of murder on Monday in the killings of two women at his high-rise apartment.

title: For French Giant Publicis, a Deal for Sapient to Expand in Digital Ads
description: The French advertising giant Publicis Groupe said on Monday that it had agreed to pay $3.7 billion in cash for Sapient, a marketing and consulting company based in Boston, as it seeks to become a stronger digital competitor against Internet powerhouses like Google and Facebook.

title: What Work Went Into Reaching Your Most Difficult Goals?
description: There is an old adage, good things come to those who wait. But good things also come to people who work hard and stay focused on their goals.

title: The Right to Say God Divides a Diverse Nation
description: KOTA KINABALU, Malaysia  As the students knelt in a circle at a Christian kindergarten near the shores of the South China Sea, a 6-year-old girl in pigtails read out a chapter from a childrens Bible: Sepuluh hukum dari Allah  Gods Ten Commandments.

title: HSBC Hurt by $1.69 Billion in Legal and Other Costs
description: LONDON  The British bank HSBC said on Monday that its third-quarter profit rose 7 percent, but its results, like those of many of its European investment banking rivals, were dragged down by $1.69 billion in legal and restructuring costs.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: The Counties to Watch on Election Night
description: It used to be that you could turn to a key bellwether county and get a sense of where a state might go on Election Night. For decades, the bellwethers were a host of fairly conservative but traditionally Democratic rural counties. For much of the last decade, historically Republican suburban areas in Franklin, Ohio, or Orange, Fla., fit the bill.

title: Heres How to Avoid Getting Fooled on Election Night
description: Election Day creates a vast information vacuum  millions of Americans (and hundreds of reporters) are trying to figure out the outcome of an event before it has been decided. With few useful indicators of what is actually happening at the polls, rumors and misinformation can run rampant. Heres how to avoid getting fooled.

title: New York Today: A Hint of Winter
description: Good chilly Monday morning to you.

title: Why Do We Still Care About the Confederate Flag?
description: In the run-up to the midterm elections, with deep divides between conservatives and liberals, observers say political debates arelosing substance. Its an increasingly us-versus-them kind of scene, the Divided States of America, as NBCs Mark Murray put it in a recent article.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 3, 2014
description: Updated: Nov. 4, 2014

title: Preparing for APEC War in China
description: What price a successful international meeting? Smoggy skies, upended work routines, an abruptly weaned baby  everything, it seems, is worth it, as a bevy of government orders kicks in to prepare the Chinese capital for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting beginning on Wednesday. Prepare for the APEC war, said an item on the website of the Committee of China Energy Conservation Association.

title: Following Up on the Job Candidate Who Was Checking Out the Waitress
description: A few weeks ago, I wrote a post that asked whether a female boss can manage a chauvinist. Ive struggled with this issue for many years, and from your replies its clear that other women have endured similar experiences.

title: Today in Politics
description: Midterm Memories: Squealing Pigs, Fangate and Cowboy Poetry

title: LabCorp to Buy Covance for $6.1 Billion
description: LabCorp agreed on Monday to buy Covance for about $6.1 billion in cash and stock, taking control of one of the biggest providers of contract medical research.

title: Russia Continues to Train and Equip Ukraine Rebels, NATO Official Says
description: WASHINGTON  Hundreds of Russian troops are still training and equipping separatists in Ukraine, NATOs top military commander said Monday, activities that are heightening tensions with the West and Ukraines government that were aggravated by Sundays elections in the breakaway regions of eastern Ukraine.

title: Altice Offers to Buy Telecom Assets in Portugal for $8.7 Billion
description: LONDON  Altice, the European cable and mobile service provider, has set its sights on Portugal.

title: Manual on How to Spot a Spy Circulates in an Increasingly  Wary China
description: On the Internet, nobody knows youre a dog. Or an American spy. Or a hostile foreign force. So says the China Folk Counterespionage Manual, a how to spot a spy guide circulating on the Internet.

title: Tom Ford Explains Those Pasties, and More
description: Theres something a little surprising on Tom Fords website, and it reads kind of like honesty.

title: Daily Report: The New Dell
description: A year after spending $24.9 billion taking his computer company private, Michael S. Dell is gleeful to have his namesake firm to himself. And to be done with Wall Street, Quentin Hardy reports.

title: Morning Agenda: A Book Club That Pays
description: On the first Tuesday of the month, a book club gathers at a Republican social parlor in the Capitols shadow. But unlike a local librarys book club, this event doubles as a political fund-raiser, Ben Protess and Eric Lipton write in DealBook. For the book clubs members  an A-list of lobbyists from banks and insurance companies  the main attraction is access to the House Financial Services Committee. The cost of admission is a campaign donation to whichever committee member is playing host that month.

title: 99 Counties, 24 Hours, 2 Candidates, 1 State (Iowa)
description: Joni Ernst is one-upping the full Grassley, the 99-county tour of Iowa named after the states Republican senator, Charles E. Grassley, by taking a 24-hour, round-the-clock final campaign push. It will end with the casting of her ballot in her hometown of Red Oak, Iowa, on Tuesday.

title: Drawing Food in London
description: Menus at a beloved restaurant that are as mouthwatering as the meals.

title: Little Opposition Seen in Some Votes to Raise State Minimum Wages
description: In state after state, labor unions and community groups have pushed lawmakers to raise the minimum wage, but those efforts have faltered in many places where Republicans control the legislature.

title: Romanian Premier Faces Runoff in Presidential Race
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  Prime Minister Victor Ponta of Romania, the favorite to replace Traian Basescu as president, has been forced into a runoff after failing to capture the majority of votes in an election over the weekend that was closer than expected.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Migrants Die After Boat Capsizes North of Bosporus Off Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  A boat carrying 43 migrants to the European Union from the Middle East capsized north of the Bosporus in the Black Sea on Monday, killing at least 24 people, the Turkish Coast Guard said.

title: 1 World Trade Center, a Pillar of Resilience, Is Open for Business
description: More than 13 years after a terrorist attack destroyed the twin towers  soaring symbols of New York Citys might, financially and structurally  the first employees of the first tenant in the building erected to take their place arrived on Monday for their first workday.

title: At Autumn Festival in Paris, William Forsythe Is Everywhere
description: PARIS  The choreographer William Forsythe is ubiquitous here this fall. He is the focus of this years Festival dAutomne, with five companies presenting his work around the city over three months, and the Paris Opera Ballet offered a Forsythe program over three weeks in September and October. The appetite for Mr. Forsythes work in Paris, and the crowds that have flocked to the shows, point to the anomaly in his reputation. In Europe, where he has spent his whole professional career, he is an artistic giant; in his native United States, he is regarded with far less reverence.

title: Election Day Information for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
description: Polls in New York State are open on Tuesday from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. Voters will elect the governor, lieutenant governor, attorney general and comptroller and decide three ballot questions. There are also races for Congress, the State Legislature and local offices. Voter information is available from the State Board of Elections at vote-ny.com or by calling 1-800-FOR-VOTE (1-800-367-8683); from the New York City Board of Elections at vote.nyc.ny.us or by calling 1-866-VOTE-NYC (1-866-868-3692), or from the New York Public Interest Research Group at 212-822-0282. Voters who have problems can visit Election Protection at 866ourvote.org or call 1-866-OUR-VOTE (1-866-687-8683).

title: The Trials and Tribulations of Being That Child
description: A friend of mine, Sarah, recently put her mother, who has early-stage dementia, into a nursing home in the town where she lives. Moving her mother out of the family home after 40 years was anything but easy, but neither was driving an hour each way to check on her well-being several times a week.

title: Four States Vote to Raise Minimum Wage
description: This story has been updated to reflect election results.

title: Tenement Memories
description: Rita Ascione is one of the last living residents of the Lower East Side building that is now the Tenement Museum. She recently returned with her daughter, Valerie Carmody, to see her old apartment.

title: The Economy, and Voters Perception of It, Are Two Very Different Things
description: We learned on Thursday that the United States economy expanded at a healthy rate this summer, growing 3.5 percent from July through September. This growth  as robust as it is  is unlikely, however, to influence how the presidents party fares this week at the polls. Midterm election results are not as directly related to objective economic conditions as presidential election outcomes are, something we discussed yesterday at The Upshot.

title: Emotion Is Not the Best Medicine, Ebola Case Further Shows
description: Breast cancer, tick bites, gluten, G.M.O.s, artificial sweeteners, shark attacks  and now Ebola.

title: Virgin America Aims to Raise $300 Million in I.P.O.
description: Virgin America has moved a step closer to a Wall Street debut, filing a price range on Monday for its planned initial public offering.

title: D.C., Oregon and Alaska Vote to Legalize Marijuana
description: This article has been updated with election results.

title: Softcore Logos
description: Fashions most explicit calling card submits to some subtlety.

title: From The Upshot: Minimum Wage Faces Fresh Votes
description: The future of the Senate is not the only thing at stake in Tuesdays midterm election.

title: 1889: A Visit to Constantinople
description: CONSTANTINOPLE  The Emperor and Empress this morning [Nov. 3] attended divine service in the German church at Pera. They were escorted by a regiment of lancers. The people lining the route manifested much enthusiasm, particularly the Germans. It is estimated that nearly two hundred thousand people were in the streets to see their Majesties pass. The Sultan and his Ministers have spared no trouble or expense to combine a gorgeous ceremonial with the comfort of the Emperor and Empress, and these in turn have evinced an almost juvenile pleasure in what they have seen, whilst the attitude of the general public has been all that could be desired. On Tuesday the Emperor and Empress will take their departure, their intention being to return to Berlin by way of Venice.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 4, 1889

title: 1939: Allies Seize Contraband
description: LONDON  More than a half-million tons of contraband suspected of being destined for Germany has been intercepted and detained by the Allied contraband control organizations, the Ministry of Economic Warfare announced today [Nov. 3]. Up to October 12, seizures by the French amounted to 150,000 tons, it was stated. The British figures for October 14 to October 28 show 63,000 tons intercepted, raising the British total for the first eight weeks of the war to more than 400,000 tons. Petroleum products detained since the war began amount to 87,540 tons, including 12,000,000 gallons of gasoline. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 4, 1939

title: Warner Music to Offer $100,000 Classical Prize
description: The Warner Music Group is establishing the Warner Music Prize, a new classical music award, to be given annually to a musician between 18 and 35 who demonstrates exceptional promise during a season in which his or her performances are seen by a jury of classical musicians and music industry executives. The award includes a $100,000 cash prize, and a recording offer from Warner Classics.

title: U.S. Fines Automakers Hyundai and Kia for Misstating Mileage
description: WASHINGTON  In the largest-ever penalty for a violation of the Clean Air Act, the Korean automakers Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors will pay the federal government a combined $300 million as part of a settlement for overstating vehicle fuel-economy standards on 1.2 million cars, Justice Department and Environmental Protection Agency officials said on Monday.

title: Yildiz of Turkey to Buy British Cookie Maker United Biscuits
description: LONDON  The private equity owners of United Biscuits said on Monday that they had agreed to sell the British cookie maker to Yildiz Holding of Turkey.

title: What to Wear This Week: Nov. 3
description: Daylight savings, the final confirmation that summers longer days and warmer weather are again behind us, has ended. Well spend more time in darkness with no less to do. Explore keeping time with a device other than your smartphone.

title: Shaky Times, Strong Journalism
description: Updated, 2:50 p.m.

title: Verbatim: Joni Ernst on Being Compared to Taylor Swift
description: Joni Ernst, the Republican candidate for United States Senate, responding to incumbent Senator Tom Harkin, a Democrat who is retiring from the Senate this year, who said of Ms. Ernst: I dont care if shes as good-looking as Taylor Swift or as nice as Mr. Rogers, but if she votes like Michele Bachmann, shes wrong for the state of Iowa.

title: Taylor Swift Announces World Tour and Pulls Her Music From Spotify
description: For Taylor Swift fans, Monday morning brought a whiplash-inducing pair of announcements: news of a world tour, and a defensive statement from Spotify saying that Ms. Swift had removed all of her music from the service.

title: A Holiday Shop for Art Connoisseurs, Rare Sigmar Polke Works and More From the Art Calendar
description: Ts list of happenings worth visiting in the week ahead.

title: The Plot to Burn Chicago
description: At the beginning of November 1864, Col. Benjamin J. Sweet, the commandant of the Camp Douglas prisoner-of-war camp near Chicago and commander of the Army post of Chicago, began to hear reports of large numbers of men arriving on trains from Southern Illinois and now milling around the streets and saloons. Detectives also noted that men known to be officers in the Confederate States Army lodged in Chicago hotels. Army detectives working for other commands likewise confirmed the presence of rebel officers in the city.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Adaptly, New York, hired four employees. They are Logan Moore, director for strategic accounts; Bryn Sanders, vice president for revenue, East; Miles Rutter, account executive; and Charles Timko, director for strategic accounts.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: R.B.S. to Aid British Police in Unraveling Financial Crimes
description: LONDON  The Royal Bank of Scotland, which is 81 percent owned by the British government, has negotiated a new deal, though not one that is likely to help the bank in the league tables. The bank signed a landmark agreement to help the City of London police tackle complex financial crime.

title: Dvoraks New World Manuscript to Revisit New York
description: Antonin Dvoraks New World Symphony holds an important place in American music, not only because Dvorak composed it during his residency in this country, but also because he meant it to show that great symphonic music could be built on themes from various American folk traditions. The New York Philharmonic gave the work its premiere in 1893, but when Dvorak returned to Prague in 1895, he took the manuscript of the symphony with him. It has remained in Prague ever since, and is currently in the collection of the Czech National Museum. But it is returning to New York, briefly, for the first time.

title: Today in Small Business: The Yelp of Business Software
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: More Voters Track Candidates by Smartphone
description: New research suggests that you are probably reading this piece of political news on your smartphone, by way of Facebook or Twitter.

title: With One Band Left Behind, Gregg Allman to Tour
description: The Allman Brothers Band played the final show of its 45-year career barely a week ago, but Gregg Allman is apparently not planning to sit back and reflect on the bands accomplishments.

title: Daniel Finkels Circle-Toss Game
description: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Daniel Finkel, a regular Numberplay contributor who also runs, along with Katherine Cook, Math for Love  the Seattle-based team committed to revitalizing math education. Lets check out

title: Prudential Center Ads Declare, Theres No Place Like Home ... and Watch for Flying Pucks
description: In introducing its first brand campaign, the Prudential Center is inviting the estimated two million people who attend events each year at the arena in downtown Newark  and the millions of others who have yet to buy tickets  to feel right at home there.

title: The Carter Family: The Storms Are on the Ocean (1927)
description: This song is used with permission from Bear Family Records. Visit bear-family.com to learn more about their re-releases of the Victor and Bluebird recordings.

title: Sonya Yoncheva to Star as Mimi in Met Bohme
description: It was an operatic domino effect, or prima donna-mo effect. Anna Netrebkos decision to withdraw from a series of performances in Munich means that New York will be getting a new Mimi in La Bohme later this month: Sonya Yoncheva.

title: When Bruce Met Ruhs
description: For 14 years, the famed photographer Bruce Weber has published an annual anthology of essays, poetry and images that celebrates, with his trademark patriotism, everything from canines to cops to mountain climbers. The books latest edition, Affairs of the Heart, includes stories about the late novelist and C.I.A. agent Peter Matthiessen as well as one on a boarding school for equestrians, and features contributions by art-world heavyweights like Francesco Clemente. Most notable, however, is a piece on Kris Ruhs, the New York City-born sculptor responsible for the amazing three-story chandelier at the Azzedine Alaa store in Paris and the silver jewelry sold by Carla Sozzani (his companion and frequent collaborator) at her Milan boutique-bookstore-gallery-cafe 10 Corso Como. Weber had previously encountered Ruhss workspace when he shot the actress Marion Cotillard in the sculptors Paris studio four years ago. The day just flew by, Weber recalls, because we were so enchanted by the things that Kris had made.

title: Tracking House Elections and the G.O.P. Majority
description: This article has been updated with election results.

title: On Elections Eve, G.O.P. Is Confident, but Voters Are Sour
description: WASHINGTON  The most expensive midterm campaign in American history stumbled into Election Day on Tuesday with voters interest at record lows and their divisions deep over what they want their government to do in President Obamas final two years.

title: Gate Bearing Notorious Slogan Is Stolen From Dachau Site
description: BERLIN  A heavy metal gate bearing the Nazis infamous concentration camp slogan, Arbeit Macht Frei (Work Sets You Free), was stolen under cover of darkness on the weekend from the memorial site at the old Nazi camp of Dachau, just north of Munich, in what looked like a carefully planned crime, the authorities in Bavaria said on Monday.

title: Foraging for a Pastry Chef in the Bronx
description: Hanging out on the corner of Fordham Road and the Grand Concourse in the Bronx will not yield a lot of clues about how Malcolm Livingston II first got fired up about food.

title: Last Missing Body Is Found in Costa Concordia Wreck
description: ROME  The last missing person from the wreck of the cruise ship Costa Concordia was finally accounted for on Monday when workers dismantling the hulk found the remains of Russel Rebello, a waiter on the ship.

title: A Builder Swears Hell Stay at 49 Employees to Avoid the Mandate. Unless He Grows.
description: Todd Hawkins is a Virginia home builder who insists that the big plans he has for his business are not so big that they will put him in the path of the Affordable Care Act. That, anyway, is what he told Youre the Boss readers when he commented on a recent post about determining whether a company is subject to the laws employer mandate. I can promise we wont go over 49 employees, so A.C.A. will affect employment, at least by one company, he wrote. Mine.

title: Malpractice Reform Wont Do Much to Reduce Health Spending
description: Among the many ideas that have been tossed around for decades on how to bring down health care spending, none may be as well known as malpractice reform. Many people believe that its the key to removing waste from the health care system and making the practice of medicine better. But a growing body of evidence shows that belief is most likely mistaken.

title: Robust Sales of Jeeps and Rams Lead Big Increase for Chrysler
description: Falling gas prices accelerated American car buyers increasing love affair with trucks and sport utility vehicles last month. And a big beneficiary was Chrysler, whose Jeep and Ram pickup brands continued their surge, leading the automaker to double-digit sales gains even as its crosstown rivals General Motors and Ford Motor fell flat.

title: In Bill Grosss Latest Investment Letter, a Sly Reference to Adaptation
description: Analyzing an investment essay by Bill Gross usually requires a background in finance.

title: A Familys Truth About Marijuana Depends on the Family
description: What is the truth about marijuana? As long as Ive been an adult Ive known people who smoke marijuana, and they certainly dont fit the stereotype of skater dude or hippie holdover.

title: Banks Cycle of Misbehavior
description: The latest round of global banks taking reserves for investigations into manipulation of foreign exchange rates calls to mind Ronald Reagans famous retort in a debate: There you go again. It seems to be a never-ending refrain: Misconduct by traders and bankers is uncovered, multiple regulators mount investigations, and then millions, or even billions, of dollars in penalties are paid, all to little apparent effect.

title: When the Message on Marijuana Is Still Just Say No
description: As I wrote last month, marijuana and its use has changed. The laws around it are in flux. As of now, marijuana for medical usage is legal in 23 states and the District of Columbia; two of those states, Colorado and Washington, have legalized recreational use as well (for people 21 and over). The stuff itself, usually green, leafy and intended for smoking, is increasingly available in a form that I have also written about before: It may be a drug, but it can look like candy.

title: When Celebrities Get Political, Whats a Reporter to Do?
description: When Rob Reiner decides he wants to campaign to prevent commercial development in an affluent Southern California city, should he be subjected to the same scrutiny that a reporter might give a professional politician? Adam Nagourney, The Timess Los Angeles bureau chief and its former chief national political correspondent, weighs what happens to a story when celebrities get involved.

title: Abortion, Marijuana and the Minimum Wage: Ballot Measures Around the Country
description: Tuesdays voting will not only determine control of the Senate, but the fate of important ballot initiatives in several states. Among them:

title: In a Lisbon Band, Echoes From Afar
description: LISBON  On a warm, moonlit fall night, the band Buraka Som Sistema took the stage at an outdoor festival here. Andro Carvalho, known as Conductor, shouted out lyrics while Blaya, the bands high-octane frontwoman, leapt around in sparkly short shorts. From Portugal to the world! Kalaf Angelo, another vocalist, called out to the crowd, which ranged from pre-teenagers to retirees, all dancing to the intense beat.

title: Inside a Jumping Spiders Brain
description: Inside the poppy-seed brain of a stalk-and-pounce predator.

title: Unexpected Complexity in a Spiders Tiny Brain
description: Here is something to keep arachnophobes up at night.

title: Outside the Spring/Summer 2015 Shows in Kiev
description: A glimpse at what some of the guys and gals were wearing in and around the citys just-concluded fashion shows.

title: Big Law Firms Win 47% of Corporate Legal Spending, Analysis Finds
description: The nations top-grossing 200 law firms have garnered about half of the countrys business spending on legal services since 2010, according to a new analysis by the American Lawyer, which tracks data at the biggest law firms.

title: W.H.O. Assails Delay in Ebola Vaccine
description: The leader of the World Health Organization criticized the drug industry on Monday, saying that the drive for profit was one reason no vaccine had yet been found for Ebola.

title: Jonathan P. Hicks, Former Reporter for The New York Times, Dies at 58
description: Jonathan P. Hicks, who covered big business and all levels of New York politics, including the campaigns of three New York City mayors, over 24 years as a reporter for The New York Times, died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 58.

title: A Bach Organ Marathon Set for St. Peters in Manhattan
description: The organist Paul Jacobs once played all of Bachs organ works  more than 200 pieces  in an 18-hour marathon. That was 14 years ago, in Pittsburgh, and no, enough time has not elapsed that Mr. Jacobs is ready to do it again. But when he began discussing a Bach marathon with WQXR, as part of the stations monthlong Bachstock: 30 Days of Peace and Music, he came up with an alternative plan: he would play some works himself, and would invite 19 of his current and former students to play the rest.

title: Papers That Are Most Cited Arent Most Famous
description: It may never win a Nobel Prize, but a 1951 paper describing a way to detect protein levels in a solution tops a new list of the 100 most cited research papers.

title: What Determines the Sex of a Persimmon
description: Most plants are hermaphroditic: Each individual has male and female organs. An exception is the persimmon tree, which belongs to a small group of plants that are dioecious  that is, one sex or the other. Females need pollen from male trees to produce fruit.

title: A Gene by Any Other Name
description: Q. WHAT IS THE LOGIC IN NAMING HUMAN GENES? THE NUMBER-LETTER COMBINATIONS SEEM ABSTRACT AND HARD TO REMEMBER.

title: LabCorps $6.1 Billion Deal Doesnt Pass the Test
description: Laboratory Corp of Americas $6.1 billion deal for Covance tests positive for value destruction.

title: Type(writer) Casting: A Book of Short Stories From Tom Hanks
description: Tom Hanks has a thing for typewriters. Hes been collecting them  for no particular reason, he says  since 1978. A few months ago he released a writing app called the Hanx Writer, which mimics the sounds and motions of an old-school typewriter on an iPad. Last summer he wrote an essay for The New York Times about his favorite models, riffing on the relative merits of a Hermes 2000, a 1930s Remington or a mid-century Royal.

title: Immigration and Obamas Swoon
description: My Sunday column considered various possible and partial explanations for President Obamas long year of low approval ratings, which seem likely to help cost his party control of the Senate tomorrow. The big four I considered were structural forces (the idea that polarization and gridlock alone suffice to send most second-term presidents regressing to the low 40s), the essential mediocrity of our recovered economy, the continued unpopularity ofObamacare, and foreign policy (where the presidents approval ratings have fallen hard) as a kind of synecdoche for larger doubts about the administrations basic competence. Obviously there are many more factors one could consider, but since I write about the issue frequently I thought I should explain why I didnt include immigration, another area where the presidents approvalnumbers have plummeted as his administration has stumbled in various ways over the last year.

title: Walkabout: Investigation of Virgin Galactic Crash Continues
description: Questions Arise An investigation into the crash of a Virgin Galactic space planethat killed one pilot continues, focusing on the failure of a technical configuration. (The New York Times)

title: Eurozone Bank Regulator to Follow Up on Stress Tests
description: FRANKFURT  The eurozones new chief bank overseer insisted on Monday that a review of lenders completed by the European Central Bank last month was rigorous and credible. But she conceded that there were shortcomings that would have to be corrected later.

title: Unidentified Drones Are Seen Above French Nuclear Plants
description: PARIS  Security officials are investigating a mysterious wave of drone flights that have illegally buzzed over more than a dozen nuclear plants across France, raising security concerns around the countrys primary energy source.

title: Ways to Increase Your Wealth When Your Income Is Flat
description: Income inequality can arise from a number of things, like gender, race, social class and education. We know its an issue. But the most recent recession revealed what may be an even bigger problem: wealth inequality.

title: A Beloved Downtown Mens Wear Boutique Launches Its Own Label
description: Im quite aware of whats out there, and I never wanted to be like other stores, Sweetu Patel says about C.H.C.M., his celebrated New York mens wear boutique which has just launched its debut collection. The Indian-born, British-raised Patel  a former furniture designer and one-time founder of the high-end contemporary-furniture gallery Citizen: Citizen  started C.H.C.M. out of his Brooklyn apartment in August 2008, went online seven months later and opened his Bond Street location four years ago. Despite the nod to tradition in its name (which originally stood for Clinton Hill Classic Menswear), the store has offered ahead-of-the-curve clothing from the beginning. Its stock, which included brands like Ovadia & Sons, Arpenteur and Sunspel when they were virtually unknown, often blurred the lines between sportswear, workwear and suiting.

title: As New York Election Looms, Cuomo and Astorino Rally Voters
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo rallied supporters in the heart of Manhattan and across upstate New York on Monday, while his Republican challenger, Rob Astorino, hunted for votes across New York City and its northern suburbs, as time waned on a campaign with little suspense anywhere but in the State Senate.

title: De Niro, in Tax Fight, Wins Little Sympathy From His Neighbors
description: GARDINER, N.Y.  Even after he bought his 78-acre property here, expanded it and turned it into a veritable Bobbywood, Robert De Niro never made much of an impression on this town of 5,800 farmers, climbers, laborers and second-home owners.

title: Democrats Try Scaring Voters to the Polls
description: Much of this years election has been defined by Republicans trying to scare people into voting their fears, but Democrats are also capable of frightening voters to the polls. Their most visible attempt arrived in mailboxes in New York and elsewhere over the last few weeks in the form of a report card grading voters on their participation in past elections.

title: Donmar Warehouse to Broadcast a Politics Play on British Election Night
description: The Donmar Warehouse in London will broadcast a live performance of The Vote, a new collaboration between Josie Rourke and James Graham, on May 7, the day of the British general election. The Vote will be part of the Donmars 2015 spring season, announced Monday, which includes a revival of Patrick Marbers Closer, directed by David Leveaux and starring Nancy Carroll, Oliver Chris, Rufus Sewell and Rachel Redford.

title: Google Search Data Suggests Voter Turnout Will Not Surge
description: Two years ago, a graduate student in economics named Seth Stephens-Davidowitz discovered that Google searches including the word vote or voting could help predict turnout. In places where searches for those terms were more common, turnout was higher, even after controlling for other factors, like voter-registration rates and early-vote volume.

title: Sting and Rene Fleming Among Thanksgiving Day Parade Performers
description: Youve seen them on stage and on television, singing and dancing. Now you can see them ride in slow-moving vehicles, waving, in the vicinity of giant Spider-Man and Thomas the Tank Engine balloons. Macys has announced the celebrity roster for the 88th annual Thanksgiving Day Parade, on Nov. 27, and its an eclectic bunch. Along with the opera star Rene Fleming, the Broadway singer Idina Menzel, Muppets from Sesame Street, acrobats from Cirque du Soleil and the television chef Sandra Lee, there will be a contingent of rock stars of various stripes, including Sting, Nick Jonas, Kiss and the Vamps.

title: A Cookbook That Veers From the Usual Recipe
description: Since 1999, when the chef Gabrielle Hamilton put Triscuits and canned sardines on the first menu of her East Village bistro, Prune, she has nonchalantly broken countless rules of the food world. The rule that a successful restaurant must breed an empire. The rule that chefs who happen to be women should unconditionally support one another. The rule that great chefs dont make great writers (with her memoir, Blood, Bones and Butter).

title: Tavern on the Green Hires Jeremiah Tower as Head Chef
description: Jeremiah Tower, one of the originators of California cuisine, is best known for creating the restaurant Stars, a big, bright celebrity magnet in San Francisco that pulsed with energy and grossed millions from the mid-1980s to the late 90s.

title: Recalled G.M. Cars Remain Unrepaired
description: YONKERS  Nearly nine months after General Motors began recalling millions of its cars for a dangerously defective ignition switch, almost half of the vehicles still have not been fixed.

title: Marie-Chantals Lifestyle Site, Online Gifting Resources and More
description: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

title: A Debatable Fix for Young Eyes
description: BERKELEY, CALIF.  Lilith Sadil, 12, climbs into an examination chair here at the Myopia Control Center at the University of California. Do you know why you are here? asks Dr. Maria Liu, an optometrist.

title: An Exhibition of French Fries, Ramen for the Dining Room and More Food News
description: To Visit: Yes, Well Have Fries With That

title: Monday Motorsports: Ladys Night in Vegas
description: Erica Enders-Stevens, aiming to become the first female Pro Stock champion in the car class took a giant step toward that goal Sunday evening by winning the National Hot Rod Association nationals event in Las Vegas. Enders-Stevens, who had set a new track speed record in qualifying, beat the defending series champion Jeg Coughlin in the final round and regained the series points lead. It was her fifth nationals victory of the season.

title: Southwest Airlines Offers Free Streaming of Apples Beats Music Service
description: Airplanes are becoming more like electronics retail stores, where you can try things out before you buy them. The latest example is Southwest Airlines, which will allow passengers to test-drive Apples Beats Music for free on its aircraft equipped with an Internet connection.

title: Strays Leading the Soviets Into Space
description: There are two reasons I couldnt resist this book. First, I was born on Oct. 5, 1957, one day after the Soviet Union slingshotted the first satellite, Sputnik, into space. So Im a true space age baby who grew up obsessed with the Cold War grudge match to reach the moon.

title: What If You Had a Hypothetical Question That Needed Answering?
description: Randall Munroe, a former NASA roboticist who achieved viral fame with his website xkcd.com, has a new book called What If? Serious Scientific Answers to Absurd Hypothetical Questions.

title: Supreme Court Weighs Status of Jerusalem for Passports
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday considered the status of Jerusalem, which Solicitor General Donald B. Verrilli Jr. told the justices was the most vexing and volatile and difficult diplomatic issue that this nation has faced for decades.

title: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Turkey, the United States, India, Italy and Indonesia.

title: Stacey Snider Named Co-Chairwoman of 20th Century Fox
description: LOS ANGELES  On Monday, 20th Century Fox announced what Hollywood has long known: Stacey Snider, after a bumpy tenure as chief executive of Steven Spielbergs DreamWorks Studios, will join Fox as co-chairwoman.

title: Hes Glad You Asked
description: While giving a physics talk for high school students five years ago at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Randall Munroe could tell that his audience was, in his words, not totally with me.

title: Loss of SpaceShipTwo, Withholding Judgment on Latrines, Black Holes of Yore
description: Spaceflight

title: Why Im Not Voting in the Midterms
description: Voters share the reasons that they will not show up at the polls Tuesday for the midterm elections. Are you voting? Tweet using the hashtag #whyvotemidterms and tell us why.

title: Albums by Neil Young, Bette Midler and Miguel Zenn
description: NEIL YOUNG

title: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Suspended Tuesday
description: Because of Election Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Placebo May Aid Babys Cough
description: Need help for a babys cough? In some cases the best treatment may be a placebo.

title: The Fortepiano, Shy and Playful by Turns
description: Musicians tune their instruments before the start of each concert. But audience members sometimes need to tweak their mode of listening, too, as they settle in for a performance. This is especially true of programs featuring the fortepiano, an instrument that speaks so much more softly than the modern piano our ears are accustomed to.

title: How the Speed of Response Defined the Ebola Crisis
description: How did the timing of the large-scale intervention in the Ebola outbreak affect the number of reported cases today?

title: Liturgy and a Tale, Revived and Sprawling as Ever
description: Leonard Bernsteins Mass: A Theatre Piece for Singers, Players and Dancers begins with a 12-tone Kyrie played from the four corners of the theater. A guitar-strumming Celebrant enters in street clothes, then theres a jazzy Alleluia, like a 1950s radio jingle. A marching band enters, flanked by a chorus, dancers, a childrens choir and another choir, backed by a full symphony orchestra  and thats just in the first 15 minutes, before the rock band, the blues band and, near the two-hour mark, a climactic mad scene.

title: Political Feeding Frenzy as a Turning Point
description: In his thoughtful new book, All the Truth Is Out, the journalist Matt Bai says he can pinpoint the exact moment when the rules of politics changed, and the nation and its media took a hard turn toward abject triviality.

title: A Quiet Week at the Box Office for Broadway
description: Most holiday weekends are a boon for Broadway shows, given the spike in tourists and families buying tickets, but Halloween isnt a night made for sitting inside theaters. Last weekends combination of Halloween, the New York City marathon and the change in daylight savings time (which can throw off routines) hurt box-office business for most Broadway musicals and plays, which earn the bulk of their weekly grosses during performances between Fridays and Sundays. Broadway grossed $23.5 million for a total of 34 shows last week, or about 10 percent less than the previous week (when 32 shows were running), according to box office data released on Monday.

title: A Midterm Election Quiz: Testing Our Political Assumptions
description: Is President Obama a Republican? Was Richard M. Nixon our last liberal president? Claims like these (from Bruce Bartlett, in a cover story for The American Conservative, and Noam Chomsky, in a discussion at The Huffington Post, respectively) challenge what we think we know about political labels and about our presidents and their records in office.

title: Scene City: Fashion, Film and Art Collide at Lacma Gala
description: Leonardo DiCaprio, Quentin Tarantino, Kanye West, Kim Kardashian and Culture Club are among the guests at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

title: The Marijuana Industry Comes to New York and Everyone Wants In
description: The medical marijuana industry is coming to New York. John Leland and Mosi Secret, reporters for Metro, wrote an article on Sunday about the industry after attending the East Coast Cannabis Business Expo, Educational Conference and Regulatory Summit, their first glimpse of the people who are eager to get involved in what will become a multimillion-dollar business. Here, John describes the experience.

title: Inquiry Faults Liberia Force That Fired on Protesters
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  Liberian security forces fired with complete disregard for human life into crowds of civilians protesting a blanket Ebola quarantine over the summer, killing one teenager and seriously wounding another young man, according to the first independent investigation of the deadly clashes.

title: In Performance | Danner and Lange
description: Blythe Danner and Eric Lange play mother and son at odds in a scene from Donald Marguliess play The Country House. The show is on Broadway at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater through Nov. 23.

title: Nov. 3, 2014  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Turkey, Syria, India and the United States.

title: Pests in the Apartment, but No Ants in the Pants
description: The devastation of the climate, the ravages of capitalism, the marginal status of theater  thats a lot to cram into a single South Brooklyn apartment. Buzz, the debut play by the novelist and critic Benjamin Kunkel, takes place in the loft where Tom (Trevor Kluckman) struggles to write a play, while his girlfriend, Sasha (Jeri Silverman), awaits the birth of their baby.

title: Writer, Rejected for a Retail Job, Is Embraced and Vilified on Facebook
description: It was the usual Sunday night Facebook scroll. To be honest, what really caught my eye on Deborah Copakens How I Got Rejected From a Job at The Container Store was the image, which was of containers. I like containers; clearly, many of us do, thus The Container Store.

title: Treating Disease, and Spreading It?
description: Most infectious diseases reinforce that appealing them and us schism that so often deludes health care professionals. They, our patients, have it, their contacts out in the world are at risk for getting it, and we, their caregivers, are safely removed from the whole thing. Not Ebola: We have met the patients, and they are us.

title: The Indestructible Beat of Tamino
description: Less glockenspiel, more drumming! A very different sort of The Magic Flute took the stage at the New Victory Theater on Sunday afternoon in front of an attentive and appreciative family audience. This two-hour adaptation of Mozarts fairy tale opera was presented under the Xhosa title Impempe Yomlingo by the South African Isango Ensemble, a company that recruits performers from townships in the Cape Town area and presents classics from the Western canon in an updated, African context.

title: Ideas to Improve Financial Lives, From the Treasurers Office
description: Known primarily as number crunchers and tax collectors, treasurers for state and local governments traditionally were limited to activities like processing payrolls, managing budgets, safeguarding pensions and being the target of accountant jokes.

title: How to Watch the Elections Like an Expert
description: On election night, knowing who is ahead isnt enough.

title: Fighting an Epidemic With Hands Tied
description: WASHINGTON  Hundreds of government and civilian workers of all stripes, and thousands of military personnel, have braved the terrifying prospect of infection to respond to the Ebola emergency in West Africa. And thousands more will be needed for an effort that is expected to go well into 2015.

title: On the Infield or Onstage, a Diva Is but a Click Away
description: No, Maria Callas did not tweet. But if there were any question about how digital media are changing the worlds of opera and classical music, consider the last few weeks in the life of the great American mezzo-soprano Joyce DiDonato.

title: How Do You Measure the Mood of the Electorate?
description: The congressional reporter Jonathan Weisman is covering the midterm elections. We asked him how he gauges voters moods.

title: Sprints Tough Quarter Highlights Lost Promise of T-Mobile Deal
description: Even before Sprint ended its long pursuit of T-Mobile US, analysts and investors had come to believe that the embattled wireless carrier needed a huge shot in the arm  like that attempted merger  to reverse its fortunes.

title: The Day in Pictures
description: Get caught up on Mondays top stories.

title: For Viewers Who Set Their Sights High and Low
description: The World Series is over, and the first cancellations of the new TV season have been recorded, so that must mean its time for the mid-autumn television malaise: After weeks of being pummeled with a lot of new shows, suddenly everything seems drab. But thats why we have 300 channels now instead of just three.

title: A Tiny Stumble, a Life Upended
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Joan Rees, 79, had hardly been ill a day in her life. Her biggest problem was arthritis, mostly in her knees, but at home in San Francisco she walked every day and she traveled frequently.

title: Steps to Avoid an Accident
description: Preventing a fall, and the resulting injuries, isnt simply a matter of being more careful. Indeed, experts who have studied falls wish that people would take measures to protect themselves much as they do against heart disease or viral infections.

title: Intersection | Carnegie Hill, Manhattan
description: Agostino Magni, an Italian businessman, says he follows a family tradition of wearing custom-made shirts, monogrammed with his initials, and he chooses pocket squares to match.

title: At a Napa Festival, Taking the Appellation Trail
description: If a food festival features food from celebrity alumni of the Culinary Institute of America and is hosted in Californias Napa Valley, theres a good chance its going to appeal to travelers.

title: Election Day: The Mood of America
Skipping the Front Desk, and Checking In With a Click
description: People use smartphones today to do everything from pay for coffee to board a plane. Now, a growing number of hotels want guests to be able to unlock their guest rooms with their phones.

title: Judicial Confirmations
description: To the Editor:

title: Humans Raise Penguins as Well as Penguins Do
description: Penguin chicks hand-raised by researchers and released back into the wild survived at about the same rate as wild penguins, says a new study from the University of Cape Town. With the endangered African penguin population dropping rapidly since 2001, conservationists have been rescuing and raising abandoned chicks that would otherwise have starved. Writing in the journal PLOS One, the researchers said that of the 1,320 chicks adopted by conservationists, more than 1,100 were rereleased in 2006 and 2007, and thrived similarly to wild penguins.

title: Luring Private Investors
description: To the Editor:

title: How Citi Bike Succeeds
description: To the Editor:

title: H.I.V. Patients in Yemen Face Hospital Evictions
description: Patients infected with H.I.V. are being ordered out of hospitals in Yemen, even when they are in dire need of care, a human rights group says.

title: Remember Chocolate
description: To the Editor:

title: The Value of Older Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Nye on the Science of Creation
description: In his new book, Undeniable, the veteran television science showman Bill Nye talks about chicken knees, the importance of understanding evolution in an increasingly technologically based society and why he thinks creationists are preoccupied with death.

title: A Fight for the Young Creationist Mind
description: In February, William Sanford Nye, better known as Bill Nye the science guy, stepped onto a stage in Kentucky and faced down a hostile crowd in a debate that pitted evolution against creationism. It wasnt his first time in the ring in sciences corner. In recent years, Mr. Nye has transitioned from the zany, on-screen face of an educational show on PBS, which ran from 1993 to 1998, to a hardened warrior for science on cable news programs and speaking tours of colleges and universities around the United States.

title: Video: How to Watch Election Night
description: A guide to following the races on Election Day.

title: How to Watch Election Night
description: David Leonhardt, editor of The Upshot, offers an animated look at the six states to watch as Democrats try to beat the odds and maintain control of the Senate.

title: Under Investigation, JPMorgan Increases Its Potential Legal Costs
description: JPMorgan Chase recently added $2.4 billion to its estimate of the amount of legal costs it may face, the latest sign that investigations into the possible manipulation of the currency market are gaining momentum.

title: Scenes From the Hello Kitty Convention in Los Angeles
description: Red carpets and celebrities are a dime a dozen in L.A., but this past weekend the city feted an icon unlike any other. Hello Kitty, who turns 40 this year, was the star of a suite of events that began on Wednesday with the opening of the first annual Hello Kitty Convention. The carnival-meets-trade fair drew more than 26,000 Sanrio disciples dressed to the nines, plus several stars from the Nickelodeon set and the superfan Katy Perry, to MOCAs Geffen Contemporary in Little Tokyo. Highlights included musical performances, scholarly panels on licensing and globalization, live appearances and, last but not least,shopping, while some of the strangest sights included watching Kitty christen the Friendship Village pop-up shop as she bought a cartload of merchandise featuring herself, and the tattoo parlor that offered attendees a spectrum of free, permanent body art (Perry partook). The photographer Jacqueline DiMilia captured the style scene in and around the show; for those craving a closer look, the companion exhibition at the Japanese American National Museum next door, Hello! Exploring the Supercute World of Hello Kitty, is on view through April 26 of next year.

title: U.S. Oil Prices Fall Below $80 a Barrel
description: HOUSTON  The benchmark American oil price fell below the symbolic $80-a-barrel threshold on Monday, swooning to two-year lows, after Saudi Arabia aimed to shore up its dwindling exports to the United States by cutting its selling price for the American market.

title: Broadway Sailors New Leading Lady
description: Three sailors on a 24-hour furlough in New York City have one thing on their mind, and it isnt seeing the Statue of Liberty. Or at least so goes the story line in On the Town, the 1944 musical currently enjoying a much-lauded Broadway revival.

title: Business Aircraft Industry Climbing Back, Slowly
description: AT the convention of the National Business Aviation Association in Orlando, Fla., last month, it seemed that happy days were not quite here again, but at least the miserable days that hit the business aircraft industry in 2009 appeared to be waning.

title: Under Pressure, Burkina Fasos Military Promises to Cede Power
description: One day after street protests against the military ended in violence, Burkina Fasos interim leader, Lt. Col. Isaac Zida, insisted on Monday that the army planned to give way to a civilian-led transitional body soon.

title: Wallenda Tightrope Walk Is No Match for Walking Dead
description: Maybe its getting too easy for Nik Wallenda  or maybe walking on a tightrope across the Chicago skyline isnt as scary as walking zombies.

title: Stand-Up Routine
description: Administrivial Chance To Back Something Great Alert! Our friend Patrick Merrell  artist, author, former Wordplay blogger and general man-about-town  has launched a Kickstarter campaign to crowdfund his newest venture, a puzzle adventure story book called Zep in the Curse of the Evil Dr. Sumac Who Lives Next Door! This would make a great gift for young puzzlers, but, as Mr. Merrell says, its An amusing book for young and old alike. Its a kids book, but with a very sophisticated, multi-step puzzle hidden within its pages. Lets see what we can do to make this a reality. Click here for more information about the book and rewards for contributing to Patricks campaign.

title: Cubs, After Clearing Air Over Joe Maddon Hiring, Turn Attention to a Drought
description: CHICAGO  A Bears cap on his head, Chicago Cubs President Theo Epstein hopped two planes to Pensacola, Fla., last week. There, he drove to an R.V. park on the beach to find Joe Maddon.

title: A Photographers Promise to an Indian Child
description: Alex Masi vows to help an Indian child he photographed in Bhopal continue her schooling while he presses on with a long term project about her.

title: Mustnt Keep the Client Waiting
description: IVE spent a lot of time in planes. Im an architect, and president and principal of SB Architects. My passport reads like an atlas, with stamps from Europe, Asia, the Middle East, North Africa, the Caribbean, Central America, South America and China. We have offices in San Francisco, Miami and Shenzhen, so those are frequent stops, too. Were contemplating offices in Istanbul and So Paulo, so those may join my list of most-visited airports.

title: Not a Flight of Fancy
description: SEATTLE  ONE clear winter day in 1909, in Hampshire, England, a young man named Geoffrey de Havilland took off in a twin-propeller motorized flying machine of his own design, built of wood, piano wire and stiff linen hand-stitched by his wife. The launch was flawless, and soon he had an exhilarating sensation of climbing almost straight upward toward the brilliant blue sky. But he soon realized he was in terrible trouble.

title: Stryker Settles Suits by Hip Implant Patients for $1 Billion
description: Stryker, the major producer of artificial hip implants, said on Monday that it had reached a settlement of thousands of patient lawsuits involving now-recalled devices that is expected to cost the company about $1 billion.

title: Flattening Flattens
description: Justin Fox notes that the world is still not flat, and in fact doesnt seem to be getting flatter; global connectedness, by various measures, seems to have leveled off. In particular, north-north trade doesnt seem to be going much of anywhere.

title: Pippin to Close on Broadway
description: The Tony Award-winning Broadway revival of the musical Pippinwill close at the Music Box Theater on Jan. 4, 2015, the shows producers announced on Monday evening.

title: Her Anorexia, My Fear
description: For some people, the psychiatrists couch is a metal examining table.

title: Where Riding and Wrangling Beat Virtual Adventures
description: OGDEN, Utah  There were 5-year-olds riding woolly white sheep and fourth graders astride 600-pound bulls, all trying very hard not to fall off. Girls in pink tops took their turn at the goat tie, riding their horses toward a tethered goat, wrestling it to the ground and tying its hooves together with a rope.

title: Falling Tape Measure Kills Man at Jersey City Construction Site
description: A tower rising 50 stories. A one-pound tape measure attached to the waist of a construction worker. An unsuspecting man stepping from a vehicle at the foot of the building.

title: Maine: Nurse Reaches Agreement on Travel
description: A nurse who fought efforts by Maine to quarantine her at home after she returned from treating Ebola patients in West Africa reached an agreement on Monday with the state that largely leaves her free to travel.
