The agreement requires the nurse, Kaci Hickox, 33, to be monitored daily for Ebola symptoms and to coordinate travel with public health officials until next Monday, the end of the 21-day incubation period after her last possible exposure to Ebola. The agreement extends a temporary order issued Friday by Judge Charles C. LaVerdiere, the chief judge for Maine District Courts, who had rejected a request by Gov. Paul LePages administration that Ms. Hickox stay off public transportation, avoid public gatherings and stay three feet away from other people.

title: Returns on College Endowments Average 15.8 Percent
description: The average return, after fees, on college and university endowments was 15.8 percent in the fiscal year that ended in June, up from 11.7 percent the previous year, according to the preliminary data collected for the annual Nacubo-Commonfund Study of Endowments, which will be released in January. The largest endowments  those over $1 billion  had the highest average return, 16.8 percent. The study, based on data from 426 colleges, found that colleges were allocating more than half their investments  and almost two-thirds of the largest endowments  to alternative strategies such as hedge funds and private equity.

title: Burkina Faso: A Regional Warning
description: The African Union on Monday gave Burkina Fasos military leaders two weeks to return power to a civilian-led government or face severe sanctions. The warning by the Peace and Security Council of the 54-nation organization, posted on its Twitter account after an emergency meeting in Ethiopia, came as the countrys interim president, Lt. Col. Isaac Zida, sought to assure diplomats and residents that the military takeover of the government on Friday was only temporary. The armed forces seized control after the longtime president, Blaise Compaor, fled amid mass protests over his efforts to engineer a vote that would have allowed him to stay in office indefinitely. The United States government, which is legally obliged to suspend aid to countries where power is usurped by the military, did not immediately take a position on whether the events in Burkina Faso had amounted to a coup. Were still gathering facts, said Jen Psaki, a State Department spokeswoman. Were not going to make a policy or legal determination at this point in time.

title: An Emotional Response to Charlotte Hornets Name Change
description: MANY residents of Charlotte, N.C., have answered their doorbells in recent days to find a giant hornet standing before them, holding a purple basketball net. It was not, it turns out, a fever dream; rather, it was Hugo, the teal-and-purple mascot for the Charlotte Hornets, and he was handing out the nets to help create, as hornets are apt to, buzz.

title: Bells Tolling for Miles, Boston Offers a Goodbye to Former Mayor
description: BOSTON  Church bells tolled across Boston on Monday as a hearse bearing the body of Thomas M. Menino, this citys longest-serving mayor, rolled through the streets, from historic Faneuil Hall, where he lay in state, to the church in the Hyde Park neighborhood where he had been baptized and where mourners bid their final farewell.

title: Beverly Blossom, Solo Dancer With a Voice, Dies at 88
description: Beverly Blossom, a modern-dance choreographer and teacher and a daring, vividly imaginative solo performer, died on Saturday in Chicago. She was 88.

title: Egyptian Cleric Defends Forced Evacuation of Families From Sinai
description: CAIRO  A government-appointed Muslim clerical leader on Monday provided a religious defense of the forced evacuation of more than 1,100 families from the Sinai Peninsula in an attempt to root out militant extremists.

title: Election Day Choices
description: Poll hours: 6 a.m. to 9 p.m.

title: Brittany Maynard, Death With Dignity Ally, Dies at 29
description: Brittany Maynard, who became a public face for the death with dignity movement in the United States after she was found to have terminal brain cancer, ended her life on Saturday at her home in Portland, Ore. She was 29.

title: After 26 Miles, Thousands of Paths
description: After the completion of the New York City Marathon on Sunday, signs of the field dispersing lingered across the city. Clockwise from top left, workers on East 62nd Street collected paper cups discarded by the participants. After the race, some runners took the C train. Sunny Kang and Jason Choi, who both completed the race, walked through Central Park on the 65th Street transverse. Others just sat on the ground in the park.

title: De Blasio Unveils New Plans for Troubled Schools in New York
description: In the packed auditorium of an East Harlem high school, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a new approach to fixing New York Citys most troubled public schools on Monday, offering them more money and staffing, extending the length of their day, and arranging for social services to be delivered to students and families on site.

title: Election 2014: Your Very Predictable Vote
David M. Abshire, Who Helped Reagan Through Iran-Contra Scandal, Dies at 88
description: David M. Abshire, who led respected research groups and held high government posts but made his most visible mark by helping President Ronald Reagan navigate the political storms of the Iran-contra scandal, died on Friday in Alexandria, Va. He was 88.

title: Investigation of Honda Centers on Failure to Report Deaths From Takata Airbags
description: Federal safety regulators said on Monday that they were investigating whether Honda Motor failed to report deaths and injuries from defective airbags that can rupture violently.

title: So Far, Knicks Are Succeeding With Less Carmelo Anthony
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  For the first time in 369 days, the Knicks showed up for practice on Monday morning with a winning record. They have 79 games left to play, starting Tuesday night against the Washington Wizards, so their 2-1 record means little in the grand scheme of a season. But it means something to the players.

title: In Traveling to the Stars, Risk and Cost
description: Space travel has long been the preserve of governments and sci-fi fans, but in recent years a crop of new commercial ventures, often backed by billionaire entrepreneurs, has sought to get into the race.

title: After the Death of Her Father, She Fights Her Way Back to College
description: On a rainy Tuesday morning, Melicia Pristell sat in the lobby of Academic Building 1 on the Medgar Evers College campus, where she often comes to study. Her face buried in a book and a messenger bag across her lap, she had safely returned to her sanctuary  one she had almost lost.

title: Death by Data
description: Over the past decade or so, political campaigns have become more scientific. Campaign consultants use sophisticated data to micro-target specific demographic slices. Consultants select their ad buys more precisely because they know which political niche is watching which TV show. Campaigns trial test messages that push psychological buttons.

title: Long in Repose, Last Remnants of a Founding Family Will Leave Long Island City
description: More people are buried in Queens than are living there now. This is a story of some of the departed.

title: Hotel-Room Calls: No More Quarters in the Slot
description: Using your hotel room phone for domestic or international calls usually means getting hit with a prohibitively high bill:Properties charge a premium running up to several dollars a minute to dial direct and even tack on service fees for calling locally.

title: Merkel Toughens Position on Britains E.U. Demands
description: LONDON  Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany has indicated that she is prepared to contemplate a future for the European Union without Britain, if Prime Minister David Cameron insists on new measures to limit the rights of Europeans to live and work there, German news media reported on Monday.

title: Should Voting Be a Constitutional Right?
Gotham Recap: All Hail the Penguin
description: Season 1, Episode 7, Penguins Umbrella

title: A $15.3 Million Pitch, With a Catch
description: In his long, record-breaking career as a closer, playing in a huge baseball market, Mariano Rivera ultimately made $15 million a year, the most any relief pitcher has ever been paid.

title: Hollywood Works to Maintain Its World Dominance
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  Twice in the last few months, there was a faint knock on the door of American supremacy in the global film market.

title: Tom Magliozzi, One Half of the Jovial Brothers on Car Talk, Dies at 77
description: Tom Magliozzi, who with his younger brother, Ray, hosted Car Talk, for years the most popular entertainment show on NPR, died on Monday at his home outside Boston. He was 77.

title: Another Battle for Eisenhower
description: Dwight David Eisenhower, the 34th president and military legend who organized the Normandy invasion, might have been bemused in his grinning Kansas way at the bureaucratic retreats and aesthetic flak it has taken to win approval of an official Eisenhower memorial on a 4-acre site overlooking the Capitol. A crucial vote of approval Oct. 16 from the United States Commission of Fine Arts signaled a go-ahead for an overdue tribute first approved by Congress 15 years ago.

title: Driving Student Borrowers Into Default
description: People who pay for college with federal student loans can avoid default when they fall on hard times by making lower payments  or no payments at all  until they recover financially. Borrowers who take out private student loans from banks and other institutions typically have no such option. When they lose their jobs or suffer other financial setbacks, they have little choice but to default, which, in turn, damages their credit histories and ability to borrow for other purposes or even to find a job.

title: Sex and Drug Claims at Investment Bank Jefferies Draw Risky Retort
description: We went to our partners in health care investment banking yesterday afternoon and said, The two of us are going to go take a drug test, and do you want to join us?

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 3, 2014
Guns and Public Health
description: Mike Weisser is my favorite gun dealer. The longtime proprietor of the Ware Gun Shop in Ware, Mass., Weisser, 70, estimates he has sold more than 40,000 guns in his career as a wholesaler and retailer. He also has a nice little business teaching a gun-safety course that Massachusetts requires of all new gun owners.

title: Trying to Seal the Deal
description: Candidates across the country made their final appeals to voters on Monday before Tuesdays midterm elections.

title: What to Watch For as G.O.P. Expects Big Night at Polls
description: WASHINGTON  It is a recipe for sensory overload: Election returns will start flooding every device and screen Tuesday evening, capturing the outcomes of 36 governors contests, the battle for control of the Senate, nearly 50 competitive House races and countless ballot questions.

title: Passion and Eloquence, Smothered in Explanation
description: Theres a poignant moment in Lines in the Dust when Denitra, a working-class single mother, describes how she and her daughter sometimes put on fine clothes and visit open houses held by real estate agents in wealthy neighborhoods.

title: Heirs to the Peyton Manning-Tom Brady Rivalry? For Now, Its Up for Grabs
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The New England Patriots had trounced the Denver Broncos, 43-21, in a game between quarterback titans, and Darrelle Revis, a veteran cornerback for the Patriots, considered a question about Tom Brady and Peyton Manning.

title: For a Packed Part of Jerusalem, Expansion Plans Have Built Mostly Outrage
description: JERUSALEM  Residents jokingly refer to Lower Ramat Shlomo: In the parking area beneath apartments, instead of cars, wood-veneer doors mark homes fashioned illegally to accommodate a bursting population. Elsewhere in the ultra-Orthodox Jewish neighborhood of East Jerusalem, courtyards and porches are enclosed by wood, glass, even burlap  every available space, it seems, transformed into makeshift shacks by a community whose growth has been stymied by the fraught politics of this contested city.

title: Role for Russia Gives Iran Talks a Possible Boost
description: WASHINGTON  Iran has tentatively agreed to ship much of its huge stockpile of uranium to Russia if it reaches a broader nuclear deal with the West, according to officials and diplomats involved in the negotiations, potentially a major breakthrough in talks that have until now been deadlocked.

title: Sex After 50? Less Important for Women, Portuguese Court Rules
description: MADRID  It was difficult and depressing enough for a middle-age widow in Portugal who was unable to have a normal sex life after botched surgery.

title: A Draft Bust Playing in Vienna Pictures Life After Hockey
description: VIENNA  On the crowded cobblestone streets of Austrias largest city, the locals largely ignore the 6-foot-6 hockey player in their midst.

title: A Special Child: Whats a Mother to Do?
description: The nuclear family and the traditions of Tibetan Buddhism come into conflict in The Oldest Boy, the new play by Sarah Ruhl, about an American child who is identified by monks as the reincarnation of a revered Buddhist teacher. This revelation  if revelation it truly is  poses a painful challenge to the childs parents, a Tibetan-born father who runs a restaurant in an unnamed American city, and his Cincinnati-born mother. Buddhist practice would require that the boy  just 3 when the play begins  be sent to India to study for his calling at a monastery, a move that naturally dismays his parents, particularly his mother.

title: Sleepy Hollow Recap: And the Father Has Eight Legs
description: Season 2, Episode 7, Deliverance

title: N.S.A. Director Makes Another Visit to Silicon Valley
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Adm. Michael S. Rogers, director of the National Security Agency, said on Monday that a secure Internet was in the best interest of the United States, following disclosures that the N.S.A. had been exploiting weaknesses in the web for foreign intelligence gathering.

title: The Shake-Up at Rikers Island
description: Violence and corruption became entrenched at New York Citys Rikers Island jail because officers who ignored or even condoned that culture were moved steadily up the ladder into management.

title: Politicians Show Frustration After a Police Chiefs Exit in New York
description: Not long after Philip Banks III, the New York Police Departments highest-ranking uniformed officer, abruptly resigned on Friday, Mayor Bill de Blasio phoned several black elected officials to convey his disappointment.

title: Rangers Stand-In Lineup Comes Up Short Against Blues
description: A long list of lineup challenges, a tough Western Conference opponent and last seasons top scorer on the sideline were more than sufficient motivation for the Rangers.

title: Word of the Day | prim
description: prim \prim\ adjective and verb

title: Nets Follow a Bit of Levity With a Serious Drubbing of the Thunder
description: It had been almost 10 months since Mikhail D. Prokhorov last spoke to the reporters who cover the Nets, the team he has owned since 2010, so it felt as if there was some catching up to do Monday night at the teams first home game of the season.

title: Much Has Happened Since the Jets Last Won
description: It is with the benefit of hindsight that Sept. 7 now stands out as a rare and amazing day. For that was the Sunday when the Jets, in their season opener, actually won a game. They have not won since  not in eight games, played in five stadiums and in two time zones. Their misery is in its third month, with no relief in sight.

title: Did Someone Say 2016? Presidential Contenders Circle
description: Ready or not, the midterm elections signal the unofficial start of the next presidential campaign. Assessing the prospects of some likely candidates.

title: Few Retired N.F.L. Players Opt Out of Proposed Concussion Settlement
description: Fewer than one percent of former N.F.L. players opted out of a settlement with the league that is designed to pay players with severe neurological conditions.

title: A Design-Centric New Pizzeria From One of Mexico Citys Buzziest Chefs
description: Since 2012, Maximo, helmed by the chef Eduardo Garca, has been drawing the citys food cognoscenti to the Roma neighborhood for its innovative approach that fuses Mexican ingredients with European techniques. Now, Garca and his wife and business partner, Gabriela Lpez-Cruz, are introducing their newest venture, Lalo!, a pizzeria and cafe situated directly across the street. And thanks to Garcas training at Michelin-starred restaurants in Mexico City and New York (Enrique Olveras famed Pujol and Le Bernardin, respectively), Lalo! promises more than the average grab-a-slice experience. Potato, rosemary and truffle oil pizza, inspired by a trip to Puglia, will be on the menu, along with striped sea bass served with caramelized onions and gremolata, salads using lettuce from the Mexican region of Xochimilco and suckling pig in salsa verde paired with a Mexican succulent known as verdolagas.

title: At the Guggenheim, an Orb by Otto Piene Ascends
description: The imposing rotunda inside the Guggenheim museum in New York has just become a lot more striking thanks to Otto Pienes White Balloon installation, on display for only three days. Specially installed to coincide with this years Guggenheim International Gala, sponsored by Christian Dior, it dovetails with a longer exhibition: the first large-scale survey in an American museum of Zero, the experimental, post-World War II group. Zero: Countdown to Tomorrow, 1950s-60s presents a breadth of work by more than 30 artists from 10 countries around the world, including some of the movements founders: Piene, Gunther Ueker, Heinz Mack and Yves Klein.

title: Two Men Charged With Murder in Fatal Shooting Outside Bronx Club
description: Two men were arrested on Monday and charged with murder in the shooting of a man during a fight outside a Bronx club last month, the police said.

title: Woebegone Giants Fall to the Colts in a Rout
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  There were many things the Giants did wrong in Monday nights 40-24 defeat to the Indianapolis Colts. There were dropped passes, wayward throws, a hopelessly anemic running game, three Colts fumbles that were not recovered and a multitude of blown assignments defensively.

title: Football, the Newest Partisan Divide
description: To the list of issues that divide the country along partisan lines, you can add an unusual item: football.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 10 P.M. (HBO Signature) ADMISSION (2013) Tina Fey portrays Portia Nathan, a Princeton admissions officer who seems to take a special kind of glee in controlling the fate of applicants aspiring to the university. She also has a goal of her own: to succeed the retiring dean of admissions (Wallace Shawn) and beat out her office rival (Gloria Reuben) while reclaiming Princetons place at the top of the U.S. News & World Report rankings. But just as her smug English-professor boyfriend (Michael Sheen) dumps her for an aggressive Virginia Woolf scholar (Sonya Walger), a fellow Dartmouth alum (Paul Rudd) comes along with an unusual student (Nat Wolff) he wants Portia to consider. How could anyone make light of the brutal, capricious system by which our young people are judged and sorted? A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this comedy from Paul Weitz, adapted from the novel by Jean Hanff Korelitz. I must confess that I dont know whether to be relieved or disappointed that Admission, which had the potential to be a sharp, satirical jab at the soft belly of middle-class anxiety, chose instead to be a warm and wacky fable of wish fulfillment.

title: Corrections: November 4, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Im telling you, that banana pudding, really  its life-changing.

title: Enthusiasm Is Good (Personal and Trivial)
description: In case youre wondering about the scarcity of posts, I made a resolution: on this visit to Japan, which includes two conferences with a stretch of time in between, I would actually try to see something. Ive been visiting some of the usual sites, like the Meiji Shrine:

title: Why Dont We See More Macroeconomic Populism?
description: As Ive been noting recently, theres a lot of opposition within Japan to the Bank of Japans policy of printing more money; theres also a lot of pressure on the government to raise taxes. And thats not really very different from what has been happening in the rest of the advanced world: central banks that have pursued quantitative easing have done so despite political pressure, not because of it, and fiscal austerity has been imposed almost everywhere.

title: Saving an Ancient Opera Form
description: Last Friday in a Beijing theater, Li Baofeng and 10 of her colleagues from the Feng Yun Theatrical Company bowed to a small but enthusiastic audience after their performance of Sizhou Xi, a 200-year-old form of Chinese opera. It was the second time Ms. Li, 81, had performed in Beijing. The first time was 57 years earlier, for Mao Zedong at Zhongnanhai, the seat of the Chinese leadership.

title: Banco Santander Profit Jumps 52% Amid Recovery in Spain
description: LONDON  Banco Santander of Spain reported on Tuesday that its third-quarter profit rose 52 percent, posting its strongest earnings in more than two years as the Spanish economy continued to recover.

title: Test Yourself | At Facebook, Creating Empathy Among Cyberbullying
description: Below are the first six paragraphs of the Oct. 22 article Meet Facebooks Mr. Nice.

title: Virgin Moneys I.P.O. Is Back on Track
description: LONDON  The British financial services company Virgin Money, partly owned by the billionaire Richard Branson, said on Tuesday that it planned to list its shares in London by the end of November, after having delayed an initial public offering last month because of volatile market conditions.

title: 6 Qs About the News | An Artifact Once Was Just Home
description: Watch the above video and read the article An Artifact Once Was Just Home to answer the questions below:

title: Will the LeBron James Stimulus Be Good for Cleveland?
description: When LeBron James announced his return to the Cleveland Cavaliers in July, fans celebrated by hanging banners, getting drunk and digging old jerseys out of purgatory. They ran into the streets, honked horns and hugged strangers. And some of them started trying to figure out just how much money was about to rain down on Cleveland. According to one estimate, the return of the king, as James is known, will add $500 million a year to the citys economy. When people say this is just about an athlete making money, theres more to it than that, said Edward FitzGerald, the Cuyahoga County executive, at a news conference devoted to the anticipated windfall. Other people will make a living.

title: Treating Ebola Without Fear
description: Observing my patient through the chicken wire, I saw that the front half of his scalp was shaved  and the long gray hairs behind that equator were gathered in a kudumi, or knot. He was a temple priest. All these years later I can still see that tuft and the three broad white stripes of vibhuti, or holy ash, smeared across his forehead, proclaiming his Shaivite faith, a reminder that the world was all maya  illusion. But his discomfort was real. In my recollection, he sits cross-legged on his mat in that locked room, groaning, restless, his trunk swaying, his features anxious, grimacing as if hed tasted something bitter.

title: A Photographers Promise to an Indian Child
description: It started with $5,000.

title: Should Students Be Barred From Taking Cellphones to School?
description: New York City will be ending its longstanding ban on cellphones in public schools. For years the city argued that cellphones had no place in schools, and that they disrupted student learning. Many parents countered that cellphones were a vital link to their children.

title: European Union Lowers Growth Forecasts as Business Confidence Sags
description: BRUSSELS  European Union officials on Tuesday sharply lowered growth forecasts as member states like France, Germany and Italy showed weak economic performance, and as business confidence suffered from heightened geopolitical risks.

title: As New Rules Take Effect, Voters Report Problems in Some States
description: Some longtime voters in Texas reported on Tuesday that they were refused a ballot because they lacked newly required photo identification. In North Carolina, voters who showed up at the wrong precinct were unable to vote, reflecting a new policy. And in Georgia, hundreds of frustrated people called a hotline to say they were unsure if their voter registrations had been processed, some of the thousands of would-be new voters who reportedly faced uncertainty.

title: Greene King Meets Deadline With $1.2 Billion Offer for Spirit Pub
description: LONDON  Greene King, a British brewer and operator of pubs and hotels, said on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement on a recommended offer to acquire the Spirit Pub Company of Britain.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Americas Big Bet on Indonesia
description: Secretary of State John Kerrys presence last month at the inauguration of President Joko Widodo of Indonesia was another sign of the Obama administrations greater involvement in Asia. It was also an investment in Americas relationship with Indonesia, whose importance as an emerging democracy and the largest economy in Southeast Asia is sometimes overlooked.

title: New York Today: Elections Arrive
description: Good morning on this fine Tuesday.

title: Prosecutors Seek Appeal of Rulings on Pistorius
description: Starting a new phase in a case that captivated a global audience, South African state prosecutors began legal proceedings on Tuesday to appeal the conviction and what they called the shockingly light sentence handed down to the track star Oscar Pistorius last month for killing his girlfriend.

title: Playing the Midterm Elections Game
description: Republicans look set to cash in on voter anger.

title: Daily Report: Hotels Try Smartphone Apps as Room Keys
description: People use smartphones today to do everything from pay for coffee to board a plane. Now, a growing number of hotels want guests to be able to unlock their guest rooms with their phones, Martha C. White reports.

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Heres another batch of word mix-ups, both familiar and novel.

title: Facebook Has Its Own Get-Out-the-Vote Message
description: Facebook wants its users in the United States to vote this Election Day  and it plans to put a reminder Tuesday at the top of the news feed of each of its American users of voting age.

title: Searching for a Web Design Firm That Understands Search
description: This is part two of a series on commissioning a new website. You can read the first post here.

title: Today in Politics
description: On Election Day, Keeping an Eye on the Early Races

title: Morning Agenda: Sex, Drugs and Investment Banking
description: An investment bank has taken unusual steps to quell any idea that it tolerates drug use or promiscuous activity. In response to scandalous accusations made against a managing director, Sage Kelly, as part of a divorce and custody filing, Richard B. Handler, the chief executive of Jefferies, has defended Mr. Kelly, made an impassioned case that his firm was being unfairly smeared and ended up marching an army of bankers into a drug test in the middle of the day after approaching other members of Mr. Kellys team, Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook Column. Mr. Kelly was accused by his wife, Christina, of abusing drugs, including cocaine and ecstasy. She also contended that Mr. Kelly instigated a sexual encounter involving a client, Marc Beer, and his girlfriend.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Oct. 28-Nov. 3, 2014
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Election Night: What to Expect
description: Get some coffee or some Vitaminwater, because its going to be one of the most dramatic election nights in a long time.

title: Top British Spy Warns of Terrorists Use of Social Media
description: LONDON  One of Britains highest-ranking intelligence officials on Tuesday castigated the giant American companies that dominate the Internet for providing the command-and-control networks of choice for terrorists and criminals and challenged the companies to find a better balance between privacy and security.

title: Beyonc to Release a New Album, a Version of Her Old Album
description: So Beyonc is releasing a new album this month, but it is not quite what the Internet guessed that it was.

title: Alibaba, Shrugging Off Slowdown in Chinese Economy, Reports Strong First Earnings
description: HONG KONG  Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce behemoth, reported on Tuesday a jump in profit in its first earnings announcement since its initial public offering in September.

title: In Performance: Blythe Danner and Eric Lange of The Country House
description: This weeks video features Blythe Danner and Eric Lange as mother and son at odds in The Country House, a new Broadway play by Donald Margulies. In this scene Ms. Danner plays Anna, a veteran actress who cant hide her disappointment after learning from her son Elliot, played by Mr. Lange, that he wants to be a playwright. The show, directed by Daniel Sullivan, continues through Nov. 23 at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

title: Ye Haiyan, Rights Campaigner, Is Detained Over Photo Posted Online
description: Ye Haiyan, a prominent campaigner for the rights of women and sex workers, has been detained in the central city of Wuhan for posting a nude photo of herself on the microblogging service Weibo, her friends said.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: As Power of Terror Group Declines, Once-Feared Fighters Defect
description: BAIDOA, Somalia  Bashir was a true believer, a foot soldier who recently quit after seeing too many innocents slaughtered.

title: Nostalgic Odors on the No. 5 Train
description: Dear Diary:

title: At the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Awards, Some Surprises and Agendas
description: It was the toughest decision weve had to make, Anna Wintour, the editor of Vogue, said at the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund award dinner on Monday night.

title: Oscar de la Rentas Island Oasis
description: Tortuga Bay Hotel in Punta Cana has luxurious plantation-style villas, access to two golf courses and a V.I.P. airport terminal. And now it boasts beachfront suites redecorated by its former part owner, the Dominican Republic native Oscar de la Renta. His use of wicker, mahogany and neutral linens graciously echoes the surroundings. As part of the revamp, the on-site Bamboo Restaurant was also refurbished by de la Renta to match the propertys colonial vibe.

title: Investigators in Mexico Detain Mayor and His Wife Over Missing Students
description: MEXICO CITY  The fugitive mayor of a southern Mexican town where 43 college students were apparently abducted in September after he reportedly ordered the police to attack them was detained Tuesday along with his wife in an early-morning raid here, federal officials said.

title: Digital Ads Lift 3rd-Quarter Revenue at Time Inc.
description: Time Inc., Americas largest magazine publisher, reported on Tuesday that its third-quarter revenue had increased slightly as it continued to suffer from declines in print advertising and circulation.

title: Voting in the New York Region After a Dispiriting Campaign
description: With voters in a sour and surly mood after a campaign season many found dispiriting, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York appeared poised to win re-election, although probably not with the sweeping mandate he had once hoped for, and Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut remained locked in a tight struggle with his Republican rival.

title: Election 2014: Live Coverage
description: Our politics dashboard provides up-to-the-minute updates on the aftermath of the midterm races from our correspondents across the country.

title: 1889: Witchcraft in Michigan
description: HOLLAND  The little village of Graafschap, in Allegan county, is known as an industrious, quiet and religious place, but the silliest superstition of ancient times troubles them much at present. Lately several cases of severe and stubborn sickness have been attributed to some unknown witch, and for that reason pillows and feather beds were opened and carefully examined. The bunches formed inside are called crowns, wreaths, chickens or any imaginable thing. A case a few days ago of this description happened. A hot fire was made, and the crowns and such put in the fire, but would not burn; even the feathers would not be scorched; but while wondering about it, they had suddenly disappeared. The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 05, 1889

title: 1964: U.S. Vote Pleases Europeans
description: LONDON  It was no surprise in Europe today [Nov. 4] that Lyndon B. Johnson had been elected president of the United States, but there was considerable relief at the results and the fact that the election hiatus is now over. There has not, in fact, been such complete and unconcealed partisanship among Europeans in an American election since the end of the war. In 1964 Europe had been almost as totally committed to Mr. Johnson as the American voters turned out to be. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 5, 1964

title: A 2016 Preamble: Opposition Research for Hillary Clinton
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton hasnt said whether she will run for president in 2016, but its never too early to dig up some dirt on her potential competitors.

title: What You Sign Up For When You Marry Into the Military
description: Through the lump in my throat, Ive just finished telling my friend that my husband, a lieutenant in the United States Navy, is leaving again in a few days. It will be his fourth deployment since we were married, the first since the birth of our two children.

title: Riding Wave of Discontent, G.O.P. Takes Senate
description: Resurgent Republicans took control of the Senate on Tuesday night, expanded their hold on the House, and defended some of the most closely contested governors races, in a repudiation of President Obama that will reorder the political map in his final years in office.

title: Voters Head To the Polls
description: As voting for midterm elections starts around the country, some voters get an early start.

title: Your OkCupid Self
description: Who are you when youre online dating? Are you your real self, stripped of the pretenses you put on when youre out in the world? Do you take those pretenses with you when you log on? Or do you perhaps construct new ones, unique to the medium? And what does the self you bring to a dating site say not just about you, but about the site itself?

title: Gigya, a Social Log-In Manager, Raises $35 Million
description: Gigya was once a creature of an earlier social media age, starting in 2006 as a way to assist people with pages on the ill-fated social network Myspace.

title: Millstein Hires Sovereign Restructuring Adviser
description: Millstein & Company, the financial advisory firm founded by James E. Millstein, has hired Mark Walker, a former banker with Rothschild.

title: As a Writer, What Influences You Other Than Books?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Thomas Mallon and James Parker discuss what influences their work  aside from other books.

title: Lessons for a Grandfather, Unexpectedly Deployed to Afghanistan
description: You know you won a free round-trip ticket to Afghanistan? a perpetually busy chief master sergeant asked me one warm winter evening. We were at the gym at Robins Air Force Base in Houston County, Ga., after a day spent serving on a panel of public affairs chiefs.

title: S.N.L. Memories and Getting-Some-Rest Dreams
description: Amy Poehlers memoirish book is titled Yes Please, as in Bring it on, but its tone is more No, Really, Make This Stop, as in Get me out of here.

title: All the Worlds a Gallery
description: No longer just for pop-music hopefuls, social media has become a way for big-name artists to prop up fresh talent.

title: A New App for Travel Meet-Ups
description: People, not places, make the trip, is the motto of Tripr, a new digital travel application that allows travelers to connect with others who plan to be in the same place at the same time.

title: Restaurant Review: Tuome in the East Village
description: Look inside the head of a bright young chef and youll see a beehive of swarming ideas, a few of them just hatched and others that buzzed in from somewhere else. It can take time to sort out which are borrowed and which have the sting of the new.

title: Challenge at Mission Peak: Finding a Place to Park
description: FREMONT, Calif.  At three miles long and 2,000 feet in elevation, the hike up Mission Peak is not for the faint of heart: The trail is dry and nearly bald, and climbing it can be painfully hot. The incline near the top is rocky and preposterously steep.

title: In London, Sadlers Wells Teams Up With English National Ballet
description: The London theater Sadlers Wells announced on Tuesday that the English National Ballet would become its first associate ballet company, starting in March.

title: 3 Million Frozen Princess Dresses Sold, Disney Says
description: LOS ANGELES  More than three million Frozen role-play dresses have been sold this year in North America, reflecting the continuing cultural and financial effect of a movie that is now 12 months old.

title: Early Voting: Its Not Just for Democrats
description: When Democrats in Colorado passed a series of election changes in 2013, permitting mail-in balloting and same-day registration, it was over the furious objection of Republicans. This happens every time a state tries to make voting easier, or expand the electorate, because Republicans are convinced that new voters are biased against them.

title: New-Music Festival to Focus on Young Composers
description: Organizations that help young composers further their careers are plentiful these days, but the MATA Festival  one of those organizations, and also one of New Yorks more enterprising new-music festivals  is taking its support a step further. On Nov. 17, MATA will present its first MATA Jr. Festival at the DiMenna Center for Classical Music. The spotlight will be on works by pre-college composers, performed by Face the Music, the Kaufman Centers student new-music ensemble.

title: Republicans Have Already Won a Governors Race Today, in Guam
description: Even before noon on the East Coast, Republicans notched a governors race victory on Tuesday: in Guam, where Gov. Eddie Calvo was re-elected in a landslide. In the nearby Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, Gov. Eloy Inos, also a Republican incumbent, leads with most of the votes counted but is likely to face a runoff.

title: Tracey Emin on Middle Age and the Cuteness of Andy Warhols Cats
description: In July, the German collector Count Christian Duerckheim purchased Tracey Emins My Bed  the artists notorious Turner Prize-nominated work from the late 90s, a bed on which she had slept and left bodily secretions and discarded junk  at auction for a record $3.7 million. Somewhat more cautious buyers will have the occasion to bid on a few of the iconic British artists more modest originals  several monoprints and neon installations with estimates between $10,000 and $150,000  when Emin curates a sale for the online auction house Paddle8, which launches today. Called From the Cute to the Powerful, the auction will also feature an Emin-picked selection of works from artists such as Tim Noble and Sue Webster, Cindy Sherman and Jenny Holzer; 100 percent of the proceeds from two of Emins pieces in the show will go to support the Serpentine Trust.

title: The Fashion Fund and House of DVF Reveal Fashion Truths
description: A scene in Episode 1 of the Ovation series The Fashion Fund  the documentary that has its season premiere on Wednesday and offers a behind-the-scenes look at the selection of the winner of the 2014 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund, a.k.a. the big kahuna prize for an emerging American designer  is as revealing of current fashion-world reality as anything Ive seen.

title: What Were Watching on Election Day
description: In addition to seeing who will control the Senate, here are four specific votes well be watching:

title: Colts Blessed by All Kinds of Fortune
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Why was Reggie Wayne crying during the national anthem before his Indianapolis Colts turned MetLife Stadium into a fourth-quarter ghost town of gray empty seats Monday night in a not-as-close-as-it-sounds 40-24 demolition of the Giants?

title: An Apple-Like Valuation for a Chinese Rival
description: The Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi is a hit with customers, but its upward valuation spiral seems hard to justify. A new funding round could value the group at as much as $50 billion, according to Bloomberg News. That suggests investors are valuing it the same way they do Apple. Xiaomi is growing fast, but it lacks its American rivals dominance or innovation.

title: S.E.C. Raises Barrier to Disclosure of Information
description: The Freedom of Information Act is supposed to make it easier for journalists and ordinary Americans to obtain documents and other information about how the federal government conducts its business. As such, it is one of the bedrocks of our democracy. It is often described as the law that keeps citizens in the know about their government, boasts FOIA.gov, a website dedicated to the law.

title: Health Care at the Bagel Shop
description: Reaching businesses like Bagel Grove in Utica, N.Y., is a priority for the new health care law. But as the cost of coverage has climbed, companies are struggling to afford coverage for employees.

title: Today in Small Business: Minimum Wage and Marijuana
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Voters Head To the Polls
description: As voting for midterm elections starts around the country, some voters get an early start.

title: Providing Health Insurance Still a Struggle for Small Business
description: Brian Adams, who sells fireplaces in Indianapolis, is like many of the nations small-business owners. As the cost of providing health benefits has climbed, he has struggled to afford coverage for his employees  a problem the new health care law was designed, in part, to address.

title: A House Race to Remember That Staten Islanders Would Sooner Forget
description: The nadir did not arrive in January, Staten Islanders say, when their congressman threatened to throw a reporter off a Capitol balcony  nor in April, when the 20-count federal indictment was handed up.

title: Musical America Award Goes to Peter Sellars
description: Musical America, the venerable classical music publication, has announced its annual awards, which this year include a departure: the top award, usually musician of the year, has been renamed artist of the year. The winner, the publication announced on Tuesday, is Peter Sellars, the iconoclastic director whose biggest success this season was his inventive staging of Bachs St. Matthew Passion with the Berlin Philharmonic at the Park Avenue Armory, as part of Lincoln Centers White Light Festival. But he is also known for his productions of works by John Adams, Mozart and Handel.

title: Election 2014: The Vote You Save May Be Your Own
description: Millions of Americans will head to the polls today, and many of them will confront some of the most serious obstacles to voting in decades, including strict new photo ID requirements in several states. No voter, however, should be turned away without the opportunity to cast at least a provisional ballot. In an environment in which partisan legislatures aggressively curtail voting rights, the protections provisional ballots offer are especially vital.

title: Elisa Monte to Retire From Dance Company
description: Elisa Monte, the veteran choreographer, will retire as artistic director of Elisa Monte Dance, the noted modern dance company she started in 1981. Ms. Monte, 68, announced her retirement on Monday night, following a private tour of the Fashion Institute of Technologys Dance & Fashion exhibition. Tiffany Rea-Fisher, the companys associate artistic director, will take over from Ms. Monte in 2016.

title: Rings Around the City
description: Dough, fried. It is a humble snack, fuel for late-night stakeouts, comfort after a day toiling at the nuclear power plant.

title: He Wants His Name in Lights but Could Use an Editor
description: Hey, Broadway! Kyle Sugarman has a play called Spacebar that hed like you to read. If youve been checking your mail, you may have noticed that hes sent it three times  all several hundred pages of it.

title: A Documentary Follows the Curious Career of Maurizio Cattelan
description: The artist Maurizio Cattelan  who famously retired at the age of 51 in 2011, after a highly unconventional retrospective in which he dangled his works in the rotunda of the Guggenheim museum in New York  seems to be having a post-career livelier than his career.

title: Off to the Stars, With Grief, Dread and Regret
description: Like the great space epics of the past, Christopher Nolans Interstellar distills terrestrial anxieties and aspirations into a potent pop parable, a mirror of the mood down here on Earth. Stanley Kubricks 2001: A Space Odyssey blended the technological awe of the Apollo era with the trippy hopes and terrors of the Age of Aquarius. George Lucass first Star Wars trilogy, set not in the speculative future but in the imaginary past, answered the malaise of the 70s with swashbuckling nostalgia. Interstellar, full of visual dazzle, thematic ambition, geek bait and corn (including the literal kind), is a sweeping, futuristic adventure driven by grief, dread and regret.

title: Plan for a Times Square in Mumbai Stirs Criticism
description: MUMBAI  It was a bold, if somewhat mystifying, proposal.

title: For Republicans, What Counts as Victory?
description: You wont get formal midterm predictions from me today  thats why we have Mr. Silvers difference engine and Mr. Leonhardts Skynet, surely but I do have a couple of thoughts on the debate over what the midterm results mean for the Republican Partys political position overall. Over the weekend, as the Republican advantage seemed to solidify, a number of writers made the point that the G.O.P.could probably win the Senate without making the kind of inroads that would bode well for their chances of winning the White House (or even keeping the Senate) two years hence. This years midterm map is unusually unrepresentative of the country as a whole, the Washington Posts Patrick Egan noted, and so tonights outcomes dont tell us that much about the future; the G.O.P. is winning more on second-term disillusionment than on any positive vision or agenda, two the partys pollsters argued in the same newspaper, and isnt showing any signs of expanding the electoral map into blue territory.The upshot (if you will) of these patterns, my colleague Nate Cohn suggested, is that Republicans are poised to retake the Senate without winning over many voters who supported President Obama in 2012  an outcome that would indicate theyve made little progress in attracting voters they would need to take back the White House.

title: Cleveland Orchestra Director to Retire Next Year
description: Gary Hanson, the executive director of the Cleveland Orchestra, announced Tuesday that he would retire next October  a few years shy of the orchestras 2017-18 centennial season.

title: The Secret About Undecided Voters: Theyre Predictable
description: Candidates for Congress have aired more than two million television ads this year. They will have spent more than $3.6 billion. And yet there is still a small set of registered voters who are unsure about their votes in races that could pivot control of the Senate.

title: Letter From the Editor: A New Way to Follow Elections
description: Were going to try a new way to follow election results tonight, and were excited about it.

title: Exit Polls: Why They So Often Mislead
description: Did you think John Kerry was poised to win the presidency? That Scott Walker was close to losing the 2012 governors recall election in Wisconsin? Do you believe that the black share of the electorate in North Carolina dropped to 23 percent in 2012, from 26 percent in 2004?

title: Why Did I Vote That Way? Dont Ask Me
description: When the returns from tonights election start to become clear, the debate is likely to turn, as it so often does, to why the American people voted the way they did.

title: Election Will Leave Medicaid Policies Largely Unchanged
description: This article has been updated with election results.

title: Smartphones and Social Media Play Larger Role in This Election
description: More Americans have been following this election cycle glued to their phones and social media than ever before, according to a new report from Pew Research Center.

title: Republicans Hold Advantage in Run for Senate
description: Its been a long and chaotic election cycle, but, in the end, were about where we thought we would be: The Republicans have a 75 percent chance to win control of the Senate, according to the final run of Leo, The Upshots Senate model. But both a Republican landslide and a narrow Democratic majority remain possibilities.

title: Absurdism, Scrubbed and Domesticated
description: Isabel Sanchez takes an odd approach to housecleaning. In The Maids The Maids, at Abrons Arts Center, she bops onto the stage in a frilly apron, feather dusters and dishwashing gloves at the ready. Then she starts spilling corn chips and cheese curls all over the floor. She puts a raw egg between her teeth and crunches it. Shell and yolk and albumen drip from her lips.

title: Are European Museum Passes Worth the Money?
description: Visit the tourism office in any major city in Europe and youll most likely find an offer to purchase a museum pass  a card that gives the holder entry to multiple local museums. Some passes include additional perks  priority entrance, discounts at monuments, free use of public transportation  but the high prices have always left me skeptical: These passes are marketed to tourists as a way to save money, but how many museums do you need to visit before youve recouped the cost of the pass? And were all of those museums already on your itinerary? To determine if the passes really are bargains, I examined the offers in four museum-dense European cities popular with travelers: Amsterdam, Madrid, Florence and Paris. So whats the verdict on these supposed money-savers? It depends on the city  and on the travelers interests, allotted time and stamina.

title: Recalling Anne Frank, as Icon and Human Being
description: Eva Schloss, a playmate of Anne Franks in Amsterdam whose mother later married Annes father, recalls an 11-year-old who hopscotched, shot marbles, gossiped and talked so much her friends nicknamed her Miss Quack Quack.

title: Watch Out for the Plaster Casts
description: Jonah Bokaer, the dancer and choreographer, knows how to make an entrance. When three of his pieces were performed recently at Lightbox, a small convertible space in Hells Kitchen, he did not appear until the second section. His head entered first. It probed into the performance area on top of a spine that was slowly arching backward toward the floor. He stayed bent for a long time.

title: At Tijuana Picnic, Mexican Food With an Asian Touch
description: Headliner

title: Why One Insurer Sees a Growing Market for Small-Business Health Insurance
description: In an article The Times has just published, Reed Abelson surveys how small businesses are reacting to the Affordable Care Act. She found that some businesses are dropping coverage, and most are avoiding the government-run health insurance exchanges set up for small businesses. But Ms. Abelson encountered one insurance company that hoped to do a brisk business in the small-group market next year.

title: Warner Bros. Begins Layoffs to Cut Costs
description: LOS ANGELES  Warner Bros. on Tuesday began layoffs that will ultimately eliminate about 1,000 jobs, or 12.5 percent of the studios total staff, as it tries to increase profitability in the face of weak domestic box-office sales and a challenged television business.

title: Awash in Campaign Cash, Cuomo Benefited From Big Donors and Loopholes
description: Even as he confronted a federal investigation and sagging poll numbers, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo always possessed one source of comfort: No matter the adversity he faced, he could pay for enough television advertising to try to wash his problems away.

title: Not Rescuing Our Kids Shouldnt Mean Letting Them Flounder
description: Say helicopter parenting and then picture the buzzing drone overhead flinging string cheese and geometry answers to the helpless below. Say no-rescue parenting and picture the lifeguard who is watching your child wrestle an octopus before looking away.

title: Student Crossword | Voting in the U.S.A.
description: Test your knowledge of voting in the United States by playing our crossword (PDF). You can find the answers here.

title: Election 2014: Only the Polarized Are Actually Polarized
description: According to the conventional wisdom, American politics and politicians are more polarized now than they have been since the Civil War, reflecting a growing chasm between Democrats and Republicans. But what if the conventional wisdom is wrong? Theres no question that politicians are more divided; just look at their voting records. But what if the polarization of politicians reflects a common mistake about Americans  a widely held but false belief that Democratic and Republican voters are more divided than they actually are?

title: Why the Time Is Now to Predict (Loudly) a Democratic Victory
description: Want to be a superstar political pundit? Heres my advice: Predict the Democrats to hold the Senate. Do it now, do it loudly and do it confidently.

title: Catalonia to Defy Court With Independence Straw Poll
description: MADRID  The regional government of Catalonia said Tuesday that it would go ahead with a straw poll on independence, scheduled for this Sunday, in seeming defiance of an order from Spains Constitutional Court to suspend the ballot.

title: French Political Scions Exchange Jabs in Twitter Feud
description: PARIS  Being a teenager is seldom easy, and all the more difficult, perhaps, if you are the son of a former president or first lady in the age of Twitter, and your every impolitic outburst or adolescent angst can play out in front of thousands in a single indiscreet click.

title: Protests Erupt in Kashmir After Army Shooting
description: NEW DELHI  Protests broke out in Indian-administered Kashmir on Tuesday, a day after Indian soldiers opened fire on a car that did not stop at a checkpoint, killing two people in the car and wounding another two, all civilians.

title: As Qaeda-Backed Group Makes Gains, Rift Grows Among Rebels in Syria
description: BAGHDAD  The Nusra Front, a Syrian rebel group affiliated with Al Qaeda, has been expanding its control in the northern province of Idlib, seizing territory from two Western-supported rebel organizations and potentially threatening a critical border crossing with Turkey, according to rebels and monitoring groups.

title: Rising Stars of Fashion Take a Bow
description: Paul Andrew wins top prize at CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund dinner.

title: Judge Declines to Block Ackman From Voting in Board Fight at Allergan
description: A federal judge on Tuesday declined to block the hedge fund billionaire William A. Ackman from voting his firms shares in a fight for control of the board of Allergan, the maker of Botox, potentially bolstering his effort to force the company into a sale to Valeant Pharmaceuticals International.

title: Icahns Publicly Traded Arm Is Stung by Energy Investments
description: Carl C. Icahn has profited from a string of recent bets on prominent companies like eBay, Netflix and Family Dollar. But the energy sector is giving the activist investor some trouble.

title: David Leonhardt Thinks That Even Football Is Political
description: David Leonhardt, the editor of The Upshot, joined WNYCs The Takeaway on Tuesday morning to preview the midterm elections and discuss his piece on the politics of playing football.

title: The Fabulous Beekman Boys Pop Up in the East Village
description: Brent Ridge and Josh Kilmer-Purcell, whom some may know from their television show The Fabulous Beekman Boys (currently in reruns on the Cooking Channel), or as winners of The Amazing Race two years ago, have opened a pop-up shop in the East Village. Mr. Ridge said he chose the location because it had a sense of sustainability, grit, strife and entrepreneurship that perfectly fits where our company is at the moment. Called The Beekman 1802 Holiday Gift Emporium, the pop-up is a mini-version of the couples flagship Beekman 1802 Mercantile, in their hometown of Sharon Springs, N.Y., with some of the same offerings. These include the Lump of Kohl soap ($15) made from the milk of goats on their farm, cheese cutters forged by their blacksmith ($28), linens made by their master weaver and autographed copies of their four books.

title: Ford, Nissan and Toyota Issue Recalls
description: Ford is recalling about 200,000 vehicles in five actions in North America for problems including airbags that might not deploy in a crash, possible fires and a steering defect that was not corrected in a previous recall, the automaker said on Tuesday. In all five recalls, Ford said it was aware of one accident, but no injuries.

title: Island-Hopping in the Caribbean With Carrie Gibson
description: Colonialism has left its mark on many aspects of Caribbean life. Among them: travel.

title: Creditors Keep Troubled Law Schools on Life Support
description: A recent debt restructuring at Thomas Jefferson School of Law shows that a law school may be worth absolutely nothing.

title: What Is the Future of Alex From Target?
description: The rise to Internet fame of the young man known as Alex From Target has focused attention on Target, on teenagers, and, of course, on Alex himself. Now, those who have followed his rise are considering which of these parties will actually benefit from it.

title: Joni Ernst Votes
description: Joni Ernst, the Republican candidate for Senate in Iowa, voted in Red Oak, Iowa, after a 24-hour tour of the state ended the morning of the 2014 midterm election.

title: Numbers Tell the Story: The A.F.C. North Is the N.F.L.'s Best Division
description: At the midway mark of the season, the A.F.C. North is the best division in football. By the end of the year, it may be viewed as one of the strongest divisions in N.F.L. history.

title: Adrian Peterson Agrees to Plea Deal in Child-Abuse Case
description: Minnesota Vikings running back Adrian Peterson agreed to a plea bargain Tuesday, reducing his felony child-abuse charges to a single charge of reckless assault, a misdemeanor that comes with a $4,000 fine and an order to perform community service.

title: Verizon Wireless Under Fire for Ad-Targeting Program
description: Google and Facebook are not the only companies tracking your online activities to customize ads. Verizon Wireless has recently come under fire from privacy advocates for running a similar program on its cellular network.

title: Voters Around the Nation on Election Day
description: Voters in Manchester, N.H., Manhattan Beach, Calif., Overland Park, Kan., Greensboro, N.C., Arlington, Va., and Miami spoke out from polling stations on Tuesday.

title: Supreme Court Weighs Air Marshals Firing in Whistle-Blower Case
description: WASHINGTON  A majority of the justices seemed ready to side with a fired air marshal on Tuesday in a Supreme Court argument over whether he was covered by a federal law protecting whistle-blowers.

title: An Eclectic Evening to Start a Season
description: In the musical world, we still have work to do to broaden and update our canon, perhaps to go beyond the very idea of a canon at all. But even beyond the major orchestras and star soloists, plenty of performers have been engaged in such an effort for years.

title: A California Location for Cycling House Camps
description: The Cycling House has added Solvang, Calif., to its staple of winter training camps for the 2014-15 winter season.

title: Google Glass May Have a Blind Spot, Study Says
description: Is that an email in your eyes, or are you about to get hit by a truck?

title: Pixie Remorse and Remedies
description: It turns out not everyone is Halle Berry.

title: Voter Voice: New Hampshire
description: Ann Halloran of Salem, N.H., believes voters need to think about whats happening on the national level as they cast ballots in the midterm election.

title: An Author Mines His Niche, One Usually Filled With Song
description: David Ritz was deep in his element one recent afternoon, taking the measure of a complex life and its cherished music at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem. The occasion was a memorial service for the jazz singer Jimmy Scott, whose widow, Jeanie, sat beside Mr. Ritzs wife, Roberta, in a curved wooden pew. Draped in a black Issey Miyake tunic  his version of somber finery  Mr. Ritz,the author of Faith in Time: The Jazz Life of Jimmy Scott, sat appreciatively before a succession of songs and spoken tributes, sneaking odd glances at his own prepared remarks on an iPad screen.

title: Playing With Those Poolside Toys, Jealousy and Guilt
description: Pool (no water), which had a brief run at PS122, beginning in May 2012, has reopened off Broadway at the Barrow Street Theater, 27 Barrow Street, at Seventh Avenue South, West Village; 212-868-4444, smarttix.com. Following are excerpts from Charles Isherwoods review, which appeared in The New York Times on May 15, 2012; the full text is online at nytimes.com/theater.

title: A Swan Song Season Begins on the Jersey Shore
description: Back in 2009 and 2010, when  Nicole Polizzi was getting flattened in a bar fight and arrested for disorderly conduct on Jersey Shore, she didnt look like the future star of one of televisions most comforting depictions of middle-class domesticity. But here she is, pregnant with her second child, learning to bake, living in her prospective mother-in-laws basement. Our little Snooki has grown up.

title: Jacolby Satterwhites Kinetic Mixed-Media Creations
description: The artists work is kaleidoscopic, weird  and totally genius.

title: Wheelies: The SEMA Van Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Pictures of the Day: the United States and Elsewhere
description: The United States and Elsewhere  Pictures of the Day

title: Seeking New Tools to Address a Wage Gap
description: What can be done about income inequality?

title: Offering Playwrights a Better Deal
description: Playwrights may deliver the essential ingredient for any theater production  the script  but they are often the only people on the artistic team who go unpaid during casting auditions and rehearsals for their shows, and they usually fend for themselves with health insurance, too. But one major Off Broadway theater company is changing that, aiming to offer a model for compensation after years of national debate about ways to help often struggling playwrights.

title: Todays Best Pictures
description: As chosen by our editors. (Besides election news!)

title: A Music Video From the Lagerfeld-Approved Rapper Theophilus London
description: I got misconstrued a lot, the rapper Theophilus London says of the reception to his 2011 debut, Timez Are Weird These Days. People thought I was just some fashion kid who wanted to rap, when honestly I hadnt even walked into a Chanel store until 2010. London was  and still is  first and foremost a musician, as his sophomore album, Vibes, out today, should prove: Its a fully manifested vision, recorded entirely in Palm Springs (his last was brought to life in a Stockholm studio). The difference this time was I could focus. Much less hot babes and much more old ladies in the desert, he says. I was celibate the entire time.

title: Election 2014: The Campaign in North Carolina Is Not About Nothing
description: Chapel Hill, N.C.  Over the last few weeks it has become fashionable to ridicule this election as a jumble of debates that dont resonate with the average American. The Washington Post deemed these midterms kind of  with apologies to Seinfeld  an election about nothing, and many other journalists have echoed the comparison. The joke is an old one: as the reigning clich had it, 2002 was the Seinfeld election  an election about nothing, Frank Rich wrote in these pages 12 years ago.

title: Japan on the Brink
description: When a nation is engaged in a real policy debate  the kind were not having in the United States, because Americas right wing knows what it knows, and never looks at evidence or admits mistakes  certain decisions take on significance that goes beyond their substantive importance, because they are symbols of the broader direction. So it is with Japans current plan to hike consumption taxes a second time. Not that this is a trivial decision on the substance; it would be a fairly big deal in any case. But right now it has become more  a sort of Rubicon for policy.

title: Nov. 4, 2014  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the United States, Bahrain, Kashmir and France.

title: Final Upshot Senate Forecast: Republicans at 75 Percent
description: After the odds hovered around 60 or 70 percent for the past several months, the chances that Republicans would take the Senate rose to 75 percent in this mornings forecast from Leo, the Upshots Senate forecasting model.

title: Four Centuries, One Compositional Voice
description: If youre looking for a concert experience totally without artifice, the Peoples Symphony Concerts at the Washington Irving High School auditorium in Manhattan fit the bill. Its not just the ticket price ($14) of these concerts, now in their centenary season in this airy, acoustically bright hall, that endears. The program tells you all you need to know and little more. Generic cough drops are offered in a little bowl by the door, but few are taken. On a recent night, coats were strewed just to the left of the stage, next to a floor fan pasted with a scrawled note reading broken.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 10 Waiver Wire Picks
description: So you made it through Week 9 without Aaron Rodgers, Brandon Marshall, Sammy Watkins, Jordy Nelson, Randall Cobb, Eddie Lacy and Matt Forte. Congratulations.

title: International Mensch Fund
description: The IMF has released an audit of its own response during the aftermath of the financial crisis, which concludes that it messed up by embracing fiscal austerity in 2010. It failed to understand that you need to differentiate between economies that borrow in someone elses currency and those that dont; it failed to appreciate that the negative effects of fiscal contraction would be much larger in a zero-lower-bound environment than historical patterns might suggest.

title: 2014 SEMA Show Opens in Las Vegas
description: The Specialty Equipment Market Associations annual trade show opened here on Tuesday, spread out over more than a million square feet of space at the Las Vegas Convention Center.

title: Families Receive Loved Ones Killed in Perus Dirty War
description: The International Red Cross recently delivered the bodies, which were exhumed last year and identified in Peru.

title: Gigi Jordan, Charged in Her Sons Death, Wages Publicity Blitz as She Awaits Verdict
description: Most murder defendants avoid making public statements after a trial starts, and that rule goes double once a jury begins its deliberations.

title: Sadness Amid the Laughter
description: When he finished shooting A Merry Friggin Christmas in spring 2013, Joel McHale was proud to have played a lead role in this holiday satire about a man who comes to terms with his estranged father, and to have acted alongside Robin Williams, one of his heroes.

title: Sesame Workshop Bullish on Childrens Magazines
description: At a time when the magazine business is struggling, Sesame Workshop is making the case that the demand for magazines for young readers is still strong.

title: Voters at the Polls
description: Control of the Senate is at stake as voting in the midterm elections takes place around the country.

title: Joni Ernst Wins Iowa Senate Seat for Republicans
description: Joni Ernst, a dogged campaigner who rose from a relatively unknown one-term state senator to a household name, eked out a victory over Representative Bruce Braley Tuesday night to win a Senate seat and become the first woman elected to Congress from Iowa.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Morgan Stanley to Get $1.3 Billion Benefit
description: While other banks are reporting big additional legal costs, Morgan Stanley said Tuesday that it would get a one-time lift of $1.3 billion as a result of a change in the structure of its Morgan Stanley Smith Barney operation.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Election Spending Is Changing, as Well as Expanding
description: The title of Most Expensive Midterm Election can obscure the fact that campaigns raise and spend money very differently.

title: How 10 New Yorkers Flaunted Their I Voted Stickers
description: New Yorkers who voted on Tuesday proudly and creatively showed off their I Voted stickers. Heres a selection of Instagram photos from various New York City neighborhoods, worn by voters and even tolerated by a few pets.

title: Election 2014: Should Black Voters Keep Their Faith in Obama?
description: MY trainer, a 31-year-old black man, doesnt vote. It doesnt make any difference which party wins, he says. He doesnt believe that President Obama is really in charge.

title: Framing the Viewers, and the Viewed
description: The explicit subject of Frederick Wisemans magnificent documentary National Gallery is the stately museum that rises at the northern end of Trafalgar Square in London. Like most of Mr. Wisemans work, the movie is at once specific and general, fascinating in its pinpoint detail and transporting in its cosmic reach. Its about art and process, money and mystery, and all the many, many people gazing and gawping and, at times, lining up to see a blockbuster show. That National Gallery is also about movies is surely a given.

title: SoundCloud Signs Licensing Deal With Warner Music
description: SoundCloud, a streaming music service that attracts 175 million users each month, has moved one step closer to being legit in the eyes of the music industry.

title: China Weighing More Emphasis on Traditional Culture in Textbooks
description: Education officials in China are considering changes to elementary and middle school textbooks that would expand the study of Chinese philosophy and literature, a shift that some education experts say is connected to recent efforts by the government to emphasize Chinas cultural heritage.

title: A Change in Sales Policy Weighs on Herbalife
description: Herbalife, the nutritional supplements company, is feeling the pressure of being under Wall Streets microscope.

title: Investors Pulled $27.5 Billion From Flagship Pimco Fund
description: The asset drain at Pimco continues.

title: Researchers Seek Crucial Tool: A Fast, Finger-Prick Ebola Test
description: Searching for a new way to attack Ebola, companies and academic researchers are now racing to develop faster and easier tests for determining whether someone has the disease.

title: Nevada Could Elect First Openly Transgender State Legislator, a Republican
description: Lauren Scott, the Republican nominee in Nevadas 30th Assembly district, stands a chance of winning today and becoming the first openly transgender person elected to and seated in a state legislature.

title: Oil Continues to Plummet to 4-Year Lows as Investors Wager on OPEC Price War
description: HOUSTON  Oil prices plunged for a second consecutive day on Tuesday as commodity traders appeared convinced that a move by Saudi Arabia to cut its oil price for the United States will presage a price war by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Tribe by Theophilus London
description: The video premiere of Tribe by Theophilus London, featuring Jesse Boykins III.

title: Colombians Shed International Pariah Status
description: Traveling While Colombian is about to get significantly easier.

title: A Whisky Campaign for Those Who Want to Drink Like Don Draper
description: A BRAND of Scotch whisky that was advertised during the Mad Men years in the trade publication Advertising Age is reviving a product from the era. The goal is to capitalize on renewed interest in Scotch and other brown spirits that is attributable partly to  yes, the popularity of Mad Men.

title: Stuart Siegel
description: Mr. Siegel, 59, is the president of the recently established New York City brokerage office of Engel & Vlkers, a real estate company based in Hamburg, Germany, with around 600 offices in 38 countries. Before starting Engel & Vlkers New York in May, Mr. Siegel was a founder and principal of Ore Hill Advisors, and he served as the president and chief executive of Sothebys International Realty from 1991 to 2006.

title: Judge Denies Motion to Dismiss Lawsuit Over Anti-Semitic Bullying in a New York School District
description: In a strongly worded ruling, a federal judge has denied a motion by an upstate New York school district to dismiss a lawsuit by the families of several Jewish children who had claimed they were victims of pervasive anti-Semitic harassment.

title: Election 2014: Ill-Concealed Prejudice
description: Austin, Tex.  On the face of it, requesting identification in order to vote does not seem like an impediment to democracy. But concealed handgun licenses  one of seven accepted forms of government-issued photo identification under Texass strict voter ID law  tell a different story.

title: Recent Commercial Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Time Is Running Out for a Grand Central Bookstore
description: For 15 years, employees of Posman Books in Grand Central Terminal have perfected their response to six magic words: I have a train to catch.

title: Place For High Living
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  I dont believe I have ever come right out and said that a theme was complete and utter gibberish, but today I get to do just that.

title: Exit Polls
description: How Americans voted in the House and Senate elections, based on exit polls conducted by Edison Research.

title: The Presidents Party Will Probably Lose SeatsThats Often How It Goes
description: Assuming the polls are right, tonight the Democrats will lose the Senate and lose ground in the House. Tomorrow some pundits will beat up on the president, whos unpopular, for damaging his partys chances; others will beat up on the Democratic candidates who failed to defend his policies, becoming almost indistinguishable from their Republican opponents. There may be something to both lines of argument, but its also the case that midterm elections are, historically speaking, bad for the presidents party.

title: Ukraine: President Orders Forces Bolstered in the Separatist East
description: President Petro O. Poroshenko has ordered the military to send reinforcements to Ukraines east. The order came in response to elections held over the weekend in rebel-controlled areas, which Ukraine, the European Union and the United States say violated a peace agreement, and also after an increase in rebel military activity in recent days. Mr. Poroshenko, speaking during a meeting of his national security council, also asked Parliament to repeal a law granting special status to the separatist regions and said controls at checkpoints into and out of those areas would be stiffened.

title: Mitch McConnell Wins 6th Term in U.S. Senate
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Mitch McConnell, the taciturn leader of the Senate Republicans who overcame childhood polio and decades of political conflagrations to become the longest-serving senator in Kentuckys history, cruised to re-election Tuesday.  With his party winning control of the Senate on the same night, he fulfilled his decades-long dream of becoming majority leader.

title: A Recent Surge of Leveraged Loans Rattles Regulators
description: As regulators hunt for the next financial bubble, they are homing in on an obscure corner of Wall Street: the debt market where Tom Shannons company, a chain of flashy bowling alleys, recently borrowed nearly half a billion dollars.

title: G.M. Offers $25 Cards to Owners Who Get Ignition Switches Fixed
description: With more than a million defective small cars still on the road, General Motors said on Tuesday that it was adding an incentive for owners to have them fixed: $25 gift cards to one of seven retailers, like Applebees and Bass Pro Shops.

title: The Kentucky Pipe Dream, and How It Hurt Democrats
description: Democrats spent much of this year pouring attention and money into Kentucky, believing that Senator Mitch McConnell was vulnerable to defeat. That decision was almost certainly a strategic mistake  and not just in hindsight.

title: Kashmir Protests Follow Shootings
description: Protests broke out in Indian-administered Kashmir on Tuesday, a day after Indian soldiers fatally shot two people in a car that did not stop at a checkpoint. They and two others who were wounded were all civilians. Crowds of protesters in the main city, Srinagar, chanted anti-Indian slogans and threw stones at officials, and separatist organizations called for a strike on Wednesday. The Indian soldiers were on high alert after a huge  explosion on Sunday on the Pakistan side of the border that killed 50 people. Omar Abdullah, the chief minister of Jammu and Kashmir State, described the deaths as avoidable and discussed the matter with Indias defense minister, Arun Jaitley.

title: Amnesty International Says Israel Showed Callous Indifference in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  Amnesty International published a report early Wednesday accusing Israel of war crimes in its 50-day war with Hamas in the Gaza Strip this summer, saying its military showed callous indifference to civilians in airstrikes on homes that felled entire families.

title: Voters at the Polls
description: Control of the Senate is at stake as voting in the midterm elections takes place around the country.

title: Apple Issues Bonds in Euros for First Time
