These five specimens of reinvention deftly pop the bubbles of their own illusory worlds, drawing attention to the artifices of their norms and aiming to teach children to become not just book lovers but pint-size consumers of text. The best of these books, luckily, manage to find fresh magic in demystification, and to delight kids while spinning the heads of their grown-up companions.

title: Jim Aylesworths My Grandfathers Coat, and More
description: A really good childrens book and the ideal grandparent have something in common. Its a special kind of bonding, when you feel you just cant wait to visit time and again. A good book about a good grandparent should double the payoff. And in some cases, it does.

title: Rain Reign, by Ann M. Martin
description: Autism has come of age, rapidly growing into a matter of common knowledge. Who doesnt now know that this condition is framed by a wide spectrum, or that diagnosed cases continue to rise? With one in 68 children affected, tens of millions in the United States know someone, or of someone, on the spectrum. Those who dont can watch Sheldons autistic-like behaviors on CBSs The Big Bang Theory.

title: Money Talks? Tax Policy Could Bring a Bipartisan Deal
description: The list of issues where Republicans and Democrats might be able find common ground is not long, but on fiscal matters there could be some deal-making to be done.

title: First Draft Focus: Honoring a Civil War Hero
description: Civil War Hero Awarded the Medal of Honor at Last

title: John Rando in Talks to Direct King Kong on Broadway
description: The Tony Award-winning director John Rando, who earned critical acclaim last month for staging the Broadway revival of On the Town, is in advanced negotiations to direct the new musical King Kong that is aiming for Broadway, a spokesman for the Kong producer confirmed on Thursday. Mr. Rando is flying this weekend to Australia, where Kong was developed and had a tryout run last year, for several days of discussions with the producer about overhauling the show for New York.

title: Behind the Poster: Filler
description: Barry Hutchinson doesnt eat chicken feet. But as an artist and designer based in Jackson, Miss., he has a history with the distinctly Southern foodstuff.

title: Leaving the Monsters Behind
description: The sculptor Thomas Houseago was practically bouncing off the walls of the Metropolitan Museum of Art late last month as he toured some of the treasures on the first floor. He unleashed a torrent of praise  insane, unbelievable, crazy, weird, wicked  as he pinballed from an ancient Greek grave stele to a striking series of squatting Aztec and Maya figures.

title: An Oklahoma Courts Good Move on Abortion Rights
description: This weeks focus on the abortion-related ballot measures in Colorado and North Dakota (where personhood initiatives were emphatically defeated), and Tennessee (where a majority of voters weakened protection of reproductive rights) has obscured a notable Election Day development in a fourth state:Oklahoma.

title: In a Mothers Milk, Nutrients, and a Message, Too
description: Milk is not just food. The more closely scientists examine it, the more complexity they find.

title: Lyft Sues Former Executive, Saying He Stole Trade Secrets
description: The ride-hailing wars arent going away.

title: Boehner Says Obama Risks Burning Himself on Immigration
description: Speaker John A. Boehner, emboldened by Tuesdays election results, warned on Thursday that President Obama risked burning himself if he took unilateral action to reform the United States immigration system.

title: A Timepiece Dialed Back to the 30s
description: In this weekly series, the mens fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the artist Jay Riggio captures a timepiece from Shinola.

title: Sexual Harassment at Yale: Delicate Subject, High-Impact Investigation
description: Last weekend, Tamar Lewin wrote about a sexual harassment case at Yale University that had been unfolding for nearly five years without much public notice. The case centers around a former chief of cardiology who professed love for a young Italian researcher at the Yale School of Medicine.

title: Cafe Edison, a Broadway Haunt, Is Closing
description: Cafe Edison, the venerable domain of pastrami, borscht and blintzes that doubled as a downscale dining club for producers, stage managers, actors, ticket-takers, stagehands, musicians, and countless other creatures of old Broadway, will close at the end of the year, its manager said on Thursday.

title: Civil War Hero Awarded the Medal of Honor at Last
description: WASHINGTON  After more than 151 years, First Lt. Alonzo H. Cushing finally got his day at the White House, even if he could not enjoy it personally.

title: In Jerusalem Unrest, Signs of a Run-Over Intifada for the 21st Century
description: JERUSALEM  One cartoon circulating on social networks on Thursday depicted a car as the barrel of an automatic weapon, captioned in Arabic, Revolt and resist, even by your car. Another showed an odometer with the slogan, Oh, revolutionary, use more gasoline, so we can have Palestine back. A third simply had a vehicle in the red, white and green of the Palestinian flag hitting two men with Jewish stars on their black hats.

title: Readers Respond: On Election 2014
description: The midterm election of 2014 was a gleeful moment for many Republican readers. A lot like the World Series win by the San Francisco Giants last week, one said.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 10 Player Tiers
description: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

title: E.C.B. Threatened to End Funding Unless Ireland Took Bailout, Letters Show
description: LONDON  Newly released documents suggest that Ireland was pressured into a controversial 67.5 billion euro bailout that left taxpayers rescuing crippled banks, reigniting a fierce debate about the international aid that Dublin accepted after the financial crash.

title: Obama Honors Civil War Soldier
description: President Obama awarded the nations highest military honor to a Union soldier who was killed more than 150 years ago during the Battle of Gettysburg.

title: A Doctor-Parent Exchange Reveals a Dangerous Gap Between Fears and Facts on Ebola and Flu
description: Via Facebook, my old friend Jeff Kluger at Time Magazine drew my attention to a sobering Twitter item by David Stukus, an allergist and pediatrics professor in Columbus, Ohio:

title: In War Over Botox Maker Allergan, Technicalities Can Be Tricky
description: For those keeping score in the hostile battle for control over the Botox maker Allergan, the latest court ruling is a mixed bag.

title: In Faded Vacationland, Gamblings Promise Falls Short
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa.  In 2006, when plans were set to transform the crumbling Mount Airy Lodge here into a casino resort, the predictions about the onetime honeymooners getaway were as gaudy as its famous old heart-shaped bathtubs.

title: Jawbone Up3 Band Takes Tracking to the Extreme
description: Jawbone, the wearable activity tracker pioneer, will not be moved by the move toward smart watches.

title: Scratch Baths From the Recovery Regimen
description: In one respect, the horror film Jessabelle qualifies as unexpected. The credited screenwriter is the comedian Robert Ben Garant, a creator of Reno 911! In other regards, Jessabelle is depressingly rote. How are VHS tapes, voodoo and the specter lurking in a house connected? Your impatience for answers is likely to eclipse your trepidation.

title: David Redfern, British Photographer of Jazz and Pop, Dies at 78
description: David Redfern, whose photographs of Louis Armstrong, John Lennon, Frank Sinatra and others captured a half-century of popular music and formed the core of an extensive archive of musical images, died on Oct. 22 at his home in Uzs, France. He was 78.

title: Behind Closed Doors in Both Berlins
description: The Tower is a condensed version of a devastating German television mini-series about life in East Germany in the 1980s as experienced by a cultured family in suburban Dresden. Directed by Christian Schwochow, who grew up in Leipzig and East Berlin, this epic-scale story spans the last seven years before the demise of East German Communism. Its far from the first film to show how the Stasi, the East German secret police, infiltrated everyday life so thoroughly that no one could trust anyone, and how society was gripped by institutionalized paranoia.

title: Happiness Is a Warm Robot
description: Have the Walt Disney and Pixar animation studios become Walt Pixar, or maybe Wixar or Dixar? Its getting hard to tell these once-distinct siblings apart. Disneys latest animated feature, Big Hero 6, is a bright, visually sumptuous 3-D computer-animated feature that gives you a bit of an emotional workout. It doesnt have some of the familiar Disney markers: There are no eardrum-busting anthems or warbling critters, and it isnt a fairy tale, exactly, mostly because its about a boy. Its a Disney superhero movie with a story from a Marvel comic book, if one rendered with the wit and texture often associated with Pixar, which I guess makes it a Walt Pixar Marvel.

title: Modern Love | Into the Woods
description: Amy Butchers unexpected connection with Sam, a man she found living in a tent in the woods, gave her a lasting lesson in love.

title: Text to Text | Little Things Are Big and Students See Many Slights as Racial Microaggressions
First Editions, Second Thoughts
description: Next month, Christies will auction off 75 first editions to benefit PEN American Center. Each has been annotated by its respective author or artist.

title: On the Road to the One, Sometimes, a Rest Stop
description: I saved Sam after the park rangers third warning. A tornado was imminent, the ranger said, and we should seek shelter immediately. The Iowa state park where Sam was camping offered only a small brick outhouse, which I joked seemed the worst possible way to die, surrounded by daddy longlegs and cinder block walls on which teenagers had scribbled Weed Rules! in black Sharpie.

title: Israel Pledges to Restore Security at Religious Site
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel sought to reassure King Abdullah II of Jordan in a phone call on Thursday that Israel was committed to maintaining the status quo at a contested holy site in East Jerusalem, and that Israel would make every effort to restore calm there after weeks of escalating tensions, according to statements from both sides.

title: Matt Taibbi of Rolling Stone Spotlights a JPMorgan Whistle-Blower
description: Matt Taibbi, a prominent journalist who has written critically of Wall Street, is back in the pages of Rolling Stone magazine with a lengthy report on a JPMorgan Chase whistle-blower.

title: Warburg Institute Claims Victory After Court Ruling in Dispute With University of London
description: Both the Warburg Institute and the University of London, which houses it, claimed victory on Thursday after a ruling by Londons High Court that sought to clarify the universitys obligations to the institute, which has a world-renowned humanist library founded by Aby Warburg, a scion of the German banking family.

title: Continents in Conversation
description: WASHINGTON  On an impulse, in the early 1960s, a cultural attach for the State Department named Warren M. Robbins started buying African art, first one piece, then many, and filled his Washington house with sculptures and textiles. In 1964, he turned his basement into a mini-museum and opened it to visitors, partly as a gesture of cross-cultural outreach at a time of high racial tension in the capital and across the land.

title: Dear Teenagers: Come Babysit. Please.
description: Dear teenagers,

title: Reality, or Artful Dodge?
description: In the first shot of Actress, Robert Greenes elusive and intriguing new film, Brandy Burre stands at her kitchen sink, wearing a red dress that matches the symmetrically placed poinsettias on the windowsill. In a voice-over, she muses that she is a type A personality, which she defines as someone who breaks things.

title: New Loretta Lynn Project Includes New and Old Music
description: Loretta Lynn has not released an album of new material since Van Lear Rose, the 2004 record produced by Jack White, which won the country music album of the year Grammy. But it turns out that the 82-year old singer has been recording new material with her daughter, Patsy L. Russell, and John Carter Cash, Johnny Cashs son, for an expansive project that will include newly composed songs, and will also revisit the Appalachian folk songs and gospel tunes that Ms. Lynn heard during her childhood.

title: Recombining Identities to Define a Self
description: Panaibra Gabriel Canda begins his Time and Spaces: The Marrabenta Solos simply, by introducing himself. But introducing himself turns out to be not so simple. As a citizen of Mozambique, born in 1975, the year that nation achieved independence from Portugal, he is or has been, like his country, Portuguese, African, Communist, democratic. Combining and recombining these adjectives of identity, he keeps stopping and restarting  comically, affectingly  as he struggles to define himself.

title: The Glow Coming to Madison Square
description: Public art projects in Madison Square Park  the urban oasis between Madison and Fifth Avenues from 23rd to 26th Streets  have been beautiful, bemusing and sometimes even a tad creepy. One of the most outrageous took place in 2009, when 31 slightly different sculptures of a naked man dotted the parks grounds, were perched along rooftops on neighboring buildings and scattered around the sidewalks of the Flatiron district. The figure, cast by the British sculptor  Antony Gormley from his own body, caused quite a stir. One passer-by called 911, having mistaken a sculpture perched on the ledge of the Empire State Building for a jumper.

title: 2014 SEMA Show Tracks Industry Trends
description: LAS VEGAS  The annual Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show is traditionally a good place to track trends and find the leading edge of new technology arriving in the automotive industry. The 2014 edition, which runs through Friday, is no exception.

title: Timeline: Israel, the Gaza Strip and Hamas
description: The recent fighting between Israel and Hamas, the Palestinian group in control of the Gaza Strip, is the latest chapter in six decades of conflict.

title: A Salem Cabinetmaker in Revolutionary Times
description: The 18th-century cabinetmaker Nathaniel Gould left inkblots in his battered gray notebooks as he recorded the luxurious mahogany output of his workshop in Salem, Mass. His listings of clients and fees, found seven years ago in forgotten boxes at the Massachusetts Historical Society in Boston, have enabled researchers to attribute his mostly unsigned antiques. Next weekend, about 20 of these pieces will go on view at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem in the exhibition In Plain Sight: Discovering the Furniture of Nathaniel Gould.

title: Flirting With Trouble
description: My girlfriend maintains relationships with her former boyfriends. She drove 90 minutes through the pouring rain to counsel one (who dumped her last year) when he broke it off with his new girlfriend. She goes hiking and biking with them. And she tells me how other men flirt with her  though she never responds that shes in a committed relationship. Is it possessive of me to expect her to make clear that shes not available? Her line of demarcation seems to be shes only sleeping with me.

title: Chris Martin
description: Chris Martins first solo show at Anton Kern feels like a breakthrough, although hes been painting for decades. Big, glittering and ethereal, the canvases were made upstate last summer, and they have the sun-drenched, baked-on look of the desert, a frequent touchstone in Mr. Martins work. Many include a shimmery dusting of glitter, and not just any glitter: the holographic kind used by showgirls in Las Vegas, whose living depends on transfixing their audience.

title: Daniel Gordon: Screen Selections and Still Lifes
description: In a new group of large-scale still lifes that may be his best works yet, the photographer-sculptor Daniel Gordon hops back and forth across the analog/digital divide with a combination of playful insouciance and dogged determination.

title: Wheelies: The Mazda Motorsports Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Tommy Hartung: The Bible
description: TOMMY HARTUNG

title: American Fighter Jets Carry Out Series of Airstrikes Against Qaeda Cell in Syria
description: BAGHDAD  American fighter jets carried out a series of airstrikes in northwestern Syria on Thursday that sought to kill leaders of a Qaeda militant cell that is plotting attacks on the West, American officials said.

title: Diva? Deconstructing Pop Images of Black Women
description: The term diva has come rather unmoored from its 19th-century origins invoking the divine talents of female opera singers. Now the label seemingly can apply to just about any outsize personality in any field of endeavor. Its gotten to the point where even the poor old Miser, on certain fraught occasions, has heard the term flung in his direction by certain members of his own household.

title: The Rap on Old Age: Not a Young Mans Game
description: A few days past my 79th birthday, I am sitting in a packed house of poets and their followers at the Nuyorican Poets Cafe in the East Village, nervously waiting to compete in a slam against people who are mostly decades younger.

title: In Private Equity, Individual Investors Take a Bigger Role
description: Wall Streets private equity firms are raising an increasing share of their capital from individual investors, according to a new report.

title: 2000 | When Election Night Became Election Month
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 39 years.

title: Jana Backs Dollar Thriftys Former Chief to Lead Hertz
description: Jana Partners has already disclosed that it is one of the biggest shareholders in Hertz Global Holdings. Now, its urging the rental car service to pick its preferred candidate for the companys chief executive spot.

title: PBS to Broadcast a Sixth Season of Downton Abbey
description: Any network would want more episodes of the most-watched show in its history, and PBS is getting that with the announcement on Thursday that it had secured a deal for a sixth season of Downton Abbey.

title: Grumpy Critics Earliest Christmas Ever
description: Why dont you just shut your mouth and not be cynical for once?

title: What Happened in Virginia? Democrats Didnt Show Up
description: Some weak Democratic performances in the midterm elections Tuesday are hard to explain. Virginia is not.

title: Who Needs a Beach When Youve Got This?
description: When I saw that the only way down the 300-foot cliff was a series of ropes and roots for handholds, I gasped. Below, a field of rocks was being battered by the Atlantic. I wistfully thought about earlier Caribbean vacations, when the main activity was sitting on a beach, lifting a pastel drink that complemented the startlingly aqua water. But after reminding myself I hadnt come to Dominica for lolling, I grabbed a rope and began the climb down, backward, to reach a place called Wavine Cyrique, which Id been told was one of the best sights on the island.

title: Marquee Works Amid Buried Treasure
description: For a little taste of May in November, head to the Park Avenue Armory for the annual Print Fair of the International Fine Print Dealers Association. Now in its 23rd year, the fair, which opened on Wednesday night, continues to court veteran print collectors with Drers and Goyas and lure entry-level contemporary collectors with editions from brand-name artists.

title: New Donor Generation Stimulates U.S. Giving
description: When the Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg gave the federal Centers for Disease Control foundation $25 million to help combat the Ebola crisis last month, it served as a public service announcement of sorts.

title: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Syria, Belgium, Turkey and Afghanistan.

title: Just Cant Trust Those Americans
description: The island is interesting for its flora and fauna. That line is so bland it sounds like an enunciation exercise for English-language students, or, possibly, terrorist code for an imminent attack. Actually, as pronounced by the actor Bill Nighy, the words are deliciously rich in irony and elliptical portent.

title: Romania Hunger Strike Prompts Inquiry Into Dissidents Death
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  Andrei Ursu celebrated by eating a banana.

title: Atul Gawandes Being Mortal
description: It began with a tingle in the surgeons fingers and a pain in his neck. A couple of years later, he learned he had a tumor inside his spinal cord. That was when the difficult choices began. Should he have it removed right away in a risky operation, as his doctor recommended? Or should he take time to consider this question: At what point would the expanding tumor cause debility bad enough to justify the risk of greater debility or even death in trying to fight it?

title: Naomi Kleins This Changes Everything
description: Every inhabitant of this planet must contemplate the day when this planet may no longer be habitable. Thus spoke President Kennedy in a 1961 address to the United Nations. The threat he warned of was not climate chaos  barely a blip on anybodys radar at the time  but the hydrogen bomb. The nuclear threat had a volatile urgency and visual clarity that the sprawling, hydra-headed menace of todays climate calamity cannot match. How can we rouse citizens and governments to act for concerted change? Will it take, as Naomi Klein insists, nothing less than a Marshall Plan for Earth?

title: Empire of Sin, by Gary Krist
description: When Tom Andersons saloon opened in 1901, at the entrance to the recently designated sin district known as Storyville on the edge of New Orleanss French Quarter, people from all over town came to marvel at its opulence. Its cherrywood bar stretched half a block and was lit by a hundred electric lights. With Andersons encouragement, high-class brothels were soon flourishing down Basin Street. Josie Arlington, his business partner, had a four-story Victorian mansion with a domed cupola, mirrored parlor and Oriental statues. The exotic, mixed-race Lulu White built a brick palace that specialized in interracial sex and featured the jazz pioneer Jelly Roll Morton at the piano. Another octoroon (the appellation given to people considered to be one-eighth black), Willie V. Piazza, passed herself off as a countess and sported both a monocle and a diamond choker. Anderson, whose civic spirit earned him the title the Mayor of Storyville, published a Blue Book that contained photos and descriptions of the areas better prostitutes, annotated with symbols (w for white, c for colored, J for Jewish and oct. for octoroon). It was all a vivid expression of the citys tolerance and diversity.

title: Nov. 6, 2014  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Syria, Belgium, United Arab Emirates and Turkey.

title: At Home in Exile and The Pious Ones
description: Jews who have made their scholarly reputations studying other peoples and communities sometimes return, in the autumn of their careers, to studying their own. Simon Schama, best known as a European historian and art critic (though he did write an early book on the Rothschilds), recently produced a high-profile BBC series that became a book entitled The Story of the Jews. Now Alan Wolfe, a sociologist and political scientist highly regarded for his work on American democracy and Christian evangelicals, has published At Home in Exile: Why Diaspora Is Good for the Jews.

title: The Warhol Collaborator Billy Name on Andy, Photography and the Afterlife
description: Starting next week, Milk Gallery will host a photography exhibition celebrating the iconic works of Billy Name, the multitalented in-house archivist at Warhols Factory during the better part of the 60s. The show, titled Billy Name: The Silver Age, will coincide with next months release of a book bearing the same title and promises to feature numerous superstars who frequented the East 47th Street studio, which Name famously draped in tin foil and silver spray paint  much to Warhols delight.

title: Living Wills Still Alive for Regulators
description: Mayra Rodrguez Valladares is managing principal at MRV Associates, a New York based capital markets and financial regulatory consulting and training firm. On Twitter, she is @MRVAssociates.

title: Netflix Acquires Rights to Lemony Snicket Books
description: The streaming service Netflix continued its ambitious expansion into original programming with the acquisition of the rights to the popular childrens books A Series of Unfortunate Events by Lemony Snicket, the pen name of the American writer Daniel Handler.

title: Midterm Turnout Lowest Since 1942
description: The midterm elections on Tuesday generated a lot of buzz, but they did not draw a lot of voters.

title: When a Donation Steers Off Course
description: When he donated $500,000 in 2005, the country singer Garth Brooks never signed an agreement with Integris Canadian Valley Hospital in his hometown, Yukon, Okla.

title: The Economist Plans Espresso, a Daily News Roundup for Mobile Readers
description: The Economist has built its success by being the weekly magazine that succinctly summarizes the news of the world. Now, as it aims for mobile readers, the magazine is trimming its prose even more.

title: Cry of Protest From MetLife Signals Right Direction for Regulators
description: As of the middle of this year, the value of MetLifes bond portfolio was $214 billion, according to Bloomberg.

title: Bank of America Sets Aside $400 Million More for Currency Inquiry
description: Bank of America is nearing a deal with federal regulators to settle an investigation into the banks suspected manipulation of the currency market, the latest sign that Wall Street is bracing for another crackdown on its misbehavior.

title: Interviewers Dearest Subject
description: There are two stereotypical ways of becoming an older woman, Lynn Barber says in A Curious Career, her terrific new memoir.

title: Russian Troupe Poised for a Global Stage
description: When we think about Russian ballet, our minds inevitably drift to two companies, the Bolshoi and the Mariinsky. They represent a kind of yin and yang of Russian aesthetics, the cold elegance of St. Petersburg reflected in the extraordinary refinement of the Mariinsky ballerinas, the dynamism and bluster of Moscow in the large-scale dancing of the Bolshoi.

title: Why Migraines Deserve More Attention
description: When Susanna Styrons daughter, Emma, was 14, she began to have migraines. Emma would retreat to a dark room and tell her mother to leave her alone. Ms. Styron didnt know how to react, much less get her daughter the treatment she needed. I couldnt touch her or talk to her, Ms. Styron recalled to Op-Talk. I was so alone, and so in the dark. It would have made such a difference to know that people out there are in the same position, to know who to ask for help.

title: Rudolph Valentino in The Sheik
description: 93 YEARS AGO

title: Details on Obamas Ebola Funding Request
description: When President Obama meets with the congressional leadership on Friday, he will ask them to authorize $6.18 billion to fight Ebola, including upgrading a nationwide network of hospitals in the United States to treat patients with the disease, officials said Thursday.

title: Signs of the Evolutionary Step From Land to Sea
Tote That Barge, Snip That Book
description: Life upon the stage isnt very wicked, or even emotionally stirring, in the New York Philharmonics musically solid but dramatically pallid staging of Show Boat, the venerated 1927 musical by Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein II.

title: Martin Short to Replace Nathan Lane in Its Only a Play
description: The hit Broadway comedy Its Only a Play has a new star, a new home and a new closing date.

title: Foxcatcher | Anatomy of a Scene
description: Bennett Miller narrates a sequence from his film. featuring Steve Carell, Channing Tatum and Mark Ruffalo.

title: Assessing One Possible Change to the Affordable Care Act
description: In the wake of the resounding Republican victory in Tuesdays midterm elections, there has been much talk about bipartisan changes Republicans might want to make to the Affordable Care Act. On Wednesday, The Times reported on one possibility that could affect small businesses:

title: Court Upholds Marriage Bans in Four States
description: A federal appeals court in Ohio upheld on Thursday the right of four states to ban same-sex marriage, contradicting rulings by four similar courts and almost certainly sending the issue on a rapid trajectory to the Supreme Court.

title: Bennett Miller Narrates a Scene From Foxcatcher
description: Foxcatcher, directed by Bennett Miller, features Steve Carell in the role of the John E. du Pont, a millionaire with an interest in wrestling. Channing Tatum and Mark Ruffalo play alongside him as the wrestling brothers Mark Schultz and David Schultz. In this video, Mr. Miller discusses one particularly tense scene between the three characters. The film opens Nov. 14.

title: What the Doctor Ordered: Urban Farming
description: NEW HAVEN  At a dead-end street in a blighted section of this city, crumbling roofs of old factories, smokestacks and the Interstate 95 overpass loom overhead, casting long shadows on an October afternoon. Along one end of a field, children play soccer; on the other, men stand around motorcycles, sipping from beer cans.

title: Only One Sugar Plum Fairy a Year
description: There are no trade secrets or magic formulas revealed in Getting to The Nutcracker,'  Serene Meshel-Dillmans documentary about a dance school preparing for a big performance. The unsurprising way you get to The Nutcracker? Practice and hard work.

title: Navy SEALs Trade Secrecy for Swagger
description: A furious Navy command is asking whatever happened to the professionalism and tight secrecy of SEAL Team Six, the group of warriors who killed Osama bin Laden three years ago.

title: A Patron Gives, of Herself and Her Art
description: Agnes Gund didnt want to part with Willem de Koonings The Time of the Fire or Arshile Gorkys Housatonic Falls. She especially doesnt like to give up pieces from her collection made by artists who are her friends, which, it seems, just about every artist happens to be.

title: Crushed by a Giant, With No White Knight in Sight
description: THE INVISIBLE FRONT

title: Marco Rios: "S Is for Sincere, Formerly Formally F Is for Fake
description: Artists have been using the work of children as source material for decades: Paul Klee and the Art Brut and Cobra movements are a few examples. Marco Rios adds a twist, using his own childhood drawings, made between the ages of 3 and 5, as fodder for a new series of paintings.

title: Driver Who Sped Around Manhattan in 24 Minutes Is Convicted of Reckless Endangerment
description: A speedster who raced around Manhattan in a car and posted a video of the stunt online was convicted in absentia on Thursday of reckless endangerment.

title: Blockbusters and Theme Parks Fuel a Strong Year for Disney
description: LOS ANGELES  Disney ended its fiscal year on Thursday with $7.5 billion in profit, a hefty 22 percent increase from 2013, as hit movies and robust theme park attendance combined to offset higher sports-rights costs at ESPN.

title: A Directors Gift
description: 21 YEARS

title: Another Security Fix Is Made to JPMorgan Chases Race Website
description: The website for the JPMorgan Chase Corporate Challenge, which was hit by the same hackers that broke into the banks own network this summer, is slowly crawling back to health.

title: Humiliations on the Road From Boy to Man
description: Fugly!, the title of John Leguizamos wobbly, bittersweet new comedy, is a taunt hurled at his character, Jesse Sanchez, by neighborhood girls in the Bronx when, as a boy, he lowers his pants and exposes himself in a desperate bid for attention. That ridicule is the first of many humiliations and rejections by the opposite sex that Jesse endures in the film, written by Mr. Leguizamo and Kathy DeMarco and directed by Alfredo De Villa.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: The Soul of a Business, in a Single Photograph
description: Can you capture the essence of your small business in one photograph? If so, we want to hear from you.

title: Ex-Mayor Voted, and Now Hes on House Arrest
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Former Mayor Patrick D. Cannon, convicted in June of federal wire fraud in a bribery sting, will be on house arrest until he reports to federal prison after illegally voting in the midterm election.

title: Spielbergs Schindler Bequest
description: With blockbusters that include E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, Raiders of the Lost Ark and Saving Private Ryan, Steven Spielberg has garnered nearly every accolade Hollywood can bestow. It was 1993s Schindlers List, however, that gave the director the opportunity to create a very different legacy  something I was put on this earth to do, Mr. Spielberg said.

title: Hitting the Road to Keep a Holiday Illusion Alive
description: A MERRY FRIGGIN CHRISTMAS

title: Mortgage Insurance Paid Upfront
description: Private mortgage insurance is the bane of home buyers who cant put down at least 20 percent. The insurance protects the lender in the event that a borrower defaults on a property with little equity, but it also guarantees a considerably higher monthly mortgage payment.

title: When Yakuza Meets the Movies
description: In some filmmaking quarters, excess has turned into a short-circuiting shorthand: Make a movie nutty enough, and the eccentricity is expected to drown out considerations of quality.

title: Election Results Endanger Innovative Arkansas Medicaid Plan
description: UPDATED to include the latest number of people in the plan: to 211,000 from 205,000.

title: Democrats Pull $2 Million in Ads in Landrieu Runoff
description: Senator Mary L. Landrieus uphill climb to a runoff victory in Louisiana just got a little steeper.

title: Its a Plane! No, Its a Bird
description: Judy Irving injects just enough of herself into her Pelican Dreams to distinguish this sweet film from an episode of the PBS series Nature.

title: A Politician Slips, and an Ideal Impostor Steps In
description: VIVA LA LIBERT

title: First Draft Focus: Perrys Day in Court
description: Perry Faces Texas Court on Abuse of Power Charges

title: Love, Not Young, but New and Invigorating
description: A grumpy old man and a dotty old lady share a moment of late-life bliss in the geriatric romantic comedy Elsa & Fred. Because that fun couple are played by Christopher Plummer and Shirley MacLaine, the movies too-cute concept yields more rewards than you might reasonably expect.

title: The Wrong Question to Ask About Same-Sex Marriage
description: And just like that, same-sex marriage is very likely headed back to the Supreme Courts docket.

title: From the Lips of Desperate Poles in 44
description: An extraordinary but problematic effort in you-are-there archival work, Warsaw Uprising presents life on the ravaged ground in this Polish city in August 1944. Vivid restored wartime footage shows Poles huddled in air raid bunkers, slurping soup, flirting with soldiers, dodging sniper fire or going for a dip, all with a breathtaking sense of tangible detail.

title: Matters of the (Young) Heart
description: The pleasures of understatement abound in the assured drama The Way He Looks, a quiet, closely observed high school romance set in So Paulo, Brazil. Leonardo (Ghilherme Lobo), a shy classical music fan, is beginning to think more independently: He weighs joining an overseas transfer program, perhaps studying in the United States. His mother is skeptical; Leonardo is also blind, which the movie wisely doesnt belabor. Leonardos best friend, Giovana (an effortlessly naturalistic Tess Amorim), shares gossip with him and accompanies him to school.

title: Ill Give You the Sun, by Jandy Nelson
description: Ill Give You the Sun, the second novel by the talented Jandy Nelson, author of The Sky Is Everywhere, is told from the alternating perspectives of teenage fraternal twins, a boy and girl named Noah and Jude, each of them narrating from a different side of the accident that forever changed their lives. On one level, the book is about duality: As Jude and Noah wrangle over who will go to a prestigious art school and vie for attention and approbation and even, for a short time, the affections of the same boy, each narrator struggles to become whole, to become something other than merely half of one. Although Nelson portrays the relationship between the twins, their oneness, as comforting, more often it is claustrophobic  perhaps contributing to the books tense, almost breathless feel. One of their favorite games is to divide up the world between them, choosing and bartering the sun or the trees or the oceans. There is the sense that the world is simply not big enough for both of them.

title: Andrea Davis Pinkneys Red Pencil, and More
description: That the world can be a harsh place is unquestionable. For those of us who live in relative comfort, far from lands coping with brutal ethnic conflict and severe deprivation, the images of suffering are heart-wrenching, all the more when children are affected. With little or no firsthand experience of these distant places, how do we make sense of it? How do we help our children do so? For three North American writers, one answer is through literature.

title: Marie Lus Young Elites
description: It is 13 Juno, 1361, and Adelina Amouteru, a teenage girl from a place called Kenettra, is going to be burned at the stake for committing a murder. Several years earlier, we learn, a blood fever spread across this land. Most infected adults died. Children sometimes survived. Some of these children emerged without any sign of the infection; others, like Adelina, were marked and strangely scarred, their hair changing in color. These children, known as malfettos, are considered to have no social value and are persecuted by the government. Adelinas own father, who regarded her as worthless, was preparing to sell her off to a business associate as a mistress to complete a deal. She decided to escape rather than accept this fate, and in the process accidentally killed her father. It is this act that has brought her to the stake, an uncompromising opening to The Young Elites, Marie Lus first novel after her hugely popular Legend series.

title: Gorillas in the Midst of a Battle Over Oil
description: Showcasing the best and the worst in human nature, Orlando von Einsiedels devastating documentary Virunga wrenches a startlingly lucid narrative from a sickening web of bribery, corruption and violence.

title: Okapi Partners, Proxy Solicitor, Adds Executive to Focus on Corporate Clients
description: Okapi Partners has gained prominence in recent years for its role in advising activist investors like Elliott Management and Starboard Value in their fights against companies like the Hess Corporation and Darden Restaurants, the parent of Olive Garden. But the firm is hiring a new senior executive to help bolster its work for corporate clients.

title: Lincoln, the Beardless, Ethereal Youth
description: The story of Abraham Lincolns childhood, The Better Angels, is also a Christ story in a strange key. It opens with black-and-white images of the Lincoln Memorial, some suggestive of the view of an awe-struck visitor. The absence of color holds your eye (black-and-white has become a palette for gimmicks and obscure auteurs), as do several arcs traced by the camera, as if that visitor were looking up and even searching. The camera movements seem familiar not only because they mirror the physical effort of what its like to tilt your head and stretch your neck, to gape up at a cathedral window or gathering clouds, but also because they evoke Terrence Malick.

title: 30 Years Later, Reliving an Industrial Disaster
description: Bhopal: A Prayer for Rain dramatizes the buildup to the 1984 poisonous-gas leak from a pesticide factory in Bhopal, India. The leak, sometimes called the worlds worst industrial disaster, killed 3,000 almost instantly and has left a legacy of contamination and adverse health effects.

title: Luxembourg Minister Defends Tax Laws
description: Pierre Gramegna, the finance minister, says Luxembourg is abiding by international law after it was found that many companies are using subsidiaries there to lower their tax bill.

title: Perry Faces Texas Court on Abuse of Power Charges
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Facing abuse of power charges, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas made his first appearance before a state judge on Thursday, sitting stoically as his lawyers assailed the case against him as a comedy of errors.

title: A Monograph Celebrates the Architecture of Mario Botta
description: The Swiss architect Mario Botta once described his hometown as madre e matrigna  mother and stepmother  an apt description for the Italian-speaking Swiss province of Ticino, which possesses cultural sensibilities of both nations. And just like his nuanced patrimony, the architectural style Botta has honed over a 50-year career stems from a mixture of influences. His half-century of work is celebrated in Mario Botta: Architecture and Memory, a monograph just released from Silvana Editoriale ($60 at artbook.com).

title: Making Cars Safer: A View From the Industry
description: To the Editor:

title: Animal Abuse at the Rodeo
description: To the Editor:

title: To Catch a Crook: The F.B.I.s Use of Deception
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand and Central: A Bookstores Farewell
The Cuban and American Prisoners
description: To the Editor:

title: Investment Firm Raises New $2.1 Billion Fund for Latin America
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The investment firm Advent International said on Thursday that it had completed raising a new $2.1 billion private equity fund for Latin America, a sign of investor confidence in the region.

title: Keeping Wheelies, Kickstands and Helmets in the Family
description: In 1971, Bruce Browns sports documentary On Any Sunday took a down-home spin with American bikers of all stripes (including the motocross enthusiast Steve McQueen, who bankrolled it). Now Dana Brown, son of Bruce (who was also the man behind The Endless Summer), has tried an updated tour called On Any Sunday, the Next Chapter.

title: A Study of Opposites
description: Gina Gibney hasnt so much resuscitated the site formerly occupied by Dance New Amsterdam as transformed it. At the first installment of DoublePlus, a performance series at her newly christened Gibney Dance: Agnes Varis Performing Arts Center on Wednesday, the sleek space was as much a draw as the art.

title: Comedy Listings for Nov. 7-13
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 7-13
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Theater Listings for Nov. 7-13
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for Nov. 7-13
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Stars Offer Rewards and Risks to Charities
description: Joe Torre, the Hall of Fame baseball player and manager, was standing on a trading floor in Midtown Manhattan, surrounded by people dressed as Minnie Mouse, Gilligan, a Top Gun pilot, Oompa Loompas (from Charlie and the Chocolate Factory), John Lennon (in his protest phase), assorted pirates and the Grim Reaper, who was in charge.

title: Family Time on Prison Buses
description: A little-known network of buses and vans takes people from New York City to visit relatives in prisons scattered in small towns across the state.

title: In Army Health Surveys, Troops Report Chemical Weapons Exposure in Iraq
description: Post-deployment health assessments showed that more than 600 American service members since 2003 have indicated they believed they had been exposed to chemical warfare agent. Following are two such surveys, with names redacted to protect patients privacy.

title: Exchange Between Hagel and Congress on Chemical Weapons Exposure in Iraq
description: Letters between Representative Jeff Miller, who is the chairman of the House Veterans Affairs Committee, and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, about the secret casualties of Iraqs abandoned chemical weapons program.

title: Inexperienced, in More Ways Than One
description: Purveying a strangely sweet vulgarity, the romantic comedy Sex Ed commiserates with Eddie (Haley Joel Osment), 23, a would-be geometry teacher whos as much a virgin in the bedroom as in the classroom. Everyone except Eddie, it seems, is getting some love, from the customers in the bagel shop where he works to his cheerfully randy roommate (a bang-on Glen Powell). So when hes hired to supervise middle school detention, it seems particularly cruel that the one subject his students most need to learn is the one he may be least qualified to teach.

title: More Than 600 Reported Chemical Exposure in Iraq, Pentagon Acknowledges
description: More than 600 American service members since 2003 have reported to military medical staff members that they believe they were exposed to chemical warfare agents in Iraq, but the Pentagon failed to recognize the scope of the reported cases or offer adequate tracking and treatment to those who may have been injured, defense officials say.

title: Jazz Listings for Nov. 7-13
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: The Psycho, the Starlet and the Voyeur
description: Cleverly designed but hellish to watch, Nacho Vigalondos Open Windows unfolds entirely on a computer screen whose manipulators are sometimes visible and more often not. The result is a thriller with so many viewpoints, feints and fake-outs that it swiftly disappears up its own URL.

title: The S.E.C. Should Copy the D.M.V.
description: THE S.E.C. and other federal regulators have levied over $125 billion in penalties on Wall Street since the global financial crisis of 2008. Yet few believe that these fines are enough to change behavior.For the largest financial institutions, a multibillion-dollar penalty can amount to a speeding ticket  another cost of doing business. Repeat offenders are the real problem, and financial penalties alone are no longer an effective deterrent.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Nov. 7-13
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 7-13
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Home Depot Says Hackers Also Stole Email Addresses
description: The hackers that broke into Home Depots computer network this year took 53 million customer email addresses in addition to the payment card details for millions of customers, the company announced on Thursday.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Nov. 7-13
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Push for Fossil-Free Nonprofits
description: Nonprofits have been closely scrutinized for all sorts of practices, as varied as their overhead expenses or how pink  focused on womens causes like breast cancer  they are.

title: Bookshelf: Sea Creatures
description: New picture books include Chris Raschkas Clammy Clam and Carron Browns Secrets of the Seashore.

title: Bookshelf: Misbehavior
description: New picture books include Lisa Charriers Oh My, Oh No! and Steve Antonys Betty Goes Bananas.

title: Bookshelf: Lives of the Artists
description: New picture books include Matisses Garden, Mr. Cornells Dream Boxes and Edward Hopper Paints His World.

title: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 7-13
description: Somebody Come and Play

title: Sierra Leone Detains Journalist for Criticism of Ebola Response
description: In what reporters in Sierra Leone denounced as an abuse of the governments emergency powers to deal with the spread of Ebola, one of the countrys most prominent broadcast journalists was detained this week after he devoted a segment of his popular radio program to a critical discussion of President Ernest Bai Koromas handling of the outbreak.

title: Q. and A.: Andrew Wedeman on the Fight Against Corruption in China
description: In November 2012, Xi Jinping became the leader of the Chinese Communist Party and soon began a drive against corruption by officials that continues two years later. The campaign has left a deep imprint on political life and the economy.

title: Lets Play Scare the Actors
description: Opens on Friday

title: Spare Times Listings for Nov. 7-13
description: Veterans Day Parade and Events (Tuesday) Raymond W. Kelly, the former city police commissioner who was a Marine Corps officer in the Vietnam War, is grand marshal of this years salute to veterans. Sponsored by the United War Veterans Council, the parade pays tribute to the Marine Corps. Loree Sutton, a retired Army brigadier general, now the commissioner of the citys Office of Veterans Affairs; Mayor Bill de Blasio; and other officials will take part.

title: Ice Bucket Challenge: Can Lightning Strike Again?
description: Ice in a bucket became lightning in a bottle this summer, raising awareness and a record $115 million to combat the rare disease amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

title: A Circle of Celebration, Forged in Africa
description: One strong African woman honored another at Anglique Kidjos tribute concert for Miriam Makeba on Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall, where she was joined by Vusi Mahlasela from South Africa, Laura Mvulu from England and Ezra Koenig from the African-influenced New York City band Vampire Weekend. Whoopi Goldberg started the concert with praise for both Makeba, who died in 2008, and Ms. Kidjo.

title: Takata Internal Documents
description: Documents related to Takatas handling of an airbag inflater problem and the companys guidelines on handling airbags and other safety equipment.

title: Takatas Malfunctioning Airbags
description: In the course of reporting, The Times obtained video showing the potentially dangerous consequences of mishandling Takatas airbags. Millions of vehicles with the airbags have been recalled worldwide.

title: Events in Connecticut for No. 9-15, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: The Big Sleep
description: Maybe its best to close your eyes and fall into a Rip Van Winkle slumber for the next two years. The party that has refused to govern for half a decade and ran a substance-free campaign will now play at governing and not take up anything of substance.

title: Is Streaming Good for Musicians?
Events in Westchester for Nov. 9-15, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Church Group Has a Hammer
description: Its a rainy, late October day in Far Rockaway, nearly two years to the day since Hurricane Sandy devastated the area. Some of the streets are flooded, giving residents flashbacks to that awful time in their lives  not just to the flooding itself, but also to the construction swindles, insurance nightmares and disasters that followed. But for a few residents in the Broad Channel neighborhood, help has finally arrived.

title: Semper Fi Funds Horsemanship Program Offers Peace to Veterans
description: Eleven years after he lost his leg in a motorcycle accident that no one thought he would survive, Mike Johnston found himself on a horse last spring, a cowboy for a week, herding cattle through rolling Wyoming terrain with a dozen other former and current members of the United States military.

title: Manhattan Preschool Teacher Who Alleged Abuse Sues Over Firing
description: A teacher who reported allegations that a co-worker was touching students inappropriately, and was subsequently fired, on Thursday sued the Manhattan preschool where she had worked, saying her termination violated whistle-blower protection laws.

title: An L.A. Story: Unions Show Signs of Life
description: Gabriela Ochoa is a vivacious woman who buses tables at the Landings Restaurant at the Holiday Inn near Los Angeles International Airport, a job she has held since 2001.

title: Doing Good in Harms Way
description: As Dr. Rick Sacra prepared to fly to Liberia to treat patients in the Ebola zone, he prepared for the worst.

title: Takata Saw and Hid Risk in Airbags in 2004, Former Workers Say
description: Alarmed by a report a decade ago that one of its airbags had ruptured and spewed metal debris at a driver in Alabama, the Japanese manufacturer Takata secretly conducted tests on 50 airbags it retrieved from scrapyards, according to two former employees involved in the tests, one of whom was a senior member of its testing lab.

title: Obama Action on Immigration Could Benefit Texas Economy
description: EL PASO  With the midterm elections behind him, President Obama said he was ready to take executive action to prevent many undocumented immigrants from being deported, which analysts said could benefit Texas agricultural, construction and service industries.

title: Welcoming a Booms Cash, but Not Its Rowdier Side
description: KARNES CITY, Tex.  Circling this small South Texas city in his black Cadillac, Ray Kroll surveys empty streets, faded storefronts and a century-old mercantile building with fresh blue paint and a teetering veranda.

title: Iran: Detained Reporter Is Charged, but May Be Freed Soon, Official Says
description: The Iranian authorities have charged a detained Washington Post reporter, Jason Rezaian, with being involved in activities beyond journalism, a senior Iranian emissary said in a television interview on Thursday. The emissary, Mohammad Javad Larijani, said in the interview that he nonetheless anticipated that prosecutors or the court would set the charges aside and free Mr. Rezaian, above, in less than a month. Mr. Larijani, who spoke in English in an interview with Euronews, is secretary general of Irans High Council for Human Rights and a member of a politically powerful Iranian family; one of his brothers heads the nations judiciary system and another is speaker of the Parliament. Mr. Rezaian has been detained since July 22.

title: U.S.D.A. to Allow Chicken From Chinese Companies
description: Genuine General Tsos chicken may soon be on the plate.

title: Goldman Names New Head of Enterprise Technology Investment Banking
description: Goldman Sachs has given one of its senior technology bankers the expanded title of global head of enterprise technology investment banking, according to an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook on Thursday.

title: Russia: Putin Defends Soviet-Nazi Pact
description: President Vladimir V. Putin has revised his opinion of an important piece of Soviet history, calling the 1939 Molotov-Ribbentrop pact that Moscow signed with Nazi Germany to divide up Eastern Europe not so bad. The Soviet Union signed a nonaggression treaty with Germany, Mr. Putin said during a meeting with historians on Wednesday, according to a Russian transcript of the meeting that the Kremlin released Thursday. People say: Ach, thats bad. But whats bad about that if the Soviet Union didnt want to fight? Whats bad about it? While the Soviet Union is accused of dividing Poland, he said, Poland actually seized part of Czechoslovakia when Germany attacked that country. Serious research should show that those were the methods of foreign policy then, Mr. Putin said. Five years ago he had called the very same pact immoral. The statement is likely to increase security concerns in Eastern European states, which have been jittery about Russias intentions ever since it seized Crimea in March. Mr. Putin signed a law in May mandating five years imprisonment for anyone convicted of trying to rehabilitate Nazism.

title: In Brooklyn Churchs Ad, Question About Economy and Award for Answer
description: Donald J. Trump has done it, calling for the return of the death penalty in New York and a little backbone in American foreign policy. Cindy Crawford and Richard Gere did it, proclaiming themselves, despite tabloid rumors to the contrary, very married. It remains the mass protest medium of choice for political organizations (gay Republicans vs. Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel), professional groups (disaffected authors vs. Amazon) and even corporations (Walmart vs. the world).

title: Tuesday Aside, It Was All Over Back in March
description: AUSTIN  The election produced few competitive contests, but Tuesdays results answered some questions about the direction of the state.

title: Biotronik to Pay $4.9 Million to Settle Kickback Claims
description: The Justice Department said on Thursday that a producer of heart implants, Biotronik, had agreed to pay $4.9 million to resolve claims that it paid kickbacks to physicians to use its devices. The settlement followed a whistle-blower lawsuit filed by a former Biotronik employee, Brian Sant, who said that the company had induced physicians to use its pacemakers and defibrillators through methods like paying them inflated fees to serve on a company advisory board. The company did not acknowledge wrongdoing. In 2011, The New York Times published an article documenting an unusual pattern in the growth of Biotronik devices in some Western states. In Las Vegas, for example, the article reported that surgeons at a major hospital switched to using almost exclusively the companys devices soon after being put on its payroll as consultants. The Justice Department said its settlement with Biotronik covered the companys activities in Nevada and Arizona.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: War in the Field and in Cyberspace
description: Every fact-based war movie is a virtual monument, a cenotaph  or empty tomb  memorializing the dead who lie elsewhere. Some, like Chris Markers Level Five (1996) or Lon Poiriers Verdun, Looking at History (1928) are even self-aware cenotaphs.

title: A.C.L.U. in $50 Million Push to Reduce Jail Sentences
description: With a $50 million foundation grant, the largest in its history, the American Civil Liberties Union plans to mount an eight-year political campaign across the country to make a change of criminal justice policies a key issue in local, state and national elections.

title: Stoic Souls, Gliding as One
description: Gabe Polsky, the director of the documentary Red Army, likes to say that his film is a hockey movie for people who dont care about hockey, and its reception so far has proved him right. That the movie was well liked at the Toronto International Film Festival in September is perhaps no surprise. Hockey is, after all, the national sport there. But it was also a hit recently at Telluride and in May at Cannes, where hockey is surely the last thing on most peoples minds. The movie was originally scheduled for commercial release next year, but enthusiasm for it has grown such that it will get a brief run starting Nov. 14 so that it can qualify for an Oscar.

title: New York Judge Dismisses Murder Indictment Against Man Accused of Vigilantism
description: The case drew attention because law enforcement authorities accused a man, who shot and killed a rape suspect he had been trying to take to the police, of engaging in vigilante justice.

title: A Window Beyond the Western
description: LONDON  I think that the genre of western in film is defined by having horses and men in big hats, Tommy Lee Jones said recently. He was talking about his new film, The Homesman, which has horses and a big hat or two, but thats the closest Mr. Jones would come to any categorization of the movie, which had its premiere at the Cannes Film Festival in May to generally approving reviews and will be released Nov. 14.

title: Secret Cameras Rekindle Privacy Debate at Harvard
description: Privacy has been a prickly topic at Harvard ever since it was revealed last year that the university had searched the email accounts of some junior faculty members, prompting a major self-examination and promises by the administration to do better.

title: Ray Rice Awaits Ruling After Appeal Hearing Ends
description: After two days of testimony in New York, Ray Rices football fate is now in the hands of a former federal judge.

title: F.T.C. Settles First Case Targeting Patent Troll
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Trade Commission said on Thursday that it had settled its first consumer-protection lawsuit against a company for using deceptive sales claims and phony legal threats to try to get unsuspecting companies to license patents.

title: The Uses of Ridicule
description: What Ive been doing; en route home. Yes, I know there was a midterm election; thoughts in tomorrows paper.

title: This Weeks Movies | Nov. 7, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review Interstellar, Big Hero 6 and National Gallery.

title: Already, Marketers Look Past Christmas to the Super Bowl
description: WHEN Madison Avenue starts Halloween advertising before Labor Day and Christmas advertising before Halloween, it ought to come as no surprise that marketers are already talking about advertising during Super Bowl XLIX although it is still 86 days away.

title: Trial on G.M. Safety Defects Set for 2016
description: A federal judge has scheduled early 2016 for a trial related to safety defects in General Motors cars, including an ignition switch flaw linked to more than 30 deaths and the recall of millions of vehicles.

title: A New Bounty of Oysters in Maryland, but There Is a Snag
description: RIDGE, Md.  A diver pulled a large, porous bag of oysters from Calvert Bay and heaved it onto the motorboat, and the sucker fish and baby crabs began to scurry and skid in a vain search for escape along the slippery floor. Another bounty of bivalves, almost ready for market. But not everyone is excited.

title: Christopher Epps, Former Chief of Prisons in Mississippi, Is Arraigned
description: Christopher B. Epps, a former state corrections commissioner in Mississippi, was arraigned in federal court on Thursday on charges of participating in a corruption scheme in which he received nearly a million dollars from a contractor who paid off Mr. Eppss home mortgage and helped him buy a beach condominium.

title: Libyan Supreme Court Rules Parliament Invalid
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Libyas Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that the countrys recently elected Parliament was seated unconstitutionally, throwing fresh fuel on the countrys increasingly violent and divisive civil conflict.

title: Meager Returns for the Democrats Biggest Donor
description: WASHINGTON  In the last days before the midterm elections, Tom Steyer, the billionaire environmentalist who spent at least $57 million of his own money to influenceTuesdays outcome  more than any other single donor  set off on a frenetic get-out-the-vote tour to Colorado, Iowa and finally New Hampshire. There, he told business owners in Portsmouth that climate change is an economic issue, thanked college students in Durham for knocking on doors, and gave a pep talk to canvassers in Dover before they fanned out to collect voter data on their smartphones.

title: In Town Hall, Zuckerberg Discusses T-Shirts, Telephones and That Facebook Movie
description: Well, we finally know the secret to Mark Zuckerbergs success: He wears an identical gray T-shirt every day. I want to clear my life so I have to make as few decisions as possible beyond serving this community, Mr. Zuckerberg, Facebooks co-founder and chief executive, said on Thursday.

title: In Ukraine Crisis, U.S. Businesses Face Tit-for-Tat Response to Sanctions
description: MOSCOW  The scene was straight out of C.S.I., food safety edition.

title: Hague Prosecutor Cites Possible Israeli War Crimes in Gaza Flotilla Raid
description: PARIS  Israeli military forces may have committed war crimes when they stormed a flotilla of civilian ships delivering aid to the Gaza  Strip four years ago, but the consequences were insufficiently grave to warrant a criminal investigation by the International Criminal Court in The Hague, the courts chief prosecutor said Thursday.

title: Terminal at J.F.K. Could Soon Offer Travelers a Bit of the High Line
description: Travelers passing through Kennedy International Airport may soon be able to get a taste of the High Line without leaving JetBlues expanded terminal.

title: A Post-Election Day Certainty: New Scrutiny for the Affordable Care Act
description: WASHINGTON  This weeks elections ensure a new round of political attacks on the Affordable Care Act, but they also create potential opportunities to repair provisions of the law that people on both sides of the partisan divide would like to fix.

title: Veterans Affairs Chief Calls Culture Change Key to Improving Systems Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  Robert A. McDonald, the secretary of Veterans Affairs, spoke with reporters on Thursday about changing the culture of an agency that is still trying to recover from the scandal over delays in care at V.A. hospitals that was uncovered in May. Since then, he said, wait times for doctor visits at the hospitals across the country have gone down.

title: Chicago Archdiocese Offers Sex Abuse Data
description: CHICAGO  The Roman Catholic archdiocese here released thousands of internal documents on Thursday that detailed decades of sexual abuse by its priests, a disclosure timed just days before the retirement of the current archbishop.

title: Secret FIFA Report Stirs Dispute Between Investigators
description: For several days in September in a conference room at a Munich law office, two men discussed an investigation into potential corruption at the highest level of soccer.

title: The Governing Party
description: Every party in opposition goes a little crazy. For Republicans in the early Obama era, insanity took the form of the Sarah Palin spasm. Veteran politicos took the former Alaska governor seriously as a national figure. Republican primary voters nominated the likes of Todd Akin, Christine ODonnell and Sharron Angle. Glenn Beck seemed important enough to hold a big rally at the Lincoln Memorial.

title: Doubting the Economic Data? Consider the Source
description: The economic statistics are fake. There is no real economic recovery.

title: Triumph of the Wrong
description: The race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet midterms to men of understanding. Or as I put it on the eve of another Republican Party sweep, politics determines who has the power, not who has the truth. Still, its not often that a party that is so wrong about so much does as well as Republicans did on Tuesday.

title: Q. and A. With Sheri Fink on Covering Ebola in Liberia
description: Sheri Fink, a New York Times reporter and a physician, has been chronicling the Ebola crisis from an American-run clinic in rural Liberia. The Times invited readers on Twitter and Facebook to ask questions of Ms. Fink about what she has seen during her reporting trip. Readers asked about a variety of topics, including the characteristics of survivors and the risk of contracting the disease. Ms. Fink answered a selection of the questions.

title: Boehner Urges Against Executive Action
description: John A. Boehner, the House speaker, cautioned President Obama not to take executive action on immigration and called for the repeal of the Affordable Care Act.

title: A Soul Steadied by Pigeons Stays True as Feathers Fly
description: From his corner of the earth at 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Rene LeClerc could see the red-tailed hawk around one of the two air-conditioner shells that jut from his living room windows. Mr. LeClerc had modified the boxes into tiny lofts for pigeons, birds he has fancied and flown in the Hamilton Heights neighborhood of Manhattan since he was a boy of 10 or 11, not quite 50 years ago.

title: Broad Shield Requested Against Deportations
description: WASHINGTON  Immigrant and Latino advocacy groups and labor unions called on President Obama on Thursday to include more than seven million people in executive measures he says he will take this year to shield immigrants here illegally from deportation.

title: New York Needs a Stronger School Plan
description: The rescue plan for struggling schools that Mayor Bill de Blasio unveiled on Monday needs to be fleshed out in greater detail before it can be fully appraised. But it is already clear that the plan  which involves giving failing schools support services and seeing how that turns out  might not be sufficient to remake the citys lowest-achieving, most-dysfunctional schools. The plan could easily delay action on schools that are in desperate straits and should be reorganized or closed in fairly short order.

title: Problems With Antidoping System Cast a Shadow on Kenyan Runners
description: Frank Shorter, the American marathoner who won an Olympic gold medal in 1972 and made running cool, isnt the kind of guy to say, I told you so.

title: In Egypt, Business as Usual
description: The Obama administrations Egypt policy  to the extent that one can be discerned  has been characterized by a combination of mixed messages, wishful thinking and a willful disregard of inconvenient truths.

title: Mr. Obamas Moment on Immigration
description: President Obama said on Wednesday that he would act on his own by the end of the year to improve the immigration system, presumably by giving many  perhaps millions  of the countrys unauthorized immigrants temporary protection from deportation and permission to work. He has said this before, only to back off in deference to election-year politics.

title: Midterms, for Clinton Team, Arent All Gloom
description: In the coming weeks, Hillary Rodham Clinton will stop delivering paid speeches. She will embark on an unofficial listening tour to gather ideas from the business community, union leaders and others. And she will seek advice from such far-flung advisers as an ad man in Austin, Tex., behind the iconic Dont Mess With Texas campaign and a leading strategist at a Boston-based public affairs consulting firm with ties to the Kennedys.

title: Voters Defeat Measure to Prevent Santa Monica, Calif., From Altering Airport
description: The Santa Monica City Council in California will retain the right to make decisions about the citys airport now that voters have defeated a proposal backed by national aviation interests.

title: Manitas de Plata, Superstar of the Flamenco Guitar, Is Dead at 93
description: Manitas de Plata, a celebrity of flamenco guitar who sold millions of records, befriended Salvador Dal and Brigitte Bardot, performed for raucous crowds at Carnegie Hall, made and spent fortunes and generally lived a life of fulfilled appetites, all after growing up poor and illiterate, died on Thursday in Montpellier, France. He was 93.

title: Arizona: Woman Accused of Abuse Misses Deadline
description: Shanesha Taylor, a Phoenix mother who was charged with felony child abuse after leaving her children in a hot car while she went to a job interview, missed a deadline on Thursday to establish trust funds for the children. The prosecutor had agreed to dismiss the charges if she set aside $60,000 of the $115,000 she received in donations; he later lowered the amount to $40,000. Ms. Taylor said she had disagreements with her lawyer over the details of the trusts but still planned to finance them. A trial has been set for Dec. 10.

title: Arizona: Court Hears Arguments Over Medicaid
description: A rift between Gov. Jan Brewer and state legislators in her own party over her support of Medicaid expansion played out before the State Supreme Court on Thursday. Lawyers for Governor Brewer, a Republican, asked justices to uphold a lower courts ruling, which stopped a lawsuit by a group of Republican legislators who say the Brewer administration unconstitutionally found a way to pass the expansion with a simple majority rather than the two-thirds support they say is required. The maneuver was a devaluation of their voting rights, said Christina Sandefur, a lawyer for the lawmakers. Their injury is political, the governors lawyer, Timothy Berg, countered. Their vote hasnt been diluted.

title: Georgia: Lawsuit Over Taser Death Is Settled
description: The family of a man who died after being stunned up to 13 times with Taser devices during his arrest settled a lawsuit against East Point, an Atlanta suburb, and two police officers. Gregory L. Towns Jr., 24, fled officers who tried to stop him for questioning. The police said Mr. Towns resisted instructions after his capture, but family members said officers had acted with malice. The familys lawyerdid not disclose details of the settlement on Thursday except to say that it was for the maximum amount permitted under the citys insurance policy. One officer resigned after the episode, and another was fired.

title: A League Grins as a Star Grimaces
description: The Circus Maximus known as the National Football League alighted in London for a game between the Dallas Cowboys and the Jacksonville Jaguars. The leagues many fascinations will be on display: its wonderful athleticism, its stupendous television ratings, and its blithe disregard for the safety of its most valuable commodities, the players.

title: Another Ex-Commando Says He Shot Bin Laden
description: Who killed Osama bin Laden?

title: A Mother Confesses Her Mistakes as a Lesson for Her Daughter
description: Candor is a hallmark of Bettie Robinsons home. Especially where her 13-year-old daughter, Shantasia Mason, is concerned. Ms. Robinson makes no secret of her long drug addiction.

title: In Britain, Guidelines for Spying on Lawyers and Clients
description: LONDON  British spies have the authority to intercept privileged communications between lawyers and their clients  and may have illegally exploited that access in some sensitive security cases  according to confidential documents that were released Thursday.

title: Bad News, Ozzie: Davids Home From Nam
description: A pestilence has entered the house of Ozzie and Harriet. It is a disease of unease that creeps into their walls, their furniture, their bloodstreams, like a fast-mutating mold. The contagion was spawned on the battlefields of Vietnam; their son, newly home from the fighting, is a carrier. And their best and trustiest defense, all-American denial, isnt working at all.

title: Lines of Reasoning
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE A Patrick Berry puzzle! What a great way to cruise into the weekend. Thanks, Will Shortz.

title: Beneath a Pile of Losses, the Philadelphia 76ers Seek a Formula for Victory
description: PHILADELPHIA  For as long as there has been professional basketball in Philadelphia, Harvey Pollack has promoted it or kept statistical track of it. His 68-year career, begun in 1946, has spanned two local franchises; two comings of Wilt Chamberlain; one each of Julius Erving and Allen Iverson; a slew of colorful owners, executives, coaches and players; and four championships.

title: Putin Ally Denies Knowledge of U.S. Money Laundering Investigation
description: A commodities firm under investigation by federal prosectors on suspicion of money laundering and improper oil trading said on Thursday that it had no knowledge of the inquiry and called allegations of wrongdoing baseless and false.

title: Richard Schaal, TV Actor and Second City Veteran, Dies at 86
description: Richard Schaal, an actor, writer and first-generation member of Second City, the Chicago improvisational theater company that sparked a new comedy movement in America, died on Tuesday in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 86.

title: Charge of Trying to Hire Hit Man Dropped Against AC/DC Drummer
description: The most serious of the charges facing Phil Rudd, the drummer for the Australian rock band AC/DC  that of attempting to hire someone to murder two others  has been dropped, The New Zealand Herald reported on Friday. But the other charges, which include threatening to kill a third person and possession of methamphetamine and cannabis, remain.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 6, 2014
Nets and Knicks Resuming Rivalry Amid Cooperation
description: The intracity turf war between the Knicks and the Nets, still lukewarm after two years, will resume Friday night with a curious new wrinkle.

title: At Guggenheim, Protesters Renew Criticism of Abu Dhabi Expansion Plan
description: Town Cars carried patrons on Thursday to a black-tie benefit for the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, one of the institutions biggest fund-raising nights, where tables cost up to $75,000 apiece. As the museums supporters arrived, they were greeted by about 20 uninvited guests who stood in front of the building, at Fifth Avenue and 89th Street in Manhattan, clanging pots and pans as they paraded back and forth on the sidewalk.

title: Cappelen Grabs a Two-Stroke Lead
description: Sebastian Cappelen of Denmark had five birdies on the front nine on the way to a seven-under-par 65 that gave him a two-shot lead at the Sanderson Farms Championship in Jackson, Miss.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Nov. 7
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from the midterm elections and Halloween night.

title: S. Donald Stookey, Scientist, Dies at 99; Among His Inventions Was CorningWare
description: S. Donald Stookey, a scientist with Corning Glass Works who in the 1950s accidentally discovered a remarkably strong material that could be used not just to make the nose cone of a missile but also to contain a casserole in both a refrigerator and hot oven  its durable culinary incarnation was called CorningWare  died on Tuesday in Rochester. He was 99.

title: Man Charged With Operating Silk Road 2.0, a Black Market Website
