description: A California man has been arrested and charged with operating an online marketplace created to be a successor to the original Silk Road website, a black market for drug sales and other illegal activity that used Bitcoins.

title: The Elegance of Time
description: While smart watches are grabbing headlines, theres something thoroughly modern in bucking the trend in favor of a handsome gold timepiece with no complications.

title: A Hangout Grows in Brooklyn
description: The leisurely, largely residential Brooklyn neighborhood of Clinton Hill will become a bit livelier this weekend when the former site of a storied hardware store reopens as a design-centric restaurant, bar and live-music lounge of the same name: Sisters. Damon Gorton, the proprietor of the nearby Park Slope favorite Flatbush Farm, is the mastermind behind the new venture, which looks set to become a social and dining hub for the neighborhood and beyond. Ive lived here for 15 years and simply wanted to create a place I would really enjoy, Gorton says. Ive had my eye on a few locations, but this one came with a 30-foot high skylight.

title: Word of the Day | amorally
description: amorally \a-mor--le, ()a-, -mr-\ adverb

title: Whats On TV Friday
description: 7:45 P.M. (HBO) THIS IS 40 (2012) In this film written and directed by Judd Apatow, Pete (Paul Rudd) and Debbie (Leslie Mann) and their daughters (Maude and Iris Apatow, above from left, with Mr. Rudd and Ms. Mann; both are the real-life daughters of Ms. Mann and Mr. Apatow) inhabit a big white house in a nice Los Angeles ZIP code. There, in the course of a hectic week, they undergo a series of crises as the parents milestone birthdays approach: financial woes at Petes record label; an embezzling employee at Debbies boutique; mother-and-daughter hormones; and, not least, the state of their marriage. Do you still even like me? Debbie asks Pete in a moment of vulnerability. This Is 40 is an intensely, at times embarrassingly, personal film, by a man who has worked hard, lucked out and wants to share some of his happiness and its attendant worries with the rest of us, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. In other words, it should not be mistaken for satire.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Ive got a handful of hawk in my apartment.

title: Corrections: November 7, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Chinese Officials Issue Rules for Employing Uighurs in the South
description: Last week, 489 people from the far western region of Xinjiang got off a government-chartered train in the city of Guangzhou to start factory jobs in southeastern China. Mostly members of ethnic minorities, and in particular the Uighur minority, they are part of a labor export program that has been in place for years but is being stepped up as a result of orders from the top levels of the Communist Party.

title: Test Yourself | Designing a Robotics Lab for Big Hero Six
description: Below are six paragraphs from the Nov. 2 article Higher Learning in a Hybrid City.

title: ArcelorMittal Posts Slim Profit of $22 Million
description: LONDON  The worlds largest steel maker, ArcelorMittal, said on Friday that it earned $22 million in its third quarter, shrugging off deteriorating economic conditions in Europe and around the world.

title: 6 Qs About the News | As Myanmar Advances Resettlement Plan, Rohingya Flee
description: In As Myanmar Advances Resettlement Plan, Rohingya Flee, Jane Perlez writes about a long-persecuted Muslim minority in Southeast Asia.

title: Canary Wharf Owner Spurns Takeover Bid From Qatar and Brookfield
description: LONDON  Another high-profile piece of London real estate could end up in the hands of Qatars sovereign wealth fund.

title: Family Time on Prison Buses
description: The United States prison system puzzled the German photographer Jacobia Dahm. It seemed that every week she read something that didnt make sense: punishments outweighing crimes; racial disparities; prisoners revealed innocent decades after convictions. But how do you photograph that?

title: Would You Want Your Photo or Video to Go Viral?
description: Before this weekend, Alex Laboeuf was a 16-year-old from North Texas with Justin Bieber-ish looks who worked at a Target store. Then, in almost a mere instant, he became an Internet sensation and was being interviewed on TV by Ellen DeGeneres.

title: The Wall Cycle
description: A quarter-century later, another divide in Europe.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: What a Week
description: Good morning on this pleasant Friday. Cars are driving slower, or at least are supposed to.

title: Regional Politicians Approve Restart of Nuclear Plant in South of Japan
description: TOKYO  Japan moved closer to reviving part of its moribund nuclear power industry on Friday, as a regional government agreed to restart two reactors at a plant that is among a dozen nationwide waiting to be switched back on following the Fukushima disaster three and a half years ago.

title: Week 10 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Chiefs (5-3) at Bills (5-3)

title: Chastened Republicans Beat Democrats at Their Own Ground Game
description: The Republicans ground game and digital strategy in 2012 were disasters, bad enough to become a political punch line. The party was determined not to repeat those mistakes, and operatives were well on their way to overhauling its systems this election cycle when the Democrats announced their Bannock Street project, an ambitious voter-mobilization program.

title: In Beijing, Clearer Views Hide Real Life
description: BEIJING  As she does every year on the same day, Ms. Zhu hauled a large wreath of multihued paper chrysanthemums to Babaoshan Revolutionary Cemetery in western Beijing. Ms. Zhu, who declined to give her full name, planned to burn it, as Chinese tradition dictates, to honor her husband and parents, who are buried here.

title: South Korea Sets Independent Inquiry Into Ferry Disaster
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The South Korean National Assembly passed a bill on Friday initiating an independent investigation into the sinking of the ferry Sewol in April, which killed 304 people in a tragedy that traumatized and polarized the country.

title: Daily Report: Hidden Cameras at Harvard Raise New Privacy Concerns
description: Privacy has been a prickly topic at Harvard ever since it was revealed last year that the university had searched the email accounts of some junior faculty members, prompting a major self-examination and promises by the administration to do better.

title: Indian Navy Ship Sinks, Killing at Least One Crew Member
description: NEW DELHI  A ship collecting torpedoes from practice firings sank on Thursday off the coast of the southern Indian port of Visakhapatnam, killing at least one crew member and leaving four missing, the Indian Navy said.

title: Marin Cilic Is on the Upswing
description: There will be three newcomers at this years ATP World Tour Finals in London: Marin Cilic, Milos Raonic and Kei Nishikori. But the only rookie with a Grand Slam title is Cilic. It came all in a rush in September at the United States Open, where Cilic swept over the final three hurdles  Tomas Berdych, Roger Federer and Nishikori  without so much as a stumble or a lost set.

title: Roger Federer Is Still Game at 33
description: It has been quite a tennis year for 33-year-olds, with Serena Williams finishing No. 1 and Roger Federer set to finish No. 2 with an option to go one spot better depending on Novak Djokovics form and mood at the ATP World Tour Finals starting Sunday in London.

title: Roger Federer and Novak Djokovic Battle for No. 1 Ranking
description: The odds of Roger Federer catching Novak Djokovic for the No.1 ranking this year are now objectively long. But heading into the ATP World Tour Finals that begin Sunday in London, Federer still has a chance, and sometimes a chance is all that is required.

title: China to Punish Those Responsible for Pollution Levels in Beijing
description: With Asia-Pacific leaders gathering for a summit meeting in Beijing, forecasts that smog would envelop the capital this weekend were bad news not just for Chinas leaders, who hoped to present the city in its best light for the occasion, but for officials charged with ensuring clean air.

title: Today in Politics
description: Hide the Knives: The G.O.P. Meets Obama for Lunch

title: China and Japan, in Sign of a Thaw, Agree to Disagree on a Disputed Island Group
description: BEIJING  Signaling a potential thaw in their long-frozen relations, China and Japan announced Friday that they would talk to each other about their competing positions on islands in the East China Sea and would gradually resume diplomatic and security discussions.

title: The Trouble With Campaign Volunteers
description: For decades, idealistic and young college-educated volunteers joined political campaigns and were promptly sent off to canvass voters in factory towns and inner cities who were nothing like them.

title: Why It Took Us So Long to Finish Our New Website
description: This is part three of a series on commissioning a new website. You can read the first part here and the second part here.

title: Paternity Leave: The Rewards and the Remaining Stigma
description: Five months after Todd Bedricks daughter was born, he took some time off from his job as an accountant. The company he works for, Ernst & Young, offered paid paternity leave, and he decided to take six weeks  the maximum amount  when his wife, Sarah, went back to teaching. He learned how to lull the fitful baby to sleep on his chest and then to sit very still for an hour to avoid waking her. He developed an elaborate system for freezing and thawing his wifes pumped breast milk. And each day at lunchtime, he drove his daughter to the elementary school where Sarah teaches so she could nurse. When she came home at the end of the day, he handed over the baby and collapsed on the couch.

title: Helping Homeless Veterans Locally, and Thinking Bigger
description: Under the tracks of a northbound 5 train, Joseph Gotesman pulled a sandwich from a plastic bag and approached a man sitting near a jumble of boxes. His query was crisp and succinct: Excuse me, sir. Are you a veteran?

title: Ed Miliband, British Labour Party Leader, Denies Rumblings of Discontent
description: LONDON  Ed Miliband, the leader of Britains center-left opposition, should be looking forward to the general elections six months from now: His Labour Party holds a narrow lead in most opinion polls over the Conservatives, led by Prime Minister David Cameron, who have lost two lawmakers in defections to a populist right-wing party.

title: Teenagers in The Times | October 2014
description: In this monthly feature we try to collect everything published in The Times about young people so you can find it all in one handy spot.

title: Ex-Trader, Arrested in 2010, Pleads Guilty in Insider Trading Case in Britain
description: LONDON  Julian Rifat, a former trader arrested more than four years ago in what was then described as the largest crackdown on insider trading here, pleaded guilty on Friday.

title: Plan to Exit Bankruptcy Is Approved for Detroit
description: DETROIT  Less than 16 months after Detroit became the largest city in the United States to file for bankruptcy, a federal judge on Friday approved a plan intended to help it escape years of financial ruin and begin the hard work of becoming viable again.

title: Former Trader Ensnared in Libor Case Faces Another Inquiry
description: LONDON  The British brokerage firm Tullett Prebon Group said on Friday that it was facing a regulatory investigation over trades made by two former employees.

title: International Arts Events Happening in the Week Ahead
Morning Agenda: Bank of Americas Legal Hit
description: BANK OF AMERICA RAISES LEGAL COSTS | Bank of America said in a news release on Thursday that it was nearing a deal with federal regulators to settle an investigation into the banks suspected manipulation of the currency market, saying it had increased its legal costs to deal with the inquiry, Michael Corkery and Ben Protess write in DealBook. The increased legal bill resulted in a $400 million charge that cut into the earnings that Bank of America reported for the third quarter a few weeks ago. The charge resulted in the banks reporting a loss of $232 million, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter.

title: 1889: Nice Is Too Alluring
description: Nice has awakened from its summer slumbers and the general brush up which always precedes the winter season has almost been completed. The shops on the quais are stocked with fine things and there are all the signs around that the natives are expecting a very busy season. There can be no doubt that the old popularity of Nice is fast returning. But now that the people are coming again a very difficult problem presents itself: Where shall we put them?

title: Australia Nears Deal to Sell Cattle to China
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Australia is close to signing an agreement to ship live cattle to China, opening up a significant market for producers, who said exports could grow to one million animals a year, driven by demand there for fresh beef.

title: The Hand That Rules the Chorus
description: Once the rehearsal process for a production at the Metropolitan Opera moves from basement rooms to the main auditorium, Donald Palumbo, the companys chorus master since 2007, gets uncomfortable sitting down. He walks restlessly up and down the aisles, score in hand, watching the stage, conferring with the conductor, making notes in his head.

title: Cornyn Thinks Hes Found the Key to Winning Hispanic Votes
description: As he sailed to re-election in Texas on Tuesday, Senator John Cornyn, a Republican, won 48 percent of the Hispanic vote, besting his Democratic opponent, David Alameel, by one point among a group of voters who favored Democrats by two to one nationwide.

title: Does India Need a Times Square?
description: Add Mumbai to the list of cities hoping to model a new commercial center after New York Citys Times Square. Max Bearak, a Times contributing writer, wrote this week about the backlash from locals, who want to preserve the Kala Ghoda districts heritage, and he writes here about the notion of false equivalencies between cities.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Focusing on the Human Element of Estate Planning
description: JOHN A. WARNICK remembers exactly when he realized trust and estate lawyers like him were doing a disservice to their clients.

title: House Tour | Osanna Visconti
description: The jewelry and furniture designer shows T her Milan home and studio.

title: Alexander Wang for H&M: Calm Your Frenzy
description: The world went a bit nuts on Thursday over the debut of the Alexander Wang x H&M collection. The website crashed. On Twitter, the hashtag #alexanderwangxhm was trending. Consumers waiting to buy Mr. Wangs funky sports bras and leggings were handed color-coded tags with time slots. Desperate buyers were advised to go on eBay, where merchandise was already for sale, albeit at reportedly crazy prices. It was a case study in creating anticipation.

title: French President Says He Wont Seek a 2nd Term if Unemployment Persists
description: President Franois Hollande of France, facing dismal approval ratings at the midpoint of his five-year term, has strongly hinted in a television interview that he would not seek a second term if he could not reduce the nations stubbornly high unemployment rate.

title: Jobs Data Show Steady Gains, but Stagnant Wages Temper Optimism
description: Only days after many voters complained of worsening economic prospects, the new employment report from the government on Friday provided fresh evidence that the economy was actually getting better, with a sizable jump in the number of people saying they found a job last month.

title: The Halls of TV Justice
description: Dear Diary:

title: A Low-Carb Switch for Mashed Potatoes
description: Thanksgiving is problematic for dieters and anyone who wants to avoid carbohydrates. But what are we supposed to do about our beloved mashed potatoes? We look forward to their place on the Thanksgiving menu, especially now that we know that enriching them with butter and whole milk is not as bad for us as we once thought it was. If youve been following recent studies youre aware of the fact that fats have gained a lot of ground over simple carbohydrates in the nutritional world.

title: Khaki for Days
description: A great-looking trench makes all the sartorial difference.

title: Attacks on Fatah Sites Sharpen Tensions in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM  A series of small explosions rocked the homes and headquarters of several leaders of Fatah in Gaza early Friday, causing no casualties but sharpening tensions with the groups longtime rival, Hamas, months after they joined forces to form a new government.

title: Sears Weighs a New Unit to Hold Some of Its Real Estate
description: Over the last year, Sears Holdings has moved to sell a variety of assets to help raise money, including the Lands End business and some of its ownership in its Canadian enterprise.

title: Rallying Catalans to the Separatist Cause
description: BARCELONA, Spain  THE speech, before hundreds of thousands of pro-independence Catalans, was as straightforward as the seven-mile-long V for vote that the crowd formed along two of the main avenues of Barcelona, Catalonias regional capital.

title: 8 Distinctive Caribbean Inns for a Range of Budgets
description: The diminutive size, steep topography or far-flung nature of many Caribbean locales tend to limit resort sprawl. Whether by circumstance or by design, the following new and improved inns  ranging from budget-friendly bunks to guest-spoiling splurges  are the sort of distinctive properties that promise a memorable stay.

title: 1914: Armored Train Surprise
description: NORTHERN FRANCE  Exasperated by the defeat of their fresh army corps, the Germans this week resorted to a purposeless plan of laying Ypres in ruins and ashes. From guns concealed by a haystack they inflicted enormous damage on the town, but late in the afternoon the Germans met with summary punishment in a way for which they were completely unprepared. The puffing of a steam-engine warned them as they thought of the approach of a troop train. They waited their opportunity, expecting it to pass a section of the railway which was visible to them nearly two miles away. Their opportunity never came. They simply heard the terrific crash of the heavy guns, and within a few seconds they and their guns ceased to exist. The enemy had been surprised by an armored train  the first which the British had sent to the firing line. The armored train has now supported our artillery for several days. Its casualties up to date consist of one man wounded. The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 8, 1914

title: Job Growth Continues Apace, Offering Solace to Democrats
description: The employment picture continued to improve in October. The gains may not be drastic enough to change the electorates negative views of President Obama, but they could at least help Democrats pull themselves off the mat after a bruising Election Day.

title: A Journey Of Jubilation, 38 Years Later
description: Yes! We did it! Stevie Wonder exulted, and rightly so, about three hours into his concert at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night. He and a huge band, directed by the keyboardist Greg Phillinganes, had played his 1976 album, Songs in the Key of Life, from start to finish, 38 years later and every bit as vibrant.

title: Spanish Court Upholds Tax Fraud Charges Against Princess Cristina
description: MADRID  A Spanish court on Friday upheld tax fraud charges against Princess Cristina, who has been entangled in a corruption case centered on whether her husband and his business associates embezzled millions of euros in public funds earmarked for sports events.

title: Finding, and Battling, Hidden Costs of 401(k) Plans
description: LIKE millions of retirees who assumed their companies had taken care of them, Ronald Tussey never thought that his retirement plan might be flawed. He trusted his company so much he kept his money in his 401(k) long after he left.

title: The October Jobs Report Is Boring, in a (Mostly) Good Way
description: There was nothing surprising about Friday mornings report on the state of the American job market. And thats (mostly) good news.

title: Hunger Games Coming to the Stage in London
description: LOS ANGELES  Katniss Everdeen, having conquered books and movies, will next bring her survival skills to the stage.

title: Rock Star on a Quest for Heroes
description: Dave Grohl, the great drummer, inspirational songwriter, former member of Nirvana and current leader of the Foo Fighters, recently discovered the extent to which he is an American musician. He found out by visiting recording studios in eight cities during the production of Sonic Highways, an eight-part HBO series that he directed, about the common threads of popular music in this country.

title: Verbatim: Miss Hathaway Goes to Washington
description: Anne Hathaway, in the capital for a screening of Interstellar, musing about how to merge science fiction and Washington drama for the movies.

title: Video Reviews of Interstellar, Big Hero 6 and National Gallery
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Interstellar, Big Hero 6 and National Gallery. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: The Daily Gift: a Simple, Elegant Ear Cuff
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: Marco Zanini Is Leaving Schiaparelli
description: Theres another job opening in the fashion world.

title: Australias Little Guantnamos
description: Australia has temporarily closed its border to people from Ebola-affected West African nations, reports Dan Harrison for The Sydney Morning Herald an effort he says is meant to bolster the nations defenses against the virus.

title: Dallas Closes the Door on Its Ebola Scare
description: DALLAS  If there was a physical landmark of this citys five-week Ebola scare it was Apartment 614.

title: Events in New Jersey for Nov. 9-15, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island for Nov. 9-15, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Hollande on Taxes and Re-election Bid
description: In a television interview on Thursday, President Franois Hollande of France suggested he wouldnt run for re-election in 2017 if he was unable to lower unemployment rates in the country.

title: The Jobs Report Is Even Better Than It Looks
description: The topline of this mornings jobs report shows nonfarm payrolls expanding by 214,000 jobs in October. Its the sort of number that suggests a narrative of a continuing, albeit disappointing, economic recovery.

title: Loretta Lynch, Federal Prosecutor, Will Be Nominated for Attorney General
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will nominate Loretta E. Lynch, the top federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, to be the next attorney general, reaching outside his inner circle to fill a key post, the White House said Friday.

title: The Wendy Davis Experiment
description: I mentioned the Texas Democrats gubernatorial nominee in passing in my immediate post-election post, but I cant let the week disappear without saying a bit more about the Davis candidacys epic failure  one thats been featured prominently in discussions of how the Democrats entire roadmap for the future failed them in this cycle, as the demographically-shifting states they had targeted conspicuously failed to turn even slightly purple. Here is Bloombergs Dave Weigel on some of the Texas-specific elements of that failure; here is my colleague Jonathan Martin on the broader pattern:

title: The Disillusionist
description: In this excerpt from the forthcoming documentary film An Honest Liar, James Randi explains how Harry Houdini inspired him to also become a famed magician and escape artist.

title: Reply All: The 10.26.14 Issue
description: WHAT IF AGE IS NOTHING BUT A MIND-SET?

title: Garry Trudeau on Bringing His Political Satire to TV
description: The creator of Doonesbury and Alpha House talks with Jim Rutenberg about his change of heart on Reagan and whats inside Obamas brain.

title: When Your Childhood Home Isnt How You Remember It
description: Ever since my parents split up when I was 27, I fantasized about walking back into my childhood home, which they moved out of six years before they parted ways. The divorce seemed to invalidate my entire childhood. All the carefully saved bits and pieces that documented my existence before my 20s  concert T-shirts decorated with safety pins, a white jean skirt bought with babysitting money  were gone without explanation, tossed out by movers, lost in the chaos of a hasty real estate transaction or appropriated by new people passing through my parents now-separate lives.

title: Teddy Thompsons Folk-Rock Family Reunion
description: One evening last fall, Teddy Thompson stepped onto the stage at the Purple Crayon, a cultural center in Hastings-on-Hudson, not far from New York City. The venue regularly attracts established pop-folk singers, the kind embraced by the public-radio-listening, Subaru-driving locals; Thompson loosely falls into that category, although he has the louche glamour of a heartbreaker, as well as the reputation (I havent been invited on the Lilith tour, he once dryly pointed out in an interview). Tall, fair, lean and British, he sang that night, with what one admiring critic has called his keening tenor, a series of songs about failed relationships in which Thompson, single at 38, was usually the bad actor: I was born with a love disease/Its known as chronic hard-to-please.

title: The Unbelievable Skepticism of the Amazing Randi
description: A few minutes before 8 oclock one Sunday evening last July, around 600 people crowded into the main conference hall of the South Point casino in Las Vegas. After taking their seats on red-velvet upholstered chairs, they chattered noisily as they awaited the start of the Million Dollar Challenge. When Fei Wang, a 32-year-old Chinese salesman, stepped onto the stage, they fell silent. Wang had a shaved head and steel-framed glasses. He wore a polo shirt, denim shorts and socks. He claimed to have a peculiar talent: from his right hand, he could transmit a mysterious force a distance of three feet, unhindered by wood, metal, plastic or cardboard. The energy, he said, could be felt by others as heat, pressure, magnetism or simply an indescribable change. Tonight, if he could demonstrate the existence of his ability under scientific test conditions, he stood to win $1 million.

title: Why Cant I Clean My Boyfriends House for Pay?
description: About a year ago, I moved into my boyfriends house in a new city. Im renting out my old house for income as I look for work. I pay my partner $100 each month to cover my utility expenses. He pays his cleaning person $160 a month to clean the house twice a month. I am not convinced that the house gets cleaned well, and I have plenty of free time anyway. I offered to clean the house in lieu of the money I pay him, which would save him $60 and me $100. He refuses, claiming that it would be as if he were paying me to clean the house. Would that be so wrong? NAME WITHHELD, SANTA FE

title: After Work, Bypass the Wine and Reach for a Highball
description: The lamentations of people like me who work mostly from home dont tend to inspire much sympathy from 9-to-5ers. I can sleep in if Ive had a late night. I can go to movie matinees and spare myself the most crushing crowds at museums. But there are things I miss. Benefits. A routine. That built-in reading time during a subway commute. And most of all, the distinct pleasure of packing it in after a day at the office and heading straight to the bar to wash the stress away, even if its only for an hour or two.

title: Ferguson Waits Uneasily for Grand Jurys Decision
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Walk down West Florissant Avenue, and the scars of the summer are still there. The door and display window of a beauty supply store remain covered with plywood; a glued-up poster, Beauty Town Is Back, is the one hopeful sign of the life inside. A cellphone store, too, still has the plywood up from when riots and confrontations with the police shook this neighborhood. And the Family of Faith Baptist Church uses its billboard to proclaim, Join us as we pray for peace.

title: Rudolph, the Red-Nosed Forever Stamp
description: At the risk of being accused of holiday creep, I have to share these Rudolph, Santa, Hermey and Bumble stamps. I havent ordered my holiday cards yet, but I ordered these. Happy its-not-even-Thanksgiving-yet Friday!

title: Carrie Mathison of Homeland, My Former BFF
description: I was watching Carrie Mathison on Homeland last Sunday, and when it got to the part where she insists they bomb the terrorist Haissam Haqqani even though it would have killed her mentor and friend Saul Berenson, who was standing, like, six feet away, it made me glad that we were no longer close.

title: Building Human Pyramids for Catalonia
description: Castell competitions in Catalonia feature human pyramids that build community and celebrate culture as the region debates independence from Spain.

title: The Who of the Matter
description: The apartment checked off every box on the buyers wish list: airy, gracious, great views of the park. It was in a terrific building, one of the most prestigious on the Upper East Side. The couple moved in, unpacked and tried without success over the next few months to get settled.

title: Solvency, Lost in the Fog at the Fed
description: When it comes to the Federal Reserves emergency lending powers, the crucial word is solvent. Thats because both by tradition and, since the passage of the Dodd-Frank Act, by law, the Fed can use its emergency powers to make loans only to a solvent institution.

title: Catalonias Human Towers as a Metaphor for Independence
description: VALLS, Spain  It took the child about a minute to scramble up the wobbly human tower, more than three stories tall. He paused for a few precarious seconds, to steady himself, before raising his hand to thunderous applause from the crowds packed into this towns main square.

title: Reince Priebus, R.N.C. Chairman, Would Relish Hillary Clinton Campaign
description: Add one more name to the list of those hoping for a Hillary Rodham Clinton presidential run in 2016: Reince Priebus, chairman of the Republican National Committee.

title: On the Corner of Main Street, a Rare Institution
description: Looking for a place to impress a client, be wowed by the architecture of food, or rekindle the culinary magic from last summers trip to Tuscany? Its probably not World Pie, the self-described Italian saloon on Main Street in Bridgehampton.

title: U.N. Rights Chief Says Sri Lanka Is Obstructing War Crimes Inquiry
description: GENEVA  The United Nations human rights chief, Zeid Raad al-Hussein, sharply rebuked the Sri Lankan government on Friday for unacceptable conduct for what he said were efforts to obstruct an investigation into possible war crimes in Sri Lanka.

title: China, Japan to Overcome Difficulties
description: Ken Okaniwa, the Japanese Foreign Ministry spokesman, said Japan and China agreed on Friday to work on improving ties and to set aside tensions over disputed islands in the East China Sea.

title: Near the Waterfront, and Nearly Hidden
description: Unless you are familiar with Hastings-on-Hudson, it isnt that easy to find Forty North, which officially opened near the waterfront in mid-June. To get there, you must navigate onto the train-track overpass and search between the Hasting Tennis Clubs two big courts. The restaurants signs still look temporary, and are hard to read.

title: In Search of Townhouse Deals
description: In 1998, Leslie Feder and her husband, Dr. Garrick Leonard, paid $1.7 million for a townhouse on the Upper West Side, just half a block from Central Park. The 25-foot-wide property, at 60 West 83rd Street, was built as a single-family mansion in 1885, but had since been carved into 16 separate units, with some apartments sharing bathrooms and kitchens.

title: Exhibition Will Feature Recreation of William Blakes Studio
description: LONDON  A recreation of William Blakes London studio, based on a discovery of the original building plans, will be the centerpiece of the exhibition Apprentice & Master at the Ashmolean Museum of the University of Oxford, the museum announced Friday. The studio will be reconstructed to the exact dimensions detailed in the plans of No.13 Hercules Building, Hercules Road in the suburb of Lambeth, where Blake lived and worked from 1791 to 1800, creating most of his illuminated books and developing his own method of color printing. It will show the artists workbench and printing equipment, including a marble slab, inking stone, boards, papers and a star-wheel rolling press as well as three original prints representing his work and interests at the time.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Empire of Sin
description: This week, Gary Krist discusses Empire of Sin; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Maria Russo discusses this weeks Childrens Books section; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Empire of Sin
description: This week, Gary Krist and Maria Russo.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: New York Fed Legal Memo
description: Legal memo from 1999, introduced at the A.I.G. trial, written by a lawyer at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Joseph H. Sommer.

title: International Raids Target Sites Selling Contraband on the Dark Web
description: In the digital marketplace, they operated as a secret underground with names like Blue Sky and Silk Road 2.0 where anonymous buyers could purchase drugs, stolen credit cards and weapons, or even hire a hit man.

title: Obama and Congressional Leaders Discuss How to Move on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker John A. Boehner warned President Obama in person Friday that taking unilateral action to ease deportation of undocumented immigrants would rupture relations with the new Republican majority and would kill efforts to overhaul immigration policy as congressional leaders gathered at the White House for the first time since Tuesdays elections.

title: Trailer Home Trend: Reporters Notebook
description: Steven Kurutz identifies a new trend in the Home section on Thursday: People are investing in vintage travel trailers and transforming them in all kinds of ways.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: Asthma, childrens coughs and colon cancer rates. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Man v. Nature, by Diane Cook
description: In the title story of Diane Cooks debut collection, three men, childhood friends, are stranded in a great lake on a lifeboat. Theyre in the middle of a shipping route, and yet no one has passed them, no rescue is in sight. I want you to write me a world in which that happens, one of the friends asks the television writer on the boat. Its a grim scene. Theyre running out of food, they cant sleep or stretch out, and old tensions between the men have started to renew. The television writer creates an origin story for their predicament: a coup dtat in Canada, hostages, armed gunmen. He names the imaginary show Man v. Nature. Everything is man versus this and man versus that, he says. Its so simple. . . . Its man versus everything. Its me. Its you. Its us. Its in us.

title: Mike Curatos Little Elliot, Big City, and More
description: Weve all been there at some point. Feeling a little out of place, unnoticed. If we were lucky, perhaps we met someone who, though very different, complemented us. Maybe we met a Jim and, like Huck Finn, left our familiar though confining small town; maybe we were Maude seeking companionship in a boy named Harold; maybe we were Joe Buck, the midnight cowboy in a city that never sleeps, who befriended the lowliest of the low, Ratso Rizzo.

title: Memoirs
description: SMOKE GETS IN YOUR EYES

title: Editors Choice
description: THE BOOK OF STRANGE NEW THINGS,  by Michel Faber. (Hogarth, $28.) Faber is a master of the weird; in his defiantly unclassifiable novel, a pastor from Earth is picked to satisfy an alien planets mysterious yen for religious instruction.

title: Peter Stamms All Days Are Night
description: All literary characters are inventions, even if they are based on real people, the Swiss writer Peter Stamm has said. But we dont really like to be reminded of this fact. We have to forget it to be able to enjoy reading at all. Yet sometimes writers  including Stamm  cant resist spotlighting the authorial hands pulling the strings. The first line of Stamms first novel, Agnes, for example, reads: Agnes is dead. Killed by a story.

title: Inside the List
description: Missing Link: The high-low appeal of cultural studies, in which academics devote serious attention to the meanings and implications of pop phenomena, is nothing new. But it may have reached its happy apotheosis with The Secret History of Wonder Woman, new at No. 12 on the hardcover nonfiction list, by the Harvard historian and New Yorker staff writer Jill Lepore. It struck me that Wonder Womans origin story borrows from all the conventions of feminist utopian fiction, Lepore said in a recent interview with Comic Book Resource (the premier online comics magazine). I had never noticed that tie before, and I dont think comics fans or comics historians necessarily noticed it, either  mainly because theres not a great deal of overlap between comics historians and readers of feminist utopian fiction. Among other things, Lepores book traces the pervasive bondage scenes in Wonder Woman to suffragist politics, and locates the comic at an important point on the timeline of feminism. People often think of the womens rights movement as having taken place in waves, she told Comic Book Resource. Theres a first wave that ends with the passage of the 19th Amendment in 1920, and a second wave that begins in the 60s, and in between those two waves, its as if theres nothing going on. But once you lift the veil on the secret history of Wonder Woman, right there in the middle in the 1940s, theres Wonder Woman, inspired by the feminism of the first half of the century, and an inspiration for the feminism in the second half.

title: Pennyroyal Academy and The Princess in Black
description: Over the past decade or so, storybook princesses have gotten a worse rep than even the Koch brothers.

title: Gabriel, by Edward Hirsch
description: In the summer of 2011, when Edward Hirschs 22-year-old son, Gabriel, died of cardiac arrest after taking a club drug at a party in Jersey City, I was writing about my 1-year-old son, Ronan, who would eventually die of Tay-Sachs disease before his third birthday. During the course of Ronans life, I wrote constantly, often through the night, gripped by a need to understand a world in which such suffering was possible; and also to try to mitigate my helplessness and despair by giving myself something to do. Gabriel: A Poem  part tribute; part existential howl; part intellectual investigation of our most primal emotions; part novella-like, buoyant, unsentimental romp through the life of Hirschs wild spirit beloved son  is the kind of wrenching, meticulous study of grief I craved at that time.

title: Taking Flight, by Michaela DePrince with Elaine DePrince
description: Its a miracle Im even here, says Michaela DePrince in First Position, the 2011 documentary about aspiring ballet dancers. Everywhere you looked, you saw someone die. She wears a tutu and pointe shoes, about to go onstage, a picture of straight-backed ballerina calm. But the story she tells  now in greater detail in her inspiring Y.A. memoir, Taking Flight  is one of almost unimaginable turmoil and out-of-the-blue good fortune, much like the fairy-tale dances she now performs.

title: The Glass Cage, by Nicholas Carr
description: In his previous book, The Shallows  essential reading about our Internet Age  Nicholas Carr, former executive editor of the Harvard Business Review and author of several books about technology, discussed the detrimental effects the Web has on our reading, thinking and capacity for reflection. In this new book, The Glass Cage: Automation and Us, similarly essential if slightly repetitive, Carr explains how certain aspects of automative technology can separate us from, well, Reality. How, for all its miraculous-seeming benefits, automation also can and often does impair our mental and physical skills, cause dreadful mistakes and accidents, particularly in medicine and aviation, and threaten to turn the algorithms we create as servants into our mindless masters  what sci-fi movies have been warning us about for at least two or three decades now. (As Carr puts it near the end of The Glass Cage, when we become dependent on our technological slaves . . . we turn into slaves ourselves.)

title: Ali Bermans Misdirected, and More
description: Atheists are a despised minority. According to a recent Pew survey, voters are warier of an atheist candidate than of a lesbian, an adulterer or an erstwhile marijuana user. At the same time, atheist pride is waxing in the United States. Atheist tracts share prominent space at airport bookstores with memoirs about dogs and inspirational volumes for aspiring C.E.O.s. Atheist campus groups are multiplying, and polls show growing numbers of Americans identifying with the label.

title: The Big Easy
description: This week, Walter Isaacson reviews Gary Krists Empire of Sin, about New Orleans in the early 20th century. In the years since Hurricane Katrina, New Orleans and its fate have been the subject of many books of serious nonfiction, including Sheri Finks Five Days at Memorial and Douglas Brinkleys The Great Deluge, but the city will always attract artists as much as journalists.

title: Paperback Row
description: LITTLE FAILURE: A Memoir,  by Gary Shteyngart. (Random House, $16.) Shteyngarts first novel, The Russian Debutantes Handbook (2002), followed the bumbling efforts of a Russian migr grasping for a share of the American dream. Now Shteyngart recounts his own familys move from Leningrad to Queens in 1979, and his emergence as a writer, in a memoir that our reviewer, Andy Borowitz, called hilarious and moving.

title: A Map of Betrayal, by Ha Jin
description: Many years ago, the F.B.I. coined an acronym, MICE, to describe the motivations of the spy. This stands for Money, Ideology, Compromise and Ego. All spies, it is argued, are drawn into espionage by some combination of these factors.

title: Losing Our Way, by Bob Herbert
description: My father taught me to see what was missing from neglected public spaces  the opportunities rooted in overgrown woods, trash-strewn highways and busted public parks. You could give young people work cleaning that land, and theyd be a part of something, and learn useful skills, he would say. During the Depression, the Civilian Conservation Corps had been his school, where he had learned how to drive a truck, build lean-tos and benches, and helped support his parents.

title: The Right Word: Roget and His Thesaurus, and More
description: Children, like nations, need heroes to call their own. Parson Mason Weemss Life of Washington rolled off the presses in Philadelphia in 1800, mere months after the death of the father of our country, with Weemss stated goal to inspire young Americans to emulate the great mans shining example. We have that book to thank for the compelling image of the rambunctious 6-year-old George chopping down his fathers best cherry tree, then fessing up to his misdeed with the immortal words: I cannot tell a lie. The irrepressible parson, we now know, invented the scene out of whole cloth, which is certainly a tad ironic. Yet less cavalier authors than Weems have wrestled with the question of whether, or to what extent in the seemingly special case of a biography for young readers, a touch-up job might be in order. The 1940 Caldecott Medal winner, Abraham Lincoln, by Ingri and Edgar Parin dAulaire, ends with an illustration of the weary president resting contentedly in a favorite rocker, the Civil War having just come to a successful conclusion. You would never guess Lincoln had those theater tickets.

title: Letters: In Security
description: In Security

title: Wildlife and Even in Paradise
description: Fiona Woods enchanting Wildlife has two narrators: Sibylla, former wallflower and newly minted billboard model, and Lou, a loner bereft after the death of her boyfriend. When their 10th-grade class is thrust into the Australian equivalent of an Outward Bound program, neither realizes that her new survival skills will extend way beyond campfire-building and reptile identification. Bad friends, it turns out, are more treacherous than snakes.

title: John Darnielles Wolf in White Van
description: I dont believe in happy endings or even in endings at all, but I am as susceptible to moments of indulgent fantasy as anybody else, says Sean Phillips, the traumatized narrator of John Darnielles arresting, enigmatic debut novel, Wolf in White Van. As a kid, he was especially receptive to dark dreams of the pulpy, Conan the Barbarian, blood-oath and death-wish variety. It had a soundtrack. All screams.

title: A World Elsewhere, by Sigrid MacRae
description: Aime Ellis met Baron Heinrich Alexis Nikolai von Hoyningen-Huene in 1927, within the moment between two European catastrophes. To the casual observer, they seemed to have little in common. He was a tall, darkly handsome, high-minded Baltic-German aristocrat whose large family had served the czar loyally for generations and were then evicted from their ancestral lands by the Bolsheviks. She was an orphaned heiress from bourgeois Hartford, Conn.  shy, overconscious of her long nose (her proboscis, as her older brother called it), as gauche as she was eager to seize the world.

title: Censors at Work, by Robert Darnton
description: The impulse to censor is as old as the impulse to create. Plato, not the most liberal of men, suggested that the work of storytellers should be carefully examined and what they do well we must pass and what not, reject. His purpose was to moralize literature; others, over the centuries, have offered equally noble motives. Ibn Khaldun, the great Arab historian, reported that in the seventh century, when Muslim soldiers invaded Persia, they discovered an extraordinary number of books; wishing to carry them off as loot, they asked Omar bin al-Khattab, second caliph of the Muslims, for permission. Omars answer became legendary and was applied to other book destructions: Throw them in the river! If they hold a guide to the Truth, God has given us a better guide in the Holy Quran. And if they hold nothing but lies, may God rid us of them. In our own time, the president of Turkey, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, forced Google and Twitter to remove content objected to by his government or risk blackouts, arguing that these regulations do not impose any censorship at all on the Internet. . . . On the contrary, they make it safer and freer. Morality, truth, civilized society, freedom: All these have been invoked to defend what most people would understand as censorship.

title: 100 Sideways Miles, by Andrew Smith
description: In his ninth young adult book, Andrew Smith returns to the big-hearted realism of his prep school/rugby novel, Winger, then adds the hectic pace and catchy rhythms of his recent science fiction romp, Grasshopper Jungle. The result is a coming-of-age story packed with teenage angst, teenage sex (that is, thinking about sex), about 10 million arcane facts, deep metaphysical musing and great lashings of rank humor. That said, 100 Sideways Miles, which was a semifinalist for a National Book Award, is more interior and profound than its predecessors, and possibly more beguiling.

title: Arcadys Goal, by Eugene Yelchin
description: Any historical event, examined from the right perspective, can resemble a childrens story. In Arcadys Goal, an immensely rewarding novel by Eugene Yelchin, the protagonists parents are devoured in much the way the parents are devoured in James and the Giant Peach. Only instead of a rhino, its Stalin. And instead of the boy being made to live in the house of his mean aunts, hes sent to a home for the offspring of enemies of the state. At the risk of seeming to equate the evils of the 20th century with the fiction of Roald Dahl: If you were born, say, in the early 2000s, the fate of a boy like Arcady might seem just as strange and unreal as anything cooked up by a fabulist from the middle of the last century.

title: A Manual for Life
description: I read only two books cover to cover during high school. The first was Owen Wisters The Virginian, which I found gathering dust in the parlor of the old Wilson house on Charleston Street in Mobile, Ala. Wister, along with issues of Colliers, Life magazine, Readers Digest and the yellow-tinted Mobile Press-Register, made up the household literature. There was a public library a few blocks north of us on Government Street, but I never thought of going there. Libraries were not part of the culture in which I was raised.

title: Jane Smileys Some Luck
description: Before Marilynne Robinsons Iowa, there was Jane Smileys. While Robinson, already revered as the author of Housekeeping, was taking a long pause from publishing to teach at the Iowa Writers Workshop, Smiley wrote A Thousand Acres, a story of an Iowa farm family in extremis that won the Pulitzer Prize. While Robinson was writing Gilead, her own Pulitzer winner, and two subsequent novels about Iowa church people and their descendants, Smiley was shaking off the Heartland-Author tag with novels about real estate and tax evasion (Good Faith), Hollywood (Ten Days in the Hills) and a military wife transplanted from Missouri to San Francisco (Private Life). With a short biography of Dickens, she invited us to see her, like him, as a writer whose work is defined by its energy and range rather than its settings and subject matter. With a whistle-stop tour of 100 novels (Thirteen Ways of Looking at the Novel), she lined up with Henry James and John Updike as a writer who offsets her own fiction with spot-on commentary about other peoples work. So its appropriate to turn to Some Luck  the first novel in a projected trilogy about Iowa farm people and their descendants  by way of Smileys critical insights.

title: As an Oak Tree Grows, and More
description: A few years ago, we had a young neighbor who, walking to school, would stop by her favorite trees and ask what kind of morning they were having, maybe chat for a bit. She was a regular second grader and she talked to trees. I dont think shes the only one. Trees have always played a central role in the lives and minds of our species. Researchers tell us that surgical patients heal faster when their windows look out on trees and children do better in school when they can see green spaces. When the famous Treaty Oak in Austin, Tex., was poisoned in 1989, kids made hundreds of cards and placed them under the tree. Not all kids live near historic oaks, but most care about trees, and wonder about them. Books about trees speak to that wondering.

title: Johanna Skibsruds Quartet for the End of Time
description: Incarcerated in the German prisoner-of-war camp Stalag VIII-A in 1940, the French composer Olivier Messiaen set down what he called Quatuor Pour la Fin du Temps, the Quartet for the End of Time. It was first performed in January 1941 before a freezing audience of prisoners and German guards. The reception was said to have been respectful if bemused. As the critic Alex Ross later explained: By 1941, this composer no longer wanted to hear time being beaten out by a drum  one, two, three, four; he had had enough of that in the war. Instead, he devised rhythms that expanded, contracted, stopped in their tracks and rolled back in symmetrical patterns. The quartet, Ross observed, is the most ethereally beautiful music of the 20th century.

title: The Laughing Monsters, by Denis Johnson
description: On the plane I was reading this book.

title: Christopher Paul Curtiss Madman of Piney Woods
description: Rarely have I read a childrens book so suspenseful that its made me worry about being stranded in the weeds with the bleak, hateful aspects of human nature. But Christopher Paul Curtiss The Madman of Piney Woods did just that. Again and again, I doubted that what would happen next would be O.K. for young and old readers alike. Yet at every turn of this middle-grade novel, a companion book to the Newbery Honor-winning Elijah of Buxton, Curtis deftly makes what might have been simply heart-rending hopeful and redeeming instead.

title: Ambassador and Lowriders in Space
description: Like a bad haircut, the word alien has affixed itself to the popular perception of what it means to be Latino in the United States. To the unworldly, the average working person of Latin American descent looks like an illegal alien. For decades Latino comedians have been making satirical commentary on the absurdity (and cruelty) of using the same word to describe people with Spanish surnames and slimy creatures from other worlds, and now William Alexander has given us a middle-grade novel that stretches out the joke for an entire book. Alexander, who won a National Book Award for his 2012 novel Goblin Secrets, merges the fantastic with the everyday to create an engaging and smart allegory about the hurt and strangeness of the modern immigrant condition.

title: How Google Works, by Eric Schmidt and Jonathan Rosenberg
description: There is a footnote on Page 3 of the new book by Googles executive chairman, Eric Schmidt, and its former vice president of products, Jonathan Rosenberg, that should set readers expectations suitably low. The authors are describing Schmidts first years as C.E.O., when the board of directors was consumed with worry about its most formidable competitor, Microsoft. Back then Google employees, the authors write, referred to their archrival by a secret code name: Finland. It seems like a fresh if somewhat inexplicable detail, until the eye wanders down to the bottom of the page and this disclaimer: In fact, Finland is a code name for the code name we actually used. If we used the actual code name in this book, it wouldnt be much of a code name, would it?

title: Afterworlds, by Scott Westerfeld
description: Scott Westerfelds semi-supernatural novel Afterworlds beckons us into a universe where dutiful drones, pale from sun deprivation, spend long, lonely days toiling at an irksome task in order to prove their worth. The challenges they face are many, and their chances of survival, let alone success, are low. Though these worker bees occasionally bond with others of their ilk, theyre really on their own, forever outrunning the authority figures who regularly swoop down to assess their accomplishments and mete out punishment accordingly. The stakes are high: If the denizens of this universe fail, theyll be dropped into the black hole of obscurity where, unless they can claw their way out, theyll languish forever.

title: The Doubt Factory and Love Is the Drug
description: To be a teenager is to be acutely aware of power, in all its forms  by virtue of having so frustratingly little of it. Which means adolescent protagonists impose a limiting factor on political fiction. Young adult authors looking to vent their political spleen commonly circumvent this with one of two routes: They embrace George Eliots reminder that there is no private life which has not been determined by a wider public life, filtering political exigencies through the lens of personal experience and mapping out the Machiavellian power plays of home and high school. Or they turn to science fiction and fantasy and play politics to their hearts content: Theres no believability ceiling to how teenagers in futuristic societies can change their worlds.

title: In Real Life, by Cory Doctorow and Jen Wang
description: Games have unintended consequences, good and bad. Their mini-marketplaces and ersatz economies are just as hard to predict as their real-world counterparts. Anyone who has suffered family fallout over an evening of Monopoly, or lost sleep over a Fantasy Football roster, knows this all too well.

title: From Adolescent Mysticism to Hardheaded Experiments
description: Willow Smith

title: In Texas, Preserving a Neighborhood for Bats
description: At dusk, 20 million Mexican free-tail bats would pour from the darkness inside Bracken Cave on the outskirts of San Antonio, Tex., in a skillfully crafted black tornado against the dimming orange sunset. But a few thousand feet away, directly in their flight path, a community of 3,500 homes would soon stand.

title: Dependent Care Accounts, Hamstrung by Limits, Are Still Worth Exploring
description: If you work for an employer with a standard slate of benefits, perhaps you got the note last week. In 2015, you can put an extra $50 away in your health care flexible spending account on top of the $2,500 you could deposit this year. Every bit of tax savings counts, right?

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: F.B.I. Is Investigating Retired U.S. Diplomat, a Pakistan Expert, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  F.B.I. counterintelligence agents are investigating a veteran American diplomat suspected of taking classified information home from the State Department, and have searched her house and office for evidence, government officials said Friday.

title: Bellying Up to a Different Bar
description: Every time I walk into Trattoria Bolu, the first thing I notice is the bar. Its striking, though it doesnt have a bartender, or even bottles of liquor. What it does have is antipasti, made fresh, right there where the beer taps would be.

title: Weekend Auto Calendar: Tractor Time in the Hawkeye State
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

title: Nissan Recalls 6,600 Infiniti Hybrids for Unintended Acceleration Problem
description: Nissan is recalling almost 6,600 Infiniti hybrid vehicles for an unintended acceleration problem that the company says is caused by a software problem, according to a report posted Friday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

title: When Library Time Means Screen Time
description: Lately, my 4-year-old and I have been having a conflict about the library. One of us wants to go. This is not a debate that is playing out according to plan.

title: Going Topless, Tig Notaro Takes Over Town Hall
description: Tig Notaro couldnt possibly deliver a stand-up act as bold as her last one, right?

title: Today in Small Business: Paternity Leave
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: New York Plants Curbside Gardens to Soak Up Storm-Water Runoff
description: The gardens appeared suddenly along an industrial corridor of Brownsville, Brooklyn  one, two, a half-dozen  as if airlifted from a cul-de-sac upstate.

title: Maisonette on the River
description: An apartment at 1 Sutton Place South is poised to enter the market at $10.25 million. It is one of two maisonettes at the 1927 riverside co-op, which was designed by Rosario Candela with Cross & Cross as the architect/builder. The maintenance fee, paid four times a year, as per the buildings somewhat unusual tradition  cash-only sales are another  is $26,838.63 a quarter.

title: Latest Hotel Amenity: A Magazine
description: The Standard, a chain of five boutique hotels with properties in Los Angeles, New York City and Miami, has introduced a print edition of its cultural website, standardculture.com.

title: The Rubber Meets the Mud: Trying Out a New BFGoodrich Off-Road Tire
description: HUNTER, N.Y.  A vehicle  any vehicle  is only as good as its tires. That maxim is especially true for the generally poor driving conditions encountered when the wheels leave a paved surface. Mud, rocks and wet leaves reduce traction, and forward progress bogs down when the wheels begin spinning.

title: Supreme Court to Hear New Health Law Challenge
description: The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to hear a new challenge to the Affordable Care Act, imperiling President Obamas signature legislative achievement two years after it survived a separate Supreme Court challenge by a single vote.

title: Government Shows Growth, After Years of Shrinking
description: THE government is growing. Finally.

title: Book Review Podcast: Empire of Sin
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Walter Isaacson reviews Gary Krists Empire of Sin, about Storyville, a district on the edge of New Orleanss French Quarter, in the early 20th century. Mr. Isaacson writes:

title: Justices to Hear New Challenge to Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to hear a new challenge to the Affordable Care Act, potentially imperiling President Obamas signature legislative achievement two years after it survived a different Supreme Court challenge by a single vote.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: First Draft Focus: Leaders Who Lunch
description: On the Menu:

title: Bank Audit in Europe Cuts Doubt, Yellen Says
description: PARIS  Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, on Friday praised a recent review of eurozone banks, saying it would help remove doubts about the integrity of the financial system.

title: Bank Regulators Warn Again on Leveraged Loans
description: Bank regulators continue to sound the alarm about a type of debt that has become a hot product on Wall Street in recent years.

title: Facebook Makes Its News Feed a Little Less Frustrating
description: Facebooks news feed, the main screen that shows you what your friends are doing, is the heart of the service. Yet the mysteries of why things do and dont show up in each persons news feed have confounded users of the social network ever since the feature was introduced in 2006.

title: Joan Jett for Hot Topic, Zanini No More and Lea Ts Tresses
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: The Raging Bulls on Wall Street, Charity Division
description: Leon D. Black, the billionaire financier, watched silently as his son administered a flurry of punches.

title: U.S.D.A. Approves Modified Potato. Next Up: French Fry Fans.
description: A potato genetically engineered to reduce the amounts of a potentially harmful ingredient in French fries and potato chips has been approved for commercial planting, the Department of Agriculture announced on Friday.

title: Seeing the Whole of Antigua
description: Antigua lets you in slowly. It reveals itself cautiously, at its own unhurried pace. Youll miss it if you turn away too quickly.

title: Independent Projects Unveils New Art Fair Concept: A Show
description: The art fair has become a primary vehicle for viewing and selling art, but this doesnt mean its a static form. Independent Projects, a hybrid art fair and exhibition installed in the former Dia Art Foundation space on West 22nd Street in Chelsea, is a welcome mutation. With 40 solo shows, its a fair this weekend, but on Monday, the gallerists tables will disappear, and docents (just as in museums) will arrive. Best of all for artists and students, the Independent is free.

title: A Seafood Spot Is Reopened, but Not Remade
description: When a popular restaurant is sold, it is natural to wonder what changes, if any, to expect. Will the new owners close the place indefinitely for extensive remodeling? How much of the previous menu will be retained? What kind of turnover will there be in the staff?

title: Hello, Green Man
description: A few days after I wrote about conditions that can mimic dementia, reader Sue Murray emailed me from Westchester County. Her subject line: Have you heard of Charles Bonnet Syndrome?

title: Low-Level Employee at Dewey & LeBoeuf to Get Separate Criminal Trial
description: A former low-level employee at the law firm Dewey & LeBoeuf will be tried separately on criminal charges arising from the collapse of the once-mighty New York firm and not stand trial with three of its former top executives.

title: A Drink as Red as Congress
description: Theres only one color appropriate for this weeks cocktail: red  as in, Republican red. The G.O.P. had an even better week than almost any forecaster expected, taking the Senate by a comfortable margin, gaining seats in the House and winning governorships even in blue states like Massachusetts, Maryland and Illinois.

title: Election Stuff We Liked: From the Great to the Ingrates
description: Sticking with this newsletters election theme, The Upshot staff found several thought-provoking and visually appealing items on the web this week.

title: Letter From the Editor: The Story of Culpeper
description: Watching raw-vote counts has long been the only way for most people to follow election night. And its deeply unsatisfying. In some states, like Iowa, Democratic areas report their votes first, making the Democrat seem ahead even when hes not. In other states, like Virginia, the opposite is true. Thats why we introduced a new way to watch election returns this year  with vote counts adjusted for geography  and were deeply gratified by the response from readers and other analysts.

title: A Once-Skeptical Colorado Town Embraces Marijuana Legalization
description: Gunnison, Colo. (pop. 5,800), profiled this summer in The Timess series on legalizing marijuana, was the little town that wasnt sure about weed.

title: Gorillas in the Crossfire
description: A national park ranger in the Democratic Republic of Congo struggles to protect gorillas from a brutal civil war.

title: Gorillas in the Crossfire
description: In a national park in the Democratic Republic of Congo, a caretaker struggles to save gorillas from the violence of a brutal civil war.

title: Grand Bargain Saves the Detroit Institute of Arts
description: DETROIT  With his decision on Friday approving this citys federal bankruptcy plan, Judge Steven W. Rhodes  aided by nearly a billion dollars in private and state rescue money  ended an unprecedented threat to the Detroit Institute of Arts, whose world-class paintings and sculpture could have been parceled off at auction to help pay city debt.

title: Ed Gillespie, Republican Challenger for Senate in Virginia, Concedes
description: Ed Gillespie, the Republican candidate in Virginia who surprised nearly everyone by running a photo-finish race with Senator Mark R. Warner, conceded on Friday, saying the gap of 16,700 votes was too great to make up in a recount.

title: Clinton Accuser Returns as N.C.A.A. Defender
description: WACO, Tex.  Kenneth W. Starr stepped onto Baylors football field before a game last month wearing a track suit. He looked in better shape  less paunchy, less stressed  than he did more than 15 years ago, when he became famous for investigating a sitting president.

title: Senators Seek Inquiry of Takata Airbag Accusations
description: Three senators are calling for a criminal investigation of the airbag maker Takata after two former employees reported that it had carried out tests on airbags over a decade ago and found signs of defects, yet erased computer files containing data and threw away tested airbags.

title: Movie Review: Interstellar
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Interstellar.

title: Book Offers a New  Overview of Nick Drake
description: The singer and songwriter Nick Drakehad scant success in his lifetime, despite enthusiastic reviews and a following among English folksingers in the late 1960s and early 1970s. After three albums that sold only modestly, he was dropped by his label, and he died in 1974, at 26, of an overdose of antidepressant drugs. Since his death, however, Drakes music has won a large and still growing following, not least among young listeners tuned to the emotional fragility of his songs, and attracted by the romantic image of a darkly mysterious, sensitive songwriter who died too young.

title: Movie Review: National Gallery
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews National Gallery.

title: Movie Review: Big Hero 6
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Big Hero 6.

title: A Glutton for Ridicule Returns
description: The Comeback has come back.

title: Slower Cabs, and Safer Children: New York City Reduces Speed Limit to 25
description: On Nov. 2, 2013, one year and five days ago, my sons friend Lucian was killed by a reckless driver in Brooklyn.

title: Unraveling, in Slow Motion
description: After nearly two decades of marriage, David Grah and Mary Daniel, college sweethearts, divorced and have begun new lives. They agree that they are now better matched to others.

title: Where a Talker Sleeps
description: Leonard Lopate, the eponymous host of a long-running talk show on the public radio station WNYC, was born and bred in Brooklyn, even staying put there for college. Though he eventually decamped, living briefly in Rockland County, then for 30 years in Manhattan, he returned to the borough of his birth in 2000 after his first marriage ended.

title: Indian Army Takes Responsibility for Killing 2 Civilians in Kashmir
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian Army on Friday took responsibility for the killing of two teenagers in the Indian-administered portion of Kashmir this week, calling it a case of mistaken identity.

title: Cornbread That Gets the Most Out of Butter
description: Some cornbread falls on the light and fluffy side of the spectrum, sweet enough to pass for dessert. Then there is crisp, lean and salty cornbread, nearly as savory as the fried chicken that often goes with it.

title: Brown Butter Skillet Cornbread
description: Melissa Clark bakes tender, flavorful cornbread in a cast-iron pan.

title: Obama Seeks to Work With New Congress
description: Before a lunch meeting with Republican congressional leaders, President Obama said he was interested in setting aside partisanship to work on areas of common interest.

title: Dave Grohls Sonic Highways
description: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss Sonic Highways, the new album and HBO mini-series by Dave Grohl and the Foo Fighters.

title: Ukraine Accuses Russia of Sending Tanks Across Border
description: MOSCOW  Ukraine accused Russia on Friday of dispatching tanks, troops and other weaponry across the border to bolster separatists who control a small eastern portion of Ukraine, the latest in a series of charges and countercharges that are gradually undermining a tenuous peace plan signed two months ago.

title: All Not Right in Sears REIT Plan
description: Sears Holdings investors are too giddy about the money-losing retailers slow-motion breakup. Shares of Edward S. Lamperts struggling store chain jumped 35 percent by early Friday afternoon on the news that it may create a real estate investment trust for many of its stores and lease them back. The move would raise significant cash, but shareholders, Mr. Lampert included, would finance the deal. And the prospects for the rump retailer remain pretty dim.

title: Defying Soviets, Then Pulling Hungary to Putin
description: BUDAPEST  A quarter-century ago, as Hungary helped ignite the events that would lead to the collapse of communism, the ferment produced a new political star.

title: Tackling Cavities in Indias Slums with Xylitol Gum
description: During Morgan Snyders year of volunteering at an education charity in Bangalore, she noticed that many of the children complained of toothaches. Teachers told her that kids were missing sessions because of dental health problems, and that many did not brush more than once a day, and poorly at that. Her well-educated local friends didnt like going to the dentist, and she observed that a culture of regular dental check ups did not exist in India.

title: How Many Soldiers Were Exposed to Chemical Weapons in Iraq?
description: One of the more scandalous secrets from Americas decade in Iraq is coming to light.

title: Obama Praises Latest Jobs Figures
description: Speaking before a cabinet meeting, President Obama said that the economy had experienced the strongest job growth since the 1990s, and that the unemployment rate was at a six-year low.

title: With Deal, Staff at 2 Struggling Schools in Brooklyn Must Reapply for Jobs
description: The de Blasio administration said on Friday that it would require the entire staff at two of New York Citys lowest performing schools to reapply for their jobs next year, the result of a deal with the teachers and principals union that came just before a state deadline.

title: Fate: The Family Matchmaker
description: Kelly Aronowitz Katz and Andrew Swartz were married Oct. 26, at Tarrytown House Estate in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Popcast: Dave Grohls Sonic Highways
description: HBO is currently in the middle of showing an eight-part series about American music called Sonic Highways. Its host and director is Dave Grohl, leader of the Foo Fighters, whose new album of the same name comes out next Monday.

title: George Condo Creates Portraits in Action
description: Last June, the Metropolitan Museum of Art asked the artist George Condo to participate in a discussion on Willem de Kooning. In the course of his research on de Kooning, Condo read several texts by the art critic Harold Rosenberg and became inspired by the concept of action painting  the term Rosenberg coined to describe the intense, almost performative energy the Abstract Expressionists used to paint their canvases. Condo experimented with that idea while creating his newest body of work earlier this year in his East Hampton studio. They coalesced into the form of a portrait, rather than just a sort of abstract painting, Condo says. That series, which he calls action portraits, is on view from Nov. 8 to Dec. 20, in a 12-piece exhibition titled Double Heads / Black Paintings / Abstractions at Skarstedts Chelsea location.

title: Called by Destiny, Like Generations Before Them
description: From childhood, Kelly Aronowitz Katz had heard the story of how her maternal grandparents met. It was 1939 and her grandmothers family was visiting Poland from Palestine, then under British Mandate, when war broke out. They left for home and landed temporarily in Istanbul, where they stayed in a hotel packed with refugees.

title: Nascars Kurt Busch Is Focus of Domestic Assault Inquiry
description: Add Nascar to the list of sports organizations now having to manage domestic violence accusations against one of their stars. The police in Dover, Del., released a statement Friday saying that Kurt Busch, the 2004 Cup champion and the driver of the No. 41 Chevrolet for the high-profile Stewart-Haas Racing team, was under investigation on suspicion of domestic assault.

title: Do You Have Questions About Thanksgiving?
description: What kind of turkey are you roasting this year? Or are you braising? Or frying? Are you set on how to do that? What about dressing, side dishes, gravy, wine, how to say grace (whether to say grace!), the timing, the desserts, the fact that you said youd make delicata squash and now youre looking at the things and realize you have no idea how to make delicata squash?

title: Obama to Send 1,500 More Troops to Assist Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has authorized the deployment of an additional 1,500 American troops to Iraq in the coming months, doubling the number of Americans meant to train and advise Iraqi and Kurdish forces.

title: Whats at Stake in Supreme Courts Latest Health Care Case
description: Unlike the Obamacare case the Supreme Court decided in 2012, the one it took Friday, King v. Burwell, isnt a threat to the entire Affordable Care Act. But it could be a threat to health insurance that the law has provided to millions of Americans in 36 states.

title: For Black 47, the Pipes Are Calling
description: Larry Kirwan stood at the microphone in his well-traveled green suede shoes. Fighting bronchitis, he sipped his Jamesons whiskey with honey and surveyed the crowd. His band, Black 47, has had 2,300 performances over the years. It moved from humble origins playing in Irish pubs in the Bronx to appearing on David Lettermans show and playing in stadiums.

title: What Our Kindle Reading Says About Us
description: The wide world is all about you: you can fence yourselves in, but you cannot for ever fence it out.

title: You Cant Imagine Life Without Kids? I Can.
description: How was your sisters baby shower? I asked my friend Steph. She was gathering muddy clothes off the floor and wiping dried yogurt from the table while our 4-year-old sons hammered a plank of wood to bits in the front yard.

title: A Week of the Tried-and-True
description: In todays episode of The Triumph of the Well-Stocked Kitchen, our heroine runs out of bread and chicken broth, but is able to save the day on both occasions! Thank you, loaf-of-sandwich-bread-from-the-freezer, for this mornings toast and lunch PBJs, and thank you, Better Than Bouillon for the butternut squash soup that we will be eating tonight. Also, a gold star for me (and I had better buy another loaf of bread to throw in the freezer, that was a great save).

title: Cigna Agrees to Reduce H.I.V. Drug Costs for Some Florida Patients
description: The health insurer Cigna has agreed to reduce the out-of-pocket costs that patients in Florida must pay for H.I.V. drugs, settling a complaint filed by advocacy groups, who said the drug pricing system in the states health care plans was discriminatory.

title: Jon Stewart Sells TriBeCa Penthouse for $17.5 Million
description: A sophisticated penthouse at 161 Hudson Street, configured as a duplex loft with 2,000 square feet of outdoor options and nearly 6,000 square feet of interior space, sold for $17.5 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The voluminous unit, No. 9A/8B, with more than 40 windows providing exposures in three directions, had been owned since 2005 by the television pundit Jon Stewart, the host of The Daily Show.

title: Democrats Say Economic Message Was Lacking
