description: WASHINGTON  For all the finger-pointing among Democrats over Tuesdays election calamity, the White House, Congress and party establishment all share responsibility for weaknesses that the defeats laid bare, critics say, and should confront them as the 2016 contest takes shape.

title: Doorknob to Doorknob With the Coupon Crew
description: The battered white van came to a stop outside Knickerbocker Village, a middle-income housing complex on the Lower East Side, carrying five workers who sat knee-deep in the printed advertising circulars known as mailers. On the ride from a warehouse in East New York, Brooklyn, they had folded hundreds of mailers and stuffed them into individual plastic delivery bags.

title: Leelee Sobieski, Zo Kravitz and Other A-List Patrons at the Dior Sponsored Guggenheim Gala
description: Dior sponsored the Guggenheims big fall gala, held in the museums landmark rotunda.

title: Pampered Baby Knows How to Crawl
description: STEWARTSTOWN, N.H.  When Robert Reed and his family turned their all-terrain vehicles onto a dirt trail in far northern New Hampshire, he was surprised to see tracks from a bigger machine. The rough trail is typically used only by riders of all-terrain vehicles frolicking on a new 1,000-mile regional network of A.T.V. trails called Ride the Wilds.

title: 2015 Mercedes-Benz GLA250 and GLA45 AMG
description: The smallest Mercedes S.U.V. is based on the CLA sedan, but it can scamper in the wild.

title: Hell on Wheels, Below-the-Radar Hit for AMC, Is Renewed for Final Season
description: The Western drama Hell on Wheels is being renewed by AMC for a fifth and final season, the network announced on Friday, while at the same time declaring its decision to move the series to Saturday nights a success story.

title: Stand Up Right Now.  Notes From a Health and Fitness Reporter.
description: Gretchen Reynolds is the Phys Ed columnist for the Well blog and Science Times.

title: But How Much to Tip an Automatic Garage?
description: Someone must have been the first to realize that its not the heat, its the humidity. Likewise, in New York in the late 1920s, Milton A. Kent had a flash: It wasnt the moving cars, it was the parked ones hogging two-thirds of the roadways and clogging traffic.

title: A New Road for Women in India
description: Travelers headed to Delhi on select G Adventures trips will receive ground transportation from Women on Wheels, a team of commercially trained female drivers.

title: Founder of Anti-Money Super PAC Defends Its Poor Showing
description: Mayday PAC, started this spring as the super PAC to end all super PACs, wasnt the biggest group of its kind to have a disappointing Election Day, but it might be the one that gets the most attention for its failures.

title: Think Like a Doctor: Going Blind Solved!
description: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to solve the mystery of a 68-year-old woman who lost her vision over the course of a few months. More than 250 readers wrote in with their take on this terrifying case. A couple of you nailed it, but frankly this case was a super-zebra  at least to me.

title: W.H.O. Issues New Guidelines on Safely Burying Ebola Victims
description: GENEVA  The World Health Organization released a new protocol Friday for the burial of Ebola victims in an effort to slow transmission of the disease and reinforce signs of progress in curbing the spread of the epidemic in West Africa.

title: Obama Makes His Choice for No. 2 Post at State Department
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will appoint Antony J. Blinken as the deputy secretary of state, the White House announced Friday, placing one of his closest advisers in the State Departments No. 2 post.

title: Florida Leads the Pack  in Felon Disenfranchisement
description: Many nations around the world value voting rights so much that their citizens can vote from prison. These countries include Denmark, Finland, Ireland and Sweden. The United States, by contrast, strips felons of the right to vote, not just while they are imprisoned, but often after they have done their time and returned to their communities. This shameful practice deadens engagement in the political process, particularly in minority communities where imprisonment rates are highest and children grow up in the company of adults who cannot cast a ballot.

title: Bunny Mellons Collection, On the Block
description: The late heiresss rarefied objects go to market, emphasizing the elegance of the understated.

title: Beaten on the Boston Bombing, Then Landing a Snowden-esque Scoop
description: The Newsroom begins its truncated, six-episode final season on HBO on Sunday, and its pilgrims progress through 21st-century American journalism has brought it to the Boston Marathon bombings. This gives Aaron Sorkin, the writer of record on every episode, plenty of opportunities for finger-wagging as his fictional ACN cable news crew watches less meticulous or fortunate outlets falsely naming suspects and bannering photos of innocent people.

title: AT&T to Buy Mexican Wireless Provider Iusacell for $2.5 Billion
description: AT&T agreed on Friday to buy Iusacell, one of Mexicos biggest cellphone service providers, for $2.5 billion including debt, as it seeks to expand its international presence by moving southward.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Ukraine, Syria, the United States and Germany.

title: The Stock Market Doesnt Care About Elections
description: HOW much do investors care about election outcomes?

title: Nov. 7, 2014  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Ukraine, Syria, Scotland and the United States.

title: Passion Threaded With Silken Whispers
description: A thrilling performance of Mendelssohns Die erste Walpurgisnacht capped the Orchestra of St. Lukes season-opening concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday, proving that, under the leadership of its firebrand music director, Pablo Heras-Casado, this is an ensemble to watch. While it feels as though it has yet to achieve its full potential, the orchestra is brimming with enthusiasm and clearly hungry to nip at the heels of its more established colleagues at Lincoln Center.

title: Malaysian Court Overturns Islamic Law Banning Cross-Dressing
description: BANGKOK  A Malaysian appeals court on Friday struck down an Islamic law that banned men from dressing as women in what lawyers described as a landmark case in the stormy battle for primacy between secular and religious laws.

title: For a Student of the City, Its Always New
description: If youre curious about a particular building in New York, odds are that Andrew S. Dolkart knows something about it. Mr. Dolkart, the 62-year-old director of Columbia Universitys Historic Preservation program, spends many Sundays wandering the city with his husband, Paris R. Baldacci, 70, a law professor at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law. Mr. Dolkart, in recognition of his tireless study of New York old and new  he has written dozens of books and essays, and is working on a book about the garment district  will receive the Historic Districts Councils Landmarks Lion award on Nov. 19.

title: The Super El Nio Forecast Fadeout
description: On time scales from decades to months, fluctuations in ocean conditions present persistent challenges to climate scientists (see the pause in warming) and weather forecasters. The latest example is the fadeout of portentous predictions of a super or monster El Nio warming of the tropical Pacific. Its hard for me to avoid thinking of the departed comedian Chris Farley when exploring this weather phenomenon:

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Berlin Welcomes Back the Trabant, if Only for a Day
description: BERLIN  The two-door, 2-cylinder Trabant was  and almost certainly remains  the most familiar commodity to come out of the former East Germany. The flyweight car with plastic body panels and an engine barely more powerful than a garden tractor was best known for its dull tones and cramped, bumpy ride.

title: Accepting With Joy, and Barbs
description: LOS ANGELES  On Saturday night, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences here will give Harry Belafonte an Oscar for his long fight against injustice, racial and otherwise, at its annual Governors Awards banquet. And one thing is sure: Mr. Belafonte, true to form, will speak his mind.

title: Free Service, for One Owner Only
description: For some buyers, a new vehicles allure goes beyond handling, styling and prestige: They parse the terms of the warranty and even whether maintenance is covered. Some BMW enthusiasts were surprised this summer when the automaker announced limitations on the transfer of its four-year or 50,000-mile complimentary maintenance plan when a car goes to a subsequent buyer.

title: An Outbreak of Fluid Leaks
description: Harsh-shifting Jaguar transmissions and Volkswagens with balky door handles are among the maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: In Self-Driving Cars, a Potential Lifeline for the Disabled
description: The self-driving car, embraced as a stress-reducing convenience for harried drivers and a potential advance in road safety, could also prove to be a life-changing breakthrough for many people with disabilities, granting them a new measure of independence.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Thinking Big. Then Thinking Bigger.
description: Jim Venturi has a big idea, and it led him, on a recent afternoon, to a lush strip of overgrown vegetation in the South Bronx, through a gap in the wire fence, past a sign saying to keep out, past abandoned furniture and an empty homeless encampment.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Bright Specks of Dust From Comet Siding Spring Light Up Martian Sky
description: A comet that zipped past Mars last month dumped tons of dust into the planets atmosphere, providing a spectacular light show, scientists said Friday in presenting initial scientific findings from the flyby.

title: Jesus and the Modern Man
description: SOMETIMES, when I kneel alone in a pew in the far back shadows of a church, face buried in my hands, a forbidden thought intrudes: You should have left all this behind a long time ago. The joyful new pope has quickened the affection even of the disaffected, including me, but, oddly, I sense the coming of a strange reversal in the Francis effect. The more universal the appeal of his spacious witness, the more cramped and afraid most of his colleagues in the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church have come to seem.

title: A Harlem Throwback to the Era of Billie Holiday
description: Around 8 p.m. on a recent Saturday, a few dozen people were gathered in a narrow, dimly lit Harlem brownstone. Couples smoked in the backyard beneath Christmas lights; a group of Chilean expats sought a corkscrew; a man and his young son searched for seats.

title: Keep Warm and Carry On
description: It is not hard to find apps catering to the whims of those with disposable incomes  witness the race to help diners score reservations at the hottest restaurants or provide homeowners with a rental butler. But as two noteworthy apps that recently won competitions in New York prove, good things can happen when developers are asked to turn their attention to the public need.

title: Joe on WNYCs Money Talking
description: Whether the Democrats received a shellacking or merely a temporary bruise on Tuesday, one thing is certain: Republicans are in control of Congress and determined to prove they know how to say yes as effectively as they say no. While that might not mean passing a comprehensive immigration bill, it could be a good thing for business.

title: Sharp Words on Israel and Palestine
description: To the Editor:

title: A Linzer Torte Fit for Thanksgiving
description: At one point in my meandering cooking career, I found myself working in a French pastry shop in California. Though the owner was Swiss, nearly everything we produced was classical French: croissants, brioches, clairs, that sort of thing. There were fresh fruit tarts, chocolate gateaux and all kinds of puff-pastry delights, everything a self-respecting Francophile could dream of.

title: For Old Trauma, Fresh Sensitivity
description: There was a stretch not long ago when it seemed as if Veterans Day had been largely forgotten, but not this year, at least not on television. Programming related to Tuesdays observance is plentiful, and a lot of it seems determined to throw off the stodginess sometimes associated with the holiday, whose roots are in World War I.

title: Meet the Nations First Marijuana Critic
description: A day in the life of Jake Browne of The Denver Post.

title: Of Mops and Mad Bulls
description: Like many children growing up in Grenada, Shawn Thomas learned at an early age how to make a kite using a traditional Caribbean folk design.

title: Bill Cunningham | Marathon Medley
description: It seemed as if a kaleidoscope of colors had exploded on the runners participating in the five-borough New York City Marathon last Sunday.

title: The First One Home to Care for Dad Gets to Unpack the Most Baggage
description: Among the pithier observations from that eloquent philosopher Blanche DuBois was the idea that death is the opposite of desire. Those opposites attract, after a fashion, in You Got Older, a new play by Clare Barron about a young woman returning home to care for her father, whos learned he has a rare and aggressive cancer. Sleeping in the room next to him, Mae (Brooke Bloom) finds her fearful imaginings for his future shoved aside by wild sexual fantasies involving a mysterious cowboy.

title: The End Is Near
description: At the end of the month, after 11 years of challenging  some might say confounding  New Yorks palate, WD-50, Wylie Dufresnes world-famous culinary skunk works on the Lower East Side, is closing shop. Oldest story in the book: A developer is tearing down the building and putting up  what else?  condominiums. To celebrate (or rather, mourn) the end of his temple to molecular gastronomy, Mr. Dufresne has devised a pair of menus for his last few weeks, and on Wednesday night they drew a crowd of curious first timers, former employees back for a last repast and a man who is widely acknowledged as the restaurants best customer: Stewart Waltzer, an art dealer who has dined at WD-50 more than 300 times and has booked a table for each remaining Wednesday of the month.

title: With Eloquent Arms, Movement Gives Voice to Visceral Images
description: There are certain givens in a dance by Ronald K. Brown. Deep, spiritual seriousness. A sophisticated mastery of stage space. Music that makes you want to move. A vocabulary, drawn from many parts of the African diaspora, that Mr. Brown has developed into a personal language thats flexible, richly expressive and irresistibly kinetic.

title: A Bridge Deal From the Final of the Rosenblum Teams
description: This diagramed deal occurred during the final of the Rosenblum Teams at the world championships in China last month. It featured what was probably the most exuberant bid and one of the best defenses of the two weeks.

title: Beyonc and Cara Delevingne Celebrate a Topshop Opening
description: Topshops second-largest store settles in Manhattan after a stop at Grand Central Terminal.

title: Just Because a Policy Causes a Death Spiral Doesnt Mean Its Unsustainable
description: As my colleague Margot Sanger-Katz notes, a Supreme Court ruling against the Obama administration in King v. Burwell would cause significant disarray in health insurance markets, by denying subsidies to anyone buying health insurance on the individual market in states that rely on the federal health insurance exchange.

title: Topshops Next Stop Is Fifth Avenue
description: Can I do it like pushing a big red button? the ropy supermodel Cara Delevingne drawled on Tuesday afternoon. She was pondering the ways in which she might officially open the new Fifth Avenue Topshop store the next day, several of whose walls are covered in larger-than-life-size photographs of her beetle-browed visage. (She appears in the current ad campaign.)

title: Magnums Archive of Once-Orphaned Photos
description: Most pictures dont make the final edit. But Magnum photographers went back through their files and found delightful images that had gone unseen. Until now.

title: Corporate Disclosure of Political Donations
description: To the Editor:

title: Dior Gives the Guggenheim a Twirl
description: For the second year in a row, Dior sponsored the Guggenheims big fall gala, held Thursday in the museums landmark rotunda. And after a rocky journey that found the Dior brass grounded after extreme turbulence in Paris, a full caravan arrived to toast the occasion: Raf Simons, Diors creative director; Sidney Toledano, the companys chief executive; and many others.

title: Educating for Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuts to Weather Forecasts
description: To the Editor:

title: Signs of Secular Stagnation
description: And they arent even being ironic

title: Q and A: For Supreme Court, a Case of Economics and Politics
description: WASHINGTON  When the Supreme Court on Friday agreed to hear a new challenge to the Affordable Care Act, it caused concern for many people who support the law, which has provided health insurance to more than 10 million. The challenge poses a threat to the law, according to defenders of President Obamas policies.

title: F.B.I. Chief Backs Agent Who Posed as Reporter
description: In spring 2007, Timberline High School in Lacey, Wash., received bomb threats by email, on paper and on a bathroom wall, causing the school to be evacuated. A few days later, according to a local news report, a 10th-grade student was arrested.

title: The Life of a Pot Critic: Clean, With Citrus Notes
description: DENVER  Jake Browne was seated in a yellow suede chair, carefully rotating a marijuana bud between his fingers. Im looking for bugs, mildew, things I wouldnt want to ingest, he said, leaning forward to hold the nickel-size flower up to the light. He paused, then took a sip of water from a cup with a Miley Cyrus hologram down its side. This looks clean, he concluded.

title: Prominent Editors Exit Is Setback for Amazon Publishing Unit
description: When Amazon hired the novelist Ed Park as a senior editor in its New York publishing office in 2011, it seemed an unlikely match. Mr. Park  a member of New Yorks literary elite who had worked for the Poetry Foundation, co-founded a literary magazine and edited The Village Voices literary supplement  seemed ill suited to Amazons algorithm-driven business.

title: Friday Night Music: Suzanne Vega, Jacob and the Angel
description: Back from Japan, jet-lagged into oblivion, and not exactly wildly happy about some things. But music remains! I did an interview, which some people might find interesting.

title: Stricken by Grief, Finding Solace in a Robin
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill Cunningham | New York City Marathon Medley
description: It seemed as if a kaleidoscope of colors had exploded on the runners participating in the five-borough New York City Marathon last Sunday. Ending in Central Park, the run was set against a backdrop of autumn leaves. Some of the international runners sported traditional garb from their home countries. Curiously, a number of runners wore tutus.

title: Evening Hours | A Busy Autumn
description: A funeral mass for Oscar de la Renta, honors and costumes.

title: Atlanta Symphony Musicians and Management Reach Tentative Labor Deal
description: The two-month lockout of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra, which has delayed the start of the ensembles 70th anniversary season, could be nearing its end: federal mediators announced on Friday that the musicians and management had reached a tentative labor deal.

title: On Twitter and Instagram, Hiding in Plain E-Sight
description: My older sister hates Twitter. Absolutely hates it, and avoids it at all costs. Her feelings do not come from some slavish devotion to fully formed thoughts and sentences. No, Lizzie can speak in text pidgin with the best of em.

title: The Soviet Style
description: The director of Red Army, a documentary about Soviet era hockey, discusses the essence of the Russian style of play.

title: Want to Make a Movie, Jason Schwartzman?
description: Hanging out with Jason Schwartzman feels a bit like living inside one of his movies. The banter is ironic. The course of events is without obvious purpose. And in the end, something kind of spectacular happens.

title: With Some Dating Apps: Less Casual Sex Than Casual Text
description: Jason Sprung, a 26-year-old comedian in Brooklyn, connected last year on the location-based dating app Tinder with a Tennessee woman who was visiting New York. The two didnt get a chance to meet up while she was in town, but that didnt deter them.

title: Federal Form for Voting Is Ruled Valid
description: A federal appeals court on Friday rejected the demands by Arizona and Kansas that federal forms for voter registration used in their states require documentary proof of citizenship.

title: Larry Agenbroad, Paleontologist at Mammoths Graveyard, Dies at 81
description: Larry Agenbroad, a paleontologist who presided over the unearthing of scores of fossilized mammoths from a scrape of southwest South Dakota, helping it become an international research destination, died on Oct. 31 in Hot Springs, S.D. He was 81.

title: For Millennials, the End of the TV Viewing Party
description: The television has always been more than just an appliance. For decades, going back to the days when a single family on a block might have a color TV that the neighbors were invited in to watch, it has been a portal to a dreamscape, a status symbol, a trusted late-night companion.

title: Erased iPhone Gets a Mother in Trouble
description: Eileen Lagala, a Staten Island resident for 55 of her 60 years, and a mother of three sons and four daughters, added two new titles in the past year  one when she became a grandmother and the other when she began serving a years probation following her guilty plea in criminal court last month.

title: Weekly Wrap
description: Hello Insiders.

title: Montefiores New Bronx Medical Center Emphasizes Outpatient Care
description: The newest medical complex in the Bronx offers valet parking, views of Long Island Sound, and operating rooms equipped with overhead lamps that do not throw shadows and nonporous, plastic-lined walls to reduce the spread of infection.

title: Republican Beats Expectations but Concedes Virginia Senate Race
description: Ed Gillespie, the Republican candidate in Virginia who surprised nearly everyone by running a photo-finish race with Senator Mark R. Warner, conceded defeat on Friday, saying the gap of 16,700 votes was too great to make up in a recount.

title: 25 M.P.H. Speed Limit Takes Effect in New York
description: The 25-mile-per-hour speed limit that went into effect in New York City on Friday did not slow a black Mercedes that blazed a path down the middle lane of Madison Avenue at a brisk 34 miles per hour around 1 p.m. Nor did it deter the drivers of a tow truck going 32 m.p.h. or a city bus lumbering along at 28 m.p.h. Even a police car was spotted darting through traffic, though no emergency was apparent.

title: The Labor Picture in October
description: October Jobs data show solid employment growth.

title: Finding $816 Million, and Fast, to Save Detroit
description: DETROIT  Late one afternoon last November, leaders of some of the nations top foundations were invited into a private meeting in a courthouse conference room here as Judge Gerald E. Rosen, the appointed mediator in this citys federal bankruptcy case, made an unheard-of request.

title: U.S. Embassy in Bahamas Issues Crime Warning
description: MIAMI  Water scooter operators on Paradise Island in the Bahamas are reported to have sexually assaulted at least three American tourists since July, the United States Embassy announced in a security advisory this week that warned of increasingly brazen crimes sweeping the country.

title: A Muckraking Magazine Creates a Stir Among Evangelical Christians
description: In October, Mark Driscoll, the evangelical pastor and best-selling author,  resigned from Mars Hill, his Seattle megachurch. This month, Mars Hill announced that it was dissolving its network of 13 satellite churches.

title: Health Care Reform Imperiled
description: Will five Supreme Court justices eliminate essential health care subsidies for more than four million lower-income Americans, based on a contorted reading of four words?

title: Job Growth, but No Raises
description: The employment report for October, released on Friday, reflects a steady-as-she-goes economy. And that is a problem, because for most Americans, more of the same is not good enough. Since the recovery began in mid-2009, inflation-adjusted figures show that the economy has grown by 12 percent; corporate profits, by 46 percent; and the broad stock market, by 92 percent. Median household income has contracted by 3 percent.

title: Detroit Leaders Praise Judges Decision
description: Officials in Detroit celebrated a new day after a federal judge approved a plan to bring the city out of bankruptcy.

title: Waiting for the European Central Bank
description: The European Central Bank said this week that it was prepared to take additional steps to revive the struggling economies of the 18 countries that use the euro. The trouble is that the E.C.B. is already way behind the curve, and the steps it seems to have in mind will not be sufficient to help the millions of unemployed people.

title: Making the Rent
description: In 1981, Aleksander Ptselintsev, an Estonian Jew of Russian descent and a soldier in the Soviet army, was deployed in Afghanistan. He fought the mujahedeen for over a year, until his unit was ambushed and an explosion sent him to the hospital for eight months, leaving him with post-traumatic stress disorder.

title: Former Navy SEAL, Author of Bin Laden Best Seller, May Face Costly Penalties, Lawyer Says
description: Matt Bissonnette, a former member of Navy SEAL Team 6, will probably have to forfeit at least $4.5 million in book royalties over his failure to allow the Pentagon to review his best seller on the Osama bin Laden raid for possible security breaches, according to court documents filed by his lawyer.

title: SEMA Show Closes with a Peek for the Public
description: LAS VEGAS  The annual Specialty Equipment Market Association trade show closed on Friday with an official public event  a first in the shows 47 years of existence.

title: Pregnant Lawyer Requests Delay in New York Corruption Retrial
description: Deborah N. Misir is in the sixth month of a high-risk pregnancy. So Ms. Misir, a Long Island lawyer, has asked that an upcoming trial for one of her clients  set for about two months before her due date  be postponed.

title: How Lincoln Won the Soldier Vote
description: Francis Lieber, the famed German-born Columbia University professor, was amazed that America would hold a presidential election during the Civil War. If we come triumphantly out of this war, with a presidential election in the midst of it, he wrote in August 1864, I shall call it the greatest miracle in all the historic course of events.

title: No Need to Hype Clash Between Kansas State and T.C.U.
description: The magnitude of the game speaks for itself, so much so that Kansas State Coach Bill Snyder did not bother fretting about the Wildcats focus for Saturday nights Big 12 Conference showdown with Texas Christian.

title: To China, Shift in Obamas Political Fortunes Eclipses U.S. Economic Gains
description: WASHINGTON  The last time President Obama went to China, five years ago, he was a political supernova from a nation with a depleted, debt-ridden economy. When he returns to Beijing on Monday, he will be a political casualty from a country with a resurgent economy.

title: Drug Gang Killed Students, Mexican Law Official Says
description: MEXICO CITY  Members of a drug gang arrested in the investigation into the disappearance of 43 college students in September told investigators that they had killed the students and burned their bodies in a pyre of tires and branches, the attorney general announced Friday.

title: Transocean Challenged by Plummeting Oil Prices
description: In a sign that lower prices are starting to exact a toll on the oil industry, the offshore-rig owner Transocean announced it would take charges of more than $2.7 billion because of weakening demand for its rigs. Transocean said the charges forced it to delay its third-quarter earnings report, which was scheduled for Friday. Companies that explore for and produce oil are cutting back on investment because of sharp declines in the price of oil, which is reducing demand for rigs and lowering rates for Transoceans equipment. Brent crude, the most common benchmark for global oil, has fallen 28 percent since late June.

title: Obama Urged Iranian Leader to See Common Interests
description: WASHINGTON  In a letter last month to Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, President Obama urged Irans supreme leader to seize the opportunity of the Nov. 24 deadline for negotiating a nuclear agreement with the West, arguing that Irans interests in the Middle East would be served by proving its interest in nuclear technology was solely for the production of electricity, according to senior administration officials.

title: A Team Player to the Very End
description: HARRISON, N.J.  If retirement is near for Thierry Henry  and he is not yet saying it is  he will follow Derek Jeter as the next great athlete to leave New York, minus the season-long goodbyes and parting gifts.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 7 2014
Pregnant, and No Civil Rights
description: WITH the success of Republicans in the midterm elections and the passage of Tennessees anti-abortion amendment, we can expect ongoing efforts to ban abortion and advance the personhood rights of fertilized eggs, embryos and fetuses.

title: Big Money Wins Again in a Romp
description: Two days after the midterm elections, I met up with a man named Ira Glasser, the former longtime head of the American Civil Liberties Union. For days, the media had been full of news about the enormous sums of money likely to be spent by special-interest groups and others to influence the outcome of Senate races, House races, gubernatorial races  even judicial races. According to the Center for Responsive Politics, which issued a report just days before the midterms, nearly $4 billion was expected to be spent, in toto, on the midterms. Glasser had no problem with any of this.

title: A Resolve to Stay Young, Undimmed by Illness
description: At age 28, Irina Finkel, a gregarious film student in what was then Soviet-ruled Ukraine, came to a conclusion.

title: Latvian Minister Declares Hes Gay, Exposing Fault Lines of New Culture War in Europe
description: When Latvias foreign minister, Edgars Rinkevics, declared on Twitter on Thursday that he was proud to be gay, the announcement was welcomed there by lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender rights activists, who have faced open hostility from social conservatives in the former Soviet republic.

title: Republicans  Pipeline
description: The Keystone XL oil pipeline is so popular! Ever since the Republicans won control of the Senate, its become the Taylor Swift of political issues.

title: Derek Stepan Set to Return as Rangers Try to Stabilize Lines
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Happy faces were everywhere after the Rangers practice Friday ahead of a trip to Toronto.

title: Cardinals Bruce Arians Took Long Route to Top N.F.L. Job
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  In 1983, Bruce Arianss future stretched before him like a desert highway. He was given the keys to Temples program at age 30, becoming the youngest head coach in major college football.

title: General Theological Seminary Bringing Back Professors It Dismissed
description: Seven of the eight professors who were dismissed in late September from the General Theological Seminary, the nations oldest Episcopal seminary, will return to their classrooms on Monday.

title: A Tiny Bit Strange
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Barry C. Silk writes puzzles for grown-ups  tough yet elegant grids filled with lots of scientific and political entries  but if you look carefully, there are always a few entries that remind us that, no matter how old you are, the kid in us remains.

title: Labor Board Says Cablevision Chief Tied Raises to Vote Against a Union
description: The National Labor Relations Board has charged Cablevisions chief executive officer, James L. Dolan, with illegally threatening to deny company technicians in Brooklyn a pay increase unless they voted to quit their union.

title: Saturdays College Football Games to Watch
description: 4 ALABAMA at 14 L.S.U.

title: New York Police Officer Found After Vanishing With Money
description: A veteran New York City police officer disappeared for two days with tens of thousands of dollars intended for him and a group of his colleagues to travel to Seattle this weekend for a Giants football game, the police and a person familiar with the matter said.

title: Nets Make Knicks Look Like a Long-Term Project
description: The Knicks and the Nets share a city, three bridges and deep pockets. About $180 million in player payroll was on displayFridaynight at Barclays Center, which was treated to the renewal of an embryonic rivalry  if it can be considered that  between two teams that were merely hoping to take a step toward respectability.

title: Britain Is Granted Delay in Payment to European Union
description: BRUSSELS  Britain was given the leeway on Friday to defer a payment of 2.1 billion euros, or about $2.6 billion, to the European Union, whose demand had given ammunition to a populist party pressing the country to leave the bloc.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (Showtime) AUGUST: OSAGE COUNTY A dysfunctional clan unfurls its secrets as it gathers to mourn the loss of its patriarch in this dark comedy, directed by John Wells and adapted by Tracy Letts from his Pulitzer Prize-winning play. Sam Shepard portrays Beverly Weston, an alcoholic poet living in a rambling farmhouse in northeastern Oklahoma who hires a Native American caretaker (Misty Upham) for his shrill, pill-addicted wife, Violet (Meryl Streep)  and then disappears. Julia Roberts, Ms. Nicholson and Ms. Lewis and play Beverly and Violets daughters; Ewan McGregor, Dermot Mulroney and Benedict Cumberbatch are the men in their lives. And Margo Martindale and Chris Cooper are Violets sister and brother-in-law, who are there to lend support. But the story of the Weston family is secondary to the spectacle the actors make of themselves, A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, calling the film a thespian cage match in which a bunch of unquestionably talented performers is assembled with no instructions other than to top one another. He added, It goes without saying that nobody can beat Ms. Streep at this game. (She received an Oscar nomination, as did Ms. Roberts.) But everyone joins in.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I said if you do $100 million, we should give $20 million.

title: Corrections: November 8, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: The Daily Gift: a Gadget That Trains the Brain
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: The Company Is Still Tight-Lipped, but Shareholders Arent
description: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

title: The Stock Market Is on Edge About a Cable Merger
description: The debate over net neutrality and cable company concentration has been rattling Wall Street.

title: A Strategy for Rich Countries: Absorb More Immigrants
description: Economic debate since the financial crisis and Great Recession has often focused on issues like monetary policy, fiscal stimulus, unemployment and financial regulation. Yes, these are all important, but in the future we will need to pay much more attention to a relatively neglected field: population economics. Its an area that will prove central to understanding whether nations will grow richer  or will stagnate and lose global importance.

title: No Burden Too Heavy
description: Marcus Rede, 50, is a forklift driver for an Ikea distribution center in Bakersfield, Calif.

title: Reinventing Themselves, Without a Net
description: My husband, who is 34, recently quit his federal government job, where he worked on climate-change issues for four years. He left because we decided to move to New York for my work and because he was itching to explore other options.

title: Wearing Your Failures on Your Sleeve
description: Five years ago, Cassandra Phillipps founded FailCon, a one-day conference in San Francisco celebrating failure. Discouraged by a growing chorus of start-up founders promoting their triumphs throughout Silicon Valley, and nervous about her own prospects as an entrepreneur, she craved the stories of people who had flopped.

title: On LinkedIn, a Reference List You Didnt Write
description: LinkedIn is the industry leader in helping people make work connections. Log on, and this professional-networking site displays a sampling of people you may know  often including colleagues at a users own workplace  with whom to start hobnobbing.

title: Janet Elkin, on Not Letting the Process Defeat the Purpose
description: This interview with  Janet Elkin, chief executive of Supplemental Health Care, a health care staffing firm, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Kenneth Bae and Matthew Todd Miller, Released by North Korea, Are Back on U.S. Soil
description: WASHINGTON  North Korea released two Americans who had been accused of trying to subvert the secretive state, after the director of national intelligence for the United States flew to the country on a secret mission and left on Saturday with the men aboard his aircraft.

title: 1989: Checkpoint Charlie as a Gateway for Shoppers
description: Berlin  A statement painted on the Berlin Wall at Stresemannstrasse summed up an extraordinary weekend in West Berlin:

title: Montserrat Seeks a Comeback After a Volcano
description: Since 1995, when the SoufrireHills volcano began erupting and eventually buried its capital,Plymouth,in pyroclastic flows, the Caribbean island ofMontserrathas sought a comeback. Now it thinks it has one, and Plymouth is again part of the plan.

title: A Blank Page in the S.E.C. Rule Book, Four Years Later
description: Its something that almost everyone can agree on: Executives should return compensation earned improperly as a result of accounting shenanigans at their companies.

title: Mom, the Guarantor, Steps In
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: The Many Genres of a Salsa Giant
description: Working with Willie Coln in 1978, the great singer Rubn Blades made possibly the best-selling record in the history of salsa, Siembra. His songs were stories about class divisions, crime, love and history. With parallel careers as an actor and statesman  he was Panamas minister of tourism from 2005 to 2009  he connected with audiences across Latin America and continued to push beyond whatever he felt the constraints of Latin pop might be. (On records from the 1980s onward, he used elements of doo-wop, bagpipes, Cuban folklore and tango; many of them felt like theoretical demonstrations.)

title: Rising Quartets, Hip and Passionate
description: Is ours the new golden age of string quartets? If certainly feels that way, with a growing number of fiercely individualistic and accomplished ensembles made up of passionate young players. Two stellar groups from the European scene come to town this week: the Danish String Quartet and the Paris-based Quatuor Ebne. Catch the Danes underground at their CD release party at SubCulture or at one of two sets on Thursday at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. Joined by the pianist Gilles Vonsattle, they present music by Debussy and Vierne at the Rose Studio Concert and Late Night Rose Program. (8 p.m., Wednesday, 45 Bleecker Street, near Lafayette Street, East Village, subculturenewyork.com; 6:30 and 9 p.m. Thursday, Lincoln Center, chambermusicsociety.org.)

title: Sledders Training for a Smackdown
description: Football has been taking a lot of heat lately over the roughness of the sport, but you might prefer being tackled by a lineman to absorbing some of the hits seen in Ice Warriors: USA Sled Hockey, a documentary about that Paralympic sport Monday night on PBS.

title: Reliving the Shock of a Pas de Nude
description: Many Broadway musicals have great dance numbers. But when the shows close, those dances often fade from memory. That realization led the dancer Lee Theodore to establish the American Dance Machine, which preserves and performs musical-theater choreography, in 1976.

title: A Nazi-Era Diva as Victimized Relic
description: Light and shadow, the two secrets of motion pictures, the faded film star tells her companion in Veronika Voss. Part of a generous Fassbinder retrospective running through Nov. 26 at the Film Society of Lincoln Center, Veronika Voss uses a light-and-shadow palette (and all sorts of wipes and iris effects) to tell the story of Veronika, a star during the Nazi years, who now finds herself addicted to morphine and captive to the doctor who provides it. (Remarkably, its based on a true story.)

title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  When I have solved all of the crossword puzzles I need to solve for the blog and I need a bit of a break, I turn to cryptic crosswords for a breath of fresh air.

title: Creators Inspired by Ebony and Jet
description: Magazines and their images are part of everyones childhood experience, but thats especially the case with artists, who often mine them for motifs, materials and memories. This is the premise behind Speaking of People: Ebony, Jet and Contemporary Art, opening Thursday at the Studio Museum in Harlem. It examines the aesthetic uses that artists of African descent have made of Ebony and Jet, mainstays of black life in the United States since their founding in Chicago after World War II. (The show is titled after a column in Jet.)

title: Pope Demotes U.S. Cardinal Critical of His Reform Agenda
description: ROME  Pope Francis on Saturday sidelined a powerful American cardinal who has emerged as an unabashed conservative critic of the reform agenda and the leadership style that the Argentine pontiff has brought to the Roman Catholic Church.

title: Its Elementary: Knicks Problem Is Chemistry, Not Geometry
description: It is too early to argue that the Knicks cannot get a better grasp of the triangle offense. But it may be too late to acknowledge that the narrative of Phil Jacksons first full season as the Knicks president and Derek Fishers as coach should not have been so much about the installation of a system not ideally suited for the habits and skills of too many players, several of whom will not be around beyond this season.

title: The Places in America Where College Football Means the Most
description: It is hard to explain to someone who grew up in a big city in the Northeast just how big a deal college football is in the Southeast.

title: Loretta Lynch, a Nominee for Attorney General, Is Praised for Substance, Not Flash
description: When Kenneth P. Thompson was a young federal prosecutor in Brooklyn in the late 1990s, he was assigned to one of the biggest cases the office had ever handled, that of the police officers accused of beating and sodomizing Abner Louima, a Haitian immigrant.

title: McCain Poised to Press Obama, and Pentagon, at Armed Services Helm
description: WASHINGTON  Of all the areas where Barack Obama and John McCain clashed during the 2008 presidential campaign, none was more combustible than defense, with their starkly different views on the deployment of American men and women to wage war overseas.

title: Lynch Portrayed as Tough, Fair and Apolitical
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama announced on Saturday that he would nominate Loretta E. Lynch, the top federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, to be the next attorney general, paving the way for the first African-American woman to hold the job.

title: On Berlin Wall Anniversary, Somber Notes Amid Revelry
description: BERLIN  It was the morning after the best party ever, the tumult and joy that marked the fall of the Berlin Wall on Nov. 9, 1989. After 28 years, East Berliners were giddy with marvel that they could now visit the West.

title: Brazil Military Drills to Defend Amazon
description: MANAUS, Brazil  Brazils army is deploying troops this month to the far reaches of the Amazon in a military exercise simulating a foreign invasion of the rain forest, focusing attention on sensitivity over sovereignty in a region rising in importance as a strategic pillar of Latin Americas largest economy.

title: The Ethics of Infection
description: PRIMUM NON NOCERE or First, do no harm is supposed to be the guiding principle of health care workers. And within civil societies, at least, not harming others is considered every persons moral, ethical and even legal responsibility.

title: Democracys Circuses, Triumphs and Shams
description: The main event of the past week was, of course, the midterm elections. It was a Republican romp, far greater than any poll predicted, but for those watching it from abroad it was also a striking lesson in the enormous complexity, expense, passion and mystery of the democratic process as practiced in the worlds premier republic.

title: Medical Records: Top Secret
description: MANY readers were shocked by my recent article about Peter Drier, who received a surprise bill of $117,000 from an out-of-network assistant surgeon who helped out during his back operation. But almost as surprising was how difficult it was during my reporting for Mr. Drier to extract his own records from the hospital.

title: Private Mannings Missing Medical Care
description: As a matter of constitutional rights and basic decency, prisoners  including military prisoners  are entitled to proper care for their serious medical conditions. Yet, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel and other officials continue to deny medically necessary care to Chelsea Manning, the military prisoner formerly known as Pfc. Bradley Manning, who was convicted in August 2013 of leaking a vast cache of classified government documents.

title: Republicans Are Only Sometimes the Party of Uber
description: Republicans have hailed Uber, the smartphone-based car service, as a symbol of entrepreneurial innovation that could be strangled by misplaced government regulation. In August, the Republican National Committee urged supporters to sign a petition in support of the company, warning that government officials are trying to block Uber from providing services simply because its cutting into the taxi unions profits.

title: Pricey Doughnuts, Pricier Homes, Priced-Out Readers
description: DAVID Gonzalez approached the South Bronx street-corner preacher and said he was from The New York Times.

title: How We View A.D.H.D.
description: Readers discuss the reasons behind the increased diagnosis and treatment.

title: Our Mommy Problem
description: WHEN I hear someone telling an expectant mother that having a baby will turn her into a new person, I cant help but imagine a pathologically optimistic weather forecaster brightly warning that an oncoming tornado is about to give a town an extreme makeover. Becoming a mother doesnt change you so much as violently refurbish you, even though youre still the same underneath it all.

title: The Fight Republicans Need Now
description: FOR the second time in four years, the Republican Party has won a sweeping midterm victory without having a policy agenda to match. The party has a more-than-comfortable House majority, a solid Senate edge, and it faces a lame-duck president sealed in a bubble of sour self-regard. But if you look for consensus on the ends to which this new power should be turned, youll find ... well ... um ... repeal of the medical-device tax?

title: Living Life Secondhand
description: LIFE is an ecstasy, Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote in an essay called The Method of Nature, a founding document of American transcendentalism. Life is also electricity, as our minds synapses and heart muscles would testify if they could.

title: Eric Betzig
description: Eric Betzig is a physicist at the Howard Hughes Medical Institutes Janelia Research Campus in Ashburn, Va. He won this years Nobel Prize in physical chemistry for his role in the development of super-resolved fluorescence microscopy, which allows visualization of minute biological processes such as DNA transfer and neural activity.

title: Vibrant, Timid Berlin
description: BERLIN  A QUARTER-CENTURY ago today, the Berlin Wall fell, and since then this city has been on a roll. Its one of the party capitals of the world and an affordable center for young artists and musicians, with enough layers of history to inspire a novelist for a few lifetimes. And its economy has benefited greatly from a growing start-up scene. In a country dominated by pleasant but boring cities, Berlin is Germanys one truly cosmopolitan metropolis.

title: Makers and Breakers
description: CLEVELAND  FLIP through any newspaper and go from the foreign news to the business pages and what youll see is the other great geopolitical struggle in the world today. Its not the traditional one between nation states on land. Its the struggle between makers and breakers on the Internet.

title: Gray Hair and Silver Linings
description: I TURNED 50 just the other day, but I got the gift that I most needed nearly two years earlier, from a couple of strangers whom I never saw again.

title: A Changed China Awaits Mr. Obama
description: PRESIDENT OBAMA hasnt even begun his state visit to China and he has already been mocked.

title: A Promising Approach to Internet Rules
description: This spring, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission  proposed a plan  that would have allowed broadband companies to divide the Internet into fast and slow lanes. That idea that was roundly attacked by advocacy groups like Public Knowledge and the American Civil Liberties Union, and now the chairman is reportedly considering a new approach.

title: Prehistorys Brilliant Future
description: ONE morning last spring, I opened my email to see a photograph of the paleontologist Diego Pol. There he was, stretched out, feigning sleep, on a dinosaurs femur roughly the size of a living room couch.

title: Making My Therapist Laugh
description: My career in therapy has been a long and varied one, spanning four decades and calling on different aspects of my presented self. One of the odder things about therapy, Ive discovered, is that it comes with little in the way of a code of conduct as opposed to other situations you find yourself in  little, that is,beyond showing up, paying your bill in a timely fashion, leaving when the session comes to an end and not upending any of the shards or vessels that might be lying around the office in homage to Freuds passion for collecting antiquities.

title: Dark Money Helped Win the Senate
description: The next Senate was just elected on the greatest wave of secret, special-interest money ever raised in a congressional election. What are the chances that it will take action to reduce the influence of money in politics?

title: What Were Watching: Sunday Shows
description: Republicans swept the midterm elections this week, retaking control of both houses of Congress, several governors mansions and statehouses. President Obama, who stayed home on Election Day, will appear on CBSs Face the Nation to discuss his plans for the final two years of his presidency with a Republican-controlled Congress.

title: Deft Footwork Updates a Classic
description: Times do change, so turning a corny, conventional 1942 movie musical like Holiday Inn into a 2014 stage offering does entail risk. But the final production of the Goodspeed Opera House season  and of Michael P. Prices 46-year tenure as executive director  manages to step nimbly around the pitfalls. It avoids both desecrating the movie that gave the world White Christmas and distressing a contemporary audience with Abraham, the films appalling blackface number (sometimes omitted from TV broadcasts, as it is here).

title: Personal Ways of Untangling the Political
description: Hair pervades The Womens Room: Female Perspectives on Men, Women, Family and Nation, an exhibition of short videos at the Hudson Valley Center for Contemporary Art. It is brushed, braided, snipped and shaved. It falls in golden curls from the head of a toddler, lies thinning and gray on the scalp of an old woman, blows seductively across the faces of flawless models who twirl in the wind.

title: For LeBron James and the Cavaliers, a Passing Cloud
description: LeBron James, for one, does not think it is time to panic.

title: Seeking Her Own Stove, With Hopes of Teaching Others How to Use One
description: Amina Gilmore spent one of her first nights of homelessness on the No. 1 train, guarding her 1-year-old son as he slept. The next day she went to class. Even as her life shifted and balances wavered in a few short years, Ms. Gilmore kept her eyes fixed on her goal.

title: A Musical Education Full of Sweat and Sequins
description: Peggy Sue Johnson, a theater arts student at Molloy College in Rockville Centre, didnt sing her best at the audition for Celebrating the Music of Marvin Hamlisch, a musical theater event set to take place Saturday at the Madison Theater on the Molloy campus.

title: Indian Muslims Lose Hope in National Secular Party
description: MUMBAI, India  When he set out on a muggy morning in mid-October to vote in the Maharashtra State legislative elections, Zubair Azmi intended to cast his ballot, as usual, for the Indian National Congress, the party that has promised for years to protect Muslims like him.

title: Ottawa Senators Are Welcoming an N.H.L. Crowd in Soccers Image
description: OTTAWA  The Ottawa Senators home arena was a bit too quiet, as it often is for regular-season games not involving the Toronto Maple Leafs or the Montreal Canadiens. The opponents last Tuesday night were the Detroit Red Wings, and most of the phlegmatic Senators crowd at Canadian Tire Centre sat and watched in hushed contemplation.

title: Steelers Nation Swoops In to Annex Jets Territory
description: The Dallas Cowboys might be Americas Team, but when it comes to a national following, few teams rival the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: As Russia Draws Closer to China, U.S. Faces a New Challenge
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama flies to Beijing on Sunday to renew efforts to refocus American foreign policy toward Asia. But when he lands, he will find the man who has done so much to frustrate him lately, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia. You are pivoting to Asia, Russias ambassador to Washington said last week, but were already there.

title: U.S. Airstrikes in Iraq Target ISIS Leaders
description: BAGHDAD  An airstrike by a United States-led coalition hit a gathering of leaders of the Islamic State jihadist group in northwestern Iraq on Saturday, and Iraqi officials said they believed that a number of top militants had been killed.

title: Berlins Wall of Light
description: To commemorate the 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, the artists Christopher and Marc Bauder created a border of lights called the Lichtgrenze.

title: Lights and Celebration Where a Wall Divided Berlin
description: BERLIN  Frank Ebert, a human-rights activist from East Berlin, was so sure the breach in the Berlin Wall was temporary that he spent part of his first day in the West stocking up on ink, paper, books and other materials that would be impossible to get once he returned to the Communist side.

title: Arizona Law on Immigrant Smuggling Is Struck Down
description: PHOENIX  A federal judge here has struck down a state law against smuggling immigrants into the United States, the latest state-enacted measure against illegal immigration in Arizona to be thwarted in court.

title: A Passionate N.F.L. City, if in Absentia
description: LOS ANGELES  When running back Ben Tate burst into the end zone Thursday night, giving the Cleveland Browns an early lead, the St. Felix bar in the heart of Hollywood erupted. Andy Lytle, in his Bernie Kosar No. 19 jersey, shouted, Here we go Brownies, here we go. And the other 40 or so Browns fans answered, Woof, woof, woof.

title: Giants Focus on Starting Fast, and Get Nowhere
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  It is customary for an N.F.L. team to script the first 10 to 15 plays it plans to run to start each game. The offensive coordinator, after spending days and nights studying the defense of the next opponent, usually designs a sequence of plays he thinks have a high chance of success based on his teams strengths and the other teams weaknesses. The starting quarterback offers opinions, too.

title: U.S. Citizens Released from North Korea
description: Kenneth Bae and Matthew Todd Miller are released after months of detention in North Korea.

title: New York Prosecutor Accused of Attacking Woman at a Bar
description: A New York City prosecutor has been arrested on charges that he berated and then choked a woman at an Irish bar on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Fans Unload (and Upload) Ire, Urging Firings of Coaches and Executives
description: The online pleas for sideline and front-office changes simmer on Twitter and Facebook. The demands persist on blogs and petition sites like MoveOn.org.

title: Manhattan Speeder Says He Has Fled to Canada
description: A driver convicted in absentia of reckless endangerment for racing around Manhattan in 24 minutes said in a telephone interview that he had fled to Canada and did not intend to return to face a sentence of up to a year in jail.

title: Sundays Matchup: Giants (3-5) at Seahawks (5-3)
description: 4:25 p.m., Fox

title: Sundays Matchup: Steelers (6-3) at Jets (1-8)
description: 1 p.m., CBS

title: Colorful Characters
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  I dont give out awards for puzzles, because I think that if theyve made it into The New York Times, they already have something special going for them. If I did, however, I would give Tom McCoys puzzle a gold star, just for all of the thematic theatrics that he has piled into todays grid. It took me a while to fully appreciate the depth of the theme, but when I got it, as Will Shortz says below, it was definitely a wow.

title: Needing to Hire, Chief of V.A. Tries to Sell Doctors on Change
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.  The longtime corporate executive entered the college lecture hall to make a pitch the medical students had probably heard before: He was offering good starting salaries, well-financed research opportunities and rewarding work with patients in great need.

title: With Fear of Being Sidelined, Tea Party Sees the Republican Rise as New Threat
description: WASHINGTON  As most Republicans were taking a victory lap the morning after the elections, a group of conservatives huddled anxiously in a conference room not far from Capitol Hill and agreed that now is the time for confrontation, not compromise and conciliation.

title: Survival English
description: At Oakland International High School, about a quarter of the students are unaccompanied minors and face possible deportation back to Central American countries.

title: Honduran Youth Finds Welcome Mat at Oakland School Designed for Immigrants
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Above the bunk bed Lester Valladaras sleeps on each night, a collection of photos of his three younger sisters and his mother, Maribel Irias, is tacked to the wall. Ms. Irias made the collage during an English class a couple of years ago, before Lester came to America, writing this explanation next to the images: I have three daughters here with me and two sons still in Honduras. I miss them very much. I hope they come here one day.

title: Powerful Afghan Police Chief Puts Fear in Taliban and Their Enemies
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  With his boyish looks and hesitant smile, Lt. Gen. Abdul Raziq cuts a modest figure that belies his reputation as a man of both courage and cruelty: the tough-guy sheriff who kept the Taliban out of Kandahar.

title: Recreating Adam, From Hundreds of Fragments, After the Fall
description: It happened at 6 on a Sunday night. Adam  a strapping, 6-foot-3-inch marble sculpture by the Venetian Renaissance master Tullio Lombardo  fell to the ground on a patio at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, smashing into hundreds of pieces. Nobody knew what had happened  it could have been foul play, said Jack Soultanian, a conservator who was called to the museum that night in 2002.

title: Clement A. Price, a Cheerleader for Newark, Dies at 69
description: Clement Alexander Price, a distinguished history professor who fell in love with Newark, a city some thought unlovable, and went on to write books and articles about it, as well as to lead tours, brief journalists and shamelessly promote it, died on Wednesday in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 69.

title: Britain Plans for Future of Shale Oil and Gas Industry
description: LONDON  The British government said on Saturday that it would establish a sovereign wealth fund with the proceeds from extracting natural gas from shale.

title: Atlanta Symphony Orchestra Agrees to a New Labor Deal
description: The Atlanta Symphony Orchestra announced on Saturday that it would end its two-month lockout after reaching a deal that would give its musicians small raises but require them to pay more for their health insurance, while also allowing the orchestra to leave positions vacant longer.

title: Well-Trod Victims of the Oil Fields: Roads Used to Get There
description: CRYSTAL CITY, Tex.  With much of the town sleeping, Tino Mendoza walked across a moonlit bus yard on a recent morning, preparing for his first trip of the day. While inspecting bus No. 32, he surveyed the latest casualty of this regions newfound oil and gas economy: a small but growing crack in the windshield.

title: Getting Close to Terror, but Not to Stop It
description: WASHINGTON  After a car bombing in southeastern Iran killed 11 Revolutionary Guard members in 2007, a C.I.A. officer noticed something surprising in the agencys files: an intelligence report, filed ahead of the bombing, that had warned that something big was about to happen in Iran.

title: On Endangered Species List in Austin: White Democrats
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  When Donna Howard of Austin won a seat in the Texas House in 2006, she was the only white woman among Democrats in the state Legislature.

title: Army Returns Interception 99 Yards to Repel UConns Rally in the Bronx
description: It is not easy being a Connecticut football player in November. The calendar flips to college basketball season, and you are battling for attention on your own campus with not just one national championship team, but two: the mens and the womens programs.

title: Other Instruments, Beware; the Pipe Organs Cometh
description: KILGORE, Tex.  East Texas is about to be booming. Not from the fracking that is waking the small cities outside of Dallas, but from an arts revival that is tapping into another local resource  one of the countrys highest concentrations of mid-20th century Aeolian-Skinner organs.

title: Turnout Down in Texas, and Democrats Claim a Reason: Voter ID Law
description: Say this for the states new voter ID law  it gave Texas Democrats a patsy for the thumping they got on election night.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 8, 2014
Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 9, 2014
description: She really is the soul of grace under pressure.

title: The Mascot Will Sit This One Out, Thanks
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  Few universities venerate their sports mascots as much as Louisiana State cherishes Mike the Tiger  or Mike VI, as he is formally known here. He resides in a 15,000-square-foot habitat across the street from Tiger Stadium, replete with a waterfall, a pool and an Italianate tower, and professionals at L.S.U.'s veterinary school look after his teeth, claws and paws each day.

title: Ying Wang and Patrick Dooley
description: Ying Wang, a daughter of Xiaojun Wu and Dunrui Wang of Chantilly, Va., was married Saturday to Patrick Joseph Dooley, the son of Maureen A. Dooley and Joseph P. Dooley of Durham, Conn. The Rev. John Unni, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Cecilia Church in Boston.

title: Julie Wechsler, Erik Scott
description: Julie Alyse Wechsler and Erik Jordon Scott were married Saturday by Rabbi Elliot N. Perlstein at the Atrium at Curtis Center, an event space in Philadelphia.

title: Laura Laughlin, Stirling Cox
description: Laura Ashton Laughlin and Stirling Alexandre Cox were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton, Naples, in Naples, Fla. The Rev. Richard S. Riccardi, a priest of the Old Catholic Church of New Utrecht, officiated.

title: Swept Away in a Single-Prop Plane
description: Cynthia Greenberger Osofsky and Dr. Fredric K. Weiss are to be married Sunday at the Washington Crossing Inn in Washington Crossing, Pa. Rabbi Yair D. Robinson will officiate.

title: Mary McConnell, Daniel Cocoziello
description: Mary Elizabeth McConnell, a daughter of Helen C. McConnell and Mathew J. McConnell of Rye, N.Y., was married Saturday to Daniel Federico Cocoziello, a son of Sharon L. Cocoziello and Peter J. Cocoziello of Oldwick, N.J. Msgr. Donald M. Dwyer performed the ceremony at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye.

title: Lisa Applebaum, Michael Eskenazi
description: Lisa Applebaum and Michael Evan Eskenazi are to be married Sunday at Liberty Warehouse in Brooklyn. Rabbi Stuart L. Berman is to officiate.

title: Joui Hessel and James Hexter
description: Rabbi Joui Marlo Hessel and James Robert Hexter were married Saturday evening at the Mandarin Oriental hotel in Miami. Rabbi M. Bruce Lustig led the ceremony, with Rabbi Susan N. Shankman participating.

title: Julie Weiswasser, Andrew Hyman
description: Julie Miriam Weiswasser and Andrew Steven Hyman were married Saturday in Longboat Key, Fla. David Leeb, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Resort at Longboat Key Club.

title: Adele Lewis and Jay Gleacher
description: Frances Adele Lewis and Jay Stevens Gleacher were married Saturday at the Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. Matthew F. Heyd, an Episcopal priest and the rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Warm Words With a Frequent Visitor
description: Sarah Mitchell Yates, the daughter of Mary M. Yates and Charles R. Yates Jr. of Atlanta, was married Saturday evening to Brian John Umana, the son of Victoria J. Doran of Alexandria, Va., and John Umana of Washington. The Rev. Paul N. Walker, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Charlottesville, Va.

title: Megan Romigh, Sidney Jackler
description: Lt. Megan Elizabeth Romigh and Sidney Michael Jackler were married Saturday at the Naval Station Norfolk Chapel in Norfolk, Va. Dr. Richard Zweifler, a friend of the couple, received permission from Virginia to officiate.

title: Marcy Richardson, Scott Murphy
description: Marcy Richardson and Scott Frederick Murphy were married Saturday evening at Landmark on the Park, an event space in New York. Jean Richardson, a Presbyterian minister and an aunt of the bride, officiated.

title: Kristen Lukiewski, Michael Szczerban
description: Kristen Lukiewski and Andrew Michael Szczerban were married Saturday under Pennsylvanias self-uniting marriage statute at the Landis Valley Village and Farm Museum in Lancaster, Pa.

title: Lauren Barnett, Michael Medvin
description: Lauren Lee Barnett and Michael Jay Medvin were married Saturday evening at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Joshua Goldstein officiated.

title: Mary Monahan, Michael Kaufman
description: Mary Elizabeth Monahan and Michael David Kaufman were married Saturday at Battell Chapel on the Yale campus in New Haven. The Rev. Robert L. Beloin, a Roman Catholic chaplain, officiated, with Rabbi Richard S. Winer assisting.

title: Marlena Reese and Reginald McKnight
description: Marlena Elizabeth Reese and Reginald Brantley McKnight were married Saturday evening at Lawless Memorial Chapel on the campus of Dillard University in New Orleans. The Rev. Dr. Henry Masters Sr., a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Wallace J. McKnight Sr., an African Methodist Episcopal priest and an uncle of the groom, taking part.

title: Rachel Denny, Laurence Jackson
description: Rachel Eliza Denny and Laurence Arthur Jackson were married Saturday at Linden Terrace in Fort Tryon Park in New York. Kristopher Marx, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Leigh Jones and Christina Shaffer
description: Leigh Alexandra Jones and Christina Beth Shaffer were married Friday at their home in Philadelphia under Pennsylvanias self-uniting marriage statute.

title: Lindsey Goldstein, David Ross
description: Lindsey Beth Goldstein, a daughter of Eileen R. Goldstein and Paul D. Goldstein of Highland Park, Ill., was married Saturday evening to David Lawrence Ross, the son of Jodie L. Ross of Roslyn, N.Y., and Robert M. Ross of Long Beach, N.Y. Rabbi Vernon Kurtz officiated, with Cantor Larry Goller assisting, at the Standard Club, a private social club in Chicago.

title: Amari Coombs, Daniel Kopelow
description: Amari Joia Coombs and Daniel Avi Kopelow were married Saturday at the Chop Shop, an events space in Chicago. The officiant was Teresa Payne, a grandmother of the bride who became a minister of American Marriage Ministries for the event.

title: Dana Cohen, Adam Wolf
description: Dana Michelle Cohen, the daughter of Lisa D. Cohen and Don Cohen of East Brunswick, N.J., is to be married Sunday to Adam Paul Wolf, a son of Meryl J. Wolf of River Vale, N.J., and the late William Wolf. Rabbi Beth Kalisch is to officiate, with Cantor David Frommer taking part at the Stone House at Stirling Ridge, an event space in Warren, N.J.

title: Lauren Elinsky and Robert Meek
description: Lauren Beth Elinsky and Robert Keith Meek were married Saturday evening at Trummers on Main, a restaurant in Clifton, Va. Rabbi Laszlo Berkowits officiated.

title: Karina Conlin, Jonathan Chang
description: Karina Anne Conlin, the daughter of Victoria L. Conlin of McFarland, Wis., was married Saturday to Dr. Jonathan Stanley Chang, a son of Jean W. Chang and Dr. Stanley Chang of New York. The Rev. Connie Engmann, who was ordained at Circle Sanctuary and Pathways of Light Spiritual College, officiated at Monona Terrace, the Frank Lloyd Wright-designed convention center in Madison, Wis.

title: Libra LaGrone, Casius Pealer III
description: Libra Marie LaGrone and Casius Henry Pealer III were married Saturday at the Capital One Pavilion in Woldenberg Riverfront Park in New Orleans. Lloyd Shields, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Stevie Sharpe-Jones, Hakim Surmon
description: Stephanie Marial Sharpe-Jones and Hakim Jamal Surmon were married Saturday at the W Hoboken Hotel in Hoboken, N.J. Sola Winley, a friend of the groom who is a Universal Life minister, officiated at a ceremony that was led by Timothy H. Marshall, a deacon in the Baptist church.

title: Ohio State Rolls Past Michigan State to Bolster Playoff Hopes
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  The players and the coaches of No. 8 Michigan State and No. 14 Ohio State, speaking before Saturdays game, described their teams as mirror images.

title: Challenger Sergey Kovalev Wins Two Titles From Bernard Hopkins
description: ATLANTIC CITY  Until facing Bernard Hopkins on Saturday night, Sergey Kovalev had never fought beyond the eighth round. He had dominated each of his previous opponents. Hopkins, two months short of his 50th birthday, put up a valiant effort and lasted the full 12 rounds, but he could not match the relentlessness of Kovalev.

title: Corrections: November 9, 2014
description: SPORTS

title: Explosions Rock Afghan Capital After Months of Calm
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Three blasts on Sunday morning punctured months of relative calm in Kabul, with the Taliban carrying out at least two attacks, including a suicide bombing inside the citys heavily fortified Police Headquarters that reportedly targeted senior officials there.

title: Afghan Women, Imprisoned
description: Zohreh Soleimani first visited Afghanistan in 2001, when she was among the first journalists to reach the city of Herat after the fall of the Taliban. Some of her co-workers wondered why she got so close to the refugees she photographed, many of whom were sick. But she wanted a more intimate view of a country that had been cut off from the world.

title: Ireland Vies to Remain Silicon Valleys Low-Tax Home Away From Home
description: DUBLIN  In a sprawling conference center on the outskirts of the Irish capital, more than 20,000 people from the global tech industry gathered last week to sign deals and swap contacts.

title: The Daily Gift: Self-Inking Stamps for Custom Correspondence
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: Jeb Bush May Run for President, George W. Bush Says
description: Will Jeb Bush, a former Florida governor, try to become the third member of his immediate family to run for president? His brother calls it a tossup.

title: Keynes Derangement Syndrome
description: One of my favorite quotes in economics comes from Frank Graham, who wrote that disorder is the sole substitute in social science for the controlled experiments of the natural sciences. What he meant was that drastic events, outside the normal run of experience, offer a much better way to test competing theories than day-to-day events, which arent too hard to shoehorn into various dogmas.

title: Economics as a Science, Not
description: From Chris Simss Nobel lecture (pdf):

title: On a Memory-Filled Date, the Fall of the Berlin Wall Stands Front and Center
description: BERLIN  If memory needs places, Berlin was the place this weekend to remember the horror of the Berlin Wall, and the joy of unexpected liberation that accompanied its fall 25 years ago Sunday.

title: 1889: London Celebrates Lord Mayors Day
description: LONDON  The double anniversary of Lord Mayors Day and the Prince of Waless birthday was kept up with more than usual clat to-day [Nov.9]. Indeed, old stagers who have seen the show for twenty years past say nothing has ever been seen to equal the pageant of to-day.

title: Post-Election, Obama Says the Blame Is on Him
description: WASHINGTON  Just days after his party was routed in the midterm elections, President Obama said that he and his White House team had not succeeded in effectively selling the benefits of his policies to the American people, calling it a failure of politics that he must change in the final two years of his presidency.

title: Oscars 2015: A Scrum for Votes at the Governors Awards
description: LOS ANGELES  The movie academys Governors Awards, typically one of the classier prizefests, teetered on the brink Saturday of becoming the Golden Globes, one of the gabbier  and grabbier  galas on Hollywoods annual pre-Oscar circuit.

title: Catalonia Overwhelmingly Votes for Independence From Spain in Straw Poll
description: BARCELONA  Defying legal and political objections from Madrid, more than two million Catalans took part on Sunday in a straw poll on independence that the regions governing politicians have presented as a prelude to breaking away from the rest of Spain.

title: Tensions Mount as Israeli Arabs Protest Police Shooting
description: JERUSALEM  Israels Arab minority observed a one-day general strike on Sunday to protest the fatal police shooting of a young Arab man over the weekend, an event that raised tensions here and prompted charges that the Israeli police resort to force rashly when dealing with Arab citizens.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) WORRICKER: TURKS AND CAICOS Bill Nighy reprises his role as the British spy Johnny Worricker, now on the lam from his former employees on a Caribbean island overrun with New Jersey businessmen investing in a clandestine project. Winona Ryder (above, with Mr. Nighy) plays the groups vampy publicist, and Christopher Walken is an eccentric C.I.A. operative; both befriend Johnny. Then a British philanthropist (Rupert Graves) arrives with an associate (Helena Bonham Carter) whom Johnny knows well  prompting him to revive his cloak-and-dagger lifestyle in this follow-up to Page Eight, Part 1 in a trilogy of thrillers written and directed by the playwright David Hare. Mr. Hare doesnt want to puzzle and intrigue viewers, but to hammer home his outrage over Britains contribution to the invasion of Iraq and the United States secret prisoner rendition program, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times about this Masterpiece Contemporary production. Still, she added, viewers can trust that Mr. Nighy will deliver the most subtle, colorful performance that can be squeezed out of a sermon.

title: Big Hero 6 Leads the Box Office; Interstellar Takes Second
description: It was by no means a crash landing, but Christopher Nolans aggressively promoted Interstellar had some engine trouble nonetheless, losing the weekend box office race to the animated Big Hero 6.

title: With Signature Moves, R&B Romeo Takes a Turn as Casanova
description: Video close-ups showed the sweat pouring down Ushers face just a few songs after he started his set at Madison Square Garden on Friday. And no wonder. From the moment he hit the stage, he had been dancing nonstop: up on his toes, doing tight little twirls, strutting, pointing, making quick stop-start hand gestures, snaking his body from head to foot and matching the angled poses of his dancers, much of it while singing or rapping. It was a show of superhuman precision, control and stamina, of hitting his marks on a heavily trafficked stage, and he was just getting started.

title: Commemorating the Fall of the Berlin Wall
description: On Nov. 9, Germany marked the 25th anniversary of the fall of the wall. Here is a look back at scenes of the wall in decades past.

title: 1939: France Aims for Total Peace, Says Finance Minister
description: France is determined to fight Hitlers totalitarian war until it obtains a totalitarian peace, Paul Reynaud, French Minister of Finance, told a record gathering of members and guests of the American Club of Paris at its weekly luncheon at the Cercle Interalli yesterday.

title: In India, Modi Expands His Council of Ministers
