description: NEW DELHI  Prime Minister Narendra Modi expanded his council of ministers on Sunday in a long-expected move to reward his political allies and spread out some of the work needed to fulfill his agenda.

title: Ina Ginsburg, Arts Patron and Washington Hostess, Dies at 98
description: Ina Ginsburg, who for more than half a century elevated the arts and the art of socializing in the nations capital as a prominent hostess, a fund-raiser and a well-dressed decoder of Washington ways for unelected outsiders, including Andy Warhol and Arnold Schwarzenegger, died on Sunday at her home there. She was 98.

title: St. Francis Manuscripts Headed to U.S., in First Trip Out of Italy in 700 Years
description: TEOLO, Italy  Scattered around the steel table of a monastery in the Veneto region of Northern Italy are manuscripts, one with green, red and intensely blue medieval miniatures of dragons, another adorned with ornate leaves culminating in golden flowers.

title: Dawn of Nuclear Arms, Declassified
description: It was near midnight when John Coster-Mullen, the author of Atom Bombs: The Top Secret Inside Story of Little Boy and Fat Man, was scrutinizing one image among hundreds newly released by Los Alamos, the birthplace of the bomb.

title: Rosberg Edges Out Hamilton in Brazil Grand Prix
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  With two races left in the Formula One season before the Brazilian Grand Prix on Sunday, all Lewis Hamilton needed to do to take his second drivers title in the final race in Abu Dhabi in two weeks was to finish in second place in both races  even if his Mercedes teammate, Nico Rosberg, won both.

title: Philip M. Crane, Former Illinois Congressman and Conservative Leader, Dies at 84
description: Former Representative Philip M. Crane of Illinois, who fought for conservative causes in 35 years in the House and who made a failed run for president in 1980, died on Saturday in Jefferson, Md. He was 84.

title: Sun, Fun And Trouble In Brazil
description: Tourists of the world: Stay home.

title: Excerpt: The Band Wagon
description: Brian Stokes Mitchell and Tony Sheldon sing I Guess Ill Have to Change My Plan from the Encores! production of The Band Wagon, at City Center.

title: New HealthCare.gov Opens Early to Allow for Review of Plans
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Sunday that consumers could shop for health insurance and compare their options on HealthCare.gov starting Monday, even before the open enrollment period formally begins five days later.

title: Finally, Against Steelers, Jets Look Unlike Themselves
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Imagine being sequestered for the last nine weeks, with no access to television or smartphones or the news media, and imagine that the first act of re-entry involved attending the Jets game Sunday at MetLife Stadium.

title: Michael Barker Elected Co-Chairman of Museum of the Moving Image
description: Michael Barker, who has been a cinematic tastemaker as a founder and co-president of Sony Pictures Classics, will join the Museum of the Moving Image as co-chairman of its board of trustees, the museum plans to announce on Monday. He succeeds Herbert S. Schlosser, the former NBC president and chief executive, who served as the chairman beginning in 1985, and became co-chairman, in 2013, with Ivan L. Lustig.

title: Men in Towels on the Prowl and Other Steamy Scenes From the Sauna
description: LONDON  It is astonishing to note how the range of British dance theater has changed and grown over recent decades. In 1980, there were virtually no one-choreographer troupes or seasons other than Lindsay Kemps; almost every dance ensemble, small or large, was a repertory company. Now, the names Richard Alston, Matthew Bourne, Russell Maliphant, Wayne McGregor and Lloyd Newson are just the most internationally known of a larger number of British or British-based choreographers with their own dance collectives; and some of these have won as much recognition in the world of theater as that of dance.

title: Fricks Plan for Expansion Faces Fight Over Loss of Garden
description: Officials at the Frick Collection knew their plan to build a six-story addition to a beloved, landmark, jewel-box museum would draw detractors. But leaders of that Fifth Avenue museum say they didnt expect it to get so intense so fast.

title: Country Star Strides Back Onto the Stage
description: More than a decade ago, Garth Brooks did the most admirable thing any successful performer can do: He walked away.

title: From Eerie Shards to Vivid Emotion
description: Encores in opera houses are different than they are in concert halls, where artists usually respond to ovations by showing off something new. In opera, though, excited audiences will demand a bis  a repeat of an aria thats gone particularly well.

title: Giving Factory Faces Their Own Score
description: Echoes of the Velvet Underground filled Exposed: Songs for Unseen Warhol Films on Friday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music: 15 silent short films by Andy Warhol from 1963 to 66, rediscovered by the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh and set to live new music. The films offered a gallery of Warhol strategies  including the unadorned encounters with a camera that he called screen tests  and 1960s faces, many of them famous.

title: Tig Notaro Faces Medical Emergency
description: The comedian Tig Notaro canceled shows in Boston and Denver over the weekend because of an unspecified medical emergency, according to promoters of the performances. Notes on the Facebook accounts of the Wilbur Theater in Boston, where Ms. Notaro was scheduled to perform on Saturday, and AEG Live Rocky Mountains, which promoted Sundays event in Denver, said that tickets would be refunded and the shows rescheduled. Tig is dealing with a medical emergency and is being hospitalized, a post on the AEG Live Rocky Mountain account said. She will be all right but has to cancel the show tonight. Calls and emails to Ms. Notaros manager were not returned on Sunday. Ms. Notaro has publicly battled breast cancer, working her diagnosis into her 2012 comedy routine; she received a 2013 Grammy nomination for her comedy album Live. She performed at the New York Comedy Festival on Thursday, and received critical praise for her act. Ms. Notaro performed most of the show topless, revealing scars from a double mastectomy with no reconstruction. The next stop on her Boyish Girl Interrupted tour is Portland, Ore. As of Sunday afternoon, that sold-out performance was still scheduled for Wednesday night.

title: Globe-Trotter Dashes Into a Challenge
description: DRESDEN, Germany  Alexei Ratmanskys new Tanzsuite, created in June for the Semperoper Ballett here, is breathtakingly inventive, formally rigorous and gorgeously dancey. From the opening moments, as a bank of lights ascends to form a modernist chandelier above the neat lines of dancers, to the final heart-in-mouth swirled lift, the ballet captivates. As you watch, you feel slightly desperate about continually losing sight of the elusive felicities onstage.

title: A Midcentury Agitator, Boxing Left and Right
description: He was suspicious of characters like me, Irving Howe recalled of a genteel Princeton literary scholar he knew in the late 1940s. New York street fighters likely to cause trouble and, in any case, too political.

title: Depicting a Mans World With One Key Absence
description: You know what I think happens? Sebastian Junger says in his new documentary, The Last Patrol (Monday night on HBO). I think men protect women, and women protect children. Expanding on his idea, he says of the 2012 theater shooting in Aurora, Colo.  where several men died shielding their girlfriends  not one woman stepped in front of a man, because thats not their job.

title: Oral History Project at Primary Stages
description: The theater company Primary Stages announced on Sunday that it would move forward with its Off Broadway Oral History Project, which seeks to create a video archive of interviews with the actors, directors, designers, producers, playwrights and theater founders who have participated in Off and Off Off Broadway since World War II. The project is the brainchild of Casey Childs, the Primary Stages founder, who said he considered the idea for years after noticing a lack of firsthand information about this part of the theater world. Since July, Mr. Childs, the director Sally Plass and a team of interns have recorded about 50 hours of interviews with 20 Off Broadway leaders, including the actors Fyvush Finkel and Arthur French, the Chelsea Theater Center founder Robert Kalfin, the Playwrights Horizons founder Robert Moss and the Pan Asian Repertory Theater founder Tisa Chang. Mr. Childs said the goal was to record at least 100 interviews to be made available to the public online in the next six to 12 months. Its important to do because these people are dying every day, Mr. Childs said in a phone interview. Its a race against the clock, but were getting them. He said that he was in talks with several universities and foundations to host the videos but that it was too early to name the candidates.

title: Obstacles Limit Targets and Pace of Strikes on ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  More than three months into the American-led air campaign in Iraq and Syria, commanders are challenged by spotty intelligence, poor weather and an Iraqi Army that is only now starting to go on the offensive against the Islamic State, meaning that warplanes are mostly limited to hitting pop-up targets of opportunity.

title: Pooh Illustrations to Be Auctioned
description: How many honey pots could a silly old bear fill if he had 100,000 British pounds, or roughly $159,000? Thats the low estimate for an original illustration from A. A. Milnes 1928 book The House at Pooh Corner to be sold at Sothebys London next month. The drawing, signed by the artist E. H. Shepard, depicts Winnie-the-Pooh playing a game of Poohsticks on a bridge with Christopher Robin and Piglet. It has been part of a private collection since 1975, according to the Sothebys London sale catalog. The illustration is expected to fetch 100,000 to 150,000, or about $159,000 to $238,000, and is one of several drawings by Shepard that the auction house will feature at its English Literature, History, Childrens Books and Illustration sale on Dec. 9. Other items include drawings by Beatrix Potter and Edmund Dulac, a copy of Peter Pan signed by J. M. Barrie, and presentation copies of uncorrected Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets proofs signed by J. K. Rowling. Pooh has proved to be a lucrative draw at previous auctions. In November 2008, an original Shepard sketch of Pooh and friends sold for about $50,100 at a Bonhams auction. A month later, the Stanley J. Seeger and Christopher Cone collection of Shepards original drawings for the Winnie-the-Pooh books brought in about $1.97 million at a Sothebys London auction.

title: Imaginative Auction at the Rosenblum Teams
description: In bridge, which is the larger, the number of possible deals or the number of possible auctions? (Answer at the end.)

title: Archipelago Component
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  This weeks Monday through Thursday puzzles were part of the fourth annual Arlington (Va.) Puzzle Tournament. Will Shortz explains more about this and the worthy causes he donates puzzles to farther below.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

title: Communities Fight State Laws That Can Divide Broadband Access
description: WILSON, N.C.  Jason Bissette could throw a sweet potato from his office here in eastern North Carolina, where he and his family oversee nearly 3,000 acres, to their newest barn.

title: Ebolas Mystery: One Boy Lives, Another Dies
description: SUAKOKO, Liberia  Soon after he lost his parents to Ebola, Junior Samuel, 8, slumped in a plastic chair inside a treatment center here, listless, feverish and racked with aches. Within a day, he began bleeding from his gums, a particularly ominous sign.

title: With All-Star Benched for Lax Defense, the Nets Hang On
description: Orlandos Nikola Vucevic was picking and popping and draining jump shots with aplomb Sunday afternoon, so Nets Coach Lionel Hollins had a decision to make.

title: Modern Beer Culture Through a 19th-Century Lens
description: Documenting Denvers resurgent craft brewing culture using an appropriately old-fashioned technology: wet plate collodion, or tintype photography.

title: The Crazy Puppy and the Flying Boy
The Soul of Cowardice
A Veteran Actors Backstage Fight for Affordable Health Care
description: Richard E. Waits was lying in bed hours before his audition, envisioning his metamorphosis. He closed his eyes and imagined his easy stride transformed into a jaunty strut, his smooth baritone sinking into a gravely rasp.

title: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Kings vs. Mavericks
description: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

title: Making Chemistry Green
description: FOR nearly 40 years, the Food and Drug Administration has wrestled with regulating the chemicals triclosan and triclocarban as they have become among the worlds most ubiquitous environmental contaminants. Designed to kill bacteria, they have been added to antibacterial soaps, cosmetics and other consumer products despite longstanding concerns about their impacts on humans and the environment.

title: Glamours Girl Project Will Focus on Sending Girls to School
description: On Monday night at its annual Women of the Year Awards dinner, Glamour is set to announce the Girl Project, a collaboration with four nonprofits to raise money for girls to help them attend secondary school. Cindi Leive, Glamours editor in chief, said that the magazine started this initiative in part because of recent world events, including the girls kidnapped from their school in Nigeria and the many schools damaged in Gaza.

title: Obamas Record on Nuclear Arms
Laying Out a Case for Deporting Human Rights Abusers
description: As clichs go, the one about the long arm of the law is moth-eaten. But the law does in fact have a reach, and it can extend far. In recent years, it has stretched out to grab foreign nationals who found refuge in the United States after committing or sanctioning political murder, torture and other human rights abuses in their home countries. Hundreds of them have been sent packing, including government officials and thuggish factotums from places with troubled pasts, like Rwanda, Peru, Bosnia, Argentina, Haiti, Guatemala and Liberia. Some former guards at Nazi death camps have been dispatched to Germany and other European countries.

title: Three Are Struck by a Car in Queens, and One Dies
description: A man was killed and two women were injured after a car driven by another man struck them on Saturday in Queens, one of several deadly events in the borough that night.

title: Killed in El Salvador: An American Story
description: In 1980, the murder of four American churchwomen focused attention on the United States involvement in El Salvador. Nearly 35 years later, the case continues to take surprising turns.

title: Women in Science: Measuring the Progress
PBS to Stream Live Coverage of Miami Book Fair
description: PBS is venturing into territory that C-Spans Book TV has previously had largely to itself, with plans to stream live coverage of three days of Miami Dade Colleges Miami Book Fair International in November.

title: Pfizers Missouri Case
description: To the Editor:

title: College Help for the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Avoid Hitting Deer
description: To the Editor:

title: Yale Harassment Case
Chasing Relevancy at Any Cost, Even Free
description: DUBLIN  It took nearly 30 years for The Joshua Tree, the 1987 album that was U2s breakout ticket to megastardom, to reach 30 million people. Songs of Innocence, which was released on Sept. 9 as part of the unveiling of the iPhone 6, pulled that off in three weeks. Bono, the bands leader, explained as much to the packed audience at the Web Summit here, saying that 100 million people had listened to a song or two and that 30 million people had listened to the whole album.

title: Ethics Complaint Filed Against Law Firm
description: An ethics complaint filed against the Washington-based law firm Dickstein Shapiro accuses it of violating state law by not registering as a lobbying firm in Florida, even though it has approached the office of Attorney General Pam Bondi of Florida on policy matters.

title: The Strength or Weakness of the Shadowy Jihadist Group ISIS
description: Ben Hubbard, a Middle East correspondent, reported this week that the Islamic States momentum appears to be stalling and that the group may not be as powerful as it once appeared. We asked him how he has tracked the growth of the terrorist organization.

title: What Became of Grouchos Duck
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Obama Opposition
description: The president came to Washington thinking he could change Washington, make it better, unite it and the nation. He was wrong. As he ascended, the tone of political discourse descended, as much because of who he was as what he did.

title: As Knicks Derek Fisher Finds, Coachings Burdens Are Heavy
description: A number of years ago, I was pressed into emergency service as the coach of my daughters team in the Greenwich House Girls Basketball League.

title: Death by Typo
description: My parents used to own a small house with a large backyard, in which my mother cultivated a beautiful garden. At some point, however  I dont remember why  my father looked at the official deed defining their property, and received a shock. According to the text, the Krugman lot wasnt a rough rectangle; it was a triangle more than a hundred feet long but only around a yard wide at the base.

title: Bernard Hopkins Weighs Retirement but Still Plans to Train
description: ATLANTIC CITY  As he walked out of Boardwalk Hall shortly after 2 a.m. Sunday, Bernard Hopkins, the 49-year-old fighter known for his dedication, was already thinking about his next workout. He planned to head to Joe Hand gym in Philadelphia, his hometown, on Monday for what he calls a shake out session, which includes a fitness routine but no boxing-related activities.

title: With High Maintenance, Vimeo Invests in Original Content
description: High Maintenance, a web series on Vimeo about the many customers of a Brooklyn marijuana dealer, has won a devoted following and plenty of critical acclaim. Each of its first 13 episodes has been watched hundreds of thousands of times. The New Yorker raved that the show, freed of the constraints of formulas imposed by television schedules, radiates new ideas about storytelling.

title: Wall Streets Bonus Season Not Likely to Be Filled With Joy, Survey Finds
description: A few corners of Wall Street are expecting big bonuses, but for most of the industry it is likely to be a disappointing year.

title: Penguins Shake Off Playoff Failure
description: If ever there was a prelude for a bad season for the Pittsburgh Penguins, last spring should have been it: a three-games-to-one series lead blown against the Rangers, the fifth straight season the Penguins were ousted from the playoffs by a lower-seeded opponent; the subsequent firing of their general manager and coach; open questioning of Sidney Crosbys leadership all summer.

title: Australia Challenges Use of Unpaid Internships
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Stuart Cottles first unpaid internship here landed him on the Great Gatsby movie set. From there he headed to New York, where he worked on high-end fashion set designs.

title: Ernie Vandeweghe, Knick and Physician, Dies at 86
description: Ernie Vandeweghe, a leading Knicks player of the early 1950s while he was simultaneously embarking on a career as a physician, and later the patriarch of a three-generation family of athletes, died on Saturday at his home in Laguna Beach, Calif. He was 86.

title: Round Two for Gov. Cuomo
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo is likely to find his next four years in office a lot harder than his first term. With Republicans more solidly in control of the State Senate, his promise Tuesday night to make Albany the progressive capital of the nation sounds more challenging than ever.

title: Push to Bring Ex-Convicts and Families Together Lags
description: More than a year after New York City started a program designed to reunite up to 150 former prisoners with their families in public housing, only seven people have successfully completed the process.

title: New York City Seeks to Put Names to Unidentified Bodies
description: Traditionally, New York City officials have preferred not to draw attention to the unidentified bodies that pass through city morgues and receive public burials in mass graves on Hart Island, off the coast of the Bronx.

title: On the Hunt for Wall St. Hackers, but Not the Spotlight
description: Lawrence Baldwin is a dark hero of the Internet whom you have probably never heard of  and for good reason.

title: Chinas New Type of Ties Fails to Sway Obama
description: BEIJING  When Xi Jinping stood next to Hillary Rodham Clinton and addressed a high-powered lunch audience on the seventh floor of the State Department nearly three years ago, he was still Chinas vice president and only the heir apparent to the Communist Party leadership. But even during that visit he spoke expansively of forging a new type of great power relations with the United States.

title: A Prohibition Holdout Approves Liquor Sales
description: BRIDGEWATER, Conn.  Forget last weeks small-potato questions of who should govern or represent the people of Connecticut.

title: Steelers Fans Descend, Terrible Towels in Tow, but Find Little to Wave About
description: Last week, the Steelers urged their fans to attend the teams road game at MetLife Stadium on Sunday against the hapless Jets. They even started a Twitter campaign, BlackOutTheBigApple, to encourage fans to wear the teams black jerseys.

title: Torn Apart by Storm, a Tribute to Veterans Is Pieced Together Again
description: VILONIA, Ark.  The late April tornado screamed for 41 miles across Arkansas, but its toll was especially vicious here: Just three years after another storm had leveled Vilonia, this city was flattened anew.

title: Kevin Harvick Earns Last Spot in Sprint Cup Championship
description: AVONDALE, Ariz.  The second-to-last race of the Nascar season produced a track-record 12 caution flags, which was fitting. In recent weeks, as the number of contenders for the Sprint Cup Series championship was winnowed to four, from 16, the debris field from the aggression that has long fueled the sport widened.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Police Use Department Wish List When Deciding Which Assets to Seize
description: The seminars offered police officers some useful tips on seizing property from suspected criminals. Dont bother with jewelry (too hard to dispose of) and computers (everybodys got one already), the experts counseled. Do go after flat screen TVs, cash and cars. Especially nice cars.

title: Car Magazines Expand Video Offerings With Help From a YouTube Channel
description: TWO magazines that were covering cars when Cadillacs sported prodigious tail fins are teaming with a newcomer in the realm of automotive media for a digital content and advertising partnership.

title: Surprising for Three Quarters, the Giants Wither in the Fourth
description: SEATTLE  With flagging hopes, waning confidence and deteriorating solidarity, the Giants visited Seattle on Sunday, an unlikely place for the upset victory that would resurrect a season spiraling toward a non-postseason oblivion.

title: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Gives North Korea the Silent Treatment
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama took the unusual step of sending the nations top spy, instead of a senior diplomat, to win the release of two American prisoners in North Korea, administration officials said Sunday, specifically to signal that he would not reward the North with sanctions relief or a new round of negotiations in return for the freedom of the latest Americans to be locked up during visits to the isolated nation.

title: States Listen as Parents Give Rampant Testing an F
description: ROYAL PALM BEACH, Fla.  Florida embraced the school accountability movement early and enthusiastically, but that was hard to remember at a parent meeting in a high school auditorium here not long ago.

title: Obama Arrives in China on Trip With Complex Agenda
description: BEIJING  President Obama arrived here on Monday morning for a three-day visit that will capture the complexities of the United States-China relationship: the tensions of a rising power confronting an established one, as well as the promise that the worlds two largest economies could find common cause on issues like climate change.

title: In Cuba, Misadventures in Regime Change
description: In 1996, spurred by an appetite for revenge, American lawmakers passed a bill spelling out a strategy to overthrow the government in Havana and assist the Cuban people in regaining their freedom. The Helms-Burton Act, signed into law by President Bill Clinton shortly after Cuba shot down two small civilian American planes, has served as the foundation for the $264 million the United States has spent in the last 18 years trying to instigate democratic reforms on the island.

title: En Cuba, desventuras al intentar derrocar un rgimen
description: En 1996, motivados por un apetito de venganza, legisladores estadounidenses aprobaron un proyecto de ley promulgando una estrategia para derrocar el Gobierno de La Habana y asistir al pueblo cubano a recobrar su libertad. La Ley Helms-Burton, aprobada por el Presidente Clinton, semanas despus de que Cuba derrib dos avionetas civiles estadounidenses, ha servido como fundamento para que el Gobierno norteamericano gastara $264 millones de dlares, durante los ltimos 18 aos, en un intento por instigar reformas democrticas en la isla.

title: Link Shows How Lobby Firm Cultivates Influence
description: Attorney General Pam Bondi of Florida, after taking a free ride on a chartered jet last year to a resort island far from her home state, made an unusual offer to one of the corporate lawyers from Washington who helped foot the bill: an invitation to stay at her Tampa home while recuperating from surgery.

title: John V. Shields Jr., Who Turned Trader Joes Into National Chain, Dies at 82
description: John V. Shields Jr., a retail executive who transformed Trader Joes from a quirky Southern California grocery store chain into a billion-dollar enterprise with dozens of still-quirky but uniformly organized grocery stores across the country, died on Oct. 31 in Thousand Oaks, Calif. He was 82.

title: No Longer Business as Usual in China
description: China is changing the rule book for business, forcing multinational companies to figure out how to play a new game or risk losing out on the worlds second-largest economy.

title: Disney Film Boss Alan Horn Finds Success After Ouster by Warner
description: BURBANK, Calif.  Alan F. Horn was pushed out by Warner Brothers in 2011 after a celebrated run as its film chief  too old, too out of touch, he was told. Toddle off into a happy retirement, he was advised. Read a book.

title: Back to School, With Helping Others as Her Goal
description: Psychological and financial battles nearly broke up Caridad Manzuetas family, derailed her ambitions and left her dead. She is 20 years old.

title: Show Within a Show, Within a Memory
description: An urgent request to the helium suppliers of New York: Can you please deliver as many canisters of the stuff as you can spare to City Center, posthaste? Theres a big, bright balloon of a show there that just wont inflate. Even hot air would be welcome, in a pinch.

title: Scientists, and Universes Odd Behavior, Are Recognized With $3 Million Prizes
description: Who knew there was so much money in dark energy?

title: The Newsroom Recap: In the Premiere, a Bit of Self-Control, for Will and for Aaron Sorkin
description: Season 3, Episode 20, Boston

title: Out of Dust and Debris, a New Jewel Rises
description: The glass-and-steel prism called Fulton Center began life as a public-transit labyrinth, a spaghetti-bowl tangle of dimly-lit corridors, narrow switchbacks and baffling signage cobbled together out of five subway stations built in the early 1900s.

title: Chinas Stealth Fighter, U.S. Retail Sales and Eurozone Growth
description: CHINESE STEALTH FIGHTER EXPECTED TO MAKE DEBUT

title: In Ukraine, Shelling and Convoys of Armed Trucks Threaten Cease-Fire
description: MOSCOW  A shaky cease-fire in eastern Ukraine looked ever more tenuous on Sunday as European monitors confirmed reports of unmarked military vehicles driving through rebel-held territory while Donetsk, the regions biggest city, endured a nightlong artillery battle.

title: Cubicles Rise in a Brave New World of Publishing
description: Michael Pietsch was given his first private office when he became an editor at Charles Scribners Sons 30 years ago.

title: Can the Red Tide Be Turned Back?
Marijuana May Mean Ticket, Not Arrest, in New York City
description: The New York Police Department, which has been arresting tens of thousands of people a year for low-level marijuana possession, is poised to stop making such arrests and to issue tickets instead, according to law enforcement officials.

title: Judgment Awaits for Crew of South Korea Ferry
description: GWANGJU, South Korea  The defendants, 13 men and two women wearing green prison uniforms, entered a brightly lit courtroom last month and sat in two rows along a side wall. From the bench, three judges in black robes convened the 29th session of a trial to determine if they were guilty of mass murder and other crimes.

title: The Good Wife Recap: Is Alicia Too Entitled?
description: Season 6, Episode 8: Red Zone

title: The Affair Recap: Do Noah and Alison Have Chemistry?
description: Season 1, Episode 5

title: Climate Tools Seek to Bend Natures Path
description: UTRECHT, the Netherlands  The solution to global warming, Olaf Schuiling says, lies beneath our feet.

title: Popular Demand
description: Procter & Gamble, the consumer products giant that makes items as varied as razors and household cleaners, led advertising spenders in the third quarter, but consumer products as a whole does not dominate.

title: South Korea and China Reach Trade Accord
description: SEOUL, South Korea  China and South Korea declared on Monday that they had reached a trade agreement that would further deepen their economic ties by removing tariffs on more than 90 percent of goods traded between the two global export giants over the next 20 years, officials here said.

title: Poetic Justice
description: Finally for evening, a mood of natural elegance with loose, unadorned dresses and flat sandals.

title: The Knowledge, Londons Legendary Taxi-Driver Test, Puts Up a Fight in the Age of GPS
description: The examination to become a London cabby is possibly the most difficult test in the world  demanding years of study to memorize the labyrinthine citys 25,000 streets and any business or landmark on them. As GPS and Uber imperil this tradition, is there an argument for learning as an end in itself?

title: An Italian Designer Branches Out
description: Osanna Viscontis new collection of cast-bronze furniture takes its inspiration from forms found in nature, much like the coveted jewelry she creates with the help of her daughter, Madina.

title: Detergent Pods Pose Risk to Children, Study Finds
description: Since the introduction of colorful, single-load packets of laundry detergent in 2012 through the end of 2013, more than 17,000 children under age 6 ate or inhaled the contents or squirted concentrated liquid from a packet into their eyes, researchers reported Monday.

title: Word of the Day | condole
description: condole \kn-dol\ verb

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 10 P.M. (13) ICE WARRIORS: USA SLED HOCKEY They call it muderball on blades: Players with physical disabilities duke it out with sticks and the serrated picks used to propel their sleds across the ice, as they try to get a puck into the net. This documentary follows the 2014 United States Paralympic sled hockey team  including four servicemen wounded in Iraq and Afghanistan, and Brody Roybal (above)  as it trains for and competes in the Winter Games in Sochi, Russia.

title: For China and Japan, a New Effort to Improve Relations Produces a Chilly Scene
description: BEIJING  The meeting lasted just 25 minutes, less than half the time usually given to formal encounters between heads of government. Their national flags, often the backdrop for such meetings, were conspicuously absent. Neither man so much as mentioned the tiny islands in the East China Sea that are a major point of friction between their countries.

title: Corrections: November 10, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: G.O.P. Is Making Progress Toward Presidency but Is Still Playing Catch-Up
description: After five of six presidential elections in which the Republicans have lost the popular vote, this years midterm elections point toward a plausible Republican path to winning the White House.

title: Financial Stability Board to Propose Stricter Capital Rules for Global Banks
description: FRANKFURT  The Financial Stability Board, a panel made up of central bankers, finance officials and top regulators from the worlds largest economies, plans to announce proposals Monday that would double the amount of money that large banks would be required to have on hand to absorb losses.

title: Homeland Recap: Yes, That Was Only a Drug-Fueled Hallucination
description: Season 4, Episode 7, Redux

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: I hated that corner office. It was just incredibly isolating.

title: China Builds Financial Ties to Neighbors
description: HONG KONG  China unveiled a series of measures on Monday aimed at strengthening financial ties with neighboring nations  and potentially weakening Asias ties to the United States.

title: Dismay From China After Mexico Cancels High-Speed Rail Bid
description: Mexicos decision to cancel a Chinese-led bid to build a high-speed rail system has triggered reactions ranging from surprise to scorn in China, which has prided itself on the rapid expansion of its own rail network and on bringing that technology to other countries.

title: Militant Group in Egypt Vows Loyalty to ISIS
description: CAIRO  They have slaughtered hundreds of Egyptian soldiers and police officers, recruited experienced fighters and staged increasingly sophisticated raids from the Western desert to the Sinai Peninsula. They have beheaded informants and killed an American in a carjacking, say Western officials familiar with intelligence reports.

title: 6 Qs About the News | 25 Years After the Fall of the Berlin Wall
description: In Where the Berlin Wall Stood, Lights Now Illuminate, Melissa Eddy writes about the commemoration of the 25th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall.

title: Researchers Detail a Spike in NATO-Russia Close Calls
description: LONDON  A Scandinavian passenger jet heading for Rome lifts off from Copenhagen with 132 passengers on board. Only the alertness of its crew prevents a midair collision with a Russian surveillance plane that had not transmitted its position.

title: Test Yourself | Mike the Tiger, L.S.U. Mascot
description: Below are the first six paragraphs of the Nov. 9 article The Mascot Will Sit This One Out, Thanks.

title: Magnums Archive of Once-Orphaned Photos
description: One of the stranger parts of being a working photographer is that no matter how widely published or successful you are, the vast majority of your images are never seen by anyone else.

title: How Often Do You Watch a Television Show When It Originally Airs?
description: Watching shows whenever we like, and watching them on the screen we choose, is something many of us take for granted.

title: Blasts Kill 10 Afghan Police Officers, Including a Top Commander
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two separate bombings on Monday killed at least 10 Afghan police officers, including a prominent commander, according to Afghan officials.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: Fultons Flashy First Day
description: Good morning on this mild Monday.

title: Talks in India to Focus on Link Between Hygiene and Growth
description: NEW DELHI  Responding to new research that links childhood malnutrition with poor sanitation, Unicef began a conference here Monday to explore ways of encouraging better hygiene so children can avoid the devastating consequences of stunting.

title: Daily Report: Fighting State Laws That Can Limit Access to High-Speed Web
description: Nineteen states have laws that limit municipalities from building or expanding high-speed Internet service networks, Edward Wyatt reports. The reason behind those laws, supporters say, is to limit taxpayer exposure to projects that at times fail and for which there may be little demand.

title: Shortage of Medicaid Doctors? Not if You Ask Patients
description: One longstanding concern about Medicaid is that too few doctors will accept it, because it tends to pay providers less generously than private plans do. This concern shows up in news articles about Medicaid, driven by evidence from doctors offices. But if you ask Medicaid enrollees directly, they reveal that access to primary care is comparable to that for private plans.

title: Pondering Dot Earths Path After Seven Years and 2,500 Posts
description: In the seven years since I used a whiteboard to shape the themes and design of Dot Earth with The Timess content strategist and blog specialist,Jeremy Zilar, Ive usedthis platform to explore humanitys puberty-like growth spurt, growing pains and promising prospects through 2,500 posts. As many readers probably recognize, the flow here is more an over-the-shoulder view of me learning than a series of declarations and distillations. Given the complexity and uncertainty attending most of the issues I deal with  particularly global warming  I think this approach is the best fit.

title: HGGC to Buy Control of Survey Sampling International
description: HGGC, a middle-market private equity firm, announced on Monday that it had bought a majority stake in Survey Sampling International, jumping into the business of providing corporate surveys.

title: Today in Politics
description: For Next Steps, Democrats Debate Treading Lightly

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 10, 2014
description: Updated: Nov. 11, 2014

title: Introducing Laura Zander, a Business Owner Trying to Figure Out Social Media
description: In 2001, my husband and I ditched the dot-com rat race of Silicon Valley for a more peaceful life in the mountains of Lake Tahoe. As burned-out software engineers, we had grand visions of trading our keyboards for snowboards, our motorcycles for bicycles, and taking the trail instead of taking BART. To help support our new lifestyle, we invested our savings ($30,000) and opened Jimmy Beans Wool, a 500 square-foot yarn shop in Reno, Nev.

title: Marquis Hill Wins the Thelonious Monk Competition
description: The winner of the 2014 Thelonious Monk International Trumpet Competition is Marquis Hill. Raised on the south side of Chicago, Mr. Hill, 27, is a veteran of that citys jazz scene and a product of its institutions  he earned a masters degree in jazz pedagogy from DePaul University and plays in the Chicago Jazz Orchestra. Hes currently a teaching associate at the University of Illinois at Chicago, and has released several albums on independent labels.

title: Not-So-Breitbart
description: The wonderful folks at Breitbart have managed a twofer. First they misidentified Obamas pick for Attorney General; then they issued a correction for the ages. Just click on the link. (The post has finally been taken down.)

title: Palestinians Are Suspected as 2 Israelis Die in Knife Attacks
description: JERUSALEM  An Israeli soldier and a woman were killed on Monday in separate stabbing attacks that the authorities attributed to Palestinian men, rattling Israelis and intensifying the political pressure on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: The Mysterious Fed
description: As usual, my inbox is full of speculations about when the Fed will raise interest rates. June 2015? Earlier? Has it already waited too long?

title: Morning Agenda: Lackluster Bonus Season Looms
description: Some corners of Wall Street are expecting big bonuses, but for most of the industry, it will probably be a disappointing year, Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook. The year-end payouts could drop as much as 10 percent for the trading desks and hedge funds that not long ago were the centers of gravity on Wall Street, according to an annual survey by the compensation consulting firm Johnson Associates scheduled for release on Monday.

title: Applying the Knowledge
description: Matt McCabe calls-over a route to demonstrate just how many turns a London cabbie must take to get from Point A to Point B.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Microsofts Nadella Talks About the Future of Office
description: REDMOND, Wash.  Getting stuff done.

title: Air Quality App Forced to Stop Providing Data From U.S. Embassy
description: As a crush of world leaders, including President Obama, descended on the often smog-laden Chinese capital Monday morning, organizers of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum were most likely relieved by the clearish skies and relatively good air quality readings that started off the day.

title: Waiting for the Grand Jurys Ruling: Tension Simmers After a Police Shooting
description: A grand jury decision is expected soon on whether to indict the police officer who shot an unarmed black teenager in Ferguson, Mo., last August, inciting days of sometimes violent protest and putting the St. Louis suburb at the center of a national debate over police and race.

title: G.M. Ordered a Half-Million Replacement Switches 2 Months Before Recall
description: Nearly two months before notifying federal regulators and the public that it was recalling cars with a dangerously defective ignition switch, General Motors placed an urgent order for 500,000 replacement switches, emails to its supplier Delphi Automotive show.

title: Calvin Klein Gets a Plus-Size Controversy
description: In one of the more extreme, but socially revealing, games of Twitter telephone I have witnessed, the social media platform exploded on Sunday (HLNtvs words, not mine, though they are not inaccurate) over a Calvin Klein ad that is part of the brands Perfectly Fit underwear campaign and features a not-entirely-plus-size model named Myla Dalbesio.

title: Saving Ourselves From Not Saving
description: Americans arent saving enough.

title: Hellmanns Maker Sues Company Over Its Just Mayo Substitute Mayonnaise
description: Is mayo mayonnaise if it doesnt contain eggs?

title: First Draft Focus: Obama in China
description: Obama Arrives in China on Trip With Complex Agenda

title: Safra Group to Acquire Gherkin Building in London
description: LONDON  The private investment firm Safra, controlled by the billionaire Joseph Safra, agreed on Monday to acquire one of Londons tallest buildings, affectionately known as the Gherkin for its resemblance to a pickle.

title: Bomb at School in Nigeria Kills Nearly 50 Boys
description: CONAKRY, Guinea  A suicide attacker disguised as a student detonated a bomb at a boarding school in northern Nigeria on Monday morning, killing nearly 50 boys who were between 10 and 20 years old, officials and witnesses said.

title: A Message of Hope
description: On Slate, commenter Leif Leifnephewson on the likelihood that Sen. James Hoax Inhofe is likely to chair the Environment and Public Works Committee:

title: Obama Says Internet Service Should Be Treated as a Utility
description: President Obama released a statement today arguing that the Federal Communications Commission should reclassify broadband Internet access as a telecommunications service, which would effectively give the federal government the authority to protect net neutrality.

title: Obama Asks F.C.C. to Adopt Tough Net Neutrality Rules
description: WASHINGTON  In his most direct effort yet to influence the debate about the Internets future, President Obama said on Monday that a free and open Internet was as critical to Americans lives as electricity and telephone service and should be regulated like those utilities to protect consumers.

title: Retesting Breast Cancer Axioms
description: American women face conflicting advice about whether to be screened for breast cancer, at what age and how often. The decisions they make are often more strongly influenced by fear or a friends experience than by a thorough understanding of the benefits and risks of mammography.

title: Dendreon, Maker of Prostate Cancer Drug Provenge, Files for Bankruptcy
description: Dendreon, the biotechnology firm whose innovative treatment for prostate cancer was once predicted to become a blockbuster, filed for bankruptcy protection on Monday after sales of the drug fell way short of expectations and the company could not pay a huge debt coming due.

title: In Quick Response, Mali Thwarts an Ebola Outbreak
description: Using old-fashioned detective work, public health workers in Mali, one of the worlds poorest nations, working with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the World Health Organization, tracked and quarantined 108 people in two cities and a few roadside towns who may have had contact with a 2-year-old girl from Guinea who died of Ebola on Oct. 24.

title: Obamas Focus in China Is on Leader, Not Public
description: BEIJING  President Obama is in China for less than three days this week, but he is seeing a great deal of President Xi Jinping.

title: Domestic Violence Drives Up New York Shelter Population as Housing Options Are Scarce
description: First came Hurricane Sandy, which left her homeless for a time.

title: Obamas Net Neutrality Plan
description: President Obama outlined his suggestions to maintain an open Internet and urged the Federal Communications Commission to implement the strongest possible rules to protect it.

title: Taking the Knowledge Test: An Animation
description: As Knowledge candidates progress through the test, the posterior hippocampus, the area of the brain known to be important for memory, grows and grows.

title: ScienceTake | Jellyfish Buffet
description: Scavengers in the deep ocean are more fond of jellyfish than anyone realized.

title: Coalition Challenges Selection of Judges in Same-Sex Marriage Case
description: WASHINGTON  When a three-judge panel of the federal appeals court in California struck down bans last month on same-sex marriage in Idaho and Nevada, it was no surprise. The panel included two of the courts leading liberals.

title: A Surprising Appetite for Dead Jellyfish
description: In an ocean popularity contest, jellyfish would rank near the bottom. They sting. Their increasing population blooms clog power plant intakes, kill farmed salmon and frighten swimmers. Experts warn of the jellification of the oceans.

title: Pieces of John Lennons Guitar Up for Auction
description: Instruments owned by rock stars can command high prices when they come up for auction, particularly those used at significant performances or recording sessions. But pieces of instruments? That part of the market will be tested on Nov. 23, when Tracks, a London collectors shop that has become a force in rock memorabilia auctions, will auction the original pick guard and machine heads (the tuning peg mechanisms) from one of John Lennons guitars at Le Mridien Hotel, in London.

title: 1914: City of Light to Return
description: Paris is on the eve of becoming once again the City of Light and the capital of France. Each morning and evening the trains from Bordeaux reach the quai dOrsay crammed to overflowing with returning residents. As the newspapers have announced, the Government will probably return to Paris at the end of the month. Already all the documents relating to the different Ministries nave been brought back from Bordeaux. They were conveyed by train to the Montparnasse and Quai dOrsay stations and then taken in ministerial wagons to the buildings to which they belong. The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 11, 1914

title: The Daily Gift: A Necklace With a Message
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: Our Mommy Problem and Mine
description: This weekend Heather Havrilesky wrote astutely and humorously about how our society views mothers  or rather, Mommies. Our Mommy Problem, as she called it, is that once a woman has children, she is immediately seen as a Mommy above all else. She writes:

title: 1939: War Inspires Letter-Writing
description: One curious feature of modern war is its extraordinary stimulation of letter writing. The outbreak of hostilities coincides with a veritable epidemic of graphomania. Everyone, soldiers and civilians, feverishly starts writing letters, and people who hardly ever put pen to paper in normal times are suddenly transformed into indefatigable correspondents. Statistics cited by M. Jules Julien, French Minister of Posts and Telegraphs, show that the number of letters exchanged in France daily has increased from 1,000,000 before the war to 8,000,000 since the outbreak of hostilities.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 11, 1939

title: Kenneth Bae and Family on His Release
description: Mr. Bae, an American citizen freed from North Korea after two years of detention, and his sister, Terri Chung, spoke after he arrived in the United States.

title: Hellman & Friedman Raises $10.9 Billion for Private Equity Fund
description: Continued investor hunger for high-yielding investments has helped the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman attract billions of dollars for a new fund in a matter of months.

title: GoPro and Its Founder to Sell More Shares 5 Months After I.P.O.
description: Five months after staging one of the most promoted initial public offerings of the year, GoPro is heading back to the stock market to sell more shares. And so is the video camera makers founder, Nicholas Woodman.

title: Frauds That Prey on the Vulnerable
description: Barely a week passes in this house without one of us picking up the phone to an automated call offering my parents a free medical alert system. Of course, it is not free, but rather a well-known fraud trying to get their credit card information either for a donation, shipping or some additional emergency service.

title: Gazprom Makes a New Gas Deal With China
description: MOSCOW  Gazprom, the Russian gas giant, is adding substance to the Kremlins plan to shift its economic focus to Asia, as the company signs its second major gas deal with China this year.

title: Truth-Tellers and Liars
description: Our puzzle this week was suggested by Marco Moriconi, a regular Numberplay contributor and professor of physics at the Universidade Federal Fluminense, in Niteroi, Rio de Janeiro. (He also writes a monthly math column for the Brazilian national science magazine, Cincia Hoje (Science Today), called Qual o Problema, or Whats the Problem?). Dr. Moriconi found this weeks puzzle in a blog by its creator, Roy Cook, a professor of philosophy at the University of Minnesota who tells how he momentarily stumped the famous paradox master Raymond Smullyan with the challenge. (Check out Dr. Cooks recently-published Paradoxes and Dr. Smullyans Beginners Guide to Mathematical Logic, selected by Amazon as a favorite book of 2014.)

title: Today in Small Business: Start-Ups Founded by Women
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: No Comment Necessary: The Wrong Loretta Lynch
description: The conservative website Breitbart claimed that President Obamas attorney general nominee, Loretta Lynch, represented President Clinton during the Whitewater investigation. Actually, that was a different Loretta Lynch. The appended correction didnt really do justice to the scope of the misidentification.

title: A Tricky Transition From Fossil Fuel
description: COPENHAGEN  Denmark, a tiny country on the northern fringe of Europe, is pursuing the worlds most ambitious policy against climate change. It aims to end the burning of fossil fuels in any form by 2050  not just in electricity production, as some other countries hope to do, but in transportation as well.

title: SHV Holdings Raises Bid for Nutreco, Dutch Supplier of Animal Food
description: LONDON  The conglomerate SHV Holdings of the Netherlands said Monday that it had sweetened its offer for Nutreco, the Dutch supplier of animal food, to 2.98 billion euros or about $3.71 billion, in cash.

title: Please. Dont Decry the Divorce. Or Give Us Your CV. The Times Guide to Modern Usage
description: We investigate subjects here. We do not probe them. And no, none of the bodies here are buried in caskets; The New York Times Manual of Style prefers the term coffin.

title: Geldofs New Charity Disc Aimed at Ebola
description: The Irish rocker Bob Geldof has become better known for assembling starry charity projects  the Live Aid and Live 8 concerts, the Band Aid singles  than for the music he recorded with his own band, the Boomtown Rats. He has another charity disc in the works: on Monday, Mr. Geldof announced that he is commemorating the 30th anniversary of the first Band Aid single, Do They Know Its Christmas, with a remake that will raise money to help combat Ebola in West Africa. It is scheduled to be released Nov. 17.

title: Limiting Ebolas Spread in Mali
description: Malis Ebola scare is not yet over. But with a quick diagnosis, extensive communication, and no shortage of luck, authorities and partners may be able to limit the number of cases to one.

title: In a Topsy-Turvy World, China Warms to Sci-Fi
description: BEIJING  With a state-owned power plant in nearby Shanxi Province temporarily shut down to reduce air pollution, one of its engineers, Liu Cixin, is using the free time to work on his hobby: reigning as Chinas best-selling science-fiction author.

title: Verbatim: Nothing Can Come Between Them
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. to Ron Dermer, the ambassador to Israel, regarding the vice presidents relationship with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, in remarks at the Jewish Federations of North America General Assembly. The statement followed a report last month of a slur against Mr. Netanyahu by an unnamed senior American official.

title: Postal Service Discloses Major Theft of Its Employees Personal Data
description: WASHINGTON  The Postal Service on Monday became the latest government agency to announce a major theft of data from its computer systems, telling its roughly 800,000 employees and retirees that an attack potentially compromised databases containing postal employees names, birth dates, addresses and Social Security numbers.

title: A Super-Simple Way to Understand the Net Neutrality Debate
description: Its one of the most important policy disputes that will determine the future of the Internet, and now President Obama has formally weighed in in favor of so-called net neutrality. What has been a long-simmering battle between telecommunications and tech lobbyists is now likely to step to the front of public debate.

title: Where Audubon Found Repose, Sprayed-On Specimens Alight
description: Among the beloved prints in John James Audubons The Birds of North America is plate No. 411, a Tundra Swan, Cygnus columbianus.

title: Klinsmann Calls Up 25 Players for Next Two U.S. Soccer Friendlies
description: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States national mens soccer team, continued his effort to phase in new faces to his roster by calling in 25 players for the next two friendly matches, against Colombia in London on Friday and against Ireland in Dublin next Tuesday.

title: In This Future War, Soldiers Are Part Superhero
description: Even before the newest version of Call of Duty went on sale last week, these games about real and imagined wars made up the best-selling first-person shooter series in history, with close to 190 million copies sold, according to Guinness World Records. But despite annual sales in excess of $1 billion for five years running, there have been signs that the juggernaut is in decline. So the latest entry, Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare, is an acknowledgment that after 11 years and 11 games, its time to start over.

title: A Big Night for Bruckner Boosters
description: Fan clubs are not only for pop stars, or even for the living.

title: Democrats Own Demographic Problem: Few Younger Leaders
description: Not only did Democrats lose seats in the House, the Senate and several governors mansions last week, but they also arent getting any younger.

title: Obama for Net Neutrality
description: President Obama wrote on Monday that the Federal Communications Commission should issue strong regulations to prevent cable and phone companies from dividing the Internet into fast and slow lanes.

title: Matthew Morrison to Star in Weinsteins Finding Neverland on Broadway
description: Harvey Weinstein is going back to Plan A for his leading man in this springs Broadway musical Finding Neverland. He announced on Monday that Matthew Morrison, best known from the Fox series Glee, will star as the playwright J.M. Barrie in the show about the creation of Peter Pan.

title: Estimate of Health Coverage Enrollment Leaves Room to Grow
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Monday offered a surprisingly modest estimate of the number of people who would sign up for health insurance in the second round of open enrollment, which begins on Saturday.

title: A Rare Delacroix, Chickens in a Crypt and More from the Art Calendar
description: Ts list of happenings worth visiting in the week ahead.

title: A Bat Signal Is Jammed
description: To gain an advantage when hunting, Mexican free-tailed bats emit a special call that interferes with the calls of other bats in search of food, researchers say. Bats navigate by making calls and sensing where the sound echoes off objects. But researchers from Wake Forest University who studied recordings of hunting bats in two outdoor sites found that bats can jam competitors frequencies by producing a special signal, making it difficult for them to locate their preys position. Writing in the journal Science, the researchers noted that the bats being targeted by a jamming signal can emit their own special signal in retaliation.

title: In Performance | Joely Richardson
description: A scene from the new production of William Luces biographical play The Belle of Amherst, about the 19th-century poet Emily Dickinson. The show runs through Nov. 23 at the Westside Theater.

title: Syrian Leader Says U.N. Cease-Fire Proposal Is Worth Considering
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  President Bashar al-Assad of Syria said Monday that a United Nations proposal for a local cease-fire in Syrias largest city, Aleppo, was worth considering. It was Mr. Assads first response to the idea floated recently by the new United Nations envoy to Syria.

title: The Benefits of Being Politically Correct
description: When people bring up political correctness, theyre often talking about how much they hate it. Unlike, say, diversity or inclusion, the term is perhaps most frequently used by those who object to what it stands for, who feel that calls to change the way they speak harm them or society in some way.

title: In Tampa, the World of Poseidon
description: Poseidon played an impressive number of roles in the world of the ancient gods: he was not only the lord of the sea, but also of horses and earthquakes. How those roles were recorded in ancient art is the subject of a notable exhibit at the Tampa Museum of Art.

title: Leahy Sees Easy Road for Attorney General Pick, Now or Later
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, didnt give away much during a television appearance this morning about whether he would proceed posthaste to take up the nomination of Loretta E. Lynch, President Obamas choice for attorney general. But he made it pretty clear that he believes she should be confirmed easily no matter when the Senate votes.

title: A Young New Hampshireman and His Old British Roadster
description: BETHLEHEM, N.H.  The fascination and affection Chris Seely, 16, feels for the 1967 MGB he rebuilt and drives daily were hand-me-downs.

title: Apple Releases Web Tool for iPhone Switchers
description: Breaking up is never easy, not even with an iPhone. But Apple has released a tool to make that processcleaner.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: ACH Food Companies, Cordova, Tenn., the American division of Associated British Foods, chose Doner, Southfield, Mich., part of MDC Partners, as digital agency of record, handling all the companys digital work and part of its social media work. Billings were not disclosed. The assignment had been handled by Digitas, part of the Publicis Groupe. ACH brands include Argo, Fleischmanns, Durkee, Karo and Mazola.

title: Rothko and OKeeffe Works Among Highlights of Mellon Auction
description: The week of back-to-back important postwar and contemporary art auctions kicks off at Sothebys on Monday night with masterworks from the estate of Rachel Lambert Mellon, known as Bunny. Mrs. Mellon, who died in March at 103, spent her final years at Oak Spring Farms in Upperville, Va., surrounded by the art and objects she lovingly collected her entire life. Among them are paintings by Rothko, Diebenkorn, OKeeffe and Fontana, which will be sold at Sothebys on Monday along with an illustrated letter Manet wrote in 1880 and white bronze painted fireplace irons decorated with birds that she commissioned from Diego Giacometti in 1972.

title: Lower Projections for Health Law
description: Enrollment for health insurance purchased through the Affordable Care Acts exchanges is not expected to be as robust next year as previously projected.

title: Microsoft Hopes This Video Game Collection Wings Its Way to Success
description: Although the expression halo effect was coined long before video games or video game systems were invented, Microsoft is hoping for a Halo effect during this frenetic, competitive Christmas shopping season.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: A Rare Form of Malaria Is Spreading in Malaysia
description: A rare and sometimes lethal form of malaria usually found only in monkeys is becoming so common in Malaysia that it accounts for most malaria hospitalizations there, scientists have found.

title: Monday Motorsports: Harvick Needed to Win, and Did
description: Kevin Harvick, in a must-win situation, beat Jeff Gordon to the finish Sunday at Phoenix International Raceway, in the penultimate Nascar Sprint Cup event of the season. The victory earned Harvick one of four berths in the season finale next weekend in Homestead, Fla.

title: Italian Appeals Court Overturns Guilty Verdicts in Earthquake Trial
description: ROME  An appeals court on Monday cleared seven prominent Italian earthquake experts who were accused of failing to adequately warn the residents of a seismically active area in the months before a 2009 earthquake that killed more than 300 people.

title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Yemens Ex-President and 2 Rebel Leaders
description: CAIRO  The United States on Monday imposed sanctions on the former president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, a onetime American counterterrorism ally whom the Obama administration accused of undermining stability in Yemen.

title: The Enduring Republican Grip on the House
description: Whatever doubts existed about the Republican grip on the House should now be gone.

title: Wines for Thanksgiving That Refresh the Palate
description: Thanksgiving, like any holiday, is an act of repetition, only more so. Not just because it rolls around every year on the fourth Thursday of November, but because we ritually prepare the same meal.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Best-Selling Science Books
description: 1 BEING MORTAL by Atul Gawande. Metropolitan/ Holt. The surgeon and New Yorker writer considers how doctors fail patients at the end of life, and how they can do better.

title: U.N. to Investigate Strikes on Its Facilities in Gaza
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations secretary general announced on Monday that a five-member panel would investigate the attacks on more than 100 United Nations facilities and the death of 11 of its staff members during the Gaza conflict during the summer, defying Israeli demands to wait until the conclusion of its own government inquiry.

title: G.O.P. Faces Tougher Job Finding Democrats to Repeal Health Law
description: The Democrats Against Obamacare caucus in the House of Representatives has been decimated through retirements and election defeats. But Republicans seeking a bipartisan veneer for their efforts to dismantle the health care law could ally with a few lawmakers.

title: Sewage Science
description: A group of researchers at New York University is using sewage water to track diseases and monitor health.

title: In a New Show, Takashi Murakami Visits the Dark Side
description: On March 11, 2011, the day the the Tohoku earthquake and tsunami devastated Japan, Takashi Murakami was in his studio near Tokyo. Though his family, who live in the south, were unharmed, the artists studio assistant lost his grandmother and grandfather. The magnitude of the tragedy got Murakami thinking. I used to think of religion as something kind of false and hypocritical, but after the earthquake disaster, I realized in a time like that, religion and fairy tales and things like that are actually a necessity, he said through a translator.

title: Takata Faces Inevitable U.S. Inquiry Into Airbags
description: The Japanese manufacturer Takata is the latest company to be caught in a firestorm of controversy over how it allowed a faulty automobile part to be used for years. A report in The New York Times that the company secretly conducted tests on defective airbags four years before the first recall of vehicles that used them can be expected to touch off a wide-ranging criminal investigation.

title: Narendra Modis Cabinet Is a Rogues Gallery
description: On the campaign trail earlier this year, Indias prime minister, Narendra Modi, appealed to voters by promising to combat corruption and clean up politics. He was rewarded with a huge national electoral victory as well as success in state elections last month.

title: Jerry Tallmer, Critic Who Created the Obies, Dies at 93
description: Jerry Tallmer, who brought professionalism and a personalized approach to arts coverage to The Village Voice in its earliest days, and who dreamed up its award for Off Broadway theater, the Obie, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Our Real Mommy (and Daddy) Problem: Your Children Are Your Problem
description: We do have a Mommy problem. And a Daddy problem. Its a Baby problem and a Kiddie problem. Its even a Grammy and Grampy problem, and if you can think of any other cutesy monikers we can attach to parents and families, its that kind of problem, too.

title: Fat Man and Little Boy Revisited
description: Newly available photographs and movies have made the dawn of the nuclear weapons era go viral, providing a history lesson to a new generation.

title: New York City Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Suspended Tuesday
description: Because of Veterans Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Tuesday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: China Action Against Multinational Firms
description: Legal and regulatory action against some companies doing business in China.

title: Blue Note Owners Opening a New Club in Meatpacking District
description: The owners of the Blue Note, the legendary jazz club, are opening a new club in the meatpacking district of Manhattan that will be devoted to Latin music and world music, the Blue Note Entertainment Group announced Monday. The club, Subrosa, at 63 Gansevoort Street, will present a preview concert Wednesday night by the Pedrito Martnez Group, which will become a resident ensemble at the club with several shows every month.

title: Museum Sues Sendak Estate Over Rare Books
description: The Rosenbach Museum and Library in Philadelphia has sued the estate of Maurice Sendak, who died in 2012, claiming that the estate is withholding a collection of rare books that Sendak promised to the library in his will.

title: Players in Sayreville Football Hazing and Abuse Case Will Be Tried as Juveniles, Lawyers Say
description: The seven football players accused of hazing and sexual abuse at Sayreville War Memorial High School in New Jersey in a scandal that has led to cancellation of the season and drawn national attention will be tried as juveniles, according to lawyers representing them.

title: Marines Remember Falluja, 10 Years Later
description: On Nov. 6, 2004, NATO forces launched an assault on Falluja, a city north of Baghdad that had become a magnet for Sunni insurgent forces. Thomas Brennan, then a 19-year-old Marine Corps lance corporal, was one of the infantrymen with First Battalion, Eighth Marine Regiment who would participate in the attack. The battalion suffered numerous casualties in the battle, one of the bloodiest for American forces since Vietnam. Now a journalism student, Mr. Brennan recalls the battle with the help of some of the Marines and sailors he fought beside.

title: Interstellar Opening Tops Out Under $50 Million
description: LOS ANGELES  More air came out of Interstellar on Monday.

title: What Our Sewage Can Teach Us
description: Beneath Visionaire, a breathtaking high-rise overlooking the southern tip of Manhattan, sewage gushes through a network of pipes and then drools into a stone tank, which is draped in quivering cockroaches. They scatter as Dennis Keefe, a contractor for Natural Systems Utilities, dips a metal ladle into the putrid stew and gently stirs.

title: Groupon, Too, Turns to Multiple Apps
description: Sometimes offering one mobile app just isnt enough.

title: Atlanta School Cheating Was Conspiratorial, Ex-Governor Testifies
description: ATLANTA  The former Georgia governor who ordered a state inquiry amid suspicions of widespread cheating in Atlantas public schools testified Monday that he felt the wrongdoing was pervasive and that academic officials had tried to impede a public accounting of it.

title: Making Friends With Free Racing Tickets
description: I WASNT a big traveler growing up and when I started my career as an investment banker, I didnt travel much for work then, either. Now Im Nascars chief sales officer, and business travel is a big part of my job.

title: Is It Too Late for a Democratic ALEC?
description: After years of slumber, Democrats are finally waking up and realizing that one of the most powerful prizes in American politics  the control of state governments  has slipped from their grasp. It is likely to be many years before they have a chance of getting it back.

title: A Seductive Track from Rising Soul-Pop Songstress George Maple
description: I wanted to have a space where I could be creatively unlimited, says the 24-year-old Australian soul-pop songstress George Maple, ne Jess Higgs, of her musical alter ego. Though the pseudonym is still a relatively new one  she adopted it in late 2012, when she appeared on Flumes down-tempo electro track Bring You Down  it has already served as a vehicle for growth. Between building that character and now, I feel like theres been a fast progression of development as an artist, Maple says. Im saying what I want to say now, as opposed to when I was a little bit more timid at the beginning.

title: What to Wear This Week: Nov. 10
description: With all the talk of winter coats, sweaters and boots, its easy to forget the importance of undergarments. This week, play peekaboo with camisoles and bodysuits chic enough to want to show off.

title: How Solution Aversion and Global Warming Prescriptions Polarize the Climate Debate
description: Anyone eager to understand, and move past, the deep political polarization around global warming would do well to explore the findings in Solution aversion: On the relation between ideology and motivated disbelief, published in the November issue of the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology. The paper is behind a subscription wall, but a Duke University news release does a fine job laying out the basic findings, as does Chris Mooney, getting into gear in his new blogging position at the Washington Post. Heres an excerpt from the Duke release, followed by more from Mooney and some thoughts from me on how this work echoes points explored here for many years:

title: Supreme Court Weighs Case Over Cuts to Retirees Health Benefits
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court seemed puzzled on Monday about why it was being asked to decide whether a chemical company could cut the health benefits of its retired workers.

title: Evil Dead to Rise Again as Starz Series
description: Grab your boom stick and prepare to hail to the king, baby: Ash Williams, the super-suave opponent of demons, doppelgangers and assorted reincarnated pests  a k a the character played by Bruce Campbell in Sam Raimis Evil Dead movies  is moving to the small screen in a new cable series.

title: Verbatim: Will Rick Perry Run?
description: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, at an event in New Hampshire. For more: A look at 2016 likely presidential contenders.

title: Overseas, Lost in Transition
description: SOPRON, Hungary  Bria Hartley and Kayla McBrides preparation for their first season of professional basketball abroad was not unlike how they prepared for college. Skype accounts were set up. Xboxes were packed. Slingboxes were installed at their parents houses, ready to stream American television shows 4,250 miles away.

title: Elephant Man and The River Showcase Stars Box-Office Power on Broadway
description: The last time Bradley Cooper was on Broadway, in the 2006 play Three Days of Rain, the shows main attraction was Julia Roberts and the packed audiences were thanks to her. But Mr. Cooper is now a movie star too, and his fans were out in force last weekend for his return to Broadway in The Elephant Man, which sold out its first four preview performances, according to box-office data released on Monday. Demand for seats was so high that the average ticket price hit $163.45  the highest of any play last week, and second only to the average price for the blockbuster musical The Book of Mormon. The show, which stars Mr. Cooper as John Merrick, the title character in the 1979 play, grossed $520,087 for the four previews.

title: Its Just a (Thanksgiving Dinner) Fantasy
description: There are two Thanksgivings, for some of us. There is the one that will unfold in the real world, the Thanksgiving that involves transportation snarls, hours of televised football, family members stunned into a comatose state by rivers of gravy and lagoons of mashed potatoes, testy spats over the thermostat and, over all, a rigid adherence to the Way Things Are Supposed to Be Done.

title: Steven A. Cohen Was Buyer of Giacomettis Chariot, for $101 Million
description: The lone bidder who spent $101 million at Sothebys last Tuesday night for Giacomettis Chariot, a 1950 sculpture of a spindly woman riding atop a chariot, was the hedge fund billionaire Steven A. Cohen, experts with knowledge of the sale said Monday. The sculpture, which came from the collection of Alexander Goulandris, a member of the Greek shipping family, is considered among the artists finest.

title: Mets Make Statement, Signing Rockies Cuddyer
description: PHOENIX  Ever since Sandy Alderson took over as general manager of the Mets in 2010, the team has clung to its draft picks as if they were pure gold, always in the hope that they would lead to a glittering future. The Mets think that future begins in 2015.

title: Major League Teams Look to Cuba, Land of Bargains
description: The leading slugger in the major leagues last season was Jose Abreu, a rookie first baseman from Cuba whose six-year, $68 million contract was thought to be a reach for the owner of the Chicago White Sox.

title: How One Presidency Jump-Started Another
description: On the morning of Nov. 22, 1963, Lyndon B. Johnson and Ronald Reagan both had reason to feel they were sliding into obscurity.

title: Assessing Space on a Computers Hard Drive
description: Assessing Space

title: How to Erase Personal Information From an iPad
description: Q. I recently bought a new iPad Air and transferred all my content to it from my older iPad. Id like to pass the old model along to a friend. But how do I fully erase it so that my personal information, apps and iTunes password are permanently removed?

title: French Brandy Gains a Foothold on American Cocktail Menus
description: France has done well by the American cocktail revival. French liqueurs, bitters and aperitifs that were gathering dust on the shelf (like Lillet and Benedictine) or werent available in the United States (like Suze) now enjoy a renewed relevance.

title: Comfortable Inducing a Laugh or a Squirm
description: Oddball characters materialize fully formed in Odd Birdz, a sketch comedy show by the clever young Israeli ensemble Tziporela, which is making its American debut at the Players Theater in Greenwich Village.

title: Craig Spencer, New York Doctor With Ebola, Will Leave Bellevue Hospital
description: Craig Spencer, the New York City doctor who became the first person in the city to test positive for Ebola, is free of the virus and is set to be released from Bellevue Hospital Center on Tuesday, hospital officials said on Monday.

title: Preserving an Accident, the Salton Sea in California, for the Good of Nature
description: MECCA, Calif.  The area around this town of date palms attracts two kinds of migrants  hundreds of humans who work the land, and millions of birds that stop to rest and gorge at the nearby Salton Sea. The sea is a 110-year-old, increasingly briny, shallow lake that covers 350 square miles but is dwindling fast.

title: Transported to Paradise, but Needing More
description: Edward O. Wilson is a great biologist, a great conservationist and a great optimist. He thinks we should set aside half the planet as wilderness, and he believes we can do it. In this new book, he tells the story of a nature preserve in Mozambique to make his case.

title: Order for Summons, in Lieu of Arrest, for Possession of Marijuana
