description: The procedure for the issuance of a criminal court summons for a person found with 25 grams or less of marijuana in a public place and open to public view.

title: Walkabout: U.S. and China Lift Visa Restrictions; Space Tourists Cancel Reservations
description: Open Door News out of the APEC summit in Beijing included a surprise announcement that the United States and China will lift visa restrictions for visitors from both countries. Chinese and American tourists will now be eligible for 10-year visas, up from one year. (Quartz)

title: Q. and A.: Dennis M. Gormley on Chinas Military Capabilities
description: Every two years since 1996, the China International Aviation and Aerospace Exhibition, the largest air show in China, has been held in Zhuhai, Guangdong Province, attracting thousands of commercial traders and military enthusiasts. This year its opening was set for Tuesday, the 65th anniversary of the founding of the Peoples Liberation Army Air Force, or Plaaf, adding to the buzz around the six-day event. For those in commercial aviation, it is an opportunity to show off their wares to a fast-growing aviation market, including an increased appetite for private jets. Nearly 150 military and trade delegations attended the previous exhibition in 2012, which saw $11.8 billion in sales, according to the organizers.

title: White Rodent Finds Fame on the Great White Way
description: The Broadway cast was less than thrilled when it found out who one of their fellow performers would be. It made them squeamish  not because of who it was but because of what it was.

title: Kalettes, a Pilgrim Dinner and More Food News
description: To Serve: Two Vegetables Combine for a Taste of Their Own

title: Quandary: When the Tests Are Overwhelming, Whats Next?
description: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull from the comments, the weekly open thread or email a question that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You  the readers  provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? This weeks quandary comes from a much-commented-upon article in the National section. What can parents do if school testing is overwhelming their students, or their school?

title: A New Home for a Secretive Songbird
description: Swainsons warbler  a secretive, rarely seen songbird that nests in the swamplands of the southeastern United States  may no longer be so hard to find.

title: Showtime Renews Homeland and The Affair
description: Showtime shrugged off the occasional critical barb about the last season of Homeland and announced on Monday that it had renewed the Emmy-winning espionage drama for a fifth season.

title: U.S. to Focus on Equity in Assigning of Teachers
description: The Obama administration is directing states to show how they will ensure that all students have equal access to high-quality teachers, with a sharp focus on schools with a high proportion of the poor and racial minorities.

title: Epidemics of Confusion
description: WASHINGTON  A mysterious virus emerges in Africa and makes its way to our shores. An anxious and skeptical public rejects scientific evidence that the lethal virus is transmitted only through body fluids. There are no drugs to effectively treat infected patients, nor a vaccine to prevent new cases.

title: Hungry as a Bear
description: Q. WHICH ANIMALS ARE MOST AND LEAST EFFICIENT AT DIGESTING FOOD?

title: The Opera in Rome Is a Hotbed of Chaos
description: ROME  After the maestro Riccardo Muti signed on with the Rome Opera, in 2008, with the honorary title of conductor for life, he lifted the orchestra to new levels. Houses were packed, and audiences moved to tears. But the news in September that he had decided to pull out of productions at the house, citing a lack of serenity at this financially troubled and strike-prone theater, has plunged the opera back into uncertainty.

title: Bucket List for Tweens With Fears
description: Is there a minimum age requirement for having a bucket list? Apparently not, because on a cute new offering from Nickelodeon, three seventh-grade friends have one.

title: A Man Whose Music Animated Looney Tunes
description: Powerhouse, an electrifying account of the life of the composer Raymond Scott at the New Ohio Theater, kicks off in 1936 with the cast executing a jitterbug while Scott (Erik Lochtefeld) conducts his Quintette on radios Your Hit Parade. From there, the show hurtles forward, sustaining the controlled mad dash of the Warner Bros. Looney Tunes cartoons that adapted Scotts music.

title: The Amazing Adventures of Ronson & Chabon
description: Michael Chabons last novel, Telegraph Avenue, was set mostly in a California record shop and was packed with the kind of detail that told record collectors that Mr. Chabon was one of them. And that gave one of his readers, the British musician and producer Mark Ronson, an idea for a project: why not write to Mr. Chabon, whose earlier novel, The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay was a favorite, and invite him to write lyrics for Mr. Ronsons next album?

title: Decoding the Brains Math
description: Larry Abbott started his career working with particle colliders, but he realized that the complex mathematics of physics came in quite handy for trying to understand the brain.

title: Hear Those Tapping Shoes? Thats the Sound of Empowerment
description: Syncopated Ladies: Live in NYC is a lot like a Beyonc concert without Beyonc. For the shows premiere at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater on Friday, a nine-piece band played a handful of that singers hits, but the star wasnt a vocalist. It was seven young women mimicking the sexualized moves of Beyonc backup dancers and dressed for the part, except for the metal on the soles of their shoes. The Syncopated Ladies are tap dancers.

title: Tracking the Events in the Wake of Michael Browns Shooting
description: Updates on the events in Ferguson, Mo., following the shooting of Michael Brown, an unarmed teenager, by a police officer on Aug. 9.

title: Nov. 10, 2014  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Mexico, China, Israel and Turkey.

title: Explaining Boko Haram, Nigerias Islamist Insurgency
description: Boko Haram is an Islamist extremist group responsible for dozens of massacres of civilians and the abduction of more than 500 women and girls in its five-year insurgency in Nigeria.

title: Artists on How Pink Floyd Influenced Them
description: Not long after they first emerged in the underground music scene in mid-1960s London, Pink Floyd earned a reputation, as Rolling Stone put it in 2007, as the citys farthest-out group. And as art students at the time they got together, the band members  the bassist Roger Waters, the singer Syd Barrett, the drummer Nick Mason and the pianist Rick Wright; Barrett was later replaced by David Gilmour  firmly believed their aesthetic was as important as the notes they played. The Floyd, as they were known, provided audiences with a complete sensory experience, pairing visceral, operatic lyrics with elaborate light projections that seemed to move in turn to the music.And even as they achieved global popularity in the 1970s with a string of landmark albums including 1973s The Dark Side of the Moon, 1975s Wish You Were Here and 1979s The Wall, the band remained focused on bringing visual ideas to the forefront through their live shows and iconic album art.

title: The Burning of Atlanta
description: On the evening of Nov. 15, 1864, Union Lt. Col. Charles Fessenden Morse sat on the roof of a house and watched Atlanta burn. It was a magnificent and awful spectacle, he wrote later to his brother Robert. For miles around the country was as light as day,  the flames shooting up for hundreds of feet into the air. Earlier, over the roar and crackle of the flames, Morse had heard the 33rd Massachusetts band serenade Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman, who ordered the city torched. It was like fiddling over the burning of Rome. The next morning, nothing was left of the city except its churches the city hall and the private dwellings. You could hardly find a vestige of the once splendid R.R. depots, warehouses, &c. It was melancholy, Morse lamented, but it was war, prosecuted in deadly earnest.

title: Casting a Magnetic Field That He Happily Shares
description: The bonus track on Leaving, the most recent EP by the angelic ghost-soul singer Spooky Black, is called DJ Khaled Is My Father. Its typical of this young singers output  mournful and woozy and glancingly erotic. Needless to say, theres no apparent connection between the song and DJ Khaled, mainstream hip-hops exulter-in-chief. The titles not a joke, per se, but sort of an absurdist wink.

title: Some Benefits for Veterans From the World of Travel
description: I AM an occasionally cranky Vietnam veteran who regrets having been a little churlish recently when a cashier in an airport shop asked me if I cared to make a donation to support our troops.

title: On Veterans Day, Tales of Heroism and Loss
description: Descendants of veterans of World War I share their families stories, and describe their efforts, 100 years after the start of the Great War, to verify tales of bravery and tragedy.

title: Ask Well: Immune to Ebola?
description: Question:

title: Albums by Nick Jonas, Bobby Shmurda and New Basement Tapes
description: THE NEW BASEMENT TAPES

title: After the Fall: Preventing Catastrophe
description: After the Fall: Preventing Catastrophe

title: Learning How Little We Know About the Brain
description: Research on the brain is surging. The United States and the European Union have launched new programs to better understand the brain. Scientists are mapping parts of mouse, fly and human brains at different levels of magnification. Technology for recording brain activity has been improving at a revolutionary pace.

title: Survivor Who Hated the Spotlight
description: Mary Berg, a Polish Jewish teenager who wrote one of the earliest firsthand accounts of the Nazi genocide to be published in English, has long been something of a mystery in the annals of Holocaust literature.

title: Sarkozy Tries Quick Comeback, but France May Not Go Along
description: ST.-CYR-SUR-LOIRE, France  On a recent evening, Nicolas Sarkozy, who since being voted out of office more than two years ago has done nothing to temper his reputation as the bad boy of French politics, was on stage in a gymnasium trying to generate enthusiasm for his latest campaign.

title: Philae Lander Nears a Cosmic Touchdown
description: In its 10-year chase of a comet, the European Space Agencys ambitious Rosetta mission has pushed the edges of engineering ingenuity.

title: With a Stealth Fighter, China Tries to Gain Attention
description: BEIJING  Amid the whine of high-performance jet engines at the start of an air show in Zhuhai, the Chinese government is hoping to generate a different sort of buzz: admiration, and perhaps purchases, of its shadowy J-31 stealth fighter, which is expected to make its first public appearance.

title: Pursuing a Shipping Revolution as Big as His Airship
description: MONTEBELLO, Calif.  Somewhere beneath the graying shock of mad-professor hair, the dark circles under his eyes and the Russian-strained, cigarette-stained baritone, there remains in Igor Pasternak a boy with a dream.

title: Brokaw, Sondheim, Streep, Wonder: All Stars of Freedom
description: Tom Brokaw, Stephen Sondheim, Meryl Streep and Stevie Wonder are among the 19 recipients of this years Presidential Medal of Freedom, the White House announced Monday.

title: The Midterm Election: New Reflections
description: To the Editor:

title: Juniper Networks Changes Its Chief, Again
description: It was roughly a year ago that Juniper Networks named Shaygan Kheradpir as its chief executive, whose predecessor had resigned as the networking company was being investigated under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.

title: The Eisenhower Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Pharma and Ebola
description: To the Editor:

title: DeGrom Goes From Class AAA to the Class of the N.L. Rookie Field
description: Before Tammy deGroms youngest child and only son, Jacob, was married over the weekend, she imparted a few bits of advice. She told him to always keep his faith first. She told him to continue doing what he was doing in his profession.

title: Joan Riverss Treatment Had Numerous Violations, U.S. Inquiry Finds
description: A Manhattan clinic treating Joan Rivers in August did not notice that her vital signs were deteriorating for at least 15 minutes before she went into cardiac arrest, leading to her death several days later, a federal investigation has found.

title: The Police and the Community
description: To the Editor:

title: Sierra Leone Defends Jailing Critic of Ebola Response
description: Sierra Leones attorney general defended the arrest last week of a prominent radio journalist who criticized the governments handling of the Ebola crisis as lawful and justified, in a news release distributed over the weekend.

title: Oops! Health Insurer Exposes Member Data
description: Earlier this year, OfficeMax became a little too personal with one customer, sending a mailing to a man in Chicago with a street address that, after his own name, inadvertently included information about a family tragedy: daughter killed in car crash or Current Business. (An OfficeMax spokesman later blamed a third-party data broker the company had hired for exposure of the intimate information.)

title: High Hopes for Lo-Fi Photos
description: Every day is Throwback Thursday for Daniel Akselrad and Erik Goyenechea, who have perfected the lo-fi 90s look of Game Boy photos.

title: Who Really Tore Down This Wall?
Work-for-Welfare Gains a Foothold in Hungary
description: HALMAJ, Hungary  The big sow nearest the barn door looked especially frisky this chilly morning. About the size of a Dumpster, and nearly as fragrant, she poked her speckled snout through the bars of her pen and snorted happily as Jeno Baba, 27, stroked her bristled head.

title: V.A. Creates Plans to Consolidate Services
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs announced plans Monday for a new customer service bureau to help train employees to focus on customer satisfaction and make the department more accountable to the millions of veterans it serves. The plans also include a structural overhaul that over time could lead to consolidating a wide range of functions under a handful of regional offices.

title: The Truth About the Wars
description: AS a senior commander in Iraq and Afghanistan, I lost 80 soldiers. Despite their sacrifices, and those of thousands more, all we have to show for it are two failed wars. This fact eats at me every day, and Veterans Day is tougher than most.

title: Where Hell Is Other Patients
description: NAPA, Calif.  IN the public imagination, forensic mental hospitals  where states place the criminally insane  are hellish scenes of cages and restraints, the better to keep us safe from the Hannibal Lecters of the world.

title: Medicare Proposes Paying for Lung Cancer Screenings for Older Longtime Smokers
description: WASHINGTON  Medicare will cover annual screenings for lung cancer for older Americans with long histories of heavy smoking, the federal government said Monday in a proposal that would cover an estimated four million people, many of whom are at greatest risk for the disease.

title: How to Be French
description: PARIS  I HAVE an unusual item on my to-do list, wedged between home repairs and unwritten thank-you notes: Become French. Ive begun the long process of gathering documents to apply for French citizenship.

title: Fix the New G.I. Bill
description: THIS Veterans Day there will be over a million students on college campuses in the United States who are using their G.I. Bill benefits. The Department of Veterans Affairs forecasts that the number of student veterans will increase by 20 percent in the next few years.

title: Czechs Celebrate Commitment to Team Success
description: PRAGUE  The choreography comes automatically by now: When the Czechs win a set in a team tennis competition, the home fans behind the team bench immediately unfurl a giant Czech flag that covers the section.

title: Banks Are Laughable, Except for Ours
description: AMERICANS of a certain age may have fond recollections of banks, like getting lollipops from kindly tellers and being issued their first passbooks to deposit earnings from babysitting and paper routes, but affection for banks is decidedly scarce in the aftermath of the financial crisis. Only 32 percent of Americans rate the reputation of banks as positive, ranking it 13th among 15 sectors, with just the tobacco industry and the government held in lower esteem, according to a recent Harris Poll.

title: Re-enacting the Vietnam War
description: Each year in Oregon, a group of men gather to re-create a war that so many Americans have tried to forget.

title: Re-enacting the Vietnam War
description: Growing up in the 1980s and 90s, we were familiar with the idea of war re-enactments: masses of men in woolen uniforms dutifully recreating Picketts Charge at Gettysburg or trading puffs of white smoke across the Lexington Battle Green while families and schoolchildren look on. Although they were recreating gruesome battles, it all seemed rather quaint.

title: H. Gary Morse, Who Built Mecca for Retirees, Is Dead at 77
description: H. Gary Morse, who became a billionaire by turning a Florida mobile home park into a sprawling retirement destination, the Villages, with nearly 600 holes of golf, more than 80,000 residents and outsize political influence, died on Oct. 29. He was 77.

title: Supreme Court Stays Gay Marriage in Kansas
description: The Supreme Court on Monday temporarily blocked a federal courts order that would have allowed same-sex marriages in Kansas to start on Tuesday. In urging the Supreme Court to intercede, state officials said their case involved a novel conflict between state and federal courts in Kansas. They also relied on Thursdays ruling from the federal appeals court in Cincinnati that upheld several state bans on same-sex marriage. Justice Sonia Sotomayor, the member of the court responsible for overseeing federal courts in Kansas, issued the stay. She ordered the plaintiffs to file a response to the states emergency application by Tuesday evening.

title: Massachusetts: New Limits Are Placed on Cod Fishing in the Atlantic
description: Federal regulators on Monday restricted commercial fishing for Atlantic cod in the Gulf of Maine. Officials with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced a temporary emergency action that establishes rolling restrictions to commercial boats with gear capable of catching cod in areas of the gulf. It also limited catches to 200 pounds per trip in areas that remain open. Earlier this year, the administration released a study showing stocks of the species to be at historically low levels. The action will be in effect through the spring, but similar terms could be extended for the 2015 fishing season. Some fishermen said the cuts could put them out of business. Also Monday, the regulators increased the amount of haddock that fishermen are allowed to catch.

title: Jack Nelson, Olympic Swimmer and Gold Medal Coach, Dies at 82
description: Jack Nelson, an Olympic swimmer and coach who directed a quartet of American women to a surprising gold medal in the 400-meter freestyle relay at the 1976 Games in Montreal, died on Wednesday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 82.

title: Russian News Agency Expands Global Reach
description: MOSCOW  When Dmitry K. Kiselyov, the firebrand Russian television pundit, announced on Monday that the state news agency he leads was planning a major foreign expansion, he did not deny that the goal was to spread a type of propaganda.

title: As Federal Reserve Selects New Top Officials, Coalition Calls for Public Input
description: WASHINGTON  A coalition of community groups and labor unions wants the Federal Reserve to change the way some Fed officials are appointed, criticizing the existing process as secretive, undemocratic and dominated by banks and other large corporations.

title: For Guccifer, Hacking Was Easy. Prison Is Hard.
description: ARAD, Romania  He reveled in tormenting members of the Bush family, Colin L. Powell and a host of other prominent Americans, and also in outfoxing the F.B.I. and the Secret Service, foiling their efforts to discover even his nationality, never mind his identity. Early this year, however, the elusive online outlaw known as Guccifer lost his cocky composure and began to panic.

title: Suit Accuses Banks of Role in Financing Terror Attacks
description: A five-car convoy opened fire on a compound 30 miles south of Baghdad, a sneak attack that killed four American soldiers in one of the deadliest days in the Iraq war. A roadside bomb struck a United States military vehicle, severing part of a soldiers head. And a militant group kidnapped and killed an American journalist, dumping him in the street after firing three shots into his chest.

title: Dont Delay on the Attorney General
description: By selecting Loretta Lynch as his nominee for attorney general, President Obama wisely hopes to avoid the drawn-out confirmation battle that a more controversial nominee, like Labor Secretary Thomas Perez, would have faced.

title: Danbury Laborers Fight Unjust Arrests
description: One September day in 2006, the police in Danbury, Conn., and agents of Immigration and Customs Enforcement did a deplorable thing. An undercover officer, posing as a contractor, picked up some day laborers at a local park, drove them to a nearby parking lot and handed them over to waiting ICE agents. The laborers, 11 men from Ecuador, have been fighting deportation ever since.

title: New York Changes Marijuana Arrest Policy
description: The police commissioner, William J. Bratton, and Mayor Bill de Blasio announced that people arrested in possession of 25 grams or less of marijuana may be issued a summons instead of being arrested.

title: Classroom Breakfasts: a Good Idea, Overdue
description: When he was running for mayor, Bill de Blasio had a plan to improve the health and learning of tens of thousands of schoolchildren. It was to require all public schools to serve free breakfast in the classroom, instead of in the cafeteria before school started. The change was needed, he said, because so few eligible children take advantage of free cafeteria breakfasts  either because it is too hard to get to school that early or because participating in the program stigmatizes recipients as needy. Low participation squanders millions of unused dollars in federal aid and leaves too many children hungry.

title: Concerns in Criminal Justice System as New York City Eases Marijuana Policy
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio, who took office promising to reform the Police Department and repair relations with black and Latino communities, on Monday unveiled his plan to change the way the police enforce the law on marijuana possession.

title: Memorandum Order in Hamm Case
description: Harold Hamm is paying one of the biggest divorce settlements in history.

title: An Oklahoma Oilmans Billion-Dollar Divorce
description: During his nearly 50 years as an Oklahoma oil man, Harold Hamm has done everything on a huge scale. The chief executive and majority shareholder of Continental Resources, he owns the largest piece of the greatest oil discovery of our age, in the shale-rich plains of North Dakota. His net worth has been pegged at more than $18 billion by Forbes, making him the 24th richest man in the country.

title: NBC Executive Says He Is Very Satisfied With Pace of Super Bowl Ad Sales
description: NBC, which will broadcast Super Bowl XLIX on Feb. 1, is very satisfied with the pace of sales of commercial time during the game, according to a top sales executive.

title: More Bank Settlements Coming in Widening Currency Case
description: As authorities in the United States and Britain ready actions this week against giant banks suspected of manipulating the foreign currency market, both the number of government agencies involved and the cost of settling the cases continues to grow.

title: Its Official: Mormon Founder Had Up to 40 Wives
description: Mormon leaders have acknowledged for the first time that the churchs founder and prophet, Joseph Smith, portrayed in church materials as a loyal partner to his loving spouse Emma, took as many as 40 wives, some already married and one only 14 years old.

title: Gotham Recap:  The Cheap Thrill of Smacking a  Rich Kid
description: Season 1, Episode 8: The Mask

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 10, 2014
11 Years Later, Womans Death Is Tied to G.M. Ignition Defect
description: WASHINGTON, Conn.  Jean P. Averill warranted only a footnote.

title: Malala Yousafzai, Nobel Laureate, Is Assailed by Schools Group in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A network of private schools on Monday unleashed a scathing public attack on Malala Yousafzai, the teenage Nobel laureate, in the most concerted assault yet on her reputation in her home country.

title: Republicans Vow to Fight E.P.A. and Approve Keystone Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON  The new Republican Congress is headed for a clash with the White House over two ambitious Environmental Protection Agency regulations that are the heart of President Obamas climate change agenda.

title: Jets Jaiquawn Jarrett Steps In, Then Stands Out
description: Rex Ryan began his teleconference Monday by praising the Jets pass protection and their defense and their special teams and T. J. Graham and Calvin Pryor, and all of that came from a coach who a minute earlier had said he did not have much in the way of opening remarks.

title: Mr. Obamas Message to Myanmar
description: President Obama was ebullient during his historic visit to Myanmar in November 2012, the first by an American president to a nation that appeared on the cusp of a democratic transformation after five decades of authoritarian rule. But, in the two years since, the military-dominated, quasi-civilian government in Yangon has moved far too slowly on the commitments to reforms it made to the United States when the two nations pledged to begin a new relationship.

title: The Legacy of Fear
description: Twenty-five years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the biggest surprise is how badly most of the post-communist nations have done since. There was a general expectation back then that most of these countries would step out from tyranny and rejoin the European club of prosperous nations. Most of us did not appreciate the corrosive power of distrust, and how long it would take to heal the mental scars caused by it.

title: Day After Being Run Over, the Giants Look to Recover
description: The hopeful voices heard during Giants training camp, the ones that spoke of winning the N.F.C. East or of wild-card prospects, are no longer heard. Coaches and players now talk the talk of a losing team, speaking of the need to stay professional and not allow a poor season to spiral into an abysmal one.

title: More Transparency, More Pay for C.E.O.s
description: Its very seldom that publishing compensation accomplishes much for the shareholders. No C.E.O. looks at a proxy statement and comes away saying, I should be paid less.

title: After One Bashing, Bears Are Battered by News Media, Too
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill.  The Chicago Bears are a source of civic pride with a tradition of playing hard-nosed, blue-collar football. Though they have won only a single Super Bowl  after the 1985 season  and have missed the playoffs six of the last seven seasons, they are still the Monsters of the Midway, the proud franchise of George Halas, Mike Ditka, Dick Butkus, Mike Singletary and Brian Urlacher.

title: What Makes 'Natural' Natural?
Share a Single Bed
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  If you read James Mulherns notes below, he believes that his theme is not necessarily overly thrilling, but that in forming this theme set, he offers us some lively entries. I would have to agree. Is it the worlds most thrilling theme? No. Maybe this is a result of having solved thousands of crossword puzzles and, in doing so, inadvertently set the bar too high in my mind for themes. But is it a perfectly fine Tuesday puzzle that is a pleasure to solve? Yes, of course it is.

title: Sleepy Hollow Recap: Is It Time to Think About an Ending?
description: Season 2, Episode 8: Heartless

title: 2 Killed in Elevator at Bronx Housing Project; Police Consider Retaliation as Motive
description: Two men were fatally shot on Monday in an elevator at a public housing building in the Bronx, and the police said they were questioning a person of interest.

title: A Final Tribute for a Daughter Who Died From a Secret Illness
description: The phone rang in the middle of the night.

title: Brooklyn Landlord Pleads Guilty to Negligent Homicide in 2010 Fire
description: Late one January night in 2010, someone doused a roll of toilet paper in paint thinner in a building in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, and lit it, and five immigrants from Guatemala were killed.

title: Investigation of Charney Adds to Loss at American Apparel
description: American Apparel, a beleaguered retailer still wincing from a boardroom struggle over the summer, said sales fell 5 percent in the third quarter and losses grew  dragged down in no small part by its own investigation of the behavior of Dov Charney, who was fired as chief executive in June. The company, which has been without a permanent chief executive ever since, reported a net loss of $19.2 million, or 11 cents a share, most of which was nonrecurring costs, including $5.3 million in legal and other costs connected to Mr. Charneys departure. A year ago, the net loss was $1.5 million. Net sales in the third quarter slipped to $155.9 million, compared with $164.5 million last year. Highlighting the companys adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, which jumped 38 percent to $13.5 million, Scott Brubaker, the interim chief, said in a statement, I am encouraged by these results, and am optimistic about the future prospects of the business.

title: Jackson Offers Advice, but Knicks Fail to Follow It All
description: In his continuing effort to maintain a healthy distance between himself and the team he runs, Phil Jackson acknowledged Monday night that it was a fine balance. On one hand, he wants it to be clear to the players that Coach Derek Fisher is really in charge. But on the other, Jackson sometimes feels the urge to get involved.

title: Videos Add Details in Fatal Arizona Wildfire, but Big Question Remains
description: PHOENIX  A DC-10 airplane roars overhead. Wind chimes toll. Tree branches rustle as the wind gusts, carrying embers of fire that ignite clusters of parched grass on the sides of a dirt road.

title: Real Sociedad Hires New Manager
description: Jurgen Klinsmann, the coach of the United States men, continued his effort to phase in new faces by calling up a dozen promising players under 24 for the next two friendly matches, against Colombia in London on Friday and Ireland in Dublin next Tuesday. They include midfielders Alfredo Morales and Julian Green, and forwards Miguel Ibarra, Bobby Wood and Rubio Rubin, who, at 18, will be the youngest player in camp.

title: A Sparkling Synth-Pop Debut
description: Heaven, the debut EP from T.O.L.D., runs a bit like a three-act play. It opens with Lucifers Eyes, a deceptively upbeat electro-pop tune that lays bright steel-drum sounds over pulsing synth lines and warm, dreamy backing vocals  elements that carry into In Low Light, which leads with a guitar intro that wouldnt be out of place in a song by the XX. Like that bands music, and others to which the project will draw comparison (Tanlines or Discovery, perhaps), the EP, which will be released Nov. 18 and premieres here, finds unexpected balances between lightness and darkness. You focus on the beauty, but you use the sadness as a skeleton, says Dan Smith, the 24-year-old Birmingham-born artist behind the project.

title: Industrial Elegance
description: The interior architect Vincenzo de Cotiis  sought after in his native Italy for the dynamic monastery-meets-laboratory approach he brings to designing furniture, homes and hotels  deserves our attention.

title: Chloe Collaborates With a London Art Collective
description: Since its inception in 1994, the London-based collective Studio Voltaire has cultivated some of the brightest under-the-radar talent in the art world. To mark the organizations 20th anniversary this month, however, its director Joe Scotland is teaming up with a much more recognizable name. Beginning tomorrow and running through December, the studio will open the third installation of its biennial pop-up shop, taking place this year in partnership with Chlo and its creative director Clare Waight Keller. The temporary store, House of Voltaire, which opens tomorrow in Mayfair, will sell a curated selection of commissioned home dcor, limited edition prints and artworks as well as clothing and accessories by a variety of artists and designers. Chlo has also created a special four-piece capsule collection  a bag by Waight Keller, a top and shorts by the painter Karen Kilimnik, a dress by the multimedia artist Cao Fei and a scarf by the painter Jenny Saville  all of which will also be available on Net-a-Porter starting Friday, Nov. 14.

title: Sirius XM Adds Show Based on Popular Dance Songs on YouTube
description: By sharing data, Sirius XM and YouTube are hoping for another George Ezra.

title: All 43 Works From Bunny Mellons Collection Sell at Sothebys Auction
description: Rachel Lambert Mellon, better known as Bunny, spent her lifetime collecting whatever caught her eye, from antique porcelains and shaker baskets to abstract paintings by Rothko and Diebenkorn. Her legendary taste and style, from an era long gone, proved irresistible for scores of collectors who descended on Sothebys York Avenue salesroom on Monday night to see 43 masterworks, as the auction house called them, bringing prices that were well past anyones expectations.

title: Word of the Day | passive
description: passive \pa-siv\ adjective

title: The Great Wage Slowdown, Looming Over Politics
description: A quiz: How does the Democratic Party plan to lift stagnant middle-class incomes?

title: A Whole Different Ballgame
description: The W.N.B.A. players Kayla McBride and Bria Hartley are in their first year of playing overseas, in Hungary, and are finding life abroad a challenge.

title: Captain Gets 36 Years for Deserting Korean Ferry
description: GWANGJU, South Korea  The captain of the South Korean ferry that sank in April, killing more than 300 people, was sentenced on Tuesday to 36 years in prison for deserting his ship and its passengers in a fatal crisis. But he was acquitted of murder, infuriating family members of some of the victims in the countrys worst disaster in decades.

title: Whats on TV Tuesday
description: 7 P.M. (HBO) THE CONCERT FOR VALOR The Black Keys, Eminem, Dave Grohl, Jennifer Hudson (above), Jessie J, Metallica, Rihanna, Bruce Springsteen, Carrie Underwood and the Zac Brown Band perform in honor of American veterans and their families at this event live from the National Mall in Washington. Jack Black, Bryan Cranston, Jamie Foxx, George Lopez, John Oliver and Bob Woodruff will also appear. And Tom Hanks, Will Smith, Steven Spielberg, Meryl Streep, Oprah Winfrey and Reese Witherspoon will present filmed tributes.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: This is not the church I grew up with; this is not the Joseph Smith I love.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: Test Yourself | Country Star Strides Back Onto the Stage

title: Putin Drapes Chinas First Lady in a Blanket, and Invites Speculation

title: For Online Retailers Like Alibaba, Singles Day in China Is a Bonanza
description: Chinas slowing economy got a little retail therapy on Tuesday, as Chinese Internet users showed just how ingrained online shopping has become in the country.

description: In Honduran Youth Finds Welcome Mat at Oakland School Designed for Immigrants, Jennifer Medina writes about a boy who is trying to make a new life in the United States.

title: What an Uncensored Letter to M.L.K. Reveals
description: The note is just a single sheet gone yellow with age, typewritten and tightly spaced. Its rife with typos and misspellings and sprinkled with attempts at emending them. Clearly, some effort went into perfecting the tone, that of a disappointed admirer, appalled by the discovery of hidious [sic] abnormalities in someone he once viewed as a man of character.

title: How Well Do You Think Standardized Tests Measure Your Abilities?
description: Over the past decade students have faced an increasing number of standardized tests as the government  at federal, state and local levels  introduced new academic standards and increased accountability for schools and teachers. Have you noticed an increase in standardized tests in your school or district? Do you think these exams do a good job in measuring your intelligence, abilities and what you have learned in school?

title: High Hopes for Lo-Fi Photos
description: Daniel Akselrads photography career started in the back of a school bus. For his seventh birthday, his parents got him a Game Boy Camera  a toy his parents compromised on so he would not be buried in an antisocial video game, but involved with the world around him.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: At the APEC Summit
description: Japan and China try to dispel their differences.

title: South Africa Consolidates Graft Inquiry Against Zuma
description: LONDON  For opponents of Jacob G. Zuma, the South African president, it has become a bellwether, denoting accusations of corruption at the highest level.

title: U.S. and China Bid for Tourism With Expanded Visa Deal
description: Americans studying and working in China have welcomed the announcement that, starting Wednesday, both China and the United States will begin offering each others citizens multiple-entry visas of up to 10 years.

title: In Defense of Exhibit B
description: Re Racism and the Barbicans Exhibit B' (Opinion, Oct. 28): T.O. Molefes column on the cancellation of Brett Baileys Exhibit B in London was thoughtful, but his description of the protests against the exhibit as loud but peaceful ignores the fact that barriers were pushed over by some of the protesters, the only entrance was blocked and the audience was prevented from entering. The cancellation occurred because of clear dangers to the safety of the cast, staff and audience.

title: New York Today: Veterans March
description: Good morning on this fine Tuesday.

title: Hungarians Made Their Choice
description: Re Hungarys authoritarian descent (Opinion, Nov. 4): Kati Martons discontent with the policies of the current, right-center Hungarian government conveniently ignores the fact that just this year Viktor Orbans Fidesz party was re-elected by the overwhelming majority of Hungarian voters. Sixty percent of the electorate voted. For a second straight time, Fidesz achieved a two-thirds majority in Parliament.

title: Fighting the Stigma of Ebola
description: Re Dont let Ebola dehumanize Africa (Opinion, Oct. 31): I agree with Anglique Kidjo  it does seem that Ebola is becoming a bad stigma in Africa. People are focusing on making sure that they do not catch the disease, but not on what needs to be done so people in Africa have what they need to survive. In Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea, the infrastructure is primitive. This contributes to the spread of the disease  and is something that should have been addressed a long time ago.

title: The Book That Birthed a Potty-Mouth Genre Now Has a Sequel
description: Adam Mansbach would like to apologize.

title: In New China, Hostile West Is Still Derided
description: BEIJING  Even as his government was making red-carpet plans to host President Obama this week, the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, praised a young blogger whose writing is best known here for its anti-American vitriol.

title: Suspect in Libor-Rigging Case Is Released on Bail in London
description: LONDON  A former employee of the British brokerage firm Tullett Prebon Group made his first appearance in a London court on Tuesday in a criminal inquiry into the manipulation of a global benchmark interest rate, and he was released on bail.

description: Answers to common questions about open enrollment and the Affordable Care Act.

title: Intersection | Hip Helsinki, Finland
description: In the Kallio neighborhood of Helsinki, Finland, Sonja Sorvola, an actress who embraces tooth jewelry, likes to be more adventurous than the typical structured Scandinavian style.

title: Daily Report: Obama Calls for Strict Rules from F.C.C. Protecting Net Neutrality
description: In his most direct effort yet to influence the debate about the Internets future, President Obama said on Monday that a free and open Internet was as critical to Americans lives as electricity and telephone service and should be regulated like those utilities to protect consumers, Edward Wyatt reports.

title: Jewish Museum and Synagogues in Venice to Undergo $12 Million Restoration
description: A group of philanthropists led by the designer Diane von Furstenberg and the real estate investor Joseph Sitt have announced a $12 million restoration project for the Jewish Museum and synagogues in the Jewish ghetto of Venice, to be completed by 2016, the 500th anniversary of the ghettos establishment.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 4-10, 2014
description: Have you been following the news?

title: 1914: King Opens Khaki Parliament
description: LONDON  History was made to-day [Nov. 11] when King George opened the Khaki Parliament. Although shorn of some of its wonted splendor on account of the war and the fact that so many members of the Royal household are serving with the colors, the scene to-day in the House of Lords was an impressive one, the pomp and circumstance of the State procession tinged with melancholy by the half-mourning which was worn as a sign of the nations bereavement for those who have fallen fighting. The Royal progress through the streets, lined with khaki-clad troops, was made to the accompaniment of the cheers of crowds. The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 12, 1914

title: Welsh Carson Leads $100 Million Investment in Revel Systems
description: The private equity firm Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe, though known for its leveraged buyouts, is straying from its traditional playbook by making a minority investment in a young software company.

title: 12 Women Die After Botched Government Sterilizations in India
description: NEW DELHI  Twelve women have died and dozens more were sickened after surgical sterilizations at a government-run camp in India, where women are often paid to undergo the procedures in an effort to control population growth, health officials said on Tuesday.

title: Morning Agenda: Settlements Near in Currency Case
description: As authorities in the United States and Britain ready actions this week against giant banks suspected of manipulating the foreign currency market, banks are facing tougher settlement language and bigger fines than expected, Ben Protess and Jenny Anderson write in DealBook. The banks learned on Monday that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission in Washington was planning to announce its own settlements in the case, ending weeks of suspense over whether the agency would act in coordination with British authorities and United States banking regulators. The agency is expected to level around $300 million in fines against each of the banks, with the worst offenders paying slightly more and marginal players somewhat less.

title: The Advantages of World Leaders Looking Silly
description: Global leaders attending an economic summit meeting in Beijing on Tuesday wore their usual uniforms  dark suits, white shirts, subdued ties  for meetings and trade announcements, but the opening photos of the event that went around the world showed them in more unconventional garb: amethyst tunics with Mandarin collars.

title: Bright Passages
description: Heres another small sampling of sparkling prose in recent editions, from serious to silly to Kenny G.

title: Race: If You Cant Laugh About It
description: Asian women complain to me that theyre preyed on by white guys with yellow fever. But I say I havent paid for a meal in three years, said Kristina Wong, joking on Myx TV about men who only date Asian women. This is the type of humor that The Timess Off Color videos highlight in an effort to start a more relaxed dialogue about race. The series was created by Tanzina Vega, whose national beat is focused on Americas changing demographics, and Channon Hodge, a video journalist.

title: In Performance: Joely Richardson of The Belle of Amherst
description: Theres a touch of the poet in this weeks video, which features Joely Richardson in a scene from the revival of The Belle of Amherst, William Luces biographical play about Emily Dickinson. Charles Isherwood, in his review of the solo show, said Ms. Richardson meets the challenge of shaping the verse capably, setting the shimmering phrases apart from Dickinsons chattering monologue with a nice delicacy, and a welcome absence of ostentatious bravura. The play, directed by Steve Cosson, continues through Nov. 23 at the Westside Theater.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

Israeli Forces Kill Palestinian Man in West Bank Clash
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli forces fatally shot a Palestinian man during a demonstration in the occupied West Bank on Tuesday, a day after a pair of knife attacks by Palestinians left an Israeli soldier and a female settler dead.

title: 22 Imprisoned in Crackdown on Extremism in Xinjiang
description: BEIJING  The authorities in Xinjiang, an ethnically divided region in northwest China, have imprisoned 22 people in a mass sentencing that included charges of rape, disturbing public order and illegal preaching, a state news media outlet reported on Tuesday.

title: Excluded From the Silicon Valley Dream
description: I feel alone every day I come to work, writes Erica Joy, despite being surrounded by people. In a widely read Medium essay, she chronicles her experiences as a black woman in a tech industry dominated by white men. And in so doing, she shows how deep the effects of exclusion can go.

title: Putin Gives Shawl to Chinas First Lady
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia caused a minor stir Monday after offering a shawl to the wife of President Xi Jinping of China at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.

title: On Veterans Day, Offering Gratitude and Accepting It
description: When I told the man at the baggage counter that my husband was deployed, he immediately replied, Thank you for your service. I didnt quite know how to respond, so I smiled uncomfortably and nodded, graciously trying to clarify that my husband was the one serving. When I think of the phrase service to our country, I can hear the bayonets and see the tattered flag waving valiantly in the breeze.

title: Japanese Leader Cites Improved Ties With Beijing
description: BEIJING  Striking an upbeat note, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said Tuesday that he believed his country and China had taken a major step forward in repairing relations, and that from now on there should be frequent dialogue between them.

title: On This Day: An Armistice Is Signed
description: Thousands of people will flock to the National Mall today to commemorate Veterans Day with live music from the likes of Bruce Springsteen and Eminem.

title: Should the United States Declare Books an Essential Good?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. The French government has declared books an essential good. This week, Daniel Mendelsohn and Mohsin Hamid debate whether the United States should do the same.

description: Long a favorite of toddlers, three-wheelers have also attracted the attention of British lords, Indian maharajahs  and now, one writer hopes, a bold new generation.

title: GitHub Hits the Cloud
description: Software is eating the world, as venture capitalist Marc Andreessen noted three years ago. Now it may not even be taking the time to chew carefully.

title: Court Lets E.U. Nations Curb Immigrant Welfare
description: BERLIN  The European Unions top court put its thumb on the scale of one of the blocs most divisive issues Tuesday, ruling in effect that richer countries can limit access to welfare benefits for citizens from poorer ones.

title: Sotomayors Notable Court Opinions and Articles
Dozens Die in Bus Crash on Pakistan Highway
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least 57 people were killed and 18 were injured on Tuesday when a passenger bus rammed into a truck in southern Pakistan, officials and rescue workers said.

title: Africa Cup Disrupted by Ebola Concerns
description: Fear of the spread of Ebola has now thrown Africas most important soccer tournament into disarray.

description: UniCredit said on Tuesday that net profit more than tripled in the third quarter as the Italian bank booked lower losses related to doubtful loans.

description: For recovered Ebola patients, the new rules of etiquette demand hugs.

title: 1964: Monnet Meets With de Gaulle
description: PARIS  Jean Monnet, chief proponent of a United States of Europe, met today with its chief opponent, President Charles de Gaulle, to discuss the current crisis in the Common Market. Coming during a confrontation between France and West Germany over agriculture, stirred much speculation. Upon leaving the Elyse Palace, Mr. Monnet told reporters: I dont think the Franco- German difficulties are insoluble. A solution could be found in Brussels. Then he added with a laugh: I repeat that what Im saying does not reflect the conversation Ive just had with Gen. de Gaulle. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 12, 1964

title: 100 Years After World War I Began, Europe Remembers Its End
description: LONDON  In Britain, there were commemorative poppies by the hundreds of thousands, bright red ceramics that filled the moat of the Tower of London.

description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said meeting with President Xi Jinping of China was a big step for improving relations.

description: The iPhone may cause broken bones and concussions. Yes, Im leaving out a few in-between steps there.

description: In July, Kathy Murphy received a letter from the Social Security Administration. We are writing to tell you that you do not qualify for widows benefits, it said. You do not qualify for the lump-sum death benefit because you are not Sara Elizabeth Barkers widow or child.

title: With Persistence and Phone Calls, Defending Against Ebola in New York
description: On the 12th floor of a glass tower at the city health departments headquarters in Long Island City, Queens, workers huddle like telemarketers at banks of 30 computers, doggedly calling one telephone number after another.

description: A midterm election has come and gone, and now begins a new round of speculation about whether the Democrats can remobilize young and nonwhite voters in 2016.

title: A Dual Review of Whats New, Starring Lisa Kudrow and Jarvis Cocker
description: Lisa Kudrow, alleged Post-it note inventor and everyones favorite Friend who currently stars in a pair of cable series: Showtimes Web Therapy and HBOs The Comeback, which just came back after a nine-year hiatus, takes on Jarvis Cocker, Britpop icon and the droll subject of a new documentary on his band, Pulp: A Film About Life, Death & Supermarkets. His radio show  a nocturnal exploration of the human condition  is available on iTunes.

title: States Race to Improve Health Insurance Exchanges
description: WASHINGTON  Massachusetts and Minnesota have sharply increased the number of call center workers who will help people enroll in health plans through the states insurance exchanges. Colorado has created an online avatar named Kyla to guide consumers through the sign-up process. And Maryland has replaced its exchange, which floundered last year, with Connecticuts successful model.

description: Fans of Gillian Flynns dark view of a marriage in Gone Girl may want to read Masks, her first comic-book story, to be published by Dark Horse Comics in February.

title: Song From the Forest Charts a Musicologists Love Affair With Pygmy Music and Culture
description: Back in March, while at the South by Southwest festival to discuss data visualization with a NASA team, I had a chance to watch Song from the Forest, a deeply captivating visual and sonic exploration of the strange, music-driven life of Louis Sarno, an American ethnomusicologist who was lured to the Congo River basin in the 1980s by recordings of pygmy songs and, in many ways, never came back.

title: Today in Small Business: An S.E.O. Challenge
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: With Faith of Investors, Downtown Tulsa Reawakens
description: For decades, the Mayo Hotel had been the societal symbol of Tulsas reign as the Oil Capital of the World, catering to oil barons with names like Getty, Skelly, Phillips and Sinclair. But its closing in 1981 underscored the citys faded status as Houston became the focal point of the energy industry.

title: Celebrating Diane von Furstenbergs Memoir, The Woman I Wanted to Be
description: Oh gosh, the first dress I ever bought with my own money was a wrap dress, Chelsea Clinton said. About 10 years ago  at the Stanford shopping mall, probably. I still have it.

title: Nonclassical, a London New-Music Franchise, Expanding to New York
description: Nonclassical, the London-based indie-classical new-music label and club series run by the composer and producer Gabriel Prokofiev, is celebrating its 10th anniversary with an expansion to New York. In a collaboration with the like-minded New Amsterdam label, Nonclassical will present the first New York installment of the Classical Club-Nights series it presents monthly in London.

title: Working Parents Who Cook, or Dont Cook, Family Meals
description: These days, the advice on healthy eating seems to come from many corners. But the consensus is there.

title: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Brussels Sprouts Sliders
description: This year for Wells Vegetarian Thanksgiving were highlighting some of our favorite  and your favorite  recipes from Vegetarian Thanksgivings past. Heres one from 2014, when we asked readers to submit their own favorites. See more of Wells Vegetarian Thanksgiving selections at NYT Cooking.

title: De Blasio Hugs Recovered Ebola Patient
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York was present as Dr. Craig Spencer, who contracted Ebola while working in West Africa, was released from Bellevue Hospital Center upon being declared cured.

title: On a Mexican Island, Murals With a Conservation Message
description: The small island of Isla Mujeres, off the coast of Cancn, Mexico, is getting big dose of art with the recent inauguration of Sea Walls: Murals for Oceans, a display of 15 large-scale murals by some of the top names in contemporary street art.

title: 9 Wallpaper Studies
description: The artist Leanne Shapton painted wallpaper from museums, stately homes and National Trust houses in England.

title: A Well-Timed Book Tour for Rubio
description: Senator Marco Rubio says he is not sure whether he will run for president, but he is planning a national book tour that just happens to coincide with the start of the presidential election cycle.

title: This Veterans Day, Read (and Listen to) Family Stories
description: When I was growing up, it felt like everyone had family in the military. My father served, as did his father. We lived close to a variety of military bases; I went to college near Fort Riley, in Kansas. My roommate married a military man; my cousin and her husband both serve.

title: John Doar, Federal Lawyer on Front Lines Against Segregation, Dies at 92
description: John Doar, a country lawyer from northern Wisconsin who led the federal governments on-the-ground efforts to dismantle segregation in the South, and who later headed the team that made the case for impeaching President Richard M. Nixon in the wake of the Watergate scandal, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 92. The cause was congestive heart failure, his son Robert said.

title: New York Jazz Clubs Double as Record Labels
description: The saxophonist Ian Hendrickson-Smith has caught his share of deflected stardust: as a former foot soldier with Sharon Jones and the Dap-Kings, as a hired gun for the likes of Al Green and as a member of The Tonight Show band (which is to say, the Roots). For the rest of this year, as part of the Loston Harris Trio, hell appear Thursday through Saturday nights at Bemelmans Bar, the hobnobby lounge in the Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan.

title: Higher Counterbid Made for Club Med, With Help From K.K.R.
description: PARIS  Andrea C. Bonomi, the Italian businessman battling a Chinese-French bid for Club Mditerrane, on Tuesday announced another sweetened offer for the resort company, this time with backing from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Company.

title: The Dining Section Is Now Food
description: We have renamed this section, in print and online, to reflect its increasingly broad focus on food and drink, restaurants and home cooking, gastronomic trends and innovation. The new name looks forward, to coverage that extends beyond the dining room. But it looks back as well: Food was the name of the report Craig Claiborne edited when he joined The New York Times in 1957. It provides the foundation upon which we build today.

title: Tig Notaro Says Shes Healing After Surgery
description: The comedian Tig Notaro said on Tuesday that she was recovering from a burst cyst that had required her to undergo emergency surgery and cancel several planned performances.

title: Reporters Barred From Alito Speech? Just a Small Mix-Up
description: The Supreme Court is famously secretive, and its justices do not always make it easy for the press to cover their public appearances. Still, reporters were surprised on Tuesday morning when the Federalist Society, a conservative legal group, announced that the news media would be barred from an appearance by Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. at its annual gala black-tie dinner.

title: In Tokyo, Following Elders to Bargains
description: One of Tokyos mainstay tourist attractions is Harajuku, a labyrinthine shopping district jammed with trend-obsessed teenagers parading famously outlandish fashions. But in spite of Harajukus youthful flash and flair, to walk around the city is to realize that Japan is a country of old people. Gray-haired grandpas zip past on bicycles, impressing with their cavalier attitude toward traffic. Immaculately coifed senior women do the same, their faces freshly powdered and lipsticked, their flowered shirts neatly pressed.

title: Officials Discuss Violence in West Bank
description: The Israeli defense minister and the president of the Palestinian Authority discussed the escalating violence in the West Bank after Israeli forces fatally shot a Palestinian man on Tuesday.

title: BNP Paribas Could Make a Merger With Monte dei Paschi Work
description: BNP Paribas should be thinking seriously about Monte dei Paschi di Siena. After this years $8.9 billion fine from American regulators, BNPs shareholders probably feel theyve had enough excitement. But looking past the risks, there would be logic to swooping on the Italian lender.

title: Chris Christie: Selling Out Local Pigs for Iowa Pig Farmers
description: The National Review has brought renewed attention to an animal-welfare bill awaiting New Jersey Gov. Chris Christies signature. Somewhat unusually for a conservative publication not associated with environmental causes or animal rights, the piece argues that the Republican governor should go ahead and sign the bill, which would ban the use of gestation crates for pregnant sows.

title: Chief Defends Spotify After Snub by Taylor Swift
description: Spotify is the future. Spotify is the enemy. Spotify doesnt pay enough. Spotify is musics best bet for revenue growth.

description: The New York Times columnist Nicholas Kristof discussed the complicated agenda of President Obamas weeklong tour of Asia on MSNBCs Now With Alex Wagner.

description: BEIJING  China and the United States made common cause on Wednesday against the threat of climate change, staking out an ambitious joint plan to curb carbon emissions as a way to spur nations around the world to make their own cuts in greenhouse gases.

title: Can America and Russia Get Along?
description: Dayton, Ohio  To hear some Russians tell it, the United States has a master plan to demonize their president, Vladimir Putin, and use sanctions, imposed because of the crisis in Ukraine, to bring down his government. They also accuse Washington of backing pro-Nazi factions in Ukraine.

description: Headliner

title: Wheelies: The Duality of Honda Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Custody Agreement Reached in Investment Bankers Messy Divorce
description: An ugly divorce battle that briefly riveted Wall Street has ended with a whimper.

title: Restaurant Report: BackYard Bia Hoi in Hanoi
description: In Vietnamese, bia hoi refers to both fresh-brewed beer and the roadside restaurants where locals, perched on plastic stools, gather to consume it. The light brew is typically enjoyed with snacks like roasted peanuts and fermented sausage and simple stir-fries of whatever ingredients happen to be on hand.

title: Hotel Review: Amoy Hotel in Singapore
description: Standard rooms start at 238 Singapore dollars, about $190, at 1.25 Singapore dollars to the U.S. dollar.

title: It Wasnt Just the Shoes
description: There are tour guides, and there are tour guides. Should you visit the Philippines, see if you can still get Carlos Celdran, who is also a performance artist and has brought his very entertaining solo show, Livin la Vida Imelda, to the Clurman Theater.

title: Fearing Bombs That Can Pick Whom to Kill
description: On a bright fall day last year off the coast of Southern California, an Air Force B-1 bomber launched an experimental missile that may herald the future of warfare.

title: Two Sides, One Ensemble
description: Two ensembles showed up onstage when the storied Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra played at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday and Monday, led by its music director, Riccardo Chailly.

title: The Plight of Gay Veterans
description: As we celebrate Veterans Day, lets pause to consider the men and women who have served in the armed forces, but who dont have access to the full array of benefits available to their colleagues because theyre gay.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: In Net Neutrality Push, Internet Giants on the Sidelines
description: Silicon Valleys giant companies have been quiet lately on the question of whether the government should protect an open Internet, which theyve previously argued is vital to innovation. Dont count on them staking out a stronger position even though President Obama has stepped into the fray, and Washington looks to be gearing up for an epic battle over the rules that govern the Internet.

title: Even the Stars Are Fans
description: This is my first night out as a mother, Ms. Clinton said while accepting her award on Monday night.

title: Should Your Child Play Football?
description: To the partisan battles of red and blue America, we can apparently add another culture clash: football.

title: WNYCs Soundcheck to Go Online-Only
description: Soundcheck, the weekday music program on WNYC that has been a staple of the New York music scene since 2002, will be going off the air at the end of this week.

title: U.S. Bishops Struggle to Follow Lead of Francis
description: BALTIMORE  It was a hail and farewell moment at a tumultuous time for the Roman Catholic Church. More than 200 bishops rose to their feet Monday and gave a protracted standing ovation to Cardinal Francis George, a former president of the bishops conference, who will step down next week as the archbishop of Chicago.

title: From The Upshot: A Look at the Next Big Election
description: Why the Voters of 2016 Are Likely to Be Younger and More Diverse

title: Missouri Governor Says National Guard Is Still Option in Ferguson
description: WELDON SPRING, Mo.  Gov. Jay Nixon said Tuesday that the Missouri National Guard was part of a multiforce contingency plan by law enforcement authorities to avert violence as the region around St. Louis awaited a grand jurys return in the death of Michael Brown three months ago.

title: Detroit Emerges From Bankruptcy, Yet Pension Risks Linger
description: When the judge in Detroits historic bankruptcy case approved the citys exit plan on Friday, he said the deal Detroit cut with its retirees bordered on miraculous.

title: Grim Horrors of Modernity, via Auden
description: LONDON  Britain is awash in World War I centenary commemorations and poppy mania. Ballet companies here havent lagged behind. Both English National Ballet and the Birmingham Royal Ballet have offered war-themed programs; on Friday came the Royal Ballets contribution, with a triple bill that uses music by Britten and Leonard Bernstein from the 1930s and 40s and poetry by W. H. Auden to evoke a period in which another great war changed the world.

title: Hollywood on the Tiber
description: What could be more melancholic, extravagant, alienated, operatic and deeply strange than Italian film? Try turning Italian film into a theme park.

title: A Hot Coffee Culture in Salt Lake City
description: In a place known more for proximity to powdery ski slopes than perfect espresso pulls, its easy to assume Salt Lake City couldnt breed advanced coffee geek culture. Yet the high-desert city has become the kind of town where some cafes sell 12 ounces of roasted coffee beans for $50 and teach customers about the benefits of drinking coffee without cream or sugar.

title: Russia Reaches Deal With Iran to Construct Nuclear Plants
description: MOSCOW  Russia agreed on Tuesday to build two new nuclear power reactors in Iran, with a possibility of six more after that, in a deal that greatly expands nuclear cooperation between the two countries.

title: Argentinas Feeder System Drains Talent From Nations Top Division
description: BUENOS AIRES  Casual fans might think Argentine soccer is enjoying a golden age. The countrys national team finished second at the World Cup last summer, led by Lionel Messi, a player many consider one of the best to play the game, and Argentine players and coaches are key figures at many of the worlds top clubs.

title: A Tribute to Veterans at Attack Site in Ottawa
description: OTTAWA  Tens of thousands of Canadians streamed toward the National War Memorial on Tuesday, just three weeks after a gunman shot a soldier guarding it and rampaged through the Parliament building, plunging the capital into panic and fear.

title: Love Flows, President to President
description: The relationship between George W. Bush and his father, George H. W. Bush, might just be the most dissected filial relationship in modern history  compared, variously, to Shakespearean history, Greek tragedy and opra bouffe. In his new book, the 43rd president draws an affectionate portrait of the 41st president thats short on factual revelations and long on emotion.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 11 Waiver Wire Picks
description: We are one week away from not having to worry about bye weeks and the fantasy playoffs are just around the corner. And we are finally done with being inundated by political ads. All is right with the world, right?

title: Xi Jinpings Rapid Rise in China Presents Challenges to the U.S.
description: HONG KONG  President Obama will sit down Wednesday with the kind of Chinese leader no American president has ever encountered: a strongman with bold ambitions at home and abroad who sees China as a great power peer of the United States.

title: What Exit? For Some in New Jersey, the Answer Has Changed
description: In New Jersey, divining where someone is from can be done with a simple question or two  enough to learn a region, a county or a municipality.

title: Why the Theater Next Door Isnt Fit for a Queen
description: How badly did the Broadway producers of The Audience, a coming play starring Helen Mirren, want their first-choice theater, the Schoenfeld? Enough to brush off rival producers who were prepared to pay them $400,000 for dibs on the house.

title: The Look of the APEC Summit
description: World leaders at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum have shown off traditional apparel of the host country every year.

title: On Fifth Avenue, With Flags and Pride on Veterans Day
description: The Annual Veterans Day Parade in Manhattan began at 11:11 a.m. and proceeded from 26th Street to 52nd Street.

title: Photos From Veterans Day
description: A look at Veterans Day gatherings from around the country.

title: Police Seek Suspects in Manhattan Jewelry Store Robbery
description: An armed robber posing as a delivery man stole a bag of jewelry on Tuesday afternoon from a store in Manhattans diamond district, the authorities said, prompting a search and unsettling the usually bustling block.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: France and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Missouri May Use National Guard Again
description: As Ferguson awaits a decision on whether a police officer will face charges in the shooting death of Michael Brown, Gov. Jay Nixon said the National Guard could be deployed to protect against violence.

title: Zoetis, an Animal Health Company, Says Ackman Has Taken a Stake
description: The activist investor William A. Ackman appears to have found yet another target for his hedge fund in the health care industry: Zoetis, the former animal health arm of Pfizer that is now a $21.8 billion publicly traded company.

title: Will Bill Clinton Be First Husband? Ellens Turn to Ask
description: Interviewers of all kinds have been prodding the Clintons with questions from every angle in hopes of gathering a clue about Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential intentions.

title: European Antitrust Regulators to Hold Discussions With Googles Rivals
description: European antitrust regulators will hold discussions with the companies most concerned by Googles business practices before deepening existing investigations or resolving them, the new competition commissioner for the European Union said Tuesday.

title: Nov. 11, 2014  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from France, China, Poland and the United States.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Landing on a Comet: Inside Rosetta Orbiters Philae Landing Mission
description: Joel W. Parker, a planetary scientist at the Southwest Research Institute in Boulder, Colo., is the deputy principal investigator for an ultraviolet spectrograph instrument on the European Space Agencys Rosetta spacecraft, which is orbiting Comet 67P/ChuryumovGerasimenko. Dr. Parker was not working on the Rosetta project at the very beginning, more than two decades ago, but he has been working on it for a long time, since 1998.

title: Playing at DOC NYC
description: Images of some of the films appearing in the festival.

title: A Murder Mystery Thaws After 5 Decades in the Freezer
description: Television is full of true-crime stories, many of them trashily told, but the genre is well served by the one offered on Wednesday night on LMN, Footsteps in the Snow. Its a movie-length treatment of what is often described as the coldest cold case ever solved, the 1957 murder of a 7-year-old girl in Sycamore, Ill. A man named Jack McCullough was finally convicted of the crime in 2012.

title: Images That Dare You to Turn Away
description: To hell and back describes the psychological journey of the great Brazilian photographer Sebastio Salgado in the magnificent documentary The Salt of the Earth. Directed by Wim Wenders and Juliano Ribeiro Salgado, Mr. Salgados son, the film is a crowning moment in DOC NYC, the nonfiction film festival starting on Thursday. Some of Mr. Salgados black-and-white photos are grisly, Boschian tableaus of the worlds horrors with the formal beauty and grand composition of paintings by the Renaissance masters.

title: How to Cure the Housewife Blues
description: The libretto of Shostakovichs bitterly satirical 1934 opera, Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk, sets the first scene in the bedroom of Katerina, the restless wife of a dull merchant who has taken over the prosperous family business from his oafish father. Katerinas husband has left for work, and she has gone back to bed. But she is too bored and depressed to sleep.

title: Soccer Player Convicted of Rape Will Train With Old Club
description: A Welsh soccer player who spent two years in prison for rape will resume training at his former club in England, Sheffield United, the club said in a statement.

title: As Sears Gasps, Lampert Turns to Financial Engineering to Revive It
description: Sears Holdings is dying a slow, sad death led by its chief executive, Edward S. Lampert, and his hedge fund, ESL Investments, yet Wall Street is going mad over its stock.

title: Yahoo Buys BrightRoll, a Video Ad Platform, for $640 Million
description: Yahoos chief executive, Marissa Mayer, is starting to spend the $6.3 billion that the Internet company netted from selling shares in Alibabas initial public offering.

title: As Currency Settlement Draws Near, Barclays Gets Cold Feet
description: On the eve of a multibillion-dollar settlement with six giant banks suspected of manipulating the foreign currency market, regulators in Washington and Britain encountered a last-second complication: One of the banks was dropping out of the deal.

title: Recent Commercial Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Animation of How New Missiles May Work
description: In an artistic rendering from Lockheed Martin, tactical missiles that operate using artificial intelligence are shown selecting and destroying their targets.

title: Lawyers for the Homeless
description: To the Editor:

title: Replacing Workfare
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sports Boycott of Iran?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ways to Improve New Yorks Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Pictures, Raising Children
description: A generation of female photographers is looking to one another for advice and support as they raise children while still going on assignment overseas.

title: Lame-Duck Session Is First Crucial Test of Breaking Gridlock
description: WASHINGTON  Fresh from an election that emphatically punctuated voter dissatisfaction with a gridlocked Washington, lawmakers return Wednesday for a lame-duck session that will provide the first crucial test of whether Democrats and Republicans can cooperate or if the next Congress will be another study in dysfunction.

title: First Aluminum-Body Ford F-Series Pickup Trucks Come Off Assembly Line
description: DEARBORN, Mich.  It was hardly planned this way, but Ford Motor on Tuesday began building its most fuel-efficient pickup ever, just as gas prices kept dropping to their lowest level in years.

title: U.N. Seeks a More Nimble Response to Ebola in Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS  A shortage of international health workers and delays in building Ebola treatment clinics in West Africa are forcing the United Nations to change course in fighting the virus, and to call for smaller and more mobile treatment units that make greater use of local staff  and in turn require more money.

title: Should Herms, LVMH and Kering Keep Their Fights Private?
description: When a French labor court finally ruled last week against the designer John Galliano in his wrongful-dismissal case against the house of Dior and Galliano (which is owned by Dior)  a case that dates back more than three years  the symbolic, almost-comical amount of one euro that he was ordered to pay suggested that a certain message was being sent to both sides: Enough is enough.

title: Are Democrats Losing the Youth Vote?
description: ATLANTA  ONCE again, the youth vote went firmly Democratic in last weeks election  but the actual numbers, combined with some telling survey results, indicate that the partys grip on the young may be loosening.

title: Mexico: Protesters Burn Party Office
description: Teachers and students protesting the abduction and apparent murder of 43 college students in September set fire Tuesday to the headquarters of President Enrique Pea Nietos party in Guerrero State. The protesters, who clashed with the police over several hours, at one point detained the state security chief but later released him. A number of demonstrations have erupted since Friday, when federal officials said they had found burned remains that may be those of the missing students. Witnesses have told the authorities that the students were abducted by the police and turned over to a drug gang that killed them.

title: Oregon Passes Florida State in College Football Playoff Rankings
description: Under the Bowl Championship Series and its two-team championship, a late-season game like Saturday nights between Michigan State and Ohio State  ranked No. 8 and No. 14 at the time in the Associated Press poll  would have had few playoff implications.

title: Wobbling on Climate Change
description: GREENBELT, Md.  IM a climate scientist and a former astronaut. Not surprisingly, I have a deep respect for well-tested theories and facts. In the climate debate, these things have a way of getting blurred in political discussions.

title: Guyana: Legislature Is Suspended
description: The president of Guyana has suspended the National Assembly in an escalating conflict with the political opposition. President Donald Ramotar used a constitutional mechanism that gives him the right to disband the legislature for up to six months. He said he had taken the step on Monday to keep the legislature from holding a no-confidence vote. In a speech to the nation, Mr. Ramotar criticized opposition politicians for an atmosphere of confrontation and pledged to seek an agreement with them that would allow the legislature to return to work. David Granger, a retired general who leads the opposition, called the presidents action a denial of democracy, according to The Associated Press, which said legislators had staged a protest outside the Parliament building.

title: Volkswagen to Sponsor a CNN Series
