description: The Salon: Art & Design, the toniest of the November fairs (and certainly the one with the most aristocratic title), reminds you how the categories of art and design tend to blur in the rarefied world of ultra-high-end dcor. Installed at the Park Avenue Armory for a third season, it caters to browsing design aficionados as well as trophy-condo buyers and their interior designers with a mix of furniture from the 18th to the 21st centuries and an even wider range of art (and in the lounge, for those with V.I.P. cards, caviar made by hand from sustainably farmed white sturgeon.)

title: Then We Could Swing a Cat From a Chandelier
description: In Dumb and Dumber To, Peter and Bobby Farrelly  and the stars Jim Carrey and Jeff Daniels  have boldly if unoriginally returned to the scene of their inaugural crime: their 1994 directing debut, Dumb and Dumber. An anti-classic of its disreputable, guffawing type, it wasnt the first movie to elevate human idiocy into an intentional art; Jerry Lewis and Caddyshack, among many others, got there long before Lloyd (Mr. Carrey) and Harry (Mr. Daniels) hit the road in their memorably fuzzy puppy-mobile with the wagging tongue.

title: New Museum Triennial to Examine the Surround Audience
description: The New Museum announced on Thursday that its triennial, which focuses on emerging artists and opens its third iteration on Feb. 25, will feature 51 artists and collectives from more than 25 countries and will delve deeply into what one of its curators, Lauren Cornell, describes as a contemporary condition wherein we are encircled by a smarter and more participatory world.

title: Prison Officials Seeking Ways to Recruit and Retain Guards
description: BEEVILLE, Tex.  Seventeen soon-to-be corrections officers in blue-and-gray uniforms listened attentively as Maj. Robert Lopez explained the importance of their professional appearance and warned them of the corrupting influences they will face on the job.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Nov. 13
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include images from Veterans Day and a visit with a rat starring on Broadway.

title: Warner and Tencent Announce Licensing Deal
description: In the music industrys latest effort to make money from China, the Warner Music Group has signed an extensive licensing deal with Tencent, one of Chinas biggest Internet businesses, the companies announced on Thursday.

title: Ebola Scare Behind It, Texas Is Bracing for the Next Viral Crisis
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Texas recently closed the book on its first cases of Ebola. The remaining people still being monitored after having come into contact with the man who died of the disease in Dallas last month, or with two nurses who contracted it, were cleared a week ago. But the virus, or something like it, can be expected to return, said the new head of a state task force on infectious diseases.

title: This Weeks Movies | Nov. 14, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review Foxcatcher, Rosewater and Beyond the Lights.

title: A Local Prize Could Ease a Losss Sting
description: Leticia Van de Puttes decision to run for lieutenant governor always had a win-or-win-by-losing flavor to it. The Democrats campaign came in the middle of her current Senate term. Had her run been successful, she would be on her way to the corner office outside the Legislatures upper chamber. A loss was largely without cost. She remains a senator, and while Democrats are still the minority party, the Senate is the kind of place where an experienced player in the minority can sometimes exercise real power.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Goldman Sachs Recasts Its Reputation to Woo Tech Talent
description: A panel of Goldman Sachs employees spent a recent Tuesday night at the Columbia University faculty club trying to convince a packed room of potential recruits that Wall Street, not Silicon Valley, was the place to be for computer scientists.

title: For a Liberian Family, Ebola Turns Loving Care Into Deadly Risk
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  Days after Kaizer Dour died of Ebola at the edge of a mangrove swamp, strangers carried his rotting corpse in a dugout canoe for a secret burial. Out on an uninhabited, bush-covered island, far from the national basketball court where Kaizer won acclaim as one of Liberias most valuable players last season, the strangers fulfilled one of the most important duties of a Liberian family  burying the young man.

title: In India, Latrines Are Truly Lifesavers
description: The mural on the wall outside of Chandramani Janis home is more message than art. It depicts a sari-clad woman relieving herself behind a bush, looking worried as a man advances. A large thought bubble suggests the woman wishes for a toilet of her own, clean and complete with the privacy of a door.

title: Ex-Executive Donald Blankenship Is Indicted in Disaster at Coal Mine
description: The former chief executive of the company involved in the nations worst coal mine disaster in 40 years, in which 29 men died in West Virginia in 2010, was charged on Thursday with widespread violations of safety rules and deceiving federal inspectors.

title: Many Forces Are Pulling DreamWorks Animation in Diverse Directions
description: LOS ANGELES  Walt Disney is a big studio built around smaller units: Marvel Entertainment, Pixar and the classic Disney animation shop, among others.

title: Clayton Kershaw and Mike Trout Run Away With M.V.P. Votes
description: The connection is unmistakable, now more than ever, though Sandy Koufax always maintains that Clayton Kershaw is his own man, and not a protg. Koufax deeply admires Kershaw, the modern ace of the Los Angeles Dodgers, and asked to present him with the Cy Young Award last January at the baseball writers dinner in New York.

title: A Review of the Sept. 19 White House Incident
description: A report by the Department of Homeland Security noted performance, organizational, technical and other failures that allowed a man to get inside the mansion in September.

title: With a Whisper, Pfister Takes a Comedic Jab at Highbrow Faucet Commercials
description: HOUSEHOLD faucets are the essence of functionality, but they are often advertised as luxury goods. Last year, for example, one of the leading faucet brands, Moen, introduced a television commercial in which a model in an evening dress sashays into a bathroom and puts on a gleaming, oversize necklace. The necklace then slips from her neck and, through digital animation, scatters into pieces on the counter, reassembling as a faucet. Statement piece for your bathroom, says a voice-over.

title: An Agreement on Climate Change
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors as Targets
description: To the Editor:

title: Net Neutrality
description: To the Editor:

title: Gov.-Elect Larry Hogan, a Republican, Stands Tall in Democratic Maryland
description: DUNDALK, Maryland  Um, Larry who?

title: For Equity in Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor de Blasios Lateness
description: To the Editor:

title: Federally Contracted Food Workers Strike Over Wages
description: WASHINGTON  The cafeteria lines in the Capitol Visitors Center and the National Zoo may have moved slower on Thursday after hundreds of federally contracted food service workers went on a one-day strike.

title: A Fatally Flawed Switch, and a Burdened G.M. Engineer
description: DETROIT  Raymond DeGiorgio was just another obscure engineer at General Motors  until the company blamed him for starting the worst safety crisis in its history.

title: Psychologists to Review Role in Detainee Interrogations
description: WASHINGTON  The nations largest organization of psychologists will conduct an independent review into whether it colluded with or supported the governments use of torture in the interrogation of prisoners during the Bush administration.

title: Jurgen Klinsmann, Back in London, Sees Exhibition as Important Test for U.S. Mens National Team
description: LONDON  In the drizzle outside Craven Cottage, the stadium that is home to Fulham, one of Englands oldest professional teams, the knots of fans who gathered during training sessions Thursday night for a shot at the autographs of their heroes had two men atop their lists.

title: Portugal: Legionnaires Disease Alert
description: An outbreak of Legionnaires disease has killed at least five people and sickened more than 300 in Portugal, the World Health Organization reported Thursday. It said Portuguese health authorities had first taken notice a week earlier, identifying 17 cases in Villa Franca de Xira, a suburban area of Lisbon. Since then, the W.H.O. said, the disease has spread rapidly and is now considered to be a major public health emergency. The precise cause of the outbreak remained under investigation, but the W.H.O. said health officials in the affected area had taken protective steps, including increasing the chlorine used in tap water and issuing public warnings to avoid showers, Jacuzzis and whirlpools. Legionnaires disease is a type of pneumonia caused by the Legionella bacteria, which survive in water or mist. It is named after a 1976 outbreak that afflicted people who attended a convention of the American Legion in Philadelphia.

title: The Agency Moment
description: George Eliot was an emotionally needy young woman. Throughout her 20s, she fell for a series of inappropriate and unavailable men, craving their affection. At one point, she got herself involved in a bizarre tangle with an editor and two other women. It was like a tragic farce as the women competed for his sympathy, complete with shifting alliances, slammed doors and storms of tears.

title: Pentagon Studies Reveal Major Nuclear Problems
description: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon will have to spend billions of dollars over the next five years to make emergency fixes to its nuclear weapons infrastructure, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel will announce on Friday, after two separate Pentagon studies concluded that there are systemic problems across the nuclear enterprise, according to senior defense officials.

title: Turkey: After an Attack on U.S. Sailors, 12 Suspects Are Charged and Released
description: Twelve Turks arrested in Istanbul in connection with a videotaped assault on three visiting American sailors were charged on Thursday with insult, inflicting injury and violating Turkeys protest and rally law, but all of them were released, Turkeys Anadolu news agency reported. It said prosecutors were still investigating the assault, which happened on Wednesday. It was unclear when the suspects would reappear in court. The sailors, out of uniform, had just left their ship, the guided missile destroyer Ross, when the assailants from a nationalist youth group taunted them with anti-American insults, lobbed balloons filled with red paint at them and pulled bags over their heads. Turkish officials have denounced the attack.

title: Who Burned Atlanta?
description: At 7 a.m. on Nov. 16, 1864, Maj. Gen. William T. Sherman accompanied the last corps of his Union army as it left Atlanta to begin a virtually uncontested March to the Sea, which would end in Savannah five weeks later. Three miles outside the city, he stopped for a final look back. Behind us lay Atlanta smoldering and in ruins, the black smoke rising high in the air and hanging like a pall over the ruined city, he recalled. Presently a nearby infantry band struck up John Browns anthem. Never  have I heard the chorus of Glory! Glory! Hallelujah! done with more spirit. The men were proud of what they had done.

title: Window Washing Skills Beyond a Robots Reach
description: As a pair of window washers clung to a scaffold dangling outside the 68th floor of 1 World Trade Center on Wednesday, the captivating drama left some below wondering: Why were they up there at all?

title: Obama, Down but Not Out, Presses Ahead
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama emerged from last weeks midterm election rejected by voters, hobbled politically and doomed to a final two years in office suffering from early lame-duck syndrome. That, at least, was the consensus in both parties. No one seems to have told Mr. Obama.

title: China, Coal, Climate
description: Its easy to be cynical about summit meetings. Often theyre just photo ops, and the photos from the latest Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting, which had world leaders looking remarkably like the cast of Star Trek, were especially cringe-worthy. At best  almost always  theyre just occasions to formally announce agreements already worked out by lower-level officials.

title: A House Is Not a Credit Card
description: THIS fall, federal regulators made a controversial decision to back down from tough new underwriting standards for mortgages. Some affordable-housing advocates, allied with parts of the corporate housing industry, had successfully argued that the proposed standards would make it too hard for people to qualify, thereby reducing homeownership and hurting the housing market. Last summer, that same trump card stopped a bipartisan bill to reform the mortgage market, more than six years after Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac had to be taken over by the government.

title: Kerry Is Optimistic After Meeting Over Holy Site in Jerusalem
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Secretary of State John Kerry said on Thursday that Jordan, Israel and the Palestinians were committed to taking concrete steps to ease strife over a volatile holy site in the Old City of Jerusalem.

title: Big and Bold on Immigration
description: President Obama is apparently ready to go big, as he promised, to fix immigration on his own  to use his law-enforcement discretion to spare perhaps five million unauthorized immigrants from deportation. Aides speaking anonymously have told The Times that Mr. Obama is considering some options for executive action that would give parents of children who are citizens or legal residents, as well as people who were brought here illegally as children, temporary legal status and permission to work.

title: The Fed and Full Employment
description: In late 2012, when the unemployment rate was 7.8 percent, Ben Bernanke, then the Federal Reserve chairman, said that the Fed would not raise interest rates as long as unemployment was above 6.5 percent. At that time, he expected the jobless rate to stay above 6.5 percent until at least mid-2015, which dovetailed with an earlier Fed projection for rate increases starting around mid-2015.

title: A Smarter Approach to Airline Safety
description: John Pistole, who announced recently that he would retire as head of the Transportation Security Administration at the end of the year, saw it as his mission to transform the agency from a bureaucracy that took a one size fits all approach to airplane security to one that takes a more risk based approach. That needed change is far from complete.

title: Iraq and Kurds Reach Deal on Oil Exports and Budget Payments
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs central government and the autonomous region of Kurdistan reached an interim agreement on Thursday over oil exports and budget payments, at least temporarily easing a bitter dispute that has threatened the governments stability.

title: Race, Politics and Drawing Maps
description: As long as politicians are entrusted with drawing legislative maps, they will use their pen to gain partisan advantage. Courts generally do not interfere with that process, but there are limits to this where race is involved. The problem is figuring out which motive  race or partisanship  underlies the redistricting. On Wednesday, the Supreme Court considered this issue in a thorny case that could have significant implications for the future of the Voting Rights Act.

title: At 9 Years Old, Her Troubles Were Just Beginning
description: When Paulette Bermudez was 9 years old, a man climbed through the window of her familys third-floor apartment in Brooklyn, grabbed her and held a knife to her neck. He threatened her mother, then locked up Ms. Bermudez. In a closet, she thinks. She does her best to forget the details.

title: U.N. Commission Presses U.S. on Torture
description: WASHINGTON  A United Nations panel that monitors compliance with an antitorture treaty expressed skepticism Thursday about American law enforcement and national security practices.

title: The Parole Paradox
Shift on Marijuana Policy Was a Long Time Coming, and Too Late for One Man
description: Anthony Welfare closely followed this weeks news that New York City no longer will bring criminal charges against people who are seen with small amounts of marijuana, as long as they are not smoking it in public.

title: Taking Issue With the Grind of the N.B.A. Season
description: No sooner had Oklahoma City defeated Boston on Wednesday night than the Celtics disappointment was washed away by the anticipation of Friday nights game at home against the Cleveland Cavaliers and the Big 3 of LeBron James, Kevin Love and Kyrie Irving.

title: The Wasp Goddess, Imperious, Vulnerable and (Gasp) Unmasked
description: Some women never seem to get older, because they never looked young to begin with. You know, the kind who make you think they must have been born 35, in their bountiful prime and in full makeup. You cant help wondering, though, about what really lurks behind the lipstick, and if the mask theyre wearing ever feels too tight.

title: What Might Break Peoples Trust
description: Administrivial Deb-Amlen-In-N.Y.C. Fun Times Alert! Pencils up, New York! If you plan to be in New York City on Sunday, Nov. 16, come hang out with me at the Ace Hotel, located at 20 West 29th Street, as I show people that they can solve the Sunday crossword puzzle with a minimum of tears and bloodshed. The fun starts at 11 a.m. E.T. and its open to the public. Hope to see you there, and if you are a Wordplayer, please be sure to come up and say hi. If youre not around this weekend, the Ace has added two additional dates  December 14, 2014 and January 18, 2015  so put it on your calendar and come solve with me! Click here for more information.

title: E-Cigarettes Gain Among High School Students, C.D.C. Finds
description: The share of American high school students who use e-cigarettes rose to 4.5 percent in 2013 from 2.8 percent in 2012, according to a survey of youth tobacco use released on Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The share of middle school students who use e-cigarettes remained flat at 1.1 percent over the same period.

title: Gisle Masson Dies at 89; Fed the Famous at La Grenouille
description: Gisle Masson, the grande dame of La Grenouille, the classic French restaurant on the East Side of Manhattan that was a favorite of high-society types and celebrities of various stripes, of fashion moguls and publishing executives, died on Nov. 5 in Paris. She was 89.

title: Nowhere to Run in Eastern Ukraine
description: DONETSK, Ukraine  Teachers preside over half-empty classrooms. Cars breeze through streets once chronically choked with traffic. Restaurant windows are boarded up.

title: In Sharp Pivot for N.B.A., Commissioner Backs Sports Betting
description: N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver broke from years of precedent by calling for the legalization of sports gambling in an article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times on Friday.

title: Sudan and Rebels Under Pressure to Find Path to Peace
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  After several postponements, negotiations between Sudans government and rebels resumed here this week in an effort to bring peace to the worn-torn country.

title: At Trial, Epilepsy and Questions of Blame in a Fatal Crash
description: Vincent Zanfardino had been repeatedly warned by his doctor not to drive before he had an epileptic seizure behind the wheel two years ago and crashed into another car, killing a 25-year-old man, a Bronx prosecutor said Thursday.

title: Delford Smith, Founder of Aviation Company, Dies at 84
description: Delford Smith, who founded a major international aviation company but who may be most remembered for his determination to preserve the mammoth seaplane known as the Spruce Goose  built in the 1940s by the wealthy recluse Howard Hughes  died on Nov. 7 at his home in Yamhill County, Ore., near Portland. He was 84.

title: Plan for a Desalination Plant Is Halted by New York State Officials
description: In a decision hailed by local residents and environmental groups, New York State officials on Thursday ordered a company that provides water to most of Rockland County and parts of Orange County to drop its efforts to build a desalination plant on the Hudson River in an effort to boost its water supply.

title: Framing New York
description: I was born in New York, but left with my family when I was young. I grew up in South Florida, where I spent most of my time in the ocean, surfing. In 1998, I returned to the city to work with the photographer Bruce Weber.

title: This Teacher Spends Life Being Taught
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Steve Kerr grinned when he was asked to recall his first basketball practice at Arizona.

title: Resurrecting the Artistry, and the Name, of a Singular Guitar Craftsman
description: When John DAngelico died in 1964, at the age of 59, he left behind a line of guitars that he had made by hand, one by one, in his shop below his apartment on Kenmare Street on the Lower East Side. His archtop guitars produced a stirring sound that could stand up to horns and percussion in big bands, and became some of the most coveted instruments in the world.

title: Gus Vlahavas, 76, Who Ran a Brooklyn Culinary Haven, Dies
description: On Saturday mornings, Toms restaurant in Brooklyn is so popular that people line up outside just to be served old-fashioned diner cuisine like chocolate egg creams and all manner of pancakes. It has been that way for years, and until the owner, Gus Vlahavas, died this month at 76, the patrons patience was rewarded with the free coffee, cookies, sausage bits and orange slices he handed out while they waited.

title: Struggling Avalanche Find an Answer Against the Rangers
description: Joe Sakic remembers well his early years with the Quebec Nordiques, when he and his fellow young teammates Mats Sundin and Owen Nolan were scoring in bunches for the struggling team.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 13, 2014
Prosecutions of Parents Can Vary After Children Left in Sweltering Cars Die
description: Haley Wesley, Lyn Balfour and Mikey Terry each had a different experience with the criminal justice system.

title: A Successor Shares Martin Brodeurs Stamina
description: NEWARK  When the Devils acquired Cory Schneider in a draft-day trade in 2013, they acquired the heir apparent to the legendary goaltender Martin Brodeur.

title: Brushing Off a French Stigma That Doggie Bags Are for Beggars
description: LYON, France  Fabrice Moya, a chef with a boyish grin who opened a restaurant by the same name here 12 years ago, has no problems with doggie bags.

title: A New One-Stop Shop for Practical, Internationally Sourced Home Goods
description: Three years ago, Momoko Mizutani gathered a collection of finely crafted homewares shed accumulated while traveling and opened a store, Objects for Use, in Londons East End. Mizutanis items were pragmatic and of diverse origin  doughnut pans from Denmark, five-kilo sauerkraut pots from Germany, woven bamboo baskets from Japan  and they represented her interests in ethical craftsmanship and traditional techniques as much as her own personal history. Originally from Japan, Mizutani moved to London as a teenager to study product design, and the objects she selected reflected her bicultural identity. Each item was made for a specific purpose in one culture but could be used in new ways, she says. They each suggested a sense of place.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
description: Warm winter pieces are putting their fuzziest feet forward this season via Muppet-like textures and shaggy shapes. Bold colors create a floral motif on a Michael Kors angora sweater and the appearance of a cuddly face on Fendis hairy handbag. The color-blocked fur on a pair of Brian Atwood shoes and Peter Pilotto collar add extra oomph to any outfit, while the understated fluff on a pair of Max Mara S Max cuffs or a Michael Kors hat will complement any wardrobe all season long.

title: An Anemic Auction Yields Just $52 Million at Phillips
description: Even after more than $1 billion worth of contemporary art sold at Sothebys and Christies earlier this week  an unprecedented sum for any auction season  there were still a few shoppers with the itch to spend. But at Phillips on Thursday evening, they spent carefully.

title: Word of the Day | downcast
description: downcast \daun-kast\ adjective

title: Nebraska: Center to Treat Ebola Patient
description: An Ebola patient in Sierra Leone will be transported to a hospital in Nebraska on Saturday if he is healthy enough to make the trip, hospital officials said on Thursday night. The patient, who recently tested positive for Ebola, would be the third person treated for the virus at Nebraska Medical Centers special biocontainment unit in Omaha. The hospital said in a statement that that the man would be evaluated for possible treatment by a medical crew flying to Sierra Leone. The members of the crew will determine whether the patient is stable enough for transport  if he is, he would arrive in Omaha sometime Saturday afternoon, the statement said. The hospital previously treated two Americans: Ashoka Mukpo, a freelance cameraman released last month, and Dr. Rick Sacra, a missionary released in September. Eight of the nine people treated for the virus in the United States have recovered from it.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 8 P.M. (CBS) HOLLYWOOD FILM AWARDS Queen Latifah hosts the first televised ceremony, live from the Hollywood Pavilion in Los Angeles, of this event, founded in 1997 and billed as the official launch of the awards season. Janelle Mone is to perform; Amy Adams, Steve Carell, Benedict Cumberbatch, Johnny Depp, Robert Downey Jr., Angelina Jolie, Jared Leto, Keira Knightley, Michael Keaton and Channing Tatum are scheduled to appear. Red-carpet coverage leads in at 7:30; Charlie Rose, Norah ODonnell and Gayle King will interview winners and recap the evenings highlights in The CBS Hollywood After Party, at 10.

title: South Korea Suspends Asiana Flights Between Incheon and San Francisco
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Koreas transport ministry decided on Friday to suspend Asiana Airlines flights between Incheon, South Korea, and San Francisco for 45 days as a penalty for the crash of one of its jets in the United States last year.

title: Corrections: November 14, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: They were together, a strong family, but this Ebola broke the entire family apart.

title: E.U. Accuses Starbucks and Netherlands of Making Unfair Tax Deal
description: BRUSSELS  European Union authorities have accused the Netherlands of making a special deal with Starbucks that helped the company lower its taxes, creating unfair advantages over other countries in the bloc.

title: Q. and A.: Edward J. Ramotowski on Implications of the New U.S.-China Visa Policy
description: The United States and Chinese governments announced on Monday a significant easing of visa regulations that would grant 10-year multiple-entry business and tourist visas for each others citizens. Students and exchange visitors could receive five-year visas. Under previous rules, most visitors received only one-year visas. China already sends the largest number of nonimmigrant foreign visitors to the United States, recently overtaking Mexico. The visa changes are expected to accelerate that increase.

title: Eurozone Eked Out Growth in Third Quarter
description: PARIS  The European economy is barely managing to pull out of a rut, raising concern among global policy makers that continued sluggishness in the eurozones richest countries may begin to ripple beyond the Continents borders and pose risks to the recovery in the United States.

title: North Korea to Send Senior Envoy to Russia
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Koreas leader, Kim Jong-un, plans to send a senior envoy to Moscow, state-run media announced on Friday, as the country seeks to improve its relations with Russia.

title: Gold Bars, Moldy Cash and a Chinese Officials Mom Who Can Explain It All
description: Chinese newspapers provided a valuable life lesson on Friday: If you stumble over 37 kilograms of gold bars and more than 40 boxes holding $20 million or so of moldy cash in a closet, dont panic! Ask your mother.

title: Test Yourself | Alex From Target: The Other Side of Fame
description: Below are the first seven paragraphs of the Nov. 12 article Alex From Target: The Other Side of Fame.

title: 6 Qs About the News | In Deaths of Dogs in Arizona, a Human Story of Loss and Intrigue
description: In In Deaths of Dogs in Arizona, a Human Story of Loss and Intrigue, Rick Rojas writes about the deaths of 22 dogs in June at a boarding business in Arizona.

title: An Elusive Roof of Ones Own in Lisbon
description: They dont live, they survive.

title: How Much Do Your Parents Help With Your Homework?
description: Whats the homework situation in your family? How much do your parents help with your homework? And in what ways?

title: Q. and A.: Kung Tsui-chang on Life as the Heir to Confucius
description: Kung Tsui-chang is a 39-year-old businessman in Taiwan who is the 79th-generation direct descendant of Confucius. He inherited the title of Sacrificial Official to Confucius from his grandfather, Kung Te-cheng, who died in 2008. The position was created by the Republic of China in 1935 after it abolished the title of Duke of Yansheng, a noble rank in Imperial China given to the descendants of the Chinese scholar and philosopher.

title: ABN Amro to Cut Jobs in Shift to Digital
description: LONDON  ABN Amro, the state-owned Dutch lender, said on Friday that it planned to cut up to 1,000 jobs in its retail bank and invest significantly in its digital platform over the next four years, as customers increasingly conduct their financial lives online.

title: Obama and Aung San Suu Kyi Meet Again, With Battle Scars
description: YANGON, Myanmar  The last time President Obama met with Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, in 2012, it was in the glow of Myanmars opening to the West  a historic turn toward democracy that handed Mr. Obama a diplomatic victory and catapulted Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi, the pro-democracy icon, from house arrest to the political front lines.

title: The Philae Lander Is Onboard Comet 67P
description: The European Space Agencys Rosetta mission successfully landed a small craft on the surface of a comet.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: The Week in Pictures
description: Good morning on this semi-wintry Friday.

title: Week 11 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Eagles (7-2) at Packers (6-3)

title: Thomas Middelhoff, Ex-Chief of Bertelsmann, Gets 3-Year Prison Term Over Misuse of Funds
description: In the dour environs of German executive suites, Thomas Middelhoff always stood out. In a nation of engineers, he was a deal maker, a salesman and a digital prophet who tried to turn the staid media giant Bertelsmann into an Internet company.

title: Art Spawned by Hong Kong Protest; Now to Make It Live On
description: HONG KONG  Thousands of pastel Post-it notes, marked with messages of support for pro-democracy demonstrators, form a fluttering collage that snakes around the wall of a staircase outside Hong Kong government headquarters. Nearby stands Umbrella Man, a 12-foot-tall wood sculpture of a figure holding a bright yellow umbrella.

title: Daily Report: E-Book Standoff Is Over, but Fear of Amazon Persists
description: Hachette won an important victory on Thursday in its battle with Amazon: the ability to set its own prices for e-books, which it sees as critical to its survival. But even as the publisher and retailer announced a negotiated peace after sparring since January, hardly anyone seemed in the mood for celebratory fireworks, David Streitfeld reports.

title: First Look at Health Insurance Rates for Next Year Is Encouraging
description: Early evidence suggests that competition in the new Affordable Care Act marketplaces is working, at least in some areas. Health insurance premiums in major cities around the country are barely rising.

title: 1914: Indian Infantry Routs Turks
description: ADEN  (delayed in transmission) The shells of a British cruiser have demolished the Turkish forts at Sheikh Said, near Perim. Indian infantry, which was landed from a transport under the enemys fire, has blown up the guns and magazines of the position. The Turks fled in disorder before the irresistible advance of the Indians. Some of them were captured and brought here. The British casualties were slight. Three native infantrymen were killed and a few were wounded. Two British officers were wounded. There were no naval casualties. The enemys losses, on the other hand, were considerable. Sheikh Said is an important strategical position, commanding the Straits of Bab-el-Mande.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 15, 1914

title: Building a Serious Website Without Serious, or Any, Coding Skills
description: For many start-ups, a website is just the businesss online presence, a place to be found. For other start-ups, however, the website is the business. Think Airbnb, Match.com, Kickstarter or eBay. Generally, entrepreneurs who want to build that kind of business either have to employ software engineers or be software engineers. But Bubble, a cloud-based tool, hopes to change that.

title: Today in Politics
description: And Then There Were 5: Races Still Awaiting a Victor

title: Morning Agenda: Net Neutralitys Effect on Comcast
description: NET NEUTRALITY COULD AFFECT COMCASTS DEAL | Comcasts $45 billion deal for Time Warner Cable may have seemed like a good idea earlier this year. But now that President Obama has endorsed net neutrality, Comcast might have buyers remorse, Steven Davidoff Solomon writes in the Deal Professor column. Given how much detractors have urged the Federal Communications Commission to reject the deal, Comcast may now find, ironically, that the only way out is to have the F.C.C. block the transaction. This F.C.C. battle all comes down to whether bigger in and of itself is a problem, and President Obamas statements only add to the troubles for this deal, Mr. Davidoff Solomon writes.

title: U.S. to Give $3 Billion to Climate Fund to Help Poor Nations, and Spur Rich Ones
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama announced on Saturday that the United States will contribute $3 billion to a new international fund intended to help the worlds poorest countries address the effects of climate change.

title: How Did Obama Lose American Voters?
description: In December 2012, 56 percent of Americans approved of President Obamas leadership. About 40 percent disapproved.

title: Pizza, Dubstep and the Fight for Net Neutrality
description: Groups that support a free and open Internet turned a protest outside the Federal Communications Commission headquarters into a party on Thursday night, as they tried to pressure the agency to keep the web that way and celebrated President Obamas support of their effort.

title: International Arts Events Happening in the Week Ahead
Princess Dianas Wedding Dress Designer Is Back, in an Unexpected Way
description: Elizabeth Emanuel, one-half of the design team that made the sartorial meringue that went round the world (otherwise known as Princess Dianas wedding dress), is back and taking a somewhat  different approach to her business, now called the Art of Being.

title: Sweden Says Mystery Vessel in Its Waters Was a Foreign Submarine
description: Swedish officials said Friday that a mysterious vessel detected in the waters off Stockholm last month was a foreign submarine that had violated its territorial waters.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: NYTLNreads | Send Us a Photo That Shows Teaching or Learning With The New York Times
description: This week we received two photos we just couldnt keep to ourselves  and they made us wonder what other interesting images teachers and students might send in if we just asked.

title: Cat-Sitting Is Heaven for a Writer
description: Dear Diary:

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: The Daily Gift: Graphic Trays That Pop
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: Bittersweet Sixteen
description: Sixteen is when they slip out the door. It happens so unexpectedly you hardly notice. Until you do.

title: Nicola Sturgeon Becomes Leader of Scottish National Party
description: LONDON  After 10 years as deputy leader, Nicola Sturgeon moved into the top job of the pro-independence Scottish National Party on Friday and immediately suggested that the party might seek another referendum on separation from the United Kingdom after the defeat of an independence vote in September.

title: The Folklore of Finance: Beliefs That Contribute to Investors Failure
description: WHEN most people think of folklore, they think of ancient stories passed down through the ages. The tales may be instructive, amusing or both, but few take them as entirely true. Still, they represent an oral tradition that once helped people make sense of the world.

title: Obama Meets Myanmars Opposition Leader
description: President Obama and Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Myanmar opposition leader, spoke after meeting at her residence in Yangon.

title: First Draft Focus: A Peek at British Burma
description: Obama and Aung San Suu Kyi Meet Again, With Battle Scars

title: The Policy at the Heart of the Jonathan Gruber Controversy
description: The controversy this week around the comments of a health economist, Jonathan Gruber, about President Obamas health law has centered on his most explosive remarks, captured on video, about the stupidity of the American voter and the suggestion that the law was passed dishonestly. It was those blunt remarks that have Republicans in Congress talking about a new round of hearings to assail the law and, one imagines, a man who helped create its intellectual architecture.

title: Hatching a Pilot
description: You with your feet up, remote in one hand and beverage in the other, being all judge-y about this falls new network dramas and sitcoms. Just take a moment, will you, and think of us writers gutting ourselves trying to create them. Think of us lumbering from lot to Hollywood lot, fingernails in our teeth and oil in our bowels, pitching what we hope youll be criticizing next fall.

title: Choosing to Live Abroad in Retirement
description: IT began with a spontaneous kiss from a man she had met only a few days earlier, in a restaurant in Vence, a small town in the South of France. It was shocking to me, recalled Patrice Smith, when the handsome Dutch computer engineer so impetuously bussed her.

title: Mysterious Visitor, Clad in Fur, Puts Paris on Edge
description: PARIS  Police officers were sent to guard schools, while hundreds of security officers scoured large areas near the French capital. Spooked drivers locked their car doors. Residents cowered at home, fearful that a menacing tiger would devour them whole.

title: Domestic Violence and Homelessness: Reporters Notebook
description: On Nov. 10, Mia Navarro wrote an article about the connection between domestic violence and New York Citys rocketing homeless shelter population. Here she supplies insight into how she put her affecting  and disturbing  story together.

title: Win or Lose on Sunday, Social Media Is a Draw
description: Jerry Knaak knows the Oakland Raiders record, but he also has a job to do. So the day after the Raiders lost in Seattle to drop to 0-8, Knaak, their director of digital media, set about reviewing a Twitter post promoting the midseason report on the teams website.

title: 1964: C.I.A. Notes Split in Red Bloc
description: WASHINGTON  Central Intelligence Agency Director John A. McCone said last night [Nov. 14] that the depth of the schism between the Soviet Union and Communist China is greater than generally believed and that the problems of repairing it appear insurmountable. In his first public address since taking office more than three years ago, Mr. McCone admitted that the fall of Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev was a distinct surprise to us. But he also said the ouster was an equal surprise to the Soviet party Presidium. They didnt know they had the strength to remove him until they sat down to their final meeting on Oct. 14, Mr. McCone said. The C.I.A. director gave his agency credit for predicting Communist Chinas first nuclear explosion almost to the day. To defeat the ultrasophisticated security apparatus in every Communist country, he said, required the use of highly refined technical devices. In analyzing recent events in the Soviet Union, Mr. McCone said the Russian people resented their governments tremendous expenditure on military hardware while they were forced to go without. He said this internal problem was created by the Soviets spending beyond their resources.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 16, 1964

title: Love and Reflux
description: A few months ago, after months of throat and bronchial problems, I was told I had a silent form of gastroesophageal reflux disease, or GERD.

title: French Hunt Wild Cat in Paris Suburbs
description: French officials discussed the search for a large cat, originally thought to be a tiger, that was first spotted close to Disneyland Paris on Thursday.

title: Virtual Reality Fails Its Way to Success
description: Of all the praise heaped upon Oculus, the virtual-reality company that Facebook acquired for $2 billion earlier this year, perhaps the most significant has been this: non-nauseating. I can testify to that after my visit last month to the groovy downtown Manhattan offices of Relevent, a marketing agency that has created a virtual-reality demo for HBO to help promote its hit series Game of Thrones. Without much small talk, Ian Cleary, Relevents vice president of innovation and ideation, escorted me into a steampunk cage the size of a phone booth, made of iron and wood. He fitted me with headphones and the Oculus Rift, as the companys flagship product is called, a blocky set of black maxigoggles with an internal screen positioned inches from the eyes. I promptly lost awareness of the screen, and after a few seconds, a bass speaker under the floorboards began to boom. All I knew next was that I was shooting up, as in an outdoor elevator, to a windy summit and then trudging through lightly packed snow  crunch, crunch, crunch  onto a vertiginous ledge of ice.

title: Warren Opposes a Treasury Nominee With Wall Street Ties
description: Less than 24 hours after ascending to a leadership post in the Senate Democratic caucus, Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts is flexing her populist, anti-Wall Street muscle and opposing a high-profile Obama administration nominee.

title: The Death of the Private Eye
description: Imagine, for a second, a modern private-detective movie. A weeping wife is seated in the smoky, wood-paneled office of Skip Tracer, private investigator and overwrought clich. She suspects that her husband is having an affair and wants Skip to tail him. He agrees, shakes on it, then cruises hubbys Facebook profile to find that  quite by accident, being both a rookie adulterer and lousy with his iPhone settings  he has publicly announced his presence at one of those by-the-hour joints, right around the corner. Skip escorts his client to the precise latitudinal and longitudinal coordinates, where she catches her soon-to-be-ex in flagrante delicto. Case closed. Having unearthed no leads about jewel-encrusted falcons or municipal water theft, our modern P.I. vanishes back into the past, deserting a present moment that doesnt have much use for him anyway.

title: What if an Athlete Wants to Bet on Himself?
description: An athlete who bets against his team  or himself  clearly has a conflict of interest in the outcome of the game. Its not obvious to me, however, why an athlete betting in favor of his team (or himself) would be doing anything unethical whatsoever. What am I missing? GRAHAM SINGER, CHICAGO

title: The Ice-Bucket Racket
description: Ever since the ice-bucket challenge swept the Internet this summer, raising more than $115 million for A.L.S. research, a legion of imitators has sprung up to try and cash in themselves. In the approaching holiday season, as fund-raising appeals swell, we can now smash a pie in our faces, snap selfies first thing in the morning or take a photo of ourselves grabbing our crotches, among other tasteful gestures, to express solidarity with various worthy causes. But the failure of these newer gimmicks to enjoy anywhere near the same popularity as the frigid original demonstrates the peculiar and finicky nature of our altruism  a psychological puzzle that both scientists and economists are trying to decipher.

title: My Country of Origin? Its Complicated
description: In April, I was stopped at a police checkpoint at 2 in the morning. Being pulled over for any other reason is a drag; being pulled over for a sobriety check when youre cold sober is exhilarating. It doesnt matter where you are in life; for those five minutes, youre an all-star. Can you recite the alphabet starting at D and ending at W? Can I ever! Watch me nail it. I need you to count backward from 97 to 63. I hope youre recording this. Because youre going to be so impressed youre going to want to play it for all your friends back at the station.

title: Reply All: The 11.2.14 Issue
description: MY CAPTIVITY IN SYRIA

title: European Official on Economic Growth
description: Mina Andreeva, the European Commission deputy chief spokeswoman, called new economic growth in the eurozone a small piece of good news, but warned policymakers not to become complacent.

title: For Democrats, Turnout Efforts Look Successful (Though Not Elections)
description: The Democrats invested millions of dollars in a vaunted field operation to mobilize the young and nonwhite voters who do not usually participate in midterm elections. Yet it was not enough to save Democrats from a Republican landslide.

title: Nina Jacobson Isnt Afraid to Fight Hollywoods Old Guard
description: The producer of Mockingjay talks with Taffy Brodesser-Akner about getting the most out of the Hunger Games franchise (without being too grabby) and the rise of the female protagonist.

title: Airbus Might Face Higher Costs on Delayed Military Transport Plane
description: PARIS  The Airbus Group warned Friday that the costs associated with a much-delayed military transport plane could increase after the European aerospace giant failed to meet a deadline for equipping the aircraft with combat capabilities.

title: Going Blind a Little at a Time
description: Her eyes were healthy, so why couldnt she see?

title: Speed Gun in Hand, Everythings a Target
description: A radar gun seems like such an elegantly simple device in the hands of a cop or a coach.

title: Fresh Pumpkin Pie
description: Melissa Clarks trick for making creamy pumpkin pie: use fresh butternut squash instead of canned pumpkin.

title: Deciding Whether to Disclose Mental Disorders to the Boss
description: ABOUT six months ago, Patrick Ross knew things had reached a breaking point at work. An angry email he had sent to a superior  combined with occasional temper flare-ups and brusque interactions with colleagues  was endangering his job of two years as deputy director of communication at the United States Patent and Trademark Office.

title: Ask Well | Are Eggs Good for My Heart?
description: Readers asked Well, are eggs heart-healthy after all? Watch this video before you eat.

title: If It Moves, Clock It
description: Armed with a radar gun, the reporter Andy Newman attempts to measure the speed of a running dog, a kite and a sea lion in Prospect Park.

title: Feit, Maker of Handmade Luxury Shoes, Sets Up Shop in NoLIta
description: For brothers Josh and Tull Price, handmade isnt just a promise on a label but the basis of their burgeoning brand, Feit. The founders of the luxury shoe and accessories line, which is currently sold online and at specialty stores like Dover Street Market, are old-school cobblers disguised as contemporary conscientious creatives. Their designs are intentionally minimal to show off technique; the limited-run, slow-fashion approach is tailored to ensure a smaller environmental impact. Now, the Australian-born duo has opened their second stand-alone store and first in North America in NoLIta. The 500-square-foot space was conceived with the artist Jordana Maisie and is being touted as an installation, rather than a traditional shop. We wanted to create a space that would allow the elements of craft and creativity to come to the forefront, Tull says.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE PARTHENON ENIGMA,  by Joan Breton Connelly. (Vintage, $17.95.) Since the Enlightenment, the Parthenon  that glorious Athenian temple built between 447 and 432 B.C.  has been venerated as the definitive symbol of Western democratic values. Deftly challenging conventional wisdom, Connelly reaches back across millenniums to reinterpret the buildings 525-foot-long sculptured frieze, seeing in the elaborate narrative tableau not a snapshot of a civic festival but rather a mythical tale of human sacrifice.

title: Indian State Recalls Pills Linked to Sterilization Deaths
description: NEW DELHI  The women who died after sterilization surgery in the Indian state of Chhattisgarh might have been given antibiotic pills contaminated with rat poison, a senior official said on Friday.

title: An #AskDrH Question on Energy Science for Obamas Science Team
description: John P. Holdren, President Obamas science adviser, is soliciting questions via Vine, Twitter, Facebook and Instagram. Heres mine, as submitted via Twitter:

title: Ask Well: How Many Eggs Can I Eat?
description: Question:

title: A Side Show Number for Times Square
description: The sideshows of Times Square have been gone for decades. But a bit of their spirit will be resurrected there on Nov. 17 when a digital billboard will broadcast the Act I finale of the Broadway revival of the musical Side Show, live from the St. James Theater.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE LAUGHING MONSTERS,  by Denis Johnson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) Johnsons cheerfully nihilistic novel about two scammers and rogue spies in Africa derives much of its situation from several of his early journalistic pieces.

title: Virgin America Soars in Stock Debut
description: Shares in Virgin America rose more than 27 percent on Friday morning, as the low-cost airline backed by Richard Branson began its new life as a publicly traded company.

title: Inside the List
description: Completely Different: So, Anyway. . . , a memoir by the British comedian and actor John Cleese, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 9. Is Cleese the funniest movie star of all time? Last summer, when Time Out London ranked the Top 100 comedies, Cleese and his accomplices in Monty Python had two films among the top five  Life of Brian at No. 3 and The Holy Grail at No. 5  while The Meaning of Life came in at No. 58. Cleese also appeared in a couple of non-Python movies on the list: Clockwise at No. 80 and, with his Python sidekick Michael Palin, A Fish Called Wanda at No. 87. (This dominance may explain why the American Film Institute, compiling a similar project in 2000, stayed true to its name and limited the choice to American films.)

title: The President Who Never Earned His Varsity Letter
description: For a president who never made the front line of his college squad, football played a surprisingly large part in Richard Nixons life.

title: Divided by a Windfall
description: Most New Yorkers would look upon the good fortune of the residents of Southbridge Towers with envy. They paid, on average, $17,500 for their Lower Manhattan apartments, many with stunning East River views. The average maintenance fee in the middle-income development in the financial district near South Street Seaport is $620 a month. And soon, their fortunes could soar even higher.

title: Daniel Bolgers Why We Lost
description: The author of this book has a lot to answer for. I am a United States Army general, Daniel Bolger writes, and I lost the Global War on Terrorism. The fault is not his alone, of course. Bolgers peers offered plenty of help. As he sees it, in both Afghanistan and Iraq, abysmal generalship pretty much doomed American efforts.

title: Claire Prentices Lost Tribe of Coney Island
description: In 1904, two years after Americas victory in the Philippine-American War, the United States government tried to put the best face on its colonization of the archipelago of more than 7,000 islands. Thirteen hundred Filipinos from a dozen tribes were put on display at the St. Louis Exposition, in replicas of their home villages, intended to reinforce an underlying message that our little brown brothers, in the words of William Howard Taft, were not ready to govern themselves. The most popular exhibit in this human zoo were the Igorrotes, who ate dog meat and hunted heads. The man in charge of the Igorrote village, Truman Hunt, had served as a medical doctor during the war and stayed on, eventually rising to become the lieutenant governor of Bontoc Province.

title: Letters: Uncommon Woman
description: Uncommon Woman

title: The Internet and the Mind
description: CURIOUS  The Desire to Know and Why Your Future Depends on It  By Ian Leslie  Basic Books, $26.99.

title: More Awesome Than Money, by Jim Dwyer
description: Books about technology start-ups have a pattern. First theres the grand vision of the founders, then the heroic journey of producing new worlds from all-night coding and caffeine abuse, and finally the grand finale, immense wealth and secular sainthood. Lets call it the Jobs Narrative. The trouble is that Silicon Valley now believes its own press, and the proliferation of great men in history stories from the grinding code-mills of Northern California is contributing to a bigger problem of exclusion and exploitation.

title: On His Own Terms: A Life of Nelson Rockefeller, by Richard Norton Smith
description: I am imaginative, Nelson Rockefeller said of himself near the end of his life. I am not bright.

title: William Wells Brown, by Ezra Greenspan
description: If the publishing industry reflects the American zeitgeist, things have changed when it comes to black American historical figures. As a graduate student at Harvard decades ago, I came across William Wells Brown, the fugitive slave, abolitionist, lecturer, travelogue writer, novelist and performer whose wide-ranging intelligence turned a gaze on white people (for a change). Back then he was to be found in only one full-length biography, William Edward Farrisons William Wells Brown: Author and Reformer (1969). Published by the University of Chicago Press in the twilight of the second Reconstruction and at the dawning of African-American studies, it depicted Brown as a representative black American. In the absence of the biographical scholarship coming after 1969, Browns colleagues remained ill defined. Farrisons biography was reviewed only in publishing trade papers and a couple of history journals. What was the problem?

title: Thrown, by Kerry Howley
description: It probably started with Homer. The Iliad includes some snappy sports reporting, and writers ever since have been probing athletes for signifiers, for metaphor amped by grit under pressure.

title: Tennessee Williams, by John Lahr
description: Tennessee Williamss career began and ended very badly. The boffo finish of his first Broadway-bound play, Battle of Angels (1940), was a big onstage fire  a special effect that generated so much smoke a number of theatergoers fainted while others bolted for the exits. If ever the professional debut of a major playwright was a greater fiasco, John Lahr writes in his new biography of Williams, piquantly subtitled Mad Pilgrimage of the Flesh, history does not record it. Five years and a lot of crummy jobs later, Williams clawed his way back with a play that would make him famous, The Glass Menagerie, whose premiere almost proved an even bigger disaster. Laurette Taylor, plucked from a long alcoholic oblivion to play Amanda Wingfield, was found an hour and a half before opening curtain in an alley outside the stage door, soaking wet in the rain and all but dead drunk. Occasionally pausing to vomit in a bucket offstage, she gave the performance of her life and thus saved our greatest postwar playwright from almost certain ruin.

title: Chinas Rise as Arms Supplier Is Put on Display
description: ZHUHAI, China  Queen Bee anti-tank rocket system. Halberd supersonic target drone. Sky Dragon 12 surface-to-air missile system.

title: Man Alive, by Thomas Page McBee
description: What makes a man? We know its not quite enough to be born one. It never has been, really: In America, manhood has long been bound up in aspiration, a thing more ideological than biological.

title: The Deluge, by Adam Tooze
description: The defining political fact of the modern world is American power. The supremacy of the American colossus is still so imposing, it leaves former rivals scrambling for labels beyond superpower: The former French foreign minister Hubert Vdrine called the United States the hyperpuissance, while for the German commentator Josef Joffe, it was the berpower.

title: Verbatim: A Kitchen Ambush for Hagel
description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel responding to a reporters question about why he had a bandage on his face, adding, Ive had more bandages than this on my face in my career and been in tougher spots.

title: Patricia Cornwells Flesh and Blood, and More
description: Heres a steamy romantic scene for you, right out of Patricia Cornwells new thriller, FLESH AND BLOOD (Morrow, $28.99): I trace the second cervical vertebra down to C7, gently, slowly digging my fingertips into the Longus colli muscle, feeling him relax. The sexual hoyden showing off her bedroom technique is Dr. Kay Scarpetta, the chief medical examiner for the state of Massachusetts and an awesome force in the field of forensic science. Scarpetta and her husband, the F.B.I. profiler Benton Wesley, are getting in the mood for a sybaritic vacation in Florida when her expertise is suddenly needed with a murder victim, a man once accused of being a terrorist who has been killed by two shots from a snipers rifle. The use of copper bullets is unusual enough to make this case interesting. But with the coming Boston Marathon trial stoking anti-Islamic passions, and President Obama in town to speak against the indiscriminate hostility toward Muslims, the terrorism angle is also a factor. So much for that vacation.

title: Call to Congress: End Loophole for Tax on Elite
description: Now that Republicans control both houses of Congress, they need to show they can accomplish something, and President Obama has just two years to burnish his legacy. So the search is on for bipartisan consensus.

title: Afghan President Out to Ease Relations on Visit to Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD  Hoping to recast an often strained relationship with a crucial neighbor, President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan made his first state visit to Pakistan on Friday.

title: How Bobby Shmurda Danced Into the Hot 100
description: The 20-year-old East Flatbush rapper Bobby Shmurda has just jumped from No. 8 to No. 6 on the Billboard chart.

title: The Trick to Great Pumpkin Pie
description: You can make pumpkin pie anytime, but its essential at Thanksgiving, where a thick and creamy slice  preferably buried under a mound of whipped cream  is the classic followup to the meal.

title: Health Cares Next Test: Getting More to Enroll
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas Affordable Care Act will face a substantial new test starting Saturday, when the second enrollment period for buying health insurance under the law begins and proponents embark on a three-month mission to persuade millions more Americans to sign up.

title: Sewing Up a Loose End on West End
description: A drawn-out and often divisive plan to create a new neighborhood atop railroad tracks on the Far West Side  and, surprisingly, one having nothing to do with Hudson Yards  is embarking on its final phase.

title: Dreaming of the Departed
description: I ran into my father at a deli the other day. An undramatic encounter: I was waiting at the counter for a takeout order when I spotted him sitting at a corner table, yakking with friends from his senior residence, their walkers and canes carefully folded or propped against the wall.

title: In a Soft-Spoken Romanian Prosecutor, Some See an Earthquake
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  TELEVISION crews are on permanent standby outside the offices of Laura Codruta Kovesi, ready to transmit live images of the next episode of Romanias most talked about and, for the countrys corruption-addled business and political elite, most terrifying drama in 25 years.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Napoleon: A Life
description: This week, Andrew Roberts talks about his new biography of Napoleon; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Yochi Dreazen discusses The Invisible Front; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Facts & Figures: Americans Like Their Obamacare
description: A large majority of Americans say they like the insurance coverage they obtained through government exchanges, which were set up by the Affordable Care Act.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Napoleon: A Life
description: This week, Andrew Roberts and Yochi Dreazen.

title: Popcast: Bobby Shmurda Dances Into the Hot 100
description: Hot Boy, by the 20-year-old East Flatbush rapper Bobby Shmurda, with hyper-local lyrics about guns, drugs and money, has just jumped to No. 6 from No. 8 on the Billboard chart.

title: After Losses, Liberal and Centrist Democrats Square Off on Strategy
description: WASHINGTON  The Democrats widespread losses last week have revived a debate inside the party about its fundamental identity, a long-running feud between center and left that has taken on new urgency in the aftermath of a disastrous election and in a time of deeply felt economic anxiety.

title: Expert in Xs and Os Was Inspired by His Father, a Man of Letters
description: At a corner table in a cozy restaurant in the West Village  Steve Lavins neighborhood  he had to strain his voice to be heard above the din of the dinner crowd. This didnt inhibit him. Its a coachs way of life.

title: Elviss First Recording Up for Auction
description: Having dipped a toe into the world of memorabilia auctions in August, Graceland, Elvis Presleys estate in Memphis  now a shrine to the singer  is holding a second Elvis auction on Jan. 8, which would have been his 80th birthday.

title: Window Washers, in Trouble at World Trade Center, Just Grabbed On
description: When Juan Lizama and Juan Lopez went to work cleaning windows on Wednesday morning, they were prepared. Before they descended from the side of 1 World Trade Center, they had secured not only themselves to the rigging but also all of their equipment.

title: Finding the Right African Safari
description: Knowing how, when and where to book that first safari can be complicated, said Jennifer Goetz, a founder of Your African Safari, a new website dedicated to helping travelers research and locate a reliable safari company thats right for them.

title: How to Be French (When Asking for a Cigarette)
description: Pamela Druckermans Tuesday op-ed, How to Be French, on formally and culturally becoming a French citizen, might seem to have a very specific audience. But it quietly rose to become the most emailed story on NYTimes.com, and more than 300 commenters shared their thoughts.

title: Book Reviewer Tell-All: Dwight Garner on Reading, Reviewing and Avoiding Blindness
description: Dwight Garner is a book critic for The Times. Here is a sense of how he does his sometimes eye-taxing job.

title: Alibaba, the I.P.O. Darling, Is Also the Star of Hedge Fund Reports
description: Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce website, was the hot initial public offering of the year on Wall Street. And not surprisingly, shares of Alibaba wound up in the portfolios of many well-known money managers in the third quarter.

title: Weekend Auto Calendar: Auctions Everywhere
description: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend:

title: Vows | A Dog, Then a Family
description: Frank Nussbaum, a real estate developer, never felt ready to settle down until he went out with Carlye Adler, a writer and single mom.

title: House Tour | The Fonseca Family Home
description: The writer Isabel Fonseca pays homage to her childhood home.

title: Movie Review: Beyond the Lights
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Beyond the Lights.

title: Isabel Fonseca on the House on West 11th Street
description: The writer pays homage to her childhood home  the hub of her familys creativity and a refuge in a changing Greenwich Village.

title: Europe Takes Aim at Deals Created to Escape Taxes
description: LONDON  American companies have plowed more money into the Netherlands than any other country in the world  for five years running.

title: Tensions Over Park Behavior as Homelessness Rises in New York City
description: In Harlem River Park in Manhattan, homeless men can be seen sleeping on benches around the basketball courts and sprawled out on a soccer field by day, then hunkering under an overpass at night.

title: Movie Review: Foxcatcher
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews Foxcatcher.

title: Nevada Provides Test Case in Debate Over a Skills Gap
description: Employers increasingly complain they cant find enough workers to fill jobs that require more than a high school diploma but not quite a bachelors degree. Some economists say the principal reason for a so-called skills gap is that employers arent willing to pay more to attract these employees. But new research argues that the problem is real, in part because work-force development has shriveled.

title: How Can Community Colleges Get a Piece of the Billions That Donors Give to Higher Education?
description: Last year at its annual gala, LaGuardia Community College, arguably the most ethnically diverse college in the country, honored Marilyn Skony Stamm, the chief executive of a global heating and air-conditioning business. A child of the South Side of Chicago who had gone to Northwestern on scholarship, Ms. Stamm maintained a committed interest in education and joined LaGuardias foundation board six years ago, proving herself a skilled networker for an institution with minimal capacity for soliciting money.

title: And Puppy Makes Four
description: Carlye Rebecca Adler and Frank Joshua Nussbaum were married Saturday evening at Caneel Bay Resort in St. John in the United States Virgin Islands. Peter S. OBrien, who was ordained by the Universal Life church, led a ceremony that will incorporate Jewish elements.

title: Wheelies: The Blue Devil Returns Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: The Garden at the Frick, and How It Grew
description: The Frick Collections proposed expansion is the latest preservation argument to arise on the Upper East Side, as the addition would mean the loss of the intimate 1977 garden tucked away on 70th Street off Fifth Avenue.

title: If Youre Not Rich, Divorce Can Be Financially Devastating
description: There is a long list of women* who have amassed personal fortunes by divorcing rich husbands  and as far as I can tell, they deserved every penny. This week Sue Ann Hamm joined it when a court ordered her ex-husband, Harold Hamm, the Oklahoma oil man, to pay her some $1 billion in cash and assets, or about $38 million per year of a 26-year marriage.

title: House Passes Bill Directing Obama to Proceed on Oil Pipeline
description: The House voted 252 to 161 on Friday to approve a bill that would direct the federal government to move forward on the Keystone XL oil pipeline, ahead of a vote scheduled for Tuesday in the Senate that could send the measure to President Obamas desk.

title: Self-Promotion, but With Self-Respect
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: House Votes to Pass Pipeline Bill
description: House Passes Bill Directing Obama to Proceed on Oil Pipeline

title: Operatives Emails Echo Infighting of 2008 Clinton Campaign
description: Taken in isolation, the emails between the Democratic operatives Robby Mook and Marlon Marshall to a network of political friends called the Mook Mafia arent particularly incriminating.

title: Same-Sex Couples Petition Supreme Court on Right to Marriage
description: WASHINGTON  Gay and lesbian couples filed petitions on Friday asking the Supreme Court to decide whether there is a constitutional right to same-sex marriage. The petitions arrived eight days after the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, upheld bans on same-sex marriage in Kentucky, Michigan, Ohio and Tennessee.

title: Yale Medical School Removes Doctor After Sexual Harassment Finding
description: Yale Medical School has removed a doctor after a finding of sexual harassment as director of its Cardiovascular Research Center, the latest development in a nearly five-year-old case that has agitated the institution.

title: New York Public Library Names New Chairman
description: The New York Public Library is expected to name a new chairman at its board meeting on Tuesday. Evan R. Chesler, the chairman of the law firm Cravath, Swaine & Moore, will replace Neil L. Rudenstine, who announced in October that he would step down.

title: Capping a Strong Performance With an Exit Strategy
description: Everyone likes to make a graceful exit. It increases the likelihood that your time will be remembered fondly. You may even be invited back. And many of us were raised to think that a timely departure is the right thing to do.

title: Walmarts Dark November, Ralph Ruccis Departure, and Who Is Beyonce?
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Asking Justices to Decide on Gay Marriage
description: Same-Sex Couples Petition Supreme Court on Right to Marriage

title: Grace Gets Three Michelin Stars in Latest Chicago Guide
description: Grace, a Chicago restaurant barely two years old, has just been awarded three stars from the Michelin Guide. It is only the second restaurant in the city to claim that distinction, joining Alinea. Last month, Michelin gave three stars to Benu and Saison in San Francisco, the first in that city, although two Napa Valley restaurants, the French Laundry in Yountville and the restaurant at Meadowood in St. Helena, have long had three stars in the annual rankings.

title: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Really Big Beets
description: This year for Wells Vegetarian Thanksgiving were highlighting some of our favorite recipes from Vegetarian Thanksgivings past. Heres one of Food Editor Sam Siftons favorites, Really Big Beets, a reader-submitted recipe from 2014. See more of Wells Vegetarian Thanksgiving selections at NYT Cooking.

title: Justice Dept. Apologizes for Inaccuracy in National Security Letters Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has apologized to a federal appeals court for providing inaccurate information about a central issue in a case challenging the constitutionality of a disputed law-enforcement power known as national security letters.

title: Florida State Player Fled Crash but Got Only Traffic Tickets
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  In the early morning hours of Oct. 5, as this college town was celebrating another big football victory by Florida State University, a starting cornerback on the team drove his car into the path of an oncoming vehicle driven by a teenager returning home from a job at the Olive Garden.

title: Shubert Organization to Complete Acquisition of New World Stages
description: The Shubert Organization, which owns 17 of Broadways 40 theaters, is expected to complete a seven-figure deal on Monday to take over New World Stages, the Off Broadway complex of five subterranean theaters on West 50th Street, according to two theater executives with knowledge of the transaction. They spoke on condition of anonymity because Shubert business is meant to be confidential.

title: Inflation Truth, Really
description: Im in Argentina for the day  literally (stuff came up, forcing me to make this a very quick visit; sorry, no time for media interviews or anything not already booked). And I thought it might be worth telling people something they may not know about the history of MITs Billion Prices Project.

title: Comparing Two Hit and Run Cases
description: A starting cornerback for the Florida State University football team left the scene of a collision on Oct. 5 but was not charged with a hit-and-run, an examination by The New York Times found. That contrasts with another case in the same area in the same month.

title: Today in Small Business: Next Generation of Lender or Boiler Room?
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: WNYC Sets Replacement Schedule for Soundcheck
description: WNYC has set a replacement schedule for Soundcheck, the nightly music show hosted by John Schaefer that is going online-only next week.

title: Dear Dr. Psych Mom: Im Almost a Parent Myself, and My Parents Are Smothering Me
description: Dr. Psych Mom is Samantha Rodman, a clinical psychologist who practices in Maryland. She answers questions as your friendly neighborhood blogapist at DrPsychMom.com.

title: Behind the G.O.P.s Misleading Shutdown Statements
description: Senator Mitch McConnell said yesterday that he would not shut down the government, over immigration or anything else, after he takes over as Majority Leader in January. On the same day, Speaker John Boehner refused to rule out a shutdown. Both were being deceptive, but Mr. McConnell, as usual, was a little more clever about it.

title: Video Reviews of Foxcatcher, Rosewater and Beyond the Lights
description: In this weeks video, Times critics share their thoughts on Foxcatcher, Rosewater and Beyond the Lights. See all of this weeks reviews.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Friday Night Music: Suzanne Vega, I Never Wear White
description: I know, its early afternoon, but Im on the road, and probably wont have a later chance. Sorry, all her Joes Pub shows this weekend are sold out:

title: A Boyish Patriarch Leaps Over Boundaries
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sitting in the airy studio on the top floor of his home here, a restored 1906 house in the Pacific Heights neighborhood, the conductor Michael Tilson Thomas recently said that a lot of old pictures and concert programs have been turning up lately in connection with this birthday thing.

title: New Black Fest to Present Short Works Responding to Michael Brown Shooting
description: The New Black Fest, which last year commissioned 10-minute works on Trayvon Martin, race and privilege, will present a free showcase of works on Monday called Hands Up: Six Testaments, a project inspired by events in Ferguson, Mo., where in August a police officer fatally shot Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager.

title: The Quiet Bravery of a Doomed Revolt
description: What do you think of when I say archive? asked Rachel Lithgow, the executive director of the American Jewish Historical Society. A solitary place of research, perhaps, with big old filing cabinets with dusty paper and some person with granny glasses? she suggested. Certainly not the site of a new commission centered on that least sedentary, most physically alive of art forms: dance.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: After Military Service, Taking Advantage of Educational Benefits
description: A host of educational benefits are available to those who have served in the United States armed forces, but figuring out which program a service member is eligible for can sometimes be a challenge.

title: Battle Over Immigration Poses Risks for G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas looming action on immigration is the first real opportunity for the new Republican leadership in Congress to demonstrate they can avoid the pitfalls of opposing the presidents policies at all costs and instead unite around a governing agenda of their own.

title: The Big Money Behind the Push for an Immigration Overhaul
description: When President Obama announces major changes to the nations immigration enforcement system as early as next week, his decision will partly be a result of a yearslong campaign of pressure by immigrant rights groups, which have grown from a cluster of lobbying organizations into a national force.

title: A New Brooklyn Condo With a Prewar Aesthetic
description: The goal for 265 State Street was to create a towering, 20-story condominium with a design sensibility that takes its cues from the nearby brownstone-dotted neighborhood of Boerum Hill.

title: Troubles at Petrobras Raise Broader Questions for Investors
description: When the worlds most indebted company postpones an earnings release due to a widening corruption scandal, a wobble in the markets is to be expected.

title: Work to Do, but Novak Djokovic Sews Up Top Year-End Ranking
description: LONDON  Novak Djokovic is still the third man, the bendable champion who breaks serve so often yet still ranks behind Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal in career achievement and global recognition.

title: For Ferguson Grand Jury, Details and Responsibilities Are Abundant
description: After hearing testimony for nearly three months in the death of Michael Brown, the 18-year-old unarmed African-American who was shot by Officer Darren Wilson on a Ferguson, Mo., street on Aug. 9, a St. Louis County grand jury is nearing a decision on whether to bring criminal charges.

title: In India, Jewels a Maharani or Grandmother Could Love
description: My grandmother was an avid traveler, and in every place she visited  Bangkok, Cairo, Rome  she would buy a piece of jewelry. My sisters and I could rummage through her jewelry box, and take a virtual tour of the world.

title: Talking Ships With Sting
description: Sting was breaking a promise he had made to himself.
