title: Youd Have to Search Long and Hard to Find Another Artist Like This
description: PARIS  On Friday evening here visitors in the basement of the Palais de Tokyo watched, amused and then surprised, as Sven Sachsalber, an Italian artist based in New York, literally did the figuratively near-impossible.

title: Texas, 3 Ways
description: You might say that a certain otherness has always characterized Texas as a whole  and by whole, I refer to that entire 269,000-square-mile sui generis behemoth on the map, mallet-headed and dainty-footed, with a single dorsal wing and a swollen belly that appears to contain two or three neighboring states.

title: Equatorial Guinea Replaces Morocco as Africa Cup Host
description: Equatorial Guinea has agreed to host Africas most important soccer tournament early next year after Morocco refused, citing fear about the possible spread of Ebola.

title: After Emotions Are Stirred, a Cocktail Goes for Clarity
description: On Saturday, Americans who dont have health insurance through their employer or the government can go to HealthCare.gov to enroll in a health insurance plan. The rollout was nothing less than a fiasco last year, but this year it should go better. There will still be some confusion  we provide some answers here  but the software is expected to work, and the process is more transparent.

title: Letter From the Editor: Health Care Drama
description: Its the biggest expansion of government and Washingtons biggest response to inequality in decades. So no wonder its the political story that wont die.

title: Stuff We Liked: Health Care Is a Focus, but Dogs Get a Look, Too
description: We like to share the interesting articles and graphics we find on the web.

title: Pedigree on a Prime Block
description: An Upper East Side townhouse distinguished by a front facade with two levels of copper-clad bay windows above fluted columns, a glass solarium/breakfast room overlooking a 26-foot-deep rear garden, and a pedigree dating to 1869, sold for $31 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Do You Want To Know About Your Brain?
description: Do you devour the latest neuroscience news, eager to learn more about how your brain works? Or do you click past it to something else, something more applicable to your life? If youre in the latter camp, you may bein the majority. A new study suggests that many people just dont pay that much attention tobrain science, and its findings may raise a question: Is neuro-literacy really necessary?

title: Some Back-of-the-Envelope Calculations in Deal for Baker Hughes
description: Baker Hughes may be worth more than investors think. Shares of the No. 3 American oilfield services firm rose 15 percent on Thursday after news broke of deal talks with the No. 2 company, Halliburton. A back-of-the-envelope calculation suggests that Halliburton, worth $46 billion, should be willing to pay nearly 40 percent more than Baker Hughes $22 billion undisturbed market valuation to seal a deal.

title: The Surprisingly Elusive Number That Suggests Full Employment
description: Last month the national unemployment rate fell from 5.9 to 5.8 percent, ticking one-tenth of a point closer to the rate of full employment in the American job market. Of that, Im confident. What that rate of full employment is, no one knows. As the Federal Reserve prepares to begin removing its monetary support from the economy, acknowledging that uncertainty becomes increasingly important.

title: Two in Ricin Terrorism Plot Are Each Sentenced to 10 Years in Prison
description: GAINESVILLE, Ga.  Ending a case that involved questions about the line between rhetoric and criminal conduct, a judge on Friday sentenced two men to a decade each in prison for their roles in a plot that included using ricin in a series of attacks in major cities.

title: Jasmin Shokrian, Designer to the Art World, Pops Up at MOCA
description: Jasmin Shokrian may create clothing for a living, but shes very much a creature of the art scene. Her degree is in fine art; her clients are the sort of women who either work in galleries and museums or frequent them. Now the Los Angeles-based designer is making her first foray into retail in typically unfashiony fashion: by commandeering a section of MOCAs gift shop. Starting tomorrow, the space will sell styles from Shokrians fall collection and her new mens wear offerings, as well as furniture, beauty goods and accessories from her network of creative friends, such as Rgime des Fleurs fragrances, home objects from the design studio Apparatus and jewelry made especially for the shop by Annie Costello Brown. Its a sliver of what I would do if I had a store, Shokrian says. As for her now-classic tops and totes that read Je Pars Habiter  Los Angeles:Theyll be there, along with matching iPhone 6 cases, just in time for the holidays.

title: Where the Sofas Come and Go
description: When NYC & Company is ready to replace Taylor Swift as its Global Welcome Ambassador, it should consider enlisting Marissa Webb, the global creative director of Banana Republic, who is as charismatic as any pop star. Born in Korea, Ms. Webb was raised in Pennsylvania, lived in Hoboken while she studied at the Fashion Institute of Technology and now lives in the quintessential loft near Union Square.

title: Bill Cunningham | Autumnal Mood
description: Its as true today as it ever was  fall in New York is pure magic.

title: Weekend Reading: Round 2 of the Foreign Exchange Inquiry
description: Now that the big banks have been fined and vulgar chat room messages exposed, other numptys in mkt are watching as the currency-rigging case shifts to criminal misconduct.

title: Cooking More Tacos and Looking for Recipes for Leftover Oatmeal
description: We ate well last week. Korean Grilled Beef Lettuce Wraps were a hit both for dinner, and in lunches (and a fantastic friend suggested this slow cooker version for too-snowy-to-grill days ahead). Slow cooker flank steak fajitas were ridiculously easy and delicious. And fried rice  the only food for which I am willing to act as a short-order cook  is one of those things I know every one in our family will enjoy.

title: Cadillac Unveils ATS-V.R. Racecar
description: Cadillac announced Friday that, in addition to the sporty ATS-V model it confirmed this week, it was introducing the ATS-V.R. racecar. It unveiled the car, which will be available next year, at the Circuit of the Americas in Austin, Tex.

title: Window Washers on Dangle at Trade Center
description: Juan Lopez and Juan Lizama, window washers who were left dangling from 1 World Trade Center after a malfunction on their scaffold, talked about the fear and how happy they were to be rescued.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: Ebola, sugar and breast cancer exams. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: A Bar Born to Be in Pictures
description: EXTERIOR, NIGHT: In a turbulent part of Brooklyn that condo developers have so far ignored, a seductive glow radiates from the windows of a three-story, 19th-century mansion, out of place among abandoned lots and fast-food joints.

title: Cadillac Signs Lease for Headquarters in Hudson Square
description: Cadillac has signed a lease for 34,000 square feet on the top two floors of 330 Hudson Street, the buildings owner said in a statement Thursday. The 16-story building is in Manhattans Hudson Square neighborhood, and will serve as the luxury automotive brands new global headquarters starting next year.

title: Updated: Why Shopping Is So Important in Health Enrollment
description: This article was updated Nov. 20 with rate information from all 50 states.

title: A Reading of Marriage Nests by Jill Bialosky
description: The American poet offers her view of the somber realities of matrimony.

title: Consumers Satisfied With Health Exchanges, Poll Finds
description: The Affordable Care Acts second enrollment period, which begins this weekend, has been ushered in with a litany of criticism about everything from rate hikes to old comments from one of the people who helped craft the law.

title: F.C.C. Asks AT&T for Details on Plans to Halt Fiber Expansion
description: WASHINGTON  When Randall L. Stephenson, AT&Ts chairman and chief executive, said this week that the company would halt some of its plans for fiber-optic expansion until federal regulators decided on a net neutrality policy, at least one important party was listening: the Federal Communications Commission.

title: A Player With a Modern Ear Explores the New in Traditional Fugues
description: Like most pianists, Pierre-Laurent Aimard studied Bachs seminal The Well-Tempered Clavier, the two books of paired preludes and fugues in all the major and minor keys, when he was a student. But when, at 19, he became a founding member of Pierre Boulezs Ensemble InterContemporain, the important modern music group in Paris, Mr. Aimard turned into a new-music specialist. Bach was among the composers he put on the shelf during those years.

title: Smithsonian Unveils $2 Billion Plan to Renovate Its Museums and Public Spaces
description: The Smithsonian Institution has announced the details of a new $2 billion plan to renovate the area of museums and gardens in its South Mall campus, including a revitalization of the Castle, its administrative headquarters.

title: Less than 50 Days Till Christmas
description: Dakota Fanning, Baz Luhrmann and Catherine Martin unveil Barneys holiday windows.

title: Quivering and Curving
description: An oxbow, in case you dont know, is the bend in a river that curves in the shape of a U. Its also the title of Ivy Baldwins perplexing new dance, the most compelling part of which is its set. Placed toward the back of the stage under purposely murky lighting, the design resembles a gnarled, twisted tree growing on the side of a cliff. Its serpentine lines, some delicate and others knotty with erosion, give this dancing space a well-needed frame.

title: Out of Unravelings and a Loss, a New Star
description: Mary Warner Greenway and Bernard Rogers were married  he for the third time, she for the second  on June 16, 2001, in Basalt, Colo. Their wedding, which appeared in the Vows column on June 24, 2001, took place outside his log cabin, a meticulously built place filled with books, Navajo rugs, a stuffed bear and thick down quilts covering the beds like new snowfalls.

title: Barneys Holiday Party Designed by Baz Luhrmann
description: Thanksgiving turkeys arent yet in the oven, but the Rockettes were already kicking, the Empire State Building was lit up red and green and, over on Madison Avenue, Barneys holiday windows were unveiled on Thursday with ice dancers, step-troupers, opera singers, a cappella warblers and two break-dancing elves.

title: A Hunt for Inspiration
description: The typical Sunday for most people rarely includes planning a dinner for 4,000. But for David Stark, an event designer, it often does. It is a lot of odd hours, Mr. Stark, 47, said of his work, which includes the Whitney Museum Gala on Nov. 19. Even if your own parties are more modest, Mr. Stark had some advice: Oftentimes hosts think their job is over once theyve set the table and put the food out, he said. I feel the process begins when people walk in the door. You brought them together because you like them, so dont drop the ball on the socialization aspects of the evening. Mr. Stark lives in Brooklyn Heights with his husband, Migguel Anggelo  a singer, dancer and actor  and a complete collection of Golden Girls episodes.

title: Your Wedding Accessories
description: The Vows section publishes an occasional series of photos called Wedding Album. This months theme was unique wedding accessories.

title: Tune In to The Times
description: Emily Bazelon, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine, joined The Colbert Report on Comedy Central to discuss the Supreme Court and the latest on health care reform.

title: Bill Cunningham | Autumnal Mood
description: Its as true today as it ever was  fall in New York is pure magic. The foliages tiptop colors were reflected in the clothes of passers-by. But the big surprise: women wearing moody combinations of black, gray and white.

title: On the Market in Miami
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in Miami, Fla.:

title: National Cathedral Holds Muslim Prayer Service
description: Followers of Islam attended a Friday prayer session that was the first of its kind at the church in Washington.

title: Evening Hours | Fall Festivities
description: The party season is in full swing.

title: Is Quantum Entanglement Real?
description: FIFTY years ago this month, the Irish physicist John Stewart Bell submitted a short, quirky article to a fly-by-night journal titled Physics, Physique, Fizika. He had been too shy to ask his American hosts, whom he was visiting during a sabbatical, to cover the steep page charges at a mainstream journal, the Physical Review. Though the journal he selected folded a few years later, his paper became a blockbuster. Today it is among the most frequently cited physics articles of all time.

title: A Diesel BMW for the Long Haul
description: TESTED 2015 BMW X3 xDrive28d

title: What the Birds See
description: As the holiday season approaches, many New Yorkers may be dreading a packed slog through one of the metropolitan areas three major airports. But if they had Jeffrey Milsteins vantage point, they might see the airports in a more flattering light.

title: Suddenly, a 3-Wheel Traffic Jam
description: Children who begin their vehicular life on tricycles typically migrate to 2-wheelers by the time they start kindergarten, eventually graduating to 4-wheelers. Now some grown-ups are returning to their 3-wheel roots, though without the pedals this time around.

title: Low to the Ground and Out of This World
description: Living in the same home for nearly 30 years, I am accustomed to the neighborhood teenagers asking, What kind of car is that? when a new model to be reviewed arrives in my driveway.

title: Strength in Odd Numbers
description: With the 3-wheeled Slingshot, Polaris aims to blow open what has been a minor market niche.

title: Figuring Out if a Financial Institution Is Too Big to Fail
description: David Zaring is associate professor of legal studies at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Giving Thanks in the South Pacific
description: A Thanksgiving Immersion Package and the Norfolk Island Food Festival are being offered for the first time on Norfolk Island, a small island just a short flight from Sydney, Brisbane and Auckland.

title: A Certain Metaphysical Attraction
description: For a guy who was then the director of academic communications at Parsons the New School for Design in New York, Mark Hannah was at a surprising, embarrassing loss for words.

title: Five Decades of Patter
description: With a half-centurys worth of experience driving a yellow cab in New York City, Sal Locascio, 87, knows the streets as well as anyone.

title: Lost Key? Copies From the Cloud
description: When Greg Marsh moved to New York three years ago, he discovered that his girlfriend often lost her keys and he had to spend hundreds of dollars changing the locks on their apartment.

title: Steering Wheels That Do Much More Than Turn Corners
description: Modern cars put a variety of controls at the drivers fingertips: Switches and buttons for the cruise control, navigation and audio systems, among other functions, all jostle for the limited real estate on the steering wheel.

title: U.S. Men Make Employment Gains
description: THE men are finding work.

title: Paradise Regained
description: This issue kicks off with a droll riff by our critic at large Andrew OHagan about the great luxury of the Internet. It is too easy to be nostalgic for the good old days before smartphones were appendages of our bodies  days rewarded by patience and hassle and banal chitchat with acquaintances youd rather not run into at the supermarket. Instead of closing us off to conversation and delight, technology has actually given us more time for the kind of analog pleasures this issue highlights  like reading, experiencing art, riding a bicycle and hiking in the woods.

title: How Gwyneth Paltrows Goop Has Become a Role Model for Other Celebrities
description: Gwyneth Paltrow, the 42-year-old Oscar-winner, conscious-uncoupler and Tracy Anderson devotee, is changing.

title: I Nearly Died. So What?
description: LOS ANGELES  FOUR years ago this fall, I spent several days in a medically induced coma after contracting a freakishly severe case of flea-borne typhus. A bacterial infection caused by fleabites led to liver failure, kidney problems, meningoencephalitis and, among other complications, a particularly deadly condition called disseminated intravascular coagulation.

title: Passing Through Time, Never Alone
description: Over the last two decades, in addition to choreographing thoughtful works for her company, Hilary Easton has earned a high reputation as an educator. Her day job, at Juilliard, might help explain the presence of teenage students in her new dance I Am With You.

title: Dreamy Collections of Little Nemo and Moomin
description: The fantasy writer Neil Gaiman once wrote, Tales and dreams are the shadow-truths that will endure when mere facts are dust and ashes and forgot.

title: The Brotherhood of the Stay-at-Home Dad
description: DENVER  Choo-choo-wa! Choo-choo-wa! Choo-choo-wa-wa-wah!

title: Twisting Their Flesh as Symbols of Virility
description: Of the many unsettling images in Animalinside, a new duet by the Slovakian choreographer Jaro Vinarsky, the first is the hardest to forget. On Thursday at Abrons Arts Center, frothy lounge music played as the audience filed into the Experimental Theater. Then darkness fell, and a tense wail hijacked the soundtrack, like a siren stuck at one pitch.

title: Rare Ferns: Thriving in Fumes and Grime
description: Some people still believe that cities are biological wastelands, infested with pigeons, rats and weeds gone amok, no place for serious scientific study. But a new concept has gradually emerged among die-hard naturalists and researchers.

title: Standing Up to Aggression, or Ensuring Security
Jeffrey Deitch Is Back on the Art Auction Scene
description: Call the cops, theres Yukon gridlock at Christies.

title: Inventing a Drybar for Meditation
description: LOS ANGELES  Ill just be honest: I expected Suze Yalof Schwartz and her new guided meditation studio to be highly annoying.

title: Smile, Youre on Aura Camera
description: At Magic Jewelry, on Centre Street just off Canal, one can buy all manner of healing crystals and semiprecious stones. But most of the people who filed into the tiny shop on a recent rainy Saturday were there to have their auras captured.

title: Resinging the Song of a Life Cut Short
description: Telling someones life story, warts and all, requires the alignment of several parties who ordinarily might not share a goal. People who want the subject treated hagiographically have to see eye to eye with people who want to acknowledge the fullness of a person, even the failures. Plus, there is the matter of ownership  sometimes the people with legal rights to a story arent best suited to tell it.

title: Economists Inflammatory Remarks
description: A remark made by Jonathan Gruber, a health economist who advised the White House on the Affordable Care Act, has been interpreted by critics of the law to mean that it was passed dishonestly.

title: James Middleton Will Put a Happy Face on Your Smores
description: Late on Wednesday afternoon, as many Manhattanites eyes trained on the harrowing scene at 1 World Trade Center, James Middleton was cocooned in a 15th-floor suite at the Ritz-Carlton on Central Park South, regarding the lush carpet of autumn foliage beneath.

title: Team Landrieu Not Shy on Pipeline Politics
description: Its been a pivot to the pipeline.

title: Facebook Will Curtail Unpaid Ads by Brands
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Facebooks executives are not terribly worried about upsetting people these days.

title: A Maestro Returns, First There, Now Here
description: For the most prominent Czech conductor of his generation, the rejection hit uniquely close to home. Jiri Belohlavek had been chief conductor of the Czech Philharmonic  for just a year when its musicians won the right to elect their leaders freely in 1991. They voted him out.

title: The Comfort Women and Japans War on Truth
description: WASHINGTON  In 1942, a lieutenant paymaster in Japans Imperial Navy named Yasuhiro Nakasone was stationed at Balikpapan on the island of Borneo, assigned to oversee the construction of an airfield. But he found that sexual misconduct, gambling and fighting were so prevalent among his men that the work was stalled.

title: Vigilant Eye on Gender Pay Gap
description: The first step is admitting you have a problem, but its another thing to actually address it.

title: Lift Bridge for Metro-North Trains Is Getting Big Repairs
description: In 1954, the Supreme Court outlawed racial segregation in public schools. The Senate censured Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, whose scowling rants about Communist subversion had prompted witch hunts. The Grand Ole Opry in Nashville advised a skinny young truck driver named Elvis Presley to stay behind the wheel.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Recipes for Health: Beans for Your Thanksgiving Table
description: If you havent started thinking about vegetarian main dishes for Thanksgiving, now is the time. This year I am focusing on beans from North America. I have been enjoying a number of heirloom beans native to the Southwest and Mexico, and they were the inspiration for these dishes, most of which also incorporate other foods native to the Americas  squash, corn, potatoes, sweet potatoes, tomatoes.

title: Facts About Foghorns and Garbage on the Sidewalk
description: Q. It was remarkably foggy one morning this week, and it reminded me of a foggy day last winter, when I could have sworn I heard a foghorn as I sat one afternoon in the theater district. Is that possible? Ive lived in Manhattan since childhood, and I dont remember hearing one before. Are there foghorns in the waters off Manhattan or, for that matter, anywhere else in New York City?

title: A New Holiday Tradition for the Dutch: Arguing About Blackface
description: Hundreds of Dutch citizens plan to don blackface this weekend for parades in honor of St. Nicholas, who according to local lore is accompanied by a dark-skinned helper know as Zwarte Piet, or Black Pete.

title: New York City Agency Subpoenas 2 Santander Auto Lenders
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs said on Friday that it was investigating whether dealerships that sell used cars might have misled low-income borrowers into taking out expensive loans with hidden fees.

title: Vintage Americana and Spicy Chicken
description: Until 1898, when Queens and the other boroughs were consolidated to create the modern New York City, Flushing was an independent town with its own magistrates. FLUSHING TOWN HALL is one of the last vestiges of what Flushing looked like before it became a nexus of glass and concrete, Asian restaurants and stores.

title: Buying the Farm, Building a Subdivision
description: A quick assignment on a farm turned into a two-decade look at what happened when developers transformed the farmland into a suburban subdivision.

title: Inside Ts Luxury Issue
description: Ts Luxury Issue offers an intimate look at some of literature, art and designs most respected figures. In the issues centerpiece, authors including Philip Roth, George Saunders, Marilynne Robinson and Lydia Davis revisit, in candid prose, the circumstances and motivations that shaped some of their greatest works. (They also share annotated pages from those books  a sampling of a December auction of annotated first editions by 75 authors to benefit the PEN American Center, the range of which can be seen on Ts website.) Next, we celebrate the master decorator Robert Kime, whom we encounter at his picturesque farmhouse in the north of England; Rita Konig tours the property and gets a firsthand look at the English eclecticism that Kime has brought to his high-profile clients homes for decades. The polymath Danish artist Olafur Eliasson opens the doors to his sprawling studio in a converted brewery in Berlin and explains how art is just one of the ways  along with politics, philanthropy and cooking  he hopes to change the world. Elsewhere, Cathy Horyn answers the question, To fast or feast? by doing both in Germanys Black Forest; Andrew OHagan opines that, yes, life really is better in the iPhone age; Christine Smallwood puzzles over a bizarre new theme park in Rome dedicated to Italian film; and one of Ts very own editors explores New York City on three wheels in an ode to the trusty and stylish, if oft-forgotten, tricycle. See all stories from the issue >>

title: Pictures of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Turkey, India, Ukraine and China

title: Nov. 14, 2014  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Turkey, India, Ukraine and China.

title: A Bar for Whitman and Other Adventurers
description: Long before New York artists and writers convened regularly at the Algonquin and, later, Elaines, an eclectic group distinguished largely by crushing poverty and creative potential gravitated to a subterranean saloon  decidedly not a salon  named Pfaffs.

title: A Latin Musician Translates a Meeting of Cultures
description: The reality that jazz and Afro-Latin music have been mixed for a century can sometimes lead to the myth that a musician trained in one tradition is effectively trained in the other, and that fluency runs both ways at all times, in all places.

title: Twitter Mistakenly Labels F.S.U. Article as Spam, for a Time
description: Florida State Universitys football program has been the focus in recent months of news reports detailing misconduct by its players and lenient treatment by the local police force. The latest appeared Friday when The New York Times reported that two of the universitys football players appeared to have received special treatment from the local police after a car crash.

title: Classic French Bistro, Dash of Romance
description: When Smith, the talented hospitality group that owns five restaurants in New Jersey, opened Porta in Asbury Park in 2011, it achieved a near miracle. The group made Italian food, a culinary staple in the Garden State, seem fresh and new. At Pascal and Sabine, which opened last December, it has done the same thing with French food. Dinner here manages to be both excellent and fun.

title: Bridge Books for Intermediate Players
description: As we approach the gift-giving holiday season, lets start to look at some of the worthwhile bridge books published this year.

title: A Sponsor Steps Away From the Edge
description: Moments before the San Francisco premiere of Valley Uprising, a documentary about the evolution of rock climbing in Yosemite National Park, Gary Erickson, the Clif Bar founder, was asked to stand and be acknowledged. He waved to the crowd inside a packed theater and received a warm ovation.

title: Disney Announces New Digital and Mobile Products
description: BURBANK, Calif.  Disney on Friday announced several digital and mobile projects, including a redesign of ESPN.com, an app-based childrens learning product called Imagicademy and sales of its films on Walmarts streaming service, Vudu.

title: Along With German Food, a Cultural Tradition
description: Its the perfect time of year to enjoy German food. The Oktoberfest hoopla is over and nippy weather is just beginning.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Raw Bars Thriving in Season
description: With the days growing shorter and colder, we are reminded that the darkness and the falling temperature are the price we pay for living in the beautiful Northeast. Yet at this time of year, oyster lovers rejoice. Restaurants with raw bars bustle at their blackboards, chalking up the oysters of the moment and standing by to add the names of those that will soon be ready for harvest.

title: Player Ratings: Colombia (2), U.S. (1)
description: A troublesome pattern may be emerging for Jurgen Klinsmanns United States national team.

title: In a Snug Setting, Homey Italian Fare
description: Some restaurants are so romantic, cozy and spirit-warming that upon entry your anticipation soars, sometimes so high that it cant always be realistically met by the food itself.

title: Islamic State Says It Plans to Issue Its Own Currency
description: They have paraded their own flag, formed courts and ministries and issued license plates. Now, the leaders of the Islamic State, the violent jihadist group that has seized parts of Syria and Iraq, have created their own currency, part of a plan to restore the caliphate era that dominated the Middle East more than 1,300 years ago.

title: Debates on the Existence of the Divine
description: It started, as many good things do, at Harvard. Thats where, in 1967, Dr. Armand M. Nicholi Jr., a psychiatrist, began teaching a seminar on the rationalist, atheist philosophy of Sigmund Freud. Under pressure from students, he has said, he widened the syllabus to include a more religious point of view as well, adding the writings of the Christian apologist C. S. Lewis to the course. He called it The Question of God.

title: British Royal Couple Planning New York Visit for December
description: The Duchess of Cambridge will tour a childrens center with the first lady of New York City. The Duke will, in the spirit of royal opacity, attend a technology themed event, hosted by a New York-headquartered technology company, an announcement said.

title: Apple Pay Gives Glimpse of Mainstream Appeal for Mobile Payments
description: For years, tech companies have dreamed of a future in which people ditch their wallets and pay for things with their smartphones. And for years, that has not happened.

title: Obamas Plan for Immigration Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: To Help Language Skills of Children, a Study Finds, Text Their Parents With Tips
description: With research showing language gaps between the children of affluent parents and those from low-income families emerging at an early age, educators have puzzled over how best to reach parents and guide them to do things like read to their children and talk to them regularly.

title: Bills Coach Stumbles on Fourth-Down Decisions, and Questions
description: In a big game against the Miami Dolphins, full of playoff implications, the Buffalo Bills didnt try their hardest to win. At least that was the conclusion of the NYT 4th Down Bot, which thought the Bills made two damaging decisions Thursday night, kicking a field goal on fourth-and-goal from the Dolphins 3-yard line and punting on fourth-and-6 near midfield.

title: Revenue and Losses Both Rise for Postal Service
description: The United States Postal Service increased its operating revenue for the second year in a row, with the agencys annual report showing a 9.1 percent gain from shipping and package services. The agency also reported a $5.7 billion net loss, compared with $5 billion in 2013. Officials said those figures are due to a congressional mandate that requires them to prefund health benefits for future retirees. According to the report, the service was unable to make the required contribution by the Sept. 30 deadline, noting that it would likely default on its prefunding obligations in 2015 and 2016. Overall mail volume was down this year.

title: Those Who Vote and Those Who Dont
description: To the Editor:

title: Landlords and Risk
description: To the Editor:
