title: Some Retailers Promote Decision to Remain Closed on Thanksgiving
description: This Thanksgiving, the open-versus-shut debate has grown even louder.

title: Stopping the Next Amphibian Apocalypse
description: FOR the past 25 years we have watched helplessly as a wide range of amphibians around the world have died from a pathogenic fungus, known as Bd (Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis). Now, yet another fungal contagion appears to have been unleashed. This one is spreading among salamanders in parts of Europe and threatens devastation.

title: F.D.A. Optimistic on Visas for China Staff
description: The Food and Drug Administration expects to receive long-delayed visas soon for employees bound for its China offices, an agency official said. The F.D.A. is trying to expand its presence in China to 26 American staff members from eight, but for nearly a year China has not issued the required visas. The F.D.A. commissioner, Dr. Margaret A. Hamburg, who is to visit China next week, said on Friday, We have every reason to believe that we will be getting the visas very shortly. Christopher Hickey, director of the F.D.A.s China operation, said that it had filled the gaps by bringing in experts temporarily, but that short-term workers often lack deep knowledge of trends that years in the country provide. About 15 percent of Americans food is imported, including 80 percent of seafood and 50 percent of fresh fruit, and an increasing share of it is coming from China. It is also a major world producer of active ingredients for drugs.

title: Congress Extends Itself
description: Lets play: So You Think You Can Make Tax Policy!

title: Face to Face With the Fed, Workers Ask for More Help
description: WASHINGTON  Jean Andre traveled from Queens to the Federal Reserve Boards stately headquarters here on Friday to tell the people who make monetary policy that he needs their help. He cannot find regular work on film and photo shoots. The jobs he does find pay less.

title: Algeria: President Hospitalized in France, Reports Say
description: President Abdelaziz Bouteflika, who was hospitalized for months last year after a stroke, has been admitted to a French hospital in the city of Grenoble, news agencies reported Friday, citing French police officials. Mr. Bouteflika, 77, has led Algeria for 15 years and was re-elected to a fourth presidential term in April despite his evident ill health. He has flown to France for medical care several times since his stroke. Any deterioration of his health raises questions about presidential succession in Algeria, a volatile North African state. The Algerian government has not yet made any comment about his visit to France or the state of his health.

title: 150 Years Later, Wrestling With a Revised View of Shermans March
description: ATLANTA  This city would seem a peculiar place for sober conversation about the conduct of William T. Sherman.

title: Rare Vaccine-Derived Polio Discovered in 2 Countries
description: Cases of paralysis caused by mutating polio vaccine have been found in South Sudan and Madagascar, the World Health Organization said Friday. New rounds of vaccination will be conducted in December in both areas. The two paralysis cases in South Sudan were in a displaced-persons camp where revaccination is relatively easy, the W.H.O. said, while testing suggests that the one case in Madagascar did not spread far. Vaccine-derived polio paralysis is a rare but small risk inherent in oral vaccine, so the polio eradication campaign is trying to introduce injectable vaccine wherever it is safe and practical. The injectable vaccine contains a killed virus that cannot mutate. But it provides less protection than the live, weakened virus in oral vaccine, is more expensive and is much harder to give. Only 279 cases of polio have been detected in the world this year, almost all of them in Pakistan or in Pakistani families in Afghanistan.

title: Tip on Medicare Spurs Insider Trading Investigation
description: With only 20 minutes remaining in the trading day, a Washington-based broker-dealer, Height Securities, blasted out a flash report to nearly 200 clients, including some of the biggest hedge funds on Wall Street, predicting that Medicare was about to raise some reimbursement rates.

title: Appeals Court Throws Out Suit by Columbia Professor
description: A New York State appeals court on Thursday dismissed a lawsuit by a professor at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism who had accused the school of misdirecting $4.5 million in funds tied to her endowed professorship.

title: Hasbro Said to End Talks to Take Over DreamWorks Animation
description: Hasbro has ended talks with DreamWorks Animation, people briefed on the matter said on Friday, ending discussions that would have united the parent companies of the Transformers and Shrek.

title: The Fate of Medicaid Expansion
description: Hopes for expanding Medicaid  an important goal of the Affordable Care Act  suffered a blow in the midterm elections. Several Republican governors who oppose expansion held on to their offices in close races and Republicans tightened their grip on state legislatures, which often have the final say on whether to expand.

title: Culpability in the Upper Big Branch Disaster
description: For the families of the 29 miners who died in the Upper Big Branch coal mine explosion four years ago, the criminal indictment of Donald Blankenship, the mines chief executive at the time, is a step toward justice. A federal grand jury accused Mr. Blankenship of conspiracy to violate safety laws and scheming to foil investigators safety visits, among other charges. The word greed was not used, but the indictment left no doubt about the priorities that led to the worst mine disaster in 40 years: produce more coal, avoid the costs of following safety laws, and make more money.

title: Jane Byrne, Only Woman to Lead Chicago, Dies at 81
description: Jane M. Byrne, who stunned Chicagos Democratic machine in 1979 when she was elected mayor after sharply criticizing the incumbent for his handling of a devastating winter  a victory that made her the citys first female mayor, though her tenure lasted just one term  died on Friday in Chicago. She was 81.

title: Report Offers Mixed View of Ex-Watchdog at Department of Homeland Security
description: WASHINGTON  He incessantly busted the chops of the officials he was supposed to be investigating to get his wife a job. He had his staff doing research for his doctoral dissertation and reviewing his wifes graduate school homework. And when Charles K. Edwards, the acting inspector general for the Department of Homeland Security from 2011 to 2013, met with his Ph.D. adviser in Florida, it was on a taxpayer-financed trip.

title: His Subway Listeners Venture Above
description: As the subway busker put down his violin, the spontaneous delight of New Yorkers caught in the daily grind of the raucous subway system seemed to burst like fireworks into a standing ovation and shouts of Bravo!

title: Why the F.C.C. Should Heed President Obama on Internet Regulation
description: Big telecommunications companies and many Republicans in Congress have criticized President Obamas proposal for strong rules to prevent the creation of fast and slow lanes on the Internet. They claim this is heavy-handed government regulation. But in fact, it is correcting an old mistake.

title: Building Bridges Where Needed on Chicagos South Side
description: CHICAGO  Rami Nashashibi drove down the tattered corridor of West 63rd Street, passing the occasional church or auto-repair shop or check-cashing spot, mostly skirting blocks that had been vacant so long they had dirt trails cutting through the high weeds. Near the corner of Racine, he pulled to the curb outside the grocery calling itself A Lot To Save.

title: Where Federal Health Exchange Rates Will Rise
description: A map of upcoming changes in federal health exchange rates.

title: In Ditmas Park, Armed Robbers Prey on Businesses and Their Patrons
description: The group of writers met at the trendy Brooklyn cafe as they did each week, to talk about their works in progress. Surely none of them, during discussions of character and twists of plot, guessed that a masked gunman would barge into their circle on Thursday night and rob them of their laptops.

title: Net Neutrality Rules
description: Is there anybody out there who opposes net neutrality?

title: ISIS Slave Market Day
description: In a video posted in October 2014 on YouTube, a group of men believed to be Islamic State fighters are shown sitting in a room bantering about buying and selling Yazidi girls on slave market day.

title: Yazidi Girls Seized by ISIS Speak Out After Escape
description: KHANKE, Iraq  The 15-year-old girl, crying and terrified, refused to release her grip on her sisters hand. Days earlier, Islamic State fighters had torn the girls from their family, and now were trying to split them up and distribute them as spoils of war.

title: Will Other Leagues Join N.B.A.? Dont Bet on It
description: There is no shortage of ways for fans to bet on sports, even though federal law forbids gambling on games in almost all states: Fantasy leagues, state-run lotteries and neighborhood bookies, as well as online offshore ones, will take a fans action.

title: City in Ukraine Tied to Masochism Finds Link Painful, Sure, but Some Like It
description: LVIV, Ukraine  Taras Demlan was out for a quiet drink with friends in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv, a beguiling jewel of Hapsburg architectural splendor, and his companions persuaded him to try the specialty of the house.

title: Moment Resonates, Quietly, at UMass
description: AMHERST, Mass.  As Derrick Gordons name was announced during the introduction of the Massachusetts basketball teams starting lineup Friday, a spotlight swung around the arena, and cheerleaders waved their pompoms. The Whos Baba ORiley played. There was a loud cheer at the sound of Gordons name. Yet nothing signified the occasion as anything extraordinary.

title: Christies Chief of Staff Quits for a Hospital Job
description: The chief of staff to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is leaving his job to work in the private sector, an indication of how the scandal surrounding the closing of access lanes to the George Washington Bridge last year continues to drag on the administration.

title: Weinstein Brothers Lose Dispute Over Profits to Hobbit
description: LOS ANGELES  An attempt by Bob and Harvey Weinstein to profit from the second and third Hobbit movies has failed.

title: Halliburton Raises Pressure on Baker Hughes by Targeting Its Board
description: A fight for control of a major oil field services company appeared to be brewing on Friday, as Baker Hughes disclosed that its larger rival Halliburton had threatened to replace its entire board.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 14, 2014
Bill Clinton, in Little Rock, Defends His Record With an Eye to Other Chapters
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  In front of a crowd of his former White House aides, on a podium set up inside his presidential library, Bill Clinton on Friday defended his legacy as one of policy breakthroughs achieved amid partisan battles, a record that may soon take on fresh relevance.

title: One Drug or 2? Parents See Risk but Also Hope
description: CONCORD, Calif.  Every time Matthias is kicked out of a school or day camp for defying adults and clashing with other children, his mother, Joelle Kendle, inches closer to a decision she dreads. With each morning of arm-twisting and leg-flailing as she tries to get him dressed and out the door for first grade, the temptation intensifies.

title: Falling Behind on Rent After Family Tragedies
description: Underneath Johnny Glenns cavalier exterior lies a formidable consternation.

title: In College Football, Now the Trophies Precede the Rivalries
description: MADISON, Wis.  Two weeks from Saturday, Wisconsin and Minnesota will play for the 124th time. Their rivalry is the most prolific in major college football, one that goes back to the 1890s.

title: Uber Said to Announce Music Partnership With Spotify
description: Uber has long proclaimed to be everyones private driver. Soon, those drivers will be able to play your own tunes while you ride.

title: Cosby Is Off Another Show as Rape Accusations Swirl
description: Criticism of one of televisions most beloved stars, Bill Cosby, is escalating with renewed attention to allegations that he sexually assaulted women in several incidents decades ago.

title: Cost of Coverage Under Affordable Care Act to Increase in 2015
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday unveiled data showing that many Americans with health insurance bought under the Affordable Care Act could face substantial price increases next year  in some cases as much as 20 percent  unless they switch plans.

title: Millions Due in Back Pay to Dancers at Manhattan Strip Club
description: Ricks Cabaret, a strip club in Midtown Manhattan, owes more than $10 million in back pay to about 1,900 dancers who performed there without being paid hourly wages, a federal judge ruled on Friday.

title: James A. Lebenthal, Muni Bond Expert, Dies at 86
description: James A. Lebenthal, Americas best-known municipal bond salesman, who turned the tax-free financial instruments called munis into a household word with radio and television ads dramatizing how ordinary investors built subways, sewers, bridges and schools, died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Affordable Care Act Supporter Ignites Fury With a Word: Stupid
description: WASHINGTON  Three years ago, as President Obama fought for re-election, his team was more than happy to have Jonathan Gruber, a well-known Massachusetts Institute of Technology professor, mouthing off.

title: Excursions for Some Rock Collectors
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  I nearly wept with joy when I solved Peter Wentzs puzzle. Weve had a rough week as far as fill goes, in my humble opinion, so it made me feel a lot happier to see a minimum of junk today.

title: Ernest Kinoy, a Writer of TVs Roots, Dies at 89
description: Ernest Kinoy, who wrote Broadway musicals, Hollywood screenplays and Emmy Award-winning episodes of The Defenders and Roots, died on Nov. 10 in Townshend, Vt. He was 89.

title: Saturdays College Football Games to Watch
description: 1 MISSISSIPPI STATE at 4 ALABAMA

title: Knicks Hopes of Ending Skid Are Dashed at the Buzzer
description: The Knicks entered Fridays contest against the downtrodden Utah Jazz  yet another weak opponent  with the earnest hope that their moribund start to their season could be reversed.

title: To Nets Coach Lionel Hollins, Scrappiness Counts
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Lionel Hollins offered a small but revealing look into his values as Nets coach on Thursday night.

title: Amid Little Fanfare, Americans Lose in London
description: LONDON  Tens of thousands of Americans live and work in London, and they flock in sellout numbers to help fill the 80,000-seat Wembley Stadium when N.F.L. teams come to town for the regular-season games that are now an annual fixture here.

title: Alexander Grothendieck, Math Enigma, Dies at 86
description: Alexander Grothendieck, whose gift for deep abstraction excavated new ground in the field known as algebraic geometry and supplied a theoretical foundation for the solving of some of the most vexing conundrums of modern mathematics, died on Thursday in Arige, in the French Pyrenees. He was 86.

title: Dorian Paskowitz Dies at 93: Doctor and Surfer Lived an Endless Summer
description: Dorian Paskowitz, a Stanford-educated doctor who gave up a lucrative medical practice to embark, with his family, on a peripatetic and celebrated surfing life, died on Monday in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 93.

title: Obama Offers Assurances of U.S. Shift Toward Asia
description: BRISBANE, Australia  President Obama sought to give new momentum to his strategic shift to Asia on Saturday, telling an audience of students here that the United States could be a force for order in a fast-growing region shadowed by threats like a nuclear-armed North Korea and maritime disputes between China and its neighbors.

title: The Strip  2013
description: Cartoons about current affairs from 2013.

title: The Strip  2012
description: Cartoons about current affairs from 2012.

title: An Ear for Jazz and a Nose for Business
description: The life of a jazz club is often brief and brutal, and that of the Side Door, a small room tucked away in sleepy Old Lyme, might have been expected to follow that pattern. But in the 18 months since Kenneth D. Kitchings opened the club, it has secured a spot on many a jazz musicians itinerary  and not everyone is surprised.

title: Onstage, a Classic About Racism and Tolerance
description: Before ticketholders even take their seats, they hear sporadic bird chirping. The audience has entered 1930s Maycomb County in Alabama, the setting for To Kill a Mockingbird, Harper Lees profoundly moving novel, which has been adapted for the stage by Christopher Sergel.

title: The Practical Art of Quilting
description: Quilts made by African-African women in the rural South  historically one of the least represented groups in the institutional art world  have become widely popular in recent decades. The spike of interest coincides with a growing focus on craft and folk art, possibly because of major museum exhibitions, like one at the Whitney Museum of American Art in 2002 featuring the quilts of Gees Bend, a hamlet in southwest Alabama.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 9 P.M. (Starz) THE MISSING A 5-year-old British boy vanishes during a family vacation in France, sending his parents (James Nesbitt and Frances OConnor) on a yearslong search to find out what happened to him. In this new eight-part mystery, Tcheky Karyo plays the French detective who initially leads the investigation, then comes out of retirement when a clue emerges eight years later; Jason Flemyng is the police representative on the British side; and Arsher Ali is the aspiring journalist merciless in his quest for a scoop. What begins as a wrenching but contained tragedy ripples out into widening and intersecting circles of secrecy and deceit, Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. Its a formula used not just in television and movies but also novels by Richard Price and Tana French. But, she added, " The Missing is imaginatively written, well cast, chillingly believable and quite addictive. This kind of story has been told this way before, but somehow that doesnt make this telling any less compelling.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I want to know more about what it means for him to be on two medications, and no one can really tell me.

title: Corrections: November 15, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Deporting Human Rights Abusers
description: When three Maryknoll nuns and a lay churchwoman were raped and killed in El Salvador in December 1980, the story sparked global outrage. Although five Salvadoran national guardsmen were eventually tried and convicted, no higher-ups were ever held responsible for the murders.

title: Hong Kong Activists Kept From Flying to Beijing
description: HONG KONG  A group of pro-democracy activists from Hong Kong were prevented Saturday from boarding a flight to Beijing, where they had hoped to lobby the Chinese government to heed their calls for free elections.

title: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Caramelized Onion and Fennel Risotto
description: How do you feed a vegetarian or vegan Thanksgiving guest who doesnt like sweet potatoes?

title: Pakistanis Optimistic on Ties After Afghan Leaders Visit
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Afghanistans new president, Ashraf Ghani, met with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif here on Saturday, ending a state visit that left Pakistanis optimistic about a new start for the countries often acrimonious relationship.

title: Electrical Scalp Device Can Slow Progression of Deadly Brain Tumors
description: An electrical device glued to the scalp can slow cancer growth and prolong survival in people with the deadliest type of brain tumor, researchers reported on Saturday.

title: The Daily Gift: An Aphrodisiac Powder to Warm Up Winter Nights
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: College Football Scenarios: Six Teams, Four Spots
description: We cut through the rankings turmoil to tell you which teams have the inside track.

title: The Voice That Sends Help
description: Pamela Bullock-Galloway, 52, is an emergency telecommunications operator for the city of Hartford.

title: Another Widening Gap: The Haves vs. the Have-Mores
description: Philip Rushton has been selling private jets to the global rich for more than three decades. In just about every economic cycle, sales of small jets and big jets tended to move together  rising and falling with financial markets and fortunes of the wealthy.

title: The Gang That Always Liked Ike
description: For a window into a presidents soul, look at his closest personal friends. Dwight D. Eisenhower liked to decompress with a circle of wealthy businessmen who sometimes called themselves the Gang. Among these friends were William E. Robinson, a New York Herald Tribune executive and later president of Coca-Cola; Ellis D. Slater, president of Frankfort Distillers; Clifford Roberts, an investment banker and Augusta National Golf Club chairman; W. Alton Jones, head of the Cities Service oil company (now Citgo); and George E. Allen, a lawyer-financier-lobbyist.

title: A Plumbing Problem for the Internet (and the Stock Market)
description: I dont entirely agree with W. Hodding Carter, the author of a quirky history of pipes and drains called Flushed: How the Plumber Saved Civilization.

title: 1914: Sir Ernest Shackleton Outlines His Polar Projects
description: LONDON  As already reported in the HERALD, the Shackleton expedition has left Buenos Aires for the South Polar regions. Sir Ernest Shackleton, in a cablegram to the Daily Chronicle, gives some final details of his projects.

title: Putin Gets a Cool Reception From G-20
description: As President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia joined world leaders for the Group of 20 summit meeting in Brisbane, Australia, on Saturday, he faced criticism from President Obama and other leaders over the conflict in Ukraine.

title: Buying the Bricks for Your Online Storefront
description: These days, I do nearly all my shopping online. Amazon whisks household supplies like dish soap and paper towels to my doorstep in a day or two, and grocery services like FreshDirect and Good Eggs can quickly restock my fridge and pantry.

title: Borrowers, Beware: The Robo-Signers Arent Finished Yet
description: Remember the robo-signers, those mortgage loan automatons who authenticated thousands of foreclosure documents over the years without verifying the information they were swearing to?

title: No Love for a Bench
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Hotels Providing Packages With a View to the Parade
description: The Macys Thanksgiving Day Paradehas been aNew York Citytradition since the 1920s,and attracts3.5 million spectators in the city. Guests at several hotels along the routeon Central Park West and South andAvenue of the Americaswill get some particularly good viewsof this years event.

title: Variety: A Packed Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  I had a brief fling with Russian literature when I was younger, but I found as life got busy that I just didnt have the brain power to stick with books that were more complex than the chapter books I read to my children. Now that my kids are nearly grown, maybe Ill get back into Tolstoy and Dostoevsky.

title: No. 1 With a Bullet: Nadeshot Becomes a Call of Duty Star
description: LOS ANGELES  Matt Haag, a professional video game player, makes close to a million dollars a year sitting in a soft chair smashing buttons. It is a fantastically sweet gig, and he will do about anything to keep it.

title: Living Out Knicks Dream, Complete With Nightmares
description: Dennis Doyle knows how strange it must sound, his giving up his career as a lawyer to hit the road with his favorite sports team.

title: Finishing Asia Tour, Obama Promotes More Ambitious Foreign Policy
description: BRISBANE, Australia  When President Obama ended his last trip to Asia in the Philippines in April, he delivered a defense of his foreign policy as a slow, steady pursuit of American interests  casting himself as a batter who hits singles and doubles, but avoids reckless errors.

title: More Federal Agencies Are Using Undercover Operations
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government has significantly expanded undercover operations in recent years, with officers from at least 40 agencies posing as business people, welfare recipients, political protesters and even doctors or ministers to ferret out wrongdoing, records and interviews show.

title: Top General Arrives in Baghdad to See U.S. Contribution in Fight Against ISIS
description: BAGHDAD  The top United States military officer arrived here Saturday on his first visit since the beginning of the American-led military campaign against the extremists who call themselves the Islamic State.

title: To the End, Kobe Bryant Is a Shooting Guard, Hot or Cold
description: Being a prolific outside shooter in the N.B.A. requires an almost comical amount of optimism. A player has to accept that more than half of his shots will miss but has to retain the confidence to thrust the ball toward the rim every time he has the chance.

title: In Egypt, Jihadists Release Video of an October Attack
description: CAIRO  Egypts most lethal jihadist group has released a video that appears to show its militants carrying out an attack that killed more than 31 soldiers in the Sinai Peninsula last month, raising new questions about the readiness of the governments troops to confront the insurgency.

title: A Former Police Officer Will Get a Posthumous Honor
description: Pat Burns liked to joke that he was two things: a police officer and hockey coach.

title: Some New Frustrations as Health Exchange Opens
description: WASHINGTON  The health insurance marketplace opened for business on Saturday and performed much better than last year, but some consumers reported long, frustrating delays in trying to buy insurance and gain access to their own accounts at HealthCare.gov.

title: The Unwisdom of Crowding Out (Wonkish)
description: I am, to my own surprise, not too happy with the defense of Keynes by Peter Temin and David Vines in VoxEU. Peter and David are of course right that Keynes has a lot to teach us, and are also right that the anti-Keynesians arent just making really bad arguments; theyre making the very same really bad arguments Keynes refuted 80 years ago.

title: Advice and Accolades for UConns Breanna Stewart
description: HARTFORD  Breanna Stewarts junior year at Connecticut began with a specialized course for a select group of student-athletes.

title: How the G.O.P. Can Court the Working Class
description: A defining feature of Republican economic policy for decades has been its benefits for the well off. The stated goals of that policy have been to shrink government and lift economic growth, but the main method has been cutting taxes much more for high-income families than others. At the same time, the party has opposed an expansion of health insurance for low- and middle-income families, increases in the minimum wage and college financial aid and extensions of jobless benefits.

title: Sunday Shows: What Were Watching
description: Despite protests from conservatives, President Obama has said he will act unilaterally on immigration, issuing executive orders that will protect up to five million unauthorized immigrants from deportation.

title: Winless Driver Could Wear the Crown
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla.  Ryan Newman can do something Sunday that no one else has done: win a Nascar Sprint Cup title without winning a race during the season.

title: Do It For Utica!
description: I love two places in this world. One of them is Denmark, and so I was dismayed to discover that it has a serious procreation problem. The birthrate is the lowest its been in more than a quarter century, prompting the country to revise its sexual education curriculum. The new program is called, This is how you have children!

title: Who Are We?
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  THE 9/11 suicide attack, spearheaded by 19, mostly Saudi, young men in the name of Islam, ignited a debate in the Sunni Arab world about religion and how their societies could have produced such suicidal fanatics. But it was quickly choked off by denial, and by Americas failed invasion of Iraq. Well, conversations here in Dubai, one of the great Arab/Muslim crossroads, make it clear that the rise of the Islamic State caliphate in Iraq and Syria, and its barbaric treatment of those who are against them  moderate Sunnis or Shiites, Christians, other minorities and women  has revived this central debate about who are we?

title: Delusions of the Democrats
description: DEMOGRAPHICS is not enough.

title: The Fable of Rand Paul
description: THE most interesting man in politics is what Politico Magazine crowned Rand Paul in September, when it placed him at the top of a list of 50 people to keep an eye on. And Time magazine used those exact six words, in that exact order, next to a photograph of Paul on its cover last month.

title: Prophylactic Suicide
description: Readers debate whether aid-in-dying rights should be expanded to those who are not terminally ill.

title: The Civil Wars Environmental Impact
description: The Civil War was the most lethal conflict in American history, by a wide margin. But the conventional metric we use to measure a wars impact  the number of human lives it took  does not fully convey the damage it caused. This was an environmental catastrophe of the first magnitude, with effects that endured long after the guns were silenced. It could be argued that they have never ended.

title: On Smushing Bugs
description: When my kitchen became infested with ants this summer, as it does every year, I put out ant traps, which, in another annual rite, did exactly nothing. So I did what I always end up doing inefficiently smushing the ants one by one. Sometimes Ill massacre dozens at a time in a fit of pique after catching them glutting themselves in my sugar bowl, but then, seeing a single ant moping around on the counter looking sort of forlorn and hangdog, Ill hesitate. He looks like maybe hes not having such a great day already. Getting smushed is the last thing this guy needs.

title: After Three Days on the Town in New York, European Sailors Head Home
description: More than 450 visitors from Holland, Spain and England were set to depart on Saturday from the passenger ship terminal on the West Side of Manhattan. But they are not typical tourists leaving on a cruise ship.

title: Drawing Strength From the Gifts Her Mother Left Behind
description: In their final days together, the last gift Makia Green gave her dying mother was a vision of the future.

title: Police Examine Death of a Boy and an Attack on a Girl
description: The police are investigating the death of a 3-year-old boy in the Bronx after his grandmother found him unconscious in his bed early Saturday morning, the authorities said.

title: In Flawed Giants Season, a Bit of Perfection
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Within a failing organization, it is rare when one person  and only one person  is indisputably blameless for the dysfunction. If everything seems to be going wrong on every noticeable level, how can one person be above the taint of collapse and error?

title: New Senators Tilt G.O.P. Back Toward Insiders
description: WASHINGTON  They have spent at least 70 collective years in government: five sitting members of Congress, two civil servants from the George W. Bush administration, a pair of state legislators and a former governor.

title: Applications by the Dozen, as Anxious Seniors Hedge College Bets
description: Six college applications once seemed like a lot. Submitting eight was a mark of great ambition. For a growing number of increasingly anxious high school seniors, figures like that now sound like just a starting point.

title: Cold Numbers on G.M. Crisis: A Peek Inside
description: WASHINGTON  If this Monday is like almost every other one this fall, the death toll from General Motors defective ignition switch will rise.

title: A Familiar Anger Begins to Boil Again in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  The fate of 43 college students missing and presumed killed and burned to ashes in a mass abduction in September has bred ire and indignation in many corners of Mexico.

title: Sundays Matchup: 49ers (5-4) at Giants (3-6)
description: 1 p.m., Fox

title: Warning Signs From Commodity Prices
description: For many consumers and businesses the recent drop in commodity prices has provided a tidy windfall  one analyst estimated that the typical American household would save $400 a year thanks to lower gasoline prices. But the tumbling price of fuels, metals and other commodities is also sending a warning about the global economy.

title: The Great Immigration Betrayal
description: IN the months since President Obama first seem poised  as he now seems poised again  to issue a sweeping executive amnesty for millions of illegal immigrants, weve learned two important things about how this administration approaches its constitutional obligations.

title: When Whites Just Dont Get It, Part 4
description: WHEN I write about racial inequality in America, one common response from whites is eye-rolling and an emphatic: Its time to move on.

title: A Final Dash on an Iran Deal
description: After a year of work, the major powers and Iran face a Nov. 24 deadline for completing an agreement that would limit Irans nuclear program in exchange for lifting sanctions. While a final round of negotiations is set for this week, high-level talks in Oman last week apparently failed to achieve a breakthrough on important issues, leading to growing speculation that the deadline will not be met.

title: The Shifting Ebola Epidemic
description: Recent gains in controlling the Ebola epidemic in West Africa have been encouraging, but they offer no reason for complacency. In Liberia, the hardest-hit country, the rate of new infections has declined in some areas, and several treatment units have been reporting empty beds for more than a month. But in adjacent Sierra Leone the number of new cases has shot upward, while in Guinea, where the epidemic started, the incidence of new cases appears to have stabilized over all, with growth in some districts and declines in others. All told, Ebola has infected more than 14,000 people in West Africa and killed more than 5,000 of them.

title: R. Luke DuBois
description: R. Luke DuBois is a composer, conceptual artist and an associate professor at New York Universitys Polytechnic School of Engineering. His art and his teaching focus on the visualization of data.

title: In Malaysia, Activists Draw Attention to Colonial-Era Sedition Act
description: A Malaysian high school student was investigated, suspected of sedition, after he liked an I Love Israel Facebook page. Two bloggers were charged after creating and posting a Ramadan greeting with a photo of two people enjoying pork stew. And a student activist was sentenced to a year in prison for a public statement advocating an overthrow of the government.

title: Oil Dispute Takes a Page From Congos Bloody Past
description: VIRUNGA NATIONAL PARK, Democratic Republic of Congo  The trouble started when a British company suddenly appeared in this iconic and spectacularly beautiful national park, prospecting for oil.

title: Obamas Immigration Plan Could Affect Millions
description: President Obamas executive action plans may allow up to five million unauthorized immigrants to stay in the United States and obtain work permits.

title: Giancarlo Stanton Is a Power Hitter Negotiating a Power Contract
description: In many ways, Giancarlo Stanton is the perfect choice to have the richest contract in baseball history. He just turned 25, and he has a spotless image and ferocious power in an era of declining offense.

title: Fresh Voices Must Be Heard
description: Young composers and young (and younger) performers are featured in three events this week. The New York Philharmonics Contact! new-music series kicks off Monday with an evening of works by Missy Mazzoli, Timo Andres and Daniel Bjarnason (with Ingram Marshall a septuagenarian interloper), all brought together by the composer John Adams, who hosts. (7:30 p.m., SubCulture, 45 Bleecker Street, East Village; 212-875-5656, nyphil.org.) On Wednesday, the Juilliard School opens a three-performance run of Rossinis ebullient rarity Il Turco in Italia, conducted by Speranza Scappucci and directed by John Giampietro. (8 p.m., Lincoln Center; juilliard.edu.) And on Thursday, the Brooklyn Youth Chorus gives the first of four performances of Black Mountain Songs, an evening-length staged program of works by Bryce Dessner, Richard Reed Parry, Caroline Shaw, Nico Muhly and others, based on the landmark midcentury collaborations at Black Mountain College in North Carolina. (7:30 p.m., Harvey Theater, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 651 Fulton Street, Fort Greene; 718-636-4100, bam.org.)

title: Grace Helbigs Digital Path to Fame
description: LOS ANGELES  Grace Helbig sounds almost blas about the prospect of becoming the female face of late-night television.

title: Mother and Son, Weighing Coiffure
description: The title Bad Hair may suggest a slapstick comedy, but theres nothing slapstick and not all that much comic about the subtle, striking film of that name that begins a two-week run at Film Forum on Wednesday. The movie, from Venezuela, is about a boy named Junior (Samuel Lange) who is obsessed with straightening his thick, curly hair for a school identification photo.

title: Greeting an Album With Stark Sounds
description: The brutal, atonal, harrowing sounds made by Pharmakon belong to multiple traditions  industrial music, surely, along with musique concrte and maybe shock art but sit comfortably in none of them. But then, sitting comfortably isnt really something you associate with Pharmakon, the nom de noise of Margaret Chardiet, who lives in Brooklyn and has become an unmissable young firebrand in her field.

title: Czannes Muse, at Least on Canvas
description: Of all the portraits that Paul Czanne painted during his lifetime (1839-1906), his most frequent subject was himself. Second came his wife, Marie-Hortense Fiquet (1850-1922). The exhibition Madame Czanne, opening Wednesday and running through March 15 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will present 23 of the 29 images of her that Czanne is known to have made. They dont give much away. Far from idealized as a woman or a beloved mate, she usually appears stiffly reserved, a dignified enigma. In fact, not a lot is known about her. She was 19 and working as a part-time artists model when he, 11 years older, met her and started an affair that produced a child, Paul (1872-1947). Czanne kept the relationship and the child a secret from his wealthy parents for fear of their disapproval but eventually married Hortense, in 1886. His letters to friends suggest that he regarded her as a shallow and irritating person. He excluded her from his will, leaving everything to their son. Yet he painted her repeatedly over more than 20 years. Go figure. (212-535-7710, metmuseum.org.)

title: A Rich Heritage With a Club Pulse
description: Like people, dance companies have family trees. Artistically, Lester Horton begat Alvin Ailey, who begat Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson. Mr. Rhoden and Mr. Richardson, both former principal dancers with the venerable Ailey company, founded Complexions Contemporary Ballet in 1994 to pursue their own vision of a multicultural dance that combined modern, ballet and jazz. In these ingredients, it bears the DNA of its heritage. But as a product of the 1990s, the Complexions aesthetic also internalized the sleek and sexy (and some say superficial) Era of the Supermodel, with the internal pulse of an all-night club.

title: Standing Tall to Fight Poaching
description: In China, when Yao Ming speaks, people listen. Trading on this former basketball superstars towering stature in his home country, WildAid has named Mr. Yao a spokesman on behalf of Africas severely threatened elephant and rhino populations to help curb Chinas multi-billion-dollar lust for illegal wildlife products.

title: Mishandling Rape
description: OUR strategy for dealing with rape on college campuses has failed abysmally. Female students are raped in appalling numbers, and their rapists almost invariably go free. Forced by the federal government, colleges have now gotten into the business of conducting rape trials, but they are not competent to handle this job. They are simultaneously failing to punish rapists adequately and branding students sexual assailants when no sexual assault occurred.

title: After Beating Princeton, Yale Could Share Ivy Title
description: NEW HAVEN  When the Yale Bowl opened, on a wintry November afternoon in 1914, its turf was covered with hay. The field was soggy; it had snowed the day before. But the first event was a cross-country meet, so it scarcely mattered. The runners raced out one tunnel and back in through the other.

title: Head of Music-Video Source Will Step Down From Post
description: The chief executive of Vevo, the online music-video platform that supplies some of the most popular material on YouTube, is leaving the company, according to a memo he sent to employees on Friday.

title: Still Logging in Sweet Home
description: The timber industry of Southern Oregon has shrunk because of environmental protection, mechanization and consolidation, leaving once-prosperous towns like Sweet Home searching for the next step.

title: Town That Thrived on Logging Is Looking for a Second Growth
description: SWEET HOME, Ore.  The great forest just east of town beckoned to Dan Rice when he was a young man, as it had to his father and grandfather before him, both proud loggers in a time that now survives mostly in black-and-white photos and in the talk of old men. He and his brothers kept the family log-trucking business going, he said, hauling to mills now mostly automated, partly in obligation to the legacy.

title: Dont Quit Your Day Job
description: Administrivial Deb-Amlen-in-New-York-City Fun Times Alert! Pencils up, New York! If you missed this weekends solving fun at The Ace Hotel, they have added two more dates  Dec. 14, 2014, and Jan. 18, 2015  so put it on your calendar and come solve with me! The Ace Hotel is at 20 West 29th Street in New York, so if you are planning to be in the New York area during the holiday season, please stop by and hang out. Click here for more information.

title: Familiar Ring of Triumph Since the Days of Truman
description: Of all the tools of learning on Fordhams Bronx campus, probably none are more rudimentary or more valuable in providing motivation than the Victory Bell. It sits in front of the 89-year-old Rose Hill Gymnasium, a stately reminder of the perils of war and the triumph that can be achieved in classrooms and on fields of play.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Obamas Immigration Plan Could Grant Papers to Millions, at Least for Now
description: Changes to the immigration enforcement system that President Obama is expected to announce as early as this week could offer legal documents to as many as five million immigrants in the country illegally, nearly double the number who received protection from deportation under amnesty legislation in 1986.

title: Kakha Bendukidze Dies at 58; Pushed Post-Soviet Market Change
description: Kakha Bendukidze, a biologist who became a wealthy businessman in the final years of the Soviet Union and, later, an architect of sweeping economic and governmental changes as a senior official in his native Georgia, died Thursday in London. He was 58.

title: In Shift, Pakistanis Fleeing War Flow Into Beleaguered Afghanistan
description: GULAN CAMP, Afghanistan  Through three decades of war, waves of Afghans have fled their homes along the eastern border areas, many of them seeking shelter in the Pakistani tribal regions next door.

title: Fatal Encounter in Ferguson Took Less Than 90 Seconds, Police Communications Reveal
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Audio of police radio communications and video from surveillance cameras at the Ferguson Police Department offer new details from the day that Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, was shot dead by a white police officer in August.

title: Iraq and U.S. Find Some Potential Sunni Allies Have Already Been Lost
description: BAGHDAD  When the militants of the Islamic State entered the Sunni Arab area of Al Alam, they gave its tribal leaders a message of reconciliation: We are here to defend you and all the Sunnis, they said, so join us.

title: Public Charter Schools That Failed to Meet Texas Standards Are Still Operating
description: FARMERS BRANCH, Tex.  One recent morning, Branch Park Academy looked like any other bustling suburban middle school.

title: In Texas, Beef Council Hopes to Rope In a Younger Crowd
description: AUSTIN  It has been 22 years since the racing violins and xylophonic beats of the composer Aaron Coplands Hoe-Down from his ballet Rodeo poured out of television sets, making Beef. Its Whats for Dinner one of the most recognizable advertising campaigns of the early 1990s.

title: Tours Take Border Guide Back to an Earlier Life
description: TERLINGUA, Tex.  Decades ago, Mimi Webb Miller ran horseback tours here, entertaining travelers with excursions across the boundary separating Presidio, Tex., from Ojinaga, Mexico, to one of Mexicos most beautiful and least visited regions.

title: Austin Lineup Changes as the Players Shift
description: AUSTIN  After 14 years of one governor, 12 years each with the same lieutenant governor and attorney general and little turnover in other elected statewide offices, it seems downright strange to change officeholders and top aides in the states biggest agencies.

title: The Clintons Look to the Past, for Now
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark.  Hillary Rodham Clintons in-between phase started here on Saturday, at a carefully staged appearance with her daughter and surrounded by old friends.

title: Roger Federer Shows He Can Still Generate Sparks in the Twilight of His Career
description: LONDON  You would have been forgiven for thinking that Roger Federer had done it all at age 33, with 17 Grand Slam titles and 302 weeks at No. 1 already in the bank.

title: Facing the Best, the Tide, as Usual, Are Better
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  Nick Saban clutched the lectern with one hand and pulled his other hand down his face, clearly perturbed. He had been asked if Alabama practiced any harder during the week in preparation for the programs latest biggest game, against No. 1 Mississippi State and its star quarterback, Dak Prescott.

title: Parks Department Will Try to Reopen Lasker Rink at Central Park
description: A day after the skating rink at the north end of Central Park abruptly announced that it was closing for the season, the parks department said on Saturday that it would try to make repairs so that it could reopen at some point this winter.

title: Four Workers Are Killed in Gas Leak at Texas Chemical Plant
description: Four Texas workers died and a fifth was hospitalizedSaturday morning after a hazardous gas leak at a DuPont chemical plant east of Houston.

title: Lottery Numbers
Suzanne Vega Saturday (Personal)
description: Notes:

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 16, 2014
description: Theyre coming up here not just to be against things, but to do things. I think its a very positive aspect of this class.

title: Georgia Dominates Auburn, but a Late Injury Dampens the Celebration
description: ATHENS, Ga.  It was all going so splendidly for No. 16 Georgia on Saturday night. The Bulldogs star running back Todd Gurley was shaking off rust from not playing for more than a month because of an N.C.A.A. suspension, and the Georgia defense was dominating the fast-paced spread offense of Auburn.

title: The Complexities of Matrimony
description: The Korean artist Lee Buls landscape reflects the chaos and harmony of Jill Bialoskys contemplation of the fraught nature of relationships.

title: Famine or Feast?
description: Is it more rewarding to subsist on broth and cold mountain treks at a German clinic for 10 days or to settle into five-course Michelin-starred meals? One writer heads to the Black Forest to weigh the merits of the purge and the binge.

title: At Dior, Icing on the Cake
description: Sugary pastel eyeliner made from strips of satin conjures worlds of romance and solace.

title: Shira Lahav, Michael Gladstone
description: Shira Yaffa Lahav and Michael Hamilton Gladstone were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Mendel Solomon at the Hilton Short Hills in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Lily Hayes Kaufman, Matthew Salzberg
description: Lily Hayes Kaufman was married Saturday evening to Matthew Blake Salzberg at the Rainbow Room in Manhattan. Bryanne A. Hamill, who retired as a family court judge from the Kings County Family Court in Brooklyn, officiated.

title: Francesca Perkins and Darryl Austin
description: Francesca Jeanine Evelyn Perkins and Darryl Emanuel Austin were married Saturday in New Orleans. Jesse A. Watley, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at the Academy of the Sacred Heart Chapel.

title: Jenna Segal, Jordan Zahn
description: Jenna Elyse Segal and Jordan Michael Zahn were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Carl Wolkin at the Four Seasons Hotel in Chicago.

title: Thomas OBriant Jr. and David Boul
description: Thomas Lorenzo OBriant Jr. and David Harris Boul were married Saturday by Mayor Rahm Emanuel at City Hall in Chicago.

title: Zindziswa McCormick and Timothy Drinan
description: Zindziswa Lara McCormick, the daughter of Helena Pohlandt-McCormick and Michael T. McCormick of St. Paul, was married Saturday to Timothy Edward Drinan, a son of Martha K. Hirst of Manhattan and Robert K. Drinan of Brooklyn. Jeremiah Kittredge, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at Dawn Ranch Lodge in Guerneville, Calif.

title: Judy Harvey, Matthew Henjum
description: Judy Baker Harvey and Matthew Brian Henjum were married Saturday at the Eastern Markets North Hall, a private and community events space, in Washington. The Rev. Louise Green, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

title: Hannah Edman, Michael Bornmann
description: Hannah Francine Edman and Michael Nicholas Bornmann were married Saturday evening by Cantor Ellie Shaffer at the Please Touch Museum in Philadelphia.

title: Timothy Walther, Barry Stinson
description: Dr. Timothy James Walther and Barry Lynn Stinson were married Monday at Brix Vineyard in Napa, Calif. The officiant was Lisa Lewis, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event.

title: Katherine Jollon, Michael Colsher
description: Katherine Alice Jollon and Michael James Colsher were married on Saturday at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. William J. Bergen, a Roman Catholic priest and the churchs associate pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Kathleen Brady, Alban Labauge
description: Kathleen Erin Brady and Alban Labauge were married Saturday at the Old Daley Inn on Crooked Lake in Averill Park, N.Y. Matthew Curran, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, officiated.

title: Michael Monroe, Adam McCollum
description: Michael John Monroe and Adam Rhea McCollum were married Saturday at the Forbes Galleries, a reception space within the publishing companys office in New York. Mark Grischke, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Halli Zung, Joshua Silverman
description: Dr. Halli Greer Zung and Dr. Joshua Seth Silverman were married Saturday evening at the Woodbury Jewish Center in Woodbury, N.Y. Rabbi Raphael Adler officiated, with Cantor Uri Aqua taking part.

title: Stephanie Dorman, Brett Gurwitz
description: Stephanie Lynn Dorman and Brett Rudin Gurwitz were married on Saturday by Rabbi Alan Katz at the Oyster Point Hotel in Red Bank, N.J.

title: Hadley Beier-Green and Zachary Rolf
description: Hadley Beier-Green, the daughter of Carol A. Beier and Richard W. Green of Topeka, Kan., was married Saturday to Zachary Martin Rolf, a son of Shelley Silverman Rolf and Martin P. Rolf of Great Barrington, Mass. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein officiated at the home of the brides parents.

title: Raine Katz and Michael Levoff
description: Raine Halley Katz, a daughter of Laura Jill Katz and Ira Marc Katz of Cranbury, N.J., was married Friday evening to Michael Francis Levoff, the son of Elaine Joyce Simon and the stepson of Neil Simon of New York. Libby Kelson-Fulcher, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the Four Seasons Resort Hualalai in Kailua-Kona, Hawaii.

title: Rachel Lexier, Curtis Nagle
description: Rachel Mauri Lexier, the daughter of IIlene Sue Altman and Richard M. Altman of Denver, was married Saturday to Curtis Smyser Nagle, the son of Susan N. Nagle and Frederick S. Nagle of Bedford, N.Y. Allison Dolan Hall, a Spiritual Humanist minister, officiated at the Union Club in Manhattan.

title: Giselle Barcia and Daniel Schuker
description: Giselle Barcia, the daughter of Daniel R. Barcia of Miami and the late Maria I. Barcia, was married Saturday evening to Daniel Joseph Theodore Schuker, the son of Maria M. Tatar of Cambridge, Mass., and Stephen A. Schuker of Charlottesville, Va. Judge Jesse M. Furman of Federal District Court in New York officiated at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington.

title: Happenstance or Not, It Worked
description: Rachel Grandison Trudeau, the daughter of Jane Pauley and Garry Trudeau of New York, was married Saturday evening to Robert Gary Steinsdoerfer, a son of Mary Ann Steinsdoerfer and Gary R. Steinsdoerfer of Crystal Lake, Ill. The Rev. Erik Kolbell, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at Gotham Hall, an event space in New York.

title: Corrections: November 16, 2014
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) THE NEWSROOM With Rebecca (Marcia Gay Harden) charged with defending the network against a lawsuit, Will (Jeff Daniels) tries to protect Neal (Dev Patel) in the aftermath of the Department of Defense leak. Charlie (Sam Waterston, above) and Leona (Jane Fonda) go up against the half-siblings (Kat Dennings and Chris Smith) of Reese (Chris Messina) in a hostile-takeover attempt. And Sloan (Olivia Munn) worries that Don (Thomas Sadoski) may be cashing in on insider information. In The Comeback, at 10, HBO asks Valerie (Lisa Kudrow) to bring back Jane (Laura Silverman), the producer who followed her around on Room and Bored. Valeries publicist, Billy (Dan Bucatinsky), meanwhile, gets her an appointment with the celebrity stylist Brad Goreski (as himself) for the Golden Globes.

title: Obama Says Russias Arming of Separatists Breaks Pact With Ukraine
description: BRISBANE, Australia  President Obama edged closer to describing Russias military incursions in Ukraine as an invasion, saying on Sunday that the Western campaign to isolate Moscow would continue, though additional sanctions were unnecessary for now.

title: Kabul Attack Intended for Lawmaker Kills 3
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber attacked an armored car carrying a prominent Afghan womens rights leader and member of Parliament in Kabul on Sunday morning, killing three people and wounding 32 others, Afghan officials said.

title: Obama Calls Islamic States Killing of Peter Kassig Pure Evil
description: GAZIANTEP, Turkey  Islamic State militants released a chilling videotape on Sunday showing they had beheaded a fifth Western hostage, an American aid worker the group had threatened to kill in retaliation for airstrikes carried out by the United States in Iraq and Syria.

title: Lessons in Living While Dying, From Pop
description: Weve been waiting for the results of Pops bone marrow biopsy all week. My childrens grandfather moved back in with us six weeks ago when he started having excruciating headaches. My husband, a physician, feared Pops cancer had returned. Visits to specialists, a tissue biopsy and a series of scans determined that it had, this time as a mass behind his left eye.

title: The Daily Gift: Colorful, Customizable Book Sets
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: 1889: Upheaval in Brazil
description: NEW YORK  News of the Revolution in Brazil was cabled here from London, and also cabled to Secretary Blaine by Consul-General Dockezy, at Rio Janeiro. Messrs. Charles R. Flint & Co., of this city, received the following cable from Rio Janeiro yesterday [Nov. 15]:  A Revolution has broken out here. The Brazilian armies are in control. The Ministry has resigned. The Revolution is for the purpose of forming a Republic. A coffee merchant in San Francisco is reported to have received a despatch from Rio to the effect that Dom Pedro has been deposed and that Brazil is now a Republic. An attempt was made to assassinate Baron de Landeris, Minister of Marine.

title: Assembling the International Space Station
description: A look at the main stages of the International Space Station's construction.

title: Broward County Sheriff's Office Internal Affairs Report
description: The Sheriff's Office investigated deputies regarding possible favorable treatment of a suspect in a domestic violence arrest.

title: Nostalgia Helps Dumb and Dumber To Top the Box Office
description: The aging nitwits of Dumb and Dumber To  a sequel 20 years in the making  defeated the Big Hero 6 kids to win the weekend box-office race. Costing roughly $40 million to make, Dumb and Dumber To (Universal Pictures) took in an estimated $38.1 million at North American theaters, according to Rentrak, which compiles ticketing data.

title: Puerto Ricans Once Found Solace in Churches, but the Pews Are Now Empty
description: The hum of prayers being said in Spanish echoed inside the cool, softly lighted sanctuary of St. Brigid Roman Catholic Church in the East Village, where about a dozen people clutching rosary beads encircled the statue of Our Lady of Divine Providence.

title: Vast Space and Art to Fill It
description: Taking another leap in its evolution from a disused 19th-century factory complex into a 21st-century center for visual and performing arts, the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art is set to announce on Monday that it has forged six new 15- to 25-year partnerships with big names in contemporary art, including James Turrell; the Robert Rauschenberg Foundation; the Easton Foundation, which controls the estate of the sculptor Louise Bourgeois; Laurie Anderson; and Jenny Holzer.

title: Routine Trip Turns Fatal as a Man Is Pushed in Front of a Subway Train
description: Far from the citys major Chinese enclaves, a couple left their Bronx apartment on Sunday headed to Chinatown for breakfast on a crisp fall morning. A few blocks to the D train. A short wait on the platform.

title: U.S. Intelligence Chief Describes Mission to Free Detainees in North Korea
description: WASHINGTON  The director of national intelligence, James R. Clapper Jr., described on Sunday his secret mission to seek the release of two Americans held in North Korea as a series of grim encounters with officials who expressed disappointment that he had not come bearing a breakthrough in relations.

title: Lawyer Defends Cosby Over Assault Claims
description: In response to accusations of sexual assault against Bill Cosby, his lawyer released a statement Sunday, dismissing the assertions as both old and previously discredited and promising that no one representing Mr. Cosby would comment further on them.

title: Whisked Out of Jail, and Back to the N.F.L.
description: Even after sheriffs deputies arrived at her Weston, Fla., home, Kristen Lennon remained in the bathroom, afraid to leave. Minutes earlier, she had fled there for safety as she called 911, telling the operator that her fianc had thrown her on the bed and hit her in the face and head. She was two months pregnant.

title: Japan Through the Looking Glass
description: There are indications that Shinzo Abe may indeed do the right thing and postpone the planned rise in Japans consumption tax. Lets hope so. But many people are still treating this as an agonizing choice. For example, Gavyn Davies frames it as a choice between recovery and fiscal sustainability, although he sort of acknowledges that this may be a false dilemma.

title: Roger Federer Withdraws Before Year-End Final With Novak Djokovic
description: LONDON  It was an anticlimactic year-end tournament, with no sign on court of the injured Rafael Nadal and an unfortunate surplus of lopsided matches and disgruntled fans.

title: 1914: Fearing Espionage, Officials in London Search Travelers Luggage
description: LONDON  New and rigorous measures to guard against German spies masquerading in the rle of Continental tourists were put into operation yesterday [Nov. 15], and provided interest and excitement for travellers leaving Victoria station for cross-Channel ports. Not a single passenger on the early morning three oclock train for Flushing escaped the close scrutiny of Government officials and Scotland Yard detectives. Mr. Basil Miles, with despatches from the American Embassy for Berlin, and Mr. Jarvis Bell, who left for Rotterdam, were among the few permitted to pass without questioning or without an examination of baggage.

title: Allergan Nears a Deal With Actavis to Block a Takeover by Valeant
description: After months of fending off unwanted takeover advances from Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, Allergan, the maker of Botox, is close to completing its strongest defensive move yet: selling itself to another bidder.

title: Dutch Investigators Collect Debris From Malaysian Plane Downed Over Ukraine
description: MOSCOW  Investigators on Sunday began winching large pieces of wreckage from the Malaysia Airlines passenger jet shot down over Ukraine last summer onto trucks to transport them back to the Netherlands, the Dutch Safety Board announced in The Hague.

title: AIDS Group Wages Lonely Fight Against Pill to Prevent H.I.V.
description: News articles often describe Truvada, the daily medication that has been shown to greatly reduce the risk of contracting H.I.V., as controversial. But they tend to cite one specific Truvada opponent: Michael Weinstein, the outspoken president of the Los Angeles-based AIDS Healthcare Foundation.

title: Parachuting Into a Garret, and Feeling Right at Home
description: In the third act of Puccinis La Bohme, Mim, the tubercular seamstress, says goodbye. Addio, she tells Rodolfo, her poet lover, at the end of the aria Donde lieta usci, and then repeats it for emphasis: Addio, senza rancor.

title: Florida Fires Will Muschamp With Two Games to Play
description: Will Muschamp, who has compiled a 27-20 record in four seasons as Floridas football coach, was fired Sunday, though he will remain at the helm for the teams last two regular-season games, against Eastern Kentucky and No. 1 Florida State.

title: You Seem Sad, Janacek. Cheer Me Up, Schubert.
description: Oh, there are loads of rules, Nick Hornby wrote of mixtapes in the novel High Fidelity. Jeremy Denk predictably broke them all in a series of piano works by Janacek and Schubert in his very satisfying recital at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday.

title: Rolling With Changes, the Knicks Get a Win
description: In their quest to include the mercurial J. R. Smith as a functional component of their offense, the Knicks coaches have continued to press him: to take extra shots at practice, to watch more game film, to listen to every morsel of instruction they provide.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Showcase to Earn Their Spurs
description: Ballets are strange, delicate worlds within worlds. Certain dances shatter to pieces if theyre not interpreted by veterans who know how to penetrate a role from the inside out; others flourish with students in early bloom. The dancers of ABT Studio Company fall, delightfully, somewhere in between.

title: A Portfolio With Room for Partying
description: Three major broadcast networks now have a series about a high-powered woman in the administration  or near it, since Olivia Pope, the heroine of Scandal, is in and out of the Oval Office as the presidents off-and-on mistress and consultant.

title: A Player Worth Remembering
description: The New York City bridge community lost one of its most popular members, Kathy Anday-Fallenius, on Nov. 9.

title: Ignobly Fading Away From the Rolling Stones
description: Brian Jones is to the Rolling Stones what Leon Trotsky was to the Russian Revolution: organizer, ideologist and victim of a power struggle. Jones founded the group, gave it its name and recruited the schoolboys Mick Jagger and Keith Richards, who then marginalized him, eventually expelling him from the band. Since his death in 1969, a month after he was forced out, Jones has largely been airbrushed from the groups history.

title: Gone Girl Wins Big at Hollywood Awards
description: The mystery-thriller Gone Girl took home the top prize at the 2014 Hollywood Film Awards on Friday night in Los Angeles. But while an array of Hollywood A-listers, including Angelina Jolie, Ben Affleck and Johnny Depp, showed up for the events first televised ceremony, audiences at home did not. The program, which was hosted by Queen Latifah and carried by CBS, attracted about four million viewers at its peak, according to the website TVbythenumbers.com. The previous Friday, the networks usual lineup (The Amazing Race, Hawaii 5-0 and Blue Bloods) peaked at 11.4 million. Now in its 18th year, the Hollywood Film Awards are selected by an anonymous panel of industry insiders and executives and honor movies released or scheduled for release in the calendar year. The Imitation Game, which has a Nov. 28 release date, was one of the evenings most lauded films, with acting honors for Benedict Cumberbatch and Keira Knightley and a directing prize for Morten Tyldum. The cast of Foxcatcher won best ensemble.

title: In India, Growth Breeds Waste
description: MUMBAI, INDIA  There is, we are told, a small island of plastic in the middle of the Pacific Ocean. There was, we are told, a fatberg plucked out of the sewers of London. But nowhere in the world is dirt as visible as in India. It is so visible that for many Indians who return from America, even from New York, it isnt the Grand Canyon or the Met they remember. Its how clean the streets were.

title: Games Let You Become Your Own Worst Enemy
description: Know your enemy by playing as your enemy. Video games have toyed with that idea for many years, and a new interactive historical epic called Assassins Creed Rogue tries it once again.

title: In Ferguson, Tactics Set for Grand Jury Decision in Michael Brown Case
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Several dozen people gathered in a dim church basement here on Thursday night to share plans for what to do if a grand jury chooses not to indict the white police officer who shot Michael Brown, an unarmed black youth, three months ago. Among their ideas was to descend in large numbers on the nearby county seat of Clayton at 7 a.m. on the day after the grand jurys announcement to snarl business.

title: By Turns Restrained and Rowdy, in a Playful Revolutionary Tale
description: The Mikhailovsky Ballet of St. Petersburg, currently on its first visit to the United States, is an intriguing amalgamation. Though its history dates back to the 1930s, its rise to international stature is recent. In 2007, the Russian tycoon Vladimir Kekhman took over as general director, infusing the institution with funds that have allowed it to poach ballet masters and star dancers from its better-known  and stylistically opposed  Russian rivals, the Mariinsky and the Bolshoi.

title: Solange Knowles Marries Alan Ferguson

title: A Show, Evolving, Makes a Point of Remaining Timeless

Its cavernous red-and-gold Art Deco auditorium (n 1932) is as grand as ever in this years Radio City Christmas Spectacular, with two Wurlitzer organs booming holiday music. The Rockettes, a company that has been part of the Christmas show since 1933, will charm your socks off. If youve seen them do the Wooden Soldiers number only on television at the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade lately, let me be the first to remind you: It is so much more fabulous in person.

It was warmly  nay, raucously  received, with whooping and hollering throughout, but it is a very safe bet that Constit2tion will not win any Oscars. It will not bring home a Golden Globe. Even an Independent Spirit award seems well out of reach.

title: Whats On TV Monday
description: 9 P.M. (HBO) BANKSY DOES NEW YORK (2014) In October 2013, the British street artist known as Banksy began a monthlong residency in New York City, posting one exhibit a day in an unannounced location and prompting a scavenger hunt as residents searched the five boroughs for works whose images, but not locations, were revealed ahead of time on Banksys Instagram account. Fans rushed to catch fleeting glimpses of stenciled graffiti, sculptures, videos and performance art touching on subjects like fast-food wages, animal cruelty in the meat industry, civilian casualties in Iraq and hypocrisy in the art world  and perhaps the anonymous artist. Eventually Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg condemned Banksy for defacing public and private property; some members of the press claimed that the New York Police Department was hunting him. This documentary, above, directed by Chris Moukarbel, chronicles the mayhem with the help of user-generated content from Banksys followers and foes.

She pointed to a round fancy pink diamond weighing 1.2 carats. This one may be six months older, but theyre all babies, she said. Thats how I look at them.

title: A Silent Partner Toiling for the Famous
description: PARIS  Last month, as he looked through a small cardboard suitcase containing his fathers silver models, Frdric Mathon, the head of the jewelry firm Mathon Paris, saw potential in some classic designs.

title: A Start-Up Incubator With a Fashion Focus
description: PARIS  The jewelry designer Sara Beltrn owes part of her success to a Jaipur rickshaw taxi driver she met when on a business trip. From helping her find her house, to production and business contacts, he made the introductions. But a local connection can take you only so far. The Council of Fashion Designers of America is helping Ms. Beltrn develop her jet-set beach-vibe brand Dezso into a profitable global enterprise with its in-house incubator program.

title: Oasis of Artisanry in the Berkshires
description: GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass.  This small New England town in the heart of the Berkshires, a hilly region of rural western Massachusetts, welcomes a summer influx of city dwellers from New York and Boston drawn to its tranquil setting, colonial-era charm and plethora of cultural goings-on, from museums to symphonies.

title: Reinventing the Medieval Guild
description: LONDON  For young craftsmen, making a name among well-established brands is perhaps the hardest part of the trade. To do so, the artisans working at Londons Goldsmiths Center have the backing of a group that follows the spirit of medieval guilds.

title: Doctor Being Treated for Ebola in Omaha Dies
description: WASHINGTON  This time, the challenge of Ebola was much steeper for the doctors and nurses at Nebraska Medical Center, one of a handful of hospitals specially designated to handle cases of the deadly virus in the United States.

title: U.S. Mobile Payments Market to Boom by 2019, Research Firm Says
description: Just a few years ago, the idea of paying for things at the checkout counter with your smartphone seemed like a technology company pipe dream.

title: Zoetis to Buy Abbotts Animal Health Assets
description: Zoetis, the animal health care company that has recently attracted the interest of the activist investor William A. Ackman, has made a deal of its own.

title: The Daily Gift: A Refreshing Treat for the Party Host
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: McCain Lines Up Allies for an Assault on Sequestration
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  Senator John McCain, who will become chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee when Republicans take control of Congress, took to the stage over the weekend at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, an architecturally fetching shrine to the patron saint of Pentagon spending.

title: Rachel Noerdlinger, a Top City Hall Aide, Takes a Leave of Absence
description: The end came at Gracie Mansion, where Mayor Bill de Blasio, his wife and her top aide gathered on Sunday to discuss a decision none of them had wanted to make.

title: Allergan Escapes Valeants Pursuit, Agreeing to Be Bought by Actavis
description: After seven months of bids, bluster and lawsuits, the hedge fund manager William A. Ackman and Valeant Pharmaceuticals appear to be giving up their pursuit of Allergan, the maker of Botox, as another big drug maker has trumped their hostile bid.

title: What Ties Say About Work Today
description: Few aspects of work cultureare as semiotically loaded as the tie. It signals masculinity, class status (or, at least, participation in a white-collar profession) and an adherence to a particular code of business etiquette. Some companies have deemed this code outdated, and the tie with it  but Robin Hardman wonders if theyre lying to themselves.

title: Burkina Fasos Interim Leader Speaks
description: Burkina Fasos interim president, Michel Kafando, promised to return the country to democracy in the wake of a brief military takeover.

title: For Boehner, the Benefits of Turning 65
description: A few hours later, Mr. Boehner thanked Ms. Pelosi.

title: 1914: Frances Champagne Prospects
description: M. Charles Heidsieck, writing from Rheims on the prospects of the champagne vintage, alludes to the tragic events that have happened in that district of France. In spite of the ravages of war, it seems that 1914 promises so far to be a notable year for champagne. When August began there was excellent promise of a successful grape harvest, the vines having escaped frost in the spring and having had fine weather in the early summer. Some damage was done during the advance of the German troops, but after September 13, when Rheims was reoccupied by the Allies, nearly the whole area of the vineyards was cleared of the enemy.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 18, 1914

title: Hong Kong Clears an Area of Pro-Democracy Protesters
description: HONG KONG  The Hong Kong government moved to clear pro-democracy protesters from a small area in front of an office building on Tuesday morning in the first move against the demonstrators in weeks. The authorities met no resistance, with student protesters saying they would not oppose the court order.

title: An Incipient Threat to Our Hearts
description: Millions of Americans are walking around with deposits in their coronary arteries that do not obstruct blood flow to their hearts  at least, not until a piece of the plaque ruptures and forms a blood clot, causing a heart attack.

title: Health Care Law Recasts Insurers as Obama Allies
description: WASHINGTON  As Americans shop in the health insurance marketplace for a second year, President Obama is depending more than ever on the insurance companies that five years ago he accused of padding profits and canceling coverage for the sick.

title: A Test Run for a Protest
description: A weekend passed in Ferguson, Mo., but the waiting went on.

title: Study Finds Alternative to Anti-Cholesterol Drug
description: For the first time since statins have been regularly used, a large study has found that another type of cholesterol-lowering drug can protect people from heart attacks and strokes.

title: A Birthday Bash for Terry Riley at the Ecstatic Music Festival
description: An 80th birthday concert for Terry Riley, a program of new works performed by the Bang on a Can All Stars and a concert of John Zorns music are among the highlights of the fifth Ecstatic Music Festival, which will run from Jan. 15 to April 16.

title: Inheriting a Payroll of Rich Possibilities
description: PHOENIX  The first player whom Farhan Zaidi ever sought to acquire was Ken Griffey Jr. Zaidi tried to pull him out of a box.

title: Injury to Bono Pulls Plug on U2 Tonight Show Residency
description: A bicycling accident in Central Park, in which U2s singer, Bono, was injured, has forced the band to cancel its weeklong residency on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon. The first of the groups five appearances on the show was to have been Monday evening. But in a short message posted on the U2 website on Sunday, the band (minus Bono) announced the postponement.

title: 1964: Ceiling TV for Teaching?
description: PARIS  Educational television took the teacher out of the classroom. Next it may put his image on the ceiling in reverse.

title: Peru Prepares to Host Climate Talks as its Indigenous Forest Defenders Die
description: The nonprofit group Global Witness makes some valuable points in a new report offering Peru a path to cut the violence on its poorly governed resource frontier in the Amazon. The report, Perus Deadly Environment, is being released today at a Manhattan event organized with the Alexander Soros Foundation.

title: Bank of England Chief Suggests Rules on Salaries May Be Needed, Too
description: LONDON  Just when bankers thought pay rules in Britain could not become any more complicated, the head of the Bank of England said on Monday that they might need to be.

title: Billions of Dollars Mend Health Insurers Rift With Obama
description: Once a favorite political punching bag for President Obama, the health insurance industry has reaped big benefits from the Affordable Care Act.

title: Merkel Issues Rebuke to Russia, Setting Caution Aside
description: LONDON  Tit-for-tat expulsions of diplomats. Russian naval ships showing up as world leaders meet in Australia. Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany telling Russia sternly to play by 21st-century rules  and President Vladimir V. Putin practically spitting fury over Western reaction to his annexation of Crimea.

title: Two Very Different Biennials, a Slumber Party for Creative Types and More From the Art Calendar
description: Ts list of happenings worth visiting in the week ahead.

title: New Jonathan Franzen Novel, Purity, Coming in September
description: Jonathan Franzens fans will have plenty to read next year. Theres a forthcoming biography of the author by Philip Weinstein, an English professor at Swarthmore College. And in September, Farrar, Straus & Giroux will release Mr. Franzens fifth novel, Purity.

title: No Allergan Deal, but a $2.6 Billion Profit for Ackman
