description: Depending how you look at it, William A. Ackman either had a very good day or a very bad one.

title: Monday Motorsports: Big Wins for Harvick, Enders-Stevens, MacCachren
description: Kevin Harvick won a tense finale for the Nascar Sprint Cup series Sunday in Homestead, Fla., edging the three other drivers vying for the 2014 season championship.

title: What to Wear This Week: Nov. 17
description: The annual New York Cares coat drive begins Monday, perfectly timed with a very chilly week ahead. As temperatures descend in Midtown, make winter dressing less of a head throb and let your outerwear do all the work.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
description: Gael Angoula joined Code Worldwide, London, in a new post, marketing manager. He had been the United Kingdom managing director at SmartBeacon, London.

title: The Navajo Nation Sheep Problem
description: This weeks problem was suggested by Dave Auckly, a professor of mathematics at Kansas State University. Dr. Auckly found the basic idea for the puzzle in the fraction section of Gordon Hamiltons Math Pickle website while collecting problems and activities for the Navajo Nation Math Circle Project. Lets give it a try. Heres

title: Top Democrats Urge Obama to Act Alone on Immigration
description: In a letter to President Obama, top Senate Democrats on Monday urged him to move forward unilaterally on immigration, saying they strongly support his plan to offer legal protection to some of the undocumented immigrants already in the country.

title: U.S. Considering Outside Help to Close Development Gap
description: For football players aspiring to their sports biggest stage, the obvious path is simple: Star in high school, go to a big-time Division I college and be drafted by an N.F.L. team. For would-be basketball players, the formula is pretty much the same (except some even skip the college part these days).

title: Gorillas Are More Fragile Than You Think: A Dispatch From Congo
description: On Nov. 16, Jeffrey Gettleman wrote about a struggle over oil exploration in Africas national parks that pits economic development against environmental preservation. Heres the story of his experience in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

title: Volkswagen Recalls 400 Cars, and N.H.T.S.A. Investigates Honda and Infiniti
description: Volkswagen is recalling about 400 Jettas and Passats from the 2015 model year because the front seat backs may move unexpectedly, startling the driver and potentially causing a crash, according to a report the automaker posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

title: Book Review Podcast: Napoleon: A Life
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Duncan Kelly reviews Andrew Robertss new biography of Napoleon. Mr. Kelly writes:

title: Shoahs Long Route to the Web
description: It seems natural these days to assume that any well-known, critically lauded, historically important modern film can be watched, legally, somewhere on the Internet. So I was surprised to see the announcement that Shoah, Claude Lanzmanns monumental 1985 documentary about the Holocaust, would be available for streaming for the first time at SundanceNow Doc Club.

title: A Scheduling Note: Keystone Pipeline
HSBCs Swiss Private Bank Charged in Belgium Tax Fraud Inquiry
description: LONDON  The Swiss private banking arm of HSBC has been charged by Belgian authorities with assisting wealthy individuals to avoid paying taxes on several billion dollars in assets.

title: Let It Breathe
description: A new song by Jaden Smith.

title: PCH
description: A new song by Jaden Smith.

title: A Final Visit
description: A look at the new instruments and repairs planned for the Hubble Space Telescope.

title: ScienceTake | How Birds Count
description: Researchers are exploring the mathematical abilities of New Zealand robins.

title: Today in Small Business: How Costco Codes Its Prices
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Walkabout: A Bigger, Better Mass MoCA; an Airplane Apartment on Airbnb
description: More MassAlready one of the countrys most celebrated modern art museums,Mass MoCA, in North Adams, Mass.,will be the largestafter a $55 million expansion, scheduled to be completed in 2017. (The Washington Post)

title: Ads for American Airlines Seek Great Results
description: Years before the phrase American exceptionalism became a staple of foreign policy debates, American Airlines proclaimed its exceptionalism in ads with themes like Something special in the air and Were American Airlines. Doing what we do best." Now, when many passengers would be skeptical of American  or any airline  declaring how wonderful it is, a campaign acknowledges that superiority is a destination to which American is still flying.

title: Luxe Valet App Eliminates the Headache of Finding a Parking Spot
description: Every few years, I come across a new tech service that completely upends how I navigate urban life.

title: Firestorm Erupts in Anti-Smoking Massachusetts Town
description: WESTMINSTER, Mass.  The fury  and make no mistake, it is white-hot fury  went way beyond the ordinary wrath of offended citizenry. A plan here to ban the sale of tobacco has ignited a call to arms.

title: Uber Loves Obamacare
description: It should come as no surprise that the chief executive of Uber, Travis Kalanick, likes the Affordable Care Act, a.k.a. Obamacare. After all, the law is designed to help people whose employers dont provide them with health insurance get coverage through government-run exchanges and subsidies. That is, people like the independent contractors who drive Uber taxis.

title: Erasing Sony and Nook E-Readers
description: Q. How do you remove personal information from a Sony Reader or the Barnes & Noble Nook before passing them on to other people?

title: Actavis and Halliburton Deals Make for Biggest Merger Monday of 2014
description: On Wall Street, there are merger Mondays. Sometimes, there are mega merger Mondays.

title: Facebook Testing Collaboration Tools for Businesses
description: Facebook has long been a place to go online to get a brief respite from your digital work for a look at baby photos, friends status updates or anything other than a computer screen filled with Excel spreadsheets.

title: N.F.L. Was Family, Until Wives Reported Domestic Abuse
description: CINCINNATI  Mercedes Sands and her husband, Robert, a safety for the Cincinnati Bengals, started fighting early, just a few months after they were married. But when Ms. Sands drove her car into a neighbors house while trying to flee, knocking herself unconscious and prompting a visit from the police, the Bengals became alarmed.

title: One Mealworm, Two Mealworms: More Evidence Birds Can Count
description: Evidence has been mounting for a while that birds and other animals can count, particularly when the things being counted are items of food. But most of the research is done under controlled conditions.

title: Saud bin Mohammed al-Thani, Big-Spending Art Collector, Is Dead
description: Sheikh Saud bin Mohammed al-Thani, a Qatari royal relative who was one of the worlds most prolific and idiosyncratic buyers of art, antiquities, jewelry, vintage cars and dinosaur fossils until corruption charges left him in debt, died on Nov. 9 at his home in London.

title: Police Vow 24/7 Manhunt in Fatal Subway Push
description: For several minutes after the fatal shoving of a subway rider on Sunday morning, a man sought by the police for questioning appeared to behave as if nothing abnormal had happened.

title: Seeing the Invisible Patient
description: Not once in the years I cared for my mother did any of her physicians ask me how I was doing. When was the last time I saw my own physician? Was I eating properly? Sleeping enough? Depressed?

title: Court Conflict Raises Question of Who Decides the Law, and the Breaker
description: It is a basic principle taught in every American government class: Congress enacts the laws and the executive branch enforces them. If only life were so simple. No law is perfectly clear, and circumstances change over time, opening up statutes to new interpretations.

title: Connected, Yet Often Drifting Apart
description: The first change we made when we moved into my parents house four years ago was to set up a sophisticated Wi-Fi system. With two teenage children still living with us, my older brother in residence looking for a job, and my husband and I working from home, a strong Internet signal was imperative to everyones survival.

title: Goldman, JPMorgan and Morgan Stanley Executives to Be Questioned at Commodities Hearing
description: Goldman Sachs executives will again come in for a grilling at a congressional hearing this Thursday.

title: First Draft Focus: Christie on the Hill
Quandary: Between Unknown Cousins and the Childrens Table, Thanksgiving Can Be Hard for Kids
description: In the Weekly Quandary, we pull from the comments, the weekly open thread or email a question that we know (or at least suspect) plagues more than one parent. You  the readers  provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? This weeks quandary is a classic this time of year: You know and love your Cousin Alice, but your child has never met her, or hasnt seen her in years, or has special needs that mean that even the relatively short distance between this Thanksgiving and last makes Cousin Alice a stranger.

title: For Obama, Executive Order on Immigration Would Be a Turnabout
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama is poised to ignore stark warnings that executive action on immigration would amount to violating our laws and would be very difficult to defend legally.

title: A Tactical Victory for Baker Hughes in Halliburton Deal
description: The Baker Hughes chief executive must be feeling satisfied.

title: Viewing Others Through a Prism of Money
description: Last year, a guy made headlines because he was caught using a lowly flip phone. In a world of gold iPhones and palm-size phablets, it does seem a little odd that someone would still use such a low-tech device. But it was the identity of the person using the phone that got everyones attention: Jerry Jones, owner of the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Warmer Waters Could Scuttle Activity of Crabs
description: Small crabs found on Californias shores may be capable of adapting to a warming climate, but the effort will leave them little energy for tasks like growth and reproduction, researchers are reporting.

title: Riding a Comet to Find Our Origins
description: Denton Ebel, curator of meteorites at the American Museum of Natural History, talks about how Comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko could help us to learn about the birth of our solar system and planet.

title: The Plight of Monarch Butterflies
description: New research could implicate efforts to help the Monarch butterfly in actually hurting their chances of long-term survival.

title: Whos Afraid of Executive Action?
description: As a follow-up to my latest shrill-but-accurate column on the presidents plan to bypass Congress and make immigration policy on his own, let me say something (not for the first time) about the common claim that this isnt really a case of the president making law on his own, because everything hes doing is potentially provisional, and subject to reversal by a future president. Heres Slates Josh Voorhees, offeringa version of that argument:

title: Brooklyn Hospital Is Told to Keep Girl, 2, on Life Support Amid Organ Donation Fight
description: A judge on Monday ordered a Brooklyn hospital to keep a 2-year-old girl on life support for at least another day, as her parents argue over whether her organs should be donated.

title: On This Day: Congress Comes to Washington
description: Newly elected members of Congress walked wide-eyed through the Capitol last week, soaking in their surroundings and the history of the place.

title: Draghi Sounds Hopeful Note on Europes Economy, but Reassures That E.C.B. Is Ready to Act
description: FRANKFURT  The president of the European Central Bank on Monday gave a slightly more optimistic assessment of the eurozones economy, saying that a decline in bank lending appears to have reversed and pointing out that the economies in most countries in the region are growing.

title: E.U. to Toughen Sanctions on Ukrainian Separatists, but Not Russia
description: The European Unions foreign ministers decided on Monday to impose more sanctions on individual separatists in Ukraine, but shied away from toughening sanctions against Russia despite its recent military incursions into Ukraine.

title: Jaden and Willow Smith on Prana Energy, Time and Why School Is Overrated
description: One of the gifts of being young is that particular blend of self-confidence and self-consciousness. Jaden and Willow Smith have managed to turn this form of heady teenage introspection into expression instead of ennui. Willow, the 14-year-old musician whose debut single, Whip My Hair, went platinum when she was not yet a teenager, explains that the gift of life is looking at nature and being, like, Wow, I am so lucky to have a body and to breathe and to be able to look at this.  To which her older brother Jaden, a 16-year-old actor and musician, adds: And the huge, terrible thing the world would be missing by not expressing yourself. To that end, both Jaden and Willow, the children of Jada Pinkett Smith and Will Smith, released new albums this month, including two tracks by Jaden that make their public debut here.

title: Church of England Approves Plan Allowing Female Bishops
description: LONDON  The Church of England overturned centuries of tradition on Monday with a final vote allowing women to become bishops, with the first appointments possible by Christmas.

title: Developing a Taste for Human Blood
description: Domestic mosquitoes love human blood, but that is an evolutionary adaptation: At one time they actually preferred furrier animals.

title: Governor Activates Missouri National Guard
description: Anticipating protests after the grand jurys decision in the death of Michael Brown, Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri activated the National Guard on Monday.

title: That Litany of Complaints Is Attractive
description: If you still enjoy that favorite sport of the i age  complaining about the omnipresence of electronic devices and the shortage of real conversation  the Flea Theater has a play, and a woman, for you. If, on the other hand, youve heard that particular whine too often and have made your peace with the new reality of modern life, you might have problems with the Fleas latest offering, a world premiere by Kate Robin called I See You.

title: Doctor Describes How Ebola Patient Died
description: Dr. Daniel W. Johnson, the director of critical care at the University of Nebraska Medical Center, discussed how Dr. Martin Salia died after being brought to the hospital with advanced Ebola symptoms.

title: Seeing Jupiters Red in the Lab
description: Jupiters Great Red Spot is a result of chemicals being broken down by sunlight, researchers report. The scientists, at NASAs Jet Propulsion Laboratory, blasted ammonia and acetylene gases, both found on Jupiter, with ultraviolet light. This produced a reddish material with light-scattering properties similar to those of the spot.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: In Performance | Alysha Umphress
description: Ms. Umphress, with Brett Rowe on piano, sings the number I Can Cook, Too from the 2014 Broadway revival of the 1944 musical On The Town.

title: Why More Diversity on Wall Street Might Fight Bubbles
description: Would more racial diversity on Wall Street make financial bubbles less likely to develop?

title: Newark Airport Lands Big-Name Chefs
description: First-class dining, even for passengers holding tickets in coach, is coming to United Airlines Terminal C at Newark Liberty International Airport. Some 28 new restaurants are planned, with concepts devised by 24 high-profile chefs, including Alex Stupak, Einat Admony, Amanda Freitag, Paul Liebrandt, Jacques Torres, Alex Guarnaschelli and Dan Kluger.

title: Safety in Numbers
description: Q. Can receiving multiple vaccines (like hepatitis a, typhoid and tetanus) shortly before traveling abroad weaken ones resistance to a cold or the flu?

title: How It Feels to Land a Spacecraft on a Comet
description: Peopletend to learn science from somebody that takes them out and shows them cool things, says Claudia Alexander. Now the planetary scientist has experienced whats arguably one of the coolest things in recent memory: As a project scientist on the UnitedStates Rosetta Project, she is part of the teamthat put a spacecraft on a comet for the first time ever. That spacecraft, Philae, lost battery power last week, butaccording to The Guardian, scientists believed theyd gotten 80 percent of the data they wanted by Friday. And Voxs Joseph Stromberg called Philaes outing a huge success.

title: Snakes Leave Identity Within Their Fang Marks
description: Getting a DNA swab from the fang marks of a snake bite can accurately identify the type of snake, a team working in Nepal has found.

title: Ben Ray Lujan to Helm Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee
description: Representative Nancy Pelosi named Representative Ben Ray Lujan, a 42-year-old congressman from New Mexico, to succeed Representative Steve Israel as the chair of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.

title: Another Bitcoin Auction to Be Held by U.S. Marshals
description: The United States Marshals Service announced on Monday that it would auction 50,000 Bitcoins, worth around $19 million, seized in connection with the now-defunct online bazaar Silk Road.

title: A Diverse Mix of Pupils, Learning Civilized Dissent
description: The issues could stock a Sunday talk show: body cameras for the police, Ebola panic and more. Yet the points and rebuttals came not in shouts from politicians and pundits, but from pre-teenagers formally debating topics that occasionally hit close to home in their disparate neighborhoods.

title: A Strong Start for Emma Stone in Cabaret
description: The Broadway revival of Cabaret had solid ticket sales last week for the first set of performances starring the film actress Emma Stone, who is making her Broadway debut in the role of Sally Bowles. According to box office data released on Monday, the show grossed $686,271 for eight performances, or 68 percent of the maximum possible amount; 85 percent of seats were filled. While Ms. Stone might have been expected to be a bigger draw instantly, given her fan base from movies, tickets can be expensive: The average paid admission was $112.39 last week. And sales were surely affected by the absences of the shows leading man, the Tony Award winner Alan Cumming; he was on vacation for four performances.

title: Julianne Moore in Architectural Balenciaga
description: The Star: Julianne Moore

title: A Reporter Reveals Ebolas Effect on One Family
description: Kaizer Dours family survived Liberias 14-year-long civil war, but they could not survive the Ebola virus. Last week Norimitsu Onishi told the stories of a family torn apart by Ebola. Heres what it took to piece it together.

title: An Upgrade for Newarks United Hub
description: United Airlines announced on Monday the details of a $120 million renovation plan to bring its hub at Terminal C in Newark International Liberty Airport in line with other major airports in the United States.

title: One Day, Two Deals and a Changed Calculus of Deal-Making
description: It has been awhile since weve seen a deal day like Monday, with Halliburton announcing that it had reached a $34.6 billion deal to buy Baker Hughes and Allergan selling itself to Actavis for $66 billion. The deals show that the merger and acquisitions market is changing in some obvious and not so obvious ways that may change how companies are bought and sold.

title: Interstellar: The Cinema of Physicists
description: The Earth is a dying dust bowl where a blight is destroying all the crops and oxygen. Schoolchildren are being taught that the moon landings were faked to bankrupt the Russians, and NASA is a secret agency consisting of a dozen scientists huddling underground. The Yankees are a barnstorming troupe who play games in cornfields and let ground balls go through their legs.

title: Mayday, a Super PAC to Fight Super PACs, Stumbles in Its First Outing
description: Lawrence Lessig grandly created his Mayday super PAC about six months ago to fight big money in political campaigns.

title: A Time for Revisiting Real Fears
description: In the late 1970s amateur radio operators began hearing raucous bursts of electronic chatter flooding the airwaves and interfering with normal operations. Cutting across the high-frequency bands, the staccato signals resembled a rapidly chopping helicopter blade or the steady fire of a machine gun. Some thought the sound was more like a woodpecker, and that was the name that stuck.

title: Democrats Shake Lineup in House Political Team
description: WASHINGTON  House Democrats, searching for a new generation of leaders and with an eye on the increasingly important Latino vote, have selected Representative Ben Ray Lujn of New Mexico to lead the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.

title: Weight Lifting Pries Open Doors to a Hermit Kingdom
description: North Korea, the worlds most reclusive country and an outsider in sports for decades, is in talks with the International Weightlifting Federation to host a world championship event, according to the organizations top official.

title: The Voice of Karadenes
description: Listen to Ted Karadenes sing a short clip of one of his favorite songs, Cant Help Falling in Love by Elvis Presley.

title: Angelina Jolie, Kristen Stewart and Reese Witherspoon at the Hollywood Film Awards
description: The Hollywood Film Awards took place on Friday, with the movie The Imitation Game proving to be the biggest winner. Here are some of the top red-carpet moments.

title: A Pundit Explains Whats Wrong With Washington
description: Or, actually, demonstrates by example whats wrong with Washington.

title: Even the Democratic Caucus Can Fail to Accommodate Pregnancy
description: Representative Tammy Duckworth of Illinois, who is expecting a baby in December, has asked the House Democratic Caucus leadership to allow her to vote by proxy in committee member elections next week. Her doctor has advised Ms. Duckworth (who lost both legs when her helicopter was shot down in Iraq) not to travel to Washington in the late stages of her pregnancy.

title: Two U.S.T.A. Board Members Will Be Replaced
description: Amid controversy around potential conflicts of interest, two United States Tennis Association board members will be replaced effective in January 2015, the organization confirmed Monday.

title: The Follies, the Oscars, the Troops
description: Richard Zoglins revelatory new biography of Bob Hope makes staggering claims for its subject. Is it enough to say that for the way he marketed himself, managed his celebrity, cultivated his brand and converted his show business fame into a larger, more consequential role for himself on the public stage, Bob Hope was the most important entertainer of the century? No, its not. Mr. Zoglin adds that one could argue, without too much exaggeration, that he was the only  important entertainer.

title: Speed Reading
Verbatim: Channeling Gehrig (Sort of )
description: Representative Steve Israel of New York said, jokingly, about handing off the chairmanship of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee.

title: A Master of Memory in India Credits Meditation for His Brainy Feats
description: MUMBAI, India  The young man sat cross-legged atop a cushioned divan on an ornately decorated stage, surrounded by other Jain monks draped in white cloth. His lip occasionally twitched, his hands lay limp in his lap, and for the most part his eyes were closed. An announcer repeatedly chastised the crowd for making even the slightest noise.

title: From an Egyptian-American Prisoner on Hunger Strike in Cairo, a Letter Home
description: Mohamed Soltan, an Egyptian-American in prison in Cairo awaiting trial for more than a year after his arrest at a street protest, entered the 294th day of a hunger strike on Sunday, his 27th birthday.

title: National Guard Would Play Limited Role, St. Louis Mayor Says
description: The mayor of St. Louis said Monday that he supported Gov. Jay Nixons decision to send the Missouri National Guard to his city in case there is unrest after the grand jury returns.

title: For the Monarch Butterfly, a Long Road Back
In Paris, a Culinary Homage to the French Master Alain Passard
description: So many chefs today are admired by the general public, but chefs chefs, the rare few whose mastery of the art sends their peers into fits of envy and adulation, are an elite club. In Paris, the king of them all is probably Alain Passard, whose restaurant LArpge, next to the Muse Rodin in the Seventh Arrondissement, has held three Michelin stars since 1996.

title: An Architects Vision
description: For your viewing pleasure: The architect of the Capitol posted a time-lapse video of construction of the scaffolding that currently surrounds the buildings dome.

title: As Japan Falls Into Recession, Europe Looks to Avoid It
description: PARIS  Japan looked like the model for economic revival. Growth was back on track. The stock market was surging. Inflation, which had eluded Japan for decades, was even returning.

title: F.T.C. Penalizes TRUSTe, a Web Privacy Certification Company
description: The Federal Trade Commission on Monday penalized TRUSTe, a company that certifies websites for compliance with various privacy standards, saying it had deceived consumers about its recertification program and allowed itself to be falsely portrayed as a nonprofit corporation.

title: Nov. 17, 2014  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Israel, Czech Republic, Syria and Greece.

title: Kim Deal, Beyond the Pixies
description: Though she is best known as the bassist of the iconic alt-rock band the Pixies  whose membership she departed, seemingly for good, in June 2013, following a successful run of reunion tours  Kim Deal has proven to be a linchpin for all of her musical projects. Besides fronting a 1995 album by the Amps (on which she was billed as Kim Ampersand), Deal also served as the leader and sole consistent member of the Breeders  whose albums, like 1993s platinum breakout Last Splash, often sold better than those of the band for which she was first known. But starting in early 2013, even before her split with the Pixies was confirmed, Deal began trickling out the first music to be released under her name only  a group of seven-inch singles appropriately titled the Kim Deal Solo Series.

title: Researchers Announce Advance in Image-Recognition Software
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  Two groups of scientists, working independently, have created artificial intelligence software capable of recognizing and describing the content of photographs and videos with far greater accuracy than ever before, sometimes even mimicking human levels of understanding.

title: State of Emergency Declared in Missouri for Grand Jurys Decision on Ferguson
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Gov. Jay Nixon declared a state of emergency on Monday, allowing him to activate the Missouri National Guard in preparation for a grand jury decision on whether to indict a white police officer for shooting to death an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown, three months ago.

title: Microsoft Billionaire Reboots Seattle Movie Temple
description: SEATTLE  The modern technology industry that Paul G. Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft, helped create is constantly giving people new ways to watch movies without stepping into a theater, from smartphones to tablets to streaming video on a big-screen television.

title: A House Fit for Murder, Madmen and Fashion Models
description: The stars Mary-Kate Olsen and Lauren Hutton are laughing on a beat-up couch in their Harpers Bazaar shoot, dressed for a bohemian ball, the plaster walls behind them cracked and humming in the afternoon light. In a Cosmopolitan U.K. spread, the model Megan McNierney totters down the stairs past a fresco of the Italian countryside, a Hitchcockian madman in pursuit. For a Vs. magazine feature, the actress Amber Heard reclines in a claw foot tub, wearing leather, lace, a commandants hat and knee-high boots, a riding crop clutched with menace in her hands.

title: From Mali to Israel, a Musical Bridge
description: The Israeli pianist Idan Raichel was at the airport in Berlin in 2008 when he spotted the Malian guitarist Vieux Farka Tour and decided to introduce himself. From that chance encounter has blossomed one of the most fruitful and intriguing collaborations in the grab-bag genre known as world music, a pair of critically acclaimed CDs and an enduring cross-cultural friendship.

title: An Insiders Look Before They Were Hip Hop Stars
description: Lisa Leones intimate and relaxed portraits of hip-hop figures  from rappers to graffiti writers  reveal the eye of a fellow traveler.

title: Subscribe to the Morning Briefing Email Newsletter
description: What you need to know to start your day, delivered to your inbox. Monday through Friday.

title: An Icy Hot Spot Where the Chill Scintillates
description: AZEALIA BANKS

title: Regardless of Offstage Worries, Onstage Its All Artistry
description: The Czech Philharmonic, a world-class orchestra that visits New York too rarely these days, made its first appearance at Carnegie Hall since 2004 on Sunday afternoon. Its absence, which may relate to its perilous financial state and organizational difficulties of recent decades, has made it hard to judge from afar how it may be faring artistically after those very problems under the leadership of Jiri Belohlavek, its chief conductor since 2012.

title: The Brains Depths and Romancing the Bomb
description: Neuroscience

title: National Guard to Help Police St. Louis
description: Mayor Francis G. Slay described the National Guards role in policing St. Louis in case of unrest after a decision by the grand jury in the Michael Brown case, which is expected later this month.

title: Dr. Irving Peress, Target of McCarthy Crusade, Dies at 97
description: Senator Joseph R. McCarthys anti-Communist crusade had reached a fever pitch in 1954 when Irving Peress, a New York dentist who had been drafted into the Army, became the beneficiary of a seemingly routine promotion from captain to major.

title: Schubert, Dvorak and a Sub
description: An intriguing debut marked the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Centers otherwise routine concert at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon. With the British violist Lawrence Power unable to make it to New York because of a fever, in stepped Matthew Lipman, 22, a Juilliard student who is scheduled to join the CMS Two program for young musicians, next year.

title: Sometimes Brevity Is the Soul of Music
description: Anton Webern, born in 1883, composed as if trying to obey Twitters character limit: His stark, tiny Three Little Pieces for Cello and Piano (Op. 11) encompasses about 140 notes. An elegantly rendered, concise statement is impressive in any literary or musical genre, although in Weberns chilly, atonal miniatures brevity often seems a baffling extreme.

title: At the Guggenheim, a Legendary German Art Disco Is Reborn for One Night Only
description: After the horrors of World War II, German national identity was primed for an anything-goes reinvention  and creation always needs a laboratory. This past Saturday evening, the Guggenheim transformed into a re-creation of a decades-old Dusseldorf discotheque called the Creamcheese club, where visual artists and musicians tussled with ideas of originality, abstraction and innovation. The Guggenheims one-night-only event paid homage to a space that from 1967 to 1976 served as a revolving door to nearly all of Germanys globally influential creative class.

title: Less Talk, More Therapy
description: My first session with Ann E. began as they all would: I stood against a wall wearing only a sports bra and underwear while she stood against the opposite wall, looking me over. She had me face north, south, east and west, and each time her eyes seemed to be tracing invisible lines down my body.

title: Some Ad Hoc Diplomacy in a Button-Down Era
description: In his best-known films, like Guerrilla: The Taking of Patty Hearst and Oswalds Ghost, the documentarian Robert Stone has focused on riveting bursts of violence in American history. His appealing new film does the opposite, looking at a moment of ad hoc diplomacy that may have made America safer at a time when the ultimate violence  nuclear war  seemed to be just one misunderstanding away.

title: Bringing Nixons World to Life, Detail by Detail
description: Harry Shearer knows something about playing American icons. Hes been the voice of Montgomery Burns, Ned Flanders and Principal Skinner on The Simpsons for 25 years. So playing Richard M. Nixon is no stretch. The question is, why did he go to England to do it?

title: So Far Away, Yet So Near to Us
description: Philae is talking to us, announced the manager in charge of the little piece of machinery that had just achieved the first landing on a comet, a frozen remnant from the formation of the solar system. We are on the comet.

title: Bodies Pile Up, but Business Goes On
description: With more than enough horror stories coming out of Africa lately you may have little appetite for revisiting a gruesome chapter of Liberian history from a quarter-century ago. But Firestone and the Warlord, a 90-minute Frontline special Tuesday on PBS, is an example of the reason we bother to scrutinize history. Its troubling questions are not easily answered, but merely examining them might be useful for anyone venturing into unstable areas today.

title: Ripples of the Big Bang Are Seen Through The Times
description: An occasional column looking back at The New York Timess first reference to some standbys of science.

title: Margherita Missonis Sunny Instagram, Willow Smiths Insightful Twitter and More
description: Every week, T rounds up five captivating online destinations you should be visiting often.

title: Kassigs Parents Speak After His Death
description: The parents of Peter Kassig, an American aid worker and former soldier who was held hostage and then beheaded by the Islamic State, have spoken publicly for the first time since his death.

title: The Best Odds for a Colon Test
description: The fecal occult blood test is an inexpensive and effective screening tool for colorectal cancer, but it requires taking a smear of ones own feces and mailing it to a laboratory, a procedure many are reluctant to follow.

title: Nuclear Agency Rules Are Ill-Suited for Plant Decommissioning, Leader Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Nuclear Regulatory Commissions rules are not geared for supervising the decommissioning of nuclear reactors, the task that will occupy much of its time in the coming years, the head of the agency, Allison M. Macfarlane, said Monday.

title: Justice Department Is Weighing Civil Suit Against Angelo Mozilo
description: Federal prosecutors are wrestling with whether to file a civil fraud lawsuit against Angelo R. Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial, which was at the center of the subprime mortgage boom and bust, people briefed on the matter say.

title: Is 'Big Marijuana' Inevitable?
Obesity Is Tied to Pollutants
description: Exposure to secondhand smoke and roadway traffic may be tied to increased body mass index in children and adolescents, a new study suggests.

title: At Brigham Young, Students Push to Lift Ban on Beards
description: PROVO, Utah  The dark pants, tightly knotted ties and crisp white shirts that once defined the Mormon man are nearly absent at Brigham Young University, the Mormon school that dominates this city.

title: Rethinking Shermans March
description: The March to the Sea has come down to us as an act of savage brutality perpetrated by one of the great villains of American history. Just the mention of William Tecumseh Shermans name conjures images of burning cities, ransacked plantations and terror stricken women and children,  la Gone with the Wind. Even after the passage of 150 years and dozens of scholarly books on the general and his march, most conversations about Sherman continue to generate more heat than light.

title: SunEdison and TerraForm Buy First Wind, Gaining a Toehold in Turbines
description: SunEdison, a company that grew from making chemicals and components for solar modules to become one of the leading developers of solar farms, is making an acquisition that will give it a foothold in the wind power business.

title: Jamie Horowitz, Newly Hired to Oversee Today, Is Fired at NBC
description: In a new round of turmoil at the long-roiling NBC morning show Today, Jamie Horowitz, a former ESPN executive brought in 10 weeks ago to supervise the show, was fired on Monday after what several people at the network said was a series of conflicts with members of the shows staff as well as the management of NBC News.

title: Jesus, Francis and the Church Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Pay Phones in New York City Will Become Free Wi-Fi Hot Spots
description: The modern New York pay phone will provide no shelter from the rain, no alcove for the quarreling couple seeking a private moment to reconcile. It will afford little refuge to the prospective superhero requiring a wardrobe change.

title: Egypt Will Expand Its Security Zone Near Gaza Strip
description: CAIRO  Egypts military said on Monday that it intended to double the size of a secured buffer zone in a town bordering the Gaza Strip after discovering smuggling tunnels across the frontier that were longer than expected, according to state news media.

title: Ex-Bertelsmann Chief Remains in Jail
description: FRANKFURT  Thomas Middelhoff remained in jail on Monday after a judge said he needed more time to decide whether Mr. Middelhoff, the former chief executive of the German media company Bertelsmann, should be released while he appealed a conviction on charges of embezzlement and tax evasion at another company.

title: Global Number of Youths Is Highest Ever, U.N. Reports
description: UNITED NATIONS  There are more adolescents today than ever before in human history. Whether they lift their nations to prosperity  or tear them to shreds  will depend, the United Nations warns in a new report, on how swiftly governments can respond to their demands for decent education, health care and jobs.

title: Sudan: Peace Talks Adjourn
description: Talks between the Sudanese government and a rebel group adjourned in Ethiopia on Monday, to be reconvened at a date yet to be determined. We have moved a good way forward, said the African Unions chief mediator, former President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, pictured. We are not too far from concluding the kind of peace agreement the country needs. This was the seventh round of negotiations between the government and the Sudan Peoples Liberation Movement-North, a rebel group in South Kordofan and Blue Nile, southern states along the border with South Sudan. Fighting broke out in the two areas in June 2011, when fighters once allied with rebels in South Sudan refused to disarm.

title: Avery Fisher Hall, in Search of a New Name
Coal Rush in India Could Tip Balance on Climate Change
description: DHANBAD, India  Decades of strip mining have left this town in the heart of Indias coal fields a fiery moonscape, with mountains of black slag, sulfurous air and sickened residents.

title: Clean Mining a Deception in Kentucky, Groups Say
description: In a state where coal-country creeks run red with iron, Frasure Creek Mining has been unusually clean of late: Amid tens of thousands of measurements that it submitted to Kentucky regulators in 2013 and early 2014, fewer than 400 exceeded the states limits for water pollution from coal-mine runoff.

title: A Nobel Laureates View of a Senators Energy Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: Electronic Health Records: How Systems Share
description: To the Editor:

title: Landrieu Tries to Gather Enough Votes on Keystone Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Mary L. Landrieu of Louisiana continued to work on Tuesday to round up votes for the Keystone XL oil pipeline, part of a last-minute effort to help her survive a close runoff and one of the toughest battles of her political career.

title: Blue Jays Stake Future on Former Yankee
description: The Yankees had good intentions after the 2012 season, vowing to cut back on long-term contracts and move forward without a bloated payroll and heavy taxes. One of the sacrifices was catcher Russell Martin.

title: Inspired by Airlines, Hotels Increase Fees
description: IN recent years, the airline industry has generated billions in revenue by charging fees on top of base fares. Now the hotel industry seems to be having the same idea.

title: Putin Plays Hardball
description: This week marks the fifth anniversary of Sergei Magnitskys death in a Russian prison. He was 37 years old, a member of the emerging middle class who worked as a lawyer for a man named Bill Browder, the leader of the largest Russia-only investment firm in the world. Browders company, Hermitage Capital Management, started with $25 million during the Wild West-era of early Russian capitalism and had $4.5 billion in assets by the early 2000s.

title: Ackman Has Luck of a Loser, to the Tune of $2.2 Billion
description: Heads he wins. Tails he wins.

title: Small Airports: The Scourge of a Seasoned World Traveler
description: I GREW UP in Rochester, and I started flying when I was about 1. My parents were born in India and came to the United States with a suitcase and $60 in cash. Its a typical immigrant story, and once they got settled and started working, they would save money to make a trip back to India to see family.

title: Obama in Winter
description: They say failure can be a good teacher, but, so far, the Obama administration is opting out of the course. The post-midterm period has been one of the most bizarre of the Obama presidency. President Obama has racked up some impressive foreign-policy accomplishments, but, domestically and politically, things are off the rails.

title: Setback in Atlantic City for Man Hoping to Save Parents Home
description: Charlie Birnbaum will have to go to a higher court to defend his parents home in Atlantic City, which he wanted to keep as something of a shrine.

title: President of Colombia Halts Peace Talks With Rebels After General Is Seized
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  In the first major setback in peace talks intended to end 50 years of guerrilla warfare, President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia on Monday suspended negotiations with the countrys main rebel group and accused it of taking an army general and two other people captive.

title: Bill Frenzel, Key Voice on Economics in House, Dies at 86
description: WASHINGTON  Bill Frenzel, a longtime Republican member of the House of Representatives from Minnesota who was a leading voice, respected by both parties, on trade, tax and budget policy while never serving in the majority, died on Monday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 86.

title: Miss Honduras Is Target of Search
description: MEXICO CITY  The police in Honduras said Monday that they were intensifying their search for Miss Honduras, Mara Jos Alvarado, 19, who has been missing since Thursday, along with her sister Sofa, 23.

title: M.T.A. Issues Plans on Higher Fares and Tolls
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority released its proposals on Monday for higher fares and tolls and began its campaign to win over riders and drivers skeptical of what are now routine increases.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 17, 2014
North Korea Acts to Stop U.N. Resolution on Rights
description: Worried about a looming United Nations vote on human rights that could possibly lead to criminal charges  or at least acute humiliation  North Korea has countered in recent weeks with an unusually robust mix of diplomacy, denials and threats.

title: Mega-Mergers Popular Again on Wall Street
description: Stocks are surging, corporate executives are ambitious and debt is cheap. The result is one of the biggest booms ever in mergers and acquisitions.

title: Timeline: A Rocky Path to Allergans Deal
description: A timeline of the events that led to Allergans agreement to be acquired by Actavis in the face of a hostile takeover.

title: Gotham Recap: Exploding Cash, Unmasking Moles
description: Season 1, Episode 9, Harvey Dent

title: FIFAs Farcically Shady Behavior
description: When FIFA, the group that oversees international soccer, published a summary of an investigative report on Thursday largely clearing Russia and Qatar of corruption in their bids to host the 2018 and 2022 World Cup tournaments, it said it welcomed the fact that a degree of closure has been reached. That statement turns out to have been as specious as the summary itself. Far from resolving anything, it has led soccer elites, including the leader of a European league, to attack FIFAs credibility and consider quitting the organization.

title: Colombian Peace Process at an Impasse
description: Peace talks between the Colombian government and the countrys main rebel group came to an abrupt halt on Sunday when President Juan Manuel Santos suspended the process in response to the mysterious abduction of a senior army general.

title: M&C Saatchi Buys a Stake in SS&K
description: THERE may not be a saying that advises: If at first you dont succeed, try, try advertising. But if there were, the executives of M&C Saatchi might qualify as fervent believers. After two unsuccessful tries by the London-based agency to crack the competitive New York market, M&C Saatchi is buying a minority stake in a successful New York shop, SS&K, which will serve as the M&C Saatchi outpost there.

title: Four Questions About the Four-Team College Football Playoff
description: The 12-member committee charged with determining the four teams to make the first College Football Playoff will release its latest rankings Tuesday. It will then release two others, on Nov. 25 and Dec. 2, before the final rankings, on Dec. 7  which are the only ones that truly matter.

title: Reverently and Defiantly, Czechs Honor Velvet Revolutions Anniversary
description: PRAGUE  Marta Kubisova sat in a small back room of the cafe at the Lucerna Cinema, pulled a skinny cigarette from a silver case and rattled a long strand of pearls as she remembered the Velvet Revolution.

title: The Impolitic Jonathan Gruber
description: Jonathan Gruber, a health economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, is a strong supporter of health care reform. But his careless comments at academic forums last year, caught on videotapes that surfaced recently, can only harm the reform cause. Mr. Gruber said in one comment that the Affordable Care Act relied on a lack of transparency and the stupidity of the American voter to gain passage. He said in another comment that the Cadillac tax on expensive employer-provided health insurance passed only because voters were too stupid to understand it.

title: Intersection | Hoboken, N.J.
description: Born and raised in Hoboken, Caitilin Gallagher, a buyer at Eileen Fisher, says she likes to shop for special pieces that make her feel good.

title: A Crucial Vote on the Surveillance Bill
description: The Republican Party is so badly fractured that it is impossible to tell what steps it will take on domestic surveillance once it assumes control of Congress in January. Its rising libertarian wing wants to crack down on abuses of Americans privacy, but many of its leaders express full support for any action the intelligence agencies want to take.

title: Dont Let Those Neat Uniforms Fool You
description: Something is seriously wrong with the characters in Punk Rock, Simon Stephenss tender, ferocious and frightening play at the Lucille Lortel Theater. They wear their nerves dangerously close to the skin, and their moods swing unhinged. They think of themselves as the best and the worst of all possible beings. And almost all the time, they hurt, in both the active and passive senses of the word.

title: United by Life, Divided by Dreams
description: Being a freak is virtually the new normal, so the timing couldnt be better for the thrilling Broadway revival of Side Show that blazed open Monday night at the St. James Theater. The musical by Bill Russell and Henry Krieger, about conjoined twins searching for love and fame, or maybe just a half-measure of happiness, seems eerily appropriate for an era in which oddballs, outliers and anybody with a desperate need for the spotlight  and a way with a webcam  can achieve celebrity of some kind.

title: Piece of Cake
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  I began my workweek feeling very special. Unless youre a physician, there really arent that many jobs where the first word you encounter on a Monday morning is ANAL. But there it is, at 1 Across. Happy Monday, everyone!

title: Sleepy Hollow Recap: My Mama, the Ghost
description: Sleepy Hollow, Season 2, Episode 9: Mama

title: East Ramapo School Board Is Criticized by New York State Monitor
description: A monitor appointed by the state to investigate the East Ramapo School District in Rockland County delivered a sharply critical report on Monday, saying the board had shown favoritism to the Orthodox Jewish students who attend private schools in the district and calling on the Legislature to give the district additional money while overhauling its governance.

title: Berlin After the Wall: A Microcosm of the Worlds Chaotic Change
description: BERLIN  Not far from the Brandenburg Gate, Potsdamer Platz was a no mans land during the Cold War. Then the Berlin Wall fell, and the German authorities made it a petting zoo for celebrity architecture. The corporate headquarters of Germanys new global swagger.

title: The Custodian of the Song in His Heart
description: As a toddler in Rockville Centre, on Long Island, Ted Karadenes monitored the pulse of the grown-up parties his parents often hosted at home. When things got too quiet he looked for something tall, like a chair, clambered up and broke into song.

title: Delusions Led to 2 Killings, Psychologist Says at Trial
description: A naked man who fatally stabbed two of his neighbors and wounded two others in Manhattan believed he was a character from the movie The Matrix, and was under the delusion he had to save the world, a psychologist testified on Monday.

title: P.R. Firm Urges TransCanada to Target Opponents of Its Energy East Pipeline
description: OTTAWA  The advice from a top American public relations firm was simple: A Canadian pipeline company should take aim at its opposition.

title: A Little Help Amid the First Hints of Winter
description: New York Cares began its 26th annual coat drive on Monday as temperatures dipped into the 40s. Coats will be collected through December at the Bowery Mission on the Lower East Side.

title: Facing Three Former Teammates, Rangers Flail in Loss to Lightning
description: The teams knew emotions would run high.

title: Farewell to Elaine Stritch, the Lady Who Lunched Like No Other
description: The theater community braved a seemingly endless downpour on Monday to celebrate the singular performer Elaine Stritch, who died in July at 89 after a career that spanned more than 60 years, many of them spent onstage, where she felt most at home, whether in New York or in London or on tour.

title: A Forest Threatened by Keystone XL
description: CALGARY, Alberta

title: In Sea of New Faces, Nets Run Aground Against the Heat
description: The last meeting between the Nets and the Miami Heat finished with LeBron James posturing on the scorers table at American Airlines Arena, pounding his chest, celebrating another playoff series win on another trip to the N.B.A. finals.

title: Push in U.N. to Intercept Jihadists Oil
description: A United Nations panel has urged the Security Council to order all countries to seize oil trucks coming in and out of territory controlled by jihadists in Iraq and Syria and to impose a global moratorium on the sale of antiquities from the two countries.

title: Giants Seek to Revitalize Moribund Running Game
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Eli Manning stood at his locker Monday and spoke of how restlessly he slept after tying his career high with five interceptions in the Giants 16-10 loss to the San Francisco 49ers on Sunday.

title: Man Arrested in Connection With Manhattan Jewelry Store Robbery
description: The police have arrested a man in connection with the midday robbery last week of a jewelry store in Manhattans diamond district, and they were searching for two other suspects who were involved.

title: A.E.G. to Bring Its Music Festivals to AXS TV
description: A.E.G., one of the worlds biggest concert promoters, has a portfolio of popular music festivals including Coachella and the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. It also owns a stake in AXS TV, a fledgling cable television channel trying to establish itself in a crowded market.

title: Sites Are Set For N.C.A.A.s
description: Brooklyn and Des Moines will host N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament games for the first time in 2016, and Madison Square Garden will again host a regional during the 2017 tournament.

title: Word of the Day | amalgamate
description: amalgamate \-mal-g-mat\ verb

title: Honda to Replace Airbags Throughout U.S.
description: Honda will replace potentially defective airbag inflaters in cars nationwide, according to statements the automaker gave federal safety regulators earlier this month. In doing so, it bows to pressure from lawmakers and auto safety experts who had questioned automakers limiting of the latest airbag recalls to high-humidity regions.

title: Uber Executives Comments Leave Company Scrambling
description: Emil Michael is responsible for many high-profile business partnerships struck by Uber, the popular ride-hailing start-up, and he has engineered some of the companys publicity stunts.

title: What Bourbon Producers Can Teach the Oil Industry
description: The market for crude oil is in veritable free fall. The price of a barrel has dropped 30 percent since June, and the ripples have only begun, with analysts warning of everything from bankruptcies of Texas oil fields to economic troubles in big oil-producing nations like Venezuela and Nigeria.

title: Whats On TV Tuesday
description: 10 P.M. (ANIMAL PLANET) SAVING AFRICAS GIANTS WITH YAO MING The graphic images of mutilated animals are heartbreaking. So are the statistics  only six northern white rhinos left in the world (a seventh died last month), their horns believed by some cultures to contain medicinal properties; more than 20,000 African elephants killed in 2013 for ivory to be carved into trinkets. In an effort to curb Chinas multibillion-dollar lust for illegal wildlife products, WildAid has named the former basketball star Yao Ming as a spokesman for Africas severely threatened elephants and other wildlife. This special follows Mr. Yao, above, to the Samburu National Reserve in Kenya and the Kariega Game Reserve in South Africa to witness the brutality poachers inflict on these animals. As Mr. Yao states in a public-service announcement, When the buying stops, the killing can too.

title: Suicide Attack in Afghan Capital Kills 2
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide attack targeted a base for foreign contract workers in Kabul on Tuesday morning, killing at least two security guards, the authorities said.

title: Israel Shaken by 5 Deaths in Synagogue Assault
description: JERUSALEM  The Orthodox Jewish men were facing east, to honor the Old City site where the ancient temples once stood, when two Palestinians armed with a gun, knives and axes burst into their synagogue Tuesday morning, shouting God is great! in Arabic. Within moments, three rabbis and a fourth pious man lay dead, blood pooling on their prayer shawls and holy books.

title: Corrections: November 18, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Theyre just taking away everyday freedoms, little by little. This isnt about tobacco, its about control.

title: Umbrellas Come Out at Hong Kong Graduation Ceremonies
description: Prof. Albert Chan, president of Hong Kong Baptist University, told graduates on Monday to start small, but dream big and use all available opportunities to pursue their passions.

title: A Road Test of Alternative Fuel Visions
description: LOS ANGELES  Remember the hydrogen car?

title: Polaroid Photographers Plead Their Case
description: Five photographers who regularly shoot with Polaroid instant cameras and film explain their hopes for a revival of Polaroid film by a company in the Netherlands.

title: Building a Nuclear Deal With Iran
description: Will the Nov. 24 deadline for an agreement be met? Or will the process collapse?

title: EasyJet Profit Climbs as Battle for Business Passengers Intensifies
description: PARIS  With Europes economic slump threatening to further crimp company budgets, the battle for business travelers is growing ever more heated among the regions airlines.

title: 6 Qs About the News | Teaching Civilized Dissent, Regardless of Background
description: In Teaching Civilized Dissent, Regardless of Background, Alan Schwarz writes about a recent debate tournament in the New York region.

title: Test Yourself | Quitting His Job to Hit the Road With the Knicks
description: Below are the first 10 paragraphs of the Nov. 15 article Living Out Knicks Dream, Complete With Nightmares.

title: Auto Sales in Europe Rise for 14th Consecutive Month
description: PARIS  European auto sales kept their momentum in October, industry data showed on Tuesday, growing for a 14th straight month from their nadir last year.

title: How Disney Turned Frozen Into a Cash Cow
description: The Patriot Center at George Mason University, half an hour west of Washington, is a popular place to watch concerts, college athletics, professional wrestling and other events that command the attention of the adult world. But no event in the 29-year history of the arena has attracted as many people or earned as much money as last months performances of Disney on Ice Presents Frozen.  For six days, waves of little blue-and-white Princess Elsas  and quite a few costumed parents  sang the movies hit song, Let It Go, at the top of their lungs, enjoyed $15 snow cones, posed for $25 pictures with cardboard cutouts and waved plastic sticks, which had miraculously become $28 magic wands.

title: The Dark Side of Zootopia
description: Its near closing time, but youre safely ensconced within a mirrored glass bubble, wafting above the wilds of America. A pair of grizzlies, directly below, gaze up at their reflections on your rides mute and fleeting surface as the late-afternoon sunlight casts long shadows across the third and final themed continent of the day. Asia is already but a faint early-morning memory, a quick flight of steps down off the central plaza to the mouth of the nameless river that gently winds past padding tigers, bamboo panda cottages and the nearly touchable legs of wading elephants. Africa  after a quick cafe lunch back at the plaza  you chose to traverse by foot, allowing you the illusion of mingling with the lions, gorillas, zebras and treetop-grazing giraffes.

title: What Are the Best Teaching Methods for Getting Students to Behave Well in Class?
description: Have you ever been in a class where all the students were focused and engaged? And the class seemed to run perfectly? Or have you experienced the opposite  where most students were misbehaving or, at the very least, distracted? Why do students behave in one teachers class  but then misbehave in anothers?

title: An Insiders Look Before They Were Hip-Hop Stars
description: The sharp features and bedroom eyes are eminently familiar. But the sun-dappled portrait of Snoop Dogg Lisa Leone took in 1993 surprises. The rapper appears not just young  this was just before the release of his first solo album  but soft.

title: Premiere of Hunger Games Film Postponed in China
description: The Chinese release date for The Hunger Games: Mockingjay  Part 1 has been pushed back to early next year. The film, which had its world premiere in London on Nov. 10, was originally scheduled to hit theaters in China on Friday, the same day as its premiere in several other countries, including the United States.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Prolific Shooter Aims Higher
description: Since scoring 78 points and drilling 20 3-pointers in his first two games with the Reno Bighorns of the N.B.A. Development League, Brady Heslip has tried to move on. By going to practice. By watching episodes of The Walking Dead with his teammate David Stockton.

title: New York Today: Thanksgiving Patterns
description: Good morning on this incredibly cold Tuesday.

title: Deaths Linked to Terrorism Are Up 60 Percent, Study Finds
description: LONDON  As Western governments grapple with heightened apprehension about the spread of Islamic militancy, an independent study on Tuesday offered little solace, saying the number of fatalities related to terrorism soared 60 percent last year.

title: Thailand Is Searching for Scores of Uighurs Who Fled China
description: BEIJING  The Thai authorities said Tuesday that they were searching for about 120 ethnic Uighurs who fled China and were detained in southern Thailand by the police earlier this year but escaped this month from a shelter there.

title: What Democracy Means in China Is Not What Australias Abbott Thinks
description: An evening that should have capped a day of triumph for Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia resulted in awkwardness when he mistakenly praised President Xi Jinping of China for a commitment to democracy that Mr. Xi never made.

title: Calling Early Elections in Japan, Abe Rolls the Dice on the Economy
description: IWAKUNI, Japan  When his popularity was soaring at home, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared in Washington a year ago, Japan is back.

title: With New Tablet, Nokia Returns to Devices
description: LONDON  Nokia is getting back into the device business.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 11-17, 2014
description: Have you been following the news?

title: Daily Report: TRUSTe, Web Privacy Certifier, Is Penalized by F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission on Monday penalized TRUSTe, a company that certifies websites for compliance with various privacy standards, saying it had deceived consumers about its recertification program and allowed itself to be falsely portrayed as a nonprofit corporation, Edward Wyatt reports.

title: Am I Too Important to Do Real Work?
description: In my post last week, I explained why I decided not to lay off people at my parts-finishing business  even though the inevitable result is that we are going to have some red ink.

title: Today in Politics
description: With Snowden Long Gone, Senate Examines Domestic Spying Again

title: How the Great Wage Slowdown Hurts Democrats
description: Its a simple rule: A weak economy makes for an unpopular president. President Obama is on course to become the fourth president of the last six to leave office with an approval rating well below 50 percent. Each of the previous three  both Bushes and Jimmy Carter  also had something else in common: Median family income fell during their presidencies.

title: Morning Agenda: Return of the Mega-Merger
description: RETURN OF THE MEGA-MERGER | Mega-mergers are back. Mergers worth $100 billion, made on Monday, put Wall Street on pace for a year of deal-making rivaling those during the dot-com bubble and the private equity upsurge just before the financial crisis, DealBooks David Gelles writes. The announcement of two mega-deals  Actaviss $66 billion acquisition of the Botox maker Allergan and Halliburtons $34.6 billion takeover of the oil field services firm Baker Hughes  made Monday a symbolic tipping point, Mr. Gelles writes. With those transactions, about $1.5 trillion in deals targeting United States companies have been announced this year, the most since 2000, according to Thomson Reuters.

title: Solange Knowles, Amal Clooney and the Return of the Wedding Trousseau
description: Solange Knowless much-ballyhooed wedding on Sunday heralded the advent of what will probably be numerous fashion trends: capes, all-white bridesmaid ensembles and so on. But the one that I think may really take hold is the return of the wedding trousseau. No longer is one great bridal dress enough. Now a major nuptial event demands many.

title: Rome Operas Management and Musicians Agree to End Standoff
description: Backing away from its proposal to fire 182 musicians and hire them back as freelancers, the management of the Rome Opera announced on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement with the musicians that would keep them on staff in exchange for pay cuts and a pledge not to go on strike.

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: We Are Penn State
description: At a bronze statue of Joe Paterno, the former Penn State football coach, a critic and fans spar over his legacy.

title: In Performance: Alysha Umphress of On the Town
description: This weeks video features the actress Alysha Umphress and the pianist Brett Rowe performing the number I Can Cook, Too from the Broadway revival of On the Town, the 1944 musical with music by Leonard Bernstein, and book and lyrics by Betty Comden and Adolph Green. In this jazzy song, Hildy (Ms. Umphress), a New York City cab driver, boasts to a sailor about her prowess in the, um, kitchen. My gravy will lose you your mind, she sings. The show, directed by John Rando, is at the Lyric Theater.

title: Brooklyn, Planet Earth
description: Whats next? Describing Manaus as the Williamsburg of the Amazon? Katmandu as the Cobble Hill of Nepal?

title: We Are Penn State
description: On July 12, 2012, the former F.B.I. director, Louis Freeh, issued a report on the Penn State child sex abuse scandal that pinned blame on much more than a football team: University leadership, the town itself and, most controversially, Penn States legendary football coach, Joe Paterno, were all implicated. That morning, we were at Penn State filming our feature documentary about the scandal, Happy Valley.

title: Home Depot Posts a Strong 3rd Quarter Despite a Data Breach Disclosure
description: Home Depot, the countrys largest home-improvement retailer, booked robust gains in sales and profit in its third quarter, as a brightening economic picture spurred more people to buy homes and renovate them.

title: A City Girl Confronts Country Silence
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Daily Gift: Margielas Luxe Leather Bookmark
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: A Deadly Attack in Israel
description: Four people died in a bloody assault on a synagogue in West Jerusalem on Tuesday.

title: Asia Pushes Hard for Clean Energy
description: LONDON  Even as Chinas economy begins to cool, its hunger for energy is still climbing.

title: Goodell Bars Peterson for Rest of Season and Says He Could Miss Games in 2015
description: The N.F.L. has suspended Adrian Peterson, the Minnesota Vikings star running back, for at least the remainder of the season without pay, the league announced Tuesday, two weeks after he pleaded no contest to hitting his child.

title: Should You Pack Your Childs Lunch?
description: We often hear thatmaking meals at home is the healthiest way to eat (so often, in fact, that theres been a backlash). But new research suggests that lunches at school cafeterias may actually be healthier than the ones parents pack for their kids. And the results may have larger implications for how families eat.

title: Its a Light Green Lifestyle
description: Jen Boulden was a serial start-up entrepreneur before she decided to go back to school for a masters degree in  environmental policy and management at George Washington University, in 2004. That same year, she co-founded a daily green-lifestyle email subscription service, Ideal Bite, sold four years later to Disney with 318,000 daily subscribers, for $20 million. Ms. Boulden remained with the venture, overseeing its growth to more than 500,000 daily subscribers until Disney shut it down in 2010. She then started JenB TV, a green lifestyle website on which she posts  advice weekly.

title: Emissions Loophole Stays Open in E.U.
description: MADRID  The European Union agreed last month to keep open until 2030 a loophole allowing some of its biggest atmospheric polluters to avoid bearing an increasing share of the costs of cutting global-warming emissions.

title: Growing Coral to Keep a Sea Claim Above Water
description: TOKYO  Amid warnings that rising sea levels caused by global warming could lead to the disappearance of some entire island states, two tiny uninhabited islets in the Pacific are at the forefront of Japanese research into the preservation and regeneration of coral reefs.

title: Attack on Jerusalem Synagogue
description: Four people were killed while worshiping in a synagogue in an ultra-Orthodox neighborhood in West Jerusalem on Tuesday. Police said the two Palestinian attackers were killed.

title: Indonesias Central Bank Raises Benchmark Interest Rate as Gas Prices Jump
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Responding to the first major policy move of Indonesias new president, which sent gasoline prices up 30 percent on Tuesday, the countrys central bank held an unscheduled meeting and increased its benchmark interest rate in an effort to combat inflation.

title: Holding Back the Sahara
description: WIDOU THIENGOLY, Senegal  Old people in Widou Thiengoly say they can remember when there were so many trees that you couldnt see the sky.

title: The Circular Economy of Recycled Paper
description: ROERMOND, The Netherlands  Three times a week, tanker trucks make an hourlong journey from a baby-food factory in Nunspeet, in the central Netherlands, to a paper mill in the southeastern city of Roermond.

title: How Has the Social Role of Poetry Changed Since Shelley?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. Shelley once called poets the unacknowledged legislators of the world. This week, Adam Kirsch and Leslie Jamison discuss how the social role of poetry has changed since then.

title: As Sharpton Rose, So Did His Unpaid Taxes
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton, who came to prominence as an imposing figure in a track suit, shouting indignantly at the powerful, stood quietly on a stage last month at the Four Seasons restaurant, his now slender frame wrapped in a finely tailored suit, as men in power lined up to exclaim their admiration for him.

title: In 2019 World Track Championships, Qatar Adds Second Sports Jewel
description: The tiny, wealthy Persian Gulf nation Qatar was awarded another major global sporting event Tuesday as track and fields world governing body shrugged off recent controversy and chose Doha as the host city of the 2019 world championships.

title: Democrats, by Acclamation, Retain Pelosi as Leader
description: House Democrats on Tuesday elected Representative Nancy Pelosi of California to serve as minority leader for another two years.

title: Chris Algieri, a Boxer from Long Island, Says Hes Set for Manny Pacquiao
description: Chris Algieris rise from unknown boxer to a champion worthy of fighting the superstar Manny Pacquiao on Saturday in Macau began when he saw another boxer beaten nearly to death.

title: 1939: Veterans Miss Fox Hunts
description: LONDON  This war does not measure up to the last one from the sportsmans point of view, in the opinion of British veterans who are again serving at the front.

title: The Floating Gardens of Bangladesh
description: CHARBHANGURA, Bangladesh  Each year the brown waters of the Gumani river swell during the summer monsoon, creeping over the surrounding fields to flood Charbhangura, a village of 2,500 people in the Pabna district of northwest Bangladesh.

title: Abu Dhabi Energy Company Aims for Solar-Powered Travel
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Masdar, Abu Dhabis renewable energy company, is hosting the first attempt at a round-the-world flight by a solar-powered aircraft, due to start from the emirate in March.

title: Japanese Premier Calls for Elections
description: Shinzo Abe, the Japanese prime minister, called for early elections to seek a new mandate on his economic policies after data showed the country falling into recession.

title: First Draft Focus: Say Freeze!
French Doggie Bags? The Backstory
description: The doggie bag is coming to France. Aurelien Breeden looked into a campaign, aimed at curbing food waste, that encourages the French to take home their leftovers. For the French, who rarely ask to carry out food that they havent finished (though they may ask to take home an unfinished bottle of wine), the doggie bag is associated with being cheap. Can it shake the stigma and catch on? Mr. Breeden thinks it may be too soon to tell.

title: Debbie Harry to Sing at Caf Carlyle
description: Its not your grandfathers cabaret series. The lineup announced Tuesday by the Caf Carlyle includes short residencies by several singers whose recordings once climbed the rock, R&B and pop charts, including Debbie Harry, best known as the singer of the punk-era band Blondie following in the footsteps of the New York Dolls frontman, David Johansen (in his Buster Poindexter persona), who sang at the Carlyle in October.

title: In Immigration Fight, Republicans Explore Alternatives to a Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  Americans for Prosperity, a group founded by the billionaire Koch brothers, has held informal conversations with Republican lawmakers on Capitol Hill in recent weeks, cautioning them against fighting President Obamas promised executive order on immigration with a strategy that could lead to a government shutdown.

title: Man Charged With Fatal Shoving of New York Subway Rider
description: A man was charged late Tuesday in the fatal shoving of a subway rider in the Bronx after he was taken into custody earlier in the day in a separate assault at a Manhattan subway station this month, the police said.

title: Hey Guys, the Russians Arent Buying Pabst After All
description: Remember in September when it was announced that Oasis Beverages had acquired the Pabst Brewing Company? Well, it turns out that never happened.

title: Ariel Pink on Gender-Bending, His Aversion to Suits and the Pleasures of Red Clogs
description: Ariel Pink, the famously unfiltered L.A.-based purveyor of eccentric, ironic indie pop, has been in rare form of late. Advance tracks from his new record, Pom Pom, which came out yesterday on 4AD, have been well received, as have his live shows, two ingenious Grant Singer-directed music videos and a visit to Staten Islands pint-size PS22 Chorus. But Pink has also managed to upset feminists, Eurythmics fans and supporters of late-period Madonna (including Grimes), thanks to choice remarks in interviews. If theres no such thing as bad publicity, then Pom Pom is the album of the year.

title: To McConnell, Its the Cassidy Keystone Bill
description: Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader of the Senate, does not want Democrats to claim all the credit if a bill to build the Keystone XL oil pipelinemoves forward.

title: Hes Gone. A Daddy, Deployed
description: The distinct pitter-patter of her 3-year-old feet on our weathered hardwood floor awakens me. The sun is still hidden from the horizon, and any other morning I would pull her into my bed in the dark silence, with the intention of us both catching a little more sleep. Instead, today she looks at the empty pillow next to me, and with heavy sadness in her eyes, only offers, Hes gone. Two little words for one little girl  half statement, half question  hoping the outcome has changed overnight, from a month at sea to just a normal day at work.

title: Shutdown Politics Makes Some Republicans Wary
description: Republican leaders have made clear that all options are on the table when it comes to deterring President Obama from using his executive powers for an immigration overhaul.

title: Andrew M. Cuomos All Things Possible
description: The origins of Andrew M. Cuomos new political memoir are as revealing as anything contained within its pages. In 2012, 16 successful months into the governors first term, an Albany columnist for The New York Post set out to write a Cuomo biography, and Cuomo agreed to cooperate. But his relationship with The Post subsequently soured, and last year he announced he would be writing his own book  for the same publisher, which has since backed away from the first book.

title: Pier A Harbor House Opens Downtown
description: Headliner

title: 1964: Italy Ousts Two U.A.R. Envoys
description: ROMEThe Italian government today [Nov. 18] expelled two United Arab Republic diplomats caught trying to ship a bound, drugged prisoner to Cairo in a trunk labeled diplomatic mail. Italian police said the crated man, 28-year-old Josef Dahan, had worked as a spy first for the U.A.R. government and later for Israel. They said that Mr. Dahan, a Moroccan-born linguist, was an Israeli citizen. [In Jerusalem, police said Mr. Dahan is an Israeli defector with a criminal record. They said his real name was Mordecai ben Masuud Louk and that he had defected to Egypt in 1961. They denied that he had ever spied for Israel. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 19, 1964

title: Landrieu Calls Ad for Her Challenger Sexist and Ageist
description: With the midterm election two weeks in the rearview mirror, it may seem that the time for pointed campaign ads has passed. But election season remains in full swing in Louisiana, where Senator Mary L. Landrieu is making a final push to keep her seat in a December runoff.

title: Collecting Debts on Dubious  Foreclosures
description: In early 2012, when five big banks settled with government officials over foreclosure abuses in the housing bust, the settlement sum, $26 billion, was actually a small price for the banks to pay. It was small compared to the economic damage from the banks reckless lending and abusive foreclosures. And it was small compared to what the banks got in return.

title: U.S. Agencies Review Policy on Hostages
description: The Obama administration confirmed on Tuesday that it was reviewing its policy on securing the release of United States citizens taken hostage abroad, but that the ban on paying ransom would not change.

title: Two Approaches on Expiring Tax Breaks
description: How the Senate and the House have been addressing nearly 60 tax breaks and other rules that are set to expire at the end of the year.

title: Heart Drug, Losartan, Falls Short of Promise in a Study
