description: The idea seemed compelling: A blood pressure drug was found to block the effects of a gene mutation that causes Marfan syndrome, a condition that leads to terrible heart problems. The drug worked in mice with a gene that causes Marfan, doing just what everyone hoped it would do. A pilot study with 17 children showed the drug seemed to work in them, too, although there was no group that, for comparison, did not get the drug.

title: Carl Sanders, 89, Dies; Led Georgia in 60s
description: Carl E. Sanders, who as a young Democratic governor of Georgia in the mid-1960s helped spur Atlantas growth while taking what for a white politician in the South were progressive stances on race and segregation, earning him a reputation as an early leader of the New South, died on Sunday in Atlanta. He was 89.

title: Time Runs Out for Rock of Ages
description: Rock of Ages, the jukebox musical that was built on guitar-driven 1980s hair-band hits and that became a long-running Broadway hit, will play its final performance on Jan. 18, its producers announced Tuesday. The show will by then have played 2,328 Broadway performances (and 22 previews), first at the Brooks Atkinson Theater, where it opened in 2009, and then at the Helen Hayes Theater, to which it transferred in 2011.

title: Its Crunch Time in Congress for Tax Breaks
description: WASHINGTON  The Georgia Aquarium is hardly a showcase in Atlanta urban renewal. The largest marine exhibit in the United States sits near the World of Coca-Cola museum, CNN headquarters, the citys lavish sports stadiums and its famed Centennial Olympic Park  an area more playground than poverty-stricken.

title: Sony Executive Is Cautious as Music Streaming Grows
description: Taylor Swifts feud with Spotify continues to reverberate throughout the music industry, with a top Sony executive questioning the value of free music as streaming services grow around the world.

title: President Named for Lucas Museum in Chicago
description: Headed from one kind of American-themed, billionaire-founded museum to another, Don Bacigalupi, president of the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark., will become the founding president of the museum that the director George Lucas is planning for Chicagos lakefront.

title: First Draft Focus: From the Heart
Michael Gennaro Will Head Goodspeed Musicals
description: For 46 years, Goodspeed Musicals has been synonymous with Michael Price, who is known for keeping a vintage barber chair in his office and standing at the foot of the grand staircase at the end of performances to personally greet departing patrons after musicals like Little Johnny Jones, Going Up and Annie  which originated there.

title: Organic Farms Become a Winner in Putins Feud With the West
description: MOSCOW  Boris Akimovs cellphone, which quacks like a duck, started to sound like a whole flock soon after President Vladimir V. Putin imposed sweeping food sanctions barring many Western imports last August.

title: The Flaws in Valeants Activist Deal Effort
description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals has tried a seven-month M.&A. experiment that its boss, J. Michael Pearson  and other corporate chiefs  should think twice about repeating.

title: Today in Small Business: Unrealistic Value Expectations
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

title: Model Railroad Builders Win Auction, but Must Raise Money to Pay the Tab
description: POTTERSVILLE, N.Y.  You could forgive Clarke Dunham if the events of the last few months have him feeling as if he were a character in a Frank Capra movie  special dispensation, naturally, accorded to anyone who calls Pottersville home.

title: Thanksgiving Recipes Across the United States
description: Weve scoured the nation for recipes that evoke each of the 50 states (and D.C. and Puerto Rico). These are our picks for the feast. Dig in, then tell us yours.

title: Bill to Restrict N.S.A. Data Collection Blocked in Vote by Senate Republicans
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans on Tuesday blocked a sweeping overhaul of the once-secret National Security Agency program that collects records of Americans phone calls in bulk.

title: Key Republican Votes to Watch on N.S.A. Overhaul
description: As the Senate heads toward an important procedural vote this evening on a proposed National Security Agency overhaul, backers of the measure are working to line up Republican supporters to break the 60-vote threshold.

title: Voter ID Laws Scrutinized for Impact on Midterms
description: In North Carolina, early voting was cut by seven days. In Kansas, 22,000 people were stopped from registering to vote because they lacked proof of citizenship. And in Texas, Democrats say the countrys toughest voter ID law contributed to a one-term congressmans losing a tight race to his Republican rival.

title: Uber Attacks the Press
description: Success appears to have bred arrogance and vindictiveness at Uber. That is the only conclusion to draw from the news that a senior executive at the company said it planned to uncover and spread personal information about journalists who wrote critical articles.

title: The Structure of Obamacare
description: The big revelation of this week has been how many political pundits have spent six years of the Obama administration opining furiously about the administrations signature policy without making the slightest effort to understand how it works. Theyre amazed and in denial at the suggestion that it has the same structure as Romneycare, which has been obvious and explicit all along; they are shocked, shocked to learn that it uses the mandate as an alternative to taxing and spending, which has always been completely obvious and open.

title: Thanksgiving Office Hours: Ask All Your Questions
description: The phones are ringing here in our offices, our email servers straining, our social-media accounts pinging or going beep: panicky readers, spouses, cousins, sources, friends. Can you buy parsley in Telluride on Thanksgiving morning? A family of five just invited themselves to dinner, and were up to 22 for the meal  can we say no? Do you have a recipe for venison, since my sister just got her first buck and wants me to cook some for the feast? How can we help others while celebrating our own bounty? Should we play music during the meal? What wines should we drink? And how do you make kuchen, anyway?

title: Shubert Organization Taking Over New World Stages
description: The Shubert Organization, which owns 17 of Broadways 40 theaters, has completed a deal to take over New World Stages, the Off Broadway complex with five small theaters that could now become home to Shubert-related projects, leaders of the organization announced Tuesday. The terms were not disclosed, but theater executives familiar with the negotiations said that acquiring the lease from its current holder, the European producer Stage Entertainment, was a seven-figure deal. The current productions at New World Stages will continue to run.

title: Philadelphia Casino Project Adds to Frenzy in Northeast Gambling Market
description: A $425 million project with a casino and a boutique hotel rising in the stadium district of Philadelphia is the latest entrant into the tumultuous world of East Coast gambling.

title: The Editors Daughter, Tempered by Homelessness, Picks Up Her Pen
description: The English writer Penelope Fitzgerald (1916-2000) didnt publish her first book until she was nearly 60 and wasnt much noticed, at least in the United States, until she was in her 80s. Many found her easy to overlook and easy to condescend to. She tended to comport herself, as Julian Barnes, an admirer of her novels, put it, like some harmless, jam-making grandmother who scarcely knew her way in the world.

title: India Isolates Ebola Survivor at an Airport
description: NEW DELHI  A 26-year-old Indian man who recovered from Ebola was being held at a quarantine facility at the New Delhi airport as a cautionary measure after his semen tested positive for the virus, health officials announced Tuesday.

title: Vamo Start-Up Simplifies Booking of Complex Trips
description: SEATTLE  If you want to fly to Paris or London for a few days, online travel booking sites like Expedia, Orbitz and others have that down pat. The process gets a little more ungainly when a traveler is planning a more complicated trip and wants to know how adding and subtracting destinations will affect price.

title: Choosing Fast and Cheap Over High-End Chic in Yokohama, Japan
description: It was breakfast time in Yokohama Station, a half-hour by train from Tokyo, and I was having some of the best soba noodles of my life. The chewy buckwheat strands were sublime, the broth deeply savory and piping hot. A fresh-cracked egg floated on top, its yolk a gorgeous sunrise orange.

title: Arguing the Church
description: At America Magazine today, theres a very long dialogue between myself and Father James Martin of the Society of Jesus, the prolific author and commentator, that jumps off from my recent, perhaps-slightly-controversial column on Pope Francis and the situation within the Roman Catholic Church. Im very grateful to Father Martin and the editors at America for putting the conversation together, and hopefully our dialogue will be interesting to readers, even if we did not exactly resolve every intra-Catholic division across our 6,000-odd words of back and forth.

title: From the Makers of AnonyWatch, Introducing  The Monocle Meter
description: Ever since I wrote a column early this year about a Times story reporting a supposed monocle trend, people have been sending me their candidates for other stories that deserve a similar shout-out. This goes beyond trends to any Times story whose premise may be dubious or whose qualities of self-parody  intentional or otherwise  induce a certain level of eye rolling.

title: Viber Messages for the World to See
description: Viber built its name  and the foundation for its $900 million takeover by the Japanese retailing giant Rakuten this year  on private messaging and phone calls.

title: In the Hippie Stronghold of Ojai, Calif., a New Design Store for Modern Bohemians
description: If theres a single object that symbolizes the state of things in Ojai, California, it may be the handcrafted, eco-sensitive childrens tepee for sale at In the Field, a new boutique which opened this past weekend. In this picturesque city of 8,000,mindfulness is a long-standing way of life, not a fresh buzzword. But with a growing stream of full- and part-time denizens migrating 90 miles northward from Los Angeles, Ojais cultural atmosphere is also becoming more design-conscious. The latest signal of this shift is the self-described lifestyle store that the actor and interior designer Channon Roe and his wife, the former Ford model and actress Bianca, opened this past Saturday.

title: Deal Tips From Buffett and Berkshires Other Managers
description: Lawrence A. Cunningham, a professor of business law at George Washington University and a former deal lawyer at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, has written numerous business books including, most recently, Berkshire Beyond Buffett: The Enduring Value of Values. This post is excerpted from that book.

title: Former Controller of Medical Nonprofit Is Charged With Embezzling $1.8 Million
description: A former official of the Hereditary Disease Foundation, a New York-based nonprofit group that supports research into genetic illness, has been charged with embezzling more than $1.8 million of the organizations funds and using the money for personal expenses.

title: FIFA Turns Over Report on World Cup Bidding to Swiss
description: Days after declaring that its investigation into the bidding for soccers 2018 and 2022 World Cups had not found any evidence pointing to a corruption of that process, FIFA announced on Tuesday that it was turning over the report from the inquiry to the Swiss authorities because it suspected that its investigators had uncovered criminal activity.

title: Its Best Not to Make Him Angry
description: The mass-murdering title character of Christopher Marlowes Tamburlaine, a man proud to call himself the scourge of God, has never been big on apologies. Not for him the regretful introspection of short-tempered Shakespearean tyrants like Macbeth, Lear or even nasty old Richard III.

title: Jerusalem Synagogue Victim Descended From Storied Dynasty of Hasidic World
description: Rabbi Moshe Twersky, one of the four men killed on Tuesday at a Jerusalem synagogue, was a descendant of one of the oldest Hasidic dynasties of Europe  the Twerskys.

title: WhatsApp Adds Android Encryption
description: Facebooks WhatsApp, the popular messaging app, is getting a security upgrade. WhatsApp messages on Android phones are now encrypted all the way through the transmission process and on their own servers using respected, open-source encryption techniques developed by Open Whisper Systems.

title: Keystone Pipeline Pros, Cons and Steps to a Final Decision
description: Q. What is the Keystone XL pipeline?

title: Regulators Warn Against Reimbursing Employees for Health Premiums
description: Since the implementation of the Affordable Care Act, many small businesses have been intrigued by the possibility that they might be able to stop dealing with health insurance entirely and instead offer their employees a stipend to go buy insurance on the individual exchanges. But in a clarification issued in early November, the federal government appears to have taken a stand against that strategy.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: How Much Did Health Insurance Rates Go Up? Its Complicated
description: Americans could find the new insurance rates for the Affordable Care Act in online marketplaces last week. Prices of many plans went up. But just how much depends on how you measured them.

title: Goldman Sachs Dismisses Trader Linked to Currency Inquiry
description: LONDON  Goldman Sachs has dismissed a currency trader because of his ties to an inquiry into potential manipulation of benchmark currency rates, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

title: Mets Bring In Fences, Again
description: Baseballs Moneyball era has brought drastic changes in how managers handle their pitching staffs and where they position players on the field. Armed with newly revealing statistical analysis, scouts assess players differently, and fans view the game differently.

title: Iraqi Troops Seen Inside Besieged Oil Refinery
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi state television on Tuesday displayed images of triumphant soldiers inside the Baiji refinery, the first confirmation of many previous reports that government forces had broken a siege by the extremists who call themselves the Islamic State.

title: S.E.C.s Delay on Crowdfunding May Just Save It
description: While the Securities and Exchange Commission dawdles, states are rushing to adopt their own crowdfunding rules. Ironically, it may just be the thing that rescues crowdfunding from a regulatory death grip.

title: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Vegan Mac N Cheez
description: Macaroni and cheese casserole is a great standby for a holiday table that includes picky eaters, particularly children. But it is not an option for children who cant tolerate foods with dairy.

title: A Chilling New Music Video From an Up-and-Coming Electronic Artist
description: Bloom is only the second track the 27-year-old Cork, Ireland, native Eoin French has released under his Talos moniker, but its taut, chilling complexity belies his newcomer status. The song is essentially about change and how were all, in a weird way, kind of terrified of it, French says, and the idea of someone changing and morphing into something a lot darker.

title: After a Slow Start, the Rodgers Show Hits Its Stride
description: When an athlete is having an excellent season, it is common for the home fans to break into chants of M.V.P. from time to time. This year, in Green Bay, a five-letter cheer may be more appropriate.

title: In Hong Kong, One-Bedroom Apartments That Could Fit in a Bedroom
description: HONG KONG  There are breathtaking views of Victoria Harbor from a 23rd-floor apartment that recently sold for $722,000 in the new Le Riviera building. The high-end German appliances and marble countertops evoke European luxury. In the entrance of the building, colorful wire mesh sculptures by Spanish artists hang from the ceiling.

title: Landrieu Argues for Keystone Pipeline
description: Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, urges the Senate to pass the Keystone bill by arguing that it will provide energy independence for the country.

title: Texas ID Law Keeps Hundreds of Ballots From Being Counted
description: HOUSTON  Provisional ballots cast by hundreds of voters in Texas on Nov. 4 never became official in the days after the election, part of the little-noticed fallout from the states tough voter ID law.

title: Colombian Forces Search for General Seized by Rebels
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Government troops and airplanes scoured northwestern Colombia searching for Gen. Rubn Daro Alzate on Tuesday, as his capture by guerrillas over the weekend threatened to upend peace talks meant to end a 50-year insurgency.

title: In Test for Premier, Italians Rally Against Plan to Relax Labor Rules
description: ROME  In Naples, demonstrators blocked traffic. In Padua, Pisa and Milan, they clashed with the police. Here, they lobbed eggs at government buildings and climbed to the top of the Colosseum to unfurl a protest banner.

title: AT&T and Starbucks Bring Wireless Phone Chargers to Some Coffee Shops
description: Wireless device charging has been around for years, but most people still stick with old-fashioned cords. Now AT&T and Starbucks are teaming up to try to make this power technology more popular in the mainstream.

title: In Beverly Hills, Three Sisters Open a New One-Stop Beauty Spot
description: Its often been said that Los Angeles is a youth-obsessed kind of place, which may be why the citys hair and makeup experts are sometimes celebrities in their own right. Among this talented pack are the California-born Streicher sisters, who are something of a beauty triumvirate in town, each skilled in a different craft. Theres the older sister Jenn, a makeup artist for regulars like Emily Blunt and Claire Danes. Then theres the middle sibling Kristie, who first trained as a makeup artist but rose to stardom with her signature feathered brow (and counts an NYC flagship in addition to her L.A. outpost). And the hairstylist Ashley, the baby of the bunch, who rumples and tousles the manes of the Hollywood set, including Elijah Wood and Hailee Steinfeld.

title: United Nations Urges North Korea Prosecutions
description: United Nations members voted decisively on Tuesday for a groundbreaking resolution that condemns North Korea for human rights abuses and for the first time recommends the prosecution of its leaders for crimes against humanity at the International Criminal Court.

title: In Switzerland, Charlie Chaplin in Focus
description: The English actor Charlie Chaplin was a regular guest at the Beau-Rivage Palace in Lausanne, Switzerland, in the Lake Geneva region, and now the 168-room property has a City Lights Package to coincide with the Chaplin, Between War and Peace exhibition at the nearby Muse de lElyse.

title: Verbatim: The Right Impression
description: Josh Earnest, the White House press secretary, when asked if President Obama was leaving open the option of not vetoing Keystone XL pipeline legislation if it comes to his desk.

title: Death Without Regrets
description: I think that few of us consider the impact of our daily activities on the final accounting anyone might render at the time of our death. Because I have had cancer for more than 15 years now, I have had a lot of time to think about this.

title: Restaurant Report: The Lost Kitchen in Freedom, Me.
description: We drove right by Freedom, in central Maine, past grazing bulls and empty chicken houses, before realizing our mistake and finally locating the aptly named restaurant the Lost Kitchen.

title: Bank of Tokyo Fined for Misleading New York Regulator on Iran
description: More than a year after paying a steep penalty for doing business with Iran, one of the worlds biggest banks is back in regulators cross hairs.

title: My Three Sons and All Their Troubles
description: They bestride the world, or at least the West, like colossi. Thronging the halls of Congress and, until just recently, the Oval Office. Running giant corporations. Meeting and greeting at powwows in Switzerland. I speak of the species known as the straight white male, the most unoppressed of the worlds peoples. They are feared, envied, occasionally attacked and derided. But pitied? Not so much.

title: California Paper Asks Its Employees to Produce, Then Deliver, the News
description: As financial troubles continue to plague the newspaper industry, some companies are coming up with new ways to trim their year-end costs. At The Orange County Register, it involves some old-fashioned shoe leather.

title: Senate Defeats Bill on Keystone XL Pipeline in Narrow Vote
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats, by a single vote, stopped legislation that would have approved construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, one of the most fractious and expensive battles of the Obama presidency.

title: De Blasio Dumps Rachel Noerdlinger, Accuses the Press of McCarthyism
description: Somethings gone wrong here, said Mayor Bill de Blasio on Monday, in impromptu remarks about the departure of Rachel Noerdlinger, chief of staff to his wife, Chirlane McCray.

title: Missouri Governor Announces Members of Ferguson Commission
description: An African-American pastor and a white civic leader will lead a state-appointed Ferguson Commission that will work toward healing and positive change in the St. Louis area, Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri announced Tuesday.

title: Wheelies: The Runaway Fusion Edition
description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Koolhaas-Designed Miami Beach Arts Center to Open Next Year
description: A new Miami Beach arts center designed by Rem Koolhaas is to open in December 2015, its founder, Alan Faena, is set to announce.

title: A Carbon Tax Could Bolster Green Energy
description: A couple of years ago, the smart money was on wind. In 2012, 13 gigawatts worth of wind-powered electricity generation capacity was installed in the United States, enough to meet the needs of roughly three million homes. That was some 40 percent of all the capacity added to the nations power grid that year, up from seven gigawatts added in 2011 and just over five in 2010.

title: Neighbors Mourn Harlem Squatter, Known Widely but Not Well
description: Outside the cluttered lot, the flicker of candles said something mournful had happened. Neighbors and others who regularly walked past realized that Baruba had died.

title: Mickalene Thomas Creates a Wine Label
description: Michael Lynne, the former CEO of New Line Cinema, is a longtime art collector and supporter; as an entertainment lawyer in the 1970s and 80s, he represented artists like Julian Schnabel and Jean Michel Basquiat in exchange for some of the works they were creating. Today, he is both the owner of the North Fork, Long Island, winery Bedell Cellars and a Museum of Modern Art trustee  which is how, at a MoMA party in May, he found himself seated next to his friend, the artist Mickalene Thomas, whose work he also collects. They were actually serving his wine, Thomas remembers, and the bottles had Barbara Krugers on them, and Eric Fischls. Bedells long-running series of artist collaborations has also featured works by Chuck Close, Ross Bleckner, April Gornik and Howard Schatz. Tapping Thomas to contribute a label was a natural next step  and an uncomplicated one. He just sort of asked if I would be interested, and I said sure, itd be fun, Thomas says. It was just one of the easiest projects to do.

title: Does Ahab Now Need an Icebreaker?
description: From the episode titles on Wednesday, it might seem like theme night on PBS, and, in a way, it is. Nature has an episode called Invasion of the Killer Whales, and right afterward in many markets, Nova has one titled Killer Landslides.

title: The Racist Origins of Felon Disenfranchisement
description: The state laws that barred nearly six million people with felony convictions from voting in the midterm elections this month date from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, when Southern lawmakers were working feverishly to neutralize the black electorate.

title: When Is a Chocolate Shortage a Good Thing?
description: Milk chocolate, dark chocolate or not enough chocolate?

title: Rodrigo Nio
description: Mr. Nio, 45, is founder and chief executive of Prodigy Network, a developer that specializes in crowdfunding. Its projects include three extended-stay hotel condominiums, two in partnership with Korman Communities.

title: Fantasy Football: Week 12 Waiver Wire Picks
description: An early happy holidays to those of you who have been hanging onto Browns receiver Josh Gordon for 11 weeks.

title: If Either Halliburton or Baker Hughes Call Off Deal, It Would Be Costly
description: If the proposed takeover of Baker Hughes by Halliburton falls apart, it will cost at least one of the companies dearly.

title: De Blasios Approval Rating Wanes, but Is Still Solid, Quinnipiac Poll Finds
description: Nearing the end of his first year in office, Mayor Bill de Blasio is receiving waning, if still fairly robust, support from New Yorkers, with a sharp racial divide over his performance, according to a poll released on Tuesday.

title: Contrite Over Failed Urban Renewal, Washington D.C. Refreshes a Waterfront
description: WASHINGTON  The Potomac waterfront in the southwest quadrant of the nations capital was once a symbol of urban renewals high hopes and then of its crushing failure. It is undergoing a significant redevelopment that promises to remake the little-used mile-long stretch along the rivers Washington Channel into a vibrant, mixed-use community.

title: Senate Panel to Look Into MoneyPak Prepaid Scams
description: Phone scams involving reloadable prepaid debit card products like the popular MoneyPak card will be the subject of a Senate committee hearing on Wednesday.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Fans May Like Home Runs, but They Love a Winner
description: In movable outfield walls the Mets trust.

title: A Dream Piano, Played by a Dreaming Pianist
description: Aaron Parks took a moment, during the homestretch of an hourlong solo piano performance in Midtown on Monday night, to acknowledge the inward turn of his state of mind. Im just up here kind of dreaming, he said, with an obliging half-grin. It wasnt an apology; it didnt feel like a disclaimer. Mr. Parks, working within his usual radius of essential poise, was simply checking in, making sure that he was being understood.

title: Netanyahu and Abbas Condemn Attacks
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority denounced Palestinian attacks at a synagogue in West Jerusalem that killed four people.

title: The New Republic at 100: A Century of Bickering
description: The New Republic will celebrate its 100th birthday on Wednesday with a black-tie gala in Washington featuring remarks by Bill Clinton and Ruth Bader Ginsburg, a performance by Wynton Marsalis and a 400-person guest list studded with boldface names.

title: U.S. Regulators Call for Takata Airbag Recall to Be Extended Nationwide
description: In a significant shift, federal safety regulators on Tuesday called on automakers to conduct a nationwide recall of vehicles that contain drivers-side airbags made by the Japanese supplier Takata.

title: American Ballet Theater and Segerstrom Center in California to Open Ballet School
description: American Ballet Theater and the Segerstrom Center for the Arts in Costa Mesa, Calif.,will open the American Ballet Theater William J. Gillespie School on the Segerstrom campus in September, both organizations announced on Tuesday. The school, which will be open to students ages 3 to 14, is named after William J. Gillespie, an Orange County resident who has been on Ballet Theaters board since 1999. Alaine Haubert, a former dancer and ballet mistress with Ballet Theater, has been appointed principal of the school.

title: $2.6 Billion to Develop a Drug? New Estimate Makes Questionable Assumptions
description: The Tufts Center for the Study of Drug Development has just released its newest estimate for the cost to develop and bring a drug to market. At $2.6 billion, this figure is bound to get a lot of attention. We should take this announcement with a grain of salt, however. While it is no doubt expensive to create a drug, such announcements have come under attack before, often with good reason.

title: Father Prevails, Halting the Donation of His Brain-Dead Daughters Organs
description: The fight over the fate of a 2-year-old Brooklyn girls organs ended on Tuesday, with the girls father prevailing in his wishes to keep her body intact.

title: A Power Struggle, Roots and All
description: In a quietly transfixing scene from the Venezuelan director Mariana Rondns Bad Hair, the camera gazes through the eyes of a 9-year-old, Junior (Samuel Lange), as he and a playmate (Mara Emilia Sulbarn) survey the teeming Caracas housing development across the street and make up stories about its residents. What they see in a giant building that resembles a dingy, crumbling factory is a social microcosm of the impoverished Venezuelan capital, where the threat of violence hangs in the air.

title: Forest City Ratner Buys Out Partner in Brooklyn Residential Tower
description: The battle over one of the slowest moving residential towers in New York Citys history is over.

title: Tarnished Halos at Penn State
description: The people on screen in Happy Valley, Amir Bar-Levs powerful new documentary, frequently describe Penn State football as a religion. This is almost not a metaphor. The film pays periodic visits to a large outdoor mural in State College, Pa., where Nittany Lion luminaries are depicted as if they were figures in an Italian Renaissance tableau of biblical luminaries. At one point, a halo is painted in over the head of Joe Paterno, the former Penn State head football coach who died in 2012, a few months after being fired from the position he had held for 46 seasons. Mr. Bar-Levs interview subjects sometimes describe Paterno as a god or a saint, and he is almost universally recalled as a beloved and benevolent patriarch.

title: All Together Now: Smile
description: IF IT MAKES YOU feel happy, do it, advises a notecard mounted on a shelf of succulents by the Broadway entrance of & Other Stories, a much-anticipated spinoff of the Swedish chain H & M that arrived last month next to the big Prada mother ship. (R.I.P., Guggenheim SoHo.)

title: Keystone Vote Unlikely to Change Odds for Mary Landrieu
description: It is not much exaggeration to suggest that theres one real reason that the Senate voted on whether to advance the Keystone pipeline: Senator Mary L. Landrieu.

title: Stars Attend The Imitation Game Premiere in New York
description: Keira Knightley, Benedict Cumberbatch and other actors host the New York premiere and after party.

title: Beyond the Stereotyped South
description: Tamara Reynolds looks at the American South as a native, going beyond the obvious to capture the regions spirit.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Israel and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Nov. 18, 2014  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Israel, Syria, Mombasa and Iran.

title: Live Side Show Simulcast Wasnt Live After All
description: A bid to make Broadway history by broadcasting a scene from the opening night performance of the musical Side Show live in Times Square didnt come off as planned, though the crowd that gathered to watch in the rain may not have known what they were missing at all.

title: House Democrats Keep Leaders After Losses
description: WASHINGTON  House Democrats, after bruising midterm election losses, opted on Tuesday to stick with their current party leaders.

title: Fanfare for the Common Man (and a Band)
description: There was a time in the 1990s in Britain when everyone seemed to be singing Pulp songs. Kitchen sink stories of awkward lust and washing dishes, of inept sex and inevitable aging, they left lewd, lingering images of blue collar yearning. As written by Jarvis Cocker, a founder of the group and its gyrating frontman, the music at its best evoked Chris Difford and Glenn Tilbrooks work for Squeeze, whose 1979 hit Up the Junction remains a tiny miracle of songwriting.

title: In Turkey, the Arts Flourish, but Warily
description: ISTANBUL  At a glittering dinner on an island in the Bosporus here last week, Ali Gureli, the chairman of Contemporary Istanbul, the citys annual art fair, told hundreds of international collectors, gallery owners and artists that Istanbul had secured its place as a global art capital.

title: ClassDojo Adopts Deletion Policy for Student Data
description: The maker of ClassDojo, a popular behavioral tracking app used in schools across the United States, announced revisions on Tuesday in the way it retains student information.

title: Stylistically Diverse, but United by One Soul
description: For the composer John Adams, hosting the New York Philharmonics Contact! program at SubCulture in the East Village on Monday night must have felt like getting back to basics in contemporary music. Two days earlier, the Metropolitan Opera had presented the final performance of Mr. Adamss opera The Death of Klinghoffer, which at the start of its run drew hundreds of protesters angry over this ruminative works attempt to grapple with a brutal terrorist act. The last performance played to a sold-out house; Mr. Adams and the cast received a prolonged ovation.

title: Applying to College: Race to the Summit
Alabama Takes Top Spot in the College Football Playoff Rankings
description: On Tuesday night, when it released its fourth set of rankings, the College Football Playoffs 12-member selection committee told the five major conferences how it really felt about them.

title: K.K.R. and Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Said to Plan Joint Bid for PetSmart
description: Three months after formally putting itself up for sale, PetSmart appears to have drawn takeover interest from at least two private equity firms.

title: Please Address Me as Dr. or Professor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Storm Over Jonathan Grubers Stupidity Remark
Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: A Sustainable Solution for the Corn Belt
description: Its hard to imagine maintaining the current food system without Iowa. Yet that state  symbolic of both the unparalleled richness of our continents agricultural potential and the mess weve made of it  has undergone a transformation almost as profound as the land on which cities have been built. A state that was once 85 percent prairie is now 85 percent cultivated, most of that in row crops of corn and soybeans. And that isnt sustainable, no matter how you define that divisive word.

title: How Medical Care Is Being Corrupted
description: WHEN we are patients, we want our doctors to make recommendations that are in our best interests as individuals. As physicians, we strive to do the same for our patients.

title: In Overhaul, Pizza Hut Tries Adventurous Menu Offerings and a Dash of Irreverence
description: MUCH is at stake as Pizza Hut begins on Wednesday what executives are calling the biggest campaign in its 56-year history, promoting changes in just about every aspect of its identity: products, packaging, logos, color palettes, uniforms and websites.

title: In Sales of Luxuries, Geography Matters
description: Luxury automakers from Audi to Mercedes-Benz reported record sales last year. Their vehicles made up more than one million of the 16 million sold in the United States in 2013, adding to the millions of older luxury vehicles already speeding along Americas highways.

title: The Thrill of the Hunt for Discount Prices
description: The Internet can tell us how long it takes to walk the length of the Great Wall of China (10 months), how many girlfriends George Clooney has had (lots) and even how many snowflakes fall in a year (about a septillion). But consumers still cant quickly and easily compare prices for a leather purse (big enough to tote a laptop, please) or a 10-quart aluminum stockpot.

title: Judge Declines to Drop Felony Charges in 1 World Trade Center Jump
description: Three sky divers who parachuted off 1 World Trade Center moved a step closer to trial on Tuesday as a judge declined to throw out felony charges against them, saying they had shown a callous disregard for the safety of the community.

title: An Encounter Along Shermans March
description: My great-grandfather John Langhans enlisted in September 1864, joined the 154th New York Volunteer Infantry in Atlanta, and made the subsequent marches through Georgia and the Carolinas under Maj. Gen. William T. Sherman. He went on to live another 60 years, but when he died, the headline of his obituary identified marching with Sherman as the central event of his life.

title: Player Ratings: Ireland (4) vs. United States (1)
description: On a cold night in Dublin, the United States national team suffered its worst second half collapse in years and ended its 2014 schedule on the wrong end of a 4-1 rout by Ireland in an exhibition match on Tuesday night.

title: New YouTube Music Plan Faces Challenge
description: YouTube unveiled its long-awaited subscription music plan last week, giving the music industry a potentially big new source of revenue.

title: The Case for Black With a Capital B
description: PHILADELPHIA  I WAS sitting in my office at Temple University when I overheard an exchange between a colleague and his student. The student had come to see her professor to go over a paper, and he was patiently explaining that the abundance of grammatical mistakes detracted from her compelling content. I sympathized with my colleague as he pointed out error after error. Until he came to this one.

title: From Profits to Politics
description: Just two years ago, during his first term at the helm of Colorado, John Hickenlooper did a quick mental survey of his fellow governors and realized something that he found surprising.

title: Did Dubai Do It?
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Ever since the Arab awakening in late 2010, America has lurched from one policy response to another. We tried decapitation without invasion in Libya; it failed. We tried abdication in Syria; it failed. We tried democratization in Egypt, endorsing the election of the Muslim Brotherhood; it failed. We tried invasion, occupation, abdication and now re-intervention in Iraq and, although the jury is still out, only a fool would be optimistic.

title: In a City Wary of Skyscrapers, a New Tower May Rise
description: PARIS  The last skyscraper built in Paris opened in 1973, an unadorned dark block, rising 59 stories  the Montparnasse Tower. It was considered a disaster. To this day, Parisians joke that the tower offers the best views in the city, because it is the only place from which you cannot see it. City officials went to work banning future skyscrapers altogether.

title: Norwegian Filmmakers Apologize for Fake Syria Video
description: Norwegian filmmakers apologized on Tuesday for planting fake video of the war in Syria on YouTube last week, and removed the original footage following a torrent of criticism from journalists and rights advocates who said such deceptions undermine their efforts to document real abuses.

title: Executives Aggressive Push to Revamp Today Prompts His Dismissal
description: The top executive at NBCs Today show who was fired on Monday after just 10 weeks on the job alienated key decision-makers at NBC News by pushing too hard and too quickly for potential changes on the show, especially among the prominent, on-air names, according to senior executives with knowledge of his departure.

title: Horror in Jerusalem
description: There is no comprehending the murder of four men, including three rabbis, at a synagogue complex in a neighborhood of West Jerusalem on Tuesday.

title: Jewish Victims, All From One Jerusalem Street, Were a Congregations Wise Scholars
description: JERUSALEM  The car crawled slowly through the streets of Har Nof, a loudspeaker on its roof, broadcasting psalms and announcing the funeral at 2 p.m. of Rabbi Moshe Twersky, one of four Jewish men killed at prayer on Tuesday morning when two Palestinians armed with a gun and butcher knives stormed a neighborhood synagogue complex.

title: Europes Central Bank Defies Its Own Rules in Cyprus Bailout
description: In July 2012, a top official at the European Central Bank emailed the head of the central bank of Cyprus with some advice on how to keep the countrys second-largest financial institution from failing.

title: The Anatomy of the General Motors Recall Coverage
description: On Tuesday, auto safety regulators called for vehicles with airbags made by Takata, a Japanese supplier, to be recalled nationwide. Earlier this year, General Motors also announced huge recalls; in February it began recalling 2.6 million cars because of a defective ignition switch. Later, Times reporters revealed that the company had misled families who had lost loved ones because of the faulty vehicles. Bob Goetz, assistant editor for the Business desk, describes the all-hands-on-deck approach to presenting the monthslong story on the greater impact of auto recalls.

title: De Niro and New York Town End Fight Over Property Taxes
description: Unlike most of Robert De Niros work, this drama has a happy ending.

title: Anti-E.U. Party in Britain Strives for Wider Clout
description: LONDON  Last month the brash, populist U.K. Independence Party won its first seat in Parliament, capitalizing on resentment against immigration, disenchantment with the European Union and a general disaffection with politicians.

title: Manhattans D.A. Addresses a National Problem
description: Manhattans district attorney, Cyrus Vance Jr., made a public commitment last week to use $35 million in civil forfeiture assets he controls to help other jurisdictions reduce their large backlogs of untested rape kits.

title: Long-in-the-Tooth Dental Advice
description: Terry OBrien, 73, a retired administrative assistant in Billerica, Mass., recently had to make a tough decision about her dental care.

title: A Citizens Guide to Buying Political Access
description: David G. Herro, a well-known money manager in Chicago, has given more than $2 million to political campaigns and causes over the last seven years. So perhaps it is not too surprising that a United States senator and other prominent politicians have dropped by his offices just to chat.

title: Profiles in Online Identity Cleansing
description: When a stranger knocked on her door three years ago, Susan Manion decided to do more to protect her private information. As a musician in Northern Illinois, she was used to people getting in touch. But her work had started to draw unwanted attention.

title: Finding a Retirement Haven to Suit You
description: More than 10 years ago, Barbara Zierten and her husband retired to a small town in Californias scenic gold country, in the Sierra Nevada foothills.

title: Science (and Quacks) vs. the Aging Process
description: For thousands of years, people have sought to escape or outrun their mortality with potions, pills and elixirs, often blended with heavy doses of hope and will.

title: The True Cost of Daddy, Can I Have a Pony?
description: In third grade, Amanda Ferrara persuaded her parents to let her take horse-riding lessons. She had always loved animals, and her parents, Bronx born but living in a rural part of Westchester County, N.Y., agreed. Nine years later, her family owns one horse and leases two more.

title: Adrift, but Anchoring to Each Other
description: On July 30  the day before our sons eighth birthday  my husband arrived home early from his office with some unwelcome news: The ad agency he worked for had decided to cut costs and eliminate his position.

title: Congress Must Act on War Authority
description: The United States is fighting a new and costly war in Iraq and Syria. Yet, for months, members of Congress have ducked their constitutional responsibility for warmaking. They have neither initiated a meaningful debate on the use of American force against the Islamic State, which is known as ISIS, nor shown any inclination to vote on whether to endorse or modify the mission.

title: Constitutional Limits of Presidential Action on Immigration
The Under-the-Tray-Table Upgrade
description: Flying is not what it used to be. What was once glamorous now feels like walking through a mall to get to a cattle chute. Airlines are expanding first class and squeezing coach passengers into tighter quarters. Every spare inch of space and every service from bag-checking to expedited security has a price.

title: In Compromise Plan, Limited Fracking Is Approved for National Forest in Virginia
description: Drilling for oil and natural gas will be mostly off-limits in the largest national forest in the East, whose streams bring drinking water to Washington and Richmond, Va., the federal government said Tuesday.

title: Defective Takata Airbag Grows Into Global Problem for Manufacturer
description: SIBU, Malaysia  Law Suk Leh, late in her pregnancy, was driving in the industrial outskirts of this steamy riverside city when her 2003 Honda City collided with a turning car.

title: Vaticans New Tone Gains a Voice in Chicago as Blase Cupich Becomes Archbishop
description: In Pope Francis most significant move yet to reshape the leadership of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States, Blase J. Cupich took his seat in Chicago on Tuesday as archbishop of the nations third-largest Catholic archdiocese and called on the church not to be afraid of change.

title: In Jerusalems War of Neighbors, the Differences Are Not Negotiable
description: JERUSALEM  Amid the condemnations from all corners of Tuesdays deadly attack at a Jerusalem synagogue, there were also disturbing signs of celebration. A cartoon of a bloody meat cleaver like the one used in the attack that killed four Orthodox Jews circulated on social media. Residents of the Gaza Strip paraded in the streets singing victory songs, giving out candy, waving flags.

title: Following Her Mothers Example, in Addiction and Then in Sobriety
description: Nicole Gurley followed her mothers path; first to her detriment and later to her salvation. Both women are former drug addicts who can now jointly celebrate their sobriety.

title: U.N. Urges Arab World to Denounce Islamic State
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations top human rights official called on the Muslim world to denounce the monstrous crimes of the extremist group that seeks to establish an Islamic state in Iraq and Syria, calling its actions both a violation of international law and Islamic tenets.

title: Cyprus Government Report Points Fingers on Bank Collapse
description: How can a midsize bank torpedo an entire economy?

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 18, 2014
Uber, a Start-Up Going So Fast It Could Miss a Turn
description: In just four years of operation, Uber has ignited a new global ride-sharing industry with the promise of transforming urban transportation and helping many people get by without owning cars.

title: Opposition to N.F.L. Settlement Centers on Coverage for Neurological Disease
description: During his nine-year career as an N.F.L. linebacker, Jesse Solomon was a solid contributor, a 12th-round draft pick who rarely missed games despite numerous injuries. After 116 games with five teams, he retired in 1995 after a quadriceps tendon separated from his kneecap.

title: Republicans Sure Love to Hate Unions
description: A paradox of American politics is that Republicans take organized labor more seriously than Democrats do.

title: Bucks, Young and Rebuilding, Look to Jabari Parker to Lead the Way Back
description: ST. FRANCIS, Wis.  The Bucks rookie forward Jabari Parker has a favorite moment from his brief N.B.A. career. A few weeks ago, his high school, Simeon Career Academy in Chicago, sent busloads of students two hours north to Milwaukee to see a game against the visiting Bulls. Parker had friends and family members in the stands while he squared off against a childhood hero, Derrick Rose, another Simeon graduate.

title: Honduras: 2 Arrested in Disappearance of Miss Honduras and Her Sister
description: The police said they arrested two suspects Tuesday in the disappearance last Thursday of Miss Honduras, Mara Jos Alvarado, 19, and her sister Sofa, 23. One of the suspects, Plutarco Ruiz, is the boyfriend of Sofa Alvarado. The police did not identify the other suspect. Video footage showed officers raiding what it said was Mr. Ruizs home, protected by a large gate. The two women attended a birthday party for him last Thursday but have not been since. Ms. Alvarado was scheduled to leave for the Miss World contest in London on Wednesday.

title: Words of Certainty
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  Jacob Stulberg made his New York Times debut nearly a year ago with a puzzle that was just golden, in my opinion. Today, hes back with a puzzle that is mildly multidirectional.

title: The Murphys Dont Know What to Do With Their House
description: By the Water, a new play by Sharyn Rothstein, might be called a kitchen sink drama thats conspicuously missing a kitchen sink. Also absent: Furniture, save a tattered plaid couch. And walls. The living room in which the play takes place, in a beachside Staten Island house ravaged by Hurricane Sandy, does feature a giant picture window  without the glass.

title: Republicans React to Keystone Defeat
description: Senators Mitch McConnell of Kentucky and John Hoeven of North Dakota, the co-sponsor of the Keystone XL pipeline bill, discussed their strategies for passing it next year.

title: Womans Remains Being Tested for Ebola in New York
description: A woman who died of an apparent heart attack at a New York City hair salon on Tuesday will be tested for the Ebola virus out of an abundance of caution because she had recently been in West Africa, city health officials said.

title: For One Staten Island Campaign, a Special Prosecutor Instead of an Auditor
description: Washed ashore in the afternoon tide of prisoners in the Staten Island criminal court were two men standing before a judge, hands clasped behind their backs, looking a bit dazed. The men, David Jones, 71, and David Thomas, 57, faced a rack of felonies including grand larceny, criminal possession of stolen property and conspiracy.

title: Hong Kong Protesters Try to Break Into Legislative Building
description: HONG KONG  Demonstrators attempted to break into Hong Kongs legislative building late Tuesday night and early Wednesday by smashing windows. Police officers in riot gear used pepper spray to help quell the protest and arrested four men.

title: Charles Champlin, Critic and Memoirist, Dies at 88
description: Charles Champlin, an arts critic and memoirist best known for his writing about movies for The Los Angeles Times, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 88.

title: At Meeting, Senators G.M. Bryan Murray Discusses Illness
description: TORONTO  Days after announcing that he had advanced colon cancer, Bryan Murray of the Ottawa Senators carried on his duties Tuesday at the N.H.L. general managers meeting.

title: Deal by Cystic Fibrosis Foundation Raises Cash and Some Concern

title: Does Exercise Really Make Us Smarter?
description: Exercise seems to be good for the human brain, with many recent studies suggesting that regular exercise improves memory and thinking skills. But an interesting new study asks whether the apparent cognitive benefits from exercise are real or just a placebo effect  that is, if we think we will be smarter after exercise, do our brains respond accordingly? The answer has significant implications for any of us hoping to use exercise to keep our minds sharp throughout our lives.

title: Fidelity Makes a Virtual City of Stocks
description: In this town, everywhere could be the financial district.

title: Composer Aims to Capture the Spirit of Detroit

title: Word of the Day | epilogue

title: Jason Kidd, About to Face Nets, Again Sheds Little Light on His Departure

title: Whats on TV Wednesday

(13, 49) TO CATCH A COMET As part of PBSs Think Wednesday programming block, this documentary chronicles the challenges facing the European Space Agencys spacecraft Rosetta across 10 years and four billion miles as it chased down the Comet 67P/ChuryumovGerasimenko  a 2.5-mile-wide ball of rock, ice and dust moving faster than 40,000 miles an hour  and released the Philae, a 220-pound lander the size of a washing machine, onto the comets surface last Wednesday.

Yet, Tamara Reynolds has done just that in Southern Route, looking hard at the American South, which she calls home, and offering a searing, honest portrayal of the countrys most stereotyped region.

title: Daily Report: Uber, a Start-Up in Need of a Cultural Shake-Up

title: A Start-Up Lets College Students Skip Washing Their Sheets
description: The Pitch: Many college students loathe having to wash and change their bedsheets, but because their beds serve many purposes  as a couch, a kitchen table and a study desk, to name a few  those sheets can get pretty dirty. Afresheet makes a fitted, disposable, 100 percent recyclable bottom sheet.

title: Morning Agenda: Inside the E.C.B.s Cyprus Mess
description: Confidential communications from the European Central Bank during the Cyprus banking crisis show how the central bank has been wiling to ignore its own bylaws and dictate policy to sovereign governments to prevent wider financial contagion in the eurozone, Landon Thomas Jr. reports in DealBook. Documents show that the E.C.B. effectively proposed that the central bank of Cyprus inflate the value of Cyprus Popular Banks collateral, so that it might funnel more emergency loans to the failing bank. This appears to be violating the E.C.B.s core principle that it may not become involved in the rescue of a bankrupt bank by resorting to its printing press.

title: In Syria, Doctors Become the Victims
description: Working in a field hospital is like death, a surgeon told us two weeks ago in Turkey, where more than two dozen Syrian doctors and other health workers had come for training. As if treating victims of the Syrian Armys weapon of choice, the barrel bomb, wasnt enough, they themselves were often victims of those same terrible devices.

title: Germanys Foreign Minister, a Man in the Middle

Both were apparently self-radicalized and traveled to Syria on their own. Both turned to the web to promote the Islamic State, with one posting images of a female Kurdish soldiers severed head on his Twitter profile.

description: CHICAGO  The pairing of Gillian Flynn and Cheryl Strayed seems at once too obvious and not obvious enough.

title: 1914: Turcos Drive Germans Out
description: LONDON  The English public was delighted to learn through the news from the front to-day [Nov. 19] that those picturesquely-dressed, magnificently-built warriors from Algeria, which the French group under the common name of Turcos, had taken a distinguished part in the fighting. Tracy-le-Val, between the Oise and the Aisne, which a few days since was captured from the Germans, was the object of a fierce charge on the part of the Kaisers troops on Tuesday, who essayed to retake it. They were at first successful. It was then that the Algerian contingents showed their mettle. They fell upon the German forces with all the fury and disregard for their own lives for which these fighters of the desert are famous, and turned a German capture into a German rout.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 20, 1914

title: Delicious Medicine for the Body and Soul
description: Like most people I know, I spent much of the autumn . . . sick. Sick with the sort of mild but hydra-headed illness that in me, and in other people of general good health, eventually beats its own retreat. I carried on  stoically, I hope  gripped by a deep desire, same as everyones, to get well soon.

title: Please Dont Abandon Me
description: Note: Asia Bibi, a Christian Pakistani woman, was sentenced to death for blasphemy against Islam in 2010. The year before, while picking fruit with Muslim women, she took a sip of water from the local well. She was immediately accused of making the water impure by the other workers, who told her that they could no longer use the well. According to her husband, Ashiq Masih, and others, men and women started beating her and accusing her of making derogatory remarks against the Islamic prophet Muhammad, a charge she denies. Asia is currently in prison waiting to be hanged after losing an appeal on Oct. 16. She has told her story in a memoir, Blasphemy: A Memoir: Sentenced to Death over a Cup of Water, written with French journalist Anne-Isabelle Tollet.

title: 1964: U.S. Force in Vietnam Grows
description: WASHINGTONUnited States sent another 1,200 military men into South Vietnam this month, officials disclosed today [Nov. 19]. More American air-transport units also have been thrown into the struggle. The additional manpower brings U.S. military strength in Vietnam to about 21,200 men  up 5,000 since midsummer, sources said. Some of the reinforcements are U.S. Special Forces.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Nov. 20, 1964

It is a shift from the 1990s, when amid concerns about environmental impacts and displaced people, multilateral lenders like the World Bank backed away from large hydroelectric power projects.

Now, with 1,300 employees working out of 12 offices, and five manufacturing plants, the company specializes in bioethanol, waste-water and biochemical technologies.

Bush checked into a Houston hospital with a bad cough that worsened by the day. Despite increasing pain, he retained his fuddy-duddy sense of humor. Its not the cough that carries you off, he joked one day to his visiting son and daughter-in-law. Its the coffin you go off in.

title: Classical Playlist: Handels Messiah, Beethoven, Schumann and More
description: BEETHOVEN: Piano Concerto No. 5, Choral FantasyLeif Ove Andsnes, pianist and conductor; Mahler Chamber Orchestra(Sony Classical 43058862; one disc)With this new recording, the superb Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes completes his Beethoven Journey, a multiyear project capped by his recordings of the five Beethoven concertos with the Mahler Chamber Orchestra. The last album in the series offers his vibrant, elegant, uncannily clear-textured accounts of the mighty Emperor Concerto and, joined by the fine Prague Philharmonic Choir, the episodic Choral Fantasy. Every note speaks in Mr. Andsness distinguished playing. And he proves an insightful conductor, drawing comparably lucid and lively music-making from the excellent orchestra. (Anthony Tommasini)

Since 2012, Sphinx has also awarded an annual medal of excellence to three young musicians who have shown what the organization describes as artistic excellence, outstanding work ethic, a spirit of determination and great potential for leadership. The awards include a $50,000 grant for career development.

His latest, A Particle of Dread (Oedipus Variations), which opens Sunday after two weeks of previews, is a fragmented tale that reimagines Sophocles Oedipus Rex, about a man who cannot escape a prophecy that ultimately dooms him.

description: The insurance commissioner of Connecticut, Thomas B. Leonardi, will be joining the investment bank Evercore as a senior adviser, focusing on the insurance industry

title: Twine, the Video-Game Technology for All
description: Perhaps the most surprising thing about GamerGate, the culture war that continues to rage within the world of video games, is the game that touched it off. Depression Quest, created by the developers Zoe Quinn, Patrick Lindsey and Isaac Schankler, isnt what most people think of as a video game at all. For starters, it isnt very fun. Its real value is as an educational tool, or an exercise in empathy. Aside from occasional fuzzy Polaroid pictures that appear at the top of the screen, Depression Quest is a purely text-based game that proceeds from screen to screen through simple hyperlinks, inviting players to step into the shoes of a person suffering from clinical depression. After reading brief vignettes about what the main character is struggling with  at home, at work, in relationships  you try to make choices that steer your character out of this downward spiral. The most important choices are those the game prevents you from making, unclickable choices with red lines through them, saying things like Shake off your funk. As your character falls deeper into depression, more options are crossed out. You cant sleep; you cant call a therapist; you cant explain how you feel to the people you love. In the depths of depression, it all feels impossible.

title: A First-Person History Lesson From Robert Rubin
description: For the last 25 years or so, Robert E. Rubin, a former co-senior partner at Goldman Sachs when it was a private partnership, has played an inordinately important role in Washington. Some of his extraordinary influence has been overt, as when he served President Clinton as head of the National Economic Council and then as Treasury secretary, and some of it has been subtler but no less significant. For instance, his fingerprints are all over the Obama administrations cabinet and its economic team: Timothy F. Geithner, Lawrence H. Summers, Peter R. Orszag, Gene B. Sperling, Jason Furman, Jacob J. Lew, Michael Froman and Sylvia Mathews Burwell at one time or another have had  or still have  close ties to Mr. Rubin.

title: Uber Scandal Highlights Silicon Valleys Grown-Up Problem
description: Ubers latest scandal is a doozy: A top executive of the ride service reportedly described a Nixonian plan to dig up dirt on journalists who criticize it and sully their reputations.
