description: The three men gathered in a Los Angeles warehouse, bringing a 12-gauge shotgun, a .38 revolver, zip ties for handcuffs and a duffel bag to carry the 20 to 25 kilograms of cocaine, worth more than $500,000 wholesale, they expected to steal.

title: FIFA Ethics Report Will Get Independent Review
description: The small group of people who have seen a secret FIFA report on corruption in the World Cup bidding process will soon grow by at least one. And possibly by even more.

title: At Holiday Party, Obama Encounters a Guest With Family Ties
description: At a holiday party last night at the White House for President Obamas donors and supporters, Margaret Wong congratulated the president on his decision to protect millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation with executive action.

title: The Lexus LF-C2 Concept: Topless, Not Convertible
description: LOS ANGELES  The Lexus LF-C2 concept, introduced here on Wednesday at the 2014 Los Angeles auto show, is the ultimate in topless motoring. Seriously. It has no top at all. Thats because, Lexus announced, its a roadster concept. In Lexus thinking, it doesnt need a top.

title: Living With Cancer: Gravy Days
description: When I was diagnosed in November 2008, I began counting forward, assuming I would die by November 2013, at the latest. Prognosis for late-stage ovarian cancer is three to five years, even with state-of-the-art treatment. November, which happens to be the month of my birthday, became a memento mori: an annual observance of my projected end. A statistical approximation, the prognosis tolled in my ears like a death sentence.

title: What Is President Obamas Immigration Plan?
description: The plan would grant as many as five million unauthorized immigrants temporary reprieve from deportation and provide many of them with authorization to work in the U.S.

title: A Recipe for Wrath (Grapes Optional) in Minnesota
description: As Thanksgiving spreads go, this one was lavish.

title: Indiana Governor Weighs Suit to Stop Obama on Immigration
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana is leaning toward filing a lawsuit to halt President Obamas immigration action, he said in an interview, making him the third Republican governor to threaten such a move.

title: Behind the Urbane Wit, a Crackling Fervor for His Art
description: When the lights are dimmed on Broadway Friday night in honor of the director Mike Nichols, who died on Wednesday at 83, the neighborhood where he plied his trade for half a century will feel even darker than usual. Mr. Nichols emanated a luminous glamour that was once commonplace in the theater, but now flickers only fitfully in an increasingly corporate, profit-driven, financially anxious world.

title: Living Higher, Thanks to Barley
description: A study of ancient life on the Tibetan Plateau  the so-called roof of the world  says it was the ability to grow barley that allowed humans to establish permanent settlements at very high altitudes.

title: Fernando Alonso Out, Sebastian Vettel In, for Ferrari Next Season
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  The Ferrari racing team on Thursday announced the end of one era and the beginning of another as it said goodbye to a two-time world champion and welcomed a four-time world champion.

title: Fantasy Football: Picks for Week 12
description: The Bears have only one victory in their last four games, but win or lose, quarterback Jay Cutler is going to throw the football, which is good news for receivers Brandon Marshall and Alshon Jeffrey.

title: Hotel Review: Radisson Blu Warwick Hotel, Philadelphia
description: Rooms from $289.

title: Marcos Restaurant in Brooklyn Is Closing
description: After a little more than a year in business, Marcos, the sibling of the 10-year-old Brooklyn restaurant Frannys, will close after the dinner dishes are cleared on Dec. 13. The reason, said Francine Stephens, who owns both restaurants with Andrew Feinberg, is that Marcos was not profitable enough.

title: A Limited-Edition G-Shock With a Vintage Feel
description: In this weekly series, the mens fashion editors of T invite creative personalities to put their own aesthetic spin on a new watch. Here, the illustrator Jay Riggio captures a timepiece from Casio.

title: More Light Needed on Wall Streets Revolving Door
description: The dizzying revolving door between Wall Street and the United States government risks an overdone response. Going from a job as an overseer to the private sector, or moving in the other direction, can raise conflicts. Such shifts warrant clear rules, but cross-fertilization has value.

title: Ideas for E.L.L.s | Teaching About Food
description: The topic of food has the potential to fulfill all the prerequisites necessary for creating an engaging and effective language-development lesson:

title: Hispanic Voters Are Important for Republicans, but Not Indispensable
description: President Obamas plan to defer deportation and grant work permits for up to five million undocumented migrants is having two utterly predictable results: outrage from congressional Republicans, and speculation about how the politics will play in 2016.

title: Mayor de Blasio Urges Culture Change at Rikers Island
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio declared on Thursday that Rikers Island deeply needs a culture change and called ending the pervasive violence at the jail complex a top priority of his administration, acknowledging that he had previously underestimated the level of dysfunction there.

title: Carnitas El Atoradero in the South Bronx
description: The plastic cups arrived on a terra-cotta plate, one cup filled with a pickled pigs knuckle, another with a hank of goat sloughed off the bone and unraveling. There were sips of soup, too, shining with fat, and a dark sauce that tasted like smoke incarnate.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: H Is for Helicopter, G Is For Guilt  Whats Your Modern Parent Letter?
description: Here at Motherlode, weve fallen  hard  for Q is for Quinoa, A Modern Parents ABC. From A App to Z Zumba its an alphabet that encapsulates a certain 21st-century parent experience, and the illustrations perfectly capture every age from B Babiators to U Unreasonable to D Drama.

title: The New Republics Party Includes Bill Clinton, Toasts and Whispers of Unease
description: WASHINGTON  The New Republic has made a specialty of viciously skewering Democrats over the years, and few have endured tougher jabs than Bill Clinton.

title: At Odds in the Citys Parks
description: Last week, Lisa Foderaro reported on the tension between New York Citys parkgoers and the growing homeless population that has taken refuge in these public spaces. The reporting process required approaching people she might not have otherwise, and she had some unexpected encounters along the way.

title: An Easier Death, and Less Costly, Too
description: Saving money isnt really the point of hospice care. Helping dying patients have the best possible remaining life, followed by a good death, is really the purpose.

title: Bulls Derrick Rose Takes a Seat, and a Stand
description: Derrick Rose, the Chicago Bulls phenomenal, injury-prone point guard, offered one of the wisest insights Id heard from a young player about negotiating injury and longevity in pro sports.

title: Uprooted by War, Focused on Joy
description: Young Syrians in a refugee camp in Jordan captured how sports provide a diversion from lives uprooted by war.

title: Tips for Traveling While Pregnant
description: Between babymoons and business trips, more and more women are traveling during their pregnancies.

title: Enigmatic Dreamers Flora and Fauna
description: The Chelsea art district has some spectacularly extroverted exhibitions going on now. There are two jam-packed Picasso shows, one at Gagosian on 21st Street and another at Pace; theres a Takashi Murakami extravaganza at Gagosians 24th Street gallery; and David Zwirner has big, crazily surrealistic paintings by Neo Rauch on 19th Street and a selection of cheerfully unruly works by Franz West on 20th Street. Then, at Matthew Marks on 24th Street, theres the opposite of all that: an exhibition of small paintings by Albert York (1928-2009), who was about as introverted and reticent as an artist could be without disappearing altogether from the art world. Presenting 37 small paintings dating from 1963 to 1992, its a beautiful, soul-stirring show.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: cholesterol, milk and colon cancer screening. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: A Figaro on a Big Stage, Another in Your Lap
description: Two Barbers of Seville plied their trade in New York this week. On Tuesday, the Metropolitan Opera revived Bartlett Shers winning production of Rossinis comic classic Il Barbiere di Siviglia, with Michele Mariotti conducting. The title role was sung by the charismatic baritone Christopher Maltman, who made a spectacular entrance atop a wagon pulled by adoring citizens. He oozed sex appeal during his opening aria, Largo al factotum, wearing a magnificent red Phrygian cap like a royal insignia.

title: Error Reported in Health Enrollment Numbers
description: Immigration is the story of the day, but President Obamas health law is also back in the spotlight following a report that enrollment figures were overstated.

title: A Wealth of Modern Dance
description: For the Miser, one of the immediate benefits of moving north was far greater access to modern dance, a discipline he wasnt exactly encouraged to take an interest in back home, where he was raised in a culture inclined to produce more traditionally staid and stoic Southern males. Two performances and an exhibition this weekend exemplify New Yorks rich modern dance scene, at prices perfectly suited to the less-than-rich.

title: Argentinas Case Has No Victors, Many Losers
description: The winners have gained nothing.

title: Exercise Thats Aided by Vivid Mimicry
description: IM biking on a wide road in Tucson, and an S.U.V. passes me as I try to catch up to my team, pedaling ahead on the shoulder next to cactuses and other desert shrubbery. I lean sideways into the turn, clenching my abs as I balance.

title: Tennessees Haslam Elected Chairman of Republican Governors Association
Fantasy Football: Week 12 Player Tiers
description: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

title: Pretty Crowded for an Empty Nest
description: Hope arrives in the form of dread toward the end of the first act of Edward Albees A Delicate Balance, which opened on Thursday night in a revival at the Golden Theater. Up to that point in this production, directed by Pam MacKinnon, its been hard to detect much feeling of any kind within the carefully color-coordinated, dust-free, energy-free environs that have been installed onstage.

title: Renewed Interest for Lockwood de Forests Designs
description: The 19th-century taste maker Lockwood de Forest went through career phases, painting moonlit landscapes, importing antiques, designing interiors and furniture and running a workshop in India. Not much material from any of his pursuits has emerged until this year; now about 7,600 of his brass filigree panels, made at his Ahmedabad workshop, have come on the market.

title: New at JetBlue: Baggage Fees
description: JetBlue has finally succumbed to the latest trends in raising airline revenue: adding seats and baggage fees.

title: Hans Haacke
description: An ecologist in the broadest sense of the term, Hans Haacke has been working valiantly to promote sane thinking about the real world and its interwoven systems for more than four decades. This exhibition brings together new and old works to synergistic effect.

title: The Old Country Never Goes Away
description: Stones in the Sun is a wrenching portrait of Haitian exiles struggling to build new lives in New York City after fleeing their country in the late 1980s. Jean-Claude Duvalier had departed, but his generals remained in power and continued his reign of terror. The film, written and directed by Patricia Benoit, is a powerfully acted exploration of the different ways that people deal with the traumatic wounds of the past.

title: Saying No to Force-Feeding at Guantanamo Bay
description: The Navy is persecuting a nurse with 18 years of military service for refusing to perform a procedure that the American Medical Association condemns as unethical. That is, for refusing to force-feed prisoners on a hunger strike at Guantanamo Bay. Now the American Nurses Association is pushing back.

title: Into the Woods, With Sketchpad
description: Nearly a century and a half after his death, the 19th-century French landscape painter Thodore Rousseau is having his first retrospective in the United States. The Untamed Landscape: Thodore Rousseau and the Path to Barbizon, at the Morgan Library & Museum, features only drawings and oil studies  a total of 65  but its an incisive prism for examining his sensibility and achievement. Rousseau (1812-67) could overwork his paintings, but he rarely missed on paper.

title: Snooze, You Lose
description: I am starting to resent the people who cant quite commit to coming to my Thanksgiving dinner. One close friend says she needs to keep it open, and has no idea when she will be able to confirm because her partner is having a hard time. Another says hed like to drop by at some point, but doesnt know when because he wants to go to another dinner first. This is driving me crazy. A lovely group is coming, and there are others I would like to invite if I can resolve these uncommitted guests. What can I do?

title: Anatomy of a Scene | A Girl Walks
description: The director Ana Lily Amirpour narrates a sequence from her film.

title: Think Back: Americas Immigration Debate
description: The Timess Sam Tanenhaus explains government efforts to keep immigrants out of the country and links President Ronald Reagans amnesty for Latino Americans to todays debate.

title: Iran Said to Free Imprisoned Pioneer Blogger
description: A pioneering Iranian blogger convicted of crimes including blasphemy, obscenity and seditious propaganda has been freed from prison after six years, he said Thursday in posts on social networks widely reported in Irans press.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
description: Ukraine and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Nov. 20, 2014  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Ukraine, India, Lithuanian and China.

title: A Sign of Protest
description: https://twitter.com/alanblinder/status/535537228080898048

title: Ex-Senator Jim Webb Explores Presidential Candidacy
description: WASHINGTON  Former Senator Jim Webb of Virginia has announced a presidential exploratory committee, becoming the first candidate in either party to take such an overt step toward a White House bid. He called for economic justice and a restrained foreign policy, and vowed to re-establish a transparent, functioning governmental system in our country.

title: Weekend Entertainments from the Archives of The New York Times
description: 77 YEARS AGO

title: New Leader at CBS News as Another Returns to 60 Minutes
description: CBS News announced a shake-up in leadership on Thursday, elevating David Rhodes to the top position in the division, while moving the chairman, Jeff Fager, back to running the networks flagship news program, 60 Minutes, full time.

title: Tunisians Are Shaken as Young Women Turn to Extremism
description: TUNIS  Leila Mustapha Saidi returned home on a recent day to find her daughter Henda missing, along with her computer. Mrs. Saidi, who had watched her daughter grow religious and obsessed with the conflict in Syria, said she feared she had run off to join Islamist fighters there.

title: Agency Cites Improper Loan Approval for New Tappan Zee Bridge
description: New York State officials proceeded in almost furtive fashion  without sufficiently informing the public or holding enough open meetings  in approving a $511 million loan from federal clean-water funds for the construction of a new Tappan Zee Bridge, an investigation by an independent state budget office reported on Thursday.

title: Ana Lily Amirpour Narrates a Sequence From A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night
description: In this video, the director Ana Lily Amirpour discusses a sequence from her Persian vampire thriller featuring Sheila Vand and Mozhan Marn.

title: Attorneys General for Sale
description: Every state has laws regulating lobbying, but almost all of those laws apply to lobbying members of state legislatures, not attorneys general. For the most part, states never anticipated that their chief legal officers would be the subject of aggressive pressure from big businesses and special interests.

title: Reaching Out Between the Bars
description: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by the actor Joshua Jackson, followed by a conversation with the writer Joshua Fattal, in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the play button below.

title: Sothebys Chief to Step Down; Drew Fire From Loeb
description: The chairman and chief executive of Sothebys is stepping down, the auction house said on Thursday, a little more than a year after the billionaire hedge fund manager Daniel S. Loeb derided the company as an old master painting in desperate need of restoration and demanded sweeping changes.

title: 2014 National Book Awards: A Stop-Motion
description: A stop-motion featuring the books of the winners and the finalists.

title: Get Off My Lawn, Werewolf
description: LATE PHASES

title: A New Proposal for South Street Seaport Museum
description: The South Street Seaport Museum would be saved, redesigned and possibly moved closer to historic ships under a proposal presented Wednesday by the Seaports developer, the Howard Hughes Corporation. Were completely committed to the long-term viability  making sure the museum is not only vibrant but sustainable, David Weinreb, the companys chief executive, said in an interview. In its revised proposal for the pier, unveiled at a meeting of a community-working group, Hughes said there would be money for the museum.

title: 2014 National Book Awards: Highlights
description: A video montage of the evenings best moments from behind the podium.

title: Steven Cohens Firm to Stop Paying Bonuses for Best Trading Ideas
description: Steven A. Cohen continues to take steps to send a message to federal authorities that his $10 billion family office will not run afoul of the law in the way his former hedge fund did.

title: Gego and Gerd Leufert: A Dialogue
description: As scholarship on modern art in Latin America continues to unfold, Hunter College helps fill out the record with a small, perfectly poised exhibition of work by Gego (Gertrude Goldschmidt, 1912-1994) and Gerd Leufert (1914-1998), European contemporaries who emigrated at different times to South America. They met and made a life together in Venezuela, and had a significant influence on both the art world there and on each other.

title: Most Heavy Drinkers Are Not Alcoholics
description: Most people who drink to get drunk are not alcoholics, suggesting that more can be done to help heavy drinkers cut back, a new government report concludes.

title: Suki Waterhouse Wears Romantic Burberry
description: The Star: Suki Waterhouse

title: Susan Te Kahurangi King: Drawings From Many Worlds
description: Since the early 1960s, the New Zealand artist Susan Te Kahurangi King, 63, has been reworking Looney Tunes characters like a rogue animator, abstracting, distorting and disassembling them in surreal and psychedelic landscapes. A small installation of her drawings was the undisputed hit of this years Outsider Art Fair. She is now making her gallery debut, with a bigger presentation, organized (like her art fair display) by the independent curator Chris Byrne.

title: Albert Oehlen: Fabric Paintings
description: A big Wow is in order. Albert Oehlens scintillating Fabric Paintings, now around 20 years old, are quite a sight  and theyve barely been seen before. According to the Skarstedt gallery, this show is their international debut as a group. It presents 14 of the 20 that Mr. Oehlen made from 1992 to 1996, and mostly kept in his studio.

title: For Phil Klay, a National Book Award Winner, War Is Too Strange to Process Alone
description: Phil Klay, an Iraq war veteran who first wrote for The New York Times in 2010, won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday for his short story collection, Redeployment.

title: A Restless and Turbulent Unconscious
description: The Norwegian director Mona Fastvold, who makes her feature debut with the thriller The Sleepwalker, knows her way around mood. This spare study of two couples  Andrew (Christopher Abbott) and Kaia (Gitte Witt), who has inherited an estate they are renovating; and Kaias sister, Christine (Stephanie Ellis), and her wealthy boyfriend, Ira (Brady Corbet)  is set in Massachusetts but has a Scandinavian sense of reserve.

title: The End Is Here, Onstage
description: While many artists may feel moved to address climate change, the matter has special urgency for the Samoan choreographer Lemi Ponifasio and the members of his company, Mau. In a program note for his Birds With Skymirrors, which had its United States premiere on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Musics Howard Gilman Opera House, Mr. Ponifasio explains that many of the performers hail from low-lying atolls in the Pacific. In that part of the world, Radical climate change is not an apocalypse about to happen, he warns. It is already here.

title: From Hymns to Hard-Driving Euphoria, a Quartet That Likes to Mix It Up
description: The jazz pianist Frank Kimbrough has a gift for flowing ethereality, along with a fondness for earthy rapture. Hes a deft proponent of lyrical abstraction, though he knows when to let a melody have its say. His style is rooted in a pliability of form and feeling, which explains why almost all of the best moments in his early set at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday were suffused with a sense of transition.

title: Comic Complications Swathed in White Terry Cloth
description: Any shortlist of the most confusing plots in comic opera  and there is lots of competition  would place Rossinis Il Turco in Italia right near, or even at, the top. That this daffy opera, introduced at La Scala in Milan in 1814, is such a tangle of romantic intrigue and overlapping story lines may be one reason it isnt staged very often.

title: A Holy Man in India, Descended From New York Fashion
description: MONK WITH A CAMERA

title: For 124 Families, This Lotterys Jackpot Was an Affordable New Home in Manhattan
description: Anette Christopher took a few steps into her new apartment and dropped to her knees, arms stretched toward the ceiling. Its everything I dreamed of, she said through her tears. It took me a long time to be happy like this. I worked very hard for this. After a hushed prayer of thanks, Ms. Christopher put on her eyeglasses to read and sign the lease to her home.

title: A Redesign of Draculas Cape
description: By the time the vampire in the chador is skateboarding down a dark, desolate street, the director Ana Lily Amirpour has ensured that A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night will roll on in your memory. The vampire, a Persian-speaking waif called the Girl (Sheila Vand), also wears a striped fishing shirt and an occasional smear across her mouth that isnt lipstick. Shes taken the skateboard from a nameless tyke (Milad Eghbali), whose indomitable quality and threadbare clothes evoke the children populating Abbas Kiarostamis early films and, in turn, those of Italian neorealism. Whatever the inspiration, the kid is just one of a number of character types drifting through Ms. Amirpours cinematic fun house.

title: Phil Klays Literary Salon on the F Train
description: Im a book voyeur on the subway, a game that has become less fun in the era of e-readers and smart phones. So when I see someone reading a print book, my eyes perk up.

title: Bills-Jets Game Is Moved to Detroit as Snow Blankets Buffalo Area
description: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y.  A storm that has dumped more than six feet of snow in the Buffalo area this week, prompting officials to declare a state of emergency, led to the N.F.L.s decision Thursday to relocate the Bills-Jets game, scheduled for Sunday at Ralph Wilson Stadium, to Detroit on Monday night.

title: A New Destination for African Art
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  A few weeks before the revamped Harvard Art Museums reopened here, a new university-affiliated art space, the Ethelbert Cooper Gallery of African & African American Art, made its debut in modest quarters, two former storefront offices off Harvard Square, filling a slot that other local institutions left all but empty. The raw spaces were unpromising, to say the least, but the architect David Adjaye has done miracles in linking them and carving out eight nichelike galleries for the first show, "Lumins/C/ity.Ordinary Joy: From the Pigozzi Contemporary African Art Collection, for which he also served as curator along with Mariane Ibrahim-Lenhardt.

title: Perfect Timing on the Right Side of the Tracks
description: A photographer who went to document New York Citys bridges and elevated train tracks discovered worlds of activity underneath them.

title: Metropolitan Operas Deficit Swells to $22 Million
description: The Metropolitan Operas deficit ballooned to an estimated $22 million last year, the company said Thursday, as weaker-than-expected contributions and ticket sales combined with expenses related to the companys labor talks to create its most serious shortfall in decades.

title: Equity-Building Mortgage Challenged
description: A proposal by the American Enterprise Institute for a low-cost, 15-year mortgage intended to help low- and middle-income borrowers build equity has attracted considerable attention over the last two months, including in this column. But the concept is getting some pushback from the Urban Institute.

title: Highlights From the 2014 National Book Awards Ceremony
description: Last night, the National Book Foundation presented awards to this years winners in the categories of fiction (Phil Klay for Redeployment), nonfiction (Evan Osnos for Age of Ambition: Chasing Fortune, Truth, and Faith in the New China), poetry (Louise Glck for Faithful and Virtuous Night) and young peoples literature (Jacqueline Woodson for Brown Girl Dreaming). The American author Daniel Handler hosted the 2014 National Book Award ceremony and benefit dinner, which took place at the Cipriani ballroom in New York City and saw humorous and emotional acceptance speeches from celebrated writers. Here, courtesy of the foundation, a look at some of the evenings best moments from behind the podium.

title: An Orientation in Several Shades
description: One new couple is trying to get things together. One longtime couple is trying not to break apart. One paunchy, white-bearded man in a towel is trying to get some satisfaction in a steam room. And one angelic 11-year-old is learning that his priest doesnt want to hear about a young boys sexual stirrings. With those stories, Sergio Tovar Velardes 4 Moons (Cuatro Lunas) paints a spirited and sensitive portrait of gay boys and men in 21st-century Mexico.

title: Romantic Passion With a Whiff of Ambiguity
description: In a short scene in his documentary The Thorn in the Heart, Michel Gondry gathers the aging residents of his aunts village in southern France and shows them a movie. He projects the film, Jean Grmillons 1941 melodrama Remorques, on a large screen in a clearing in the woods, and the townspeople sit as if in a cathedral, the faces of Jean Gabin and Michle Morgan hovering above them while the soft, flickering light reflects onto the trees.

title: Comedy Listings for Nov. 21-27
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Theater Listings for Nov. 21-27
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 21-27
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Federal Site Helps Consumers Avoid Financial Fraud
description: PERHAPS its a caller urging you to invest in precious metals like gold or silver, and even offering to arrange a loan to help you do so. Or perhaps its a radio advertisement, offering fast profits from investing in exotic foreign currencies.

title: Chapter 6 Has Great Advice for Gangsters
description: Casting Sylvester Stallone as a gossip-site publisher obviously modeled on Matt Drudge is one of many counterintuitive ideas that backfire in Reach Me. In this preposterous ensemble piece, residents of the greater Los Angeles area become better people through the extended influence of a motivational book.

title: Activists Wield Search Data to Challenge and Change Police Policy
description: DURHAM, N.C.  One month after a Latino youth died from a gunshot as he sat handcuffed in the back of a police cruiser here last year, 150 demonstrators converged on Police Headquarters, some shouting murderers as baton-wielding officers in riot gear fired tear gas.

title: Americas 11 Million
description: The demographics of Americas undocumented immigrants, more than half of whom have been in the United States for more than 10 years and nearly a third of whom own homes.

title: 5 Guantnamo Inmates Are Sent to Eastern Europe
description: WASHINGTON  The government transferred five low-level Guantnamo Bay prisoners to Eastern Europe on Thursday. Four of the men were Yemenis, and their resettlement was a significant policy change in the Obama administrations effort to close the prison at the naval base in Cuba.

title: Charles XVI: An Inept Hunter, but You Can Count on Him
description: The French animated film The King and the Mockingbird has been more influential than known or seeable, at least in the United States. The movie is belatedly opening here in a subtitled restoration, with special dubbed showings for children.

title: Pop, Rock & Cabaret Listings for Nov. 21-27
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Sifting the Ashes of Bible Belt Church Fires
description: Theres nothing fancy about Little Hope Was Arson, a documentary on the 2010 church fires in East Texas, and thats the beauty of it. The filmmaker, Theo Love, presents the people in the story as they are, without passing judgment and without apology, whether they are investigators or pastors or just ordinary folks caught up in the inexplicable. Its Americana unvarnished and, because of that, as absorbing as it is respectful.

title: Despite Setbacks, Filmmaker Zhang Yimou Moves Forward
description: Under a sky ablaze with fireworks, more than 600 drummers decked out in brilliant red filled the square between the Water Cube and Birds Nest stadiums in Beijing last week to welcome leaders to the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting. The spectacle recalled the dazzling opening ceremony of the 2008 Beijing Olympics, and no wonder  both were choreographed by the renowned Chinese filmmaker Zhang Yimou.

title: Another Kind of Mystery Date
description: All Relative, a tepid romantic comedy written and directed by J. C. Khoury, thinks its being surprising, but really its merely weaving several male sex fantasies together and making nothing insightful out of the resulting story.

title: When Three Into One Equals More
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Six years is a long time for an art museum to go dark, and at Harvard, make that two museums, and eventually three. Such was the case when the university decided to unite its three very different museums  the Fogg (Western European and North American art), the Busch-Reisinger (art from German-speaking Europe) and the Arthur M. Sackler (Asian, Middle Eastern and Mediterranean art)  under one new Renzo Piano roof. Closings started in 2008, with a promised 2013 reopening. The clock ticked. The date passed. Still no lights, but much discontent, inside and out.

title: Jazz Listings for Nov. 21-27
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Agreeing on the Really Big Stuff, Like the Proposal
description: Steven Okuley and Richard Dusseau often say that, if they had looked for love online, where matches are generally made according to similarities and common ground, they would have never met.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Nov. 21-27
description: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Making Music, Not War
description: Frankly, death metal sounds a lot scarier in its Wikipedia entry than it looks in this documentary from Jeremy Xido.

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 21-27
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Close Encounters of the Woodsy, Slasher Kind
description: You would never mistake the horror movie Extraterrestrial for the Steven Spielberg classic E.T. the Extraterrestrial, but you might be surprised by the number of scenes this picture borrows from other movies: the threatened woman in the phone booth, from the first Matrix; furtive, emaciated, long-armed aliens, as in Dark Skies and countless other films; Paranormal Activity"- style snatches of found video. A character grabs a carving knife at one point, and, you guessed it, there are young people imperiled in a cabin in the woods.

title: Smoldering Dance, Unadorned
description: For decades now, Carlos Saura has been cinemas chief archivist of Iberian performing arts, most notably with his Flamenco Trilogy in the early 1980s, and more recently with a documentary on Portugals fado tradition. Flamenco, Flamenco, a sequel to his Flamenco, from 1995, collects more impassioned song and dance.

title: A Fathers Plea for Peace
description: As businesses in Ferguson, Mo., braced themselves for potential riots, Michael Browns father taped a public service announcement pleading for peace ahead of a grand jurys decision on whether Officer Darren Wilson will be indicted in Mr. Browns death. The decision could come as soon as this weekend. At the same time, Jeff Roorda, a Missouri state representative and business manager for the St. Louis Police Officers Association, told The Associated Press that Officer Wilson was confident that he would not be indicted. In an interview, Neil Bruntrager, a lawyer for Officer Wilson, dismissed the comment. The only expectation we have is that they will look at everything thoroughly, he said of the grand jury.

title: In for a Penny, in for a Pound, and Better Work Conditions
description: However you look at it, Food Chains is a mouthful. Gathering at least three films under one rousing umbrella  the fair-wage struggle of tomato pickers in Florida  this emphatic and empathetic documentary (directed by Sanjay Rawal and narrated by Forest Whitaker) presents the plight of our farm laborers as modern-day slavery.

title: When Activist Investors Aim at Strong Companies
description: Bill George is a professor of management at Harvard Business School and a former chairman and chief executive of Medtronic.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Nov. 21-27
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Some in G.O.P. Fear That Their Hard-Liners Will Alienate Latino Voters
description: WASHINGTON  All but drowned out by Republicans clamorous opposition to President Obamas executive action on immigration are some leaders who worry that their party could alienate the fastest-growing group of voters, for 2016 and beyond, if its hottest heads become its face.

title: Her Family Valued
description: No matter how many hundreds of thousands of words, typically in the form of anodyne blog posts and womens magazine articles, have been devoted to the subject of how crucial it is to achieve work-life balance, most of us still find it virtually impossible to believe the political or business figure who abruptly leaves a vaunted position and cites as the reason the need to burrow down in the cocoon of family.

title: Deep Down Dark, by Hctor Tobar
description: In 1987, a toddler who became known to the world as Baby Jessica fell into an abandoned well in a backyard in Midland, Tex., where she was stuck for 58 hours. Watching the coverage as a 7-year-old, I couldnt get an answer from the newscasters or my parents that explained why it was taking so long for so many smart grown-ups to solve such a simple problem. Even now, I find it hard to believe that the human race can be outmatched by such a primitive adversary as a hole in the ground.

title: Embattled Rebel, by James M. McPherson
description: Among the verses Union Army soldiers sang to the tune of John Browns Body as they marched through the rebellious South was one about hanging Jeff Davis from a sour apple tree. For many of them, as for Abraham Lincoln and his administration, Davis was a rebel and a traitor who was waging bloody war against the United States in defense of slavery and the world it made possible. Who better deserved the punishment that treason customarily imposed? But from the rebel point of view, Davis was president of what they called the Confederate States of America  Lincoln and others referred to it as the so-called Confederacy  and thus, according to their constitution, the commander in chief of the rebellion and the government they had hastily established.

title: A Secret Life in Zurich
description: Stefan Haupts The Circle takes its name from an underground journal and gay club in Zurich in the mid-20th century. Our entrance to this corner of history comes through the story of Ernst Ostertag and Rbi Rapp, which is told through documentary interviews with this sweet, be-sweatered elderly couple and a conscientious dramatization of their courtship in the 1950s.

title: Philip Larkin: Life, Art and Love, by James Booth
description: James Booths new biography of Philip Larkin is not very exciting, perhaps because Booth has the sense to leave the exciting writing to Larkin. But it is very welcome. If you believe that Larkin (1922-85) wrote some of the best English-language poems of modern times, then it has been a trial to see his questionable track record as an everyday human being get in the way of his reputation as an artist.

title: Shermans Maps
description: In March of 1864, William T. Sherman succeeded Ulysses S. Grant as the commanding general of the Military Division of the Mississippi. Grant, who had moved up to command all the Union armies, instructed Sherman to strike against Gen. Joseph E. Johnstons army in Georgia, and then penetrate the deep interior of the Confederacy in order to inflict as much damage as possible on the resources that fueled the rebellion. These instructions became the basis for the Atlanta campaign, where Shermans three armies advanced from northwestern Georgia to Atlanta from May to September. Subsequently  and more notoriously  Sherman continued the assault by spreading his men into a moving front up to 60 miles wide as they marched to Savannah and then up through the Carolinas.

title: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 21-27
description: Four Seasons: A Spinning Planet

title: Health Enrollment Counting Error Shows Where System Is Still Broken
description: The Obama administrations overcounting of the number of people enrolled in Affordable Care Act health plans reveals how all the glitches in the governments computer system have yet to be worked out.

title: This Weeks Movies | Nov. 21, 2014
description: The New York Times film critics review The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1, A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night and Happy Valley.

title: Bill de Blasio Defends Al Sharpton After Report on Tax Woes
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio defended the Rev. Al Sharpton on Thursday amid questions over his unpaid taxes, emphasizing Mr. Sharptons work on civil rights issues and adding that he knew a lot of good people who had struggled with tax troubles.

title: New York Citys Week in Pictures: Nov. 20
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include a couple of cold days and a visit by Batman to a City Council hearing.

title: An Obamacare Do-Over
description: MANY political analysts were surprised by how close I came to winning the Virginia Senate race earlier this month. I received more than a million votes running on a five-point plan for economic growth, and the first point was a specific proposal to replace the Affordable Care Act.

title: Difficult Decisions in Treating A.D.H.D.
Israelis Confiscate Weapons Bound for East Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  Thousands of commando-style knives, swords, fireworks and small devices capable of delivering an electric shock were found hidden in two shipping containers supposedly loaded with Christmas decorations, the Israeli police and customs authority said Thursday.

Obamas Immigration Action Has Precedents, but May Set a New One
description: President Obamas action to shield millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation and grant them work permits opens a new front in the decades-long debate over the scope of presidential authority.

description: To the Editor:

title: Airbus Wins Delta Order on Promise of Delivery
description: Airbus scored a big victory over Boeing on Thursday when Delta Air Lines said it would buy 50 new planes from Airbus, including its newest long-range A350 aircraft.

title: Rent-Stabilized Leases Shielded in Bankruptcy
description: In a decision with implications for millions of tenants, New York States highest court ruled Thursday that a lease for a rent-regulated apartment is a public benefit and cannot be seized as an asset in a personal bankruptcy.

description: President Obama hasnt started to speak, but supporters and critics are already weighing in:

title: Obamas Speech: The Duel on Twitter and Beyond
description: President Obama announced his executive action on immigration tonight in a speech from the East Room of the White House. Reaction has been percolating all day, and escalated as the president wrapped up his remarks.

title: 7th Accuser Joins Claims of Assault by Bill Cosby
description: A seventh woman has stepped forward publicly with allegations that the comedian and actor Bill Cosby sexually assaulted her decades ago.

title: Jim Parsons, Big Bang Theory Star, to Promote Intel as Innovator
description: THE technology giant Intel, eager to make a bigger bang in a crowded and competitive category, is turning to a comedic actor who makes a Big Bang several times a day.

title: The Democrats Immigration Problem
description: SAN DIEGO  PRESIDENT OBAMAS executive order eliminating the threat of deportation for millions of undocumented immigrants is good policy. It is the right thing to do. But it is a dangerous move for the Democratic Party.

title: Ferguson Looks to Holiday Shopping Rush With Unease
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Honoring the 21st-century tradition of holiday retail, Best Buy is planning to open its St. Louis-area stores at 8 a.m. on Black Friday, promising early-bird discounts on flat-screen televisions, iPads and laptop computers.

title: New York Citys Unemployment Rate Drops to Lowest Level in Six Years
description: The plunge in New York Citys unemployment rate continued in October, falling to 6.4 percent, its lowest level in six years, the states Labor Department reported on Thursday.

title: Sculptor Offers Another Clue in 24-Year-Old Mystery at C.I.A.
description: The artist who created the enigmatic Kryptos, a puzzle-in-a-sculpture that has driven code breakers to distraction since it was installed 24 years ago in a courtyard at C.I.A. headquarters in Langley, Va., has decided that it is time for a new clue.

title: Perils, Platforms and a Prize
description: The Hong Kong-born artist Paul Chan has won the $100,000 Hugo Boss Prize, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation announced on Thursday.

title: Colombias Data-Driven Fight Against Crime
description: One Monday in 1988, El Mundo newspaper of Medelln, Colombia, reported, as it did every Monday, on the violent deaths in the city of two million people over the weekend. An article giving an hour-by-hour description of the deaths from Saturday night to Sunday night was remarkable for, among other things, the journalists skill in finding different ways to report a murder. Someone took the life of Lus Alberto Lpez at knife point  Lus Alberto Patio ceased to exist with a bullet in his head  Mario Restrepo turned up dead  An unidentified person killed Nstor Alvarez with three shots. In reporting 27 different murders, the author repeated his phrasing only once.

title: G.M.s Victims Get an Extension
description: The administrator of a compensation fund General Motors set up to pay victims of an ignition switch defect that could cause cars to turn off while they were being driven made the right call when he extended the deadline by a month for people to submit claims for deaths and serious injuries.

title: Falling Wages at Factories Squeeze the Middle Class
description: For nearly 20 years, Darrell Eberhardt worked in an Ohio factory putting together wheelchairs, earning $18.50 an hour, enough to gain a toehold in the middle class and feel respected at work.

title: The Duchess of Alba, an Unconventional Aristocrat, Dies at 88
description: MADRID  The Duchess of Alba, a flamboyant Spanish aristocrat known for her lifestyle, her vast wealth, her art collection and her unmatched list of titles, died on Thursday in her palace in Seville. She was 88.

title: A New Clue to Kryptos
description: The creator of Kryptos, a sculpture that contains an 865-character encrypted message, has released a second clue for the final unsolved section.

title: Ebola Spread Has Slowed in Liberia, C.D.C. Says
description: WASHINGTON  The international response to West Africas Ebola epidemic, coupled with more effective action by local communities, has stopped the exponential spread of the disease in one of the hardest-hit countries, Liberia, the director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Thursday.

title: Long-Sought Roof for U.S. Open Is Taking Shape at Arthur Ashe Stadium
description: During last summers United States Open, the evidence of roof construction at Arthur Ashe Stadium was hidden under large flower planters and inside a bar.

title: Love and Gravity
description: Most Hollywood movies are about romantic love, or at least sex. But Christopher Nolans epic movie Interstellar has almost no couples, so you dont get the charged romance you have in normal movies where a man and a woman are off saving the world.

title: Set Back by Hardship, a Student Athlete Runs Up Against an Age Restriction
description: Word came to Jason Puello in September that he was too old to play basketball in his senior year, when he would have been the starting center at a small alternative public high school in Washington Heights.

title: After Criticism, Fed Will Study Wall St. Oversight
description: Under pressure to show that it is up to the task of regulating giant Wall Street firms, the Federal Reserve issued a surprise announcement on Thursday that it would review crucial aspects of its bank supervision.

title: Suffer Little Children
description: The Tenement Museum, on the Lower East Side, is one of my favorite places in New York City. Its a Civil War-vintage building that housed successive waves of immigrants, and a number of apartments have been restored to look exactly as they did in various eras, from the 1860s to the 1930s (when the building was declared unfit for occupancy). When you tour the museum, you come away with a powerful sense of immigration as a human experience, which  despite plenty of bad times, despite a cultural climate in which Jews, Italians, and others were often portrayed as racially inferior  was overwhelmingly positive.

title: University of California to Raise Tuition Despite Protests
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As students with sleeping bags staged a sit-in at the University of California, Berkeley, and the police stood by watchfully, the Board of Regents of the University of California gave final approval on Thursday to a contentious plan to raise tuition steadily over five years, which students across the state protested as unaffordable.

title: Health Insurance Enrollment for Exchanges Was Overcounted
description: The Obama administration acknowledged on Thursday that it overcounted the total number of people signed up for health insurance through the Affordable Care Act exchanges. Marilyn B. Tavenner, administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services, said in September that 7.3 million people were enrolled. ButBloomberg News reported Thursday that the figure included nearly 400,000 people with stand-alone dental plans, prompting the administration to revise the enrollment figure to 6.7 million as of Oct. 15. The discrepancy was discovered by the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, which had asked for the enrollment records. About eight million people had signed up for health plans by May, according to the administration, but many are no longer enrolled. At the time, the Health and Human Services Department broke out the number who had signed up for dental but not medical plans, saying that 1.1 million people had done so. In a statement, the Department of Health and Human Services said it still estimated that a total of 9.1 million people would have medical coverage through the exchanges by the end of next year. The mistake we made is unacceptable, Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the departments secretary, wrote on Twitter.

title: Obamas Immigration Address
description: In a prime-time speech, President Obama announced a series of executive actions to grant work permits and temporary reprieves from deportation to as many as five million undocumented immigrants.

title: Christina Kim Handles Downs and Ups by Dealing Openly With Depression
description: NAPLES, Fla.  It took Christina Kim six holes to card her first par Thursday at the L.P.G.A.s Tour Championship. While hardly ideal, Kim saw her birdie, bogey, double bogey, birdie, bogey start at Tiburon Golf Club as a perfect metaphor for golf and for life.

title: 2 Worlds of Hong Kong, and a Fatal Intersection
description: HONG KONG  The banker, Rurik George Caton Jutting, a Cambridge graduate, came from London in 2013, one of thousands of expatriates who arrive in Hong Kong every year to pursue jobs in banking and burnish their rsums with Asia experience. Mostly men, they often live expense-account-subsidized lives in luxury high-rise apartments, patronizing trendy Western bars at night and socializing at members-only tennis and yacht clubs on weekends.

title: Senate Democrats Clash With White House on C.I.A. Torture Report
description: WASHINGTON  In a tense confrontation with President Obamas closest adviser on Thursday, a group of Senate Democrats accused the White House of trying to censor significant details in a voluminous report on the use of torture by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: In New Jersey, a Court Fight Over Sports Betting
description: TRENTON  The lawyers battling to allow sports betting in New Jersey did not contain their disdain for the leagues that oppose it.

title: Militants in Benghazi Attack Tied to a Qaeda Affiliate
description: CAIRO  The Libyan militant group accused of leading the attack on the United States diplomatic mission in Benghazi two years ago had previously helped train a dozen fighters who went on to participate in a deadly attack on an Algerian gas plant, according to a United Nations Security Council document justifying new sanctions on the group, Ansar al-Shariah.

title: Pregnant Lawyer Fails in Bid to Delay Trial
description: A Long Island lawyers request to postpone a trial until next September because she was in the sixth month of a high-risk pregnancy was denied on Thursday after a contentious hearing in federal court in White Plains.

title: Lottery Numbers
F.D.A. Approves Hysingla, a Powerful Painkiller
description: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved a powerful long-acting opioid painkiller, alarming some addiction experts who fear that its widespread use may contribute to the rising tide of prescription drug overdoses.

title: A Top Chinese Flyweight Is a Heavyweight at Home
description: MACAU  Given Manny Pacquiaos popularity, it is not surprising to see images of him lining the halls of a hotel this week.

title: Obama Describes Immigration Plan
description: President Obama explained actions his administration would take on the immigration system, and who those actions would and would not affect.

title: Mike Nichols: A Prolific Director
description: A look back at the career of the acclaimed director Mike Nichols, who died Nov. 20, 2014.

title: Obama Defends Plans Legality
description: President Obama defended his authority to act on immigration and challenged Congress to pass its own legislative overhaul of the system.

title: Sunday at the Opera With Edgar
description: WASHINGTON  Many decades have passed since ballet played a significant role in musical theater, which may be one reason Little Dancer, a new musical directed and choreographed by Susan Stroman, about the girl immortalized in the Edgar Degas statue of the title, has a whiff of the antique about it. This polished and pretty if less than transporting show, with book and lyrics by Lynn Ahrens and music by Stephen Flaherty, features a dramatic ballet in which the young heroine relives the rapturous highs and demoralizing lows of her life.

title: Call From the Rear
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  It will not come as a surprise to anyone who frequents this blog that people feel very strongly about their crossword puzzles.

title: Obama Says Deportation Isnt Feasible
description: President Obama argued that rounding up and deporting all undocumented immigrants in the United States would be not only unrealistic, but also immoral.

title: Louisiana: Oil Rig Explosion Kills One
description: An explosion on an oil and gas platform in the Gulf of Mexico on Thursday killed one and injured three others, according to federal officials. The Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement reported that the accident occurred just before 3 p.m. on a platform operated by Houston-based Fieldwood Energy. The three who were injured were being treated at an onshore medical facility, the agency said. According to a statement from the company, one of the injuries was serious. The platform, 12 miles off the Louisiana coast, was not in production at the time and the Coast Guard had so far found no pollution in an inspection of the site.

title: The Doll Lady of Mount Vernon
description: Elaine Baez makes clothes for dolls as a form of therapy, and then sells the dolls on the streets of Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Amid Years of Psychiatric Turmoil, a Glue Gun Helps Keep Her Life Intact
description: Elaine Baez dresses her models in brightly colored fabric, paints their nails, slicks their hair with gel and pierces stud earrings into their tiny hands to look like rings. She washes them thoroughly.

title: U.S. Lays Out Limits It Seeks in Iran Nuclear Talks
description: VIENNA  As six world powers and Iran race to meet a Monday deadline for an agreement that would constrain Irans nuclear program, the United States has staked out an ambitious goal for what an accord should accomplish.

description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Nazi-Era Art Collection Appears to Find a Home
description: BERLIN  A collection of more than 1,000 artworks obtained by a Nazi-era art dealer and kept private for decades by his son is expected to be accepted by the Kunstmuseum Bern, a small museum in Switzerland, fulfilling the sons final wish.

title: Austin Takes the Far Right in Moderation
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  The rapidly fizzling challenge to House Speaker Joe Straus undercuts a noisy populist wing of the Republican Party in favor of an establishment hoping to quell what it regards as an unnecessary storm of temper tantrums and manufactured drama.

title: Both Ends Want Bullet Train; Its Those in Middle Who Object
description: DALLAS  Steve Drake regularly makes the nearly four-hour drive from this city to Houston to visit his fiances family. So he was excited about the news that a private company intended to build a bullet train that would cut that trip to 90 minutes.

description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Bradford Gilde, a Houston lawyer, stumbled across some unexpected evidence as he was preparing to sue Aruba Petroleum on behalf of a North Texas couple who believed fumes from the companys natural gas wells were making them sick.

title: Eavesdropping on Pakistani Official Led to Inquiry Into Former U.S. Diplomat
description: WASHINGTON  American investigators intercepted a conversation this year in which a Pakistani official suggested that his government was receiving American secrets from a prominent former State Department diplomat, officials said, setting off an espionage investigation that has stunned diplomatic circles here.

description: A 33-year-old Bronx man was charged on Thursday with manslaughter in connection with the death of his wifes 3-year-old grandson, the authorities said.

title: Undocumented Immigrants Tune In as Obama Makes Long-Awaited Pledge
description: HYATTSVILLE, Md.  She was not going to believe it until she saw it with her own eyes: President Obama speaking on the big television screen, saying he would give protection from deportation to millions of immigrants in the country illegally.

title: Events on Long Island for Nov. 23-29, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Food Bank Chief Fuels Up on Faith and Breakfast
description: Margarette Purvis, a Mississippi native now living in Harlem, runs the nonprofit Food Bank for New York City, which will provide 80,000 turkeys to food pantries and soup kitchens for Thanksgiving Day. Ms. Purvis, who declined to give her age  Im a true Southern woman  said she saw all types of people lining up for meals these days, including many who were more educated. For her part, Ms. Purvis will be in Mississippi for the holiday, enjoying family and food, and if they live up to expectation, she will most likely pronounce them yummy.

title: Harland Stonecipher, Insurance Pioneer, Dies at 76
description: Harland C. Stonecipher, an insurance salesman whose legal problems after a head-on car crash prompted him to pioneer a new way for people to insure against future legal costs, died on Nov. 10 in Ada, Okla. He was 76.

title: A Game of Plates
description: A few months ago, Gabe Thompson, the chef at LApicio, an Italian restaurant in the East Village, started reading the Game of Thrones novels by George R. R. Martin. Already a fan of the bloody, beardy HBO drama based on the books, Mr. Thompson was struck by how obsessed the original works were with culinary matters. They were all about food, he said the other day. The insight had prompted an epiphany: Why not host a Games of Thrones feast, matching dishes taken from, or inspired by, the books with beers produced by Ommegang, the Belgian-style brewery near Cooperstown, N.Y., that recently released a limited-edition line of Game of Thrones beer? When the dinner was announced this month, the 35 seats sold out almost immediately. And on Tuesday night, a ravenous crowd of Games of Thrones fans  including five old friends from law school  descended on LApicios private dining room for a hearty, medieval-style repast.

title: Helping Felix Avoid Oscar
description: They are among the most pressing questions to confront someone moving to New York City: Where will I live, and with whom? When I arrived here, I was so desperate for a place that I took the first one available (leading immediately to my first bad-roommate arrangement). It is situations like these that a new app called MatchPad is designed to help users avoid.

title: Colonial Williamsburg Plans Expansion and $600 Million Campaign
description: Colonial Williamsburgs art museums are to expand as part of a $600 million campaign, the foundation that runs the historic site in Williamsburg, Va., is to announce on Friday.

description: escapade \es-k-pad\ noun

title: Clashes Erupt Over Missing Mexican Students
description: MEXICO CITY  A day of mostly peaceful antigovernment mass marches on Thursday to protest the disappearance, and presumed murders, of 43 college students ended with clashes with the police who tried to prevent some demonstrators from damaging the National Palace in the city center.

title: UKIP Wins 2nd Seat in the British Parliament, Dealing a Blow to David Cameron
description: LONDON  The populist U.K. Independence Party won its second seat in the British Parliament early Friday with a striking victory that threatened to destabilize the Conservative Party of Prime Minister David Cameron.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Uprooted by War, Focused on Joy
description: A project run by the photographer Brendan Bannon in the Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan gave young people digital cameras to chronicle the details of their lives, which were shaken by war in Syria, their home country.

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (Showtime) LOST SONGS: THE BASEMENT TAPES CONTINUED (2014) The director Sam Jones watches as Rhiannon Giddens, Jim James, Taylor Goldsmith, Marcus Mumford and Elvis Costello compose and record music at Capitol Studios in Los Angeles, with the help of the producer T Bone Burnett, for two dozen lyrics written by Bob Dylan in the summer of 1967 and only recently rediscovered. The result of the collaboration, Lost on the River: The New Basement Tapes, followed the release this month of The Basement Tapes Complete, a six-disc set of the 1967 recordings made by Mr. Dylan and the Band in upstate New York. Its a project that could have easily capsized under its own self-consciousness and the weight of the Dylan legacy, Jon Pareles wrote in The New York Times about the new album. But the personalities of the songwriters, who are bandleaders on their own, push through.

title: Japan Orders Takata to Investigate Flawed Airbags
description: TOKYO  Japan stepped up pressure on the airbag supplier Takata on Friday over safety problems that have been linked to at least five deaths outside the country and led to a Senate hearing in Washington.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: To those members of Congress who question my authority to make our immigration system work better, or question the wisdom of me acting where Congress has failed, I have one answer: Pass a bill.

title: Corrections: November 21, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Chinese Journalist Accused of Stealing State Secrets Affirms Innocence at Trial
description: BEIJING  Amid heavy security, Gao Yu, a journalist accused of stealing state secrets, went on trial in Beijing on Friday in a closely watched case analysts said was aimed at silencing a voice that gave the world rare glimpses into internal Communist Party politics.

title: 6 Qs About the News | A Sponsor Steps Away From the Edge
description: In A Sponsor Steps Away From the Edge, John Branch writes about Clif Bars second thoughts about supporting certain high-risk sports.

title: Should Millions of Undocumented Immigrants Be Allowed to Live in the U.S. Without Fear of Getting Deported?
description: An estimated 11.4 million unauthorized immigrants reside in the United States. On Thursday night, President Obama announced that he is taking a series of executive actions to grant up to five million of them permits to work in the United States and temporary reprieve from deportation. What do you think?

title: Perfect Timing on the Right Side of the Tracks
description: How does a photographer drawn to intimate, personal moments capture 700 miles of elevated infrastructure for cars, trucks and trains in New York City?

title: Latin Grammys Wait for Obama, Then Quickly Move On
description: The 15th annual Latin Grammy Awards had a serious warm-up act: President Obama announcing his executive actions to shield many undocumented immigrants from deportation. The Spanish-language network Univision, which broadcast the Latin Grammys live from the MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas, delayed the start of the awards to show the presidents entire speech.

title: Chinas Millenniums-Old Salt Monopoly No Match for Economic Reform
description: China plans to scrap its state monopoly on the sale of salt, marking the end of a system with nearly 2,700 years of history. The move is intended to bolster competition, the Beijing Youth Daily reported, citing the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology.

title: Mario Draghi Says E.C.B. Will Do What We Must to Stoke Inflation
description: PARIS  Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank president, strongly signaled on Friday that he and his colleagues were preparing a new round of powerful monetary stimulus to jolt the flagging eurozone economy.

title: As Verrazano Bridge Turns 50, a Myth About Its Tolls Persists
description: A cloud of discontent that always seems to be menacing Staten Island, where people are accustomed to feeling ill used by the rest of New York City, is darker than usual these days.

description: Good morning.

description: Good morning on this frosty Friday.

description: Cardinals (9-1) at Seahawks (6-4)

title: Obamas Plans for Immigration Reform
description: Not everyone is pleased.

title: Police Question Indian Guru and Find Arsenal in His Compound
description: NEW DELHI  The police on Friday began questioning a self-styled Indian godman who was seized after security forces stormed his compound in northern India, where he had barricaded himself with about 15,000 followers for more than a week. An extensive cache of weapons was found inside, the police said, including ammunition stored underneath the throne from which he preached.

title: Q. and A.: Kevin Niu on Movies and the Hunger for Horror in China
description: In a few months, Kevin Niu is set to receive his Ph.D. from Harvard in physics. Hes studying nanotechnology, where he has focused on gallium nitride, which is used in the manufacture of Blu-ray Discs. So whats he going to do with that Harvard degree? Go back to his native China and teach physics? Work at a prestigious laboratory? No. Hell be spending time in Louisiana, producing a horror movie called Abattoir.

title: In China, Success Depends on Mastering a Different Set of Details
description: What you wear, how you speak and even how you stand are part of your image. In China, those are not the details that really matter  especially for foreigners.

title: Morning Agenda: China Cuts Rates
description: CHINA CUTS RATES | China has cut benchmark interest rates for the first time since July 2012, Bloomberg News reports. The one-year deposit rate was lowered by 0.25 percentage points to 2.75 percent, while the one-year lending rate was reduced by 0.4 percentage points to 5.6 percent, effective on Saturday, the Peoples Bank of China said on its website on Friday. The move is a departure for the Peoples Bank of China, which had focused on selective monetary easing and liquidity injections as the country heads for its slowest full-year growth since 1990. European stocks and United States stock index futures were higher after the announcement.

title: Officers Errant Shot Kills Unarmed Brooklyn Man

At the same time, a man and his girlfriend, frustrated by a long wait for an elevator, entered the seventh-floor stairwell, 14 steps below. In the darkness, a shot rang out from the officers gun, and the 28-year-old man below was struck in the chest and, soon after, fell dead.

title: Toward a Truth That Defies Precision
description: As far as I could tell, there were no protesters in the vicinity of Lincoln Center on Nov. 15 before a Saturday matinee, the final performance of The Death of Klinghoffer at the Metropolitan Opera. This was a big change from the opening night of the Mets season in September and the premiere of the Klinghoffer production last month, when hundreds of angry demonstrators gathered to denounce this opera by the composer John Adams and the librettist Alice Goodman as an anti-Semitic work that dared to humanize terrorists. Of course,Saturdayis the Jewish Sabbath. But the only sign I saw being held outside the Met at the sold-out matinee said, I need a ticket! in big red letters.

I prefer  but by no means need, either physically or psychologically  the extra space. My wife finds this new habit of mine rather absurd and extravagant. I agree. But is it unethical? WILL, AUSTIN, TEX.

title: Branden Jacobs-Jenkins Is, and Is Not, Writing About Race
description: You realize its backing up, Branden Jacobs-Jenkins said casually, as I turned around, midstreet, to find myself within two inches of a moving car. No, I managed, suddenly terrified, forgetting about the notes I had been taking. Jacobs-Jenkins touched my elbow, and his smile reassured me to start breathing again. Not today, he intoned, as I slid out of harms way and into Blue State Coffee in New Haven, Conn.

title: Apples From Thanksgiving Start to Finish
description: There are many reasons to visit New York in the fall, and apples are one of them. I was reminded of this when I found myself at the small Lincoln Center farmers market on a Saturday in late October. I had been testing apple recipes at home in Los Angeles the previous week for this weeks Recipes for Health, and now I regretted that I didnt have more recipes to test, so generous was my choice of apples. (This did not stop me from buying quite a selection and enjoying them, just about the healthiest snack on earth, throughout the week.)

title: Strangers at Sea
description: Ryan Breymaier is hardly known outside the national sailing community. In the port cities Barcelona and Les Sables-dOlonne, France, he is recognized as a skipper of some of the most challenging racing sailboats in the world.

title: Strangers at Sea
description: Without ever having sailed together before, Ryan Breymaier and Pepe Ribes crossed the Atlantic Ocean in a 60-foot monohull, one of five boats in the June 2014, IMOCA Ocean Masters New York to Barcelona race.

title: Inside the List
description: N Slocum: Richard Fords story collection Let Me Be Frank With You  No. 17 on the extended hardcover fiction list after debuting last week at No. 14  is his fourth book to feature Frank Bascombe, following three novels: The Sportswriter (1986), Independence Day (1995) and The Lay of the Land (2006). By now, in other words, Bascombe is as familiar as your next-door neighbor, having staked his place not just in suburban New Jersey but in contemporary literature. So I was startled to learn, while talking to Ford at an event last spring, that the character was originally named not Bascombe but Slocum. I had a working notion, Ford explained in a follow-up email, that Frank was figuratively a man sailing alone around the world  like Joshua Slocum, who wrote Sailing Alone Around the World, a book I loved. But when Ford sent his manuscript for The Sportswriter to the poet Donald Hall, a longtime friend and mentor, Hall reminded him that Joseph Hellers novel Something Happened also had a protagonist named Slocum. So I was stuck, Ford said, with a finished novel narrated by a character I didnt have a name for. This was very vexing, I hardly need say. Id always felt a characters name was totemic. Ford set out to rechristen his protagonist, deconstructing Slocum and deciding he required a two-syllable, trochaic name that emphasized its vowels rather than its consonants. I had a friend who had a middle name that was like Bascombe, he said, but I didnt want to steal my friends name. So I rejiggered it into Bascombe  a name Id never heard before but that sounded persuasive. I was actually surprised at how easily I made the transition from one loyalty to another. It was instructive.

Pollack, a Mideast expert and former C.I.A. analyst, scrupulously assesses Americas options in its intractable clash with Iran  from negotiations and sanctions to military strikes and nuclear containment  and comes to a sobering conclusion: Going to war with Iran to try to prevent it from obtaining a nuclear arsenal would be a worse course of action than containing Iran, even a nuclear Iran.

title: Carolyn Chutes Treat Us Like Dogs and We Will Become Wolves
description: There are two Maines, I used to joke, and I live in the other one. Meaning that there is the Maine of the coast and the towns, of wealth and leisure (or at least job security and weekends), of education and solid middle-of-the-road values: mowed lawns, clapboard siding, pavement.

title: A No Wing Author
description: In the race for most eccentric contemporary author, whoevers in second place probably cant see Carolyn Chute. The writer, whose novel Treat Us Like Dogs and We Will Become Wolves is reviewed by Bill Roorbach this week, lives several turns off the beaten path in western Maine, where she founded the 2nd Maine Militia. In a 2008 profile of Chute in The Times, Charles McGrath described the groups political philosophy as essentially one of cheerful, nonpartisan economic populism.

title: Three Thoughts on an Amnesty
description: 1) The first thing to say isthat it could have been worse. In the end, the White House accepted (and publicly, since they released the memo) a limiting principle contrived by its own Office of Legal Counsel,and only extended work permits to parents of citizens and green card holders, rather than widening its initial DACA grant to protect parents of those protected immigrantsas well. The White House also declined to makesome of the other moves involving agricultural workers and others  that were bruited in advance; it did expand the existing DACA program itself by changingage limits and moving the eligibility date for arrival from 2007 to 2010, but thats just a further exercise of a power that the White House had already claimed.

Such emissions contribute to harmful local air pollution and  because the main constituent of natural gas is heat-trapping methane  global warming.

title: The Man Behind the Hacking: Talking to Guccifer
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from The New York Times. In this piece from November 2014, Andrew Higgins described what it was like to meet Marcel-Lehel Lazar, the hacker known as Guccifer, in a Romanian prison. Initially famous for revealing that former President George W. Bush had taken up painting, Guccifer more recently exposed Hillary Clintons private email address and boasted that he got into her private server as well (though he has provided no evidence to back up that claim). In May 2016, as part of a deal with the Justice Department, Guccifer pleaded guilty to federal charges that he hacked the email accounts of Secretary of State Colin Powell, a member of the Bush family and former Clinton advisor Sidney Blumenthal.
