title: Letter From the Editor: Facing the Reality of Win-Lose Situations
description: I first became aware of Alan Dershowitz through cable television, and I initially didnt understand why many people seemed to consider him a brilliant law professor rather than just another talking head. But seven years ago, while reporting an article  for The Times Magazine that had little to do with Mr. Dershowitz, I ended up attending a lecture he gave at Harvard, as part of a class called Morality and Taboo. During it, I started to understand why hed been invited on so many television shows in the first place: He has an unusual ability to bring the essence of big issues to the surface.

title: An Obama Voter Leads a Lawsuit Against Obama
description: House Republicans were hoping the third time was the charm when they hired Jonathan Turley, a law professor at George Washington University, to handle their lawsuit against the Obama administration.

title: Stuff We Liked: Names That Lean Left or Right
description: As we zip around the web, sharing with you the stuff our staff liked, lets just get the eye candy out of the way: the political leanings of first names. The maker of a baby name app, Nametrix, noticed that certain names tended to be more popular with Republicans or Democrats. Were not sure that it is statistically valid, but the chart is fun  right, Jasmine and Duane? (And we know why it looks good to us; it closely resembles an innovative 2012 New York Times graphic by Mike Bostock, Shan Carter and Matthew Ericson.)

title: The Presidents Executive Order Is Not Just About Unauthorized Immigrants
description: In addition to helping 5 million unauthorized immigrants, the executive actions President Obama announced Thursday should make life a little easier for skilled workers and foreign graduates of American universities.

title: The Chain, by Ted Genoways
description: Every working day, tractor-trailers from Iowa, Nebraska and Minnesota deliver about 30,000 hogs to a pair of slaughterhouses controlled by Hormel Foods. One of the plants is in Austin, Minn., the other in Fremont, Neb.; and both produce meat for the inexpensive, highly processed edible product known as Spam. In The Chain: Farm, Factory, and the Fate of Our Food, Ted Genoways describes in appalling detail what goes into that Spam. The ingredients on the label  pork with ham, salt, water, modified potato starch, sugar and sodium nitrite  may sound harmless. But Genoways argues that the industrial system behind those little cans is inextricably linked to a variety of social problems: animal cruelty, water pollution, food-borne illness, worker exploitation, a rise in anti-immigrant sentiment, government corruption and largely unchecked corporate power. Once celebrated with some irony by Monty Python, lovely Spam, wonderful Spam looms as a sinister force in The Chain, a hidden source of misery in the nations heartland.

title: Gravitys Rainbow, Read by George Guidall
description: Gravitys Rainbow, Thomas Pynchons gargantuan parable of rocketry, sex and a whole bunch of other stuff, turned 41 this year  six years older than its author when it was first published. What happens when a novel whose scenes of coprophagia and pedophilia moved Pulitzer trustees to cancel the prize in 1974 (when Pynchon seemed poised to win) eases into middle-aged, canonical respectability? Well, for one thing, it gets an audiobook release. Since the mid-1980s, a George Guidall recording has been floating around, like some mythical lost rocket part  no one had heard it, but all Pynchon fans knew someone who knew someone who had  but in October a new version, authorized and rerecorded and burned onto 30 compact discs  hit the stands. How on earth, I wondered as I stripped the wrapper, is poor Mr. Guidall going to render the sudden outbreaks of crazed capitals, or librettos in which stoners with guitars pastiche Rossini, the instructions helpfully stating (bubububoo[oo] oo [sung to opening of Beethoven 5th, with full band])? He turns out to do it in a slow and deep-voiced manner, beneath whose calm avuncularity you can detect anxiety, even mania, bubbling but never quite erupting  although I could have sworn I heard him, in the silence at the end of CD 30, racing out the door to buy a years supply of those Thayers Slippery Elm Throat Lozenges the hero Slothrop sucks, or perhaps to check himself into the books White Visitation mental hospital.

title: Fahrenheit 451, Read by Tim Robbins
description: One ordinary evening in the not too distant past, I discovered I had exhausted all the offerings of the futuristic entertainment devices designed to help me tolerate the present. There was nothing that interested me on my high-definition television, neither on my 700 channels of cable nor on my 300 hours of recorded DVR programming, and no one to amuse me on my telephone that is also a camera or on my electronic tablet that is also a web browser. So I roused the desktop computer that is also my audio library from its digital slumber, inserted a shiny disc into its silver frame, and listened as a Hollywood movie star read Fahrenheit 451 to me.

title: Jason Segel Reads Nightmares!
description: Multitalent is a funny thing  possessing it and beholding it. Often, the multitalented are cautious, aware that special judgment awaits, cocked and spring-loaded in a way it wouldnt be if they had stuck to their original skill. We are more inclined to buy your banjo album or artisanal fig bars if youre a movie star, but also more inclined to zero in on their flaws: too much banjo. If the multi happens to be one of those people who push their projects on us like a corn gavage down a ducks throat  eat this, buy this, love this, dont you love this?  our suspicions only deepen.

title: Dan Stevens Reads Homer Translations
description: Toward the end of Homers Iliad, the Greek hero Achilles organizes a series of athletic competitions as part of the funeral rites for his fallen comrade Patroclus. As contestants line up for the chariot race, Nestor, the aged leader of the Pylians, gives his son Antilochus some unsought advice. Cling to the turning mark, Nestor directs, as translated by Robert Fitzgerald:

title: Something Rich and Strange, by Ron Rash
description: One place comprehended can make us understand other places better, Eudora Welty wrote in 1956. It is not an easy feat for a writer to portray a region so fully that enduring truths are found in local circumstance. The poet, novelist and short-story writer Ron Rash has accomplished this with his fictional account of the very real Watauga County in western North Carolina.

title: All My Puny Sorrows, by Miriam Toews
description: In a 2013 exchange thats become famous in literary circles, the novelist Claire Messud took to task an interviewer at Publishers Weekly who observed that she  the interviewer  wouldnt want to be friends with the protagonist of Messuds most recent novel and asked if Messud herself felt the same way.

title: A Chosen Exile, by Allyson Hobbs
description: One of the best birthday presents anybody ever gave me was a calling card by the conceptual artist Adrian Piper. I was in college at the time, and it felt like the ultimate inside joke handed from one racially ambiguous person to another.

title: Nuruddin Farahs Hiding in Plain Sight
description: Hiding in Plain Sight begins with a threat. One evening in Mogadishu, Aar, a logistics officer for the United Nations, receives a letter in the mail. It consists of a single, misspelled word, but its terrifying all the same: deth! Aar wants to return to his home in Nairobi on the first flight out, but at the last minute, he decides to stop by the office to pick up photos of his children. As he steps out with the pictures in hand, Shabab militants strike the building.

title: The Port Chicago 50 and The Family Romanov
description: For the past 20 years there has been a cassette tape in our car with a title along the lines of Teach Yourself Morse Code. While not exactly riveting material, this is possibly the first nonfiction audiobook I can remember listening to, and its a perfect example of why nonfiction works well in the format. The human voice lends life to words on a page. The tonal subtleties of a skilled narrator can captivate listeners with a commitment that readers of the written word must bring to a text on their own. Steve Sheinkins The Port Chicago 50: Disaster, Mutiny, and the Fight for Civil Rights and Candace Flemings The Family Romanov: Murder, Rebellion and the Fall of Imperial Russia are excellent works in their own right, but both books gain a layer of engagement through vibrant spoken narrations.

title: The End of Biography
description: They land on my doorstep every day for weeks, their sharp report the sign that a new shipment has arrived. Others are thrust into my hands by the doorman, at first with jocularity, then annoyance, bulky packages that I wrestle into the elevator, dropping half of them on the floor. I have agreed to be a judge for a literary prize, and by the time the postal onslaught ends, there are 107 more books in my house than there were before  an addition no one but me would notice, so jammed is every available space with the evidence of a bibliophiles intractable habit. Still, its a lot of books. I arrange them in piles in the guest room; soon, theyre as high as a stone wall.

title: Stephen Kings Revival
description: There is a childrens joke that goes something like this: Why was Dr. Frankenstein never lonely?

title: The Republic of Imagination, by Azar Nafisi
description: I was the only foreigner in the English Department and took it as a personal affront that she thought I could not understand Twain or Faulkner as well as she did, Azar Nafisi writes of a fellow student at the University of Oklahoma. Of what value is a novel if you have to have been born in a certain latitude in order to enjoy it?

title: What Makes Employee Resilience Possible
description: Capacity is the sort of flat, familiar word we dont typically give a second thought. Its also the key to a high-performance work culture and a sustainably productive life.

title: Amid Snowstorm, Bills Shrug, Bundle Up and Make Their Way to Detroit
description: CHEEKTOWAGA, N.Y.  Tight ends Lee Smith and Scott Chandler loaded up their suitcases, said goodbye to their families and hitched rides on snowmobiles. Wide receiver Chris Hogan started walking.

title: Riots in Mexico City
description: Protesters and police clashed Thursday in Mexico Citys main square over the governments handling of the disappearance and apparent massacre of 43 student teachers.

title: Boehner on Obamas Immigration Action
description: Speaker John A. Boehner said President Obamas executive action on immigration had sabotaged chances for bipartisan legislation.

title: Popcast: London Calls Mary J. Blige
description: Mary J. Blige, the radiant gravitas-machine of American R&B, traveled to London earlier this year to work with a group of musicians and producers who revere her. They include Sam Smith, Disclosure, Emeli Sande, Naughty Boy, Sam Romans and Jimmy Napes. Theyre all currently making hits, and theyre all interested in updates of various styles that Ms. Blige, 43, has direct or indirect connection with, from sad ballads to club music.

title: Ailing Cher Cancels Rest of Tour
description: Cher has canceled the remaining 29 concerts in her Dressed to Kill tour, which was to have run through February (with a concert at Madison Square Garden on Dec. 15) because of illness, she announced on her website on Friday.

title: Allure of ISIS for Pakistanis Is on the Rise
description: LONDON  Across Pakistan, the black standard of the Islamic State has been popping up all over.

title: Biden Condemns Russian Action in Ukraine
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. denounced Moscows behavior as a flagrant violation of the bedrock principles of the international system.

title: Anti-Government Protest Forces Biden to Skip a Kiev Stop
description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. had to beat a hasty retreat on Friday at the sight of an unruly crowd of Ukrainians in Kiev protesting the new government amid continuing unrest in that former Soviet republic.

title: Daniel Handler Apologizes Over Racist Comment at National Book Awards
description: Daniel Handler apologized for a racially tinged joke he made as the host of the National Book Awards, when he referred with mock incredulity to African-American author Jacqueline Woodsons watermelon allergy.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Deep Down Dark
description: This week, Hctor Tobar and George Guidall.

title: In Geneva, a Skating Rink With a View (and Brunch)
description: While Switzerlands largest lake, Lake Geneva, never freezes, the waterfront hotel La Rserve Genve will simulate seasonal conditions when it opens its outdoor Winter Lodge on Saturday.

title: Private Banking Firms Turn to Niche Marketing for Clients
description: CAN the financial needs of affluent African-Americans, women and members of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender communities be better served apart from mainstream wealth management clients?

title: Five Stories of Classic
description: A brownstone at 37 West 70th Street, with airy panache and a profusion of French casement windows thanks to a rigorous 1980s restoration by its former owner, the fashion designer Perry Ellis, has re-entered the market at $17.95 million.

title: New-York Historical Society to Open Center for Womens History
description: The New-York Historical Society plans to establish a new Center for the Study of Womens History, to be included within the Henry Luce III Center for the Study of American Culture, the society announced on Friday. The center, which will include both permanent and rotating exhibitions, is expected to open in December 2016.

title: 1939: Mine Sinks Japanese Liner
description: LONDON  German mines, laid secretly off the east coast of England, today [Nov. 21] claimed the 11,930-ton Japanese motor liner Terukuni-Maru, while the 329-ton steam trawler Sea Sweeper, the Fleetwood trawler Thomas Hankins and the Boston (England) trawler Delphine were all sunk by enemy action, the Sea Sweeper in the North Sea and the Thomas Hankins in the Irish Sea. Meanwhile, the Admiralty announced the loss of the 520-ton British minesweeper Mastiff by a mine explosion off the east coast of England, bringing the toll of Germanys unrestricted under-water warfare during the last five days to sixteen vessels. The loss of the Mastiff, completed last year at a cost of 46,000, was announced in an Admiralty communiqu which declared that the mine sweeping trawler was lost off the east coast by the explosion of a German mine. The next of kin of casualties have been informed. One seaman is dead and five missing.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 22, 1939

title: Greek Budget Forecasts Growth, but Creditors Are Skeptical on Deficit
description: ATHENS  The Greek authorities presented a budget Friday that forecasts healthy growth after a deep recession and includes substantial tax cuts for the first time in four years. But the upbeat assessment lacked the approval of the countrys international creditors, who remain skeptical that Greece can meet economic targets amid political uncertainty.

title: As Immigration Rules Shift, Migrants Joy Is Tempered
description: HYATTSVILLE, Md.  For 14 years, Jos Alberto Pia, a Mexican immigrant without legal papers, worked on the same landscaping crew at a Maryland golf course. It was outdoor work, running sprinklers, mowing and trimming. He liked it, Mr. Pia said, and his boss liked him.

title: Theres a Giant Contradiction at the Heart of the U.S. Economy
description: Suppose you told an economist these facts and only these facts: Long-term interest rates have fallen sharply over just a few months. Prices for oil and other much-needed commodities have been in free fall in the face of weak demand. Markets are predicting that inflation will be low in the years ahead and that the central bank will keep interest rates lower for longer.

title: A Memorial to Her Son, Until the Bank Got in the Way
description: Email haggler@nytimes.com. Keep it brief and family-friendly, include your hometown and go easy on the caps-lock key. Letters may be edited for clarity and length.

title: Fathers Criticism, Amplified
description: LOS ANGELES  Boys, as many parents are equipped to recognize, can be knuckleheads. And so when Golden State Warriors guard Klay Thompson, who led a life of privilege growing up, decided a couple of seasons ago that he was going to be the tough guy, shoving Indiana Pacers center Roy Hibbert from behind during a kerfuffle between the teams, his father instantly recognized it.

title: British Insurer Aviva Close to $8.8 Billion Deal for Friends Life
description: Aviva P.L.C. announced on Friday that it was in advanced talks to acquire the Friends Life Group for 5.6 billion pounds, or $8.8 billion, in stock, a deal that would create an insurance, savings and asset-management giant in Britain.

title: Grand Jury Still Working; County Gets Ready
description: CLAYTON, Mo.  St. Louis County on Friday began making preparations for the grand jury decision on whether to indict Officer Darren Wilson in connection with the Aug. 9 shooting death of Michael Brown.

title: The Making of a Washington Power Couple
description: Early in the Obama administration, before David Krone became persona non grata at the White House, he seemed poised to connect the Houses of Harry Reid and Barack Obama by marriage.

title: Lee Nguyen of New England Revolution Closes a Global Circle
description: Lee Nguyen knows how it feels to be treated like a rock star.

title: In Brooklyns Industry City, a Market for Objects Made in America
description: Speaking from his companys Industry City warehouse in Brooklyns Sunset Park, Mark Bollman, the founder of the mens wear line Ball and Buck, mentions the like-minded occupants of the historical manufacturing complex. One of our neighbors does stained glass, another is a woodworker and made our desks and chairs, and someone does 3-D printing, he says. These buildings were used to outfit troops going to serve in World War II  in fact, Industry City, then named Bush Terminal, established the borough as an international seaport around the turn of the century  and, from an energy standpoint, its old-world manufacturing meets the new wave of maker culture. This weekend, the space will add shoppers to the mix with the opening of Bollmans American Field pop-up market.

title: In Alabama Town, Obama Immigration Move Brings Hope and Sneers
description: ALBERTVILLE, Ala.  Residents here have long grown accustomed to the bright flourish of Hispanic flavor that has come to define their otherwise traditional Southern downtown: The bustle of La Popular, the supermarket stocked with coconut and mango, across from the sober white steeple of the First Baptist Church. The restaurant called El Sol King Pollo, with its tripe tacos and menudo, across Main Street from the Paisley Patch Boutique, with its gingham backpacks and monogrammed gifts for children.

title: F.C.C. Chairman Says Agency Will Not Rush Net Neutrality Rules
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said on Friday that the agency was taking its time formulating a net neutrality policy because he wanted to be able to defend the rules against an inevitable court challenge, which he expects whatever policy the commission approves.

title: Alibabas Finance Arm, Ant Financial, Is a Mystery to Most Investors
description: Alibabas finance arm is one of the secrets of the Chinese e-commerce groups success. Yet investors in the listed Alibaba Group dont control a single share of the business, and cant reliably estimate its worth. That puts them at a disadvantage to a select group of insiders with a seat on both sides of the table.

title: In a Queens Court, Women in Prostitution Cases Are Seen as Victims
description: By 9:30 a.m. on a Friday, the defendants start filing into the fluorescent-lit hallway outside Judge Toko Seritas courtroom in Queens Criminal Court in Kew Gardens, checking anxiously for their names on a sheet of paper behind glass. Many of the women are Chinese and find that their names, typed in English, are misspelled.

title: The Diplomatic Effort, and What a Final Agreement Might Look Like
description: VIENNA  Everything about the nuclear negotiations with Iran, now approaching a crucial moment, is complex: the international politics, the implications for the Middle East, and the science of how to prevent a nuclear energy project from turning into a nuclear weapons program. Here are answers to questions about the lead up to the diplomatic effort and what a comprehensive agreement might look like.

title: Yangons Hero, Wielding Power of Stop and Go
description: YANGON, Myanmar  For 12 hours nearly every day, Sgt. Khin Myint Maung stands in one of the most chaotic intersections in this chronically gridlocked city, untangling traffic snarls with patience and unflagging good humor.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Report on the Life of Adam Lanza Before the 2012 Shooting
description: A 114-page report provided new details into Adam Lanzas life leading up to the massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn.

title: Adam Lanzas Mental Problems Completely Untreated Before Newtown Shootings, Report Says
description: Medical experts at Yale University had called for drastic measures to help Adam Lanza in the years before he shot and killed 26 people at Sandy Hook Elementary School in Newtown, Conn., but those calls went largely unheeded by his mother, who was also shot to death, according to a new study.

title: In Berlin, Still Partying in the Ruins
description: Sunrise on a Sunday morning is barely noticeable in Berghain, the club that has been the citadel of techno music in Berlin for a decade. Its main dance floor is a perpetually dark place illuminated, infrequently, by flashing lights overhead and packed, hour after hour, with increasingly sweaty dancers. Its D.J.s play marathon sets that run nonstop, night and day, through weekends and into Monday afternoons, sustaining the metronomic mayhem of untrammeled Berlin techno: giant, booming drumbeats and bass lines bearing down and building up again and again, with relentless impact.

title: Martoma Starts Serving 9-Year Sentence for Insider Trading
description: Mathew Martoma has started his nine-year prison term for insider trading at a low security federal prison in Miami at a time that most of the former hedge fund traders and analysts also convicted in the federal governments long-running investigation have paid their debt to society.

title: Holder on Public Safety and Free Speech
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said Friday that the Justice Department had issued new recommendations to law enforcement agencies about the management of public protests.

title: A Son Writes His Own Ticket
description: At a pivotal moment in Atticus Lishs novel, Preparation for the Next Life, his heroine takes a grueling trip around Queens in a pair of deteriorating shower shoes. She intends to just go and keep going until the world ended or she ended. The closely detailed recitation of her journey comes straight from a notebook Mr. Lish kept when he took that same walk.

title: Blame the Princess
description: In a Vogue magazine spread before Amal Alamuddin married George Clooney, the fashion designer Oscar de la Renta proclaimed that the wedding gown was the most important dress in the life of a woman. He probably wasnt considering what a woman would wear, say, as she accepted a Nobel Peace Prize, or was being sworn in as the president of the United States.

title: How to Arrive at the Best Health Policies
description: When the 48-year-old man from Oregon didnt have insurance, he felt he had no place to go but the emergency room. The man, who has diabetes, went to the emergency room often when he suffered from kidney stones. Emergency rooms, from what I understand, they can never turn you away, he said. I mean, you dont have much options when you dont have insurance.

title: Tune In to The Times
description: Over the past week, New York Times reporters and contributors participated in interviews regarding their coverage and other top news stories. Below are highlights from television and radio.

title: Jordan Arrests Muslim Brotherhood Official Over Criticism of United Arab Emirates
description: AMMAN, Jordan  The Jordanian authorities have arrested a senior leader of the Muslim Brotherhood for criticizing the United Arab Emirates, the spokesman for the Brotherhoods political wing said Friday.

title: Yiddish Isnt Enough
description: Naftuli Moster was a senior at the College of Staten Island when he first heard the word molecule. Perplexed, he looked around the classroom. Nobody else seemed confused. Yet again, because of gaps in his early education, Mr. Moster was ignorant of a basic concept that everybody else knew.

title: Ryan Goslings Sexy Snub, Models in Latex and What Karl Lagerfeld Is Cooking Up Next
description: All the weeks fashion news thats fit to reprint.

title: Measuring the Apology of the Atlanta Hawks
description: This is the fourth apology in our Apology Metrics series in which we present apologies for readers to assess. Our goal is not to evaluate apologies as theatrical performances but to evaluate the apologizers behavior over time to see whether there has been genuine change. The survey for this apology will be predictive rather than retrospective. We will follow up with a retrospective evaluation after at least a year.

title: Photos From the Los Angeles Show
description: A look at some notable models from this years show.

title: Officer Darren Wilson Said to Have No Plans to Return to Ferguson Police
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Darren Wilson, the officer who fatally shot 18-year-old Michael Brown in August, has no intention of returning to the Ferguson Police Department, people close to him said on Friday.

title: Soaking Cranberries, and Heading Into Thanksgiving Week
description: You know what I wont be cooking next week?

title: Ford Announces Fuel Economy Numbers for the 2015 F-150
description: Ford announced Environmental Protection Agency fuel-economy estimates Friday for its all-new, mostly aluminum-body 2015 F-150 pickup, claiming better numbers than other full-size gasoline-power pickups on the market in the United States.

title: Pictures of the Day: The West Bank and Elsewhere
description: The West Bank and More  Pictures of the Day

title: White House Taps First Female Pastry Chef
description: The White House has shattered a glass ceiling  in its kitchen.

title: Comparing College Costs the Easy Way
description: If youre a shoestring start-up trying to get noticed in an enormous industry, theres nothing that helps more than having big players try to ban you. But from financial services to airlines, the pattern repeats itself again and again, as the lumbering giants seek to destroy rather than cooperate.

title: Turkey Hash Is a Great Thanksgiving Leftovers Dish
description: What do you like better: Thanksgiving proper or leftovers from the feast? Both can be delectable, but even if all the guests leave with doggy bags, in most households, masses of leftovers are still a given.

title: Weekend Reading: Is the New York Fed a Cop or a Fire Warden?
description: Under rising scrutiny for its ties to Wall Street, the Federal Reserve played defense in separate Senate panels on Friday.

title: Officials Revise Goals on Containing Ebola After Signs of Wider Exposure in Mali
description: The leaders of the United Nations and the World Health Organization expressed renewed alarm on Friday about Ebolas tenacity in Africa and, in particular, its potential to ravage a fourth country, Mali, where they said hundreds of people had been exposed to an infected cleric who died last month.

title: Nov. 21, 2014  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the West Bank, Kashmir, Spain and Germany.

title: Theater Owners Join Effort to Add Captioning to Films
description: LOS ANGELES  The National Association of Theater Owners on Friday joined major advocacy groups for the deaf and hearing-impaired in joint recommendations to the Department of Justice for an anticipated rule regarding captioning equipment in movie theaters.

title: Keeping Up With Kendall Jenner
description: When it was announced last week that Kendall Jenner would be the new face of Este Lauder, a coveted contract that in the past has gone to actresses like Gwyneth Paltrow and Elizabeth Hurley and supermodels like Joan Smalls, the company did not promote the news by way of the usual public-relations machine, with news releases or email blasts.

title: Priests as Husbands and Fathers?
Taubman Hires Top Sports Banker
description: Paul J. Taubman continues to poach talent from his former employer.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: How to Defeat the Impulse Buy
description: AS Thanksgiving approaches, so does the holiday shopping season. Once again, a day traditionally meant to celebrate gratitude will inaugurate a month of rampant consumerism.

title: After Rocky Transition, Tunisia Is Set for First Democratic Presidential Vote
description: TUNIS  Less than a month after electing a new Parliament, Tunisians will vote Sunday in their first-ever open democratic presidential election, completing a tumultuous democratic transition begun with their revolution nearly four years ago.

title: Book Review Podcast: Deep Down Dark
description: In The New York Times Book Review, Mac McClelland reviews Hctor Tobars Deep Down Dark: The Untold Stories of 33 Men Buried in a Chilean Mine, and the Miracle That Set Them Free. Ms. McClelland writes:

title: Biden Assails Russian Intervention in Ukraine as Unacceptable
description: MOSCOW  Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. in Kiev on Friday condemned Russia for its unacceptable military intervention in Ukraine, while exhorting Ukraines newly elected government to complete its democratic and anticorruption reforms.

title: When a Passion for Ferraris Turns Into a Commitment
description: The 1951 Carrera Panamericana road race made a lasting impression on a journalist, Rodolfo Junco de la Vega, then in his 20s, who witnessed a winning performance by powerful sports cars from the nascent Ferrari factory.

title: Protest Sites in Ferguson
description: Where people protested in the weeks after the shooting and in recent days.

title: Movie Review: Happy Valley
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott Reviews Happy Valley.

title: A Compact That Wins Style Points, but Misses the Bulls-Eye
description: The Toyota Corolla isnt much different from a Nissan Sentra that looks like a Volkswagen Jetta or a Chevy Cruze and might as well be a Hyundai Elantra. Compact car buyers are obsessed with value, dependability and economy. Style? Not so much.

title: 100 Candles and Quite a Few Darts
description: John and Horace Dodge got a jolt of free publicity in 1916. Two years after the brothers began producing their own vehicles, General John J. Pershing used a fleet of 250 Dodge-built cars to chase Pancho Villa and his gang into Mexico. After one shootout, a young lieutenant, George S. Patton, returned with the bodies of three of Villas men strapped across the hoods of three Dodge Brothers touring cars. Photos of the gory scene made Patton and the Dodge Brothers cars famous  well, more famous.

title: Verbatim: Whatever It Takes
description: President Obama, in Las Vegas, on what he was willing to do to get the House of Representatives to vote on an immigration bill.

title: On Sundays, This Chimney Sweep Is a Wrestler
description: On Monday, Cesar Granados, 39, hauled his aching body two stories up a shaky aluminum ladder onto the peaked roof of a house in the Pelham Parkway section of the Bronx and began sweeping out the chimney.

title: Creamy Broccoli and Potato Soup
description: Melissa Clark makes broccoli and potato soup with grated Parmesan and a drizzle of olive oil.

title: A Century of Dodge
description: A history of Dodge in pictures, from its early reputation as reliable and unpretentious to its troubles and rebranding efforts today.

title: Inequality and Crises: Scandinavian Skepticism
description: In early December Im supposed to talk at a Columbia conference on inequality and its consequences, and one issue Ill have to address is the ongoing question of whether rising inequality makes countries more vulnerable to financial crises, makes it harder to recover from such crises, or in some other way degrades performance.

title: Rhode Island Investigating Former State Attorney General
description: Rhode Island officials are investigating whether a former attorney general violated state lobbying rules by making appeals to his former colleagues on behalf of a Nevada gambling casino, among other corporate clients, even though he had not registered as a lobbyist.

title: ISIS Taunts United States and Britain in New Video
description: ERBIL, Iraq  The extremist organization known as the Islamic State taunted the United States, in a video released Friday on jihadist websites, for its failed mission to rescue Western hostages held by the group in Syria.

title: Buffalo Snow on Social Media
description: Residents in the Buffalo area used social media to post video of one of the worst storms in recent memory to hit western New York.

title: Bill Cosby Rape Allegations: Readers Respond
description: Timothy R. Williams is a news assistant and comment moderator for The Times.

title: Reimagined Robin Hood To Land on Broadway
description: The Heart of Robin Hood, which has been called a romance, a drama and a comedy, can now call itself headed for Broadway, the producers announced Friday.

title: Times Running Out for the Torture Report
description: Republicans take over the Senate in just a few legislative days. And when they do, they will probably snuff out the last possibility of releasing a huge report on the use of torture by the Central Intelligence Agency during the Bush-Cheney Administration.

title: A Show Now Fully Recovered
description: LOS ANGELES  Its back, and its back on a scale that is well matched to this car-centric city.

title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night.

title: Broccoli and Potato Soup With Rich, Complex Flavors
description: Sometimes its an ingredient that makes a dish shine: an unexpected jolt from lime pickle, say, or the toasty sweetness of a well-placed drizzle of maple syrup. But sometimes its all about technique. And such is the case with this broccoli and potato soup.

title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1.

title: To Delete or Not to Delete: Thats the Uber Question
description: Call it Uber Angst.

title: Dave Hickey, Live at The Peacock Room
description: The convergence of art, money and patronage was the topic at D.C. Moore Gallery in Chelsea on Thursday night. Taking it on were Darren Waterston, one of the gallerys artists, and the critic Dave Hickey, the iconoclastic author of Air Guitar: Essays on Art and Democracy and Pirates and Farmers: Essays on Taste.

title: Insider Tips: Thanksgiving Recipes
description: This week, reporters and editors from the Food section and Times Cooking app suggest Thanksgiving recipes.

title: A Wonder-full Love Story Ends
description: Peter Cott had just learned he had bladder cancer when he was interviewed last year for a Metropolitan cover article about his 58-year love affair with a man named Kenneth Leedom (58 Years and Counting. A Love Story, Sept. 8, 2013). The prognosis at the time was not bad, the couple said. They were newlyweds, declaratively in love, theatrical of bearing, refreshingly salty in their conversation. They were my mothers neighbors.

title: The Contested Site in Jerusalem
description: The holy site in Jerusalems Old City, which Jews call Temple Mount and Muslims call the Noble Sanctuary, has long been a flash point in the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians.

title: Amid Attacks, Obama Presses Congress to Move on Immigration
description: LAS VEGAS  President Obama opened up a campaign on Friday to convince Americans that five million undocumented immigrants should be protected from deportation as he told an audience of mostly Latino high school students that Congress had to revamp what he called the nations broken immigration system.

title: Mozart Melts Into Dark Shostakovich
description: While listening to Mozarts Sinfonia Concertante in E flat for Violin, Viola and Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening, it was hard not to imagine how much better the work will sound when the halls dreary acoustics are refreshed as part of a future renovation and renaming project.

title: William Spoor Dies at 91; Turned Pillsbury Into a Food Industry Giant
description: William Spoor, who rose from poverty to become chief executive of Pillsbury and transform it into a food products mega-company, died on Nov. 14 at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 91.

title: Minnesota Opera President Resigns
description: The Minnesota Opera has long been regarded as a solid, polished regional company with a reputation for commissioning new work. But like many opera companies and orchestras, it has faced budget difficulties in recent years, and those tensions appear to have taken a toll on companys management. Kevin Ramach, the president and executive director of the company since 2012, and its production manager for six years before that, resigned abruptly on Thursday, saying by way of a company announcement that he wanted to return to my creative interests. The Star Tribune reported that Mr. Ramachs predecessor, Allan Naplan, had resigned after only a year on the job.

title: Gurlitts Museum Bequest Is Challenged
description: A cousin has challenged the will of Cornelius Gurlitt hours before the Swiss museum he named in May as his sole heir was poised to accept his bequest of hundreds of artworks collected by Gurlitts father, an art dealer for Hitler. It was not certain whether the move would affect the decision of the Kunstmuseum Bern, expected by early next week. Uta Werner, a cousin of Mr. Gurlitt, applied Friday to the Munich court that is handling his estate for a certificate of inheritance on behalf of herself, several of her children and some other relatives, Thomas Pfaff, a spokesman for the family, said in a statement.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Pictures
Christmas With Death, Heels and Uplift
description: When did the holiday television movie become part of the fabric of Christmasness, as ubiquitous as Mariah Carey or sickeningly sweet lattes? This season there are at least 30 new films on seven networks, a procession that began on Nov. 1 (One Starry Christmas, Hallmark) and continues through Dec. 20 (Back to Christmas, Ion), along with hundreds of reruns from years past. Thats a lot of uplift and bad sweaters.

title: Oregon Health Study: The Surprises in a Randomized Trial
description: The Oregon Health Study upended a lot of conventional thinking about health insurance. The study made use of a 2008 state lottery that randomly assigned some low-income Oregon residents to get insurance from Medicaid and others to remain uninsured. Then it followed them for two years to see what happened.

title: Ferguson Officer Who Killed Teenager Is Said Not to Be Returning to Duty
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  The white police officer who fatally shot an unarmed black teenager here over the summer, setting off months of protests, will not return to duty in the citys police department, those close to him said on Friday, as the region braced for a grand jurys decision on whether to indict him.

title: A Proper Farewell for a Homeless Man Who Was Rich in Friendship
description: By some standards, the gathering of about 15 mourners scattered in the pews of the chapel inside a Harlem funeral home might seem a sparse turnout.

title: New York Chancellor Is Criticized for Remarks on Charter Schools
description: Charter school advocates on Friday demanded that the New York City schools chancellor, Carmen Faria, release data to support her accusation that those schools push some students out before they take state tests and later replace them with high-scoring children.

title: A Symbolic Protest at the Old Courthouse
description: ST LOUIS  At noon on Friday a handful of people performed a mock lynching across the street from the Old Courthouse here as a silent protest of the killings of Michael Brown, who was killed in August by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., and Vonderrit D. Myers Jr., who was killed in October by an off-duty police officer in St. Louis. It was a symbolic location. In 1847, a slave named Dred Scott came to the Old Courthouse to sue for his freedom.

title: Amid Familiar Repertoire, the New York Premiere of an Oceanic Journey
description: Over the 20 seasons in which Michael Tilson Thomas has led the San Francisco Symphony, audiences have come to expect panoramic, innovative programming and clean, incisive playing. But since their four concerts at the American Mavericks festival in March 2012, their Carnegie Hall programs have become predictable.

title: A Youthful Tribute to a Fallen Friend of Art
description: When he was a child, the Brooklyn-based composer and guitarist Bryce Dessner went to a summer camp in the mountains of North Carolina not far from where Black Mountain College had been. This pathbreaking institution was founded in a 1933 as a college with arts at the core of its mission. Until it closed in 1957, faculty members like Josef Albers, John Cage, Willem de Kooning and Buckminster Fuller worked so collaboratively with students that it was hard to know who was learning from whom.

title: The Young Barber and the Innkeepers Daughter, Romping Again
description: Natalia Osipova and Ivan Vasiliev performed their first Don Quixote together, on tour with the Bolshoi Ballet, in 2007, the same year that the Russian businessman Vladimir Kekhman took over as general director of the Mikhailovsky Ballet of St. Petersburg. Their debuts as Kitri, the feisty daughter of an innkeeper, and Basilio, the youthful barber she wants to marry against her fathers wishes, caused a sensation. Similar shock waves were felt throughout the dance world when, in 2011, they announced their decision to jump ship from the Bolshoi in Moscow to the relatively intimate Mikhailovsky.

title: In a New Performance Piece, Tilda Swinton Turns Fashion Into Art
description: The actress Tilda Swinton has for several years collaborated with Olivier Saillard, the director of Pariss Palais Galliera fashion museum, on an annual performance for that citys Festival dAutomne. In 2013, they did Eternity Dress, in which a garment was tailor-made  from measuring and patterning to cutting and sewing  for the actress before a live audience. The year prior, Saillard and Swinton created a piece called The Impossible Wardrobe, in which Swinton walked a selection of beautiful, fragile historical garments from the Palais Gallieras archives (Napoleons tailcoat, an ermine collar worn by Sarah Bernhardt) down a runway.

title: Audience of Ghosts, Taking Orders
description: Instead of seats, we have sheets.

title: Giving His Ex-Wife the Third Degree
description: The fluorescent lights overhead on the spare set of Mac Rogerss espionage thriller Asymmetric, now at the 59E59 Theaters, establish the clinical atmosphere, buttressed by percussive electronic music from the sound designer, Jeanne Travis. The milieu is the Washington intelligence establishment, and the C.I.A.s former ace interrogator, Josh Ruskin (Sean Williams), is yanked out of his drunken retirement by his successor, Zack (Seth Shelden), to extract information from a renegade ex-colleague.

title: When Is a War Over?
description: WARS always hurry their participants, as the Roman poet Horace once wrote of the epics that recount them, into the middle of things, as if they were already known. Wars plunge us violently and deeply into other peoples histories, myths and legends. Perhaps few know this better than one of my West Point colleagues, a major who recently visited my class, full of future Army officers, to discuss his deployment to the Afghan province of Nuristan, high and remote in the Hindu Kush, where ancient legacies coexist with modern war.

title: Poor, Violent and Up for a Dogfight
description: Lusty soap operas about the crazy ways of sneaky, unwashed hillbillies have gone missing on New York stages in recent years. In olden days, when  Tobacco Road ruled Broadway in the 1930s, slick urbanites couldnt get enough of such moonshine. But now, except for those occasions when Tracy Letts (Killer Joe) is feeling folksy and perverse, that genre has been reduced to festering on reality television.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Police Agree to Some of Protesters Rules of Engagement
description: CLAYTON, Mo.  The authorities will abide by many of the rules of engagement proposed by demonstrators once the grand jury decision is announced regarding the shooting death of Michael Brown by Officer Darren Wilson, officials said Friday.

title: Readers Respond: On a Republican South
description: As Republican control and racially polarized politics have grown in the American South during the Obama presidency, so has the willingness of many Southerners to speak frankly about racial divisions in their comments to the Times.

title: Tackling the Story of Domestic Abuse and the N.F.L.
description: It took a graphic video of Ray Rice punching his fiance in the elevator of an Atlantic City hotel to instantly change the conversation on domestic violence in the National Football League. Steve Eder, an investigative sports reporter for The Times, explains how his subsequent reporting delved into abuse in the context of the leagues close-knit culture.

title: Schools Are Closed in Anticipation of Unrest
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Eight schools in one district in the Ferguson area will be closed on Monday and Tuesday in anticipation of a grand jury decision on whether to indict a white police officer in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager in August.

title: Choosing to Look at War Porn
description: Some of the most gruesome images of war, Christoph Bangert argues, should not be hidden, but seen so viewers can get a full documenting of the costs of war.

title: Immigration Enriches You and Me
description: A BOOK, The Christian Examiner, warns that ill-clad and destitute immigrants are repulsive to our habits and our tastes.

title: Crisis Negotiators Give Thanksgiving Tips
description: The hurt feelings and the culture of psychological entrapment. The long-dormant resentments that seem to redouble like fingernails on a corpse.

title: How to Find a Job With Meditation and Mindfulness
description: Meditation has been good for Olivia Chows career.

title: Tiptoeing Through Kurdistan
description: KARS, Turkey  WE have enemies.

title: Looking Again at the Sins of the Father
description: Inescapably playful and undeniably serious, George Bernard Shaws 1905 Major Barbara pits youth against age, poverty against wealth, faith against armored tanks. You might be surprised which side you ultimately take.

title: Isaac Mizrahi, Bridge-Playing Designer
description: What bridge-playing celebrities can you name?

title: Dining in a Pirate Ship of Sorts in Brighton Beach
description: Located in the aptly named Little Odessa neighborhood of Brighton Beach, Gambrinus Seafood Cafe trades in kitsch and shellfish in generous post-Soviet portions. To walk through the wooden doors of this restaurant on the last stretch of Ocean Parkway before it ends at Surf Avenue is to stumble upon a Neverland cove in the middle of a nonstop theme party. Every flat surface is encrusted with nautical dcor, busty pirate mannequins hang from the ceiling and oversize flat screens play music videos on an endless loop.

title: Vape Joins Pot Lingo as Oxfords Word of the Year
description: Back in my day, it was just weed; it was just getting high, said Joel Schneider, 55, sipping a cup of coffee. Vaping? No. Wed never heard of vaping.

title: In Europe, a Resolution to Break Up Google
description: BRUSSELS  Legislators at the European Parliament who have long sought tough antitrust action against Google called on Friday for a resolution suggesting that Google be broken up into separate companies.

title: Cousin of Cornelius Gurlitt Challenges Will That Leaves Collection to Swiss Museum
description: A cousin has challenged the will of Cornelius Gurlitt hours before the Swiss museum he named in May as his sole heir was poised to accept his bequest of hundreds of artworks collected by his father, a leading art dealer for Hitler.

title: Whitney Museum Says Goodbye to Its Old Home
description: The youngish man in wire-rimmed Wayfarers glanced across the dinner table at Hermine Heller, who was fixing him with a puzzled stare. Youre Lyle, Ms. Heller suddenly announced to the artist Lyle Ashton Harris, the object of her fascination and the subject of a Chuck Close portrait displayed in her home. Youve been hanging on my wall for the last 12 years.

title: Netflix Snags New Series Created by Tina Fey and Robert Carlock
description: Tina Fey, a signature star of NBC, and her 30 Rock collaborator Robert Carlock will not be bringing their new series to that network, and will instead be moving it to Netflix, it was announced Friday.

title: Retreats of the Gilded and Bronzed
description: When she was writing The House of Mirth, more than 100 years ago, Edith Wharton sent her character Lawrence Selden to a fashionable town on the Riviera to flee Lily Bart and the New York winter. There, admiring the exotic coquetry of architecture, the studied tropicality of the gardens and groups of beautiful people loitering against the backdrop of purple mountains, he sought refuge from Lily and from Manhattans interminable perspective of snow-burdened days. You may have heard of the place the novelist sent him: Its called Monte Carlo.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Bratton Calls Police Shooting Accidental
description: William J. Bratton, the New York police commissioner, said that the fatal shooting of an unarmed man by a police officer in Brooklyn Thursday was accidental and that the victim was a total innocent.

title: Settlement in Apple Case Over E-Books Is Approved
description: A federal judge on Friday approved a settlement in which Apple could begin paying $400 million to as many as 23 million consumers related to charges that it violated antitrust law by conspiring with publishers to raise e-book prices and thwart efforts by Amazon.

title: Columbia Will Take Look at Football Teams Futility
description: For all its intellectual might, Columbia seemingly cannot find a way to win a football game.

title: Inquiry Focuses on Leaked Documents at Starr King School for the Ministry
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Last May, the night before she was to graduate from Starr King School for the Ministry, in Berkeley, Calif., Suzi Spangenberg pulled up in her car to the schools graduation dinner. Before going inside with her son, Ms. Spangenberg, a candidate for ordination as a Unitarian Universalist, checked her iPhone. She was shocked by the email she found.

title: Change in Health Care Law Would Take Aim at Consumer Inertia
description: People who bought Affordable Care Act health plans for 2014 but who dont go back to shop again for 2015 will automatically keep the plan they first chose, even if its price goes way up.

title: Reported Environmental Incidents in North Dakotas Oil Industry
description: Database of more than 8,600 oil and brine spills related to North Dakotas oil industry.

title: Mary McCartneys Candid Camera
description: Mary McCartney, 45, is the very definition of a someone. The oldest child of the musician Paul McCartney and Linda McCartney, Mary grew up amid wealth, privilege and celebrity. Now a professional photographer based in London, Ms. McCartney has an all-access pass to a vast assortment of glossy events and glittering parties, as well as a long list of elite corporate clients, including Mandarin Oriental Hotel Group and her kid sister Stellas fashion label.

title: Rob Moose: Breathing New Life Into Classical Music
description: AGE 32

title: Stephen Merchant: When Hello Ladies Says Goodbye
description: Last Monday at the American Airlines Theater near Times Square, Stephen Merchant, who is 6 feet 7 inches tall, was on stage attempting to lift Peter Dinklage, who is about 4-foot-5, onto his back.

title: E.P.A. Postpones Setting Standards for Biofuel Blends
description: The Environmental Protection Agency quietly announced on Friday that, after much delay, it had been unable to decide this year on a rule setting levels for the amount of biofuel it would require to be blended into conventional vehicle fuels.

title: Woman Is Arrested With Firearm and Ammunition Outside White House
description: For the second consecutive day, the Secret Service on Thursday arrested someone outside the White House for possessing a firearm and ammunition. Shortly after President Obama completed his address to the nation on immigration, plain-clothed Secret Service officers on Pennsylvania Avenue noticed a woman with a handgun holstered on her belt, law enforcement officials said. Uniformed officers confronted the woman and arrested her, the officials said. The woman, April Lenhart, 23, of Michigan, was charged with possession of an unregistered firearm and unregistered ammunition. One official said that Ms. Lenhart refused to be interviewed by the Secret Service after the incident.

title: Friday Night Music: Jessica Hernandez and the Deltas
description: I have no idea who recommended this, and I normally wouldnt have thought it was my style, but theres no arguing with sheer unadulterated joyousness:

title: Evening Hours | Warm Celebrations
description: Despite the sudden cold, the parties continued.

title: In Zimbabwes Succession Battle, Mugabe Pulls the Strings
description: LONDON  In August, he stood shoulder to shoulder in Beijing with President Xi Jinping of China. Then, in September, he addressed the United Nations to condemn the evil machinations of Western countries seeking his overthrow. And just this month, he eulogized a neighbor and political ally at the state funeral of President Michael Chilufya Sata of Zambia.

title: Recovered Data May Show if I.R.S. Targeted Conservatives
description: The Treasury Department has recovered missing data from Internal Revenue Service systems that may include emails and other documents relevant to inquiries into whether the agency had singled out conservative groups for special scrutiny, congressional investigators saidFriday. The documents belonged to Lois Lerner, a former I.R.S. official whom Republicans have accused of politically motivated misconduct. The I.R.S. has said that Ms. Lerners computer hard drive crashed in mid-2011, destroying thousands of her emails and other data sought by investigators. Republicans in Congress, incensed by what they describe as the agencys effort to thwart investigators, have questioned its claims that the documents are unrecoverable.On Friday, the inspector general of the Treasury Department informed the Senate Finance Committee that a forensic examination had turned up documents thought to have been destroyed. The inspector general plans to assess whether this data can be converted into a readable format and then produce these materials to the committee as soon as they have fully recovered and evaluated them, the committee said in a written statement.

title: Bill Cunningham | Thanksgiving Season
description: Its Thanksgiving week, and the city is full of holiday imagery.

title: V.F.W. Goes Gender-Neutral, Recognizing Female Veterans
description: When the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States secured its congressional charter in 1936, veterans were usually men and the spouses of those who fell in battle were widows. That, of course, is now very different. (Indeed, even during World War II several hundred thousand women served in the United States military, including nurses and members of the Womens Army Corps.) Now, more than 15 percent of active-duty United States service members are female. So the V.F.W. is changing, too, winning congressional approval to alter the wording of its charter. No longer is it a national association of men who served in wartime; it is one of veterans. And it is no longer to assist widows  rather, surviving spouses. The changes, approved at the national convention, were made in bills just passed by the House and Senate. We didnt change our congressional charter to be politically correct, the V.F.W. National Commander, John W. Stroud, said in a statement. We changed it because being an eligible service member or veteran is whats important to our great organization, not ones gender.

title: Grand Tour of the Self
description: BARCELONA, Spain  From the castle grounds atop Montjuic, you can see the warrens of the old city running into the Dr. Seussian spires of the new one that sprouted from Antoni Gauds imagination. Below or up high, Barcelona is a tapas menu of urban surprise.

title: Madagascar: Plague Outbreak Kills 40
description: The World Health Organization reported Friday that an outbreak of plague, the infamous scourge that killed millions in the Dark Ages, has been recorded in parts of Madagascar, the Indian Ocean island nation off the coast of southeastern Africa. In an alert posted on its website, the W.H.O. said at least 119 plague cases, including 40 deaths, had been confirmed since the nations Health Ministry identified the first case nearly three months ago. The statement said cases had been reported in seven regions, including the capital, Antananarivo, raising the risk of a rapid spread of the disease due to the citys high population density and the weakness of the health care system. Efforts to combat the outbreak, the statement said, have been hampered because fleas, the primary spreader of the disease, have developed resistance to an insecticide used to kill them.

title: Bill Cunningham | Thanksgiving Season
description: Its Thanksgiving week, and the city is full of holiday imagery. In the Greenmarket at Union Square the colors and freshness of the produce stand out. Some vendors carved out pumpkins and gourds and filled them with water and flowers, a great idea for the table on Thursday. Shoppers carried armloads of autumnal berries, grasses and flowers. A vendor carved a face on the side of a vegetable. Many women seemed dressed to match the white pumpkins. Just as the last of the golden ginkgo leaves formed a backdrop for fashion and the lions, adding to the spirit was the arrival of the Rockefeller Center tree.

title: Mr. Obamas Wise Immigration Plan
description: President Obamas speech Thursday night on immigration ended on a high, hopeful note. Mr. Obama, quoting Scriptures admonition to welcome and protect the stranger, told millions who have lived and worked here for years, many of them Americans in all but name: We cannot fix your situation yet, but for now we will not expel you, because we have better hopes for you here.

title: Judge Rejects Overhaul of Illinoiss Beleaguered State Pension System
description: An Illinois judge on Friday rejected the states effort to bolster its shaky public pension system, giving public workers a reason to rejoice that could prove short-lived.

title: F.S.U. Coachs Call-In Show Is a No-Sin Zone
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  What is it about this team, this year, that throughout your career youll always remember?

title: Will Pot Pack New Yorks Courts?
description: THIS week the New York City Police Department shifted from making arrests to issuing tickets for possessing small amounts of marijuana. The problem is that most people, frankly, do not understand how summons court, which processes such tickets, operates.

title: Obama Asks Ferguson Protesters for Peace
description: In an interview with ABC News, President Obama said that protesters in Ferguson, Mo., should keep protests peaceful and that there would be no excuse for violence.

title: Saturdays College Football Games to Watch
description: 24 U.S.C. at 11 U.C.L.A.

title: In a Shift, Obama Extends U.S. Role in Afghan Combat
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama decided in recent weeks to authorize a more expansive mission for the military in Afghanistan in 2015 than originally planned, a move that ensures American troops will have a direct role in fighting in the war-ravaged country for at least another year.

title: Robert Plant: Intro
description: Part 1: Carol Olsen Day, director of TimesTalks, introduces the musician Robert Plant.

title: Plant: What I Learned in Nashville
description: Part 4: The musician reflects on his late-in-life appreciation of American country music and roots music.

title: Plant: Griots and the Bendir
description: Part 3: The musician talks about discovering the music of North Africa and the musicians of that region he admires most.

title: Plant: Whatever It Is That Old People Do
description: Part 2: The musician recalls his earliest exposure to rock n roll and explains the influences behind his new album.

title: Plant: Collaboration and Inspiration

title: Plant: The Guys From the Yardbirds
description: Part 5: The musician reminisces about his early days as a singer and explains why he started singing in a high register.

title: Plant: Returning to Songwriting
description: Part 8: The musician reflects on how his songwriting has evolved since his Led Zeppelin days and explains what he tries to avoid as a songwriter.

title: Plant: Robert Plant vs. Damon Albarn
description: Part 15: The musician reflects on the difference between his approach to world music and that of the indie frontman Damon Albarn.

title: Plant: Recording No Quarter

title: Plant: Led Zeppelin Lyrics

title: Plant: When the Levee Breaks
description: Part 17: The musician talks about why Led Zeppelin wouldnt play certain songs live.

description: Part 11: The musician recalls his 2003 trip to Mali and explains what he learned from playing with musicians there.
