description: Part 10: The musician reflects on his solo career and reminisces about his relationship with the music mogul Ahmet Ertegun.

title: Roger Federer Is Dealt an Unlikely Defeat at Davis Cup
description: VILLENEUVE DASCQ, France  The largest crowd to watch an officially sanctioned tennis match got nothing but a tie on Friday, which is good for all those who like their Davis Cup with a hearty helping of suspense.

title: TimesTalks | Robert Plant: Preview
description: The rock icon talks about his long career, his evolution as a songwriter, his passion for North African music and his hunger for collaboration.

title: This Time, the Protesters in Ferguson May Decide to Pass
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  When protests broke out here after the police shooting of an unarmed black teenager in August, James Bass knew he had to hit the streets. His father lived in Ferguson, he lived close by, and like many young black men in the St. Louis area, Mr. Bass wanted his voice to be heard.

title: Four Decades of Solitary in Louisiana
description: Richard Nixon was president when Albert Woodfox landed in solitary confinement, along with another inmate, both convicted of the 1972 murder of a Louisiana prison guard named Brent Miller.

title: Internal Delphi Email on Defective Ignition Switch
description: This email is the first publicly disclosed document showing Delphis long-time concerns with the switch and demonstrates how G.M. pushed Delphi to manufacture a defective part.

title: A Longtime Islander Is Taking Winning in Stride
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The Islanders are a humble group after a rocky 2013-14 season, when expectations were high only to be dashed by injuries and too many early losses.

title: Dr. Donald F. Steiner, Diabetes Researcher, Dies at 84
description: Dr. Donald F. Steiner, a researcher whose discoveries transformed scientists understanding of insulin and other hormones and led to major improvements in the treatment of diabetes, died on Nov. 11 at his home in Chicago. He was 84.

title: A Billionaires Hudson River Project
description: So, what do you think of the latest idea for Hudson River Park: a performance space, with forested glades and an amphitheater, on an undulating platform over Pier 54?

title: Why Congress Can Impeach Obama
description: NOW that President Obama has granted legal relief to as many as five million undocumented immigrants, Republicans are thrashing about for an effective response. Only a few hard-liners are talking about impeachment now, but more could join them out of frustration with their other options.

title: A Push for Legal Aid in Civil Cases Finds Its Advocates
description: LOS ANGELES  Lorenza and German Artiga raised six children in a rent-controlled bungalow here, their only home since they moved from El Salvador 29 years ago.

title: G.M. Bullied Manufacturer Over Poorly Designed Part, Email Says
description: DETROIT  General Motors pressured a supplier to continue producing a substandard ignition switch a decade ago and leaned on the company to improve it even though it could not be fixed, a newly disclosed email shows.

title: Richard Eder, Arts Critic and Foreign Correspondent, Dies at 82
description: Richard Eder, a former foreign correspondent for The New York Times who became a film and drama critic there and eventually won a Pulitzer Prize for his book reviews in The Los Angeles Times, died on Friday in Boston. He was 82.

title: ISIS Releases New Propaganda Video
description: In the latest video released by the Islamic State, the British hostage John Cantlie described a failed rescue attempt and encouraged the United States and Britain to negotiate with his captors.

title: Public Housing Patrols Can Mean Safety or Danger
description: For a police officer, the stairwells of New York Citys public housing complexes can be menacing places of drug deals, domestic disputes, thievery and gang violence, where nerves can cause missteps that, in an instant, can end in tragedy.

title: Where El Nuevo Herald Is Read
description: Administrivial Win Valuable Prizes Alert! Theres a new tournament in town, and its called the Indie 500. Hosted by New York Times constructors Evan Birnholz, Andy Kravis, Neville Fogarty, Peter Broda and Erik Agard, it will take place on May 20, 2015 in Washington, D.C. and has nothing to do with race cars but will most definitely rev your solving engines. Also, they are generously opening submissions to a fifth constructor. That could be you! Look at you, with a puzzle in a tournament. You really rock, you know that? Show these guys what you can do by clicking here.

title: Struggling to Overcome Depression and Return to the Working World
description: Idleness has a way of creeping up on Kevin Williams.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 21, 2014
Britain: 12 Are Injured in Blast at Hotel
description: At least 12 people were hurt in what the police said they suspected was a natural-gas explosion in the basement of a central London hotel just before midnight Friday. The Hyatt Regency London  The Churchill, a luxury hotel in Portman Square, was evacuated temporarily after the blast, which was believed to be in a kitchen area, and injured people were treated at the scene, the Metropolitan Police said. Six people were taken to hospitals. Most of the injured were believed to be kitchen staff. None of the injuries were thought to be life-threatening. Dennis Luwer, who lives opposite the hotel, told the BBC that a hole had been blown in the side of the building.

title: Sons Killing Prompts Woman to Seek Child Welfare Inquiry
description: Poseidon Quinones had parents, but neither of them was deemed fit to care for him by New York Citys child welfare agency.

title: At Sothebys Interiors Auction, an Intimate Portrait of an Heiress
description: If there was one word to describe the collection of shabby chairs, chipped console tables, battered settees and assorted porcelain replicas of vegetables once owned by the late heiress, and apparent magpie, Rachel Lambert Mellon, known as Bunny, and auctioned off at Sothebys on Friday afternoon, it was patina.

title: Texas, No Longer in Panic Mode, Defeats California to Win 2K Classic
description: Two years ago, almost to the day, Texas lost to Division II Chaminade in the Round of 8 at the Maui Invitational. Panic spread through the Texas fan base, with the vitriol directed namely at Coach Rick Barnes, who once recruited Kevin Durant, LaMarcus Aldridge and D. J. Augustin, and now seemed to be at a crossroads with the program.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 10 P.M. (HBO) HELLO LADIES: THE MOVIE (2014) Stephen Merchant reprises his role as Stuart Pritchard, the gawky British transplant desperate to enter the realm of the beautiful people in Los Angeles  who are loath to let him in. In this 80-minute film, which wraps up the canceled series, Stuart learns that his former girlfriend is in town with her husband and sets out to impress them by hiring a Russian model to play his latest love.

title: For Some Fans, Accusations of Rape Crumble Bill Cosbys Wholesome Image
description: As woman after woman has come forward to accuse Bill Cosby of sexual assault, there has been growing public revulsion, but also a nagging question: Did it have to be Cliff Huxtable?

title: Hong Kong Moves to Refashion Itself as a Global Hub of Creativity
description: HONG KONG  When Candace Campos moved from the United States to Hong Kong six years ago, she encountered few hurdles to opening her own interior design company.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: A Community in Connecticut Remembers World War I
description: A visitor might be excused for getting a little shellshocked while roaming through the Gunn Memorial Library and Museum in the town of Washington in Litchfield County.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Hurting others or destroying property is not the answer. No matter what the grand jury decides, I do not want my sons death to be in vain. I want it to lead to incredible change  positive change, change that makes the St. Louis region better for everyone.

title: Corrections: November 22, 2014
description: SPORTS

title: In St. Louis, a Mock Lynching
description: A handful of people performed a mock lynching across the street from St. Louis Old Courthouse as a silent protest of the police killings of Michael Brown and Vonderitt D. Myers, Jr.

title: Weekly Wrap
description: Hello Times Insiders,

title: The Daily Gift: A Spinning Studio, Brought Home
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: Digging Into the Cheddar
description: Craig Gile, 34, is a cheese grader for the Cabot Creamery Cooperative in Cabot, Vt.

title: The Introvert on the Podium
description: Editors note: Heres one of our favorite stories from the archives, now being featured in our Smarter Living collection.

title: The Week That Shook the Fed
description: The Federal Reserve Board prefers to operate in a shroud of secrecy, and its officials really dont like having to answer to anybody.

title: Does Wall Street Like Gridlock? It Depends on the Grid
description: Wall Street likes gridlock. That claim has been made for decades.

title: Brewing Your Own Beer, With Help From an App
description: Two years ago, craft beers were scarce in the pubs of Northern Ireland. The taps were dominated instead by megabrands like Guinness, Harp and Heineken.

title: Conspicuous Consumption? Yes, but Its Not Crazy
description: Theres no denying the over-the-top flavor of much high-end consumption these days. A Reinast toothbrush, of solid titanium, sells for $4,200 even though it may not get your teeth any cleaner than a $2 toothbrush from Walgreens. Then theres the Greubel Forsey Double Tourbillon 30 Technique, a platinum wristwatch that sells for scores of thousands of dollars. Its intricate mechanical works may be a masterpiece of traditional engineering, but for that, you might keep your day-to-day appointments just as well with a $40 Timex.

title: A 70s Experiment, Relived in SoHo
description: Once upon a time, there was a lot of affordable loft space in SoHo. The dance and video artist Cathy Weis still occupies one such space  WeisAcres, she calls it  and this year, she has been opening the sprawling studio on Sunday nights for performances, film screenings and conversations. The free series, Sundays on Broadway, has been a low-key delight, and it continues this week with a program organized by the choreographer Catherine Galasso.

title: Hey, Im Going 55. Cough Up the Cash.
description: Dont think about this too hard, or youll be dismayed, but paying people to drive at the speed limit seems to be a better behavior modifier than pointing out to them that they might run over a small child or frail grandmother (or get a ticket).

title: Gyrating Antidote to Holiday Pounds
description: Dancing off Thanksgiving can be done pre-emptively or post-facto. Time Warp, a festival that started in Germany in 1994 and favors the crisp, abstract, un-pop propulsion of minimal techno, is making its first United States appearance. It includes 19 D.J.s over two nights, among them techno and house stalwarts like Dubfire, performing as a live hybrid Friday, and Sven Vath, Richie Hawtin and Josh Wink on Saturday. (9 p.m., 39th Street Pier, Sunset Park; time-warp.de/usa.)

title: From Tragic Tess To Prancing Bear
description: Nastassja Kinski was barely 20 when she starred in Paul Schraders erotic horror film, Cat People, as one of the last descendants of a prehistoric race whose women mated with leopards. In the heat of sex with humans, the women morphed into savage black felines who killed their lovers. The 1982 movie has a memorable score by Giorgio Moroder.

title: When Authorship Is Beside the Point
description: Since Marcel Duchamps Big Bang of 1913, when he declared mundane store-bought objects  a snow shovel, a dog-grooming comb  to be art if artists said so, cosmic echoes of the ready-made idea have bounded around the aesthetic universe in powerful and unpredictable ways.

title: A Beethoven Teaser and a Rare Cyrano
description: The Dutch conductor and violinist Jaap van Zweden was not well known in America when he took over as music director of the Dallas Symphony Orchestra in 2008. Appointing this dynamic musician proved wise. The orchestra and audiences in Dallas embraced him. Having made an enthusiastically received debut with the New York Philharmonic in 2010, he returns this week.

title: At Spains Door, a Welcome Mat for Entrepreneurs
description: Last year, after more than a decade in Silicon Valley, Stacia Carr helped sell the company she was running and went looking for a change of pace.

title: The Fight for $15.37 an Hour
description: Most Sunday mornings last summer, Julia Gould set up a table at the Hollywood Farmers Market. Alongside stalls selling shiitake mushrooms, free-range poultry and orange-blossom honey, she was selling an idea: a $15.37-an-hour minimum wage for the citys hotel workers  more than twice the federal minimum wage and one of the highest minimum wages in the nation.

title: Cruising to Christmas Markets
description: What started as a way toincreaseoff-season occupancy has turned into a high-occupancy rush as river cruise lines capitalize on the Christmas markets of Europe.

title: An Upper East Side Mansion for $50.25 Million
description: A formidable Italian Renaissance-style limestone mansion, built in 1909 as a 17,000-square-foot private home and later occupied by the now-defunct art gallery Knoedler & Company for nearly four decades, sold for $50.25 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Variety: Sit for a Spell
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  If this Variety Puzzle looks somewhat familiar to you, its because you are probably jonesing for Will Shortzs 3-D Word Hunt, which has appeared in the winter for the last few years. Im told that there is no set schedule for that particular puzzle, but Sit for a Spell turns out to be a nice substitute.

title: A Deep 2016 Republican Presidential Field Reflects Party Divisions
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  Republican presidential primaries have for decades been orderly affairs, with any momentary drama mitigated by the expectation that the party would inevitably nominate its tested, often graying front-runner.

title: The Wisdom of Peter Schiff
description: No, seriously. Well, sort of. Danny Vinik sends us to the latest from Schiff, who made a big splash in 2008-2009 predicting runaway inflation if not hyperinflation; he was a favorite of Glenn Becks.

title: Disappearing Glaciers Could Change Western Ecosystem
description: In 30 years, there may be no glaciers left in Glacier National Park in Montana.

title: Climate Change Threatens to Strip the Identity of Glacier National Park
description: GLACIER NATIONAL PARK, Mont.  What will they call this place once the glaciers are gone?

title: Thousands of Iraq Chemical Weapons Destroyed in Open Air, Watchdog Says
description: The United States recovered thousands of old chemical weapons in Iraq from 2004 to 2009 and destroyed almost all of them in secret and via open-air detonation, according to a written summary of its activities prepared by the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, the international body that monitors implementation of the global chemical weapons treaty.

title: Unlawful Assembly Arrests in Ferguson
description: Three people were charged with unlawful assembly overnight in protests in Ferguson, Mo., law enforcement authorities said early Saturday, as the St. Louis region awaits a grand jurys decision on whether to indict a white police officer who shot an unarmed black teenager.

title: Mistrust Threatens Delicate Balance at a Sacred Site in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEM  Amid roiling unrest over a contested Old City holy site, the Palestine Liberation Organization this month declared that the name used for the site by Jews, the Temple Mount, was null and void. Instead, the group said, the compound  a symbol for all Palestinians  must be called Al Aqsa Mosque or the Noble Sanctuary.

title: Missouri Governor, Trying to Keep Balance on Ferguson, Finds Its Easy to Slip
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  From the very first days of the protests over the police shooting of an unarmed black man here, Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri has been accused of hitting the wrong notes at the wrong times.

title: Daniel Snyder Bellows in Comic Opera of the Redskins
description: Once upon a time, the Redskins were a bedrock franchise of the N.F.L., a perennial playoff team and a winner of three Super Bowls. The paranoiac coach George Allen took calls from the paranoiac president Richard Nixon, who even drew up a few plays for the team. Quarterbacks Sonny Jurgensen, Joe Theismann, Billy Kilmer and Doug Williams piled up wins. Many years, all that Republicans and Democrats could agree upon was their passion for this team.

title: The Impact of Obamas Immigration Plan Across California
description: The patchwork of regulations in President Obamas executive action will resonate in different ways for foreign workers in Silicon Valley, farmworkers in the Central Valley and entrepreneurs in Los Angeles. The changes may prevent deportation of more than half of the roughly 2.5 million who are in the state illegally.

title: A Mississippi Stadium, a Civil Rights Crucible
description: The night before federal marshals escorted James Meredith onto the campus of the University of Mississippi, where he was trying to become the first black student to enroll, the universitys highly ranked football team faced Kentucky. That game, on Sept. 29, 1962, was played in the state of Mississippis largest and most prestigious showcase, Veterans Memorial Stadium in Jackson, the capital.

title: The Bay Area and Silicon Valley
description: While there are a significant number of unauthorized workers in this area, much of the focus has been on legal, temporary workers. San Francisco and San Jose are among the top areas that request H-1B visas for highly skilled workers, and the presidents plan disappointed the tech community by not increasing the cap on the number of H-1Bs issued. The plan does help fill science and technology jobs by expanding a program that allows foreign students to remain in the country temporarily for training.

title: Studying for the Test by Taking It
description: PROTESTS are flaring up in pockets of the country against the proliferation of standardized tests. For many parents and teachers, school has become little more than a series of workout sessions for the assessment du jour.

title: The Race Conversation
description: Readers respond to a series of columns by

title: The Making of an Imperial President
description: LET me be clear, as he likes to say: I believe that President Obama was entirely sincere when he ran for president as a fierce critic of the imperial executive. I believe that he was in earnest when he told supporters in 2008 that Americas biggest problems involved George Bush trying to bring more and more power into the executive branch and not go through Congress at all. I believe he meant it when he cast himself as a principled civil libertarian, when he pledged to defer to Congress on war powers, when he promised to abjure privileges Bush had claimed.

title: Promiscuous College Come-Ons
description: BETWEEN the last application season and the current one, Swarthmore College, a school nationally renowned for its academic rigor, changed the requirements for students vying to be admitted into its next freshman class.

title: John Mackey
description: John Mackey is the co-founder and co-chief executive officer of Whole Foods Market, the nations largest chain of natural foods supermarkets.

title: Faster Broadband for Schools and Libraries
description: Next month, the Federal Communications Commission will consider a proposal from its chairman, Tom Wheeler, that would raise taxes on phone lines by a modest 16 cents a month to make sure that every public school and library has reliable and fast Internet connections. The commissioners should vote yes.

title: The Piecemeal Assault on Health Care
description: Now that they will dominate both houses of Congress, Republicans are planning to dismantle the Affordable Care Act piece by piece instead of trying to repeal it entirely.

title: Jerusalems Train to Nowhere
description: JERUSALEM  ON Tuesday, two young Palestinian men from East Jerusalem attacked a synagogue at the citys western edge. Wielding butcher knives, axes and a gun, they murdered four Jewish worshipers and wounded several others, including a policeman who later died. They were both shot at the scene.

title: Dealing With North Koreas Brutality
description: A United Nations committee has sided with millions of powerless North Koreans by voting to condemn their government for human rights abuses and recommending the prosecution of the regimes leaders for crimes against humanity at the International Criminal Court. The General Assembly is expected to do the same and then put the issue to the Security Council.

title: Stampeding Black Elephants
description: SYDNEY, Australia  I PARTICIPATED in the World Parks Congress in Sydney last week and learned a new phrase: a black elephant. A black elephant, explained the London-based investor and environmentalist Adam Sweidan, is a cross between a black swan (an unlikely, unexpected event with enormous ramifications) and the elephant in the room (a problem that is visible to everyone, yet no one still wants to address it) even though we know that one day it will have vast, black-swan-like consequences.

title: The Conflict and the Coverage
description: THIS is the column I never wanted to write.

title: Companions in Misery
description: I had just arrived home from my summer vacation  a week in a Minnesota cabin whose brochure warned no crabbiness allowed  when I came upon a study that declared New York the unhappiest city in America. I doubt many people were surprised by the results  New Yorkers, both in lore and reality, can be hard to please, and famously outspoken about their grievances  but as a born-and-raised New Yorker, and as a philosopher, I was suspicious of how the study defined happiness.

title: Writing to the Beat
description: Rhythm has informed my writing from as early as I can remember. It all began with the beat.

title: After Fans Jump Around, Wisconsins Band Keeps the Place Hopping
description: Before there was Jump Around, there was Youve Said It All.

title: The Rules of Psychotherapy
description: When Julia first appeared in my office, she was approaching her 35th birthday. She had resolved it would be her last.

title: Central Valley
description: Nearly 40 percent of immigrants in the Central Valley are estimated to be here illegally, and nearly half of them are employed in agriculture. Some farmworkers may benefit from the presidents executive action because they have children born in the United States. But for the many farmworkers who have no family here, their status will remain the same.

title: G.O.P.-Led Benghazi Panel Bolsters Administration
description: WASHINGTON  A report released late Friday about the fatal 2012 attacks in Benghazi, Libya, left Republicans in the same position they have been in for two years: with little evidence to support their most damning critiques of how the Obama administration, and then-Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, responded to the attacks.

title: Thrill Is Gone; So Is Donovan
description: CARSON, Calif.  For someone who can make playing soccer look so easy, Landon Donovan has never been shy about conveying how hard the sport can be for him. He has made no secret that the responsibility and the trappings that came with being the standard-bearer of American soccer for more than a decade had long ago become a burden, and that in recent years he had begun to view his talent not so much as a gift, but as an obligation.

title: Landon Donovan on His Sabbatical, His Time in Europe and His Retirement
description: Los Angeles Galaxy midfielder Landon Donovan, who will retire after Major League Soccers playoffs, sat down with Billy Witz in October to discuss the end of his career for a profile that appeared in Sundays Times. Among the other topics of discussion that day:

title: Hours Drive Outside Kabul, Taliban Reign
description: CHARKALAH, Afghanistan  The explosion ripped through the floor of the Humvee, tearing a hole in the armored vehicle and injuring the district governor. The crack of Taliban gunfire followed.

title: Jersey City: A Flower Blossoming as a New Colossus
description: On a warm Saturday in Jersey City last month, the siren call of the sofa and cable television was probably a bit muted for many residents.

title: In Iran Talks, U.S. Seeks to Prevent a Covert Weapon
description: VIENNA  Behind the efforts to close a nuclear deal with Iran this weekend lies a delicate question that has been little discussed in public: how to design an agreement to maximize the chances that Western intelligence agencies would catch any effort to develop an atomic bomb at a covert site.

title: The Downside of the Boom
description: North Dakota took on the oversight of a multibillion-dollar oil industry with a regulatory system built on trust, warnings and second chances.

title: An Eye for the 20th Century
description: In his mid-20s and residing in Paris, Roy R. Neuberger read a biography of Vincent van Gogh that crystallized his commitment to contemporary art. Appalled by van Goghs struggles to sell his paintings during his lifetime, Mr. Neuberger returned to New York determined to find a way to support artists in the United States. Until his death in 2010, at the age of 107, he did just that.

title: Asias Big Guy Spreads Cash and Seeks Influence in Pacific Region
description: BEIJING  When Chinas leader, Xi Jinping, visited the Australian state of Tasmania last week, he was greeted by a front page of the local newspaper written in Chinese. He ate the islands salmon, which will soon be available in China, and met a rare beast known as the Tasmanian devil.

title: Roger Federer Has Davis Cup Within Reach
description: VILLENEUVE DASCQ, France  Cowbells, anyone?

title: Barriers Set Up Around St. Louis County Police Headquarters
description: CLAYTON, Mo.  Officials here set up barriers around the county Police Headquarters on Saturday and prepared to restrict traffic near the courthouse where grand jurors have been deliberating, part of the St. Louis areas continued preparations for unrest.

title: Fighting to Preserve Sag Harbors Literary Flavor
description: There was a time, less than a decade ago, when five bookstores contributed to the literary mystique in Sag Harbor. You could smell it on a deep inhale: the salty air, the worn wood, the books.

title: Roll Over, Mahler: U.S. Orchestras Are Shrinking
description: Composers have long dreamed of bigger orchestras.

title: Far From Perfect, Harvard Ends Impeccably Against Yale
description: BOSTON  With a brisk wind in his face, more than 30,000 chilled fans in thrall and an unblemished season on the line, Harvard quarterback Conner Hempel paid all of the above no heed. His right shoulder sore and wobbly, his team similarly shaken after surrendering a 17-point lead, Hempel coolly directed a winning drive Saturday in a wild finish.

title: An Old Recipe for Success at Sherwoods, in Larchmont
description: Twenty-five years in, Jack Hekker, the owner of Sherwoods in Larchmont, knows he may have to make a few changes.

title: In Ferguson, Protesting and Waiting
description: Demonstrators took to the streets again on Friday night as they awaited a grand jurys decision on whether to indict Officer Darren Wilson in the fatal shooting of Michael Brown.

title: Marshall, Aiming High, Earns Few Style Points in Latest Win
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Unbeaten Marshall escaped with a 23-18 victory over Alabama-Birmingham on Saturday, but the Thundering Herd were in no mood to discuss how an unimpressive performance could affect their chances of playing in a New Years bowl game.

title: The Real Thing, Like Spicy Numbing Frogs
description: So heres a dining situation that brims with promise. Youre at a restaurant devoted to a particular regional cuisine, and every patron except you is from that region  as is the waiter, whos attempting gently to steer you away from Menu Item X toward something you will like more.

title: Bidding in Government Auction of Airwaves Reaches $34 Billion
description: WASHINGTON  A government auction of airwaves for use in mobile broadband has blown through presale estimates, becoming the biggest auction in the Federal Communications Commissions history and signaling that wireless companies expect demand for Internet access by smartphones to continue to soar.

title: Arizona States Elevation to Division I Alters Hockeys Profile in the West
description: On a sunny 74-degree day in Tempe, Ariz., as most other college hockey teams were snowed in or coping with freezing temperatures, Arizona State made a surprise announcement that it would join N.C.A.A. Division I next season.

title: New Jersey Restaurants Offer Training and Work-for-a-Meal Programs
description: On a break from working the cash register at Kula Cafe here recently, Lanashia Paige, 19, contemplated her future in the restaurant business.

title: Community Leaders Criticize Police Over Fatal Shooting of Unarmed Brooklyn Man
description: Two days after an unarmed black man was shot and killed by a police officer in a darkened stairwell of a Brooklyn housing project, community leaders expressed exasperation with the pace of change at the New York Police Department.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Growing Criticism Confronts The N.F.L.

title: Surround Sound
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  First, if you are wondering, 66 Across needs to be pronounced ROTSY (ROTC) PAPARAZZI in order for it to work. The Reserve Officers Training Corps is abbreviated ROTC and sometimes pronounced as a kind of acronym.

title: With Borscht and Rifle Scopes, Volunteers Power Ukraine Forces
description: DNEPROPETROVSK, Ukraine  In a cramped kitchen that smelled strongly of cabbage and beets, a small army of women labored into the night, preparing what would become dried borscht to supply Ukrainian soldiers in the field.

title: Shoppers on Long Island Are Getting a Culinary Lift
description: It was a Friday night at Roosevelt Field mall in Garden City, and after doing some shopping, Andrea Morra sat with her husband, Christopher, at Havana Central and sipped pink rum punch through a straw. A framed poster of Lucy and Desi presided over the restaurants tropical-themed banquettes, slow-moving ceiling fans and crowded bar. As Mr. Morra dug into guava-glazed pork ribs, a live salsa band set up for the evening performance.

title: An Ethnic Chinese Christian, Breaking Barriers in Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Jakarta, the sprawling Indonesian megacity of 10 million people, has a new governor with a difference.

title: Giants and Tom Coughlin Near a Crossroads
description: During an August interview a week before the Giants opening game, one of the teams owners, John Mara, spent nearly an hour analyzing the changes that had been made to the roster in the off-season.

title: Europe Takes Stronger Measures, Albeit Symbolic, to Condemn Israeli Policies
description: LONDON  European nations, Israels largest trading partners and a historical bastion of support, are taking stronger measures to support Palestinian sovereignty and condemn what many see as aggressive, expansionist Israeli policies.

title: Mondays Matchup: Jets (2-8) at Bills (5-5)
description: 7 p.m. Monday, in Detroit

title: Sundays Matchup: Cowboys (7-3) at Giants (3-7)
description: 8:30 p.m., NBC

title: Texas Man Treasures Finds in Updikes Trash
description: MANCHACA, Tex.  A man can get rich off his old emails and aborted novels, if that man is Ian McEwan. This spring, Mr. McEwan, 66, the Booker Prize-winning author of Atonement and On Chesil Beach, fetched $2 million for his archive from the Harry Ransom Center at the University of Texas at Austin.

title: The Election Is Over, but Many Candidates Are Still Running
description: The Texas Legislature will start the 2015 session with a handful of empty chairs and unfinished elections.

title: Injuries Can Help in the Long Run
description: At home on Friday night, the Oklahoma City Thunder were leading the underwhelming Nets, 53-49, at halftime. In any other season, a victory would have been all but certain, but in this season of rapidly diminishing expectations for Oklahoma City, the Thunder slowly let the game go the Nets way.

title: For One Night, She Felt Like Cinderella at the Ball
description: Little things can make a big difference. Things like a dress. And going to the prom.

title: Tight Bond Between Abbott and Aide
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  After his decisive election as the next governor of Texas earlier this month, one of Greg Abbotts first orders of business was naming Daniel Hodge to lead his transition team.

title: Saints Revisit Days of Futility, Without the Fun
description: NEW ORLEANS  For two decades starting in the late 1960s, fans supported the New Orleans Saints as lovable losers. O.K., they were not always lovable. The Saints once lost so many games that they lost a consonant and became the Aints. Some fans wore bags on their heads. But they still showed up as clever contrarians.

title: After Years With Caregivers, Cherishing Her Independence
description: For Dejulaira Lopez, trust is in short supply. At 2 years old, she became a ward of the state and spent the next 18 years in more than half a dozen foster homes, where, she said, she often experienced physical and emotional abuse.

title: Opening Her Home to Many Children, and Worrying About Keeping Out the Cold
description: A row of free-standing two-story houses sits on a quiet street in the Bronx near Soundview Park. On one of the houses, dark red brick and trim complement the cream-colored siding. In early October, orange curtains and fake spiders hung in the bay window and a plastic pumpkin sat below them.

title: In Ferguson, Preparation and Anticipation as Grand Jury Decision Nears
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  The grand jury weighing charges against a white police officer who shot an unarmed black teenager has not reached a decision and will continue considering the case, people with knowledge of it said Saturday. It is possible that the grand jury will not meet again until Monday.

title: Raleigh Trevelyan, Chronicler of a Notable Family, Dies at 91
description: Raleigh Trevelyan traced his family across five centuries of British history, a rich delta of ancestor-achievers that included Sir Walter Raleigh, the 16th-century explorer; Thomas Babington Macaulay, an influential 19th-century politician; and a parade of historians, colonial governors, military men and martyrs of various rebellions across the empire.

title: Victor Elmaleh, 95, Builder and Entrepreneur, Is Dead
description: One translation of Victor Elmalehs Arabic last name is the master, and he lived up to it. He imported some of the first Volkswagens to the United States. He developed $7 billion worth of real estate. He painted more than 4,000 watercolors, most of them small-scale, which were shown in many gallery exhibitions. He won national championships in handball and squash and a squash tournament at 81.

title: After Snow, Western New York Prepares for Floods
description: BUFFALO  As dump trucks, plows and payloaders continued laboring to clear snow as high as seven feet, western New York girded on Saturday for the feared second act of the storm  widespread flooding.

title: Los Angeles
description: Unauthorized immigrants in Los Angeles are among the most settled in the country  many have been here at least 10 years. They contribute to about 7 percent of the regions economy. This area, which has more than one million unauthorized immigrants, had the largest number of people who were approved for a two-year deportation deferral under the presidents initial program that began in 2012.

title: Turmoil Over Immigration Status? California Has Lived It for Decades
description: LOS ANGELES  There may be no better place than California to measure the contradictions, crosswinds and confusion that come with trying to change immigration law.

title: Lawyer Who Represented Bin Laden Kin Is Sentenced in Tax Case
description: A defense lawyer who represented a son-in-law of Osama bin Laden on terrorism charges was sentenced to 18 months in prison on Friday for impeding the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Boy, 12, Shot and Wounded by Cleveland Police Officer
description: A Cleveland police officer shot and wounded a 12-year-old boy who was carrying what turned out to be a fake pistol outside a recreation center on Saturday after witnesses said the boy had brandished the gun on a playground, the authorities said.

title: Chrysler Details Its Plans to Improve Recall Efforts
description: Chrysler agrees with federal regulators that roughly 1.6 million Jeeps being recalled over a deadly fire hazard in rear-impact crashes are not being fixed quickly enough, and it plans to improve, according to a letter the automaker sent to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration on Friday.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 22, 2014
One Game In, Knicks Jose Calderon Has More Wins Than 76ers
description: About 10 minutes before the opening tip, Jose Calderon stood at midcourt while a Knicks trainer massaged his right leg. Injuries had kept Calderon out of the lineup since training camp, but he was set to make his season debut Saturday night at Madison Square Garden. His mere presence was a source of hope for the Knicks.

title: A Controversial Prosecutor
description: A look at Robert P. McCulloch, the St. Louis County prosecutor in the grand jury case of Officer Darren Wilson. Protesters argue that he should have recused himself from the case.

title: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 23, 2014
description: My parents are going to be able to qualify under this program.

title: Amanda Murphy, Anthony Piccirillo
description: Amanda Marie Murphy, the daughter of Tina M. Murphy and Daniel P. Murphy of Lebanon, N.J., was married Friday to Anthony Carmen Piccirillo, a son of Debra A. Piccirillo and Stephen J. Piccirillo of Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Stephen M. Fields, a Roman Catholic priest who is an associate professor of theology at Georgetown University, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Newark.

title: Lindsay Addison, Stephen Hauss
description: Lindsay Margaret Addison and Stephen Michael Hauss were married Saturday at the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington. Judge Frank D. Saylor IV of the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts, for whom the groom was a law clerk from 2006 to 2007, officiated.

title: Kimberly Eskow, Aaron Sobel
description: Kimberly Brooke Eskow and Aaron Fausto Sobel were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Stephanie Bernstein at the Ritz-Carlton in McLean, Va.

title: Shannon Coughlin, Matthew Shane
description: Shannon Kasey Coughlin and Matthew Owen Shane were married Saturday at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York. The Rev. Joseph G. Marina, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Julie Wertheimer, Benjamin Waxman
description: Julie Michelle Wertheimer and Benjamin Robert Waxman were married Saturday evening by Rabbi George Stern in the atrium at the Cira Centre, an office high-rise in Philadelphia.

title: Amy Wolf, Kevin Malone
description: Amy Elizabeth Wolf, the daughter of Barbara C. Wolf and Steven J. Wolf of New York, was married in New York Saturday evening to Kevin Louis Malone, the son of Pamela M. Morris of Austin, Tex., and Kenneth M. Malone of Sonoma, Calif. Rabbi Ari Lorge officiated at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park.

title: Lauren Margulis, Daniel Bader
description: Lauren Michelle Margulis, the daughter of Felice J. Margulis and Justice Ira H. Margulis of Hollis Hills, Queens, was married Saturday evening to Daniel Adam Bader, the son of Barbara Bader and Gary Bader of East Hills, N.Y. The brides father officiated, with Cantor Sol Zim assisting at the Lawrence Yacht and Country Club in Lawrence, N.Y.

title: Mariam Khan and David Levine
description: Mariam Said Khan and David Joshua Levine were married Saturday evening at the National Press Club in Washington. Yohannes A. Abraham, the chief of staff for the office of public engagement and the office of intergovernmental affairs at the White House, officiated with permission from the District of Columbia.

title: Jacklyn Fleer, Bradley Cohen
description: Jacklyn Sara Fleer, a daughter of Lynn K. Fleer and Saul M. Fleer of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married Saturday to Bradley Dean Cohen, a son of Michele S. Cohen and Barry P. Cohen of Sydney, Australia. Rabbi Scott B. Weiner officiated at the Yale Club of New York City.

title: Steven Sumser and Michael Engler
description: Steven Alexander Sumser and Michael Charles Engler are to be married Sunday at their apartment in New York. Dr. Kurtis Birusingh, a Universal Life minister, is to officiate.

title: Rebecca Karp and David Leaf
description: Dr. Rebecca Sara Karp, the daughter of Dr. Susan R. Rosenthal and Dr. George I. Karp of East Brunswick, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Dr. David Evan Leaf, a son of Jeanette B. Leaf and Dr. Robert J. Leaf of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Norton D. Shargel officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York.

title: Bitsy Sather and Jay Wainwright
description: Laura Whitney Sather and Jonathan Mayhew Wainwright Jr. were married Saturday at the Maidstone Club in East Hampton, N.Y. The Rev. Denis C. Brunelle, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Kathryn Weeks, Bryan Howard
description: Kathryn Frances Weeks and Bryan Mark Howard were married in Washington Saturday at St. Francis Hall, a part of the Franciscan Monastery U.S.A. The ceremony was led by Matthew Lee Ashley, a friend of the couple who was granted permission by the District of Columbia.

title: Lucila Pescarmona and Bud Nolan
description: Lucila Maria Pescarmona and Robert Bernard Nolan III were married Friday at the Civil Registry Office in Buenos Aires. Liliana Sofia Gurevich, a justice of the peace, officiated. On Nov. 29, the couple is to take part in a blessing ceremony led by the Rev. Juan Carlos Vignoli, a Roman Catholic priest, at the Roman Catholic Church of Lujn de Cuyo in Mendoza, Argentina.

title: First the Patience, Then the Passion
description: Colleen Marie Canney and Olivier Benjamin Thibault Pissonnet de Bellefonds were married Friday at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. James Mitchell, an employee of the New York City Clerks Office, officiated.

title: Morgan Osthimer and Aaron Schoonhoven
description: Morgan Alexis Osthimer and Aaron Lee Schoonhoven were married Saturday evening at the Pacific Union Club in San Francisco. Charles E. Osthimer IV, the brides brother, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Corrections: November 23, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Manny Pacquiao Defeats Chris Algieri by Unanimous Decision
description: MACAU  Manny Pacquiao defeated Chris Algieri by unanimous decision Sunday at the Venetian Macao to retain his World Boxing Organization welterweight championship.

title: Marion Barry, Washingtons Mayor for Life, Even After Prison, Dies at 78
description: WASHINGTON  Marion S. Barry Jr., a sharecroppers son and civil rights pioneer who became a flamboyant and polarizing mayor of Washington, went to prison on a cocaine charge and then recaptured City Hall in one of the most improbable comebacks in the history of American politics, died early Sunday in Washington. He was 78.

title: Prosecution of Uighur Students Underscores Perils of Chinese Clampdown
description: BEIJING  Ambitious and fluent in Mandarin, the young Uighur strivers from the Xinjiang region of northwest China had earned coveted slots at the nations top university for ethnic minorities. Most were the first in their families to attend college.

title: Coming Back Home to a Lower East Side Tenement
description: When Rita Ascione, 88, recently visited the tenement at 97 Orchard Street where she lived in the 1930s, she noticed that the neighborhood had changed dramatically. But the old building itself remained largely the way she remembered it: Thats because it was preserved by the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, which now occupies the space.

title: What Cloud Computing Means to Your Job
description: Technology has been accused of making many a job disappear, like the production line or the accounting office. And it is not done yet.

title: Biking Napoleons Route
description: Following in the footsteps of Europes greatest conquerors isnt easy. Thats why Ride and Seek, an international tour company in Sydney, Australia, suggests doing it on a bike. Next summer the group is introducing its second epic historical cycling tour, the Napoleon Expedition, a 45-day journey from Paris to Moscow.

title: Our Marriage Ended. Our Family Did Not.
description: My birth plan was eight pages long. At 26, I hadnt planned my pregnancy, so I was determined that our babys debut would be precise. Throughout those nine months, I read any parenting book I could get my swollen fingers on, dog-earing every other page. I considered whether our baby boy would be circumcised, how many months I would breast-feed, what preschool he would attend. Id carefully carved out the details for any possible mishaps and milestones of our sons little life  except for one. I never considered what would happen if I divorced the man whod made me a mother.

title: Blind Massage Wins Golden Horse Award for Best Feature
description: The director Lou Yes Blind Massage  a bittersweet tale set in a massage parlor run by blind masseurs  won for best feature film at the 51st Golden Horse Awards in Taipei, Taiwan, on Saturday. The accolade, given each year to a Chinese-language film, is widely considered Asias most important film prize.

title: The Daily Gift: Soft Pillows Handmade Using Traditional Techniques
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: Packers Aaron Rodgers Throws Off Defenders With His Voice
description: During every Green Bay training camp, an inexperienced defensive lineman rotates in for a play or two, and quarterback Aaron Rodgers stifles a laugh. He glances at the Packers defensive line coach, Mike Trgovac, who knows precisely what Rodgers is about to do but is powerless to stop it.

title: China Said to Turn Reef Into Airstrip in Disputed Water
description: BEIJING  A major reclamation project by the Chinese government on a tiny reef 500 miles from the mainland would enable China to land military aircraft there, expanding its reach into the contested South China Sea, analysts have said.

title: Iran Nuclear Negotiators, Facing Key Differences, Weigh Extending Deadline
description: VIENNA  With a deadline for an agreement to curb Irans nuclear program just a day away, American officials finally acknowledged Sunday that the two sides would not reach a deal by Mondays deadline but would probably extend the talks a second time to explore a series of possible solutions.

title: Obama Acknowledges Broad Gaps Between 2 Sides in Iran Nuclear Talks
description: WASHINGTON  The gap in negotiations over the Iranian nuclear program remains significant, President Obama said in an interview broadcast Sunday, a day before the deadline for the talks.

title: Blast at Game Kills Dozens in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As many as 40 people were killed Sunday after a suicide bomber detonated explosives in a crowd gathered for a volleyball match in a village in eastern Afghanistan, a spokesman for the provincial governor said.

title: When Their Workday Ends, More Fathers Are Heading Into the Kitchen
description: Sometimes, Joe Kreisberg ponders the question during his morning commute. Sometimes, he considers it at his desk at an advertising agency in Manhattan or on his afternoon stroll for a caffeinated pick-me-up.

title: Survivors Pulled From Ruins After Quake in Japan
description: TOKYO  Police officers and firefighters rescued almost two dozen people, including a 2-year-old toddler, from beneath their collapsed houses on Sunday, a day after a powerful earthquake shook mountainous central Japan. At least 40 people were injured, but no deaths were reported.

title: 1914: Churches Of Ypres Are Targets For German Guns
description: IN BELGIUM  When the history of the terrific fighting in and around Ypres is written  Ypres, where the Huns have repeated the sacrilege and outrages of Louvain and Rheims, where once more they have selected the cathedral, churches, town hall and all the beautiful examples of Flemish architecture as the special targets of their heavy artillery  it will add another chapter of infamy to the record of German kultur in this great war. Filled with fierce joy over the destruction of the imposing Hall of the Draper; and of the classic little Town Hall, the Huns have added the beautiful cathedral of Ypres to the sacrifices which Belgium has made for freedom. I have been in many towns and villages desolated and ruined by the Germans during this war, and everywhere I have noted the terrible truth that the temples of God  the beautiful churches of France and Belgium have been picked in advance of all other edifices for destruction.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 24, 1914

title: Latest Hunger Games Film Opens Big, but Not as Big as the Previous One
description: The third Hunger Games movie, Mockingjay Part 1 (Lionsgate), sold an estimated $123 million in tickets at North American theaters over the weekend  by far Hollywoods largest opening of the year but one that nonetheless marked a substantial comedown for the mega-franchise.

title: Brown Familys Lawyer Criticizes Process
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Benjamin Crump, a lawyer representing the family of Michael Brown, the unarmed black teenager killed by a white police officer in August, again called the grand jury process on the review of the shooting completely unfair in an interview on Sunday with ABC News.

title: Israeli Cabinet Approves Nationality Bill
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli cabinet on Sunday approved contentious draft legislation that emphasizes Israels Jewish character above its democratic nature in a move that critics said could undermine the fragile relationship with the countrys Arab minority at a time of heightened tensions.

title: Parents Charged in Shooting of 9-Month-Old Girl in Brooklyn
description: The parents of a 9-month-old girl who was shot in the hip at her home in Brooklyn were charged on Sunday in connection with the shooting, the police said.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (13, 49) JAY LENO: THE MARK TWAIN PRIZE Mr. Leno, above, the 17th recipient of the Mark Twain Prize for American Humor, is honored at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington in this ceremony, taped on Oct. 19. In addition to hosting The Tonight Show from 1992 to 2014 (with time off in 2009 and 2010), Mr. Leno makes more than 100 live stand-up appearances annually; shows off his car collection in his online series, Jay Lenos Garage; writes childrens books; does voice-over work; and writes a monthly column in Popular Mechanics magazine. Among the friends and colleagues cheering him here are Garth Brooks, Kristin Chenoweth, Kevin Eubanks, Jimmy Fallon, Chelsea Handler, Robert Klein, Al Madrigal, Seth Myers, Jerry Seinfeld, J. B. Smoove, Wanda Sykes, Jamie Foxx and Betty White. What an honor! Mr. Leno said when he learned about the award. Im a big fan of Mark Twains. In fact, A Tale of Two Cities is one of my favorite books.

title: FBI Declassifies Additional Portions of 2010 Inspector General Report on Problems With Exigent Letters
description: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit filed by The New York Times, the FBI has declassified additional portions of a 2010 inspector general report about exigent letters and other informal requests for telephone records. The new version contains about 125 words or passages that were previously redacted.

title: Watercolor Attributed to Hitler Sells for $161,000
description: A watercolor believed to have been painted by Adolf Hitler sold for about $161,000 (130,000 euros), on Saturday at a German auction house, Reuters reported.

title: 12-Year-Old Boy Dies After Police in Cleveland Shoot Him
description: Officials in Cleveland were investigating the police shooting of a 12-year-old boy who died on Sunday, a day after an officer shot him outside a recreation center when he reached for a weapon that turned out to be a fake pistol.

title: Release of Evidence Used by Grand Jury Is Uncertain
description: A St. Louis County circuit court judge had not yet agreed to the release of records from grand jury proceedings in the Darren Wilson case, a court official said in a statement on Sunday, an indication that there is no guarantee that the public will receive access to transcripts and recordings detailing what has happened in the grand jury room.

title: 1939: French Join Americans in Thanksgiving Rites
description: Despite the alarms of war, Thanksgiving Day was observed by Americans in Paris yesterday with traditional religious and festive rites at the American Church and Pershing Hall, where American war veterans congregated with their French comrades to enjoy a real Thanksgiving dinner in a spirit of good fellowship recalling the dramatic days of 1914-18.

title: Sudan and Rebels in Darfur Region Begin Peace Talks
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia  Talks between the Sudanese government and two rebels groups from the Darfur region began here in the Ethiopian capital on Sunday.

title: Obama Defends His Use of Executive Authority on Immigration
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, in an interview broadcast on Sunday, said he rejects Republican criticism that he has exceeded his authority in moving to spare millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation, adding that he has been very restrained in his use of executive authority.

title: Roger Federer Burnishes Legacy as the Swiss Capture a Long-Sought Title
description: VILLENEUVE DASCQ, France  It looked like an ending, with the confetti floating down and a record crowd watching Roger Federer and his Swiss teammates celebrate for the first time with the big, bright and shiny Davis Cup.

title: Afghanistan Quietly Lifts Ban on Nighttime Raids
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The government of the new Afghan president, Ashraf Ghani, has quietly lifted the ban on night raids by special forces troops that his predecessor had imposed.

title: Sailing Off on a Gender Bender
description: Twice, I thought I saw Patti LuPone onstage. They were just look-alikes, but Fabulous! The Queen of New Musical Comedies, which occupies the microscopic stage at the New Write Act Repertory Theater, has its fair share of other divas.

title: Red Bulls Fall to Revolution in First Game of Conference Finals
description: HARRISON, N.J.  The Giants and the Jets seasons are disasters. The Knicks and the Nets? Whatever. November is still a bit too early to pass judgment on the Rangers, the Islanders and the Devils. The Yankees and the Mets? Seek therapy.

title: The Prescription for Japans Economy?
description: More Abenomics.

title: Fleeing Ukraine With Little More Than Wit
description: It came as a great surprise to Lev Golinkin when he discovered, at the age of 9, that there was more than one town named Lafayette in the United States.

title: Celebrating Half a Century of Creativity
description: Meredith Monk, the composer, vocalist, director and choreographer whose multidisciplinary works have influenced a couple of generations of American artists, is being celebrated this season for 50 years of creativity in New York. On Friday night, the day after she turned 72, the essential American Composers Orchestra opened its 38th season with a program at Zankel Hall titled Monks Sphere, conducted by the ensembles music director, George Manahan, the first of its two Orchestra Underground concerts in that popular subbasement performance space at Carnegie Hall.

title: A Club Celebrates Being a Drawing Card
description: The most-attended bridge club in the United States last year was the Hartes Club in White Plains, with 13,622.5 tables.

title: Beyonc Repackaged for the Holidays
description: Last December, Beyonc surprised her fans with a new, self-titled album, which after only three weeks sold 1.3 million copies, making it one of the top sellers of the year.

title: As Temperatures Warm in Buffalo Area, Melting Snow Raises Fears of Flooding
description: BUFFALO  With temperatures rapidly warming here, people began to emerge on Sunday in some of the areas worst affected by a series of lake-effect storms that dumped more than six feet of snow across the region last week and left at least 12 people dead.

title: Seeking an Intimate Sound Across a Cavernous Expanse
description: In the most memorable chamber music concerts, the performances seem spontaneous; the listener can sense musicians feeding off one anothers energy, taking risks and enjoying a visceral experience together.

title: How Colleges Deal With Rape Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: The Plan for an Offshore Park in the Hudson
Sealing Juvenile Records
description: To the Editor:

title: Reasons to Refinance
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety on Chemicals
description: To the Editor:

title: Alastair Mitchell, on Running With Your Dreams
description: This interview with  Alastair Mitchell, the chief executive of Huddle, a cloud-based collaboration software company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Alastair Mitchell, on Running With Your Dreams
description: This interview with  Alastair Mitchell, the chief executive of Huddle, a cloud-based collaboration software company, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Judaism Must Embrace the Convert
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  THE recent arrest of an Orthodox rabbi in Washington, who was charged with having watched women showering via a hidden camera installed at the mikvah, or ritual bath, at his synagogue, has drawn attention to the challenges faced by potential converts to Judaism. The scandal put a spotlight on the near-total control exercised by the rabbi over converts into the Jewish faith. The system lacks oversight. It leaves those wanting to become Jews vulnerable to exploitation.

title: A Secret Falls From the Family Tree, and a Girls Identity Branches Out
description: The documentary Little White Lie would be provocative simply for what it says about race and identity. The director Lacey Schwartz grew up Jewish in Woodstock, N.Y., yet something seemed off. Her peers would ask if she was adopted. At Ms. Schwartzs bat mitzvah, a member of her synagogue assumed she was an Ethiopian Jew. Her family attributed her darker skin to a Sicilian great-grandfather. Only gradually did Ms. Schwartz, now 37, begin to suspect what might seem obvious to an outsider: that her biological father was black.

title: Texters Expression
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  If you are a member of the texting generation, you will be very familiar with todays theme, although I have just been handed an update by my kids, who say that ROFL, or ROLLING ON THE FLOOR LAUGHING, is kind of pass already. If you can imagine.

title: Good News on Energy
description: SAN FRANCISCO  WHEN the worlds two largest polluters join in establishing new goals for reducing emissions of climate-disrupting gases, criticism and skepticism are predictable. And there was plenty following the recent agreement between the United States and China to do just that.

title: Virtual Worlds Invite Visitors Into the Story
description: There is no agreement among designers on the best way for video games to tell stories. Some games have branching plotlines and characters who live or die based on the players decisions. Others are tightly constrained and offer no choices that alter the narrative. Some use text to deliver information, while others use sound or moving images. Most mix all of those qualities.

title: Visual Arts Come to the Theater as Genres Blend and Bend
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  With the recent proliferation of dance in museums, artists and curators have had to reimagine nontheatrical spaces  galleries, hallways, atriums  as sites for performance, a task more delicate and complicated than it might sound. But what if the challenge were inverted? What would happen, say, if a performing arts center temporarily reimagined itself as an art museum?

title: With Hunger Games Campaigns, Lionsgate Punches Above Its Weight
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  With its cutting-edge social-media campaigns for The Hunger Games, the tiny 27-person marketing department at Lionsgate has become a model for Hollywoods legacy studios: scrappy, thrifty, forward-thinking.

title: Indianapolis Star Newspaper Apologizes for Cartoon on Migrants
description: The Indianapolis Star removed a cartoon from its website over the weekend after readers complained that the drawing was racist for depicting an immigrant family climbing through a window to crash a white familys Thanksgiving dinner.

title: A Lifesaving Transplant for Coral Reefs
description: SUMMERLAND KEY, Fla.  David Vaughan plunges his right arm down to his elbow into one of nine elevated tanks where thousands of tiny colonies of coral are growing at an astonishing rate in shaded seclusion next to the Mote Tropical Research Laboratory.

title: A Gander at Love
description: When people ask me what my father is like, I tell them about the geese.

title: Sybil: A Brilliant Hysteric?
description: In the 1970s, the TV movie Sybil introduced much of the nation to multiple personality disorder and led to a controversy that continues to shape mental health issues.

title: Debate Persists Over Diagnosing Mental Health Disorders, Long After Sybil
description: The notion that a person might embody several personalities, each of them distinct, is hardly new. The ancient Romans had a sense of this and came up with Janus, a two-faced god. In the 1880s, Robert Louis Stevenson wrote Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, a novella that provided us with an enduring metaphor for good and evil corporeally bound. Modern comic books are awash in divided personalities like the Hulk and Two-Face in the Batman series. Even heroic Superman has his alternating personas.

title: William H. Scheide, 100, Philanthropist, Is Dead
description: William T. Scheide struck it rich in the Pennsylvania oil boom of the late 19th century and then surprised people by retiring at 42. For him, it was an easy decision. He had made more than enough money to do what he really wanted to do: buy books and read them.

title: Treasury Auctions for the Week of Nov. 24
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Solar and Wind Energy Start to Win on Price vs. Conventional Fuels
description: For the solar and wind industries in the United States, it has been a long-held dream: to produce energy at a cost equal to conventional sources like coal and natural gas.

title: Tunisia Vote for Leader Likely to Go to a Runoff
description: TUNIS  Tunisians turned out in steady, orderly lines on Sunday to vote in their first free and democratic presidential election, voicing confidence that they were turning the page on the often-fractious transition after the revolution of 2011.

title: Serial, Podcastings First Breakout Hit, Sets Stage for More
description: On Thursday, people will gather around tables everywhere and, well, talk about how bummed they are that Serial, the wildly popular podcast, is taking Thanksgiving off.

title: In Delhi, Pushing Through the Wall (of Air Pollution)
description: NEW DELHI  They wore turbans, headbands, crazy wigs and baseball caps, but almost none of the runners in this citys annual half-marathon wore masks Sunday despite air pollution levels that were among the worst in the world.

title: Graft Hobbles Iraqs Military in Fighting ISIS
description: BAGHDAD  One Iraqi general is known as chicken guy because of his reputation for selling his soldiers poultry provisions. Another is arak guy, for his habit of enjoying that anise-flavored liquor on the job. A third is named after Iraqs 10,000-dinar bills, General Deftar, and is infamous for selling officer commissions.

title: A Power Plant in California Goes Quiet, but the Stacks Still Tower
description: MORRO BAY, Calif.  The showpiece of this sparkling California fishing village is a 581-foot-high mountain of volcanic rock rising from the water, drawing gawkers and tourists from up and down the coast. Yet for 50 years, Morro Bay, which likes to call itself the Gibraltar of the Pacific, has been just as defined by a no-less-assertive landmark, staring down the rock from across the bay: three 450-feet-high power plant smokestacks, visible from 10 miles away.

title: Home-Birth Film by Ricki Lake Prepares for Redelivery, Worldwide
description: One of the most talked about and provocative documentaries about childbirth is having its own rebirth.

title: Notable Absence of New Ebola Quarantines at New York Area Airports
description: A day after a doctor who had returned from Guinea about a week earlier became New Yorks first Ebola case, the governors of New York and New Jersey announced that they would begin quarantining travelers who had been in contact with Ebola patients in West Africa.

title: Bigger Than Immigration
description: Dont let yourself get lost in the weeds. Dont allow yourself to believe that opposition to President Obamas executive actions on immigration is only about that issue, the presidents tactics, or his lack of obsequiousness to his detractors.

title: After Manny Pacquiao Wins Again, Talk Turns to a Possible Foe
description: MACAU  It was shortly after 4:30 p.m. local time when Manny Pacquiao entered his suite atop the north tower of the Venetian Macao. Approximately 100 people were there, waiting almost three hours after his fight to congratulate him on his unanimous decision victory over Chris Algieri.

title: Rock Bottom Economics
description: Six years ago the Federal Reserve hit rock bottom. It had been cutting the federal funds rate, the interest rate it uses to steer the economy, more or less frantically in an unsuccessful attempt to get ahead of the recession and financial crisis. But it eventually reached the point where it could cut no more, because interest rates cant go below zero. On Dec. 16, 2008, the Fed set its interest target between 0 and 0.25 percent, where it remains to this day.

title: In Pursuit of an Oddly Shaped Comet
description: It took more than a decade, and a looping trajectory that covered four billion miles, before a spacecraft launched by the European Space Agency caught up with a mysterious comet near Jupiter in August  and three more months before it gently lowered an automated probe to study what makes these primordial remnants from the early solar system tick. Last-minute malfunctions hampered the ability of the probe to complete its inspection of surface and subsurface conditions. Even so, the mission appears to be a history-making achievement.

title: Fellowship or Internship? In Media, the Definition Has Become Fluid
description: Since graduating from Wesleyan University last year, Rachel Pincus has completed two journalism internships and one in publishing. But now Ms. Pincus is pursuing fellowships.

title: In Her Third Chance at Life, She Discovers an Appetite for Living
description: Twice in her life, Lidia de los Santos has dropped onto the tracks of the New York City subway system, as the thundering of a coming train sounded through the tunnels.

title: Iran Grants Bail to Woman From Britain Held 5 Months
description: TEHRAN  A British-Iranian woman detained in Iran since June, whose case attracted international attention after her family said she had been arrested after trying to attend an all-male volleyball match, was released on bail on Sunday.

title: A Step Forward on Child Care
description: Ensuring access to safe, good and affordable child care is crucial for helping to lift low-income parents out of poverty and build futures for their children. The child care bill signed on Wednesday by President Obama is a bipartisan step in the right direction, and it holds promise for further progress.

title: Sting Climbs Aboard Foundering Ship
description: Can Sting save his sinking ship on Broadway?

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Sid Lee USA and Movember Take Relationship to New Level
description: IF, as the saying goes, advertising is a relationship business, an agency, Sid Lee, and one of its clients, the mens health charity known as the Movember Foundation, have entered the cohabitation stage.

title: A Breakout Season for Lydia Ko, a Low-Key 17-Year-Old
description: NAPLES, Fla.  Eleven days after Tiger Woods won the Masters in his first full season on the PGA Tour, an 8-pound, 8-ounce girl was born in Seoul, South Korea. Seventeen years later, Lydia Ko provided further evidence that the games next transcendent player, the crown prince to Woodss king, may in fact be a princess.

title: Will Texas Kill an Insane Man?
description: On Dec. 3, Texas plans to execute an inmate named Scott Panetti, who was convicted in 1995 for murdering his in-laws with a hunting rifle. There is no question that Mr. Panetti committed the murders. There is also no question that he is severely mentally ill, and has been for decades.

title: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Pelicans at Wizards
description: As a season filled with parity continues, some of the teams off to fast starts are beginning to look less like early-season upstarts and more like legitimate contenders. In the Western Conference, the Grizzlies and the Warriors had each lost only two games going into Sunday. In the Eastern Conference, the Raptors, the Wizards and the Bulls have taken center stage as the Heat and the Pacers have declined.

title: Week Ahead: Updates on Europes Economy, and an OPEC Meeting
description: INVESTMENT PLAN IS EXPECTED FROM EUROPEAN COMMISSION

title: In Brooklyn, 2 Young Men, a Dark Stairwell and a Gunshot
description: For two flights down a darkened Brooklyn stairwell, Akai Gurley descended, mortally wounded by gunfire but apparently unaware that the single shot had come from a police officers 9 millimeter weapon.

title: The Affair Recap: Alison Hits Brooklyn, Girls Style
description: Season 1, Episode 7

title: Freed & Fighting for Chinas Environment
description: The environmental activist Wu Lihong was jailed for speaking out about pollution in Chinas Lake Tai. Freed in 2010, he is still speaking out about Chinas challenges to protect its waterways.

title: Uncertainty Upends Lives as Ferguson Awaits Grand Jury Decision
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  At Spencers Bakery near the barricaded police station here, there have been fewer Thanksgiving orders, including for pumpkin pie.

title: Despite Persecution, Guardian of Lake Tai Spotlights Chinas Polluters
description: ZHOUTIE, China  By autumn, the stench of Lake Tai and the freakish green glow of its waters usually fade with the ebbing of the summer heat, but this year is different. Standing on a concrete embankment overlooking a fetid, floating array of plastic bottles, foam takeout containers, flip-flops and the occasional dead fish, Wu Lihong, the lakes unofficial guardian, shook his head in disgust.

title: As Snow Fades, California Ski Resorts Are Left High and Very Dry
description: TWIN BRIDGES, Calif.  At ski areas up and down the jagged peaks of the Sierra Nevada, where Californias drought has hit historic proportions and the broader threat of climate change hangs heavy over an industry built on optimism, the man-made snow is flying.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 23, 2014
Senator Pauls War Resolution
description: Mr. Paul of Kentucky has asked Congress to declare war  something it has not done since World War II  on the Islamic State.

title: Nets Face Stiff Test; Then the Game Starts
description: As one of the best one-on-one players in the N.B.A., Joe Johnson has dispatched his share of the leagues most suffocating defenders. But his most stubborn adversary  the persistent thorn in his side, the one who will never go away  might be a 51-year-old assistant coach named John Welch.

title: Rand Paul Calls for a Formal Declaration of War Against ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Rand Paul is calling for a declaration of war against the Islamic State, a move that promises to shake up the debate over the military campaign in Iraq and Syria as President Obama prepares to ask Congress to grant him formal authority to use force.

title: N.F.L. Players Union Deals With a Shifting Conduct Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Those looking at a tough Thanksgiving workweek  a snow plow driver in Buffalo, say, or a toll collector on the New Jersey Turnpike  can take solace in the knowledge that it could be worse: They could be working for the N.F.L. Players Association.

title: Workers in Silicon Valley Weigh In on Obamas Immigration Action
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Silicon Valleys constant stream of new apps and services depends on hundreds of thousands of foreign-born engineers to help create them. So the technology industry has been pushing for changes to the nations immigration policy for more than a decade to allow more skilled workers into the country.

title: Nations Ponder How to Handle European Fighters Returning From Jihad
description: BERLIN  Months after Kreshnik B. slipped over Turkeys border into Syria in 2013, convinced that it was his duty to help the people overthrow President Bashar al-Assad, he found himself desperate to go home. In a lengthy confession read in a Frankfurt court, the 20-year-old, wearing a black T-shirt and hoodie, said he realized that he could achieve absolutely nothing in Syria.

title: Marion S. Barry Jr.: A Complicated Man Whose Legacy Recounts Both Greatness and Blunders
description: WASHINGTON  Marion S. Barry Jr. was a man who knew how to make an entrance, even when he was late to church.

title: Where Oil and Politics Mix
description: After an unusual land deal, a giant spill and a tanker-train explosion, anxiety began to ripple across the North Dakota prairie.

title: Authors Sign Up to Raise Barnes & Nobles Black Friday Sales
description: In an effort to increase holiday sales, which have fallen for the last two seasons, Barnes & Noble is hoping to lure customers into stores this Black Friday with something book lovers cannot download: signed copies.

title: Call Out the Patricide Squad
description: Though theres no discounting the exponential possibilities of television spinoffs, it seems unlikely that a series called CSI: Ancient Thebes  will be appearing on your screens anytime soon. If you feel this leaves a yawning vacuum in your crime-show-addicted life, you might want to take a look at A Particle of Dread (Oedipus Variations), the new play by Sam Shepard that opened on Sunday night at the Pershing Square Signature Center.

title: The Newsroom Recap: Enter the Love Police
description: Season 3, Episode 22: Main Justice

title: Homeland Recap: Was Saul Heroic? Or Something Else?
description: Season 4, Episode 9: Theres Something Else Going On

title: In Partisan Washington, Health Law Faces Grave Legal Technicalities
description: WASHINGTON  In March 1997, two congressmen proposed a welfare law so detailed that it had 77 sections. Within a month it sailed through the House by voice vote.

title: A Funeral for a Father
description: Gary Kwok, whose father, Wai Kuen Kwok, was killed when he was pushed off a Bronx subway platform into the path of an oncoming subway train on Nov. 16, led a funeral procession for him on Mulberry Street in Chinatown in Manhattan on Sunday.

title: Slates Former Top Editor Takes Helm at Travel Site
description: As editor in chief of the pioneering online magazine Slate, David Plotz ran his own group of well-regarded writers, had a platform for podcasting and earned health insurance.

title: Snow Brings Days of Tumult for Residents of Nursing Home Near Buffalo
description: BUFFALO  Three days after one of their own died during a snow evacuation, residents of the Garden Gate Health Care Facility outside Buffalo were still wondering who she was and how it happened.

title: Private Oncologists Being Forced Out, Leaving Patients to Face Higher Bills
description: When Dr. Jeffery Ward, a cancer specialist, and his partners sold their private practice to the Swedish Medical Center in Seattle, the hospital built them a new office suite 50 yards from the old place. The practice was bigger, but Dr. Ward saw the same patients and provided chemotherapy just like before. On the surface, nothing had changed but the setting.

title: Ray Sadecki, Who Helped Cardinals Win World Series, Dies at 73
description: Ray Sadecki, a pitcher who won 135 games during 18 seasons in the major leagues  including 20 wins with the St. Louis Cardinals in 1964, when he helped lead them to victory in the World Series  died on Nov. 17 in Mesa, Ariz. He was 73.

title: Popular Demand
description: As the holiday shopping season begins, news and commentary about retailers soar. To devise the media value of online activity, a dollar value is assigned as if companies had bought ads. Target finished in the top spot.
