description: PARIS  France will postpone handing over a sophisticated French-built warship to the Russian Navy until further notice, President Franois Hollande said on Tuesday.

title: A Task Force in Black Tuxedos
description: Penguins of Madagascar promises a reasonable share of wit the minute it opens with a voice-over by Werner Herzog, in a sendup of his documentary on Antarctica, Encounters at the End of the World. That film posed the question of whether penguins could exhibit insanity. In the case of this spirited animated movie, the answer is assuredly yes.

title: Thoughts on Race in America, as a Backdrop to Ferguson
description: In Nov. 2014, the country saw renewed violence in Ferguson, Mo., after a St. Louis County grand jurys decided not to bring charges against a police officer, Darren Wilson, whoshot and killed an unarmed black teenager named Michael Brown.

description: Pro-democracy demonstrators faced off against the police Tuesday after part of a protest site in the Mong Kok neighborhood of Hong Kong was cleared.

description: It will not surprise people who spend time in nursing homes  who live or work there, who volunteer or visit family members  that residents can lash out at each other.

description: Many analysts were downright jubilant about a Commerce Department report Tuesday that the economy grew at a 3.9 percent annual rate in the quarter from July through September, better than the 3.5 percent earlier estimated.

title: The Punk Legend Viv Albertine Tells All
description: In the 1970s, Viv Albertine was fully entrenched in the English punk scene, a world defined for her by music, blokes and, often, violence. Albertine befriended now-infamous figures like Johnny Rotten and Sid Vicious of the Sex Pistols (Vicious unceremoniously kicked her out of their band Flowers of Romance). She dated the Clash founder Mick Jones after noticing his flamboyant dress in the cafeteria at their art college. And in the late 70s, Albertine joined the legendary band the Slits as guitarist and they released Cut, one of the most influential punk albums of all time. All that, and Albertine wasnt sure that these memories would make for a fascinating memoir.

title: Pope Says Europe Seems Elderly and Haggard
description: European leaders should pay close attention to a speech Pope Francis delivered to the European Union Parliament on Tuesday, in which he chastised them for not doing enough to alleviate the suffering of the less fortunate.

title: After Obamas Immigration Action, a Blast of Energy for the Tea Party

title: Sharpton Announces Civil Rights Meeting
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton condemned the grand jury decision in Ferguson, Mo., and announced a meeting of civil rights leaders to determine a new activism strategy.

title: As Music Streaming Grows, Spotify Reports Rising Revenue and a Loss
description: Spotify, the company that has come to symbolize the growth of streaming music around the world, had more than $1 billion in revenue in 2013. But it has yet to turn a profit.

title: A Quarterback Rating That Tries to Measure All the Little Things
description: In 2011, ESPN introduced Total QBR, or Total Quarterback Rating, a proprietary statistic intended to capture several of the hidden aspects of quarterback play. The next year, the Indianapolis Colts drafted quarterback Andrew Luck. And while he has helped revitalize the franchise, he has also served as one of the shining examples of how Total QBR credits players for positive plays that are otherwise ignored.

description: Conceptual illustrations of oil well bores in North Dakota

Holder Jr., saw that the streets of Ferguson, Mo., had changed since this summer when he helped soothe tensions there after the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager by a white police officer.

title: Schumer Calls Passing Health Act in 2010 a Political Mistake
description: One of the Senates top Democrats said Tuesday that it was a political mistake to pass the Affordable Care Act in 2010, because voters at the time were looking for relief from the recession  not universal health care.

title: A Defense Against Hostile Takeovers Develops a Downside
description: A recent judicial decision may just upend the hidden world of companies and poison puts, a world that frankly could use some clarity.

title: Farm to Table, Hawaiian Style
description: The crispy Chinese duck, served atop soft Japanese white bread with five-spice gravy and garbanzo mash, was unexpected, and robustly savory. Its like Asian Thanksgiving, my dining companion said as she mopped up the gravy and I extracted the delicately crunchy pieces of duck at Honolulus light-filled, elegant MW Restaurant. Something for everyone.

title: Chart Your Seating
description: Thursday morning comes quickly out of the dark, and with it the promise of the Thanksgiving feast. Have you set the table yet? You should. Set it as if for a sacrament. The Thanksgiving meal is Americas most holy secular ritual.

title: In Quiet Puglia, Lots of Classes
description: The Adriatic coast in Italys Puglias region is a popular summer vacation spot and usually tourist-free come colder weather, but the Borgo Egnazia resort is trying to lure an off-season crowd with its new Nowhere Else Academies.

title: A Missed Chance for Tax Revenue: Congressional Parking
description: When the newly elected Republican majority takes over the Senate and dozens of legislators from the House head back to their states in retirement, a lot of real estate will begin changing hands in the Capitol complex.

title: Clues to Bees History, Tucked Away in Drawers
World Music Institute Names New Leaders
description: The World Music Institute, an organization that presents performances of traditional and folk music from around the globe, announced on Tuesday that it had appointed Par Neiburger as its new artistic director and Cynthia McVay as acting executive director. Both positions were held until recently by Karen Sander, who left the institute to become director of public programs at the CUNY Graduate Center.

title: Reading the Subtleties of Islamic Fashion
description: THERE ARE SO MANY fashion weeks these days, from the Big Four (London, New York, Paris and Milan) to Tokyo, Rio, Miami and Abu Dhabi, among others, that I often think I could pass the year going from one to another, the way John Cheevers Swimmer stroked his way across the pools of the suburbs.

title: The Meaning of the Ferguson Riots
description: The St. Louis County grand jurys decision not to indict the white police officer who in August shot and killed Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, would have generated widespread anger and disappointment in any case. But the county prosecutor, Robert McCulloch, who is widely viewed in the minority community as being in the pockets of the police, made matters infinitely worse by handling this sensitive investigation in the worst possible way.

title: Two Suicide Bombers Kill Dozens in Nigeria
description: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria  Two suicide bombers, at least one of them a woman, blew themselves up on Tuesday at a crowded market in this northeast Nigerian city, killing dozens of shoppers and merchants, including some who witnesses said were decapitated by the explosions.

title: HBO Plans Documentary on Cobain
description: Kurt Cobain: Montage of Heck, an authorized documentary about Nirvanas frontman and songwriter, whose life and work still fascinate music fans 20 years after his suicide in 1994, will have its premiere on HBO in 2015, the network said. A specific date was not given.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Rules on Mercury From Power Plants
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court agreed Tuesday to hear a major challenge to the limits set by the Obama administration on emissions of mercury and other toxic pollutants from coal-fired power plants.

title: The Damage in Ferguson
description: More than a dozen buildings in Ferguson, Mo., were significantly damaged in the rioting that followed the announcement that Darren Wilson, a white police officer, would not be indicted in the shooting death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager.

title: Panel Rejects Sternest F.D.A. Warning for Steroid Shots
description: SILVER SPRING, Md.  A panel of medical experts advising the Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday decided not to recommend slapping the sternest federal warning on steroid injections for neck and back pain, allowing their use to continue relatively unchanged. Millions of Americans get such treatments annually.

title: Mu Ramen Headlines Restaurant Openings
description: Headliner Mu Ramen

title: Justices Take a Major Environmental Case
description: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Rules on Mercury From Power Plants

title: A Dual Review of Whats New Starring Joan Collins and Alexander Wang
description: Joan Collins, O.B.E.-decorated English actress, no-holds-barred memoirist and sharpclawed catfight queen whose cosmetics, skincare and fragrance line, Timeless Beauty, is available through QVC UK, takes on Alexander Wang, American fashions boy wonder and creative director of Balenciaga whose recent H&M collection further established the downtown scenester as a household name.

title: E.U. Investment Plan Aims for Billions to Spur Economy
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union authorities are set to unveil a long-awaited investment plan on Wednesday with the ambition of channeling 315 billion euros into public infrastructure projects like transportation, communications and energy over the next three years.

title: S.E.C. Settles Swiss Banking Secrecy Case With an HSBC Unit
description: Washingtons crackdown on Swiss bank secrecy gained steam on Tuesday, as HSBCs private banking unit in Switzerland settled an investigation into how it had solicited American clients.

title: Mazda Recalls 100,000 Cars for Defect in Tire Pressure Sensor
description: Mazda is recalling almost 100,000 Mazda 6 sedans from the 2014-15 model years because the federally mandated low-tire pressure warning system may not work, the automaker said in a report posted Tuesday on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

title: A Warning on Nutmeg
description: In these early days of the holiday season, as cooks begin sifting through recipes rich in spice and sugar, consider this small warning from toxicologists: Measure your nutmeg carefully.

title: Obama Threatens to Veto $440 Billion Tax Deal
description: WASHINGTON  With negotiators nearing an accord on permanent tax breaks for businesses worth $440 billion over 10 years, President Obama rallied Democratic opposition on Tuesday and promised a veto.

title: First Look Abandons Plans to Publish The Racket After Matt Taibbis Departure
description: First Look Media, the $250 million news organization started by the billionaire Pierre M. Omidyar, announced on Tuesday that it had abandoned plans to publish The Racket, an online magazine that was to be run by the Rolling Stone writer Matt Taibbi, and will lay off most of the magazines staff.

title: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Vegetable Tarts, Big and Small
description: A vegetable tart is a welcome addition to the Thanksgiving meal, offering vegetarian guests a hearty main course and tempting the turkey-eaters as a pleasing side dish.

title: A Trio of New Holiday-Scented Hostess Presents
description: This season, chic new holiday scents make for nice hostess gifts that keep on giving, and taking one to Thanksgiving dinner or winter cocktail parties with a thoughtful note is thanks enough.

title: A Raw Scene as Ferguson Turns Violent
description: Protests turned into riots in Ferguson, Mo., Monday night after a grand jury decided not to charge Officer Darren Wilson for the death of Michael Brown.

title: Instagramming the Ferguson Decision
description: A grand jurys decision in Missouri not to indict Darren Wilson, a white police officer who fatally shot Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager, set off a wave of video reactions on social media.

title: Covering the Ferguson Verdict Protests, With Kids in the Minivan
description: We didnt rent a minivan yesterday afternoon so we could be ready to pack up our three children and head out to the streets after the Ferguson verdict to cover the protests in Union Square and Times Square. We rented a minivan in preparation for a Thanksgiving road trip.

title: Brown Family Lawyer Calls for Change
description: Benjamin Crump, the attorney for Michael Browns family, called for changes in procedure after a grand jury decided not to indict the officer that fatally shot Mr. Brown.

title: An Ex-Congressman Whose Retirement Plan Is Charity
description: For the past 12 years, the campaign account of John LaFalce, a former Democratic congressman, has acted like a mini-foundation for the charities and civic institutions of Western New York, giving small amounts of money around the year.

title: A Pioneers Tribute Is Both a Reward and a Reminder
description: WASHINGTON  Charlie Sifford is a man of few words, but on Monday he was nearly moved to tears.

title: The Slippery Slope of Silicon Valley
description: Ahh, Thanksgiving, the time of year to stop the daily drudgery and give thanks for what we have. To be grateful for our family, friends and health. Maybe this is also a perfect time to be thankful for all the wonderful things technology start-ups have done for society.

title: Pope Francis Addresses European Union
description: In Pope Francis first address to the European Parliament, he called for a united response to the plight of migrants. We cannot allow the Mediterranean to become a vast cemetery, he said.

title: Fight Brews in Congress Over Spending Bill
description: Its that time of year again  falling leaves, pumpkin pie and, yes, the fabled Cromnibus.

title: I.O.C. Corrects Record on 1964 American Skating Pair
description: A little more than 50 years after they skated in the 1964 Winter Games in Innsbruck, Austria, the American figure skaters Vivian and Ronald Joseph can finally call themselves Olympic bronze medalists  and, unlike in years past, they now have the International Olympic Committee to back up their claim.

title: Unpredictable East Coast Storm Could Snarl Thanksgiving Travel
description: First the snows buried the Buffalo area, a result of a sudden rush of cold air that plunged much of the nation into a deep freeze. Then came the warmth, with temperatures in New York City soaring above 70 degrees on Monday.

title: A Hong Kong Street Switches From Ships to (Michelin) Stars
description: As rentals escalate in neighboring districts, the once nondescript Ship Street in Wanchai, Hong Kong  which sits on reclaimed land where ships once docked for repairs  is fast becoming the site du jour for trendy dining outposts headlined by a coterie of big-name chefs lining the narrow side street. Perhaps most telling of its gentrification is 18 Ship Street, where the streets only preserved tong lau (pre-1960s Chinese shophouse) has been home to a private kitchen, Yin Yang, a Ship Street stalwart, since 2008. Yin Yang has recently relocated.

title: Another Destination for a Player Often on the Move
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Sometimes my life feels like a maze. I continually come to a fork in the road and I am presented with a tough decision. My entire career, I have been faced with choices, and I have sometimes felt compelled to create paths that werent offered.

title: What Ferguson Says About the Fear of Social Media
description: The most significant challenge encountered in this investigation has been the 24-hour news cycle and its insatiable appetite for something, for anything, to talk about. Following closely behind were the nonstop rumors on social media.

title: Kenneth P. Martin
description: Mr. Martin, 51, is the chief executive and president of REMCO, a company that provides building restoration and maintenance services. REMCO has worked on several iconic buildings throughout New York, such as Grand Central Terminal, St. Patricks Cathedral and the New York Stock Exchange. Its recent projects include work on One World Trade Center.

title: Blood Brothers and Their Feuds, for Generations
description: Bad blood flows down through the generations in Ghost Brothers of Darkland County, a Southern Gothic musical with a book by the literary spookmeister supreme, Stephen King; songs by John Mellencamp; and musical direction by T Bone Burnett. A semi-staged touring version of the show, directed by Susan V. Booth, made a pit stop in New York for one night only at the Beacon Theater on Monday, attracting a healthy crowd that seemed equally divided between King fans (like the guy in the shirt that screamed Redrum) and followers of either Mr. Mellencamp, whose pop-rock career dates back to the late 70s, or Mr. Burnett, whose rsum includes a hefty 13 Grammys and music supervision for the first season of the terrific television series Nashville.

title: Colombia to Receive Some Garca Mrquez Effects
description: There was an outcry in Colombia after the announcement on Monday that the archive of Gabriel Garca Mrquez would go to the University of Texas instead of his native country. Many in the Colombian cultural establishment questioned why the national library had let such a valuable part of its patrimony slip away.

title: Hewlett-Packard Profit Declines as Breakup Plan Begins
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When celebrities break up, it is a conscious uncoupling, and done in a few weeks. At a big technology company, the split is no less deliberate, but considerably more complex.

title: A Reading of God and Me by Edward Hirsch
description: The American poet questions his own belief in a higher power.

title: First Draft Focus: Chicago Greeting
In Moscow, a Financial District in Name Only
description: MOSCOW  In the coveted corner office, a bearded man in sweatpants scrambled eggs at a kitchenette, all the while taking in the serene beauty of the city lights twinkling far below.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Catch up on the days top stories.

title: Restaurant Report: La Parada in Cape Town
description: If youre an ambitious Cape Town chef worth your proverbial salt, youre on Bree Street. Formerly the domain of mechanics shops, this downtown stretch has been recently hosting a culinary renaissance.

title: To Russia, With Tough Love
description: Dear Moscow,

title: Soup, Salad and Stir-Fry With Thanksgiving Leftovers
description: I love turkey sandwiches as much as the next person, but this year I have some other plans for my leftover meat: soup, salad and a stir-fry. Even better, these dishes will also serve as vehicles for other leftovers.

title: Escaping the Friend Zone
description: Youll never be confused about who the enemy is in Women Who Flirt, Pang Ho-cheungs new romantic comedy. Hailey (Tang Sui) is the kind of passive-aggressive young woman who talks in a babyish voice to men, reacts to a scratch on her leg as if it might require amputation and bursts into tears at less than the drop of a hat, demanding at higher and higher volume to be consoled. In one restaurant scene, Hailey sobs like a stricken toddler and insists on being taken home after learning that her main course is a rabbit delicacy. (Girls dont eat bunnies! she wails.)

title: Stepping Back (Gracefully) From a Sculpture to Frame Its Story
description: WASHINGTON  Like the Dark Lady of Shakespeares sonnets and Vermeers Girl With a Pearl Earring, Degass Little Dancer has become both symbol and myth: Shes a source of fascination, inspiration and speculation. But, just as Alice in Wonderland and Peter Pan were based on real children, we know who inspired this 1881 sculpture: Marie van Goethem, a young dancer who joined the Paris Opera Ballet in 1880.

title: Former Under Secretary of Defense Withdraws Her Name for Pentagons Top Post
description: WASHINGTON  Another leading candidate to be the next secretary of defense has pulled out of consideration.

title: Putins Kleptocracy, by Karen Dawisha
description: Now in his third (nonconsecutive) presidential term, Vladimir Putin presents himself as the strong and virtuous leader who rescued Russia from the chaos, corruption, penury and weakness of the 1990s.

title: On Display, and on a Hot Seat
description: PARIS  Jelle Saminnadin plays a black odalisque, a seminude Congolese slave gazing in a gilded mirror. A leather bond encircles her neck and chains her to a bed of lace and pillows in a scene mimicking a colonial human zoo of the early 20th century.

title: Nothing Is True and Everything Is Possible, by Peter Pomerantsev
description: The name Vladimir Putin is almost impossible to find in Nothing Is True and Everything Is Possible: The Surreal Heart of the New Russia. He usually appears only as the President, lording over and lurking behind the tales of tragedy and absurdity in Peter Pomerantsevs captivating new book about modern Russia and its discontents.

title: Equity Tries to Influence Show Tours
description: CHICAGO  Some of the sets looked flimsy, the acting was uneven, and the signature red wig needed bounce. But none of that mattered to Lilly Hickman, 6, as she watched Annie, presented here by Broadway in Chicago, a booker of national musical tours.

title: The Georgetown Set, by Gregg Herken
description: Gregg Herken had what must have seemed like a terrific idea  to revisit the large drama of the Cold War era by setting it on a small stage: Georgetown, the former port town on the Potomac River that became a celebrated Washington neighborhood. After all, its inhabitants once included such central figures as Dean Acheson, W. Averell Harriman and Allen Dulles, as well as journalists who not only got scoops from their neighbors but sometimes influenced and even participated in the events that they covered.

title: Limonov, by Emmanuel Carrre
description: Everyone in Russia knows Eduard Limonov as the sinewy old man with the little goat beard, surrounded by a coterie of young hoodlums (members of his outlawed National Bolshevik Party, now called the Other Russia)  the snippy contrarian who gets arrested every other month when he comes out to protest for the right to free assembly, guaranteed by the Russian Constitution, and who, in his vagabond youth, lived as a down-and-out migr in the New York of the 1970s.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Governor Deploys More National Guard
description: Gov. Jay Nixon of Missouri said that a total of over 2,200 National Guard members would be in the Ferguson area after earlier protests led to rioting and looting.

title: Pulling No Punches in a Round of Letters
description: There were many reasons to hope that this collection of letters would be great or near-great, yet Selected Letters of Norman Mailer is mostly low-wattage, a rolling brownout of his vast intellect and talent. Mailer (1923-2007) loathed composing letters and tended to dictate them in industrial-size batches, as many as 50 in a day. Working on them made him feel slack and etiolated, like a marathoner forced to stagger around the track a second time.

title: Pouring Shots and Shooting Portraits in the Old Times Square
description: In a Times Square bar called  fittingly  the Terminal, Sheldon Nadelman served drinks and made portraits of its denizens, from pimps and prostitutes to actors and nurses.

title: Take Cover: A Dispatch From Ferguson
description: John Eligon is reporting on the protests in Ferguson, Mo. He tells what it was like on the ground after the verdict was announced Monday night. Follow him on Twitter for updates.

title: Exploring Thanksgiving History in Massachusetts
description: The 400th anniversary of the Mayflowers landing at Plymouth in 1620 is still a few years out, but the group charged with organizing festivities around the quadricentennial isnt waiting to begin commemorations.

title: University of Virginia Officials Vow to Combat Campus Rape Problem
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va.  Shocked, tearful and at times defensive, members of the board that oversees the University of Virginia insisted that they would combat the problem of sexual assault on campus after a magazine article reported a gang rape at a campus fraternity and allegations that the university was more concerned about its reputation than a history of sexual assault embedded in its hard-drinking social life.

title: Cuomos Response to Buffalo-Area Snow: Praised, With Exceptions
description: BUFFALO  It was threatening to snow again here on Tuesday. The temperature was falling, the winds were unpleasant and the skies were as gray as the pavement. Everything, in other words, seemed back to normal.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Pierre Huyghes First Retrospective Lands at LACMA
description: Not only is the third and final stop at LACMA of the French artist Pierre Huyghes retrospective  which, following runs in Paris and Cologne, opens to the public today and is on view until Feb. 22, 2015  one of Los Angeless most anticipated exhibitions of the year, it is also one of the citys most seductive, inscrutable and generally impressive shows in recent memory. In truth, the water shortage is not the only drought to have withered Southern California in 2014. For whatever reasons  one might be MOCAs transitional climate  there has also been a dearth of large-scale institutional shows by living artists to go above and beyond tidy, studious presentations of their work. The Huyghe retrospective, on the other hand, is messy, extravagant and unpredictable, inspiring a genuine sense of discovery even for those well-acquainted with his work.

title: Thanksgivings Busy Week in Air Travel Is Now a Daily Routine
description: Thanksgiving weekend has traditionally been the busiest time of the year for air travel, but that distinction is quickly becoming a thing of the past. With airlines merging and consolidating operations in fewer hubs, congestion that was once characteristic of the holiday is becoming more common at major airports all year round.

title: Pictures of the Day: The United States and Elsewhere
description: The United States and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Nov. 25, 2014  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Egypt, Hong Kong, Kenya and the United States.

title: Sony Pictures Computers Down for a Second Day After Network Breach
description: Sony Pictures Entertainments computer systems were down for the second day in a row Tuesday after hackers claimed responsibility for breaching the companys network and defacing its website.

title: Same Top 4 in Rankings, but College Football Playoff Keeps Things Interesting
description: Before this season, those who favored going from a two-team playoff under the Bowl Championship Series to a four-team playoff  without expanding to six or eight teams, as some had hoped  cited the Goldilocks principle.

title: Recent Commercial Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Obama to Introduce Sweeping New Controls Aimed at Ozone
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is expected to release on Wednesday a contentious and long-delayed environmental regulation to reduce ozone, a smog-causing pollutant linked to asthma, heart disease and premature death.

title: Talking About Racism With White Kids
description: White parents need to be talking to our children about racism. As Ive written before, more than once, not talking about racial differences doesnt tell children that we dont notice that people have different colored skin and differently textured hair. It tells them that we dont talk about things like that.

title: Its Grip on Oil Weakening, OPEC Will Meet on Prices
description: LONDON  As oil prices continue to plummet, the once-dominant international cartel of producers is losing its sway over the global energy markets.

title: U.S. Wants Teacher Training Programs to Track How Graduates Students Perform
description: The federal Department of Education announced preliminary rules on Tuesday requiring states to develop rating systems for teacher preparation programs that would track a range of measures, including the job placement and retention rates of graduates and the academic performance of their students.

title: When Immigrants Lose Their Human Rights
description: President Obamas recent initiative on immigration has reignited the national debate on the issue. This interview, the first in a series on political topics, discusses philosophical ideas that underlie this debate. My interviewee is Joseph Carens, a professor of political science at the University of Toronto. He immigrated to Canada from the United States in 1985 at the age of 40 and is a citizen of both the United States and Canada. He is the author of The Ethics of Immigration.  Gary Gutting

title: Protect Yourself While Shopping on Black Friday, and Beyond
description: Over the past year, so many data breaches at retail chains and restaurants have come to light that its hard to keep track. So what does that mean for shoppers, as the holiday season gets underway?

title: In Ferguson, Issues of Race and Justice
A Dearth of Legal Services
description: To the Editor:

title: Hagels Exit From Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: College Admission Games
description: To the Editor:

title: Glacier(less) National Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Memories of Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Shakespeare Folio Discovered in France
description: First folios of Shakespeares plays are among the worlds rarest books, intensely scrutinized by scholars for what their sometimes-minute variations  each copy is different  reveal about the playwrights intentions.

title: How the Chicken Built America
description: THIS season millions of Americans will celebrate with turkey on the table. The turkey is, after all, the native North American animal that Benjamin Franklin considered a much more respectable bird than the scavenging bald eagle. But while the eagle landed on the countrys Great Seal and the turkey gets pride of place at our holiday dinners, neither bird can claim to have changed American culture more than their lowly avian cousin, the chicken.

title: The Problem With Prostate Screening
description: TUCSON  SCIENTIFIC data from clinical trials provides the foundation of medical decision making, from a doctors prescription pad to sweeping public health policies. Public trust that the data is accurate and unbiased is the glue that binds our $3 trillion health care system. I worry that this trust, particularly when it comes to American men and their physicians and screening programs for prostate cancer, is now at risk.

title: Holder Criticizes Violence in Ferguson
description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. emphasized the need for protesters to honor the wishes of Michael Browns father by demonstrating peacefully.

title: Inquiry Into Rape Claims Against Irish Republican Army
description: DUBLIN  The police and child protection agencies in Ireland are investigating rape and sexual abuse allegations against more than 30 former members of the Irish Republican Army, based on tips from people who were themselves once linked with the group.

title: When Italians Meet Turkey
description: Thanksgiving Day is almost upon us, and I havent yet summoned the nerve to tell Uncle Mario and Aunt Carolyn, who host it, that I may not arrive until a quarter past noon. Thatll make me more than an hour late, which by my rough arithmetic translates into 12 chilled shrimp, 15 mozzarella balls, four meatballs, a medium-size plate of stuffed mushrooms and a sizable wedge of frittata.

title: For New York City Officers, Drawing Guns Is Based on Discretion, Not Rules
description: There are some New York City police officers who can count on one hand the number of times they have drawn a gun, even over decades on the force.

title: Disney Pairs Up With Turner to Promote TCM and Great Movie Ride
description: THERE is a saying in Hollywood, attributed to Katharine Hepburn, about why the pairing of Fred Astaire and Gingers Rogers worked so well: He gave her class, and she gave him sex. Two familiar names in entertainment that are teaming up for another pas de deux may not be Astaire and Rogers, but they are giving each other something each wants.

title: Steven Cohens Ex-Wife Gets Outside Financing for Lawsuit
description: Steven A. Cohen may have fended off the government for the most part, but his former wife is another story. Patricia Cohen continues to pursue Mr. Cohen, claiming that the billionaire investor cheated her out of money during their divorce some two decades ago and potentially owes her millions of dollars.

title: Food Power!
description: There are four basic ways to change the food system. I talk about three of them a lot: The first is to eat differently, focusing on good food and especially plants; the second is to bring change to your work, whether that means becoming a farmer or helping other people eat better through your role as a teacher, doctor, artist, techie, lawyer or journalist. The third is to work locally to effect change in, for example, school systems or municipal politics.

title: Colombia: Rebels Free Two Soldiers
description: The countrys main rebel group on Tuesday released two low-ranking soldiers captured after a recent clash with government troops, but it remained unclear when it would free a general and two others it seized separately. The capture on Nov. 16 of the general, Rubn Daro Alzate, embarrassed the army and prompted President Juan Manuel Santos to suspend peace talks with the rebels, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. The guerrillas later agreed to release the general. But they warned this week that military operations in the region where the general was captured could disrupt his release. Mr. Santos has promised to resume peace talks once the captives are freed.

title: How the Civil War Created Thanksgiving
description: Of all the bedtime-story versions of American history we teach, the tidy Thanksgiving pageant may be the one stuffed with the heaviest serving of myth. This iconic tale is the main course in our nations foundation legend, complete with cardboard cutouts of bow-carrying Native American cherubs and pint-size Pilgrims in black hats with buckles. And legend it largely is.

title: A Call to Save a 12th-Century Minaret, Heard Far and Wide
description: JAM, Afghanistan  It is the place that launched a thousand postcards, back in the day when tourists still came in any numbers to Afghanistan: the Minaret of Jam.

title: Increase in Tax Revenue Lifts New York Citys Finances
description: The de Blasio administration released an updated plan on Tuesday for the current fiscal year, painting a relatively rosy financial picture amid higher-than-anticipated tax revenue and strong returns on pension investments.

title: New Frontier for Ebola
description: The huge, impoverished country of Mali looks like the new frontier in the fight to control the Ebola epidemic in West Africa. The virus has killed thousands in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, the three countries where the virus first emerged, but it has not gained much of a foothold elsewhere. Small outbreaks of 20 cases in Nigeria and a single case in Senegal were declared over in October. Now the potential for many more cases in neighboring Mali has health authorities scrambling to contain a small outbreak before it can get very far.

title: Lewis Baltz, Photographer of American Landscapes, Dies at 69
description: Lewis Baltz, whose caustic but formally beautiful black-and-white images of parking lots, office parks, industrial garage doors and the backs of anonymous warehouses helped forge a new tradition of American landscape photography in an age of urban sprawl, died on Saturday in Paris. He was 69.

title: Despite Chaos, Police in Ferguson React With Restraint Not Shown After August Killing
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  The night of smoke, fire, looting and chaos began not so much with an event, but a sound.

title: Nancy H. Teeters, First Woman on Federal Reserve Board, Dies at 84
description: Nancy H. Teeters, a liberal economist who was the first woman appointed to the Federal Reserve Board and who broke with tradition by openly criticizing decisions of fellow board members that she felt hurt consumers and working people, died on Nov. 17 in Stamford, Conn. She was 84.

title: Negative Numbers Piling Up for the 76ers
description: For the Philadelphia 76ers, the grind of an abysmal season has led to observations that are intended to seem optimistic but instead feel like the opposite.

title: A Passion for Writing, About War and Love, Is Celebrated Decades Later
description: A mailman by day, John J. Donaldson wrote by night in his Long Island home, where he had sacred space, a tenth of a Levittown living room, said Peter S. Donaldson, his eldest son. Everyone knew this corner. You didnt touch the notepads, the pencils. Dad would be there all hours typing, working on drafts.

title: Who Will Save the Democratic Party From Itself?
description: Not everyone agrees that Hillary Clintons selection as the Democratic nominee is unstoppable. The first to challenge her is Jim Webb, a one-term former senator from Virginia.

title: Seeking Par Off the Greens
description: NAPLES, Fla.  The woman wanted to practice with her boyfriend, a professional golfer, at T.P.C. Scottsdale, a regular stop on the PGA Tour. Her boyfriend, Martin Piller, received a free bag of pristine balls and access to the back range, where he could work in peace, close to the chipping area and practice green and away from the 30-handicappers and snowbirds.

title: State Investigating Womans Death After Nursing Home Evacuation
description: The State Department of Health is investigating the death of an elderly woman after she was evacuated from a nursing home outside Buffalo during last weeks huge snowfall, a Health Department official said Tuesday.

title: News Drumsticks
description: Thanksgiving is a time for dinner-table conversation. If youre short of news drumsticks to chew on, here are a few you may have missed.

title: A Potent, Overlooked Greenhouse Gas
description: Five years ago in Copenhagen, President Obama pledged to reduce Americas greenhouse gas emissions 17 percent below 2005 levels by 2020. In Beijing a few weeks ago, as part of a landmark agreement with China, he went one better by pledging a 26 percent to 28 percent cut by 2025. The first target will be hard to reach  and the second virtually impossible  without a determined effort on his part to cut methane emissions from the oil and gas industry.

title: Mixed Motives Seen in Prosecutors Decision to Release Ferguson Grand Jury Materials
description: A day after the St. Louis County prosecutor took the rare step of releasing thousands of pages of grand jury testimony in the Michael Brown case, his move prompted a sharp debate among legal experts, some of whom charged that what looked like the prosecutors transparency and neutrality cloaked his real goal  to ensure that no indictment of the police officer occurred.

title: Macys Thanksgiving Parade Brings Teenage Invasion to New York
description: There were ponytails and pompoms, the piercing squeals of teenage salutations and a pileup of girls sitting cross-legged in the middle of a hallway, blocking all traffic, oblivious to everything but their sparkly pink phones.

title: U.S.-Led Raid Frees 8 Qaeda Hostages From a Yemeni Cave
description: WASHINGTON  In a predawn raid on Tuesday, United States Special Operations commandos and Yemeni troops rescued eight hostages being held in a cave in a remote part of eastern Yemen by Al Qaedas affiliate there, officials from both countries said.

title: Group Seeks to Restore Retirement Pay for Army Officers
description: A bipartisan group of 15 senators has asked the Army to change a policy that strips some soldiers of their officer-retirement pay if the Army-wide drawdown forces them to retire. Currently, enlisted soldiers who become officers but have not served eight years before being forced to retire must retire at their highest enlisted pay  a difference of about $1,000 per month. In a letter to Army Secretary John McHugh, Senators Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, and Johnny Isakson, Republican of Georgia, said that to demote these soldiers in retirement is an injustice that devalues their service and will materially disadvantage them and their families for the rest of their lives.

title: Dodo Cheney, a Tennis Champion for Decades, Dies at 98
description: Dodo Cheney, a daughter of tennis royalty who wore lace and pearls as she rolled through generations of competitors on the way to winning 391 tennis championships in the United States, most of them after she turned 55, died on Sunday in Escondido, Calif. She was 98.

title: U.N. Extends Help for South Sudan
description: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Tuesday to extend its peacekeeping mission in South Sudan, where a nearly year-old civil conflict has killed thousands of civilians, uprooted more than 1.5 million and put more than seven million at risk of hunger and disease.

title: Focusing on Education for Familys Success
description: It is seldom easy to achieve ones dreams, but Naomi Bradshaw, 43, wishes it had not been quite so difficult.

title: Hagels Departure Bears Little Likeness to Rumsfelds Removal
description: WASHINGTON  With his party in a shambles after a disastrous midterm election and his administration ensnared in a messy war in the Middle East, the president stood in the East Room and showed his defense secretary the door.

title: When Cops Kill
Rescue Plan for a Marooned Miami Stadium
description: MIAMI  In a young city predisposed to wrecking and rebuilding, impressive works of architecture can sometimes be discarded as effortlessly as last years runway accessories.

title: Lettermans Favorite Activity
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  I liked this puzzle a lot for a few different reasons.

title: First Decision of the Game: For Belichick and the Patriots, Its No Tossup
description: It is well known that New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick likes to walk the unconventional line, whether it is going for it on fourth down, taking a deliberate safety or completely changing his offensive game plan in seven days.

title: Last of 5 Men Pleads Guilty in 2010 Drug Theft at a Connecticut Warehouse
description: NEW HAVEN  On a blustery, rainy Saturday night in March 2010, five men arrived at an Eli Lilly warehouse in Enfield, Conn. Their trip from South Florida had been planned for two months, prosecutors said, and they were about to steal millions of dollars in prescription drugs.

title: U.N. Urges Protection of Privacy in Digital Era
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations adopted a resolution on Tuesday urging all countries to protect the right to privacy in digital communications and to offer their citizens a way to seek remedy if their privacy is violated.

title: Reaction to Ferguson Decision Shows Racial Divide Remains Over Views of Justice
description: Paul McLemore, the first African-American to become a New Jersey state trooper, was on the streets of Newark in 1967 when riots following a police beating of a black taxi driver left 26 dead. He spent decades as a civil rights lawyer and years as a municipal judge in Trenton. His wife and children have gone on to enjoy accomplished careers.

title: For Former Embassy Hostages, a Special Interest in Iran Talks
description: WASHINGTON  When the United States agreed on Monday to extend the nuclear negotiations with Iran for another seven months, it was met with immediate protest from Republicans and some Democrats in Congress, as well as from hard-liners in Irans Parliament.

title: Thousands Protesting Ferguson Decision Block Traffic in New York City
description: Thousands of protesters marched through the streets of New York City for the second night on Tuesday, chanting loudly and blocking traffic on some of Manhattans busiest streets to express outrage over the decision not to indict a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo., in the death of an unarmed black man.

title: Obama Speaks About Ferguson Frustration
description: The day after a grand jury declined to indict Darren Wilson, President Obama addressed those unhappy with the decision, calling the concerns of the protesters rooted in realities.

title: North Korean Leader Assails American Aggressors
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Koreas leader, Kim Jong-un, condemned American aggressors as cannibals on Tuesday, as his government orchestrated a huge outdoor rally in Pyongyang to protest an American-supported move at the United Nations to refer the Norths leaders to an international court for human rights abuses.

title: Jets Join Hands as They Tumble Downhill
description: The Jets lost again, and it doesnt make a whole lot of sense to Rex Ryan.

title: With Ad, Neighbors Zero In on Bill de Blasio in Truck Ramp Dispute
description: A battle in Mayor Bill de Blasios backyard could become the next big public-relations headache for City Hall.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 25, 2014
With Carmelo Anthonys Back Ailing, Knicks Load Just Got Heavier
description: DALLAS  After another loss in a season already brimming with them, J. R. Smith spotted Carmelo Anthony in the locker room. It wasMondaynight at the Toyota Center in Houston, and Smith knew enough to keep his distance.

title: Bronx Driver Who Had Seizure Is Found Not Guilty in Fatal Crash
description: A Bronx man who had an epileptic seizure while driving two years ago and caused a crash that killed a 25-year-old man was cleared on Tuesday of all criminal charges.

title: Schumer Criticizes Timing of Affordable Care Act
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said Tuesday that it was a political mistake to pass the Affordable Care Act in 2010 because voters were looking instead for relief from the recession. Mr. Schumer, in remarks at the National Press Club, said Democrats should have built on the stimulus package that Congress passed to create programs to help middle-class Americans. Unfortunately, Democrats blew the opportunity the American people gave them, Mr. Schumer said, according to his prepared remarks. We took their mandate and put all of our focus on the wrong problem  health care reform. Republicans, he added, were able to exploit a sense among voters that Democrats were interested in creating new government programs that did not benefit them, helping to spawn the Tea Party movement.

title: Report Faults New York City Hall for Closed-Door Meeting
description: Mayor Bill de Blasios aides violated state law and city regulations in barring journalists from a meeting he attended with members of the Communications Workers of America at a Brooklyn public school in July, according to a new report by two city investigative agencies.

title: Balanced Villanova Casts Aside Some Lingering Doubts
description: There was valid reason to be skeptical about No. 12 Villanova entering Mondays marquee matchup against Virginia Commonwealth in the Legends Classic.

title: Making Sense of Ferguson
description: What article or book would you recommend for those who want to better understand events in Ferguson? We asked Times colleagues to weigh in.

title: Egypt: Apartment Building Collapses
description: An apartment building in Cairo collapsed Tuesday, killing at least 19 people as rescuers and neighbors frantically dug through rubble with their hands to find survivors, the authorities said. The building, in the eastern Matariya district, caved in around 1:30 a.m. as many inside slept, witnesses said. The collapse highlighted the longtime problem of shoddy construction across Egypt. Neighbors said several floors had been added illegally to the seven-story building. Egyptian developers frequently build without permits amid a housing shortage, rampant corruption and lax government oversight.

title: Obama Faces Protests in Chicago That Immigration Plan Is Too Meager
description: CHICAGO  It was supposed to be a triumphant homecoming for President Obama, and a chance to cast his executive action on immigration as the latest chapter in Americas history of welcoming foreigners.

title: Trustee Moves to Repay Creditors in Mt. Gox Bitcoin Exchange
description: Customers of Mt. Gox, once the worlds largest Bitcoin exchange, are closer to getting back at least some of the money they lost this year when it shut down and announced that their funds had gone missing.

title: Why Antioxidants Dont Belong in Your Workout
description: Antioxidant vitamins are enormously popular with people who exercise. The supplements are thought to alleviate muscle damage and amplify the effects of exercise. But recent studies have raised questions about whether antioxidants might be counterproductive for runners and other endurance athletes. And now a cautionary new experiment adds to those doubts by finding that antioxidants may also reduce the benefits of weight training.

title: Chris Rock: The Times Interview
description: The filmmaker, actor and comedian Chris Rock discusses his career and his latest film, Top Five.

title: Whats on TV Wednesday
description: 9 P.M. (Animal Planet) THE WHALE: REVENGE FROM THE DEEP (2014) Martin Sheen portrays Old Thomas Nickerson, who reminisces about his stint as a cabin boy on the ill-fated final voyage of the whaling ship Essex in this two-hour adventure. Adapted from real-life accounts of the boats sinking  written by First Mate Owen Chase (Jonas Armstrong) and Capt. George Pollard Jr. (Adam Rayner), and said to have inspired Melvilles Moby-Dick  the movie was filmed in Malta and Britain, using high-tech equipment to recreate the stormy seas that left the crew members fighting for survival against one another and a whale that refused to go peacefully.

title: Protests in New York Streets
description: In New York, thousands of protesters blocked streets on Tuesday night, protesting the decision not to indict a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo., for the fatal shooting of Michael Brown.

title: Protesters Flip Police Car in Ferguson
description: Protesters in Ferguson, Mo., flipped over a patrol car Tuesday evening. Tense demonstrations erupted in cities across the nation, although many of them were peaceful.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: People who try to stop these things are heroes, in my mind. I was disappointed that some members of the community resorted to violence.

title: Corrections: November 26, 2014
description: NEW YORK

description: equity \e-kw-te\ noun

title: Eat Turkey, Become American
description: When I was growing up in northern Minnesota, our familys Thanksgivings were straight out of a Norman Rockwell painting.

description: In The Thanksgiving Recipes Googled in Every State, The Times compiled a list of the most distinct holiday recipes searched for online by state.

title: British Telecom Giant BT in Talks to Acquire EE
description: LONDON  The European telecommunications giants Orange of France and Deutsche Telekom of Germany confirmed on Wednesday that they were in early-stage discussions to sell their joint venture EE to the British fixed-line provider BT.

title: Zimbabwes Vice President Is Barred From Party Panel
description: LONDON  A power struggle over who will succeed President Robert G. Mugabe of Zimbabwe seemed to sharpen on Wednesday when the state news media reported that the countrys vice president, once seen as his heir apparent, had been disqualified from an important panel of the governing ZANU-PF party because she had plotted to have Mr. Mugabe assassinated.

title: Test Yourself | An Amazing One-Handed Catch
description: Below are the first six paragraphs from the Nov. 24 article, Even Under Microscope, Catch by Giants Odell Beckham Jr. Earns Applause.

title: Pouring Shots and Shooting Portraits in the Old Times Square
description: The Times Square of the 1970s and 80s offered more than enough noir for any would-be Weegee. But many pictures of its characters  menacing or tragic, crumpled or proud, flamboyant or anesthetized  look exactly like what they are: voyeuristic images, grabbed on the fly by photographers who quickly moved on to other subjects.

title: What Is Your Reaction to the Sexual Assault Allegations Against Bill Cosby?
description: Until recently, Bill Cosby was one of TVs most beloved father figures for his role in the hit 1980s sitcom The Cosby Show. He now faces public allegations from at least 15 women  and the number is growing  that he raped them. Mr. Cosbys lawyers have vehemently denied the allegations.

title: European Legislator Urging the Breakup of Google Has Ties to a Law Firm
description: Andreas Schwab, a German member of the European Parliament, has been making headlines in the last week after drafting a resolution that calls for the breakup of Google.

title: Bean Sprouts Tainted With Banned Additive Are Again Found in China
description: Bean sprouts are back in the news for all the wrong reasons. Not for the first time, Chinese inspectors have found bean sprouts tainted with a banned food additive, in this instance in a production center on the southern outskirts of Beijing.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: New York Today: Snow Snarl
description: Good morning on this stormy getaway Wednesday.

title: Establishing Her Position in the Post
description: Late this summer, as Michele A. Roberts was finishing up one of her first long interviews as the newly appointed executive director of the National Basketball Players Association, she confessed to feeling some dread about moving into the spotlight of the news media.

title: A Ferguson Protest, in the Shadow of the Capitols Dome
description: The police were simply bystanders last night as protesters marching shoulder to shoulder clogged the streets in downtown Washington in a peaceful protest that was interrupted by at least one act of vandalism and a flag-burning.

title: Reaction in Ferguson After the Decision in the Michael Brown Shooting
description: Journalists with The New York Times in Ferguson, Mo., have been following a grand jurys decision not to indict Darren Wilson, a white police officer, in the shooting death of Michael Brown, an unarmed black teenager. Live updates have ended.

title: The Giving Tree: Take What You Want, Leave What You Can
Daily Report: Navigating Silicon Valleys Slippery Moral Slope
description: Ahh, Thanksgiving, the time of year to stop the daily drudgery and give thanks for what we have. To be grateful for our family, friends and health. Maybe this is also a perfect time to be thankful for all the wonderful things technology start-ups have done for society, Nick Bilton writes in his Disruptions column.

title: When a Business Owner Gets Cancer
description: In the spring of 2008, I had symptoms of what I thought was a heart condition. It made sense because I had a family history of heart disease. After several sleepless nights, I went to the doctor.

title: China Asks for Help Identifying and Returning Fugitive Officials
description: China wants other countries to do more to find and return Chinese officials suspected of having fled the country with purloined assets, a senior Foreign Ministry official said on Wednesday, as President Xi Jinpings anticorruption campaign seeks to extend its reach abroad.

title: Today in Politics
Happy Thanksgiving
description: Were taking a brief break for the holiday, but well return on Dec. 1 with our usual Monday offerings including Whats Going On in This Picture?, our daily Student Opinion question, 6 Qs About the News and more. Plus, during the first week of December well name the winners of our 15-Second Vocabulary Video Contest and announce our next student contest. Stay tuned!

title: Polio Crisis Deepens in Pakistan, With New Cases and Killings
description: LONDON  Pakistans polio crisis has reached new depths this year, health officials say, intensified by a deadly mix of ruthless militant violence, large-scale refugee displacement and political chaos that has cemented the countrys role as the central global incubator of a disease that other conflict-torn countries have managed to hold in check.

title: Ferguson, Still Tense, Grows Calmer
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  As residents swept broken glass from the sidewalks here on Wednesday and painted hopeful messages on boarded-up storefronts, public officials cautiously said that tighter security measures and hundreds of additional National Guard troops had helped stabilize this St. Louis suburb after a night of arson, looting and violence.

title: Morning Agenda: Financing for Suit by Steven Cohens Ex-Wife
description: FINANCING FOR SUIT BY STEVEN COHENS EX-WIFE | Steven A. Cohen may have fended off the government for the most part, but his former wife is another story, DealBooks Matthew Goldstein reports. Patricia Cohen continues to pursue Mr. Cohen, claiming that the billionaire investor cheated her out of money during their divorce some two decades ago and potentially owes her millions of dollars. Helping to fuel the long-running legal battle is Asta Funding, a financial backer of a Beverly Hills, Calif., firm that has provided litigation financing to Ms. Cohen. Asta and the firm that is financing Ms. Cohens lawsuit, Balance Point Divorce Funding, have an agreement to share in the proceeds of legal recoveries by clients. Ms. Cohens lawyers are scheduled to take a deposition from Mr. Cohen on Dec. 10.

title: O.K., Lets Make Something Great
description: Theres a scene in Top Five, the new film written by, directed by and starring Chris Rock, in which the action on screen and the soundtrack are in perfect harmony, precisely because theyre at complete odds.

title: The Daily Gift: A Basket Purse Inspired by Jane Birkin
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: Tech Toys That Go Beyond the Screen
description: When we talk about childrens access to digital technology, we often focus on screen time, but that term is a bit antiquated. Across the industry, the Internet is escaping the screen.

title: A Window Washer Looks Back
description: Dear Diary:

title: Daily Clip Report
description: Good morning. Here is Daily Clip Report, a collection of articles about The Times and the media sent by email each morning to senior executives and newsroom editors. The email is produced by the Corporate Communications Department at The Times.

title: Geno Smith Will Start for Jets Against Dolphins
description: This season, the Jets have won two games and made two quarterback changes. They hope starting Geno Smith in their next game will help break the tie.

title: Sharing Polling Numbers on Twitter: Decoding a Mystery
description: Perhaps the most bizarre electoral news since the midterms is the allegation that Republican operatives and outside groups used clandestine Twitter accounts to share polling data.

title: Exploring Stories of an Infamous Duo
description: The trial and execution of the anarchists Sacco and Vanzetti, a scandalous cause clbre during the 1920s, is the subject of the latest work from Joseph Silovsky, who creates theater mixing robotics, puppetry and video. Send for the Million Men, part of the season at the genre-blending Here Arts Center, will use original text, historical documents and spontaneous storytelling to explore the stories of Sacco and Vanzetti, who were convicted of killing two men during the armed robbery of a Massachusetts shoe factory, and whose execution sparked an international outcry.

title: Keynes Is Slowly Winning
description: Back in 2010, I had a revelation about just how bad economic policy was about to get; I read the OECD Economic Outlook, which called not just for fiscal austerity but for interest rate hikes  350 basis points on the Fed funds rate by the end of 2011!  because, well, because.

title: Elvis, Brooding and Alienated
description: Directed by Don Siegel, the evocatively titled Flaming Star (1960), out on Blu-ray from Twilight, is arguably the best movie Elvis Presley ever made: a wide-screen western as steeped in racial animus as John Fords The Searchers (1956).

title: Indian Factories Will Count and Sell Their Energy Savings
description: SAN FRANCISCO  India, the worlds third-largest producer of greenhouse gas, after China and the United States, has resisted international pressure to commit to capping planet-warming emissions. But when it comes to saving energy, India is moving ahead briskly.

title: Yearning to Make the Connection
description: LOS ANGELES  One of this years surprise cinematic success stories centers on the independent film Still Alice, which tells the tale of an Ivy League linguistics professor dealing with early-onset Alzheimers.

title: David Baldacci: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of The Escape was a library rat growing up: Libraries are the mainstays of democracy. The first thing dictators do when taking over a country is close all the libraries, because libraries are full of ideas.

title: Deep Dish From Sam Sifton, The Timess Cooking Editor
description: Q.

title: An American in Paris Takes to the Stage
description: The stars align for the theatrical debut of a Gershwin classic.

title: 1914: Naval Squadron Shells Belgium
description: LONDON  There was a heavy bombardment of Zeebrugge and Heyst (the sea end of the Bruges canal) by a British naval squadron on Monday afternoon. An unknown number of ships appeared unexpectedly through the mist, and at once began a heavy attack from between three and four miles range. A German battery at Heyst was knocked out of action. Hotels and buildings of which the Germans had taken possession were severely shelled, and a big building near the harbor was set on fire. Fugitives report that the Palace Hotel, in which the German Naval Staff was quartered, had been levelled to the ground.  The New York Herald, European Edition, Nov. 27, 1914

title: A Dive Where Regulars Were Shot Regularly
description: Few movies capture the despair and degradation of 1970s New York better than Taxi Driver. So it is perfectly fitting that the Terminal Bar should have had a cameo role.

title: 7 Officers Arrested in Beating of a Protester in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  Seven police officers were arrested in Hong Kong on Wednesday, accused in the beating of a pro-democracy protester last month.

title: Reply All: The 11.16.14 Issue
description: WELCOME TO THE FAILURE AGE!

title: Sri Lankan Kottu Roti, by Way of Staten Island
description: In the atlas of Little neighborhoods  the Little Italys, Little Tokyos, Little Indias of the world  New Yorks Little Sri Lanka may be the littlest. Its just one and a half blocks, and its groceries and restaurants share the Staten Island North Shore streetscape with bodegas and an Albanian pizzeria. But around here is where youll find one of the largest Sri Lankan communities in the United States  roughly 5,000 people, many of whom came to escape their homelands decades-long civil war, starting in 1983.

title: Two Cocktails to Chill Your Chill Away
description: As any New Yorker will recall, last winter was brutal. But when the first big storm rolled in, I knew just what to do. I grabbed a long-languishing bottle of crme de cacao and a not-quite top-shelf brandy, and I rooted through my pantry for whole nutmeg. Then I pulled on my boots and my parka and slogged to the deli for a pint of heavy cream. When I got home, I shook up the first brandy Alexander I had made, or even drank, in years, and declared it my official house cocktail of that whole interminable winter. For the next few months, I took great pleasure in greeting visitors with a drink at the ready and my nutmeg grater in hand. Brandy Alexanders proved irresistible to even the most stern, steadfast I-dont-like-sweet-stuff sorts.

title: The Iguana in the Bathtub
description: When the temperature dipped below 40, iguanas started falling from the trees. Small, sleek green iguanas; big iguanas as long as four feet from snout to tail, scales cresting gloriously from their heads; orange-and-green iguanas, their muscled, goose-pimpled arms resolving into sharp claws. Iguanas were everywhere: in the bushy areas surrounding canals, on sidewalks, in backyards, lying helpless among the fallen, rotting fruit of mango and orange trees.

title: Sarah Koenig Cant Promise a Perfect Ending to Serial
description: The journalist talks with Taffy Brodesser-Akner about striking a balance between entertainment and journalism as she investigates a 15-year-old murder case.

title: Should Free Office Food Be Taken Home?
description: My company offers certain food items free in our office pantry. Every morning, my co-worker Brandon eats a serving of Cheerios from the pantry while getting settled for the day. Would it be acceptable for him to take the cereal home the night before and eat it before going to the office? Brandon swears that hes more productive after he eats, and taking the cereal home would allow him to eat on his time (instead of after arriving at the office). Since the food is offered freely, whats the harm? DAVID McCORMACK, NEW YORK

title: The Militarys Rough Justice on Sexual Assault
description: Col. Don Christensen, the chief prosecutor of the United States Air Force, sat in economy class on a flight to Venice and studied the folder of the sexual-assault case that would ultimately end his career. It was August 2012, and he was en route to Aviano Air Base to try a court-martial. Looking over the case, he could see why the judge advocate general, or JAG, at the base had requested him. Christensen had prosecuted more sexual-assault courts-martial than any other lawyer in the Air Force, and this case called for someone with experience. There would most likely be generals testifying. The accused himself was a senior officer. Even Christensen had seldom handled cases involving men of high rank. There was a simple reason for this: Victims were reluctant to report such officers, who enjoyed their own set of rules in the military justice system.

title: The Mine Disaster That Shook Turkey
description: That morning, Tugba woke at 4 to clean the three-room stone house, which leaned into a hill full of apple trees. She and her husband, Ahmet, grew up here in Kayrakalti, a village in the western Aegean region of Turkey, between conservative Anatolia and the raki-and-cigarettes coast. Already, a bus that would pick up Ahmet for work was making its way through the areas cypress trees and olive farms. Tugba had gone to the bedroom to nurse their daughter, who was just three days shy of her first birthday, and they had fallen back asleep, so Ahmet left without eating breakfast. Tugba was 18 and Ahmet 30, and sometimes they still blushed around each other; their faces shone with youth, hers heart-shaped, his angular and fair. That morning, Tugba, asleep with the baby who looked like her, did not say goodbye.

title: Theo Jansens Lumbering Life-Forms Arrive in America
description: On a blustery October afternoon, on a gently raised hill above Ypenburg, the Netherlands, roughly halfway between The Hague and Delft, the 66-year-old once-aspiring physicist Theo Jansen and several assistants busily prepared to launch an odd sort of species invasion. In a few weeks, Jansens strandbeests  the huge self-propelled beach-striding contraptions that Jansen has spent the better part of the past quarter-century conceiving, evolving and constructing from out of ever more ambitious concatenations of lightweight yellow PVC tubing and spiny white sails  would be strutting their improbably lifelike stuff up and down Miami Beach at Art Basel, to the drop-jawed amazement of all. But for the moment, Jansen had to carefully, with near-veterinary skill, slice and fold six of the wide-slung beests into two 40-foot-long shipping containers, so that they would survive the rigors of their Atlantic passage.

title: A New Fleet of Spacecraft
description: The new generation of spacecraft, expected to be in use beginning in 2015.

title: New York Schools Lose Millions Amid an Inquiry, Comptroller Says
description: New York City has been missing out on tens of millions of dollars a year in technology funding for schools from the federal government because of a continuing investigation into the Education Department, the city comptroller said this week.

description: Winter storm Cato is predicted to make its way up the Eastern states from North Carolina to Maine just in time to drop anywhere from one to six inches of snow in the Northeast and mid-Atlantic United States on one of the busiest travel days of the year.

description: LONDON  Europe is taking aim at Google, again.

title: Tate Museums Offer Minecraft Maps of Famous Artworks
description: LONDON  You can stop telling your children to get off the computer. The Tate museums and the wildly popular 3-D video game Minecraft have teamed up to create Tate Worlds, a series of virtual environments based on specific artworks. The game, which allows players to create their own virtual worlds, will use the paintings and sculptures, called maps, to generate activities or tasks that relate to the themes of the artwork.

title: Letter From the Editor: The Search for Food
description: Internet access in the United States is now sufficiently close to ubiquitous that Google searching has become a tool of social science, a way to understand what Americans are thinking and doing. Searches for the words vote or voting have helped predict voter turnout in the last few elections. Searches on various flu symptoms help public-health researchers track epidemics. Search patterns can also help forecast the unemployment rate and vehicle sales.

title: Stuff We Liked: The Sweet Season
description: The Upshot staff had such fun with our state-by-state Thanksgiving food searches that it made us hungry for more.

description: Thanksgiving is here, which gives writers across the country an easy theme to work with. Were not too proud to play along, fantasy football-style:

title: Another Word for Mr. President? Obamas Action on Immigration Draws Suggestions
description: President Obamas executive action on immigration has provoked outrage, especially on the right and a range of epithets or comparisons, directly or in passing, to other figures of authority. Here are a few examples.

title: After Ferguson, When Will We Listen?
description: The American justice system has proven time and again that if you are a person of color and/or poor in this country, your life does not matter as much. All one has to do is be suspicious and appear out of place  which is the definition of being poor and/or of color in our country  and state induced violence will always receive the benefit of the doubt.

description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals just spent the year in the make William Ackman even richer business.

title: Afghans Are Surprisingly Optimistic
description: After the lives lost and the billions spent and often wasted in Afghanistan, it is easy for Americans to be discouraged about the countrys future. The Taliban continues to be a serious threat as does corruption, while the economy is largely dependent on dwindling international handouts.

title: 36 Hours in Santa Fe
description: Explore street view, find our points of interest and sign in to your Google account to save your map.

title: Editors Choice
description: PENELOPE FITZGERALD: A Life,  by Hermione Lee. (Knopf, $35.) In this delicate portrait, Lee takes on the challenge of an elusive late-bloomer, the great novelist and biographer who published her first book at 58 and became famous at 80.

title: Paperback Row
description: WEALTH AND POWER: Chinas Long March to the Twenty-First Century,  by Orville Schell and John Delury. (Random House, $17.) Many countries revel in their victories, but China is driven by the humiliations it has suffered at the hands of foreigners over the past two centuries. Through 11 biographical sketches of Chinese intellectuals and political leaders  Wei Yuan, Sun Yat-sen, Deng Xiaoping  Schell and Delury trace the cultural origins of the countrys ascent from imperial doormat to global economic powerhouse.

title: Shops on Wheels, but the Goods Arent Sold From the Trunk
description: Most weekday mornings, Jessie Goldenberg can be found driving around the Flatiron district or Lower Manhattan searching for just the right parking space for her truck. And Black Friday will be no different, as competition for consumer dollars heats up for the holiday season.

title: Elegy for a Stranger
description: One of Margaret Wise Browns more controversial picture books was The Dead Bird, published in 1958, in which a group of children find a dead bird, feel bad, but are then glad they found it because now they can dig a grave in the woods and bury it. They could have a funeral and sing to it the way grown-up people did when someone died.

title: Harry Reid Wants to Talk About the Vatican
description: On a recent afternoon in the Senate majority leaders office, Harry Reid decided he was done talking about his chief of staff, David Krone. Instead, he and his top aide wanted to chat about the Vatican.

title: Classical Playlist: Dvorak, Haydn, Monteverdi and More
description: DVORAK: Symphony No. 6, American SuiteLucerne Symphony Orchestra, James Gaffigan, conductor(Harmonia Mundi 902188)The talented young American conductor James Gaffigan leads his Lucerne Symphony Orchestra in a powerful, polished account of Dvoraks Sixth, glowing with sunshine in the first movement and crisply focused in the last. If theres room for more feverish intensity in the Scherzo, Mr. Gaffigan and the orchestra largely get there by the end of the Finale, as they also do in a bonus: the gleaming, swirling American Suite, both tender and ferocious. (Zachary Woolfe)

title: Dont Believe the Hype: Holiday Sales Wont Make or Break the Economy
description: If theres one thing that the news media across the country can agree upon every November, it is this: The holiday sales season is a time of huge stakes for the economy.

description: A roundup of motoring news from the web:

title: Intensive Thanksgiving
description: The overtired resident approached the entry to my sons hospital room.

title: App Smart | Magic at Your Fingertips
description: Kit Eaton reviews three apps designed to help you dazzle friends and family with magic tricks that use your phone as a prop.

title: Reading The Times With Spike Feresten
description: Spike Feresten hosts the Car Matchmaker TV series on Esquire Network. He says he reads the paper with a hot cup of coffee and a locked door to keep the kids away. Here are his thoughts on Tuesdays paper and The Times in general.

title: A Little Abracadabra on the Phone
description: THOUGH few of us will ever be as deft at prestidigitation as Penn and Teller, or as slick at illusion as David Blaine, most of us already possess a tool for performing impressive conjuring tricks: a smartphone. With the right apps and a bit of practice, your smartphone can help you learn classic magic and even play a part in some 21st-century sleight of hand.

title: Putins Power, and Cold Feet
description: This week, Rajan Menon reviews Putins Kleptocracy, Karen Dawishas book about Vladimir Putins rise to power. The book argues, in part, that Putin has extensive links to organized crime.

title: New Novellas About Family by Ludmilla Petrushevskaya
description: It is hard to resist Ludmilla Petrushevskayas darkly comic new collection of novellas, There Once Lived a Mother Who Loved Her Children, Until They Moved Back In. The suffocating domestic life she renders so vividly begins before you even open the book. The cover itself is cleverly claustrophobic with the title crammed above a drawing of an unhappy family staring at a picked-over roast.

title: Stalin, by Stephen Kotkin
description: Two contrasting pictures emerge from the appraisals of Joseph Stalin written by his revolutionary colleagues and competitors. On the one hand, there was, for example, a fellow Georgian who knew Stalin in his early years as a Bolshevik organizer and who describes his unquestionably greater energy, indefatigable capacity for hard work, unconquerable lust for power and above all his enormous particularistic organizational talent. On the other, there are the unflattering judgments of his most virulent opponents in the Bolshevik hierarchy, from Leon Trotsky, who thought Stalin the outstanding mediocrity of our party, to Lev Kamenev, who considered the man who came to preside over the vast expanses of the reconstituted Russian empire a small-town politician.

title: Spies Like Hers
description: This years news felt disarmingly retro. Israel bombing Gaza. Russia invading portions of Ukraine. A nuclear arsenal ramp-up by both America and Russia. Had we traveled back in time to the 1980s, albeit with a millisecond-long news cycle sped up by smartphones and social media?

title: Tolstoys False Disciple, by Alexandra Popoff
description: In 1910, Lev Tolstoy died of pneumonia in a filthy house at a provincial train station. He had fled home at the urging of his closest disciple, Vladimir Chertkov, a cunning, talentless man. How did the mediocre Chertkov come to be beside Russias greatest writer as he died, even as Tolstoys wife, Sophia, stared through the window, denied entry? In Tolstoys False Disciple, Alexandra Popoff, the author of the biography Sophia Tolstoy and The Wives: The Women Behind Russias Literary Giants, draws on long unavailable archival materials, including Chertkovs letters, to examine the relationship that tore apart Tolstoys family and threatened his literary legacy.

title: Letters: Inside Attica
description: Inside Attica

title: Leningrad: Siege and Symphony, by Brian Moynahan
description: On May 1, 1945, Joseph Stalin proclaimed Leningrad a hero city for the bravery it showed during World War II. So it is fitting that the real hero of Brian Moynahans often harrowing Leningrad: Siege and Symphony is the city itself and not Dmitri Shostakovich, who composed his wartime Symphony No. 7 (Leningrad) in its honor.

title: George Marshall, by Debi and Irwin Unger with Stanley Hirshson
description: Where have all the great generals gone? The United States has been at war since 2001  its longest period of uninterrupted conflict  and for considerable stretches of the last half-century. Yet during all those years the nation has produced no military commanders of undeniable greatness.

title: Ismail Kadares Twilight of the Eastern Gods
description: The narrator of Twilight of the Eastern Gods is unnamed, but we might as well call him Ismail. Like Ismail Kadare, he is a student at the Gorky Institute for World Literature in Moscow in the late 1950s. He tells someone hes writing a book about a dead army commanded by a living general  an allusion to Kadares 1963 novel, The General of the Dead Army, in which an Italian officer returns to Albania after the Second World War to disinter the bones of his soldiers.
