description: Julia Belluz has a nice piece about weight loss, which a lot of us will be thinking about tomorrow morning. Two things really resonated: The absence of any well-defined best diet, and the importance of tracking.

title: Behind the Fanciful Creatures and Wide-Eyed Waifs
description: The Kingdom of Dreams and Madness documents the inner workings of Studio Ghibli, the Japanese animation studio, at a time when its two most celebrated directors were making new films. The movie largely focuses on Hayao Miyazaki, who formally announced his retirement after The Wind Rises had its premiere in 2013. The Tale of the Princess Kaguya, by Isao Takahata (Grave of the Fireflies), Mr. Miyazakis discoverer and friendly rival, opened in New York this year.

title: Home Sweet Home on the Isolated Ice
description: The extremes of Antarctica: A Year on Ice might seem routine to fans of nature documentaries, but the photographer and director Anthony Powell produces some dazzling imagery in his droll study of isolation way, way down under. His varied tour of Antarcticas scientific stations and their long-term residents is like a jokey, expertly shot slide show from another world.

title: Liberal Treasury Nominees Wall St. Prowess May Be a Vulnerability
description: WASHINGTON  In 2012, Antonio F. Weiss took his 15-year-old son, Nico, from the gilded aerie of their Manhattan apartment on Central Park West to Cleveland to canvass for President Obamas re-election. Mr. Weiss, 48, was also the co-author of a white paper calling for higher taxes on the rich and has donated hundreds of thousands of dollars to the Democratic Party.

title: Is Our Art Equal to the Challenges of Our Times?
description: A. O. Scott and a panel of cultural figures ponder whether and how artists should address social issues like race and class through their work. Mr. Scotts essay is below; the panel discussion is here.

title: Who Knew the Classics Could Be So Combative?
description: In The Historian, life at a university classics department barely stops short of brawling. The movie conveys this hostile atmosphere almost immediately, when the domineering department leader, Dr. Valerian Hadley (William Sadler), corrects a student. The Romans didnt invent crucifixion, he says. They perfected it. He uses the student for a pantomime demonstration.

title: A New Home at the Frick for a Rare Murillo Work
description: The Frick Collection has always been rich in Spanish paintings, particularly works by Velzquez, El Greco and Goya. The museums founder, Henry Clay Frick, bought three canvases by El Greco on his travels to Spain, and they currently hang together as part of El Greco in New York, an exhibition organized in collaboration with the Frick, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Hispanic Society to commemorate the 400th anniversary of the artists death.

title: Whos Who
description: KEN BURNS is a documentarian whose PBS series include The Roosevelts: An Intimate History. He is executive producer of The Emperor of All Maladies, due next year.

title: Swiss Unveil Art Amassed by Dealer in Nazi Era
description: BERLIN  Fresh mysteries and marvels of the art trove amassed by a Nazi-era art dealer and kept secret for decades unfurled on Thursday when the Swiss museum that inherited the collection revealed all 1,600 or so works to the world for the first time.

title: Race, Class and Creative Spark
description: A. O. Scott and a panel of cultural figures ponder whether and how artists should address social issues like race and class through their work. The panel discussion is below; Mr. Scotts essay is here.

title: Klara Liden Unveils Its Complicated
description: Its Complicated, Klara Lidens most ambitious New York show to date, is well named. Continuing Ms. Lidens inspired yet homey and often utilitarian transformations of space, materials and social relationships, it presents a video and improvised furniture on each of two adjacent floors. While not as flashy as her last show  which filled the gallery with discarded Christmas trees  this one compellingly mixes art and life, labor and relaxation, and various bodies and limbs, animate and not.

title: Germany and France Aim to Avert a Lost Decade
description: PARIS  The economy ministers of France and Germany called on Thursday for urgent overhauls and a series of investments in both countries to help prevent them and the eurozone from falling into a stagnation trap.

title: At Minnesota, a Staff Devoted to the Long Run
description: MINNEAPOLIS  It took a few moments for Matt Limegrover, Minnesotas offensive coordinator and line coach, to remember the last time another university tried to lure him from Coach Jerry Kills staff. He surmised it might have been after the 2011 season, the first that he, Kill and Tracy Claeys, the defensive coordinator, spent with the Golden Gophers.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: The Numbers Add Up to Republican Dominance
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Texas, a hothouse for Republicans, is a decidedly hostile environment for Democrats. If that was not obvious in the first readings of election results this month and in the continuation of the Republican winning streak in statewide races, a dive into the numbers shows the depth of the hole Democrats are trying to fill.

title: Twangy, Jazzy, Stately, Holy
description: THE holidays are a time for family, for reflection, for conspicuous consumption. For musicians, theyre a time to tackle old standards and see who comes out on top, or to try to record new ones, because theres no bigger gift than hubris. Here, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times reach down into their stockings and hope theres no coal. (Prices may vary, depending on whether youve been naughty or nice.) JON CARAMANICA

title: Texas Must Now Decide Where to Spend Oil Boom Money Dedicated to Roadwork
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Eighty percent of Texas voters approved a measure this month to increase transportation funding without raising taxes or fees. Proposition 1 is expected to add billions to the state highway fund by dedicating some of the tax revenue from the oil boom to road construction and maintenance.

title: Lone Star State Bets Heavily on a Space Economy
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Someday capsules sent aloft from a New Mexico desert will whisk celebrity passengers on flights into suborbital space.

title: Financial Incentives in Health Care
Food Safety and Worker Safety Are Inextricably Linked
description: To the Editor:

title: The Monitoring of Protests at the Supreme Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Detroits Pension Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Shoppers Line Up for Black Friday Deals
description: Work crews were still cleaning up confetti from the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade when the lines began forming outside the storefronts in Herald Square. Some shoppers were there for the sales, starting across the nation earlier than ever this year. Others were there just to revel in the spectacle of what many retailers are now calling Gray Thursday.

title: The Trick to Being More Virtuous
description: SEVERAL years ago, I visited Provo, Utah  in the heart of what its residents call Happy Valley  to deliver a lecture at Brigham Young University. My gracious hosts sent me home with a prodigious amount of branded souvenirs: T-shirts, mugs  you name it. The Mormons are serious about product placement.

title: Remember the Sand Creek Massacre
description: NEW HAVEN  MANY people think of the Civil War and Americas Indian wars as distinct subjects, one following the other. But those who study the Sand Creek Massacre know different.

title: An Inclusive Emerging Economy, With Africa in the Lead
description: At a time when news about Africa has been dominated by Ebola, its worth observing that a highly encouraging change has been quietly spreading across the continent. Over the past five years, the number of Africans  mainly women  who have joined village-based savings and loan associations has soared to more than nine million. These groups are now operating in 40 countries in Africa. Globally, its estimated that 10.5 million people are members of formally trained savings groups in about 65 countries. (PDF) The big story about these groups, including their surprising success and emerging importance in development, comes from Africa.

title: After a Time Without a Team, Ex-Ranger Michael Del Zotto Settles In With the Flyers
description: Michael Del Zotto acknowledged that being a visitor at Madison Square Garden was a strange feeling.

title: Theater Listings for Nov. 28-Dec.4
description: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Comedy Listings for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
description: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Conflicting Policies on Syria and Islamic State Erode U.S. Standing in Mideast
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  American and Syrian warplanes screamed over the Syrian city of Raqqa in separate raids this week, ostensibly against the same target, the Islamic State militants in control there.

title: Israel Says Hamas Ring Plotted West Bank Attacks
description: JERUSALEM  The Shin Bet, Israels internal security agency, says it has exposed an extensive Hamas military infrastructure in the West Bank that was planning to carry out attacks on Israelis, according to a statement issued by the agency on Thursday.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Beauty Brand Creates Campaign to Combat Mental Illness
description: NEARLY 40,000 Americans commit suicide annually, about the same number that die from breast cancer. But while countless brands adopt pink packaging to raise awareness during Breast Cancer Awareness Month in October, corporate support for mental illness, the cause of most suicides, is decidedly scant.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
description: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Jazz Listings for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
description: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Opera & Classical Music Listings for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
description: Reviews of classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Events on Long Island for Nov. 30-Dec. 6, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Westchester for Nov. 30-Dec. 6, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Events in New Jersey for Nov. 30-Dec. 6, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events in Connecticut for Nov. 30-Dec. 6, 2014
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Kindle Versus Ipad: Which Tablet Is Best for Kids?
description: As loving parents and grandparents, we are hardwired to seek out the best for our offspring, whether it be food, strollers or a college education. Strollers are generally straightforward purchases, but what about first tablets?

title: Dance Listings for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
description: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

title: U.S.-Backed Mortgages Put to Test in an Innovative Lawsuit
description: When Hayward Ferrell of Huber Heights, Ohio, fell behind on his mortgage payments several years ago, his bank did not meet with him to try to work out a plan to make the loan easier to pay, he says.

title: Museum & Gallery Listings for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
description: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Spare Times for Children for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
description: The Amazing Adventures of Harvey and the Princess

title: Urban Farmers Trade Goods and Stories at Crop Swaps
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  The Bay Area is a culinary never-never land, a place where aspiring apiarists hire beekeeping coaches, and even 7-year-olds can discuss the virtues of Himalayan salt.

title: Spare Times for Nov. 28-Dec. 4
description: Around Town

title: Fridays College Football Games to Watch
description: STANFORD at 9 U.C.L.A.

title: As Mexican Border Town Tries to Move On, Some Are Stuck in Limbo
description: TIJUANA, Mexico  Under a gleaming midday sun, in the fetid drainage canal that is the Rio Tijuana, Valentin Gomez plunged a hypodermic needle of crystal meth just under a friends collarbone.

title: With Naming Rights, Perpetuity Doesnt Always Mean Forever
description: After Philippe de Montebello agreed at breakfast two decades ago to name the Metropolitan Museum of Arts Roman Sculpture Court, in perpetuity, for the philanthropists and antiquities collectors Leon Levy and his wife, Shelby White, Mr. Levy predictably, but politely, posed an impertinent question.

title: For New Tappan Zee, Questions Persist Over How High the Tolls Will Climb
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.  One of the great travel bargains in the New York City area is crossing the Hudson River from Rockland County into Westchester County.

title: The Ambition Explosion
description: In 1976, Daniel Bell published a book called The Cultural Contradictions of Capitalism. Bell argued that capitalism undermines itself because it nurtures a population of ever more self-gratifying consumers. These people may start out as industrious, but they soon get addicted to affluence, spending, credit and pleasure and stop being the sort of hard workers capitalism requires.

title: A Tilt Toward NATO in Ukraine as Parliament Meets
description: MOSCOW  As Ukraines new Parliament, firmly controlled by a coalition of pro-Western parties, convened for the first time on Thursday, President Petro O. Poroshenko urged lawmakers to repeal a 2010 law that codified the countrys nonaligned status in global affairs, and to instead pursue membership in NATO.

title: Pollution and Politics
description: Earlier this week, the Environmental Protection Agency announced proposed regulations to curb emissions of ozone, which causes smog, not to mention asthma, heart disease and premature death. And you know what happened: Republicans went on the attack, claiming that the new rules would impose enormous costs.

title: In Peru, a Fight Over Land Rights
description: In September, four indigenous activists who stood up to unscrupulous loggers in a remote region of Perus rain forest were slain. The deaths could have easily gone unnoticed. Their village, Saweto, is a seven-day canoe ride from the nearest city. There is minimal government presence in the countrys vast rain forest, which is home to more than 300,000 indigenous people.

title: At 0-15, 76ers Are Perfecting the Art of Tanking
description: PHILADELPHIA  An hour before the Philadelphia 76ers hosted the Nets on Wednesday night, Dan Norfleet stood inside the Septa station near the Wells Fargo Center, where he coordinates trains as they come and go. Norfleet is a familiar face to Philadelphiafans, and in his job he directs them  depending on the season  to the nearby baseball, football and basketball arenas.

title: Mexican Leader, Facing Protests, Promises to Overhaul Policing
description: MEXICO CITY  Facing waves of anger and frustration after local officials and the police were implicated in the disappearance and presumed murder of 43 college students, President Enrique Pea Nieto on Thursday proposed a broad plan to revamp local policing, stamp out corruption and establish the rule of law nationwide.

title: Gay Men Should Be Allowed to Give Blood
description: Although the American Red Cross regularly warns that the national blood supply is too low, the Food and Drug Administration arbitrarily excludes a slice of the population from becoming a donor. Any man who has had sex with another man since 1977 is deferred  a euphemism for banned  since the deferral lasts a lifetime.

title: The New G.O.P. Showdown Threat
description: Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama announced with great gravity the other day that Republicans had decided not to impeach President Obama over his plan to allow millions of immigrants to remain in this country without fear of deportation through his executive authority. But that concession is not the end of the matter. He is planning much more serious mischief: using Congresss power of the purse to pressure the White House into backing off.

title: In Ferguson, Officer Defused Eruptions as Crowds Grew Tense
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Late Wednesday, two nights after rioting left blocks of this suburban city in smoldering ruin, a small but angry crowd assembled at the police station on South Florissant Road.

title: Eagles Come Out Strong Against Cowboys and Take Division Lead
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The fake was so good, a classic read-option sleight of hand, that a blue wave of Dallas Cowboys defenders crashed down the line of scrimmage toward LeSean McCoy like surf at high tide.

title: Chinese Dissidents Trial to Begin
description: HONG KONG  A prominent Chinese dissident, Yang Maodong, and another activist were set to go on trial in southern China on Friday, the latest adversaries of the Communist Partys censorship and controls likely to be convicted and imprisoned for years on charges of disrupting public order.

title: In Arizona, a Textbook Fuels a Broader Dispute Over Sex Education
description: GILBERT, Ariz.  The textbook, the one with the wide-eyed lemur peering off the cover, has been handed out for years to students in honors biology classes at the high schools here, offering lessons on bread-and-butter subjects like mitosis and meiosis, photosynthesis and anatomy.

title: Despite Aid Push, Ebola Is Raging in Sierra Leone
description: KISSI TOWN, Sierra Leone  Military choppers thunder over the slums. Nearly a thousand British soldiers are on the scene, ferrying supplies and hammering together new Ebola clinics. Crates of food and medicine are flowing into the port, and planeloads of experts seem to arrive every day  Ugandan doctors, Chinese epidemiologists, Australian logisticians, even an ambulance specialist from London.

title: Lester Bernstein, 94, Dies; Wide-Ranging Journalist Edited Newsweek
description: Lester Bernstein, a former editor of Newsweek magazine who also wrote for The New York Times, was a foreign correspondent for Time magazine and, as a vice president of NBC in 1960, helped arrange Americas first televised presidential debates, died on Thursday at his home in Lido Beach, N.Y. He was 94.

title: Time of Annual Madness
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  So there I was, cruising along with an unusually successful solving streak, when I ran into Tracy Grays Friday puzzle and totally tanked.

title: Restoring Lost Names, Recapturing Lost Dignity
description: OVID, N.Y.  For a half-century, a slight and precise man with an Old World mustache resided as a patient at the Willard State Psychiatric Hospital, here beside spectacular Seneca Lake. You are not supposed to know his name, but it was Lawrence Mocha. He was the gravedigger.

title: A Son Seeks Art Looted by the East Germans
description: Just after sunrise on a March morning in 1982, the secret police pounded on the door of Helmuth Meissner, a Dresden art collector known for his refined taste.

title: Grateful for Whats Left, Not Mourning Whats Lost
description: Stricken by polio as an infant, Anna Maria Walsh regained her lost mobility as a teenager, crediting a miracle for sparing her life and restoring her body.

title: Anger Upstate Over Power Plan for New York City
description: RHINEBECK, N.Y.  Residents of the rolling landscape in much of the Hudson Valley have long lived with high-voltage electric transmission lines and the giant columns of hulking steel towers that look as though they were assembled out of a childs Erector set. The lines have cut corridors through the countryside since at least the 1930s.

title: Fordham Finds Key to Success, and Drills It Home
description: When Joe Moorhead took over the football program at Fordham, after it struck bottom with a 1-10 record in 2011, the technical aspects of the sport were secondary to his emphasis on discipline, work ethic and attention to detail.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 27, 2014
The Future of Wearable Tech
Japan to Ask Automakers to Recall Vehicles With Faulty Takata Airbags
description: TOKYO  Japan will follow the United States in forcing automakers to recall all vehicles containing potentially dangerous drivers-side airbags made by the Takata Corporation, the transportation minister, Akihiro Ohta, announced on Friday, saying the problem put Japans car-making reputation at risk along with drivers safety.

title: Two Boys Trapped for Hours in a Snow Mound Are Rescued
description: Two boys in upstate New York were trapped under a seven-foot mound of snow for more than four hours before they were freed early Thursday by rescue workers and relatives who dug with their hands and shovels, the police said.

title: Corrections: November 28, 2014
description: NATIONAL

title: Whats on TV Friday
description: 9 P.M. (13) KRISTIN CHENOWETH: COMING HOME Ms. Chenoweth, above, journeys back to Broken Arrow, Okla., her hometown, to perform in the theater named for her, accompanied by a 13-piece orchestra and some Broadway friends. The playlist, culled from her new album, Coming Home, includes I Could Have Danced All Night, My Coloring Book, Enough Is Enough, All the Things You Are, Over the Rainbow, and Popular and For Good from Wicked, in which she originated the role of Glinda.

title: Though Strain and Damage Are Visible, Uneasy Truce Holds in Ferguson
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Gov. Jay Nixon said on Friday evening that he was calling a special legislative session to find a way to pay for mounting state costs for handling the unrest that has gripped this city.

title: After Ferguson
description: Residents of Ferguson are still reeling from the protests that followed a grand jurys decision not to indict the police officer who fatally shot Michael Brown.

title: China Drafts Its First Domestic Violence Law, but Rights Advocates Say It Falls Short
description: For nearly two decades, Chinese feminists, lawyers and rights advocates have called for laws to tackle violence in the family. This week the government published a draft of what would be Chinas first national law addressing the issue, and while activists welcome it as a step forward, they also say it falls short of what is needed.

title: Q. and A.: Ann E. Carlson and Alex Wang on the U.S.-China Climate Accord
description: The biggest commitments to come out of President Obamas recent visit to China involved climate change policy. The leaders of the two nations stood beside each other in Beijing and pledged to curb greenhouse gas emissions, sending the world a powerful message that climate change is important to both men, and that the two countries intend to work together on the issue.

title: When Glamour Speaks Your Name
description: The 1960 publicity photo depicts a famous singer, a woman both statuesque and beautiful, smiling radiantly. A man kneels before her, adjusting her glistening gown. In the context of the image, the interaction between the two is metaphoric: a mortal kneeling before a goddess.

title: European Union Gives Belgium, France and Italy Time to Comply on Budget Rules
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union authorities on Friday gave Belgium, France and Italy three more months to bring their budgets in line with legal requirements.

title: Eurozone Inflation Rate Dips, Stirring Deflation Fears
description: PARIS  The eurozone inflation rate is slipping toward zero, even as the job market remains moribund, official data showed on Friday, highlighting the weak demand at the heart of the blocs economy and posing a test of the European Central Banks pledge to head off deflation.

title: New York Today: Property Rights and Wrongs
description: Good morning on this chilly Black Friday.

title: Australia Promises Scrutiny After Death of Cricket Star Phillip Hughes
description: LONDON  With the world of cricket in shock after the death of an Australian player struck by a ball, organizers of the sport on Friday promised an investigation into safety measures, including the design of protective helmets. But they displayed little readiness to disrupt what one administrator called the games finely tuned balance between bat and ball.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Week 13 N.F.L. Matchups
description: Patriots (9-2) at Packers (8-3)

title: A Facebook Change Makes It Harder for Political Campaigns to See Your Friends
description: When you log in to a politicians Facebook app, the campaign enjoys relatively easy access to your friends on the social network. But starting next year, that automatic access will go away.

title: Shopping on a Phone Is Still Uncommon but Growing Fast
description: Throngs of people still camp out awaiting Black Friday doorbuster sales, but it is more for the sake of tradition and sport than for good deals. Those can just as easily be found online.

title: 1964: Selassie Calls for Congo Parley
description: ADDIS ABABA  Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie has called for an extraordinary African summit conference on the Congo situation, it was announced today. His request has been sent to all African heads of state, the announcement said.

title: British Premier Plans Tougher Stance as Anti-Immigration Sentiment Grows
description: LONDON  With his eye on a general election just five months away, Prime Minister David Cameron on Friday sketched out proposals to make Britain less attractive to immigrants that, he acknowledged, would require tough negotiations with European Union partners and changes to union treaties.

title: Indias Economic Growth Slows to 5.3%
description: MUMBAI, India  Indias economic growth slowed to 5.3 percent in the three months ended in September from a year earlier, government data showed Friday, supporting expectations of a delayed recovery in Asias third-largest economy, after China and Japan.

title: Fall Rain: Central Park
description: Dear Diary:

title: Japanese Newspaper Prints Apology for Using the Term Sex Slaves
description: TOKYO  The Yomiuri Shimbun, the conservative newspaper that is the largest-circulation daily in Japan, has apologized for using the term sex slaves to refer to the women many historians say were coerced into working in a sprawling network of brothels supervised by the Japanese military during World War II.

title: Can the New Creative Director Johnny Coca Reverse Mulberrys Fortunes?
description: After almost 18 months without a creative director  18 months in which it issued numerous profit warnings  Mulberry finally named a new designer on Thursday: Johnny Coca, Clines former design director for accessories. Will he be able to turn around the brands fortunes?

title: Abstract Notions of Assorted People
description: Richard Linklater, the director of Boyhood, one of the years most acclaimed indies, has often been philosophically inquisitive, and never more so than with Waking Life (2001), screening Sunday at the Museum of the Moving Image as part of its See It Big! Animation series. As in Slacker (1991), Mr.Linklaters debut feature, the camera wanders around Austin, Tex., but here, it largely follows a young man (Wiley Wiggins) as he meets assorted people and discusses consciousness, the nature of reality and other abstract notions.

title: The Daily Gift: Pencils With a Personal Touch
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: As Ebola Rages in Sierra Leone, a Lonely Death
description: While health officials are making headway against the Ebola epidemic in neighboring Liberia, the disease is still rampant here, despite a big international push.

title: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
description: Welcome to Motherlodes weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

title: Up Early in Pursuit of Deals, Black Friday Shoppers Find Small Crowds
description: Tinged with protests and wintry weather, Black Friday still lured crowds into stores across the country, even as some shoppers expressed exhaustion over what has become a long, drawn-out start to the holiday sales.

title: Cashless Society? Its Already Coming
description: Ive spent the past few weeks using Apple Pay, the mobile payments app on the iPhone 6 and 6 Plus, as much as possible. I sought out every opportunity to press my thumb to the smartphones screen to make a payment at a store.

title: French Legislators Debate Stand on Palestinian Statehood
description: PARIS  French lawmakers debated on Friday a nonbinding motion to recognize a Palestinian state, following similar moves in other European nations amid increasing criticism of Israeli policies in Gaza, the West Bank and East Jerusalem.

title: British Premier on Curbing Immigration
description: As a general election neared in Britain, Prime Minister David Cameron said the country must be able to control immigration while it upholds the idea of freedom of movement within the European Union.

title: What Jim Webb Will Bring to the Presidential Race in 2016
description: By all accounts, he is an extreme long shot, but Jim Webb has set up an exploratory committee to see about running for president in 2016.

title: Pope Francis Starts 3-Day Turkey Visit
description: Pope Francis thanked Turkey for being a witness and helping refugees as he visited the country to strengthen ties with Muslim leaders.

title: An Asylums Final Secrets
description: In New York, more than 55,000 deceased psychiatric patients lie in unmarked graves. Near the former Willard Asylum, a small committee has spent the past three years fighting to memorialize the dead.

title: Getting a Foothold
description: Uptown and downtown, East Side and West, an elite cadre of prewar centenarians  give or take a decade  preside over Manhattan as if conscious of their pride of place, handsome and historic exteriors, and enduring stature.

title: Give Unto Others
description: From a Marie Antoinette drinking bowl, modeled after her breast, to a shepherds blanket hand-loomed in Portugal, the most special gifts each have their own story to tell.

title: She Knows When Shes Right
description: Suzan-Lori Parks shot up in bed at 3 a.m., her playwriting imagination on fire.

title: For Afghans, the Fighting Now Knows No Season
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban insurgents pressed government forces on several fronts on Friday, killing at least eight Afghan soldiers in three separate episodes.

title: Diminishing Returns Arent Waste (Wonkish)
description: Theres a new paper out of China, claiming that more than a third of investment spending since 2008 was wasted. Its a claim that resonates, given what we know about corruption, ghost cities, and all that. But as SR of The Economist points out, the paper itself doesnt actually do what it claims. It doesnt at all show that there has been a lot of waste  in fact, the data it cites are perfectly consistent with no waste at all.

title: 1939: Textile Rationing Cards Issued
description: AMSTERDAM  German official insistence on its large supply of raw materials has been considerably weakened with the issuance of textile ration cards. Even ardent Nazis from a political point of view shook their heads when they were shown copies of the cards and said, this is hard to take.

title: Wedding Q.&A.
description: His Friend Is Not Her Friend

title: Braise Your Way Through Winter
description: Carnivores, the season for meaty braises has arrived. Deep-flavored stews, amped up with assorted aromatics, are just right for cooking throughout the cold-weather months.

title: In Turkey, Pope Francis Advocates Dialogue in Battling Fanaticism
description: ISTANBUL  In his first visit as pope to a predominantly Muslim country, Pope Francis said in Turkey on Friday that interreligious dialogue, more than just military action, was required to combat the fanaticism and fundamentalism that threaten Christians and other religious minorities along the countrys southern border.

title: New York Immigration Groups Prepare to Meet Demands of New Policy
description: President Obamas sweeping executive actions on immigration present daunting logistical challenges across the nation, but especially in New York, which Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has called the gateway for immigrants worldwide.

title: Amid Tumult, Michigan Football Aims to Reclaim Its Footing
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Michigan football has had unsuccessful seasons in its storied history, but maybe none have been as disastrous as this one.

title: After London, Protesters Interrupt Showing of Exhibit B Near Paris
description: PARIS  Protesters interrupted a showing of Exhibit B, a controversial art installation by Brett Bailey, near Paris on Thursday evening, demonstrating against what they said was a racist performance.

title: Retirees Turn to Virtual Villages for Mutual Support
description: RICK CLOUD, 68, knew that he wanted to stay in his home in Austin, Tex., as he aged. But Mr. Cloud, who is divorced, was not sure how he could do that without relying on his two daughters.

title: A New Condo Pushes SoHos Boundaries
description: An unusual elliptical tower rising along the Avenue of the Americas on SoHos western edge has drawn many eyes as the most visible indication of a spate of development transforming the areas primarily commercial streets into a residential neighborhood.

title: A Jordanian Spins Comic Book Tales to Counter Terrorist Ideologies
description: OSLO  SULEIMAN BAKHIT has made a career of studying heroes.

title: In Front Of Your Macroeconomic Nose
description: Simon Wren-Lewis says most of what needs to be said about Tyler Cowens attempted riposte to my post about Keynes rising. Id add that Cowen seems to have missed my point; I wasnt talking about the merits of the Keynesian case, which I believe have always been overwhelming, but about the way macroeconomics is discussed in the media and among VSPs in general. My sense is that this is shifting in a Keynesian direction, while Cowen is arguing (wrongly, Id say) that it shouldnt shift because of Osborne or something. Wrong answer to the wrong question.

title: Two Dylan Songs You Probably Never Heard Of, but You Can Buy Them
description: The manuscripts of two early and virtually unknown songs by Bob Dylan  Talking Folklore Center and Go Away You Bomb  will be auctioned by Christies on Dec. 4 in New York, and in some ways the manuscripts provenance is as interesting as the pieces themselves. (Mr. Dylan may be in town to bid on them himself if he wants; the sale takes place the day after he finishes a five-concert run at the Beacon Theater that starts Friday night.)

title: Rare in New York City, the Wild Cranberry Is Tart and Sweet
description: The story of 17th-century Native Americans introducing European settlers to a small, water-loving, trailing vine has lasting appeal  we celebrate the gesture each Thanksgiving, now nearly 400 years later. The settlers named the innocuous plant craneberry, as its flowers reflexed petals and long, graceful stems reminded them of the head and neck of a crane. The tiny pink flowers must have seemed incomprehensibly delicate in the bleak wilderness of the new world.

title: The Cinque Terre on a Budget
description: The stunning profile stretched into the distance before me: miles of craggy coastline punctuated by five pastel villages, each nestled amid cliffs and sparkling sea. But on a pleasant afternoon in mid-October, only one other person was admiring this spectacular view of Cinque Terre, on the northwestern coast of Italy.

title: Creature Comforts: The Vermont Country Store Catalog
description: As the days grow colder and darker, one writer finds contentment in the companys frugal, anachronistic and entirely unflattering wares.

title: Construction Worker Dies After Ceiling Collapse at Staten Island Car Dealership
description: A construction worker died after part of a concrete ceiling in a Staten Island car dealership collapsed on Friday morning, the authorities said.

title: Cricket Players Death Highlights Sports Dangers
description: Phillip Hughess death has reverberated more widely than any previous cricket fatality. Earlier deaths, even that in 1998 of Raman Lamba, who had played for India before such status conferred instant celebrity, were essentially local tragedies.

title: 6 Are Killed in Egypt After a Call for Protests Rattles the Authorities
description: CAIRO  Six people were killedin political violence on Friday as a small and little-known Islamist groups call for protests failed to turn out big numbers but still spooked the military-backed government into locking down the capital.

title: Indian Army Indicts 9 Soldiers in Killing of 2 Civilians in Kashmir
description: NEW DELHI  The Indian Army has indicted nine of its soldiers in the killing of two civilians early this month in the Indian-administered portion of Kashmir, moving with unusual swiftness toward a court-martial in a case that provoked antigovernment demonstrations.

title: And a Little Child Shall Lead Them
description: LOS ANGELES  Ridley Scotts 3-D Exodus: Gods and Kings has computer-generated plagues, waves and tornadoes. It has boat-chomping crocodiles, 400,000 digitally rendered Hebrew slaves and a sword-wielding Christian Bale as a Gladiator-like Moses.

title: Those Artsy Early Birds Flew Away
description: MIAMI BEACH  It was a really devastating message, the Miami art dealer Fredric Snitzer said, recalling the personal impact when Emmanuel Perrotins 13,000-square-foot outpost closed in 2010. If he couldnt make a go of it, what I am doing here?

title: French Lawmakers Debate Palestine
description: Members of the French National Assembly debated a bill on whether France should recognize Palestine as a state.

title: With Art, Investing in Genius
description: If there were any remaining doubts that making money is art, as Andy Warhol famously pronounced in his 1975 book, The Philosophy of Andy Warhol, they were surely vanquished on Nov. 12. His silk-screen print Triple Elvis (Ferus Type), an image taken from a Hollywood studio publicity shot showing Elvis Presley with a gun, sold for nearly $82 million at a Christies auction packed with bankers, hedge fund managers and art dealers.

title: The Force Was With Them
description: Cue the Star Wars theme music, please:

title: The Goldbergs Focuses a Nostalgic Lens on Family Dysfunction
description: CULVER CITY, Calif.  Sitting in his office, Adam F. Goldberg, creator of the ABC sitcom The Goldbergs, had the impish grin of a kid in a toy store. Mostly because Mr. Goldbergs office, on the Sony Pictures lot here, is filled, corner to corner, with toys.

title: From the Ashes, a Proto-Punk Revival
description: One day in 1980, I reached a milestone in a Jewish boys journey into manhood: spending my bar mitzvah money on punk rock records. I was searching the racks at a record store for Adult Books, the debut single by the Los Angeles band X, and the only 45 that remotely fit the bill featured a couple of white Xs on the front cover, separated by a dash, above a photo of the bare backside of a woman bound at the ankles. The back-cover band photo corresponded somewhat to the group Id read about in a zine  four members, one of them female  though the label credited the single to Drome Records instead of Dangerhouse. So a band name starting with X, a multigendered quartet, a record label beginning with D, a whiff of the forbidden: Close enough, I thought, and made my purchase.

title: Modern Mythology, Yours for a Dime
description: With todays multiplexes muscle-bound from too many superheroes, and TV frantic with the antic shuffle of tiny zombie feet, S.H.I.E.L.D. spymasters and more, its easy to forget there was a time when mainstream comic books were in genuine conversation with the broader culture, instead of being meekly strip-mined for profit by other media.

title: The Music Runs Through Her
description: People used to tell Linda Celeste Sims that she looked like an Ailey dancer. She didnt have a clue what that meant. I knew it was a modern thing, she said, but I didnt know the grandness.

title: A Singular World That Wont Fade Away
description: The traffic was light, the sky dark, the sidewalks mostly empty on a bitterly cold recent Sunday evening in TriBeCa. Looking down shadowy side streets, it was possible, for a moment or two at a time, to imagine being back in the forbidding, exhilarating downtown New York of the 1970s.

title: A New Tome Captures the Southern California Skate-Punk Scene of the 80s
description: In punk and hardcore circles, the name Spot is legend. Born in Southern California, Spot produced albums for some of the most seminal bands of those scenes in the 70s and 80s  Black Flag, the Misfits, the Minutemen, the Meat Puppets and Hsker Du among them. When he wasnt behind the mixing board at SST Records, the label founded by Black Flags Greg Ginn, he was likely to be roller-skating the boardwalks  or behind the lens of his Nikon, photographing the skate ramps, the beaches, the house parties. Bruised and bloodied and tanned from the days skating, everyone would head to see whichever band was playing that night, and then Spot would stay up late in the darkroom afterwards. Those sleepless, exciting times are documented in Spots first book of photographs, The Sound of Two Eyes Opening, out Friday from Sinecure.

title: 1957 | Fidel Castro Is Still Alive
description: David W. Dunlap is a Metro reporter and writes the Building Blocks column. He has worked at The Times for 39 years.

title: Reindeer at the St. Regis
description: Reindeer are a quintessential symbol of Christmas, and on Dec. 13, the St. Regis New York will celebrate the holiday by having two of them outside its doors in Midtown Manhattan from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Putins Kleptocracy
description: This week, Karen Dawisha discusses Putins Kleptocracy; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Stephen Kotkin talks about his new biography of Stalin; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Matching the Way You Give to the Cause You Give To
description: SCOTT STEVENS gives differently to charities depending on the cause. Money to National Public Radio is charged monthly to his credit card. He donates annually by check to the American Cancer Society in memory of his mother.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Putins Kleptocracy
description: This week, Karen Dawisha and Stephen Kotkin.

title: New York Taxis Retirement: A Quiet Life on Country Roads in Vermont
description: SPRINGFIELD, Vt.  The yellow sedan parked in front of a convenience store here in the Green Mountains caught the eye of Lucille Stanley  the N.Y.C. TAXI markings on the vehicles flank could not be missed.

title: An Insult Is Now a Name Tag
description: STARKVILLE, Miss.  Just a few months ago, Starkville was known  when it was known at all  as a sleepy Southern town, even by the standards of sleepy Southern towns.

title: A Cornucopia of Views
description: The allure of an entire floor with birds-eye views near the top of One57, the Extell Development Companys glass-sheathed Midtown statement-maker at 157 West 57th Street, continued to persuade buyers to invest upward of $50 million in personal aeries there, as No. 80 traded for $52,952,500 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

title: Italian and Palestinian Protesters Wounded by Israeli Forces
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli forces shot and wounded an Italian activist and a Palestinian demonstrator with live ammunition on Friday during a weekly protest in the West Bank village of Kufr Qadoum, according to local activists and Palestinian medical officials.

title: Oil Prices Are Plunging. Heres Who Wins and Who Loses.
description: While Americans were stuffing their faces with poultry Thursday, global oil markets were in chaos. And the implications are far-reaching.

title: Black Friday in the U.S. and Europe
description: Shoppers from London, Glasgow, New York City and Washington, D.C., took part in Black Friday. The practice of offering low prices the day after Thanksgiving is spreading across the Atlantic.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Book Review Podcast: Putins Kleptocracy
description: In a special issue of The New York Times Book Review devoted to the theme of Russia, Rajan Menon reviews Karen Dawishas Putins Kleptocracy: Who Owns Russia? Mr. Menon writes:

title: A Respectful Deference to Elders Curdles Into a Fight Over Assets
description: The trailer opens with a picture of an olive green house, then a sunny yellow kitchen. A narrator extols the virtues of the world-famous chicken and dumplings that the family matriarch once made there.

title: Fatal Attack Causes Chaos at Mosque in Nigeria
description: KANO, Nigeria  Militants struck the central mosque in one of Nigerias biggest cities on Friday, intensifying the violence that has swept across the nations north in recent months.

title: Ousted Greek Prime Minister Pushes for a New Party Leader, Perhaps Himself
description: ATHENS  Former Prime Minister George A. Papandreou, who was forced to step aside in 2011, has burst back onto the political scene here with a bid to wrest control of his Socialist party from his successor.

title: Moving Pictures and Opportunity for Change
description: An innovative collaboration that began with documenting the lives of teenagers who were sex-trafficking victims hopes to engage viewers and spur them to act.

title: Black Friday Embrace by British Retailers Brings Discounts and Disorder
description: LONDON  Black Friday, virtually unknown here just a few years ago, has tightened its grip on British retailing, bringing with it scenes of disorder and chaos, at least two arrests and police criticism of the big stores that encourage shopper frenzy.

title: Venezuelan Cuisine, With a Side of Cabaret
description: Achieving culinary prowess, it could be argued, is a labor of love  one that requires talent but also devoted practice. The same could be said of show business; as well as talent, a single-minded dedication is usually needed to become a successful singer, dancer or actor. So, can a person do both? Is it possible to attain mastery as both a chef and as an entertainer?

title: Inside the List
description: Mother and Daughter: The cover of Brooke Shieldss latest memoir, There Was a Little Girl (new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 11), shows the author sometime in the mid-1970s, relaxing happily on the lap of her mother and manager, Teri Shields, their hands touching and their heads tilted girlishly together. Its a sweet and wholesome image, and a far cry from a photo that ran around the same time on the cover of New York magazine, depicting Brooke in full makeup with a haughty stare while her mother grasped her shoulders. Meet Teri and Brooke Shields, the cover read. Brooke is 12. She poses nude. Teri is her mother. She thinks its swell. Shields doesnt mention that article in her book, which is subtitled The Real Story of My Mother and Me, but she does talk about the media uproar surrounding Louis Malles 1978 film Pretty Baby, in which she played an underage prostitute, and all of the racy jobs that followed. There was a sense of fury and a need to assume that I was a victim, she writes. There was a firestorm, and Mom took most of the heat. Although Shields writes frankly and painfully about her mothers chronic drinking and poor career decisions, the book  which was prompted, she says, by her reaction to The New York Timess obituary after Teri Shields died in 2012  is mostly tender. It is not a Mommie Dearest tale. But Im not holding her up on a pedestal, either, she writes. It is simply my turn to tell the story as I saw and felt it.

title: Japan Addresses Takata Airbag Flaw
description: TOKYO  In April last year, Japans transportation minister was asked at a news conference about potentially dangerous airbags made by Takata, the Japanese auto parts supplier. About 700,000 cars had just been recalled in the country because of defective Takata airbags, part of a larger global recall that has since ballooned to include more than 14 million vehicles.

title: Hong Kong Clashes Flare as Protesters Return to Camp
description: HONG KONG  Clashes between the police and protesters flared in a crowded shopping district of Hong Kong on Friday night, days after the police dismantled a pro-democracy camp there.

title: Laurie Sperring on Staying Clean
description: From prison, Laurie Sperring talks about the challenges of staying away from heroin that an addict faces.

title: Driving the Seam of Hispaniola
description: Ive never liked the idea of bucket-list travel. Why make another to-do list when faced with your own mortality?

title: Does Your Job Make You Happy?
description: On-site exercise equipment. Paid volunteer time. A wall of baking tools you can borrow. These may sound like the perks some flush tech companies extend to their engineers.

title: A Home for the Headlines
description: A structure that just missed the New York City landmarks preservation law of 1965 was the 1905 Times Tower at 42nd Street at Broadway. Reminiscent of the Florentine campanile by Giotto, it was an expansive gesture by The New York Times, then moving uptown from Park Row. The newspaper left the building around 10 years later, but the tower survived for 60 years before being stripped to its skin. By the time the landmarks law was passed, even the skeleton had disappeared from view.

title: Please Forgive My Spotless Home
description: I was vacuuming the basement stairs when the ceiling started to shake. It was my two sons in the living room above, jumping between sofa and coffee table, their noises a dangerous mix of laughing and grunting that portended someone (the younger, usually) getting hurt.

title: Even Among Harvard Graduates, Women Fall Short of Their Work Expectations
description: Women are not equally represented at the top of corporate America because of the basic facts of motherhood: Even the most ambitious women scale back at work to spend more time on child care. At least, that is the conventional wisdom.

title: U.N. Panel Cites Concerns With U.S. Security Practices
description: GENEVA  The United States needs to make numerous changes to bring its security policies and domestic law enforcement practices fully into line with an international treaty banning torture and cruel treatment, a United Nations panel said Friday.

title: Kindly Pipe Down
description: I was friendly with this girl in high school. We are in our 20s now and will be seeing each other soon. I heard from friends that she got pregnant by accident last year, carried the baby and gave it up for adoption, rather than terminate the pregnancy. I was impressed. I dont know anyone else who would do that. I want to tell her that I admire her, but Im not sure how to bring it up. Any ideas? JANE

title: Why C.E.O.s Are Growing Beards
description: THESE are dark days for the shaving industry. After experiencing a century of fairly steady growth, makers of razors and other shaving equipment have seen revenues level off or fall in the last few years. Beards are back.

title: Silent Worship
description: The deaf Catholic community of New York wonders about its future, since the Archdiocese announced it is merging a deaf parish with a larger, hearing congregation.

title: Ray Rice Wins Reinstatement to N.F.L. in Arbitration
description: An arbitrator on Friday overturned the National Football Leagues indefinite suspension of Ray Rice, the former Baltimore Ravens running back who knocked out his fiance in an elevator altercation. The decision called the penalty arbitrary and in conflict with the facts of the case.

title: On the Upper East Side, Silent Prayers to Save a Sanctuary for the Deaf
description: The choir members filed up to the altar in robes the color of the red roses of Saint Elizabeth, the patron saint of their beloved church. They arrayed themselves on two risers and looked to the choir director for a cue. Then they raised their hands in unison and began to sign.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: The Weekly Health Quiz
description: In the news: Type 2 diabetes, calorie counts and heavy drinkers. Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Art of New York
description: Have friends with empty coffee tables? Heres a selection of New York holiday gift books.

title: Coming to a Theater Far, Far Into the Future
description: This will be a day long remembered by fans of science-fiction fantasies, aficionados of mega-budget movie franchises and viewers who regard the Star Wars series with a reverence bordering on the religious.

title: Trickier Time-Off Policies as Employers Test New Ideas
description: TRIBUNE PUBLISHING, owner of newspaper institutions like The Los Angeles Times, created a near riot in its newsrooms this month when it abruptly announced a major change to vacation and sick day policies for most employees beginning in the new year: no more separate vacation, sick and personal days. Under its new discretionary time-off policy, it would be up to each employee and supervisor to agree on almost all time off.

title: Artistic Expression in a Repressive State
description: Still Life With Apples is a small gouache of six rosy apples resting on a blue table, painted with gestural brush strokes by the artist Vladimir Yakovlev in 1973. It is a lovely picture; nothing about it appears contentious. Yet its very creation at that time in the Soviet Union was an act of political defiance.

title: Yearning for a BB Gun and a Happy Family
description: Dont expect the Ghost of Christmas Past, or any other ghost, to pop up in A Christmas Story: The Musical. The entertaining show playing at the John W. Engeman Theater at Northport is nothing like A Christmas Carol, the dark-tinged tale by Charles Dickens that also became a musical. A Christmas Story, based on the popular 1983 film narrated by the humorist and radio personality Jean Shepherd (who also wrote the book that inspired the movie), is a sunnier Christmas yarn, centered on a childs concern that he wont get the present he wants.

title: Leave Them Stirred, Not Shaken
description: Art-inspired barware and storage gift ideas for couples who like to the keep the party going.

title: The Making of Harmony
description: The Fabulous Lipitones doesnt set out to be fabulous, and that makes this friendly show all the better. Indeed, this a cappella musical works just fine without much glitter or glamour  its greatest pleasures spring from the simplest of intentions.

title: Obama Pushed Fullest Extent of His Powers on Immigration Plan
description: WASHINGTON  Months before President Obama took executive action last week to reshape the nations immigration system, Jeh C. Johnson, the secretary of Homeland Security, quietly convened a small group of advisers to explore the legal limits of the presidents powers.

title: His Nightmares Starred Communists, Not Nazis
description: LONDON  Composers lives are usually less interesting than lore has it, amounting to long hours at a desk, putting ideas on paper. But one relatively recent life reads like a John le Carr Cold War thriller. It is the story of Andrzej Panufnik, who was born into the Polish middle class in 1914, died an English knight in 1991 and, in between, led an existence plagued by war, politics and exile that twice stripped him of all he had achieved and forced him to start again.

title: Use Caution in Updating Adobe Flash Player or Reader
On Instagram, Celebrities Have Jokes ... Especially About Kim Kardashian
description: Imitation really is the sincerest form of flattery, it seems.

title: Got a Best Seller? Chipotle May Come Calling
description: The author Jonathan Safran Foer was eating in a Chipotle not long ago with nothing to read when he had a truly out of the box idea: What if his meals packaging could display ennui-alleviating text?

title: As Time Went By, They Never Lost Touch
description: Stephen Bogart and Carla Soviero were married Nov. 15, at the Skylark in New York.

title: Tastes of a Bangkok Childhood
description: Most casual suburban Thai restaurants arent known for their innovative menus, offering chicken satay, papaya salad and pad thai, with a few red or green curries thrown in.

title: More Plot Twists Than The Maltese Falcon
description: Seventy years ago, Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart burned up the silver screen as they fell in love while filming To Have and Have Not.

title: Banksy Work to Be Offered for Sale in Miami
description: Art Buff, a work by Banksy that appeared in September in Folkestone, a British town on the English Channel, will be sent to Miami for sale by the owner of Palace Amusements, the building on which it appeared. The painting, which shows an elderly woman wearing headphones looking at an empty plinth, had been defaced and the Folkestone Herald reported that the family that owns the building did not want the responsibility of protecting the painting from further vandalism.

title: A Deal From the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams
description: The Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams is the premier event at the Fall North American Championships in Providence, R.I. It takes place Friday through Dec. 7, with play on the last day to be broadcast at bridgebase.com.

title: A Pre-Thanksgiving Ritual: Cocktails, Catch-Ups and Maybe a Kiss
description: There was a short line outside the Stumble Inn on 76th Street and Second Avenue in Manhattan on Wednesday night. Women decked out in what seemed to be matching puffy coats huddled together under the bars overhang. Men wore Uniqlo flannel.

title: A Holiday Respite With a Turkish Accent
description: A must-add to this papers recent list of interesting restaurants for holiday shoppers on Long Island is Krinti, a Mediterranean grill with an emphasis on Turkish cuisine located in a shopping center in Woodbury. The four-month-old establishment is easy to find, with its name in blazing white letters affixed to a building outlined in tiny white lights. The food is memorable and the service exceptional.

title: Ray Rice Suspension Ruling
description: Barbara S. Jones, a onetime district court judge, issued her decision Friday in the N.F.L.s suspension of Ray Rice.

title: African Books for Western Eyes
description: ABUJA, Nigeria  MY close friend Mercy, when she heard about my novel, congratulated me: I had found out what the white people wanted to read and given it to them.

title: New Yorks Next Big Thing
description: NEW YORK is the most diverse, dynamic city on Earth. More than 55 million people are projected to visit this year, bringing with them a total economic impact of more than $60 billion and supporting about 350,000 jobs.

title: The Downside of Resilience
description: BEHIND a half-century of policies to promote child development, there lies an assumption: that children are essentially equally affected by the environments they grow up in, and that positive interventions like preschool education should therefore help all children. But what if this isnt true?

title: A New Puccini Production Offers Explanations for Its Storys Gaps
description: MUNICH  What was it that so offended Anna Netrebko?

title: Critiquing a Republicans Alternative to Obamacare
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Learning for Children at Risk
Bauble, Burger and Beer
description: With Thanksgiving behind us, were in for it: Hanukkah, Christmas, Kwanzaa and New Years, with all their trimmings and trappings and snowballing expenses. What would the Grinch do? If you cant stop it from coming, you might as well join in the fun and the feasting. One way to dine out during the holidays while guarding your solvency is to perch at the bar in a high-end restaurant that either has a dedicated bar menu or lets bar patrons pick and choose from the main menu. A boon is that bartenders, in our experience, offer unusually attentive, companionable service.

title: Teams That Could Use Ray Rice
description: Finding a team willing to take on the public-relations hit of signing Ray Rice will be difficult. But anyone saying it is impossible is ignoring other famous cases of players returning after damaging incidents. Leonard Little, a defensive lineman, played 12 seasons in the N.F.L. after killing a 47-year-old mother in a drunken-driving accident. Donte Stallworth, a wide receiver, played three seasons after pleading guilty to manslaughter for killing a pedestrian in a hit-and-run accident that occurred after he had been drinking. And Michael Vick, the backup quarterback for the Jets, has played six seasons since serving a federal sentence in connection with a dogfighting ring that he participated in.

title: A Poetry Personal and Political
description: A finalist for the National Book Award in poetry, Claudia Rankines Citizen: An American Lyric is audacious in form. But what is perhaps especially striking about the book is that it has achieved something that eludes much modern poetry: urgency.

title: New Yorks Holiday Windows
description: Celebrated displays keep the crowds coming back.

title: Holiday Window Displays Lure Them Inside, by Dazzling Outside
description: Theres a leering elf in the windows of Barneys New York caressing a supersize psychedelic mushroom and doing the splits.

title: The Last Rites for Death by Audio
description: As eulogies go, the final showcase at Death by Audio, a D.I.Y. Williamsburg club, was a kicker, loud and sweaty and appropriately raucous. Smelly, too. For seven years, the space hosted thousands of indie bands, becoming a launching pad for punks, noise acts, experimental electronica and underground rap, and a clubhouse for every self-respecting music obsessive in between. The programming for its last week of shows this month was a closely guarded secret, yet fans turned up in droves, waiting hours each night for one more chance to stomp the checkerboard floor, dive off the beaten-up stage and guzzle cheap beer in the back room.

title: The End of Artificially Low Rates
description: For years those of us pointing to low interest rates as evidence that fiscal scolds were all wrong met, over and over again, one stock answer: those low rates were meaningless, because the Fed was buying up government bonds and keeping rates artificially low. There was a big logical problem with that story: How can the Fed do that without causing inflation? There was also the fact that rates failed to spike when the Fed temporarily ended QE in 2011  one big thing I got right and Bill Gross got wrong. But the story line has persisted nonetheless.

title: Collections Pissarro Is Called Looted Art
description: BERLIN  Minutes after the Kunstmuseum Bern in Switzerland revealed for the first time a list of artworks Cornelius Gurlitt had stashed in his second home near the Austrian Alps, its promise of full transparency seemed to clear away decades of murky silence about a delicate Pissarro painting showing the Louvre in Paris and bridges spanning the Seine.

title: The Last Cinema in Paradise
description: The Peoples Theater has enchanted the tiny town of Honokaa, Hawaii, since 1930. More than a place to watch movies, it holds history and memories. But can it survive the digital age?

title: Turings Spirit Hovers at a Restored Estate
description: BLETCHLEY, England  When Captain Ridleys shooting party gathered here in late August 1938 as weekend guests at Bletchley Park, a Buckinghamshire country house, they were accompanied by one of the finest chefs from the Savoy hotel. But the hunting that took place wasnt the usual. The visitors were members of MI6 and the Government Code and Cypher School in Britain, scouting out a retreat for code breakers who would be needed in the coming war.

title: Saving the Peoples Theater in Hawaii
description: HONOKAA, Hawaii  Phaethon Keeney was 6 when she and her father, the physician for this old plantation town on the Big Islands Hamakua coast, moved into a room behind the screen of the towns old cinema, the Honokaa Peoples Theater.

title: Thanksgiving Weekend Blues
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J.  THANKSGIVING weekend in 1990, I spent two hours at the loneliest place in the world for an obscure novelist  the book-signing table at a Waldenbooks in a suburban New Jersey mall.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Bridging Tacky and Tasteful
description: Nick Lowe, the British producer and songwriter, is surely up there with Bob Dylan, and Scott Weiland of Stone Temple Pilots, as one of the most surprising artists to record a Christmas album.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Elton John and Darren Walker on Race, Sexual Identity and Leaving the Past Behind
description: Its hard to imagine two people coming from worlds as different as those of Elton John and Darren Walker.

title: Ex-Chief of Obama Security Works to Boost Scarred Secret Service
description: WASHINGTON  On his way to work every morning, Joseph P. Clancy passes his new obsession and likely legacy: the seven-and-a-half-foot fence that surrounds the White House.

title: Do You Have a Light? Ralph Lauren Does
description: Forget the wrist  that body part is so last season. Wearable tech has moved on for the holidays, and now its all about ... the crook of the elbow.

title: Sterilization in India
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Basel Miami Beachs Not-to-Be-Missed Parties and Events
description: No matter what it looks like on social media, Art Basel is all about the art. Well, at least the original one in Basel, Switzerland is. As for the Miami Beach edition, which takes place in the coming week (officially Thursday through Sunday, though festivities begin as early as Monday), it is still a horde of ancillary art shows and performances, with the parodic parade of parties swirling around them. Here are 10 buzzworthy happenings where culture, taste and excess all combine to electric effect.

title: Only 9 Breakup Days Left Till Christmas
description: I am frankly surprised by the lack of public service reminders about this, but this coming week is your last chance to break up before Christmas.

title: An Exam for Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Caution on Heavy Drinking
description: To the Editor:

title: At 80, Richard Chamberlain Is Ready to Speak Volumes
description: At 80, Richard Chamberlain isnt so great with stairs these days, though in some ways he seems downright boyish, with a palpable aura of enthusiasm and a habit of tapping both hands on a tabletop when he lands on a topic that moves him.

title: On Black Friday, Walmart Is Pressed for Wage Increases
description: While millions of shoppers flocked to Walmart stores nationwide on Black Friday, thousands of protesters descended on Walmarts to protest what they said were the retailers low wages.

title: Evening Hours | Youth and History
description: Honors for the elders and trains for the kids.

title: The Sinking of the Greyhound
description: In late November 1864, the Union troop transport Greyhound was steaming down the James River in Virginia from the Bermuda Hundred Plantation, where the army of Maj. Gen. Benjamin Butler had been bottled up for weeks. Butlers superior, Lt. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant, had planned to send Butler due south toward Richmond, thereby trapping Gen. Robert E. Lees Army of Northern Virginia between two large concentrations of Union troops. But Butler soon found himself in a stalemate against entrenched Confederate forces, far outside Richmond.

title: The Pain of the Watermelon Joke
description: AS a child in South Carolina, I spent summers like so many children  sitting on my grandparents back porch with my siblings, spitting watermelon seeds into the garden or, even worse, swallowing them and trembling as my older brother and sister spoke of the vine that was probably already growing in my belly.

title: Bill Cunningham | Thanksgiving
description: For many, Thanksgiving has stretched into five days of festivities.

title: Doing Some Heavy Lifting
description: In their long, frequently triumphant but totally unfinished struggle for equal employment rights, women keep coming up against the matter of lifting heavy bundles.

title: Ohio State Walk-On Is Missing
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Around 1:30 a.m. Wednesday, Kosta Karageorge, an Ohio State football player and wrestler, sent a text message to his mother, apologizing if he had been an embarrassment, explaining that he had been affected by concussions.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,339 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: In Northern Ireland, a Wave of Immigrants Is Met With Fists
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland  More than 16 years after the Good Friday peace deal brought real hope that Protestants and Roman Catholics could live together in relative harmony, Northern Ireland is being racked by another wave of violence.

title: In a Twitter Post, Malaysia Airlines Sends the Wrong Message
description: BANGKOK  Malaysia Airlines tried to appeal to travelers sense of adventure in a year-end promotional campaign.

title: Brooklyns Lubavitch Community: A Culture Captured by the Ultimate Outsider
description: One day during Hanukkah 26 years ago, the grand rabbi of the Lubavitch-Chabad Hasidim briefly turned away from the hundreds of men gathered before him in synagogue to cast his eye toward the womens balcony. Then he extended an arm, offering someone there a roll of nickels. That recipient, in turn, was meant to fulfill the rabbis design by giving the coins to charity.

title: Free Fall in Oil Price Underscores Shift Away From OPEC
description: HOUSTON  Since the economically crippling oil embargo of 1973, every American president has pledged to seek and achieve energy independence.

title: Denham Harman, 98, Dies; Sought Leverage on Aging
description: Dr. Denham Harman, a research biochemist who asserted that old age was just another disease, and who drew support from medical experts for his claim that aging could be managed  if never quite cured  with vitamins and other so-called antioxidants, died on Tuesday in Omaha. He was 98 and lived in Omaha.

title: A Conundrum for Saudis: Women at Work
description: Claudia Goldin, a Harvard professor, is not just an expert on working women. As one of the nations most prominent economists, she also exemplifies the growing stature and independence of women in American society. So it was unusual to find Ms. Goldin covered in an abaya while meeting in Saudi Arabia not long ago with government officials from the kingdom in an opulent hotel that offered male-only seating areas and forbade women from using its spa.

title: Protesters United Against Ferguson Decision, but Challenged in Unity
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  Demonstrators forced the temporary closing of the St. Louis Galleria mall after staging a mass die-in on Friday afternoon, lying on the floor for four and a half minutes of silence to represent the hours that Michael Brown was left on the street after a police officer shot him dead.

title: Team Sells Its Best Players, and Doesnt Pay for It
description: SOUTHAMPTON, England  Les Reed remembers the venom. He remembers the anger and the worry and the stress. He remembers  much as he may try to forget  the cursing. Just moments after the end of Southampton F.C.'s final home match last season, Reed, the clubs executive director, sat in his seat at St. Marys Stadium and absorbed a steady stream of salty language from fans as they stomped up the aisles.

title: Budget Problems? Kentucky and Elsewhere Find Answer in Bottle
description: LAWRENCEBURG, Ky.  Alcohol may not be single-handedly saving state and local budgets from the red, but it is certainly helping.

title: Global Weakness, Americas Problem
description: At their policy meeting in October, Federal Reserve officials were blas about economic weakness in Asia and Europe. According to the minutes of the meeting, the Fed noted that growth in the United States might be slower than anticipated in the next year or two if global conditions were to deteriorate further.

title: Improvements for Rikers Island
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio acknowledged last week that he initially underestimated the dysfunction that had allowed chronic violence and corruption to flourish at the Rikers Island jail complex, adding that he intended to make reforming this troubled system a top priority.

title: A Rare Chance for Two Governors
description: The infamous traffic jam last year on the George Washington Bridge  a bizarre political payback organized by aides to Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey  did one good thing. It focused lawmakers on the urgent need to reform the huge, secretive Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the bistate agency that owns the bridge and other major facilities in the region.

title: Wrestling With an Aging Arsenal
description: What do a wrench, a blast door and an intercontinental ballistic missile have in common? They are part of an American nuclear weapons program plagued by operational, personnel and leadership problems. Evidence of dysfunction has been mounting since 2007 when six nuclear missiles went missing for 36 hours after a crew at Minot Air Force Base in North Dakota mistakenly loaded them onto a plane and flew them across the country. Two recent Pentagon reports suggest that things have not improved.

title: What Should the Pope Do in New York City?
description: The Vaticans envoy to the United Nations disclosed this month that Pope Francis would almost certainly come to New York City in 2015. Heres a list of a few prime possibilities for stops. What do you think he should do?

title: Ray Rice Ruling Highlights Roger Goodells Missteps
description: Its a good guess that Roger Goodell, the once-powerful commissioner of the N.F.L., doesnt want to hear about his mistakes anymore. Like how his willy-nilly punishments of players gone wrong have caused him to lose credibility, or how his efforts to stand up for those who have suffered from domestic violence seem only like public-relations moves.

title: More Pastors Embrace Talk of Mental Ills
description: EAGLE SPRINGS, N.C.  The pastors phone rang in the midnight darkness. A mans voice rasped: My wife left me and Ive got a shotgun in my mouth. Give me one reason why I shouldnt pull the trigger.

title: Nicotine Without Death
description: I attended Wells Fargo Securities 2nd Annual E-Cig Conference last week, and if I had to describe the mood of the speakers it would be a cross between cautious optimism and deep frustration.

title: Palestinian Refuge for 6 Decades, Now Flooded From Syria
description: SHATILA CAMP, Lebanon  An enormous iron key hangs on a water tower above a crossroads in the Palestinian refugee camp of Shatila, just south of downtown Beirut. The sculpture alludes to the rusting keys that many families here treasure, from houses lost when they fled what became Israel in 1948.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 28, 2014
Saturdays College Football Games to Watch
description: It is hard to imagine a better day of college football. From noon to prime time Saturday, rivals will square off in the distinctively named Iron Bowl, Egg Bowl, Civil War and Clean, Old-Fashioned Hate and Apple Cup as well as for Paul Bunyans ax. Division titles are on the line. Teams with nothing to lose versus those who think they deserve a spot in the College Football Playoff. Expect the unexpected.

title: At Assisted-Living Home Set to Close, Holdouts Dig In as Services Dry Up
description: Mealtimes at the Prospect Park Residence, a building in the classical revival style overlooking Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn, were once dignified affairs. The residents sat down to carefully folded napkins and pale-green tablecloths in a spacious dining room bustling with neighbors, medical aides and servers. The windows offered sweeping views of Prospect Park.

title: Not Found in This Puzzles Answer
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  One of the things I like the most about Elizabeth C. Gorskis puzzles is the sense of humor that pervades them. And the visuals. I think its safe to say that Ms. Gorski is the queen of the visual crossword-puzzle elements.

title: Still Awaiting Union Ruling, Northwestern Players Focus on Field
description: EVANSTON, Ill.  The day Northwestern football players voted on unionization in April, the ballots were impounded, carried away from Ryan Field in two shiny silver locked boxes. Seven months later, they have yet to be counted. College sports look markedly different anyway. N.C.A.A. governance has been overhauled; universities and conferences have pledged greater scholarship protection and better health care; a federal judge has ruled that players can be paid for the use of their images.

title: Finding a Salve for His Depression on Two Wheels
description: Paul Watson speaks haltingly in a low, soft voice. He is shy and moves around his world with careful steps, nodding to answer questions when he would rather not talk. But, in his quietest moments, his smile often speaks for him.

title: Woman, 67, Dies From Injuries Caused by Fire in the Bronx
description: A 67-year-old woman died on Friday after she was badly burned in an apartment fire in the Bronx, the police said.

title: Ready, Aim, Fire, Then Relax in the Lounge
