description: CENTENNIAL, Colo.  At a gun club in this Denver suburb, Marc Rabinoff sat in the V.I.P. lounge, amid a sea of leather couches, the fireplace at his back. The air smelled vaguely of perfume. At an adjacent range, his wife, Diana, fired bullets from her purple glitter pistol, her hands wrapped in gloves of leather and lace.

title: Mary Hinkson, a Star for Martha Graham, Dies at 89
description: Mary Hinkson, one of Martha Grahams most important leading dancers, whose performances from the 1950s through the early 70s were filled with unbridled dramatic power, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

title: Frank Yablans, Paramount Executive in Fertile 70s, Dies at 79
description: LOS ANGELES  Frank Yablans, a blunt-spoken filmmaker and studio executive who oversaw the release of the first two Godfather films while president of Paramount Pictures and later was both a producer and a writer of Mommie Dearest and North Dallas Forty, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 79.

title: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 29, 2014
description: In human history, there has never been a better time to be a drinker.

title: Roberto Gmez Bolaos, Mexicos Comedic Artist Chespirito, Dies at 85
description: Roberto Gmez Bolaos, a Mexican comic actor, writer and director familiar around the world for his characters El Chavo and El Chapuln Colorado, died on Friday in Cancn. He was 85.

title: Sabah, Enduring Star in Arab World Entertainment, Dies at 87
description: Sabah, a prolific and provocative Lebanese singer and actress whose fame in the Arab world endured for six decades, died on Wednesday in Beirut. She was 87.

title: In Return to Thunder, Westbrook Dominates the Knicks
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  After the officiant prayed for Russell Westbrooks continued recovery as part of the pregame invocation here at Chesapeake Energy Arena, Westbrook approached the opposing bench and hugged Derek Fisher, a teammate not so long ago.

title: Derek Fisher Returns to Oklahoma City, Where He Ended His Career
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  After spending two-plus seasons as his Thunder teammate, Oklahoma City Thunder guard Russell Westbrook said he knew it was going to be odd to see Knicks Coach Derek Fisher in a suit on the opposing sideline.

title: Whats on TV Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (Lifetime) GRUMPY CATS WORST CHRISTMAS EVER (2014) Grumpy Cat, above, the sourpuss feline who rose to fame via the Internet about two years ago; appeared on the cover of New York magazine; and published a book, The Grumpy Guide to Life, tries out her acting chops. With the help of the vocal talents of Aubrey Plaza, of Parks and Recreation, Grumpy plays a lonely cat living in a mall pet shop  no one wants to take her home. She discovers that she can communicate with a 12-year-old girl. All of which leads Grumpy reluctantly to thwart the kidnapping of an exotic dog she personally cant stand and then, after the mall closes on Christmas Eve, rescue her new friend as well.

title: Corrections: November 29, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: In Playoff Push, Baylors Style Is to Focus on the Task at Hand: Winning
description: At No. 7 in the College Football Playoff, the Baylor Bears are perched on the periphery of the inaugural playoff system. But Coach Art Briles would not budge when pressed on the issue of style points or politicking.

title: Conservationists Continue Push to Block Hong Kong Ivory Sales
description: Protesters gathered Saturday outside a Hong Kong department store that had been prominently selling ivory products, part of an effort to publicize the citys key role in the trade, which activists say contributes to the poaching of elephants.

title: Darren Wilson, Officer in Ferguson Shooting, Resigns From Police Dept.
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  The white police officer a grand jury declined to indict last week in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black teenager has resigned from this citys Police Department, his lawyer said on Saturday night.

title: Egyptian Judges Drop All Charges Against Mubarak
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian court dropped all remaining criminal charges against former President Hosni Mubarak on Saturday in a sweeping repudiation of the Arab Spring uprising that forced him from power.

title: Making Sense of Ferguson: Part 2
description: What article or book would you recommend to those who want to better understand events in Ferguson? We asked Times colleagues to weigh in. Read recommendations from Nicholas Kristof, Tanzina Vega and others here.

title: The Daily Gift: Handsome Cutting Boards With Leather Handles
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: Saturday Morning Music: Stay Gold
description: Sorry, family stuff was going on and I completely forgot to post last night. Meanwhile, Switzerland is about to vote on a proposal to keep 20 percent of its enormous reserves in gold which can never be sold.

title: Biking New Zealands Wine Country
description: New Zealand is known for its Great Walks, but now it has Great Cycles  a series of 23 bicycle trails across the country.

title: Attack in Western China Leaves at Least 15 People Dead
description: HONG KONG  The police in Xinjiang, the volatile region of western China, shot dead 11 members of a gang who killed four people and wounded 14 in an attack on a street lined with restaurants and food stalls, official Chinese media said Saturday.

title: Egypt Drops Case Against Mubarak
description: An Egyptian court drops its case against ousted president Hosni Mubarak on charges of ordering the killing of protesters in 2011.

title: When Vermin Come to Visit
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: Variety: A Spiny Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Todays acrostic quote is a good example of why Im glad they invented marketing. If someone hadnt said, You know what this LOBSTER stuff needs? A better image. Lets put it next to some parsley, some melted butter and lemon wedges, and charge upwards of $10 a pound, we might have missed out on one of the most incredible treats on the face of the Earth.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Marco Polo
description: John Fusco, creator of the Netflix series Marco Polo, narrates a scene in which the 13th-century traveler enters the court of Kublai Khan.

title: Still Dressing Up; Growing Up, Too
description: At nu-metals peak, Slipknot was the act with the grandest sense of theater, identifying band members with numbers, not names, and performing in ostentatious clown masks and jumpsuits, like the house band at a Stephen King fan convention. Its music was generally more straightforward, though: pummeling and direct, heavy on grinding drums and horror vocals.

title: Who Knows What This Means?
description: The choreographer Neil Greenberg is allergic to the word about when it comes to discussing his dances. Arent the days of dances having to be about something long gone? Inspired by Susan Sontags Against Interpretation, Mr. Greenberg, in his new dance This, fights the idea that meaning must be assigned to choreography. His last work, (like a vase), presented four years ago, explored the tension created by the desire for meaning. In This, he goes further by focusing on dance as a crystallization of the performance moment.

title: Acting Out a Nightmare
description: Its a parents worst nightmare: You momentarily drop your childs hand, and in a heartbeat he vanishes into the ether. So to portray Tony Hughes, a British father whose 5-year-old son, Oliver, disappears during a family vacation in France in The Missing, a mini-series shown Saturdays on Starz, James Nesbitt intended to mine his experiences with his own two daughters. And found that he couldnt. Theres an actual defense that causes us to pull the shutters up, he said in a phone interview, and we disallow ourselves from going there.

title: Influences and Exhibitions
description: Known for everything from place mats made of laminated newspaper articles to stretched canvases featuring the entire handwritten text of Oscar Wildes The Picture of Dorian Gray, Allen Ruppersberg would seem like a tough act to follow. But as a pioneer of the Conceptual art movement  in 1971, he transformed a small Sunset Boulevard house into a functioning hotel that he revived for Frieze New York last May  he has influenced a younger generation of artists working today. Now the gallery Greene Naftali in Chelsea has assembled a group of those artists for the exhibition The Novel That Writes Itself.

title: Dead Composers Stage a Comeback
description: Readers of Think Denk, the pianist Jeremy Denks witty blog, have enjoyed his musicological observations and wit  which he recently channeled into a libretto. Inspired by Charles Rosens Classical Style, a textbook from the 1970s, Mr. Denk has created characters that include not only Mozart, Beethoven and Haydn (who have read a newspaper article declaring the death of classical music), but the Tonic and Dominant Chords. The Classical Style: An Opera (of Sorts), with a score by Steven Stucky, debuted at the Ojai Festival last summer. It will be performed on Thursday with a cast including the soprano Jennifer Zetlan and Robert Spano conducting the Knights. (7:30 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall; 212-247-7800, carnegiehall.org, limited availability.)

title: How to Build an Empire, the Netflix Way
description: In the first episode of Marco Polo, Netflixs coming original series, the Mongolian emperor Kublai Khan sits on a throne in his gilded palace and plots the future conquests of his growing empire.

title: Tales Told Out of School in Pyongyang Cause Stir
description: A memoir by a Korean-American author about teaching English to adolescent boys at a private university in Pyongyang was certain to anger the North Korean government.

title: Pope Brings Message of Interreligious Peace to Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL  On the second leg of his trip to Turkey, Pope Francis was welcomed on Saturday by curious bystanders and tourists from around the world as he visited the historical district here to deliver his message of further interreligious dialogue for peace.

title: A Lesser Warning? Maybe
description: On a recent morning at a Starbucks in Richmond, Va., Patrik Hildingsson ordered a latte and, between sips, tucked a pouch of tobacco into his upper lip.

title: Mark Strand, 80, Dies; Pulitzer-Winning Poet Laureate
description: Mark Strand, whose spare, deceptively simple investigations of rootlessness, alienation and the ineffable strangeness of life made him one of Americas most hauntingly meditative poets, died on Saturday at his daughters home in Brooklyn. He was 80.

title: Studying Snus, a Smokeless Tobacco From Sweden
description: The warning label on cans of Swedish snus sold in the United States says that this product can cause mouth cancer and cautions that it is not a safe alternative to cigarettes.

title: Slamming the Window on Investors
description: Its becoming a full-time job cataloging the contortions some companies go through to avoid addressing their shareholders concerns.

title: Roger Ferguson of TIAA-CREF: Always Act as if Youre an Owner
description: This interview with  Roger Ferguson, chief executive of TIAA-CREF, the retirement services provider, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

title: Taliban Overrun an Afghan Army Base
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Taliban fighters overran an Afghan National Army outpost in Helmand Province in the countrys south late Friday night and by Saturday morning had killed as many as 14 soldiers in one of the insurgents deadliest attacks against Afghan soldiers this year, local officials said.

title: For Accomplished Students, Reaching a Good College Isnt as Hard as It Seems
description: Earlier this year, Harvard announced that it had accepted 5.9 percent of the nearly 35,000 students who applied for admission to the class of 2018. The next day, Stanford announced an even more exacting 5.07 percent admission rate, the lowest in the universitys history.

title: The Absence of Two Stars May Have Lifted the Thunders Game
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  The home locker room here at Chesapeake Energy Arena is nearly as big as a warehouse, except the carpet is nice and the center of the room features a shiny mosaic of the Oklahoma City Thunder logo. It is spacious and comfortable, with plenty of room for people to spread out.

title: What Were Watching: Sunday Shows
description: From Ferguson, Mo., to Los Angeles to New York City, thousands marched this week to protest a St. Louis County grand jurys decision to not indict a white police officer who shot and killed an unarmed black teenager, Michael Brown. Benjamin Crump, a lawyer for the teenagers family, will give insight on how Mr. Browns parents are coping with the decision on CBSs Face the Nation.

title: Pelicans Are in Anthony Daviss Slipstream
description: Everyone knew Anthony Davis was talented, but in a remarkable start to the season, he is showing that he may be the most valuable player in the N.B.A.

title: Heroin Takes Over a House, and Mom, on New Yorks Staten Island
description: Darkness fell on Wood Court on Staten Island, and they came. Footfalls on the gravel path, their crunch-crunch-crunch setting dogs barking, babies wailing, parents peering out windows, night after night.

title: On the Other Side of the Glass
Just Plane Ugly
description: THE woman in 27E doesnt have only one carry-on plus a small bag for a laptop or personal items. She has one carry-on plus a purse the size of a bassinet plus some canvas vessel for all of her electronics plus two different plastic totes for various pillows, blankets and possibly an ottoman and a coffee table. Shuffling down the aisle, she looks more like a Peruvian llama than anything human. She grunts and buckles.

title: Japan Is Back in the Hunt for Whales
description: Claiming purely scientific motives, Japans political leaders are cynically planning to resume whale hunting in the Southern Ocean, despite the International Court of Justice finding that the Japanese government regularly violated its obligations under the international ban against commercial whaling off Antarctica.

title: In Praise of Impracticality
description: I SAW a girl on a Manhattan-bound subway train one day wearing a knockoff Louis Vuitton head scarf and false eyelashes long enough to make a daddy longlegs envious. Her look  a sort of Sally-Bowles-does-Brooklyn  was complete with a matching knockoff L.V. handbag and umbrella. She was seated next to a young man who was as dashing in his way as she was adorable, but she took no notice of him as she was completely absorbed in a paperback titled something like Becoming a Practical Thinker.

title: Can Mushrooms Treat Depression?
description: I TRIED magic mushrooms out of curiosity and in middle age. Id been on the amateur mycological circuit for a couple of years, but hallucinogenic species were rarely mentioned at the foraging expeditions and conferences I attended. Its almost as if they were the black sheep of mycology: embarrassing to serious taxonomy jocks. I read some books on the subject, but most were trippers guides that didnt utilize, um, specific language or current science. Psychoactive mushrooms had been in a kind of scientific ghetto ever since they were criminalized in 1968. But now the drug derived from the mushroom, psilocybin, is finally being re-examined for its medical applications.

title: Bernhard Misof
description: Bernhard Misof, an Austrian evolutionary biologist at the Alexander Koenig Zoological Research Museum in Bonn, Germany, is coordinating a comprehensive insect tree of life using genetic data from more than 1,000 species.

title: Where Do We Go After Ferguson?
description: WASHINGTON  WHEN Ferguson flared up this week after a grand jury failed to indict the white police officer Darren Wilson for killing the unarmed black youth Michael Brown, two realities were illuminated: Black and white people rarely view race in the same way or agree about how to resolve racial conflicts, and black people have furious moral debates among ourselves out of white earshot.

title: When Whites Just Dont Get It, Part 5
description: WE Americans are a nation divided.

title: The Retreat to Identity
description: LAST summer, around the anniversary of Martin Luther King Jr.s I Have a Dream speech, I wrote a column making  gingerly  a case for optimism about race and politics in America.

title: Hydrogen Cars, Coming Down the Pike
description: The once-distant promise of clean, affordable hydrogen-powered cars is starting to become a reality.

title: Oil Drills and Spills
description: Readers discuss the environmental damage in North Dakota from oil extraction.

title: When Doping Isnt Cheating
description: TORONTO  THE undisputed facts of the case are that the South African cyclist Daryl Impey  the first African rider to wear the leaders jersey at the Tour de France  visited a pharmacy in Durban on the eve of his countrys national road cycling championships in February. He purchased some pills to boost his race performance. A few months later, authorities announced that he had tested positive for probenecid, a substance sometimes used to mask the presence of other drugs.

title: Homeownership and Wealth Creation
description: Since the housing bust, renting has been in and owning a home has been out, especially among young adults who in earlier decades would have been first-time home buyers. As the rate of homeownership has declined, from a peak of nearly 70 percent in 2004 to a 20-year low of 64.3 percent recently, the number of owner-occupied homes has barely budged, while the number occupied by renters has increased by nearly 25 percent.

title: A Salad Chains Surprise Ingredient: Tech Money
description: Why is a venture capital firm led by online pioneers backing a farm-to-table salad chain?

title: The Art of the Amateur Online Review
description: When Camilla Vsquez and her husband, Rubn, went to a dealership to shop for a new car last June, they found the salesman affable and low-key. To their surprise, Dr. Vsquez said, the hard sell began after the deal was sealed. Thats when the salesman pulled out a binder of online reviews he wanted the couple to use as models for reporting on their shopping experience.

title: Pain Is Colorblind
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  THE fight was in the early rounds, and it was just the diversion I needed. I had spent the previous few days covering the Michael Brown case, caught up in the gloomy guessing game of what might happen if a grand jury decided not to indict the police officer who killed him.

title: Epiphany, With Encyclopedias
description: WAY back when I was in college, before the Internet, before the personal computer, back when only businesses had electric typewriters, I sold encyclopedias one summer to help pay for my senior year. And in doing so, I had an epiphany that helped me understand the extraordinary and enduring tension in America between anti-intellectualism and academic achievement.

title: Sex and the Saints
description: WHEN ushered into the master bedroom of the Mormon patriarch Brigham Young at his winter home in St. George, Utah, a few years ago, I felt duty-bound to ask an obvious question: Where did the other women sleep?

title: Exchange-Rate Issue Is Cold Cash to N.H.L.
description: The N.H.L.s general managers count on the salary cap to rise every year. But what if, as some fear, it does not go up next season?

title: Raised Hands, and the Doubts of a Grand Jury
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  It is the image that became indelible, fueling protests nationwide after the confrontation on a muggy August day here: Michael Brown, an unarmed 18-year-old African-American, with hands raised in surrender moments before a white police officer fired the shots that killed him.

title: Movies, Meet 4D Theme Park
description: To increase attendance, theaters are trying to redefine the moviegoing experience with amenities and effects like mist, scents and moving seats.

title: To Lure Young, Movie Theaters Shake, Smell and Spritz
description: LOS ANGELES  Having tried 3-D films, earsplitting sound systems and even alcohol sales in pursuit of younger moviegoers, some theater chains are now installing undulating seats, scent machines and 270-degree screens.

title: Gun Play for Grownups
description: A married couple bonds over their shared love of the local shooting range.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Independent Is Elected Taipei Mayor as Taiwans Governing Party Falters
description: HONG KONG  A doctor running as an independent won the mayors race in Taipei, the capital, on Saturday, as Taiwans governing party suffered heavy losses in local elections. In response to the defeats dealt to the party, which favors closer ties with China, the prime minister resigned.

title: Amid Slump, Brazil Congress Seeks Raise
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  After a tight re-election victory marked by quarreling over a sluggish economy and yawning budget deficits, Brazils president, Dilma Rousseff, has ushered in a new economic team led by Joaquim Levy, a University of Chicago-trained banker nicknamed Scissorhands for his readiness to slash public spending.

title: Concussions, by the New Book
description: It happens dozens of times in every N.F.L. game. There is a fierce collision, or perhaps a running back is slammed to the ground. Most of the time, all the players rise to their feet uneventfully.

title: For the Buckeyes, a Win and a Loss
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  J. T. Barrett lay flat on his back, looking up at the sky, his arms spread wide, and Ohio Stadium watched in silence as Ohio State trainers attended to his right leg. In the fourth quarter, against the teams rival Michigan, Barretts leg had been caught beneath a pile of maize and blue.

title: Where Grass Is Greener, a Push to Share Droughts Burden
description: RANCHO SANTA FE, Calif.  In these hills overlooking San Diego, the only indication of the continuing drought  now among the worst in Californias recorded history  is the perpetually cloudless sky.

title: G.O.P. Gains by Tapping Democrats Base for State Candidates
description: WASHINGTON  As Republicans took control of an unprecedented 69 of 99 statehouse chambers in the midterm elections, they did not rely solely on a bench of older white men. Key races hinged on the strategic recruitment of women and minorities, many of them first-time candidates who are now learning the ropes and joining the pool of prospects for higher office.

title: Shaking Off Injuries, Rangers Subdue Flyers
description: The Rangers were depleted even before they took the ice Saturday for their home-and-home finale with the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: As Mexico Addresses Climate Change, Critics Point to Shortcomings
description: EJIDO RANCHO OJO LAGUNA, Mexico  For six years, while drought ravaged Chihuahua State, Mario Ruiz clung to his small herd of cattle.

title: At Clemsons Stadium, a Rock Meets a Hard Place
description: CLEMSON, S.C.  Cameras are trained 24 hours a day on a black granite pedestal that is inside the gate behind the east end zone at Clemson Memorial Stadium. A plexiglass case protects a precious quartz stone that is embedded in the top of the shiny, polished pedestal. Those who dare to get too close may hear a recorded warning that they are being watched by police.

title: Egyptian Activists Protest Mubarak Verdict Online and Outside in a Sealed Tahrir Square
description: In the hours after an Egyptian court dropped all remaining charges against former President Hosni Mubarak on Saturday, activists who supported the uprising that drove him from power in 2011 jeered the ruling online and in the streets near Cairos Tahrir Square, which was closed by the security forces.

title: In Comeback Stride, Sarkozy Wins French Party Leadership
description: PARIS  Former President Nicolas Sarkozy was elected as the leader of his center-right party on Saturday evening in a widely expected victory that could serve as a steppingstone for his 2017 bid to become president of France again.

title: Roger Goodell Has 32 N.F.L. Owners in His Corner, for Now
description: From the moment seven years ago that N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell began his law-and-order campaign aimed at cleaning up the leagues dubious image, he has been criticized for abusing his sweeping powers to penalize players and teams for infractions large and small.

title: Suit on Health Law Puts Focus on Funding Powers
description: WASHINGTON  In mounting the latest court challenge to the Affordable Care Act, House Republicans are focusing on a little-noticed provision of the law that offers financial assistance to low- and moderate-income people.

title: City Tarnished by Defeat Gets to Bask in Victory
description: BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil  Their telltale faces represented the two sides of Brazil.

title: Japanese Unearth Remains, and Their Nations Past, on Guadalcanal
description: GUADALCANAL, Solomon Islands  Using a trowel to dig into the shadowy floor of the rain forest, pausing only to wipe away sweat and malaria-carrying mosquitoes, Atsushi Maeda holds up what he has traveled so far, to this South Pacific island, to find: a human bone, turned orange-brown with age.

title: Intrusion on Sony Unit Prompts a Shutdown of Messaging Systems
description: LOS ANGELES  While rivals focused on the holiday box office, Sony Pictures Entertainment spent Thanksgiving weekend coping with the continuing effects of a cyberattack  and investigating what provoked the onslaught, including whether there were any ties to a coming comedy that has elicited the ire of North Korea.

title: Zap!
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  I spent a good part of my early career in advertising, and I was always amazed at how hard the media department worked to make sure that the clients products got in front of the television-viewing audience.

title: Squandering Two Leads, Red Bulls Are Ousted
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  The New England Revolution booked a ticket to the M.L.S. Cup final on Saturday as two goals by Charlie Davies gave them a 4-3 aggregate win over the Red Bulls for the Eastern Conference championship.

title: Tradition Saves Camels Spot in Jordans Desert Forces
description: WADI RUM, Jordan  Hitched up in the sandy lot by the police station, next to the four-by-four trucks and the dune buggy, is some other important equipment for enforcing the law in this parched and forbidding desert valley: eight surly and perpetually masticating camels.

title: Doing What It Takes to Keep Her Family Together
description: Sprawled on the floor of her bathroom atop a clean bedsheet, Aislinn Kennedy gave birth to her son JahMeire in February 2012. She was 26 weeks into her pregnancy.

title: Sundays Matchup: Giants (3-8) at Jaguars (1-10)
description: 1 p.m., Fox

title: End of Texas Schools Book Ban Doesnt Mark the Last Chapter
description: HIGHLAND PARK, Tex.  In mid-September, about two weeks after sophomores at Highland Park High School began reading The Art of Racing in the Rain, by Garth Stein, in their English classes, they were told to stop.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Why Was Beckhams Catch A Big Deal?

title: Three Years After Fire, a New Culprit Threatens a Texas Parks Rebirth
description: BASTROP, Tex.  Greenery has begun to cover the scars of a fire that ripped through 32,000 acres of Central Texas three years ago. Feeding on tinder and trees withered from a searing drought, the Bastrop County wildfire burned for nine days and destroyed more than 1,600 homes before it was brought under control.

title: Will Texas Meet Budget? It Is All in the Math
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  A small group of Texas legislators will meet this week to decide how much they think the states economy will grow in the next two years.

title: In Religious Order, Texas Women Find a Place to Call Home
description: BURNET  Instead of the name of her school, the sparkly letters on Caroline Smiths homecoming mum, or large corsage, spelled Jesus is my homecoming king.

title: Bob Dylan, Not Looking Back
description: The latest stretch of Bob Dylans Never Ending Tour, which started a five-night stand at the Beacon Theater on Friday, is, no surprise, a hard-nosed conundrum.

title: A Soaring Emblem of New York, and Its Upside-Down Priorities
description: The observatory, with the wraparound, nosebleed views, is not finished. Almost half the office space isnt leased yet. But a bakers dozen years after Sept. 11, 1 World Trade Center is up and running.

title: Black Friday Sales Slip as Discounts Start Earlier
description: Even as more stores opened their doors on Thanksgiving, hoping for a jump start to the holiday season, an initial reading suggested that combined sales on Thanksgiving and Black Friday fell 0.5 percent from the same period last year.

title: Honoring Small Business, Obamas Go Book Shopping
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, joined by his daughters, went shopping Saturday at Politics and Prose, an independent bookstore in the capital, in what has become a Thanksgiving weekend tradition for the first family to honor Small Business Saturday  an outing that mixed policy and purchases.

title: Glossy Photo Cards, Highlighting Grief
description: The best holiday card we received the year that our daughter died said simply, Continuing to lift you up in prayer and came from an aunt and uncle we hadnt seen in years.

title: Taxi Owners in New York Seek Inquiry on Medallion Prices
description: The Greater New York Taxi Association, a trade group for the citys taxi medallion owners, is calling for an independent investigation of reports published by the citys Taxi and Limousine Commission that said average prices for taxi medallions were steady when they were actually falling.

title: Mississippi Pulls Out of Its Skid and Leaves Mississippi State Adrift
description: OXFORD, Miss.  It was not two months ago here that Mississippi beat Alabama, the goal posts came down (one of them was carried to the historic Square downtown), and anything  Ole Misss first division title since 2003, or even its first national championship since the 1962 season  seemed possible.

title: On Rooftops of Ferguson, Volunteers Patrol, With Guns
description: FERGUSON, Mo.  When Sam Andrews awoke on Tuesday morning, he found his wife watching a television interview with a woman whose bakery had been vandalized during the violent unrest hereon Monday.

title: Measuring Up a Big Ten Expansion
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  It wasnt quite the Big Tens most traditional annual classic, known as the Game, between Michigan and Ohio State. But at least it became an entertainingly competitive and even compelling contest, like the scare the unranked Wolverines put into the heavily favored Buckeyes before losing by 14 points Saturday at the Horseshoe in Columbus.

title: Winning Lottery Numbers for Nov. 29, 2014
Islanders Hold Off Devils to Wrap Up a Strong November
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The Islanders have dominated their Metropolitan Division rivals this season, a key reason they are off to the best start in franchise history. On Saturday, they took advantage of another division opponent, with a 3-1 victory against the Devils at Nassau Coliseum in the teams first meeting this season.

title: Mario Cuomo, Former Governor of New York, Is Hospitalized
description: Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York has been hospitalized for treatment of a heart problem.

title: Krista Dubin and Eric Giambattista
description: Krista Alexandra Dubin, a daughter of Randi and Michael Dubin of Manhattan, was married Saturday in Long Island City, Queens, to Eric Matthew Giambattista, the son of Janet and Brian Giambattista of San Jose, Calif. The brides father, who became a minister of the Open Ministry for the event, officiated at the Metropolitan Building.

title: Joanne Bruno and Michael Peters
description: Joanne Helen Bruno, a daughter of Jacqueline J. Bruno of Maspeth, Queens, and the late Daniel Bruno, was married Saturday to Michael Perry Peters, a son of Maryanne and Parry M. Peters of Marlboro, N.J. The Rev. Eugene Pappas performed the ceremony at the Three Hierarchs Greek Church in Brooklyn.

title: Leslie Kaufmann, Lyron Bennett
description: Leslie Kaufmann, a daughter of Susan Kaufmann and Ronald H. Kaufmann of New York, was married Saturday evening to Lyron Elisha Francis Bennett, a son of Dominique M.C.N. Raccah and Raymond W. Bennett of Naperville, Ill. Rabbi Neil Zuckerman officiated at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: Morgan Handsman, Ian Spitalnick
description: Morgan Jena Handsman and Ian Harris Spitalnick were married Saturday evening by Rabbi Howard Stecker at Guastavinos in New York.

title: Laura Waluch and Michael Solomon
description: Laura Rebecca Waluch, a daughter of Paula G. Waluch and Dr. Victor Waluch of Altadena, Calif., was married Friday to Michael Stern Solomon, the son of Janet Stern Solomon and Lewis D. Solomon of Chevy Chase, Md. The grooms father, who was ordained at the New Seminary in New York, officiated at San Ysidro Ranch, a hotel in Montecito, Calif.

title: Amy Lerner, Evan Gold
description: Amy Beth Lerner and Evan Matthew Gold were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton, Pentagon City, in Arlington, Va. Rabbi Esther Lederman officiated.

title: Dana Klinek, Jason Pinter
description: Dana Lauren Klinek and Jason Lee Pinter were married Saturday evening at Shadowbrook, an event space in Shrewsbury, N.J. Cantor Gabrielle Clissold of the Monmouth Reform Temple officiated.

title: Jordana Gruenwald and Jonathan Beck
description: Jordana Wendy Gruenwald, a daughter of Laurel R. Gruenwald and Abraham I. Gruenwald of New City, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Jonathan Scott Beck, a son of Janet S. Beck and Bruce Beck of White Plains. Rabbi Jonathan Blake officiated at the Oheka Castle in Huntington, N.Y.

title: Jennifer White, Martin Lawlor
description: Jennifer Lee White and Martin John Lawlor were married Saturday at the Grand Cascades Lodge in Hamburg, N.J. The Rev. Nancy Young, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Sarah Rothenberg, Evan Schonfeld
description: Sarah Rachel Rothenberg, a daughter of Caren Rothenberg and Larry L. Rothenberg of Livingston, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Evan Benjamin Schonfeld, a son of Amy Rothman Schonfeld and Dr. Steven M. Schonfeld of East Brunswick, N.J. Rabbi E. Samuel Klibanoff officiated at the Hanover Marriott Hotel in Whippany, N.J.

title: Michael Meltzer and Monte Albers de Leon
description: Michael Ted Meltzer and Monte Roberto Albers de Leon were married Saturday evening at the Harvard Club of New York. Matt Levy, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Joey Pakes and Prentiss Nelson
description: Michal Joey Pakes and Robert Prentiss Nelson were married Saturday in Cambridge, Mass. Sol Matthew Pakes, the brides brother, who became a Universal Life minister for theevent, officiated in Adolphus Busch Hall at Harvard.

title: Sharing a Love of the Outdoors
description: Siyana Yordanova Kukularova, a daughter of Seta K. Kukularova and Yordan K. Kukularov of Plovdiv, Bulgaria, was married Wednesday to Andrew Christopher Huszar, a son of Dr. Theresa G. Huszar and Dr. Gabor B. Huszar of Woodbridge, Conn. Angel L. Lopez of the New York City Clerks office officiated at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau.

title: Surging Sabres Edge Canadiens in Shootout
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The Islanders have dominated their Metropolitan Division rivals this season, a key reason they are off to the best start in franchise history. On Saturday, they took advantage of another division opponent with a 3-1 victory against the Devils at Nassau Coliseum in the teams first meeting this season.

title: Corrections: November 30, 2014
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Bill Cunningham | Thanksgiving
description: For many, Thanksgiving has stretched into five days of festivities. One highlight this week was the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade, where youngsters gathered curbside and clowns entertained. Older women dressed in colorful outfits came out with walkers decorated in pink and green. Two of the more amazing sights were the balloons and the many visitors who wore headgear resembling turkeys. Another highlight of the week was the New-York Historical Societys train exhibition. It was a tour de force in its design. Nothing was static; it was all moving. Children can watch through a clear protruding bubble.

title: Qatar Frees U.S. Couple in Death of Daughter
description: DOHA, Qatar  An American couple in Qatar who spent nearly two years fighting accusations that hey had killed their adopted daughter from Ghana were cleared of wrongdoing on Sunday in an emotional courtroom reversal by an appellate judge who said that they were good parents and that the prosecution had no case.

title: Kin of Thai Princess Stripped of Royal Name
description: BANGKOK  In a rare public display of palace intrigue in Thailand, relatives of a prominent member of the royal family have been charged with numerous counts of corruption and stripped of their royally bestowed name.

title: Math Anxiety: Why Hollywood Makes Robots of Alan Turing and Other Geniuses
description: Math movies have become a dependable genre. There is a shot of a genius staring rapturously at mind-bending numbers. He is an insufferable person. There will be much drama about whether he can learn to value human emotion over cold fact.

title: Racing From New York to Barcelona
description: The documentary Strangers at Sea was really the result of conversations going back four years seeking a compelling video that would introduce professional sailing to The Timess audience. At the last minute, I tried to capture the finish of the Vende Globe  a solo, nonstop around-the-world race  from the perspective of both the sailors and fans.

title: The Daily Gift: Picasso Plates for Creative Dining
description: Each day until Christmas, the editors of T share a new holiday gift idea.

title: 1889: Metropolitan Opera House Reopens in New York
description: Wealth, art and society were well represented at the reopening of the Metropolitan Opera House. It marked the beginning of the sixth season of opera in German. The house had a brilliant appearance when the curtain rose on the first act of Wagners Flying Dutchman. Although it rained in torrents all the evening, the ladies appeared in their rarest toilettes, and the boxes literally blazed with diamonds. Mrs. Astor was in white pink brocade, and occupied a box with Miss Marion Longdon and Mr. Ward McAlister. Miss Longdon wore pale yellow with a long boa of ostrich feathers. In an adjoining box sat Mrs. William C. Whitney in a dcollet dress of pale green and silver, with diamonds in her hair. Mrs. Paran Stevens wore a brocade toilette, and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt wore white brocade and pearls. On the stage interest centred chiefly in Theodore Reichmann, the popular Viennese barytone, and in Fraulein Sophie Weisner, the soprano, who made their debut in this country as Senta and Vanderdecken. Reichmann scored a great and instant success, thanks as much to his admirable and artistic acting as to his rich and sympathetic voice. Fraulein Weisners success was less emphatic, although, like Reichmann, she was warmly applauded. The New York Herald, European Edition, Dec. 1, 1889

title: Police Break Siege of Government Offices in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  Pro-democracy demonstrators in Hong Kong suffered a setback on Monday, when their attempt overnight to besiege government offices collapsed and the police thrust into the protesters biggest street camp.

title: Whats On TV Sunday
description: 10 P.M. (Sundance) THE KINGS SPEECH (2010) Colin Firth, above with Helena Bonham Carter, in the role for which he won an Oscar for best actor, portrays Albert Frederick Arthur George, or Bertie, as his family called him, the shy second son of George V of Britain (Michael Gambon) in this film from Tom Hooper. Geoffrey Rush is Lionel Logue, the speech therapist who helps Bertie conquer a debilitating stutter. And Ms. Carter is Elizabeth, his wife and staunch support system, who cant quite stomach Wallis Simpson (Eve Best), the divorced American who leads Berties older brother, David (Guy Pearce), to abdicate as Edward VIII. It isnt exactly Pygmalion, not least because Mr. Hooper has no intention of satirizing the caste system that is one of this movies biggest draws, Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, said of the film, which received 12 Oscar nominations and won four. Like many entertainments of this pop-historical type, she added, The Kings Speech wears history lightly, no matter how heavy the crown.

title: Netanyahu Hints at Possibility of New Elections
description: JERUSALEM  Amid a political crisis over a proposed nationality law and growing acrimony among the fractious partners of Israels governing coalition, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu hinted on Sunday at the possibility of new elections only 20 months after his current government was formed.

title: Leader Asserts Chinas Growing Importance on Global Stage
description: BEIJING  Sounding confident after a burst of high-profile diplomacy, President Xi Jinping told Communist Party officials in a major address here over the weekend that China would be nice to its neighbors in Asia but that he would run an active foreign policy and be relentless in promoting Chinas rejuvenation onto the global stage.

title: Optimism Faces Grave Realities at Climate Talks
description: WASHINGTON  After more than two decades of trying but failing to forge a global pact to halt climate change, United Nations negotiators gathering in South America this week are expressing a new optimism that they may finally achieve the elusive deal.

title: Plane Evacuated at Kennedy Airport After Bomb Threat
description: A plane was evacuated at Kennedy International Airport on Sunday amid an investigation into a bomb threat, the authorities said.

title: 1914: Russians Dominate in East Poland
description: PETROGRAD The steady increase in the strength of the Russian troops is transforming the appearance of the battles in East Poland. During the recent fighting in this region, and more particularly on Thursday, the Germans have sustained enormous loss. After a multitude of charges by the Russian cavalry, the state of the fields and roads rendered the use of automobiles absolutely impossible. The Russians have consequently garaged a large number of their machines at Lodz, whither they are also sending hundreds of transport and ammunition wagons captured from the enemy. The prolongation of the struggle in the neighborhood of Lodz is probably due to the feverish activity on the German strategic railways on the Silesian frontier. The enemy is bringing up troops with all possible speed, and it is estimated that 50,000 men, or nearly half the garrison of Breslau, were despatched north-west to Czenstochowa to join the newly-formed army in that region. Another great battle is to be expected somewhere between Lodz and Kalisz. The New York Herald, European Edition, Dec. 1, 1914

title: The European Outlier
description: Im doing some work on matters European, which should see the light of day shortly, and for future reference I want to post a simple chart. It makes the same point already made by Francesco Saraceno and Simon Wren-Lewis, but in a more stripped-down and possibly clearer (?) way.

title: Swiss Voters Reject Move to Restrict Immigrants
description: COLOGNE, Germany  Swiss voters on Sunday overwhelmingly rejected a proposal to drastically curb the influx of foreigners seeking to work and live in their country in the second major effort this year aimed at restricting immigration.

title: Pope, in Turkey, Issues Call to Protect Middle Eastern Christians
description: ISTANBUL  Pope Francis and his counterpart in the Orthodox Church on Sunday vowed to work together to prevent an exodus of Christians from the Middle East, and they called for constructive dialogue with Muslims to resolve conflicts in the embattled region and around the world.

title: Churches Urge Healing, but Also Activism, After Stormy Week in Ferguson
description: ST. LOUIS  At worship services around this region, clergy on Sunday called for recovery and healing after a week that began with an announcement that a grand jury would not indict a white police officer who shot an unarmed black teenager in Ferguson and that then careened through looting, fires, and tense standoffs with the police and National Guard soldiers.

title: Afghan Fires His Cabinet; Police Chief Offers to Quit
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Unable to form a new government, the new president of Afghanistan, Ashraf Ghani, settled for the next best thing on Sunday: He fired the old one.

title: Beijing Wind
description: The umbrellas arent holding up in Hong Kong.

title: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Warriors at Bulls
description: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

title: A Big Man Shrinks Into a New Role
description: LOS ANGELES  In early September, months after the last N.B.A. season had ended, Mike Conley tuned in to watch the FIBA Basketball World Cup on television. He saw someone with a resemblance to his Memphis Grizzlies teammate Marc Gasol: same bushy beard, same stern game face and same backward shuffle down the court after shooting a jumper from just beyond the free-throw line.

title: Choreography That Stretches Performers and Their Art
description: PARIS  This city has been important to William Forsythe. It was here, in 1987, that his In the Middle, Somewhat Elevated had its premiere at the Paris Opera Ballet, earning him international recognition. In 1990, his own company, the Frankfurt Ballet, began an eight-year residence at the Thtre du Chtelet, performing there for several weeks every year. During that time, Mr. Forsythes faithful fans could see almost all of his new work and track the evolution of his artistry.

title: Funny, This Little Town Is Full of C.I.A. Operatives
description: Dear Brock Clarke:

title: A Not-So-Mad Scientist and His Blue-Eyed Buddy
description: Stanley, one of the stars of Joseph Silovskys Send for the Million Men, stood behind a lectern during a recent rehearsal. Stanley has wide blue eyes and excellent posture. Collegial and professional, hed long since memorized his lines and his blocking, which he executes with his eight fingers, mismatched joints and tangle of wires.

title: Raising a Defiant Hand Against the Fist of the Law
description: In Ungli, written and directed by Rensil DSilva, four young professionals  led by Kangana Ranaut and Randeep Hooda  set out to avenge the aggrieved and the powerless amid widespread malfeasance in Mumbai. They are giving the finger to unscrupulous police officers and officials (ungli is the Hindi word for finger), and finding ingenious ways to expose those misdeeds publicly.

title: Opaque Justice in China
description: BEIJING  It was so important to the British screenwriter Guy Hibbert to preserve the unexpected ending of One Child, a television drama about executions in China, that he waited years for a financial backer who agreed to do so.

title: Crossovers Add Flavor to Classics
description: To many classical music lovers, crossover is a dirty word. And who can blame them? The holiday season is especially rich in ill-advised CD releases by opera stars belting out operetta arias or crooning Christmas jingles in arrangements that do no favors to either the singers or the songs.

title: Two Titles Won at Bridge Leagues Fall Championships
description: At the American Contract Bridge Leagues fall championships in Providence, R.I., the first two national titles were won on Saturday evening. The Smith Life Master Womens Pairs was captured by Bronia Jenkins of Vero Beach, Fla., and Bernace De Young of Miami. They led after each of the four sessions, finishing three-tenths of a board ahead of Victoria Gromova and Tatiana Ponomareva from Russia. The Russians, who were second after each session, won this event in 2012. Third were Ljudmila Kamenova of South Setauket, N.Y., and Linda Lewis of Las Vegas.

title: Notes on the Floating Crap Game (Economics Inside Baseball)
description: Link replaced

title: New Sugarplum Memories
description: When did The Nutcracker become more than just a ballet? With its intoxicating mix of the fantastical and the human, this venerated dance is a ritual that has stuck around for good reason: How many works of art are able to capture memory and the passing of time so profoundly on both sides of the stage? The Nutcracker has as much importance for the dancers who grow up performing it as it does for the audience members who grow up watching it. The charge in the air is real; somehow the dancers and the audience unite in the middle.

title: Secure in Its Sound and Fury, Despite Transitions at Its Core
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Heres what a Slayer concert does. You might hear gigs by 500 bands and feel pretty certain there is something inherently good about aesthetic change. Then you get to one by Slayer, and you might think, no, there is not anything inherently good about aesthetic change. Its not necessary.

title: The Hunger Games Dominates the Holiday Weekend
description: Moviegoing over the Thanksgiving holiday dropped 21 percent compared with the period a year ago, as two new wide-release movies, Penguins of Madagascar and Horrible Bosses 2, became the latest studio efforts to underperform. The No. 1 movie in North America was again The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1, which took in an estimated $56.9 million from Friday to Sunday, according to Rentrak, a box-office tracking firm. Domestic ticket sales for Mockingjay now total a hefty $225.7 million but are nonetheless running roughly 24 percent behind the last Hunger Games film.

title: Celebrating Singers, Current and Not So Much
description: Youve probably never wondered what would happen if PBS were to merge with MTV, or at least with the MTV of yore, the one that was defined by music. But you can get a glimpse of that mythical hybrid this week as PBS lets its hair down.

title: A Certain Win for the Giants? Not So Fast
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  The Giants season may already have been lost, but grim realities remain in the shocking and absurd ways they can pivot so quickly from bad to worse.

title: Egyptian President Wont Pursue Action Against Mubarak
description: CAIRO  President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi said on Sunday that he accepted the end of legal actions against the former president, Hosni Mubarak, declaring in a statement that Egypt must now look to the future and cannot ever go back.

title: The Billionaires Park
description: CAN billionaires remake the Manhattan shoreline? Apparently so, in light of the news that a new park will be just offshore in the Hudson River, largely financed by the media mogul Barry Diller and situated, conveniently, a short walk from his office in Chelsea.

title: Take Part in a Buddy System
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  What better way to start our solving week than with a message from an ADORING constructor?

title: Late Bloomer Finds Audience for His Art
description: The Palisades were a blazing blur of orange, red and yellow, but Jay Moss had no time to savor the autumnal Hudson River view. He grabbed a small plank of soft wood and went to his bedroom, hunched over a band saw and slowly carved the contours of a masklike face. Specks of sawdust floated in the sunlight, their slightly burned odor filling the air.

title: A Father Strives to Rebuild Ties Strained by Divorce and Alcoholism
description: Leonard Sharp limped toward a park bench in front of the Queens public school he had attended as a boy. On another bench an older man sitting with two quiet companions discreetly lit a smoke under the cover of his hooded sweatshirt.

title: Missing for Four Days, Kosta Karageorge, an Ohio State Defensive Lineman, Is Found Dead
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Ohio State defensive tackle Kosta Karageorge was found dead Sunday, four days after he had last been seen, Sgt. Richard Weiner of the Columbus Police Department told reporters.

title: Long Overshadowed in Realm of Business Magazines, Inc. Grabs the Spotlight
description: For many years, Inc. was a magazine that featured obscure entrepreneurs and quirky start-ups on its covers.
